2	en_US	abstract	This paper presents practical issues involved in e-learning at the Faculty of Mathematics and Physics (FMF), University of Ljubljana, Slovenia. It begins with a short history of e-learning at FMF followed by a discussion about the choice of the open source software (Moodle, svn, wiki platform) as the foundation for the web based learning, about its advantages and disadvantages. We focus on materials that enhance classroom learning, conform to learning standards, and at the same time address the needs of the end users: the students. We conclude by presenting the result of a survey about the students' attitude towards e-learning in general and about the e-learning environment at FMF.	string
9	en_US	abstract	Some graphs admit drawings in the Euclidean plane (k-space) in such \\r\\na (natural) way, that edges are represented as line segments of unit length. \\r\\nWe say that they have the unit distance property. \\r\\nThe inﬂuence of graph operations on the unit distance property is dis- \\r\\ncussed. It is proved that the Cartesian product preserves the unit distance \\r\\nproperty in the Euclidean plane, while graph union, join, tensor product, \\r\\nstrong product, lexicographic product and corona do not. It is proved \\r\\nthat the Cartesian product preserves the unit distance property also in \\r\\nhigher dimensions.	string
17	en_US	abstract	A geometric (n<sub>4</sub>) configuration is a collection of n points and n lines, usually in the Euclidean plane, so that every point lies on four lines and every line passes through four points. This paper introduces a new class of movable ((5m)<sub>4</sub>) configurations---that is, configurations which admit a continuous family of realizations fixing four points in general position but moving at least one other point---including the smallest known movable (n<sub>4</sub>) configuration.	string
70	en_US	abstract	Let <em>G</em> be a transitive group of odd prime-power degree whose Sylow <em>p</em>-subgroup <em>P</em> is abelian with <em>t</em> elementary divisors. We show that if <em>p</em> &gt; 2<sup><em>t</em> − 1</sup>, then <em>G</em> has a normal subgroup that is a direct product of <em>t</em> permutation groups of smaller degree that are either cyclic or doubly-transitive simple groups. As a consequence, we determine the full automorphism group of a Cayley digraph of an abelian group with two elementary divisors such that the Sylow <em>p</em>-subgroup of the full automorphism group is abelian.	string

11	en_US	abstract	The star complement technique is a spectral tool recently developed for constructing some bigger graphs from their smaller parts, called star complements. The most frequently, the implementation of those technique requires using the computers. Therefrom, we develop an SCL (star complement library) – the set of programs providing easy and quick implementation of those technique. Here, we present the facilities of SCL. In further, we determine some star complements for 1 or (√5 – 1)/2 as the second largest eigenvalue of a graph. Finally, using the SCL, we consider the maximal extensions of the star complements obtained.	string
12	en_US	abstract	We are motivated by the following question concerning the direct product\\r\\nof graphs. If $A\\times C\\cong B\\times C$, what can be said about the\\r\\nrelationship between $A$ and $B$? If cancellation fails, what properties\\r\\nmust $A$ and $B$ share? We define a structural equivalence relation\\r\\n$\\sim$ (called similarity) on graphs, weaker than isomorphism, for which\\r\\n$A\\times C\\cong B\\times C$ implies $A\\sim B$. Thus cancellation holds,\\r\\nup to similarity. Moreover, if $C$ is bipartite, then\\r\\n$A\\times C\\cong B\\times C$ if and only if $A\\sim B$. We conjecture that\\r\\nthe prime factorization of connected bipartite graphs is unique up to\\r\\nsimilarity of factors, and we offer some results supporting this conjecture.	string
13	en_US	abstract	This paper introduces a family of tetravalent graphs called ";rose window graphs";, denoted R_n(a, r), and investigates their symmetry properties. Four families of these graphs are shown to be edge-transitive and it is conjectured that every R_n(a, r) which is edged-transitive belongs to one of these families. Proofs and conjectures about the size of a dart-stabilizer and about regular maps containing these graphs are also offered.	string
14	en_US	abstract	In this paper we consider three classes of chain hexagonal cacti and study their matching and independence related properties. Explicit recurrences are derived for their matching and independence polynomials, and explicit formulae are presented for the number of matchings and independents sets with certain properties. Bivariate generating functions for the number of matchings and independent sets of certain size are also computed and then used to find the expected size of matchings and independent sets in chains of given length. It is shown that the extremal chain hexagonal cacti with respect\\r\\nto the number of matchings and of independent sets belong to one of the\\r\\nconsidered families. Possible directions of further research are discussed.	string
15	en_US	abstract	Recently introduced vertex-weighted Wiener polynomials are a common generalization of both vertex-weighted Wiener numbers and ordinary Wiener polynomials. We present here explicit formulae for vertex-weighted Wiener polynomials of the most frequently encountered classes of composite graphs.	string
16	en_US	abstract	When the standard representation of a crystallographic Coxeter group $G$ (with string diagram) is reduced modulo the integer $d \\geq 2$, one obtains a finite group $G^d$ which is often the automorphism group of an abstract regular polytope. Building on earlier work in the case that $d$ is an odd prime, we here develop methods to handle composite moduli and completely describe the corresponding modular polytopes when\\r\\n$G$ is of spherical or Euclidean type. Using a modular variant of the quotient criterion, we then describe the locally toroidal polytopes provided by our construction, most of which are new.	string
18	en_US	abstract	Duality and chirality are examples of operations of order $2$ on hypermaps. James showed that the groups of all operations on hypermaps and on oriented hypermaps can be identified with the outer automorphism groups ${\\rm Out}\\,\\Delta\\cong PGL_2({\\bf Z})$ and ${\\rm Out}\\,\\Delta^+\\cong GL_2({\\bf Z})$ of the groups $\\Delta = C_2*C_2*C_2$ and $\\Delta^+ = F_2$. We will consider the elements of finite order in these two groups, and the operations they induce.	string
19	en_US	abstract	We present the results of an investigation into the representations of Archimedean polyhedra (those polyhedra containing only one type of vertex figure) as quotients of regular abstract poltyopes. Two methods of generating these presentations are discussed, one of which may be applied in a general setting, and another which makes use of a regular polytope with the same automorphism group as the desired quotient. Representations of the 14 sporadic Archimedean polyhedra (including the pseudorhombicuboctahedron) as quotients of regular abstract polyhedra are obtained, and summarised in a table. The information is used to characterise which of these polyhedra have acoptic Petrie schemes (that is, have well-defined Petrie duals).	string
20	en_US	abstract	<p>A nut graph has a non-invertible (singular) 0-1 adjacency matrix with non-zero entries in every kernel eigenvector. We investigate how the concept of nut graphs emerges as an underlying theme in the theory of singular graphs. It is known that minimal configurations (MCs) are necessarily found as subgraphs of singular graphs. We construct MCs having nut graphs as subgraphs. Nut graphs can be coalesced with singular graphs at particular vertices or grown into a family of core graphs of larger nullity by adding a vertex at a time. Moreover, we propose a construction of nut line graph of trees by coalescence and a local enlargement of nut fullerenes and tetravalent nut graphs.</p>	string
21	en_US	abstract	<p>Pach and Tóth [PT] introduced a new version of the crossing number parameter, called the degenerate crossing number, by considering proper drawings of a graph in the plane and counting multiple crossing of edges through the same point as a single crossing when all pairwise crossings of edges at that point are transversal. We propose a related parameter, called the genus crossing number, where edges in the drawing need not be represented by simple arcs. This relaxation has two important advantages. First, the genus crossing number is invariant under taking subdivisions of edges and is also a minor-monotone graph invariant. Secondly, it is “computable” in many instances, which is a rare phenomenon in the theory of crossing numbers. These facts follow from the proof that the genus crossing number is indeed equal to the non-orientable genus of the graph. It remains an open question if the genus crossing number can be strictly smaller than the degenerate crossing number of Pach and Tóth. A relation to the minor crossing number introduced by Bokal, Fijavž, and Mohar [BFM] is also discussed.</p><p>[BFM] D. Bokal, G. Fijavž, and B. Mohar, The minor crossing number, <em>SIAM J. Discrete Math.</em> <strong>20</strong> (2006), 344–356.<br />[PT] J. Pach, G. Tóth, Degenerate crossing numbers, submitted, 2006.</p>	string
23	en_US	abstract	For a connected finite graph $G$ and a subset $V_{0}$ of its vertex\\r\\nset, a distance-residual subgraph is a subgraph induced on the set\\r\\nof vertices at the maximal distance from $V_{0}$. Some properties\\r\\nand examples of distance-residual subgraphs of vertex-transitive,\\r\\nedge-transitive, bipartite and semisymmetric graphs are presented.\\r\\nThe relations between the distance-residual subgraphs of product graphs and their factors are explored.	string

26	en_US	abstract	The Wythoff construction takes a d-dimensional polytope P, a subset S of {0, ..., d} and returns another d-dimensional polytope P(S). If P is a regular polytope, then P(S) is vertex-transitive. This construction builds a large part of the Archimedean polytopes and tilings in dimension 3 and 4. We want to determine, which of those Wythoffians P(S) with regular P have their skeleton or dual skeleton isometrically embeddable into the hypercubes H<sub>m</sub> and half-cubes 1/2 H<sub>m</sub>. We find six infinite series, which, we conjecture, cover all cases for dimension d &gt; 5 and some sporadic cases in dimension 3 and 4 (see Tables 1 and 2). Three out of those six infinite series are explained by a general result about the embedding of Wythoff construction for Coxeter groups. In the last section, we consider the Euclidean case; also, zonotopality of embeddable P(S) are addressed throughout the text.	string

27	en_US	abstract	Considered are graphs in which every cycle has a length divisible by a given positive integer $m\\ge3$, having at least one cycle. Sharp estimates on the number of edges in such graphs (given the number of vertices) are established and the equality instances are determined.	string
29	en_US	abstract	Fault tolerance and transmission delay of networks are important concepts in network\\r\\ndesign. The notions are strongly related to connectivity and diameter of a graph,\\r\\nand have been studied by many authors. Wide diameter of a graph combines studying\\r\\nconnectivity with the diameter of a graph. Diameter with width $k$ of a graph $G$, $k$-diameter, \\r\\nis defined as the minimum integer $d$ for which there exist at least $k$ internally disjoint paths\\r\\nof length at most $d$ between any two distinct vertices in $G$.  \\r\\nDenote by  $\\DD_c(G)$   the    $c$-diameter of $G$  and $ \\kappa(G)$ the connectivity of $G$.\\r\\nIn the context of computer\\r\\nnetworks, wide diameters of Cartesian graph products have been recently studied by\\r\\nmany authors. Cartesian graph bundles is a class of graphs that is a generalization of\\r\\nthe Cartesian graph products.  \\r\\nLet $G$ be a  Cartesian graph bundle with fiber $F $\\r\\nover base $B $, $0<a \\leq \\kappa(F)$, and  $0<b \\leq \\kappa(B)$. \\r\\nWe prove that   $\\DD_{a+b} (G) \\leq \\DD_a(F) + \\DD_b(B) +1$.\\r\\nMoreover,  if  $G$ \\r\\nis a graph bundle with fiber $F\\neq K_2$\\r\\nover base $B\\neq K_2$, then $\\DD_{a+b} (G) \\leq \\DD_a(F) + \\DD_b(B)$.  \\r\\nThe bounds are tight.	string
30	en_US	abstract	In this paper we consider the trees with fixed order $n$ and diameter $d \\leq 4$. Among these trees we identify those trees whose index is minimal.	string
31	en_US	abstract	A graph <em>G</em> is said to be 2<em>-distinguishable</em> if there is a labeling of the vertices with two labels so that only the trivial automorphism preserves the labels. Call the minimum size of a label class in such a labeling of <em>G</em> the <em>cost of </em>2<em>-distinguishing <em>G</em></em> and denote it by <em>ρ</em>(<em>G</em>). This paper shows that for <em>n</em> ≥ 5, ⌈log<sub>2</sub> <em>n</em> ⌉ + 1 ≤ <em>ρ</em>(<em>Q</em><sub><em>n</em></sub>) ≤ 2⌈log<sub>2</sub><em>n</em>⌉ − 1, where <em>Q</em><sub><em>n</em></sub> is the hypercube of dimension <em>n</em>.	string
32	en_US	abstract	For all positive integers s and t, Brown et al. \\cite{B} defined \\r\\nf(s,t) to be the smallest positive integer N such that every \\r\\n2-coloring of [1, N] has a monochromatic homothetic copy of {1,1+s, 1+s+t}. They proved that $f(s,t) <= 4(s+t)+1$ for all s, t and that the equality holds in the case where both\\r\\n$s/g\\not\\equiv0\\pmod 4$ and $t/g\\not\\equiv0\\pmod 4$ with\\r\\n$g=gcd(s,t)$ and in many other cases. Also they proved that for all positive integer m, $f(4mt,t)=f(t,4mt)=4(4mt+t)-t+1$ or $4(4mt+t)+1$. In this paper, we show that \\r\\n$f(4mt,t)=f(t,4mt)=4(4mt+t)-t+1$ and that for\\r\\nall the other (s,t), $f(s,t)=4(s+t)+1$.	string
33	en_US	abstract	We consider routing methods for networks when geographic positions of\\r\\nnodes are available. Instead of using the original geographic coordinates,\\r\\nhowever, we precompute virtual coordinates using a barycentric embedding.\\r\\nCombined with simple geometric routing rules, this greatly reduces the\\r\\nlengths of routes and outperforms algorithms running on the original\\r\\ncoordinates. Along with experimental results we show guaranteed message\\r\\ndelivery and give time bounds for the precomputation. Finally, a method\\r\\nwith a less consuming precomputation is introduced. Our methods apply\\r\\nto networks, where short routes are of great importance, and the\\r\\none-time-precomputation is affordable.	string
34	en_US	abstract	The number of non-zero eigenvalues of a graph\\r\\n is the rank of its adjacency matrix ${\\bf A}$, whose signature and nullity are\\r\\nreferred to as the  signature and nullity of the  graph\\r\\nrespectively. The effect of perturbations of a graph on  the\\r\\nsignature and rank is considered. The generators of the nullspace of\\r\\n${\\bf A}$ determine induced subgraphs called singular configurations\\r\\n(SCs). We use eigenvector techniques to obtain sharp lower bounds\\r\\nand exact expressions for the difference between the rank of a graph\\r\\nand that of an induced subgraph, which is  a SC, having the same\\r\\nnon-zero part of a nullvector as the graph. Also presented are\\r\\nalgorithms that construct maximal graphs with the same non-zero part\\r\\nof a nullvector, rank and signature as a given SC. We also relate\\r\\nSCs to zero--star complements, the non-singular graphs obtained when\\r\\ndeleting $k$ vertices from graphs of nullity $k$.	string
35	en_US	abstract	<p>There are many results on graphs with the smallest eigenvalue at least -2. As a next step, A. J. Hoffman proposed to study graphs with the smallest eigenvalue at least -1 - √2. In order to deal with such graphs, R. Woo and A. Neumaier defined a new generalization of line graphs which depends on a family of isomorphism classes of graphs with a distinguished coclique. They proved a theorem analogous to Hoffman's, using a particular family consisting of four isomorphism classes. In this paper, we deal with a generalization based on a family H smaller than the one which they dealt with, yet including generalized line graphs in the sense of Hoffman. The main result is that the cover of an H-line graph with at least 8 vertices is unique.</p>	string
37	en_US	abstract	Hamiltonicity and vulnerability of graphs are in a strong connection. A basic necessary condition states that a graph containing a 2-leaf spanning tree (that is a Hamiltonian path) cannot be split into more than <em>k</em> + 1 components by deleting <em>k</em> of its vertices. In this paper we consider a more general approach and investigate the connection between the number of spanning tree leaves and two vulnerability parameters namely scattering number sc(<em>G</em>) and cut-asymmetry ca(<em>G</em>). We prove that any spanning tree of a graph <em>G</em> has at least sc(<em>G</em>) + 1 leaves. We also show that if <em>X </em>$\\subset$ <em>V</em> is a maximum cardinality independent set of <em>G </em>= (<em>V</em>, <em>E</em>) such that the elements of <em>X</em> are all leaves of a particular spanning tree then |<em>X</em>| = ca(<em>G</em>) + 1 = |<em>V</em>| − cvc(<em>G</em>), where cvc(<em>G</em>) is the size of a minimum connected vertex cover of <em>G</em>. As a consequence we obtain a new proof for the following results: any spanning tree with independent leaves provides a 2-approximation for both MaximumInternalSpanningTree and MinimumConnectedVertexCover problems. We also consider the opposite point of view by fixing the number of leaves to <em>q</em> and looking for a <em>q</em>-leaf subtree of <em>G</em> that spans a maximum number of vertices. Bermond proved that a 2-connected graph on <em>n</em> vertices always contains a path (a 2-leaf subtree) of length min {n,δ<sub>2</sub>}, where δ<sub>2</sub> is the minimum degree-sum of a 2-element independent set. We generalize this result to obtain a sufficient condition for the existence of a large <em>q</em>-leaf subtree.	string
39	en_US	abstract	In 1977, Ganter and Teirlinck proved that any $2t \\times 2t$\\r\\nmatrix with $2t$ nonzero elements can be partitioned into four\\r\\nsubmatrices of order $t$ of which at most two contain nonzero\\r\\nelements. In 1978, Kramer and Mesner conjectured that any $mt \\times nt$ matrix with $kt$ nonzero elements can be partitioned into $mn$ submatrices of order $t$ of which at most $k$ contain nonzero elements. In $1995$, Brualdi et al. showed that this conjecture is true if $m = 2$, $k \\leq 3$ or $k \\geq mn-2$. They also found a counterexample of this conjecture for $m=4$, $n=4$, $k=6$ and $t=2$. When $t=2$, Rho showed that this conjecture istrue if $k \\leq 5$. When $t=2$ and $m=3$, we show that this conjecture is true if $k=6$ or $n\\leq 3$. As a result, we show that when $t=2$, this conjecture is true if $k = mn-3$ also.	string
40	en_US	abstract	If S is a compact Riemann surface of genus <em>g</em> &gt; 1 then S has at most 84(<em>g</em> − 1) (orientation preserving) automorphisms (Hurwitz). On the other hand, if <em>G</em> is a group of automorphisms of S and |<em>G</em>| &gt; 24(<em>g</em> − 1) then <em>G</em> is the automorphism group of a regular oriented map (of genus <em>g</em>) and if |<em>G</em>| &gt; 12(g − 1) then <em>G</em> is the automorphism group of a regular oriented hypermap of genus <em>g</em> (Singerman). We generalise these results and prove that if |<em>G</em>| &gt; <em>g</em> − 1 then <em>G</em> is the automorphism group of a regular restrictedly-marked hypermap of genus <em>g</em>. As a special case we also show that a marked finite transitive permutation group (Singerman) is a restrictedly-marked hypermap with the same genus.	string

This construction is related to a previous construction by Schulte that solves the problem   \\r\\nwhen the entry of the Schläfli symbol is 6.	string

44	en_US	abstract	A program computing isomorphisms between association schemes was applied to speed up the computation of normalizers of permutation groups. A transitive permutation group forms an association scheme while a permutation group which may not be transitive forms a coherent configuration. In this paper we discuss the extension of the above program to compute isomorphisms between coherent configurations and show some typical examples of computing normalizers.	string
45	en_US	abstract	A. Juri¥v{s}i¥'c and J.H. Koolen proposed to study 1-homogeneous \\r\\ndistance-regular graphs, see Figure 1.1,\\r\\nwhose $¥mu$-graphs (that is, the graphs induced \\r\\non the common neighbours of two vertices at distance 2) \\r\\nare complete multipartite. \\r\\nExamples include \\r\\nthe Johnson graph J$(8,4)$,\\r\\nthe halved $8$-cube, \\r\\nthe known generalized quadrangle of order $(4,2)$, \\r\\nan antipodal distance-regular graph constructed by T. Meixner\\r\\nand the Patterson graph.\\r\\nWe investigate a more general situation, namely, requiring the graphs \\r\\nto have complete multipartite $¥mu$-graphs, and \\r\\nthat the intersection number $¥alpha$ exists. \\r\\nThe latter condition is satisfied by any 1-homogeneous graph. \\r\\nLet $K_{t¥times n}$ denote the complete multipartite graph with \\r\\n$t$ parts, each of which consists of an $n$-coclique. \\r\\nWe show that if $¥G$ is a graph whose $¥mu$-graphs are all isomorphic \\r\\nto $K_{t¥times n}$ and whose intersection number $¥alpha$ exists, \\r\\nthen $¥alpha =t$, as conjectured by Juri¥v{s}i¥'c and Koolen, \\r\\nprovided $¥alpha ¥ge 2$. \\r\\nWe also prove $t ¥le 4$, and that equality holds only when $¥G$ is the\\r\\nunique distance-regular graph $3.O_7(3)$.	string
46	en_US	abstract	Soliton automata are a graph theoretic model for electronic switching at the molecular level. In the design of soliton circuits, the deterministic property of the corresponding automata is of primary importance. The underlying graphs of such automata, called deterministic soliton graphs, are characterized in terms of graphs not having even-length cycles and graphs having a unique perfect matching. On the basis of this characterization, a modification of the currently most efficient unique perfect matching algorithm is worked out to decide in <em>O</em>(<em>m</em> log<sup>4</sup> <em>n</em>) time if a graph with <em>n</em> vertices and <em>m</em> edges defines a deterministic soliton automaton. A yet more efficient <em>O</em>(<em>m</em>) algorithm is given for the special case of chestnut and elementary soliton graphs. All of these algorithms are capable of constructing a state for the corresponding soliton automaton, and the general algorithm can also be used to simplify the automaton to an isomorphic elementary one.	string
47	en_US	abstract	By a patch on a fullerene we mean a region of the fullerene bounded by an elementary circuit. In general, the structure of the interior of a patch is not uniquely determined by the boundary. That is the fullerene may be changed into a different fullerene by making alterations entirely within the patch. When the patch is not uniquely determined by its boundary we say the patch is ambiguous. Since each fullerene contains exactly 12 pentagonal faces, the number of pentagons in a patch is determined by its boundary. Patches that enclose two or more pentagons usually can be altered by changing the positions of these pentagons relative to one another. In this paper we show that every ambiguous patch must include one or more pentagons.	string
48	en_US	abstract	The paper investigates relationship between algebraic expressions and graphs. We consider a digraph called a Fibonacci graph which gives a generic example of non-series-parallel graphs. Our intention in this paper is to simplify the expressions of Fibonacci graphs and eventually find their shortest representations. With that end in view, we describe the number of methods for generating Fibonacci graph expressions and carry out their comparative analysis.	string
50	en_US	abstract	<p> We develop a rigorous algebraic background for representations of triangle groups in linear groups over algebras arising from factor rings of multivariate polynomial rings. This is then used to substantially improve the existing upper bounds on the order of epimorphic images of triangle groups with a given injectivity radius and, analogously, the size of the associated hypermaps of a given type with a given planar width.</p><p> </p>	string
51	en_US	abstract	In this paper we are mainly concerned with the Cayley isomorphism problem for groups containing $Q_8$. We prove that the group $Q_8\\times C_3$ is not a CI-group with respect to colour ternary relational structures. Further, we prove that the non-nilpotent group $Q_8\\rtimes C_3$ is not a CI-group with respect to graphs.	string
52	en_US	abstract	B. Grünbaum and G. C. Shephard have classified one-ended, 3-connected, planar, edge-transitive maps. It turns out that each of these maps can be described uniquely by an edge-symbol ‹<em>p</em>, <em>q</em>; <em>k</em>, ℓ›. Recently the growth rate of each of these maps has been determined by S. Graves, T. Pisanski and M. E. Watkins. We determine the number of edge-transitive maps for a given growth rate.	string
53	en_US	abstract	Let $\\Gamma$ denote a $Q$-polynomial distance-regular graph with diameter $D \\geq 3$ and\\r\\nstandard module $V$ . Recently Ito and Terwilliger introduced four direct sum decompositions of $V$ ; we call these the $(\\mu, \\nu)$–split decompositions of V , where $\\mu, \\nu \\in \\{\\downarrow, \\uparrow\\}$. In this paper we show that the $(\\downarrow, \\downarrow)$–split decomposition and the $(\\uparrow,\\uparrow)$–split decomposition are dual with respect to the standard Hermitian form on $V$ . We also show that the $(\\downarrow, \\uparrow)$–split decomposition and the $(\\uparrow,\\downarrow)$–split decomposition are dual with respect to the standard Hermitian form on $V$.	string
54	en_US	abstract	A graph $H$ is defined to be light in a family $\\mathcal{H}$ of graphs if there exists a finite number $\\varphi(H,\\mathcal{H})$ such that each $G \\in \\mathcal{H}$ which contains $H$ as a subgraph, contains also a subgraph $K \\cong H$ such that the $\\Delta_G(K) \\leq  \\varphi(H,\\mathcal{H})$. We study light graphs in families of polyhedral graphs with prescribed minimum vertex degree $\\delta$, minimum face degree $\\rho$, minimum edge weight $w$ and dual edge weight $w^*$. For those families, we show that there exists a variety of small light cycles.	string
55	en_US	abstract	For a group $G$, and a subset $S$ of $G$ such that $1_G \\notin S$, let $\\Gamma = Cay(G, S)$ be a Cayley graph. Then $\\Gamma$ is said to be $s$-transitive, if $Aut(\\Gamma)$ is transitive on $s$-arcs set but is not transitive on $(s + 1)$-arcs set. An arc-transitive graph $\\Gamma$ is said to be 1-regular if $Aut(\\Gamma)$ acts regularly on 1-arcs set. In this paper we give a classification of 1-regular Cayley graphs of valency at most 5 on some of dihedral groups. In addition, we give a complete classification for $s$-transitive Cayley graphs of valency 5 on finite abelian groups.	string
56	en_US	abstract	A graph $X$, with a subgroup $G$ of the automorphism group $Aut(X)$ of $X$, is said to be $(G, s)$-{\\em transitive}, for some $s \\geq  1$, if $G$ is transitive on $s$-arcs but not on $(s + 1)$-arcs, and $s$-{\\em transitive} if it is $(Aut(X), s)$-transitive. Let $X$ be a connected $(G, s)$-{\\em transitive} graph, and $G_v$ the stabilizer of a vertex $v \\in V(X)$ in $G$. If $X$ has valency 5 and $G_v$ is solvable, Weiss [Math. Proc. Camb. Phil. Soc. 85(1979), 43-48] proved that $s \\leq  3$, and in this paper we prove that $G_v$ is isomorphic to the cyclic group $\\mathbb{Z}_5$, the dihedral group $D_10$ or the dihedral group $D_20$ for $s = 1$, the Frobenius group $F_20$ or $F_20 \\times \\mathbb{Z}_2$ for $s = 2$, or $F_20 \\times Z_4$ for $s = 3$. Furthermore, it is shown that for a connected 1-transitive Cayley graph $Cay(G, S)$ of valency 5 on a non-abelian simple group $G$, the automorphism group of $Cay(G, S)$ is the semidirect product $R(G)\\rtimes Aut(G, S)$, where $R(G)$ is the right regular representation of $G$ and $Aut(G, S) = \\{\\alpha \\in Aut(G)\\vert S^\\alpha = S\\}$.	string

71	en_US	abstract	A graph is half-arc-transitive if its automorphism group acts transitively on its vertex set, edge set, but not arc set. For a prime $p$ it is well known that there is no tetravalent half-arc-transitive graph of order $p$, $2p$ or $p^2$. Xu [J. Algebraic Combin.,<br />1(1992) 275-282] classified the tetravalent half-arc-transitive graphs of order $p^3$ and Feng et al. [European J. Combin., 29(2008) 555-567] classified the tetravalent half-arc-transitive graphs of order $p^4$. By Alspach and Xu [J. Algebraic Combin., 3(1994) 347-<br />355], one may deduce a classification of tetravalent half-arc-transitive graphs of order $3p$ and Feng et al. [European J.Combin, 28(2007) 726-733] classified the tetravalent half-arc-transitive graphs of order $4p$. In this paper, we shall show that there is no tetravalent half-arc-transitive graph of order $2p^2$.	string

60	en_US	abstract	The problem of deciding whether an arbitrary graph $G$ has a homomorphism into a given graph $H$ has been widely studied and has turned out to be very difficult. Hell and Ne\\v{s}etril proved that the decision problem is NP-complete unless $H$ is bipartite. We consider a restricted problem where $G$ an arbitrary triangle-free hexagonal graph and $H$ is a Kneser graph or its induced subgraph. We give an explicit construction which proves that any triangle-free hexagonal graph has a homomorphism into one-vertex deleted Petersen graph.	string

63	en_US	title	Nonorientable Regular Embeddings of Graphs of Order $p^2$	string
63	en_US	abstract	<p> A map   is   called {\\em regular} if its automorphism group<br />acts regularly on the set of all  flags (incident vertex-edge-face triples).An orientable map is  called {\\em orientably-regular} if the group of all   orientation-preserving automorphisms is regular on the set of all arcs (incident vertex-edge pairs). If an<br />orientably-regular map   admits also orientation-reversing<br />automorphisms, then it is   regular, and called {\\em reflexible}.<br /> A {\\em regular embedding} and {\\em orientably-regular embedding} of a graph $\\cal G$  are  respectively  a   2-cell embeddings of $\\cal G$ as  a regular map and orientably-regular  map on some closed surface. In [1],  the orientably-regular embeddings of graphs of order $pq$ for   two primes $p$ and $q$ ($p$ may be equal to $q$) have been classified,  where all the reflexible maps can be easily  read from the classification theorem. In [2], Du and Wang classified the nonorientable regular embeddings of these graphs for $p\\ne q$.  In this paper, we shall classify the nonorienable regular embeddings of graphs of order $p^2$ where $p$ is a prime (see Theorem~\\ref{main}) so that a complete classification of regular embeddings of graphs of order $pq$ for two primes  $p$ and $q$ is obtained. All graphs in this paper are connected and simple.</p><p> References: [1] S.F. Du, J.H. Kwak and R. Nedela, A Classification of regular embeddings of graphs of order a product of two primes, J. Algeb. Combin. 19(2004), 123-141. </p><p>[2]  S.F. Du and F.R.Wang, Nonorientable<br />regular embeddings of graphs of order a product of two distinct<br />primes, submitted, 2007.</p>	string

13	en_US	sponsor		string
10	en_US	abstract	Given a drawing of a graph G, two crossings are said to be dependent if they are incident with the same vertex. A set of crossings is independent if no two are dependent. We conjecture that if G is a graph that has a drawing all of whose crossings are independent, then the chromatic number of G is at most 5. We show that this conjecture is true if the crossing number of G is at most three. We also show that if all crossings are independent, then the chromatic number of G is at most 6, and the independence ratio of G is at least 3/16.	string

67	en_US	title	General neighbour-distinguishing index via chromatic number	string
67	en_US	abstract	An edge colouring of a graph $G \\neq K_2$ is neighbour-distinguishing if any two adjacent vertices have distinct sets consisting of colours of their incident edges. The general neighbour-distinguishing index of $G$ is a minimum number $\\mathrm{gndi}(G)$ of colours in a neighbour-distinguishing<br />edge colouring of G. Győri et al. proved that $\\mathrm{gndi}(G) \\in \\{2, 3\\}$ provided $G$ is bipartite and gave a complete characterisation of bipartite&nbsp;graphs according to their general neighbour-distinguishing index. The aim of this paper is to prove that if $\\chi(G) \\geq 3$, then $\\lceil log_2 \\chi(G)\\rceil + 1 \\leq \\mathrm{gndi}(G) \\leq \\lceil \\log_2 \\chi(G) \\rceil + 2$. <br />Therefore, if $\\log_2 \\chi(G) \\notin \\mathbbb{Z}$, then <br />$\\mathrm{gndi}(G) = \\lceil \\log_2 \\chi(G)\\rceil + 1$.	string

68	en_US	title	Edge-contributions of some topological indices and arboreality of molecular graphs	string
68	en_US	abstract	Some graph invariants can be computed by summing certain values, called <em>edge-contributions</em> over all edges of graphs. In this note we use edge-contributions to study relationships among three graph invariants, also known as topological indices in mathematical chemistry: Wiener index, Szeged index and recently introduced revised Szeged index. We also use the quotient between the Wiener index and the revised Szeged index to study tree-likeness of graphs.	string

69	en_US	title	Omittable lines	string
69	en_US	abstract	Given a collection of <em>n</em> lines in the real projective plane, a line $\\ell$ is said to be <em>omittable</em> if $\\ell$ is free of ordinary points of intersection---in other words, if all the intersection points of $\\ell$ with other lines from the collection come at the intersection of three or more lines. Given a collection of lines $\\mathcal{L}$, denoting by $\\mathcal{O(L)}$ the set of all omittable lines in the collection and by $g(\\mathcal{L})$ the cardinality of $\\mathcal{O(L)}$, we describe three infinite families of lines that can serve as $\\mathcal{O(L)}$ for suitable $\\mathcal{L}$ and also display a finite set of sporadic additional examples in which $\\mathcal{O(L)}$ does not fall into any of the three families. We derive bounds on the size of $g(\\mathcal{L})$ when $\\mathcal{O(L)}$ falls into one of the three infinite families and weaker bounds for the more general case.	string

72	en_US	title	Characterizing posets for which their natural transit functions coincide	string
72	en_US	abstract	The standard poset transit function of a poset <em>P</em> is a function <em>T<sub>P</sub></em> that assigns to a pair of comparable elements the interval between them, while <em>T<sub>P</sub></em>(<em>x</em>,<em>y</em>) = {<em>x</em>,<em>y</em>} for a pair <em>x</em>, <em>y</em> of incomparable elements. Posets in which the standard poset transit function coincides with the shortest-path transit function of its cover-incomparability graph are characterized in three ways, in particular with forbidden subposets.	string

73	en_US	title	On the extremal values of ratios of number of paths	string
73	en_US	abstract	In this paper, we analyze the ratios of the numbers of paths <em>p</em><sub><em>i</em></sub>(<em>G</em>) and <em>p</em><sub><em>j</em></sub>(<em>G</em>) of different length in graph <em>G</em>. Namely, we are interested in the extremal values of these ratios for acyclic and cyclic graphs with given maximal degree. The values of infinum and supremum for graphs with given maximal degree are obtained. Also, the infinum of these ratios for trees with given maximal degree are obtained. Suprema for trees of given maximal degree are given when ratios of paths of length 1 and 2 are observed, and when ratios of paths of lengths 1 and 3 are observed. As the main result, a linear algorithm (in terms of maximal degree) for finding suprema of the ratios of the numbers of paths of length 2 and 3 for trees with given maximal degree is presented.	string

74	en_US	title	The Cycle Theorem, Overlap-Matrices, and the Counting of Spanning Trees	string
74	en_US	abstract	The Cycle Theorem (CT) was introduced under that name by Klein, Sachs and the present authors in 2004. It provides a formula for calculating how many spanning trees a graph has (its complexity) and it also highlights a certain duality in the structure of the graph. The latter aspect is discussed in Part I of the present paper. In Part II a computer program is developed which uses CT to calculate the complexities of some non-planar graphs which can be embedded on a torus, forming symmetrical tri-valent tessellations thereon. Because of shortage of space, the proofs of several assertions must be sought in the literature, references being supplied.	string

75	en_US	title	The strongly distance-balanced property of the generalized Petersen graphs	string
75	en_US	abstract	A graph <em>X</em> is said to be <em>strongly distance-balanced</em> whenever for any edge <em>uv</em> of <em>X</em> and any positive integer <em>i</em>, the number of vertices at distance <em>i</em> from <em>u</em> and at distance <em>i</em> + 1 from <em>v</em> is equal to the number of vertices at distance <em>i</em> + 1 from <em>u</em> and at distance <em>i</em> from <em>v</em>. It is proven that for any integers <em>k</em> ≥ 2 and <em>n</em> ≥ <em>k</em><sup>2</sup> + 4<em>k</em> + 1, the generalized Petersen graph GP(<em>n</em>, <em>k</em>) is not strongly distance-balanced.	string

76	en_US	title	VERTEX-TRANSITIVE EXPANSIONS OF (1,3)-TREES	string
76	en_US	abstract	A nonidentity automorphism of a graph is said to be {\\em semiregular} if all of its orbits are of the same length. Given a graph $X$ with a semiregular automorphism $\\gamma$, the quotient of $X$ relative to $\\gamma$ is the multigraph $X/\\gamma$ whose vertices are the orbits of $\\gamma$ and two vertices are adjacent by an edge with multiplicity $r$ if every vertex of one orbit is adjacent to $r$ vertices of the other orbit. We say that $X$ is an {\\em expansion} of $X/\\gamma$. In {\\em J. Comb. Theory} (Ser. B) {\\bf 53} (1991) 114--129, Horton and Bouwer considered a restricted sort of expansions (which we will call `strong' in this article) where every leaf of $X/\\gamma$ expands to a single cycle in $X$. They were able to determine all cubic arc-transitive strong expansions of simple (1,3)-trees, that is, trees with all of their vertices having valency 1 or 3, thus extending the classical result of Frucht, Graver and Watkins (see {\\em Proc. Camb. Phil. Soc.} {\\bf 70} (1971) 211--218) about arc-transitive strong expansions of $K_2$ (also known as the generalized Petersen graphs). In this article another step further is taken by considering the possible structure of cubic vertex-transitive expansions of general (1,3)-multitrees (where vertices with double edges are also allowed).	string
76	en_US	discipline	Mathematics; graph theory	string
76	en_US	subjectClass	05C25	string
76	en_US	subject	graph; tree; cubic; vertex-transitive; arc-transitive; expansion	string
76	en_US	sponsor	Agencija za raziskovalno dejavnost Republike Slovenije, research program P1-0285	string

These bases are expressed in terms of the cycle structure of the symmetric digraph on <em>G</em>.	string

79	en_US	title	Cayley graphs and symmetric 4-polytopes	string
79	en_US	abstract	Previously we have investigated the medial layer graph $\\mathcal{G}$ for a finite, self-dual, regular or chiral abstract 4-polytope $\\mathcal{P}$. 81	en_US	title	Recent trends and future directions in vertex-transitive graphs	string
81	en_US	abstract	A graph is said to be <em>vertex-transitive</em> if its automorphism group acts transitively on the vertex set. Some recent developments and possible future directions regarding two famous open problems, asking about existence of Hamilton paths and existence of semiregular automorphisms in vertex-transitive graphs, are discussed, together with some recent results on arc-transitive graphs and half-arc-transitive graphs, two special classes of vertex-transitive graphs that have received particular attention over the last decade.	string

82	en_US	title	HOMOGENOUSLY ALMOST SELF-COMPLEMENTARY CAYLEY GRAPHS	string
82	en_US	abstract	A graph $\\G$ is called a {\\em homogenously almost self-complementary}  if it is isomorphic to $\\G^{c}-\\mathscr{F}$ with respect to some $1-$factor $\\mathscr{F}$ and $(Aut\\G)_{\\mathscr{F}}$, the subgroup of $Aut\\G$ which fixes $\\mathscr{F}$ setwise, acts transitively on $\\G$. A Cayley graph $\\G=\\cay(G, S)$ is said to be a {\\em perfect almost self-complementary} if $\\G^{c}-\\mathscr{F}$ is a Cayley graph on the same group $G$ and the associated almost self-complementary isomorphism, called a {\\em perfect isomorphisms}  belongs to $Aut(G)$. It is proved that  in all such perfect almost self-complementary Cayley graphs the\\r\\nperfect isomorphisms can be taken from a Sylow $2-$subgroup of $Aut(G)$. Some applications of this result for finite abelian  groups and inner cyclic groups are also obtained.	string

83	en_US	abstract		string
83	en_US	discipline		string
83	en_US	subjectClass		string
83	en_US	subject		string
83	en_US	sponsor		string
84	en_US	abstract	\\begin{abstract}\\r\\nFor two vertices $u$ and $v$ in a graph $G = (V, E)$, the \\emph{detour distance} $D(u, v)$ is the length of a longest $u$--$v$ path in $G$.  A $u$--$v$ path of length $D(u, v)$ is called a $u$--$v$ \\emph{detour}.  A set $S \\subseteq   V$ is called a \\emph{detour set} of $G$ if every vertex in $G$ lies on a detour joining a pair of vertices of $S$.  The \\emph{detour number} $dn(G)$ of $G$ is the minimum order of its detour sets and any detour set of order $dn(G)$ is a \\emph{detour basis} of $G$.  A set $S \\subseteq V$ is called a \\emph{connected detour set} of $G$ if $S$ is detour set of $G$ and the subgraph $G[S]$ induced by $S$ is connected.  The \\emph{connected detour number} $cdn(G)$ of $G$ is the minimum order of its connected detour sets and any connected detour set of order $cdn(G)$ is called a \\emph{connected detour basis} of $G$. Graphs $G$ with detour diameter $D \\le  4$ are characterized when  $cdn(G) = p$, $cdn(G) = p -1$, $cdn(G) = p -2$ or $cdn(G) = 2$.\\r\\nA subset $T$ of a connected detour basis $S$ of $G$ is a \\emph{forcing subset} for $S$ if $S$ is the unique connected detour basis containing $T$. The \\emph{forcing connected detour number} $fcdn(S)$ of $S$ is the minimum cardinality of a forcing subset for $S$. The \\emph{forcing connected detour number} $fcdn(G)$ of $G$ is min$\\{fcdn(S)\\}$, where the minimum is taken over all connected detour bases $S$ in $G$. Several results concerning the forcing connected detour number of a connected graph are presented. The forcing connected detour numbers of certain classes of graphs are determined. It is also shown that for each pair $a$, $b$ of integers with $0 \\le  a < b$ and $b \\ge  3$, there is a connected graph $G$ with $fcdn(G) = a$ and  $cdn(G) = b$.\\r\\n\\r\\n\\end{abstract	string

86	en_US	title	On the extremal values of ratios of number of walks	string
86	en_US	abstract	In this paper we analyze the possible values of the ratios of numbers of walks w_{i}(G) and w_{j}(G) of different length in the same graph G. We are interested here in the extremal values of ratios for acyclic graphs and for all graphs with given maximal degree. The supremums of these ratios for graphs with given maximal degrees are obtained. Infinums for the ratios w₂(G)/w₁(G),w₃(G)/w₁(G) and w₃(G)/w₂(G) for graphs with given maximal degrees are obtained and they are also obtained for trees with given maximal degree. Supremums of the ratios w₂(G)/w₁(G) and w₃(G)/w₁(G) are obtained for trees with given degrees, while for the calculation of supremums of the ratio w₃(G)/w₂(G) for trees with given degrees linear algorithm (in terms of maximal degree) is presented.	string

87	en_US	title	The distinguishing chromatic number of Cartesian products of two complete graphs	string
87	en_US	abstract	A labeling of a graph $G$ is distinguishing if it is \\r\\nonly preserved by the trivial automorphism of $G$. The \\r\\ndistinguishing chromatic number of $G$ is the smallest \\r\\ninteger $k$ such that $G$ has a distinguishing labeling \\r\\nthat is at the same time a proper vertex coloring. \\r\\nThe distinguishing chromatic number of the Cartesian product\\r\\n$K_k\\cp K_n$ is determined for all $k$ and $n$. In most\\r\\nof the cases it is equal to the chromatic number, thus \\r\\nanswering a question of Choi, Hartke and Kaul whether \\r\\nthere are some other graphs for which this equality holds.	string

88	en_US	title	A catalogue of simplicial arrangements in the real projective plane	string
88	en_US	abstract	An <span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-style: italic;">arrangement</span> is the complex generated in the real projective plane by a finite family of straight lines that do not form a pencil. The <span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-style: italic;">faces</span> of an arrangement are the connected components of the complement of the union of lines. An arrangement is <span class="Apple-style-span" style="font-style: italic;">simplicial</span> if all its faces are simplices (triangles). The present paper updates the only previous catalogue of simplicial arrangements, published almost 40 years ago, and presented in a very condensed form. The simplicial arrangements often provide optimal solutions for various problems. A problem that seems very hard is to decide whether the collection presented here is a complete listing of simplicial arrangements.	string

89	en_US	title	Almost all quartic half-arc-transitive weak metacirculants of Class II are of Class IV	string
89	en_US	abstract	<p>A {\\em half-arc-transitive graph} is a vertex- and edge- but not arc-transitive graph.<br />A {\\em weak metacirculant} is a graph admitting a transitive metacyclic group that is a group generated by <br />two automorphisms $\\rho$ and $\\sigma$, where $\\rho$ is $(m,n)$-semiregular for some integers $m \\geq 1$ and $n \\geq 2$,<br />and where $\\sigma$ normalizes $\\rho$.<br />It was shown in [D.~Maru\\v si\\v c and P. \\v Sparl, On quartic half-arc-transitive metacirculants, <br />J. Algebr. Comb. 2008, doi:10.1007/s10801-007-0107-y] that <br />each connected quartic half-arc-transitive weak metacirculant $X$ belongs to one (or possibly more) <br />of four classes of such graphs, reflecting the structure of the quotient graph $X_\\rho$ relative to the semiregular <br />automorphism $\\rho$. <br />The first of these classes, called Class~I, coincides with the class of<br />so-called tightly attached graphs. Class~II consists of the quartic half-arc-transitive weak <br />metacirculants for which the quotient graph $X_\\rho$ is a cycle with a loop at each vertex. <br />Class~III consists of those graphs for which each vertex of the quotient graph $X_\\rho$ is connected to three other<br />vertices, to one with a double edge. Finally, Class~IV consists of those graphs for which $X_\\rho$ is a <br />simple quartic graph.</p><p>This paper consists of two results concerning graphs of Class~II.<br />It is shown that, with the exception of the Doyle-Holt graph and its canonical double cover, <br />each quartic half-arc-transitive weak metacirculant of Class~II is also of Class~IV.<br />It is also shown that although quartic half-arc-transitive weak metacirculants <br />of Class~II which are not tightly attached exist they are ``almost tightly attached''. <br />More precisely, their radius is at most four times their attachment number.</p>	string

91	en_US	title	Cayley graphs, Cori hypermaps, and dessins d'enfants	string
91	en_US	abstract	This paper explains some facts probably known to experts and implicitely contained in the literature about dessins d'enfants but which seem to be nowhere explicitely stated. The 1-skeleton of every regular Cori hypermap is the Cayley graph of its automorphism group, embedded in the underlying orientable surface. Conversely, every Cayley graph of a finite two-generator group has an embedding as the 1-skeleton of a regular hypermap in the Cori representation. For non-regular hypermaps there is an analogous correspondence with Schreier coset diagrams.	string

92	en_US	title	A partial generalization of the Livingstone-Wagner Theorem	string
92	en_US	abstract	For a transitive permutation group <em>G</em> on a finite set Ω, the Livingstone–Wagner Theorem states that if <em>G</em> is <em>k</em>-homogeneous then <em>G</em> is (<em>k</em> − 1)-transitive. It can be conjectured that the number of <em>G</em>-orbits on <em>k</em>-subsets of Ω is greater than or equal to the one on ordered (<em>k</em> − 1)-tuples of Ω, if |Ω| is sufficiently large. For the simplest case <em>k</em> = 3, we prove this by establishing a result on edge-colorings of complete digraphs.	string

93	en_US	title	Large sets of long distance equienergetic graphs	string
93	en_US	abstract	Distance energy of a graph is a recent energy-type invariant, defined as the absolute deviation of the eigenvalues of the distance matrix of the graph. Two graphs of the same order are said to be distance equienergetic if they have equal distance energy, while they have distinct spectra of their distance matrices. Examples of pairs of distance equienergetic graphs appear in the literature already, but most of them have diameter two only.<br />We describe here the distance spectrum of a special composition of regular graphs, and, as an application, we show that for any <em>n</em> ≥ 3, there exists a set of <em>n</em> + 1 distance equienergetic graphs which have order 6<em>n</em> and diameter <em>n</em> − 1 each.	string

93	en_US	subject	Distance spectrum; Distance energy; Join; Regular graphs.	string
93	en_US	sponsor	ARRS, Serbian Ministry of Science	string
49	en_US	abstract	<p>In 1969, Grünbaum conjectured that snarks do not have polyhedral embeddings into orientable surfaces. We define the defect of a graph and use it to study embeddings of superpositions of cubic graphs into orientable surfaces. Superposition was introduced by Kochol to construct snarks with arbitrary large girth. It is shown that snarks constructed by Kochol do not have polyhedral embeddings into orientable surfaces. For each <em>k</em> = 2 we construct infinitely many snarks with defect precisely <em>k</em>. We then relate the defect with the resistance <em>r</em>(<em>G</em>) of a cubic graph <em>G</em> which is the size of a minimum color class of a 4-edge-coloring of <em>G</em>. These results are then extended to deal with some weaker versions of the Grünbaum Conjecture.</p>	string

100	en_US	title	Eigenspaces of Hamming graphs and unitary Cayley graphs	string
100	en_US	abstract	In this work, the eigenspaces of unitary Cayley graphs and certain Hamming graphs are considered. It is shown that these graph classes are closely related and admit particularly simple eigenspace bases for all eigenvalues, namely bases containing vectors only with entries from the set {0, 1, −1}. A direct consequence is that the considered graph classes are integral.	string

103	en_US	title	Distance spectrum of graph compositions	string
103	en_US	abstract	The <em>D</em>-eigenvalues <em>μ</em><sub>1</sub>, <em>μ</em><sub>2</sub>, ..., <em>μ</em><sub>p</sub> of a graph <em>G</em> are the eigenvalues of its distance matrix <em>D</em> and form the distance spectrum or the <em>D</em>-spectrum.  In this paper we obtain the <em>D</em>-spectrum of the cartesian product if two distance regular graphs. The <em>D</em>-spectrum of the lexicographic product <em>G</em>[<em>H</em>] of two graphs <em>G</em> and <em>H</em> when <em>H</em> is regular is also obtained. The <em>D</em>-eigenvalues of the Hamming graphs Ham(<em>d,</em> <em>n</em>) of diameter <em>d</em> and order <em>n</em><sup><em>d</em></sup> and those of the <em>C</em><sub>4</sub> nanotori, <em>T</em><sub><em>k</em>,<em>m</em>,<em>C</em><sub>4</sub></sub>, are determined.	string

104	en_US	title	A note on quasi-robust cycle bases	string
104	en_US	abstract	We investigate here some aspects of cycle bases of undirected graphs that allow the iterative construction of all elementary cycles. 106	en_US	abstract	The D− eigenvalues {μ1, μ2, . . . , . . . , μp} of a graph G are the eigenvalues of its<br />distance matrix D and form its D− spectrum. The D− energy, ED(G) of G is given<br />by ED (G) =<br />Pp<br />i=1<br />|μi|. Two non cospectral graphs with respect to D are said to be D−<br />equi energetic if they have the same D− energy. In this paper we show that if G is an<br />r− regular graph on p vertices with 2r  p − 1, then the complements of iterated line<br />graphs of G are of diameter 2 and that ED(Lk(G)), k  2 depends only on p and r.<br />This result leads to the construction of regular D− equi energetic pair of graphs	string

108	en_US	title	The generalized Reye configuration	string
108	en_US	abstract	Given an embedding in the plane of the vertices of a cube, we consider conditions on the embedded vertices such that they are the projection of the vertices of a 3 dimensional polyhedron combinatorially equivalent to the cube. We are particularly interested in conditions expressible as incidence conditions for the lines induced by the given vertex set in the plane. We show that the vertices and their incidences extend to a Reye configuration in the plane if and only if the vertices are the projection of a parallelepiped. More generally, the positions of the embedded vertices result from projecting a polyhedron combinatorially equivalent to the cube if and only if they belong to a plane configuration we call the generalized Reye configuration.	string

109	en_US	title	Strongly regular edge-transitive graphs	string
109	en_US	abstract	<p>In this paper, we examine the structure of vertex- and edge-transitive strongly regular graphs, using normal quotient reduction. We show that the irreducible graphs in this family have quasiprimitive automorphism groups, and prove (using the Classiﬁcation of Finite Simple Groups) that no graph in this family has a holomorphic simple automorphism group. We also ﬁnd some constraints on the parameters of the graphs in this family that reduce to complete graphs.</p>	string

110	en_US	title	Genus distributions of graphs under edge-amalgamations	string
110	en_US	abstract	We present a general method for calculating the genus distributions of those infinite families of graphs that are obtained by iteratively amalgamating copies of some base graphs along their <em>root-edges</em>. 111	en_US	title	Genus distribution of graph amalgamations: Pasting when one root has arbitrary degree	string
111	en_US	abstract	<div>This paper concerns counting the imbeddings of a graph in a surface. In the first installment of our current work, we showed how to calculate the genus distribution of an iterated amalgamation of copies of a graph whose genus distribution is already known and is further analyzed into a <em>partitioned genus distribution</em> (which is defined for a <em>double-rooted graph</em>). 112	en_US	title	Immersing small complete graphs	string
112	en_US	abstract	<div>Following in the spirit of the Hadwiger and Hajós conjectures, Abu-Khzam and Langston have conjectured that every <em>k</em>-chromatic graph contains an immersion of <em>K</em><sub><em>k</em></sub>. They proved this for <em>k</em> ≤ 4. Much before that, Lescure and Meyniel [F. Lescure and H. Meyniel, On a problem upon configurations contained in graphs with given chromatic number, Graph theory in memory of G. A. Dirac (Sandbjerg, 1985), 325−331, Ann. Discrete Math. 41, North-Holland, Amsterdam, 1989] obtained a stronger result that included also the values <em>k</em> = 5 and 6, by proving that every simple graph of minimum degree <em>k</em> − 1 contains an immersion of <em>K</em><sub><em>k</em></sub>. They noted that they also have a proof of the same result for <em>k</em> = 7 but have not published it due to the length of the proof. We give a simple proof of this result. This, in particular, proves the conjecture of Abu-Khzam and Langston for every <em>k</em> ≤ 7.</div>	string

114	en_US	title	On Cartesian skeletons of graphs	string
114	en_US	abstract	Under suitable conditions of connectivity or non-bipartiteness, each of the three standard graph products (the Cartesian product, the direct product and the strong product) satisfies the unique prime factorization property, and there are polynomial algorithms to determine the prime factors. This is most easily proved for the Cartesian product. For the other products, current proofs involve a notion of a <em>Cartesian skeleton</em> which transfers their multiplication properties to the Cartesian product. The present article introduces simplified definitions of Cartesian skeletons for the direct and strong products, and provides new, fast and transparent algorithms for their construction. Since the complexity of the prime factorization of the direct and the strong product is determined by the complexity of the the construction of the Cartesian skeleton, the new algorithms also improve the complexity of the prime factorizations of graphs with respect to the direct and the strong product. We indicate how these simplifications fit into the existing literature.	string
114	en_US	discipline	Mathematics, graph theory	string

114	en_US	subject	Graph  product,  Cartesian skeleton, prime factorization of graphs, graph algorithms	string

115	en_US	title	Maximal core size in singular graphs	string
115	en_US	abstract	A graph <em>G</em> is singular of nullity <em>η</em> if the nullspace of its adjacency matrix <strong>G</strong> has dimension <em>η</em>. Such a graph contains <em>η</em> cores determined by a basis for the nullspace of <strong>G</strong>. These are induced subgraphs of singular configurations, the latter occurring as induced subgraphs of <em>G</em>. We show that there exists a set of <em>η</em> distinct vertices representing the singular configurations. We also explore how the nullity controls the size of the singular substructures and characterize those graphs of maximal nullity containing a substructure reaching maximal size.	string

118	en_US	title	The excluded minor structure theorem with planarly embedded wall	string
118	en_US	abstract	<p>A graph is “nearly embedded” in a surface if it consists of graph <span class="math"><em>G</em><sub>0</sub></span> that is embedded in the surface, together with a bounded number of vortices having no large transactions. It is shown that every large wall (or grid minor) in a nearly embedded graph, many rows of which intersect the embedded subgraph <span class="math"><em>G</em><sub>0</sub></span> of the near-embedding, contains a large subwall that is planarly embedded within <span class="math"><em>G</em><sub>0</sub></span>. This result provides some hidden details needed for a strong version of the Robertson and Seymour’s excluded minor theorem as presented in:</p><p>T. Böhme, K. Kawarabayashi, J. Maharry and B. 119	en_US	title	Examples of computer experimentation in algebraic combinatorics	string
119	en_US	abstract	We introduce certain paradigms for procuring computer-free explanations from data acquired via computer algebra experimentation. Our established context is the field of algebraic combinatorics, with special focus on coherent configurations and association schemes. All results presented here were obtained by the authors with the aid of computer algebra systems, especially COCO and GAP. A number of examples are explored, in particular of objects on 28, 50, 63, and 210 points. In a few cases, initial experimental data pointed to appropriate theoretical generalizations that yielded an infinite class of related combinatorial structures. Special attention is paid to algebraic automorphisms (of a coherent algebra), a fairly new concept that has already proved to have far-reaching consequences. Finally, we focus on the Doyle-Holt graph on 27 vertices, and some of its related structures.	string

121	en_US	title	On pseudocyclic association schemes	string
121	en_US	abstract	The notion of a pseudocyclic association scheme is generalized to the non-commutative case. It is proved that any pseudocyclic scheme the rank of which is much more than the valency is the scheme of a Frobenius group and is uniquely determined up to isomorphism by its intersection number array. An immediate corollary of this result is that any scheme of prime degree, valency <em>k</em> and rank at least <em>k</em><sup>4</sup> is schurian.	string

122	en_US	title	Wada dessins associated with finite projective spaces and Frobenius compatibility	string
122	en_US	abstract	<p><em>Dessins d'enfants</em> (hypermaps) are useful to describe algebraic properties of the Riemann surfaces they are embedded in. In general, it is not easy to describe algebraic properties of the surface of the embedding starting from the combinatorial properties of an embedded dessin. However this task becomes easier if the dessin has a large automorphism group.</p><p>In this paper we consider a special type of dessins, so-called <em>Wada dessins</em>. Their underlying graph illustrates the incidence structure of finite projective spaces <strong>P</strong><sup><em>m</em></sup>(<strong>F</strong><sub><em>n</em></sub>). Usually, the automorphism group of these dessins is a cyclic <em>Singer group</em> Σ<sub><em>l</em></sub> permuting transitively the vertices. However, in some cases, a second group of automorphisms Φ<sub><em>f</em></sub> exists. It is a cyclic group generated by the <em>Frobenius automorphism</em>. We show under which conditions Φ<sub><em>f</em></sub> is a group of automorphisms acting freely on the edges of the considered dessins.</p>	string

124	en_US	title	Small vertex-transitive graphs of given degree and girth	string
124	en_US	abstract	We investigate the basic interplay between the small <em>k</em>-valent vertex-transitive graphs of girth <em>g</em> and the (<em>k</em>, <em>g</em>)-cages, the smallest <em>k</em>-valent graphs of girth <em>g</em>. We prove the existence of <em>k</em>-valent Cayley graphs of girth <em>g</em> for every pairof parameters <em>k</em> ≥ 2 and <em>g</em> ≥ 3, improve the lower bounds on the order of the smallest (<em>k</em>, <em>g</em>) vertex-transitive graphs forcertain families with prime power girth, and generalize the construction of Bray, Parker and Rowley that has yielded several of the smallest known (<em>k</em>, <em>g</em>)-graphs.	string
129	en_US	title	Facial parity edge colouring	string
129	en_US	abstract	A <em>facial parity edge colouring</em> of a connected bridgeless plane graph is an edge colouring in which no two face-adjacent edges (consecutive edges of a facial walk of some face) receive the same colour, in addition, for each face <em>α</em> and each colour <em>c</em>, either no edge or an odd number of edges incident with <em>\\alpha</em> is coloured with <em>c</em>. From Vizing's theorem it follows that every 3-connected plane graph has a such colouring with at most Δ<sup>*</sup> + 1 colours, where Δ<sup>*</sup> is the size of the largest face. In this paper we prove that any connected bridgeless plane graph has a facial parity edge colouring with at most 92 colours.	string

125	en_US	title	Half-arc-transitive graphs of order 4p of valency twice a prime	string
125	en_US	abstract	A graph is half-arc-transitive if its automorphism group acts transitively on vertices and edges, but not on arcs. Let <em>p</em> be a prime. Cheng and Oxley [On weakly symmetric graphs of order twice a prime, J. Combin. Theory B 42 (1987), 196−211] proved that there is no half-arc-transitive graph of order 2<em>p</em>, and Alspach and Xu [1/2-transitive graphs of order 3<em>p</em>, J. Algebraic Combin. 3 (1994), 347−355] classified half-arc-transitive graphs of order 3<em>p</em>. In this paper we classify half-arc-transitive graphs of order 4<em>p</em> of valency 2<em>q</em> for each prime <em>q</em> ≥ 5. It is shown that such graphs exist if and only if <em>p</em> − 1 is divisible by 4<em>q</em>. Moreover, for such <em>p</em> and <em>q</em> a unique half-arc-transitive graph of order 4<em>p</em> and valency 2<em>q</em> exists and this graph is a Cayley graph.	string

126	en_US	title	A new construction for symmetric (4,6)-configurations	string
126	en_US	abstract	Geometric (4,6)-configurations are collections of points and straight lines, in the Euclidean plane, so that every point has four lines passing through it and every line has six points lying on it. In this paper, we present a new construction for (4,6)-configurations which have high degrees of geometric symmetry, by superimposing  4-astral 4-configurations with certain properties.	string

127	en_US	title	The symmetric genus spectrum of finite groups	string
127	en_US	abstract	The symmetric genus of the finite group <em>G</em>, denoted by <em>σ</em>(<em>G</em>), is the smallest non-negative integer <em>g</em> such that the group <em>G</em> acts faithfully on a closed orientable surface of genus <em>g</em> (not necessarily preserving orientation). This paper investigates the question of whether for every non-negative integer <em>g</em>, there exists some <em>G</em> with symmetric genus <em>g</em>. It is shown that that the spectrum (range of values) of <em>σ</em> includes every non-negative integer <em>g</em> =!= 8 or 14 mod 18, and moreover, if a gap occurs at some <em>g</em> == 8 or 14 modulo 18, then the prime-power factorization of <em>g</em> − 1 includes some factor <em>p<sup>e</sup></em> == 5 mod 6. In fact, evidence suggests that this spectrum has no gaps at all.	string

128	en_US	title	Goal-minimally k-diametric graphs from fields	string
128	en_US	abstract	An undirected graph G with diameter k is said to be goal-minimally k-diametric if for every edge uv of G the distance d<sub>G-uv</sub>(x, y) > k if and only if {x, y} = {u, v}. It is rather difficult to construct such graphs. Before our research, they were known only for diameters up to 14, except of the case k = 11. In this paper we construct such graphs of larger diameters using Cayley graphs with generators obtained by linear fractional transformations on GF(q) U {infty}.	string

130	en_US	title	Classification and Galois conjugacy of Hamming maps	string
130	en_US	abstract	We show that for each <em>d</em> ≥ 1 the <em>d</em>-dimensional Hamming graph <em>H</em>(<em>d</em>, <em>q</em>) has an orientably regular surface embedding if and only if <em>q</em> is a prime power <em>p<sup>e</sup></em>. If <em>q</em> &gt; 2 there are up to isomorphism <em>φ</em>(<em>q</em> − 1)/<em>e</em> such maps, all constructed as Cayley maps for a <em>d</em>-dimensional vector space over the field <em>F<sub>q</sub></em>. We show that for each such pair (<em>d</em>, <em>q</em>) the corresponding Belyi pairs are conjugate under the action of the absolute Galois group Gal \\overline <strong>Q</strong>, and we determine their minimal field of definition. We also classify the orientably regular embedding of merged Hamming graphs for <em>q</em> &gt; 3.	string

134	en_US	title	The action of the mapping class group on the pants complex	string
134	en_US	abstract	For any compact surface S = Σ<sub>g,b</sub> of genus g with b boundary components, there is a cell complex attached to S, namely the pants complex P(S). 135	en_US	title	Fullerene patches I	string
135	en_US	abstract	Large carbon molecules, discovered at the end of the last century, are called fullerenes. The most famous of these, C<sub>60</sub> has the structure of the soccer ball: the seams represent chemical bonds and the points where three seams come together represent the carbon atoms. We use the term <em>fullerene</em> to represent all mathematically possible structures for the chemical fullerenes: trivalent plane graphs with only hexagonal and pentagonal faces. A simple consequence of Euler's formula is that each fullerene has exactly 12 pentagonal faces; the only restriction on the number of hexagonal faces is that it not be 1. The chemical motivation for this paper is to answer the question: When is it possible to alter a fullerene by changing the structure inside a region of the fullerene bounded by a simple closed circuit? Such a region or patch is said to be ambiguous if alterations may be made to its interior without disturbing the structure of the fullerene outside of the region.  In this paper, we show that, relative to the minimum distance between pentagonal faces,  there are no small ambiguous patches.	string
135	en_US	discipline	graph theory; planar graphs; chemical graph theory	string

141	en_US	title	On the Ubiquity and Utility of Cyclic Schemes	string
141	en_US	abstract	Let $k,l,m,n$, and $\\mu$ be positive integers. A\\r\\n$\\mathbb{Z}_\\mu$--{\\it scheme of valency} $(k,l)$ and {\\it order} $(m,n)$ is a $m \\times\\r\\nn$ array $(S_{ij})$ of subsets $S_{ij} \\subseteq \\mathbb{Z}_\\mu$\\r\\nsuch that for each row and column one has $\\sum_{j=1}^n |S_{ij}| =\\r\\nk $ and $\\sum_{i=1}^m |S_{ij}| = l$, respectively. Any such scheme is an algebraic equivalent of\\r\\na $(k,l)$--semi--regular bipartite voltage\\r\\ngraph with $n$ and $m$ vertices in the bipartition sets and\\r\\nvoltages coming from the\\r\\ncyclic group $\\mathbb{Z}_\\mu$. We are\\r\\ninterested in the subclass of $\\mathbb{Z}_\\mu$--schemes that are\\r\\ncharacterized by the property $a - b + c - d\\; \\not \\equiv \\;0$\\r\\n(mod $\\mu$) for all $a \\in S_{ij}$, $b \\in S_{ih}$, $c \\in\\r\\nS_{gh}$, and $d \\in S_{gj}$ where $i,g \\in \\{1,\\ldots,m\\}$ and\\r\\n$j,h \\in \\{1,\\ldots,n\\}$ need not be distinct. These\\r\\n$\\mathbb{Z}_\\mu$--schemes can be used to represent adjacency\\r\\nmatrices of regular graphs of girth $\\ge 5$ and semi--regular\\r\\nbipartite graphs of girth $\\ge 6$. For suitable $\\rho, \\sigma \\in\\r\\n\\mathbb{N}$ with $\\rho k = \\sigma l$, they also represent\\r\\nincidence matrices for polycyclic $(\\rho \\mu_k, \\sigma \\mu_l)$\\r\\nconfigurations and, in particular, for all known Desarguesian\\r\\nelliptic semiplanes.  Partial projective closures yield {\\it mixed\\r\\n$\\mathbb{Z}_\\mu$--schemes}, which allow new constructions for Kr\\v\\r\\ncadinac's sporadic  configuration of type $(34_6)$ and Balbuena's\\r\\nbipartite $(q-1)$--regular graphs of girth $6$ on as few as\\r\\n$2(q^2-q-2)$ vertices, with  $q$ ranging over prime powers.\\r\\nBesides some new results, this survey essentially furnishes new\\r\\nproofs in terms of (mixed) $\\mathbb{Z}_\\mu$--schemes for ad--hoc\\r\\nconstructions used thus far.	string

145	en_US	title	Asymptotic enumeration of reversible maps regardless of genus	string
145	en_US	abstract	We derive asymptotic expansions for the numbers <em>U</em>(<em>n</em>) of isomorphism classes of sensed maps on orientable surfaces with given number of edges <em>n</em>, where we do not specify the genus and for the numbers <em>A</em>(<em>n</em>) of reflexible maps with <em>n</em> edges. As expected the ratio <em>A</em>(<em>n</em>)/<em>U</em>(<em>n</em>) → 0 for <em>n</em> → ∞. This shows that almost all maps are chiral. Moreover, we show log <em>A</em>(<em>n</em>) ∼ (1/2)log <em>U</em>(<em>n</em>) ∼ (<em>n</em>/2)log <em>n</em>. Due to a correspondence between sensed maps with given number of edges and torsion-free subgroups of the group Γ = &lt; <em>x</em>, <em>y</em> | <em>y</em><sup>2</sup> = 1 &gt; of given index, the obtained results give an information on asymptotic expansions for the number of conjugacy classes of such subgroups of given index.	string

146	en_US	abstract	Let <em>f</em> be a noncommutative polynomial in two variables. Alg. 57 (2009), 307-317] the authors proposed questions, what one can say about the invariant subspace structure of S under this and other related conditions. 152	en_US	title	The monophonic number of Cartesian product graphs	string
152	en_US	abstract	For vertices $u,v$ in a connected graph $G$, a $u-v$ chordless path in $G$ is a $u-v$ monophonic path. The monophonic closed interval $J_G[u,v]$ consists of all the vertices lying on some $u-v$ monophonic path in $G$. For $S\\subseteq V(G)$, the set $J_G[S]$ is the union of all sets $J_G[u,v]$ for $u,v\\in S$. A set $S\\subseteq V(G)$ is a monophonic set of $G$ if $J_G[S]=V(G)$. The cardinality of a minimum monophonic set of $G$ is the monophonic number of $G$, denoted by $mn(G)$. In this paper, bounds for the monophonic number of Cartesian product graphs are obtained. Improved bounds and exact values are determined for several classes of Cartesian product graphs. Various realization results are proved.	string

153	en_US	title	On the edge-to-vertex geodetic number of a graph	string
153	en_US	abstract	<div>Let $G = (V, E)$ be a connected graph with at least three vertices.</div><div>For vertices $u$ and $v$ in $G,$ the {\\it distance} $d(u, v)$ is the</div><div>length of a shortest $u-v$ path in $G.$ A $u-v$ path of length $d(u,</div><div>v)$ is called a $u-v$ {\\it geodesic}.  For subsets $A$ and $B$ of $V,$ the</div><div>distance $d(A, B),$ is defined as $d(A, B) = min$ $\\{d(x, y) : x \\in</div><div>A, y \\in B\\}$. A $u -  v$ path of length $d(A, B)$ is called an $A -</div><div>B$ $geodesic$ joining the sets $A, B \\subseteq V,$ where $u \\in  A$</div><div>and $v \\in B.$ A vertex $x$ is said to \\emph{lie on} an $A  - B$ geodesic</div><div>if $x$ is a vertex of an $A  - B$ geodesic. A set $S \\subseteq  E$ is called an edge-to-vertex geodetic set if every vertex of $G$</div><div>is either incident with an edge of $S$ or lies on a geodesic joining</div><div>a pair of edges of $S.$ The edge-to-vertex geodetic number</div><div>$g_{ev}(G)$ of $G$ is the minimum cardinality of its edge-to-vertex</div><div>geodetic sets and any edge-to-vertex geodetic set of cardinality</div><div>$g_{ev}(G)$ is an edge-to-vertex geodetic basis of $G.$ Any edge-to-vertex geodetic basis is also called a</div><div>$g_{ev}$-set of $G.$ It is shown that if</div><div>$G$ is a connected graph of size $q$ and diameter $d,$ then</div><div>$g_{ev}(G) \\leq q - d + 2.$ It is proved that, for a tree $T$ with</div><div>$q \\geq 2,$ $g_{ev}(T) = q - d + 2$ if and only if $T$ is a</div><div>caterpillar. For positive integers $r, d$ and $l \\geq 2$</div><div>with $r \\leq d \\leq 2r,$ there exists a connected graph $G$ with $rad$</div><div>$G = r,$ $diam$ $G = d$ and $g_{ev}(G) = l.$ Also graphs $G$ for which</div><div>$g_{ev}(G) = q, q - 1$ or $q - 2$ are characterized.</div>	string

154	en_US	abstract	<div>New constructions of regular antipodal covers (in the sense of Godsil-Hensel) of complete graphs Kn are presented. 156	en_US	title	The inner power of a graph	string
156	en_US	abstract	<div>We define a new graph operation called the <em>k</em>th <em>inner power</em>. The construction—which is somewhat analogous to the <em>k</em>th power with respect to the direct product—seems to lend itself nicely to certain questions concerning cancellation over the direct product. We prove several results about bipartiteness and connectedness of inner powers, and we prove that the inner power distributes over the direct product. We explore a potential connection between inner powers and the problem of cancellation over the direct product.</div>	string

157	en_US	title	Decomposition of skew-morphisms of cyclic groups	string
157	en_US	abstract	A skew-morphism of a group <em>H</em> is a permutation <em>σ</em> of its elements fixing the identity such that for every <em>x</em>, <em>y</em> ∈ <em>H</em> there exists an integer <em>k</em> such that <em>σ</em>(<em>xy</em>)=<em>σ</em>(<em>x</em>)<em>σ</em><sup><em>k</em></sup>(<em>y</em>). It follows that group automorphisms are particular skew-morphisms. Skew-morphisms appear naturally in investigations of maps on surfaces with high degree of symmetry, namely, they are closely related to regular Cayley maps and to regular embeddings of the complete bipartite graphs. The aim of this paper is to investigate skew-morphisms of cyclic groups in the context of the associated Schur rings. We prove the following decomposition theorem about skew-morphisms of cyclic groups Z<sub><em>n</em></sub>: if <em>n</em> = <em>n</em><sub>1</sub><em>n</em><sub>2</sub> such that (<em>n</em><sub>1</sub>, <em>n</em><sub>2</sub>) = 1, and (<em>n</em><sub>1</sub>, <em>φ</em>(<em>n</em><sub>2</sub>)) = (<em>φ</em>(<em>n</em><sub>1</sub>), <em>n</em><sub>2</sub>) = 1 (<em>φ</em> denotes Euler's function) then all skew-morphisms <em>σ</em> of Z<sub><em>n</em></sub> are obtained as <em>σ</em> = <em>σ</em><sub>1</sub> × <em>σ</em><sub>2</sub>, where <em>σ</em><sub>i</sub> are skew-morphisms of Z<sub><em>n_i</em></sub>, i = 1, 2. As a consequence we obtain the following result: All skew-morphisms of Z<sub><em>n</em></sub> are automorphisms of Z<sub><em>n</em></sub> if and only if <em>n</em> = 4 or (<em>n</em>, <em>φ</em>(<em>n</em>)) = 1.	string

157	en_US	subjectClass		string

158	en_US	title	The scope	string

159	en_US	title	The total weak discrepancy of a partially ordered set	string
159	en_US	abstract	We define the total weak discrepancy of a poset <em>P</em> as the minimum nonnegative integer <em>k</em> for which there exists a function <em>f</em> : <em>V</em> → <strong>Z</strong> satisfying (i) if <em>a</em> \\prec <em>b</em> then <em>f</em>(<em>a</em>) + 1 ≤ <em>f</em>(<em>b</em>) and (ii) Σ|<em>f</em>(<em>a</em>) − <em>f</em>(<em>b</em>)| ≤ <em>k</em>, where the sum is taken over all unordered pairs {<em>a</em>, <em>b</em>} of incomparable elements. If we allow <em>k</em> and <em>f</em> to take real values, we call the minimum <em>k</em> the fractional total weak discrepancy of <em>P</em>. These concepts are related to the notions of weak and fractional weak discrepancy, where (ii) must hold not for the sum but for each individual pair of incomparable elements of <em>P</em>. We prove that, unlike the latter, the total weak and fractional total weak discrepancy of <em>P</em> are always the same, and we give a polynomial-time algorithm to find their common value. We use linear programming duality and complementary slackness to obtain this result.	string

162	en_US	title	Polyominoes with nearly convex columns: A semi-directed model	string
162	en_US	abstract	Column-convex polyominoes are by now a well-explored model. So far, however, no attention has been given to polyominoes whose columns can have either one or two connected components. This little known kind of polyominoes seems not to be manageable as a whole. To obtain solvable models, one needs to introduce some restrictions. This paper is focused on polyominoes with hexagonal cells. The restrictions just mentioned are semi-directedness and an upper bound (say <em>m</em>) on the size of the gap within a column. As the upper bound <em>m</em> grows, the solution of the model tends to break into more and more cases. We computed the area generating functions for <em>m</em> = 1, <em>m</em> = 2 and <em>m</em> = 3. In this paper, the <em>m</em> = 1 and <em>m</em> = 2 models are solved in full detail. To keep the size of the paper within reasonable limits, the result for the <em>m</em> = 3 model is stated without proof. The <em>m</em> = 1, <em>m</em> = 2 and <em>m</em> = 3 models have rational area generating functions, as column-convex polyominoes do. (It is practically sure, although we leave it unproved, that the area generating functions are also rational for <em>m</em> = 4, <em>m</em> = 5, ...) However, the growth constants of the new models are 4.114908 and more, whereas the growth constant of column-convex polyominoes is 3.863131.	string
