165	en_US	title	A parallel algorithm for computing the critical independence number and related sets	string
165	en_US	abstract	<p>An independent set <span class="math"><em>I</em><sub><em>c</em></sub></span> is a <em>critical independent set</em> if <span class="math">∣<em>I</em><sub><em>c</em></sub>∣ − ∣<em>N</em>(<em>I</em><sub><em>c</em></sub>)∣ ≥ ∣<em>J</em>∣ − ∣<em>N</em>(<em>J</em>)∣</span>, for any independent set <span class="math"><em>J</em></span>. The <em>critical independence number</em> of a graph is the cardinality of a maximum critical independent set. This number is a lower bound for the independence number and can be computed in polynomial-time. The existing algorithm runs in <span class="math"><em>O</em>(<em>n</em><sup>2. 5</sup> √(<em>m</em>/log <em>n</em>))</span> time for a graph <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> with <span class="math"><em>n</em> = ∣<em>V</em>(<em>G</em>)∣</span> vertices and <span class="math"><em>m</em></span> edges. It is demonstrated here that there is a parallel algorithm using <span class="math"><em>n</em></span> processors that runs in <span class="math"><em>O</em>(<em>n</em><sup>1. 5</sup> √(<em>m</em>/log <em>n</em>))</span> time. The new algorithm returns the union of all maximum critical independent sets. The graph induced on this set is a König-Egerváry graph whose components are either isolated vertices or which have perfect matchings.</p>	string

166	en_US	title	Genus distributions of graphs under self-edge-amalgamations	string
166	en_US	abstract	We investigate the well-known problem of counting graph imbeddings on all oriented surfaces with a focus on graphs that are obtained by pasting together two <em>root-edges</em> of another base graph. We require that the <em>partitioned genus distribution</em> of the base graph with respect to these <em>root-edges</em> be known and that both <em>root-edges</em> have two 2-valent endpoints. We derive general formulas for calculating the genus distributions of graphs that can be obtained either by <em>self-co-amalgamating</em> or by <em>self-contra-amalgamating</em> a base graph whose <em>partitioned genus distribution</em> is already known. We see how these general formulas provide a unified approach to calculating genus distributions of many new graph families, such as <em>co-pasted</em> and <em>contra-pasted closed chains</em> of copies of the triangular prism graph, as well as graph families like circular and Möbius ladders with previously known solutions to the genus distribution problem.	string

168	en_US	title	The canonical coloring graph of  trees and cycles	string
168	en_US	abstract	For a graph <em>G</em> and an ordering of the vertices <em>π</em>, the set of canonical <em>k</em>-colorings of <em>G</em> under <em>π</em> is the set of non-isomorphic proper <em>k</em>-colorings of <em>G</em> that are lexicographically least under <em>π</em>. The canonical coloring graph Can<sup><em>π</em></sup><sub><em>k</em></sub>(<em>G</em>) is the graph with vertex set the canonical colorings of <em>G</em> and two vertices are adjacent if the colorings differ in exactly one place. This is a natural variation of the color graph <strong>C</strong><sub><em>k</em></sub>(<em>G</em>) where all colorings are considered. We show that every graph has a canonical coloring graph which is disconnected; that trees have canonical coloring graphs that are Hamiltonian; and cycles have canonical coloring graphs that are connected.	string

170	en_US	title	Maximum independent sets of the 120-cell and other regular polytopes	string
170	en_US	abstract	A <span class="math"><em>d</em></span>-code in a graph is a set of vertices such that all pairwise distances are at least <span class="math"><em>d</em></span>. As part of a study of <span class="math"><em>d</em></span>-codes of three-and four-dimensional regular polytopes, the maximum independent set order of the <span class="math">120</span>-cell is calculated. A linear program based on counting arguments leads to an upper bound of <span class="math">221</span>. An independent set of order <span class="math">110</span> in the antipodal collapse of the <span class="math">120</span>-cell (also known as the hemi-<span class="math">120</span>-cell) gives a lower bound of <span class="math">220</span> for the <span class="math">120</span>-cell itself. The gap is closed by the computation described here, with the result that the maximum independent set order of the <span class="math">120</span>-cell is <span class="math">220</span>. All maximum <span class="math"><em>d</em></span>-code orders of the icosahedron, dodecahedron, <span class="math">24</span>-cell, <span class="math">600</span>-cell and <span class="math">120</span>-cell are reported.	string

173	en_US	title	A note on Zagreb indices inequality for trees and unicyclic graphs	string
173	en_US	abstract	<p>For a simple graph <em>G</em> with <em>n</em> vertices and <em>m</em> edges, the inequality <em>M</em><sub>1</sub>(<em>G</em>)/<em>n</em> ≤ <em>M</em><sub>2</sub>(<em>G</em>)/<em>m</em>, where <em>M</em><sub>1</sub>(<em>G</em>) and <em>M</em><sub>2</sub>(<em>G</em>) are the first and the second Zagreb indices of <em>G</em>, is known as Zagreb indices inequality. Recently Vukičević and Graovac [VG], and Caporossi, Hansen and Vukčević [CHV] proved that this inequality holds for trees and unicyclic graphs, respectively. Here, alternative and shorter proofs of these results are presented.</p><p>[VG] D. Vukičević and A. Graovac, Comparing Zagreb <em>M</em><sub>1</sub> and <em>M</em><sub>2</sub> indices for acyclic molecules, <em>MATCH Commun. Math. Comput. 175	en_US	title	More results on r-inflated graphs: Arboricity, thickness, chromatic number and fractional chromatic number	string
175	en_US	abstract	The <em>r</em>-inflation of a graph <em>G</em> is the lexicographic product <em>G</em> with <em>K</em><sub><em>r</em></sub>. A graph is said to have thickness <em>t</em> if its edges can be partitioned into <em>t</em> sets, each of which induces a planar graph, and <em>t</em> is smallest possible. In the setting of the <em>r</em>-inflation of planar graphs, we investigate the generalization of Ringel's famous Earth-Moon problem: <em>What is the largest chromatic number of any thickness-t graph?</em> In particular, we study classes of planar graphs for which we can determine both the thickness and chromatic number of their 2-inflations, and provide bounds on these parameters for their <em>r</em>-inflations. Moreover, in the same setting, we investigate arboricity and fractional chromatic number as well. We end with a list of open questions.	string

178	en_US	title	How to lose as little as possible	string
178	en_US	abstract	Suppose Alice has a coin with heads probability <em>q</em> and Bob has one with heads probability <em>p</em> &gt; <em>q</em>. Now each of them will toss their coin <em>n</em> times, and Alice will win iff she gets more heads than Bob does. Evidently the game favors Bob, but for the given <em>p</em>, <em>q</em>, what is the choice of <em>n</em> that maximizes Alice's chances of winning? We show that there is an essentially unique value <em>N</em>(<em>q</em>, <em>p</em>) of <em>n</em> that maximizes the probability <em>f</em>(<em>n</em>) that the weak coin will win, and it satisfies ⌊1/2(<em>p</em> − <em>q</em>) − 1/2⌋ ≤ <em>N</em>(<em>q</em>, <em>p</em>) ≤ ⌈max(1 − <em>p</em>, <em>q</em>)/(<em>p</em> − <em>q</em>)⌉. The analysis uses the multivariate form of Zeilberger's algorithm to find an indicator function <em>J</em><sub><em>n</em></sub>(<em>q</em>, <em>p</em>) such that <em>J</em> &gt; 0 iff <em>n</em> &lt; <em>N</em>(<em>q</em>, <em>p</em>) followed by a close study of this function, which is a linear combination of two Legendre polynomials. An integration-based algorithm is given for computing <em>N</em>(<em>q</em>, <em>p</em>).	string

186	en_US	abstract	The $p$-center problem is to locate $p$ facilities in a network so<br />as to minimize the longest distance between a demand point and<br />its nearest facility. 187	en_US	abstract	Abstract. The Arakawa-Kaneko zeta function has been introduced<br />ten years ago by T. Arakawa and M. Kaneko in [22]. In<br />[22], Arakawa and Kaneko have expressed the special values of this<br />function at negative integers with the help of generalized Bernoulli<br />numbers B(k) called ”poly- Bernoulli numbers”. Kim-Kim [4] introduced<br />Multi poly- Bernoulli numbers and proved that special<br />values of certain zeta functions at non-positive integers can be<br />described in terms of these numbers. The study of Multi poly-<br />Bernoulli and Euler numbers and their combinatorial relations has<br />received much attention [2,4,6,7,12,13,14,19,22,27]. In 2002, Q.<br />M. Luo and et al (see [11, 23, 24]) defined the generalization of<br />Bernoulli polynomials and Euler numbers. Some earlier results of<br />Luo in terms of generalized Multi poly-Bernoulli and Euler numbers,<br />can be deduced. 189	en_US	title	The tomotope	string
189	en_US	abstract	Every abstract 3-polytope <em>M</em>, in particular, every polyhedral map, has a unique minimal regular cover, and the automorphism group of this cover is isomorphic to the monodromy group of <em>M</em>. Here we demonstrate that the situation for polytopes of higher rank must be very different: the tomotope <em>T</em> is a small, highly involved, abstract uniform 4-polytope. It has infinitely many distinct minimal regular covers.	string

190	en_US	title	Efficient enumeration of rooted maps of a given orientable genus by number of faces and vertices	string
190	en_US	abstract	<p>We simplify the recurrence satisfied by the polynomial part of the generating function that counts rooted maps of positive orientable genus <span class="math"><em>g</em></span> by number of vertices and faces. We have written an optimized program in C++ for computing this generating function and constructing tables of numbers of rooted maps, and we describe some of these optimizations here. Using this program we extended the enumeration of rooted maps of orientable genus <span class="math"><em>g</em></span> by number of vertices and faces to <span class="math"><em>g</em> = 4</span>, <span class="math">5</span> and <span class="math">6</span> and by number of edges to <span class="math"><em>g</em> = 5</span> and <span class="math">6</span> and conjectured a further simplification of the generating function that counts rooted maps by number of edges. Our program is documented and available on request, allowing anyone with a sufficiently powerful computer to carry the calculations even further.</p>	string

191	en_US	title	A new construction of antipodal distance regular covers of complete graphs through the use of Godsil-Hensel matrices	string
191	en_US	abstract	New constructions of regular distance regular antipodal covers (in the sense of Godsil-Hensel) of complete graphs <em>K</em><sub><em>n</em></sub> are presented. The main source of these constructions are skew generalized Hadamard matrices. It is described how to produce such a matrix of order <em>n</em><sup>2</sup> over a group <em>T</em> from an arbitrary given generalized Hadamard matrix of order <em>n</em> over the same group <em>T</em>. Further, a new regular cover of <em>K</em><sub>45</sub> on 135 vertices is produced with the aid of a decoration of the alternating group <em>A</em><sub>6</sub>.	string

192	en_US	title	Motion and distinguishing number two	string
192	en_US	abstract	A group <em>A</em> acting faithfully on a finite set <em>X</em> is said to have distinguishing number two if there is a proper subset <em>Y</em> whose (setwise) stabilizer is trivial. The motion of <em>A</em> acting on <em>X</em> is defined as the largest integer <em>k</em> such that all non-trivial elements of <em>A</em> move at least <em>k</em> elements of <em>X</em>. The Motion Lemma of Russell and Sundaram states that if the motion is at least 2 log<sub>2</sub>|<em>A</em>|, then the action has distinguishing number two. When <em>X</em> is a vector space, group, or map, the Motion Lemma and elementary estimates of the motion together show that in all but finitely many cases, the action of Aut(<em>X</em>) on <em>X</em> has distinguishing number two. A new lower bound for the motion of any transitive action gives similar results for transitive actions with restricted point-stabilizers. As an instance of what can happen with intransitive actions, it is shown that if <em>X</em> is a set of points on a closed surface of genus <em>g</em>, and |<em>X</em>| is sufficiently large with respect to <em>g</em>, then any action on <em>X</em> by a finite group of surface homeomorphisms has distinguishing number two.	string
192	en_US	discipline		string
192	en_US	subjectClass	05E18, 05C10, 20B05	string
192	en_US	subject	Distinguishing number, group action, stabilizer, motion	string

194	en_US	title	On 2-factors with long cycles in cubic graphs	string
194	en_US	abstract	Every 2-connected cubic graph <em>G</em> has a 2-factor, and much effort has gone into studying conditions that guarantee <em>G</em> to be Hamiltonian. We show that if <em>G</em> is not Hamiltonian, then <em>G</em> is either the Petersen graph or contains a 2-factor with a cycle of length at least 7. We also give infinite families of, respectively, 2- and 3-connected cubic graphs in which every 2-factor consists of cycles of length at most, respectively, 10 and 16.	string

195	en_US	title	Distinguishing partitions and asymmetric uniform hypergraphs	string
195	en_US	abstract	A <em>distinguishing partition</em> for an action of a group Γ on a set <em>X</em> is a partition of <em>X</em> that is preserved by no nontrivial element of Γ. As a special case, a distinguishing partition of a graph is a partition of the vertex set that is preserved by no nontrivial automorphism. In this paper we provide a link between distinguishing partitions of complete equipartite graphs and asymmetric uniform hypergraphs. Suppose that <em>m</em> ≥ 1 and <em>n</em> ≥ 2. We show that an asymmetric <em>n</em>-uniform hypergraph with <em>m</em> edges exists if and only if <em>m</em> ≥ <em>f</em>(<em>n</em>), where <em>f</em>(2) = <em>f</em>(14) = 6, <em>f</em>(6) = 5, and <em>f</em>(<em>n</em>)= ⌊ log<sub>2</sub>(<em>n</em> + 1) ⌋ + 2 otherwise. It follows that a distinguishing partition of <em>K</em><sub><em>m</em>(<em>n</em>)</sub> = <em>K</em><sub><em>n</em>, <em>n</em>, ..., <em>n</em></sub>, or equivalently for the wreath product action <em>S</em><sub><em>n</em></sub> Wr <em>S</em><sub><em>m</em></sub>, exists if and only if <em>m</em> ≥ <em>f</em>(<em>n</em>).	string

196	en_US	title	Gray code numbers for graphs	string
196	en_US	abstract	A graph <em>H</em> has a Gray code of <em>k</em>-colourings if it is possible to list all of its <em>k</em>-colourings in such a way that consecutive elements in the list differ in the colour of exactly one vertex. We prove that for any graph <em>H</em>, there is a least integer <em>k</em><sub>0</sub>(<em>H</em>) such that <em>H</em> has a Gray code of <em>k</em>-colourings whenever <em>k</em> ≥ <em>k</em><sub>0</sub>(<em>H</em>). We then determine <em>k</em><sub>0</sub>(<em>H</em>) whenever <em>H</em> is a complete graph, tree, or cycle.	string

197	en_US	title	Natural realizations of sparsity matroids	string
197	en_US	abstract	A hypergraph <em>G</em> with <em>n</em> vertices and <em>m</em> hyperedges with <em>d</em> endpoints each is (<em>k</em>, <em>l</em>)-sparse if for all sub-hypergraphs <em>G'</em> on <em>n'</em> vertices and <em>m'</em> edges, <em>m'</em> ≤ <em>kn'</em> − <em>l</em>. For integers <em>k</em> and <em>l</em> satisfying 0 ≤ <em>l</em> ≤ <em>dk</em> − 1, this is known to be a linearly representable matroidal family. Motivated by problems in rigidity theory, we give a new linear representation theorem for the (<em>k</em>, <em>l</em>)-sparse hypergraphs that is <em>natural</em>; i.e., the representing matrix captures the vertex-edge incidence structure of the underlying hypergraph <em>G</em>.	string

200	en_US	title	Dominating sets in triangulations on surfaces	string
200	en_US	abstract	A <em>dominating set</em> <em>D</em> ⊆ <em>V</em>(<em>G</em>) of a graph <em>G</em> is a set such that each vertex <em>v</em> ∈ <em>V</em>(<em>G</em>) is either in the set or adjacent to a vertex in the set. Matheson and Tarjan (1996) proved that any <em>n</em>-vertex plane triangulation has a dominating set of size at most <em>n</em>/3, and conjectured a bound of <em>n</em>/4 for <em>n</em> sufficiently large. King and Pelsmajer recently proved this for graphs with maximum degree at most 6. Plummer and Zha (2009) and Honjo, Kawarabayashi, and Nakamoto (2009) extended the <em>n</em>/3 bound to triangulations on surfaces. <br /> We prove two related results: (i) There is a constant <em>c</em><sub>1</sub> such that any <em>n</em>-vertex plane triangulation with maximum degree at most 6 has a dominating set of size at most <em>n</em>/6 + <em>c</em><sub>1</sub>. (ii) For any surface <em>S</em>, <em>t</em> ≥ 0, and <em>ε</em> &gt; 0, there exists <em>c</em><sub>2</sub> such that for any <em>n</em>-vertex triangulation on <em>S</em> with at most <em>t</em> vertices of degree other than 6, there is a dominating set of size at most <em>n</em>(1/6 + <em>ε</em>) + <em>c</em><sub>2</sub>. <br /> As part of the proof, we also show that any <em>n</em>-vertex triangulation of a non-orientable surface has a non-contractible cycle of length at most 2√<em>n</em>. Albertson and Hutchinson (1986) proved that for <em>n</em>-vertex triangulation of an orientable surface other than a sphere has a non-contractible cycle of length √(2<em>n</em>), but no similar result was known for non-orientable surfaces.	string

201	en_US	title	On the core of a unicyclic graph	string
201	en_US	abstract	A set <em>S</em> ⊆ <em>V</em> is <em>independent</em> in a graph <em>G</em> = (<em>V</em>, <em>E</em>) if no two vertices from <em>S</em> are adjacent. By core(<em>G</em>) we mean the intersection of all maximum independent sets. The <em>independence number</em> <em>α</em>(<em>G</em>) is the cardinality of a maximum independent set, while <em>μ</em>(<em>G</em>) is the size of a maximum matching in <em>G</em>. A connected graph having only one cycle, say <em>C</em>, is a <em>unicyclic graph</em>. In this paper we prove that if <em>G</em> is a unicyclic graph of order <em>n</em> and <em>n</em> − 1 = <em>α</em>(<em>G</em>) + <em>μ</em>(<em>G</em>), then core(<em>G</em>) coincides with the union of cores of all trees in <em>G</em> − <em>C</em>.	string

202	en_US	abstract	We investigate the uniqueness of factorisation of possibly disconnected finite graphs with respect to the Cartesian, the strong and the direct product. It is proved that if a graph has <em>n</em> connected components, where <em>n</em> is prime, or <em>n</em> = 1, 4, 8, 9, and satisfies some additional natural conditions, it factors uniquely under the given products. 203	en_US	title	Symmetric graphicahedra	string
203	en_US	abstract	Given a connected graph <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> with <span class="math"><em>p</em></span> vertices and <span class="math"><em>q</em></span> edges, the <span class="math"><em>G</em></span>-graphicahedron is a vertex-transitive simple abstract polytope of rank <span class="math"><em>q</em></span> whose edge-graph is isomorphic to a Cayley graph of the symmetric group <span class="math"><em>S</em><sub><em>p</em></sub></span> associated with <span class="math"><em>G</em></span>. The paper explores combinatorial symmetry properties of <span class="math"><em>G</em></span>-graphicahedra, focussing in particular on transitivity properties of their automorphism groups. We present a detailed analysis of the graphicahedra for the <span class="math"><em>q</em></span>-star graphs <span class="math"><em>K</em><sub>1, <em>q</em></sub></span> and the <span class="math"><em>q</em></span>-cycles <span class="math"><em>C</em><sub><em>q</em></sub></span>. The <span class="math"><em>C</em><sub><em>q</em></sub></span>-graphicahedron is intimately related to the geometry of the infinite Euclidean Coxeter group <span class="math"><em>Ã</em><sub><em>q</em> − 1</sub></span> and can be viewed as an edge-transitive tessellation of the <span class="math">(<em>q</em> − 1)</span>-torus by <span class="math">(<em>q</em> − 1)</span>-dimensional permutahedra, obtained as a quotient, modulo the root lattice <span class="math"><em>A</em><sub><em>q</em> − 1</sub></span>, of the Voronoi tiling for the dual root lattice <span class="math"><em>A</em><sub><em>q</em> − 1</sub><sup> * </sup></span> in Euclidean <span class="math">(<em>q</em> − 1)</span>-space.	string

204	en_US	title	Two atlases of abstract chiral polytopes for small groups	string
204	en_US	abstract	We construct chiral abstract polytopes in two different ways. Firstly we seek them as quotients of regular polytopes arising from the Atlas of Small Regular Polytopes (<a href="http://www.abstract-polytopes.com/atlas/">http://www.abstract-polytopes.com/atlas/</a>); the resulting atlas of chiral polytopes atlas is available on the website <a href="http://www.abstract-polytopes.com/chiral/">http://www.abstract-polytopes.com/chiral/</a>. Secondly, for each almost simple group Γ such that <em>S</em> ≤ Γ ≤ Aut(<em>S</em>) where <em>S</em> is a simple group and Γ is a group of order less than 900,000 listed in the Atlas of Finite Groups, we give, up to isomorphism, the number of abstract chiral polytopes on which Γ acts regularly. The results have been obtained using a series of Magma programs. 206	en_US	abstract	Duality is the operation that interchanges hypervertices and hyperfaces on oriented hypermaps. The duality index measures how far a hypermap is from being self-dual. We say that an oriented regular hypermap has <em>duality-type</em> {<em>l</em>, <em>n</em>} if <em>l</em> is the valency of its vertices and <em>n</em> is the valency of its faces. Here, we study some properties of the duality index of oriented regular hypermaps and we prove that for each pair <em>n</em>, <em>l</em> ∈ <strong>N</strong>, with <em>n</em>, <em>l</em> ≥ 2 (but not both equal to 2), it is possible to find an oriented regular hypermap with extreme duality index and of duality-type {<em>l</em>, <em>n</em>}, even if we are restricted to hypermaps with alternating or symmetric monodromy group.	string

208	en_US	title	An Atlas of Domination Polynomials of Graphs of order at most 6	string
208	en_US	abstract	The domination polynomial of a graph G of order n is the polynomial $D(G; x) =\\sum_{i=1}^n d(G; i)x^i$, where d(G; i) is the number of dominating sets of G of size i. 209	en_US	title	Hamilton paths and cycles in Cayley digraphs with minimal connection sets	string
209	en_US	abstract	We construct Hamilton paths and cycles in Cayley digraphs on Abelian and solvable groups with minimal connection sets.  In particular, we give a recursive construction for Hamilton cycles in Cayley digraphs on Abelian groups with minimal connection sets, which may be useful in an inductive proof of Curran and Witte's 1985 conjecture that every such digraph is Hamiltonian if the connection set has cardinality at least three.  We also construct Hamilton paths in Cayley digraphs on solvable groups with minimal connection sets, and we prove that every Cayley digraph on a solvable group with a minimal connection set of maximum size has a Hamilton path.  In addition, we give sufficient conditions on the generators for the existence of a Hamilton cycle in a Cayley digraph on a solvable non-Abelian group with two generators, and these conditions verify the Hamiltonicity of some digraphs excluded by Rankin's famous result  for Cayley digraphs with two generators.  Finally, we prove that  every Cayley digraph on the direct product of dihedral groups $D_{2n}\\times  D_{2m}$ with a minimum set of generators is Hamiltonian, where both $m$ and $n$ are odd.	string

212	en_US	title	Posets of geometric graphs	string
212	en_US	abstract	A <em>geometric graph</em> <em>Ḡ</em> is a simple graph drawn in the plane, on points in general position, with straight-line edges. We call <em>Ḡ</em> a <em>geometric realization</em> of the underlying abstract graph <em>G</em>. A <em>geometric homomorphism</em> <em>f</em>: <em>Ḡ</em> → <em>̄H</em> is a vertex map that preserves adjacencies and crossings (but not necessarily non-adjacencies or non-crossings). This work uses geometric homomorphisms to introduce a partial order on the set of isomorphism classes of geometric realizations of an abstract graph <em>G</em>. Set <em>Ḡ</em> ≼ <em>Ĝ</em> if <em>Ḡ</em> and <em>Ĝ</em> are geometric realizations of <em>G</em> and there is a vertex-injective geometric homomorphism <em>f</em>: <em>Ḡ</em> → <em>Ĝ</em>. This paper develops tools to determine when two geometric realizations are comparable. Further, for 3 ≤ <em>n</em> ≤ 6, this paper provides the isomorphism classes of geometric realizations of <em>P</em><sub><em>n</em></sub>, <em>C</em><sub><em>n</em></sub> and <em>K</em><sub><em>n</em></sub>, as well as the Hasse diagrams of the geometric homomorphism posets (resp., <em><strong>P</strong></em><sub><em>n</em></sub>, <em><strong>C</strong></em><sub><em>n</em></sub>, <em><strong>K</strong></em><sub><em>n</em></sub>) of these graphs. The paper also provides the following results for general <em>n</em>: each of <em><strong>P</strong></em><sub><em>n</em></sub> and <em><strong>C</strong></em><sub><em>n</em></sub> has a unique minimal element and a unique maximal element; if <em>k</em> ≤ <em>n</em> then <em><strong>P</strong></em><sub><em>k</em></sub> (resp., <em><strong>C</strong></em><sub><em>k</em></sub>) is a subposet of <em><strong>P</strong></em><sub><em>n</em></sub> (resp., <em><strong>C</strong></em><sub><em>n</em></sub>); and <em><strong>K</strong></em><sub><em>n</em></sub> contains a chain of length <em>n</em> − 2.	string
212	en_US	discipline	Combinatorics; graph theory	string
212	en_US	subjectClass	05C62	string
212	en_US	subject	geometric graph, homomorphism, poset	string
212	en_US	sponsor		string
213	en_US	title	Imprimitivity of locally finite, 1-ended, planar graphs	string
213	en_US	abstract	Using results from group theory, we offer a concise proof of the imprimitivity of locally finite, vertex-transitive, 1-ended planar graphs, a result previously established by J. E. Graver and M. E. Watkins (2004) using graph-theoretical methods.	string

214	en_US	title	Small cycles in the Pancake graph	string
214	en_US	abstract	<p>The Pancake graph is well known because of the open Pancake problem. It has the structure that any <span class="math"><em>l</em></span>–cycle, <span class="math">6 ≤ <em>l</em> ≤ <em>n</em>!</span>, can be embedded in the Pancake graph <span class="math"><em>P</em><sub><em>n</em></sub>, <em>n</em> ≥ 3</span>. Recently it was shown that there are exactly <span class="math"><em>n</em>! / 6</span> independent <span class="math">6</span>–cycles and <span class="math"><em>n</em>!(<em>n</em> − 3)</span> distinct <span class="math">7</span>–cycles in the graph. In this paper we characterize all distinct <span class="math">8</span>–cycles by giving their canonical forms as products of generating elements. It is shown that there are exactly <span class="math"><em>n</em>!(<em>n</em><sup>3</sup> + 12<em>n</em><sup>2</sup> − 103<em>n</em> + 176) / 16</span> distinct <span class="math">8</span>–cycles in <span class="math"><em>P</em><sub><em>n</em></sub>, <em>n</em> ≥ 4</span>. A maximal set of independent <span class="math">8</span>–cycles contains <span class="math"><em>n</em>! / 8</span> of these.</p>	string

215	en_US	cleanTitle	On Pappus’ Complete Hexagon and the SteinerPl¨ucker Configuration	string
215	en_US	abstract	M. Steiner was the first who directed the attention of<br />geometers to the complete figure obtained by joining in every<br />possible way six points on a conic...<br />G. Salmon [9] p. 379.<br />Despite that the problem above has been solved for generic (i.e.<br />non-singular conics, through Pascal’s Mystic Hexagram, the reduced<br />and reducible case (i.e. two different straight lines) may not have<br />recived the same attention. For instance: Why are there 20 Steiner<br />points in the generic case but only two in the reduced-reducible situation?<br />In this paper we thoroughly examine this special case by<br />reinterpreting the fundamental line and P point definitions from the<br />generic case. In this way we construct all the Hexagram elements in<br />our case, using also some of the better known results from the generic<br />case. Finally, we report on some subconfigurations in both cases; e.g.<br />The (203, 154) Steiner-Pl¨ucker configuration specializes, in a 1-1 way,<br />to Pappus’ Complete Hexagon.<br />	string

216	en_US	abstract	A parallel backtrack search is carried out to classify, up to isomorphism, all combinatorial (19<sub>4</sub>) configurations. A total of 269 224 652 such configurations were found. We prove that two of the combinatorial (19<sub>4</sub>) configurations are not geometrically realizable over any field. Also we confirmed the computation of the 971 171 combinatorial (18<sub>4</sub>) configurations which lacked an independent verification.	string

217	en_US	cleanTitle	Embeddings of cubic Halin graphs: Genus distributions	string
217	en_US	abstract	We derive an <em>O</em>(<em>n</em><sup>2</sup>)-time algorithm for calculating the <em>genus distribution</em> of a given 3-regular <em>Halin graph</em> <em>G</em>; that is, we calculate the sequence of numbers <em>g</em><sub>0</sub>(<em>G</em>), <em>g</em><sub>1</sub>(<em>G</em>), <em>g</em><sub>2</sub>(<em>G</em>), … on the respective orientable surfaces <em>S</em><sub>0</sub>, <em>S</em><sub>1</sub>, <em>S</em><sub>2</sub>, …. Key topological features are a <em>quadrangular decomposition</em> of plane Halin graphs and a new <em>recombinant-strands</em> reassembly process that fits pieces together three-at-a-vertex. Key algorithmic features are reassembly along a <em>post-order traversal</em>, with just-in-time <em>dynamic assignment of roots</em> for quadrangular pieces encountered along the tour.	string

219	en_US	title	On regular and equivelar Leonardo polyhedra	string
219	en_US	cleanTitle	On regular and equivelar Leonardo polyhedra	string
219	en_US	abstract	<p>A Leonardo polyhedron is a 2-manifold without boundary, embedded in Euclidean 3-space <strong>E</strong><sup>3</sup>, built up of convex polygons and with the geometric symmetry (or rotation) group of a Platonic solid and of genus <em>g</em> ≥ 2. The polyhedra are named in honour of Leonardo's famous illustrations in [1] (cf. also [2]). Only six combinatorially regular Leonardo polyhedra are known: Coxeter's four regular skew polyhedra, and the polyhedral realizations of the regular maps by Klein of genus 3 and by Fricke and Klein of genus 5. In this paper we construct infinite series of equivelar (i.e. locally regular) Leonardo polyhedra, which share some properties with the regular ones, namely the same Schläfli symbols and related topological structure. So the weaker condition of local regularity allows a much greater variety of symmetric polyhedra.</p><p>[1] L. Pacioli, <em>De Divina Proportione (Disegni di Leonardo da Vinci 1500-1503)</em>, Faksimile Dominiani, Como, 1967. <br />[2] D. Huylebrouk, Lost in triangulation: Leonardo da Vinci's mathematical slip-up, <em>Scientific American</em>, March 29, 2011.</p>	string
219	en_US	discipline		string
219	en_US	subjectClass	52B15, 52B70	string
219	en_US	subject	Equivelar polyhedron, Leonardo polyhedron, regular polyhedron, genus, Schläfli symbol, symmetry group.	string
219	en_US	sponsor		string
220	en_US	title	Triangle randomization for social network data anonymization	string
220	en_US	cleanTitle	Triangle randomization for social network data anonymization	string
220	en_US	abstract	In order to protect privacy of social network participants, network graph data should be anonymised prior to its release. Most proposals in the literature aim to achieve <em>k</em>-anonymity under specific assumptions about the background information available to the attacker. Our method is based on randomizing the location of the triangles in the graph. We show that this simple method preserves the main structural parameters of the graph to a high extent, while providing a high re-identification confusion.	string

221	en_US	title	Orienting and separating cubic distance-transitive graphs	string
221	en_US	cleanTitle	Orienting and separating cubic distancetransitive graphs	string
221	en_US	abstract	The following question is answered in the affirmative for 7 of the 12 existing cubic distance transitive graphs $G$ and negatively for the remaining 5: If $k$ is the largest $\\ell$ such that $G$ is $\\ell$-arc-transitive, is it possible to orient all shortest cycles of $G$ so that each two oppositely oriented $(k-1)$-arcs of $G$ are just in two corresponding oriented shortest cycles? The answer leads to 7 connected digraphs ${\\mathcal S}(G)$ in which all oriented shortest cycles of $G$ are minimally pulled apart. Specifically, it is shown that all cubic distance-transitive graphs are $\\{C_g\\}_{P_k}$-ultrahogeneous, where $g=$ girth, but only the 7 cited $G$ are $\\{\\vec{C_g}\\}_{\\vec{P}_k}$-ultrahomogeneous digraphs. We also show that each of the ${\\mathcal S}(G)$ is: {\\bf(a)} vertex-transitive digraph of indegree = outdegree = 2, underlying cubic graph and automorphism group as that of $G$; {\\bf(b)} $\\{\\vec{C_g},\\vec{C_2}\\}$-ultrahomogeneous digraph, where $\\vec{C_g}=$ induced oriented $g$-cycle, with each vertex as the intersection of exactly one such $\\vec{C_g}$ and one $\\vec{C_2}$;  {\\bf(c)} Cayley graph if $G$ is either $K_4$ or the 3-cube or the dodecahedral graph or the Coxeter graph; {\\bf(d)} non-Cayley graph if $G$ is either $K_{3,3}$ or the Desargues graph or the Tutte 8-cage.<br /><br />	string
221	en_US	discipline	Mathematics	string
221	en_US	subjectClass	05C62, 05B30, 05C20, 05C38	string
221	en_US	subject	Cubic distance transitive graphs.	string

226	en_US	title	Convex cycle bases	string
226	en_US	cleanTitle	Convex cycle bases	string
226	en_US	abstract	Convex cycles play a role e.g. in the context of product graphs. We introduce convex cycle bases and describe a polynomial-time algorithm that recognizes whether a given graph has a convex cycle basis and provides an explicit construction in the positive case. Relations between convex cycles bases and other types of cycles bases are discussed. In particular we show that if <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> has a unique minimal cycle bases, this basis is convex. Furthermore, we characterize a class of graphs with convex cycles bases that includes partial cubes and hence median graphs.	string

227	en_US	title	Topological hypergroups in the sense of Marty	string
227	en_US	cleanTitle	Topological hypergroups in the sense of Marty	string
227	en_US	abstract	In this paper, we introduce the concept of topological<br />hypergroups as a generalization of topological groups. A<br />topological hypergroup is a non-empty set endowed with two structures: that of a topological space and that of a hypergroup. Let $(H,\\circ)$ be a hypergroup and $(H,\\tau)$ be a topological space such that the mappings $(x,y)\\mapsto x\\circ y$ and $(x,y)\\mapsto x/y$ from $H\\times H$ to $\\mathcal{P}^*(H)$ are continuous. The main tool to obtain basic properties of hypergroups is the fundamental relation $\\beta^*$.<br />So, by considering the quotient topology induced by the fundamental relation on a hypergroup $(H,\\circ)$ we show that if every open subset of $H$ is complete part, then the fundamental group of $H$ is a topological group.	string

228	en_US	title	Facial parity edge coloring of outerplane graphs	string
228	en_US	cleanTitle	Facial parity edge coloring of outerplane graphs	string
228	en_US	abstract	A <em>facial parity edge coloring</em> of a 2-edge-connected plane graph is such an edge coloring in which no two face-adjacent edges (consecutive edges of a facial walk of some face) receive the same color, in addition, for each face <em>f</em> and each color <em>c</em>, either no edge or an odd number of edges incident with <em>f</em> is colored with <em>c</em>. It is known that any 2-edge-connected plane graph has a facial parity edge coloring with at most 92 colors. In this paper we prove that any 2-edge-connected outerplane graph has a facial parity edge coloring with at most 15 colors. If a 2-edge-connected outerplane graph does not contain any inner edge, then 10 colors are sufficient. Moreover, this bound is tight.	string
228	en_US	discipline		string

233	en_US	title	Large dicliques in a directed inhomogeneous random graph	string
233	en_US	cleanTitle	Large dicliques in a directed inhomogeneous random graph	string
233	en_US	abstract	<p>Our main interest in this paper is the large dicliques in a directed inhomogeneous random graph model $G(n,\\alpha,\\Phi)$ on $n$ vertices, which has power-law out/in-degree distributions with scaling exponent $\\alpha&gt;0$ and community structures involved in the homophyly matrix $\\Phi$. We show that there is a major difference in<br />the size of the largest diclique $\\omega^d(G(n,\\alpha,\\Phi))$<br />between the case $\\alpha&lt;2$ and $\\alpha&gt;2$ with an intermediate result for $\\alpha=2$. In addition, we show that a simple algorithm with high probability finds a large diclique of size $\\omega^d(G(n,\\alpha,\\Phi))$ in a polynomial time. Our simulation results reveal that the connections between different subcommunities are essential for the formation of large clusters in the networks. </p>	string

235	en_US	abstract	It is shown that exactly 7 distance-transitive cubic graphs among the existing 12 possess a particular ultrahomogeneous property with respect to oriented cycles realizing the girth that allows the construction of a related Cayley digraph with similar ultrahomogeneous properties in which those oriented cycles appear minimally ''pulled apart'', or ''separated'' and whose description is truly beautiful and insightful. 240	en_US	title	Complex parametrization of triangulations on oriented maps	string
240	en_US	cleanTitle	Complex parametrization of triangulations on oriented maps	string
240	en_US	abstract	We consider here triangulations of oriented maps having a specified set <em>S</em> of vertices of degree different from 6 and some other vertices of degree 6. Such map can be described by specifying the relative positions between elements of <em>S</em> using Eisenstein integers. We first consider the case of 1 parameter, which corresponds to the Goldberg-Coxeter construction. Then we develop the general theory, the special case of positive curvature studied by Thurston and finally extend the theory to quadrangulations and some other cases. In the last section we expose application of parameterizations to the study of zigzags.	string

242	en_US	abstract	<p>An L(j,k)-labeling of a graph is a vertex labeling such that the difference of<br />the labels of any two adjacent vertices is at least j and that of any two vertices of<br />distance 2 is at least k. The minimum span of all L(j,k)-labelings of G<br />is denoted by $\\lambda_k^j(G)$.</p><p>For a direct product G of a complete graph $K_m$ and a cycle $C_n$, Lin and Lam provided an upper bound of $\\lambda_1^2(G)$ and found the exact value of $\\lambda_1^2(G)$ for some $m$ and $n$.<br />%which is an exact value for some cases.<br />In this paper, we obtain an upper bound and a lower bound of $\\lambda_1^1(G)$. 243	en_US	cleanTitle	On D G Higman's note on regular 3graphs	string
243	en_US	abstract	We introduce the notion of a <em>t</em>-graph and prove that regular 3-graphs are equivalent to cyclic antipodal 3-fold covers of a complete graph. 244	en_US	title	Consensus strategies for signed profiles on graphs	string
244	en_US	cleanTitle	Consensus strategies for signed profiles on graphs	string
244	en_US	abstract	The median problem is a classical problem in Location Theory: one searches for a location that minimizes the average distance to the sites of the clients. This is for desired facilities as a distribution center for a set of warehouses. More recently, for obnoxious facilities, the antimedian was studied. Here one maximizes the average distance to the clients. In this paper the mixed case is studied. Clients are represented by a profile, which is a sequence of vertices with repetitions allowed. In a <em>signed</em> profile each element is provided with a sign from {+, −}. Thus one can take into account whether the client prefers the facility (with a + sign) or rejects it (with a − sign). The graphs for which all median sets, or all antimedian sets, are connected are characterized. Various consensus strategies for signed profiles are studied, amongst which Majority, Plurality and Scarcity. Hypercubes are the only graphs on which Majority produces the median set for all signed profiles. Finally, the antimedian sets are found by the Scarcity Strategy on e.g. Hamming graphs, Johnson graphs and halfcubes.	string
244	en_US	discipline	Discrete Mathematics, Graph Theory, Location Theory	string
244	en_US	subjectClass	05C99, 05C12, 90B80	string
244	en_US	subject	Plurality strategy, median, majority rule, Hamming graph, Johnson graph, halfcube.	string

245	en_US	abstract	We examine the distinguishing number of the Cartesian product of an arbitrary number of complete graphs. 246	en_US	title	On the minimum rainbow subgraph number of a graph	string
246	en_US	cleanTitle	On the minimum rainbow subgraph number of a graph	string
246	en_US	abstract	We consider the Minimum Rainbow Subgraph problem (MRS): Given a graph <em>G</em>, whose edges are coloured with <em>p</em> colours. Find a subgraph <em>F</em> ⊆ <em>G</em> of minimum order and with <em>p</em> edges such that each colour occurs exactly once. This problem is NP-hard and APX-hard. For a given graph <em>G</em> and an edge colouring <em>c</em> with <em>p</em> colours we define the <em>rainbow subgraph number</em> <em>rs</em>(<em>G</em>, <em>c</em>) to be the order of a minimum rainbow subgraph of <em>G</em> with size <em>p</em>. In this paper we will show lower and upper bounds for the rainbow subgraph number of a graph.	string

246	en_US	subject	Edge colouring, rainbow subgraph.	string

247	en_US	abstract	In this paper, we establish leading coefficient of Wiener index for open and closed 2-dimensional rectangular lattices, for various open and closed polygonal lattices, and for open and closed multidimensional cubes. These results enable us to establish compression ratio of Wiener index when number of rows and columns in the lattice tends to infinity.	string

248	en_US	title	Line graphs and geodesic transitivity	string
248	en_US	cleanTitle	Line graphs and geodesic transitivity	string
248	en_US	abstract	For a graph Γ, a positive integer <em>s</em> and a subgroup <em>G</em> ≤ Aut(Γ), we prove that <em>G</em> is transitive on the set of <em>s</em>-arcs of Γ if and only if Γ has girth at least 2(<em>s</em> − 1) and <em>G</em> is transitive on the set of (<em>s</em> − 1)-geodesics of its line graph. As applications, we first classify 2-geodesic transitive graphs of valency 4 and girth 3, and determine which of them are geodesic transitive. Secondly we prove that the only non-complete locally cyclic 2-geodesic transitive graphs are the octahedron and the icosahedron.	string

249	en_US	title	Edge-transitive maps of low genus	string
249	en_US	cleanTitle	Edgetransitive maps of low genus	string
249	en_US	abstract	Graver and Watkins classified edge-transitive maps on closed surfaces into fourteen types. In this note we study these types for maps in orientable and non-orientable surfaces of small genus, including the Euclidean and hyperbolic plane. We revisit both finite and infinite one-ended edge-transitive maps. For the finite ones we give precise description that should enable their enumeration for a given number of edges. Edge-transitive maps on surfaces with small genera are classiﬁed in the paper.	string

250	en_US	abstract	Let <em>G</em> be a graph. Denote by <em>L</em><sup><em>i</em></sup>(<em>G</em>) its <em>i</em>-iterated line graph and denote by <em>W</em>(<em>G</em>) its Wiener index. Dobrynin, Entringer and Gutman stated the following problem: Does there exist a non-trivial tree <em>T</em> and <em>i</em> ≥ 3 such that <em>W</em>(<em>L</em><sup><em>i</em></sup>(<em>T</em>)) = <em>W</em>(<em>T</em>)? In a series of five papers we solve this problem. In a previous paper we proved that <em>W</em>(<em>L</em><sup><em>i</em></sup>(<em>T</em>)) &gt; <em>W</em>(<em>T</em>) for every tree <em>T</em> that is not homeomorphic to a path, claw <em>K</em><sub>1,3</sub> and to the graph of "letter <em>H</em>", where <em>i</em> ≥ 3. Here we prove that <em>W</em>(<em>L</em><sup><em>i</em></sup>(<em>T</em>)) &gt; <em>W</em>(<em>T</em>) for every tree <em>T</em> homeomorphic to the claw, <em>T</em> ≠ <em>K</em><sub>1,3</sub> and <em>i</em> ≥ 4.	string

251	en_US	abstract	It is well known that for any given hyperbolic pair (<em>k</em>, <em>m</em>) there exist infinitely many regular maps of valence <em>k</em> and face length <em>m</em> on an orientable surface, with automorphism group isomorphic to a linear fractional group. A nonorientable analogue of this result was known to be true for all pairs (<em>k</em>, <em>m</em>) as above with at least one even entry. In this paper we establish the existence of such regular maps on nonorientable surfaces for all hyperbolic pairs.	string

252	en_US	title	On Dirac and Motzkin problem versus harmonic conjugate	string
252	en_US	cleanTitle	On Dirac and Motzkin problem versus harmonic conjugate	string
252	en_US	abstract	Let $ p$, $q$, $r$ be any three lines in the <br />plane passing through a common point, and suppose that $O$, $P$, $Q$, $R$ are any four collinear points, such that $P \\in p$, $Q \\in q$, $R \\in r$, $P$ and $R$ are harmonic conjugates with respect to $O$ and $Q$ (that is, $\\mid{OP}\\mid /\\mid{PQ}\\mid  =  \\mid{OR}\\mid/\\mid{QR}\\mid$). For every $k\\geqslant 2$, we construct a set $X_n$ of $n = 4k$ points which is distributed on the lines  $ p$, $q$, $r$, but each element of $X_n\\cup\\{O\\}$ is incident to at most $n/2$ lines spanned by $X_n\\cup\\{O\\}$. On the other side, we prove that any set $X$ of  $n$ points distributed on the lines $ p$, $q$, $r$ has an element incident to at least $n/2$ lines spanned by  $X$.	string

255	en_US	abstract	<p>The packing chromatic number <span class="math"><em>χ</em><sub><em>ρ</em></sub>(<em>G</em>)</span> of a graph <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> is the smallest integer <span class="math"><em>k</em></span> such that the vertex set <span class="math"><em>V</em>(<em>G</em>)</span> can be partitioned into disjoint classes <span class="math"><em>X</em><sub>1</sub>, …, <em>X</em><sub><em>k</em></sub></span>, with the condition that vertices in <span class="math"><em>X</em><sub><em>i</em></sub></span> have pairwise distance greater than <span class="math"><em>i</em></span>. We show that the packing chromatic number for the hexagonal lattice <span class="math">ℋ </span> is 7. We also investigate the packing chromatic number for infinite subgraphs of the square lattice <span class="math">ℤ <sup>2</sup></span> with up to 13 rows. In particular, we establish the packing chromatic number for <span class="math"><em>P</em><sub>6</sub>□ ℤ </span> and provide new upper bounds on these numbers for the other subgraphs of interest. Finally, we explore the packing chromatic number for some infinite subgraphs of <span class="math">ℤ <sup>2</sup>□ <em>P</em><sub>2</sub></span>. The results are partially obtained by a computer search.</p>	string

258	en_US	cleanTitle	Product irregularity strength of certain graphs	string
258	en_US	abstract	<p>Consider a simple graph <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> with no isolated edges and at most one isolated vertex. A labeling <span class="math"><em>w</em>: <em>E</em>(<em>G</em>) → {1, 2, …, <em>m</em>}</span> is called <em>product - irregular</em>, if all product degrees <span class="math"><em>p</em><em>d</em><sub><em>G</em></sub>(<em>v</em>) = ∏ <sub><em>e</em> ∋ <em>v</em></sub><em>w</em>(<em>e</em>)</span> are distinct. The goal is to obtain a product - irregular labeling that minimizes the maximal label. This minimal value is called <em>the product irregularity strength</em> and denoted <span class="math"><em>p</em><em>s</em>(<em>G</em>)</span>. We give the exact values of <span class="math"><em>p</em><em>s</em>(<em>G</em>)</span> for several families of graphs, as complete bipartite graphs <span class="math"><em>K</em><sub><em>m</em>, <em>n</em></sub></span>, where <span class="math">2 ≤ <em>m</em> ≤ <em>n</em> ≤ (<em>m</em> + 2)</span> choose 2, some families of forests, including complete <span class="math"><em>d</em></span>-ary trees, and other graphs with <span class="math"><em>δ</em>(<em>G</em>) = 1</span>.</p>	string

259	en_US	title	The L<sub>2</sub>(11)-subalgebra of the Monster algebra	string
259	en_US	cleanTitle	The L<sub>2</sub>11subalgebra of the Monster algebra	string
259	en_US	abstract	<p>We study a subalgebra <span class="math"><em>V</em></span> of the Monster algebra, <span class="math"><em>V</em><sub>M</sub></span>, generated by three Majorana axes <span class="math"><em>a</em><sub><em>x</em></sub>,  <em>a</em><sub><em>y</em></sub></span> and <span class="math"><em>a</em><sub><em>z</em></sub></span> indexed by the <span class="math">2<em>A</em></span>-involutions <span class="math"><em>x</em>,  <em>y</em></span> and <span class="math"><em>z</em></span> of <span class="math">M</span>, the Monster simple group. We use the notation <span class="math"><em>V</em> =  &lt;&lt; <em>a</em><sub><em>x</em></sub>, <em>a</em><sub><em>y</em></sub>, <em>a</em><sub><em>z</em></sub> &gt;&gt; </span>. We assume that <span class="math"><em>x</em><em>y</em></span> is another <span class="math">2<em>A</em></span>-involution and that each of <span class="math"><em>x</em><em>z</em>,  <em>y</em><em>z</em></span> and <span class="math"><em>x</em><em>y</em><em>z</em></span> has order <span class="math">5</span>. Thus a subgroup <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> of <span class="math">M</span> generated by <span class="math">{<em>x</em>,  <em>y</em>,  <em>z</em>}</span> is a non-trivial quotient of the group <span class="math"><em>G</em><sup>(5, 5, 5)</sup> =  &lt; <em>x</em>,  <em>y</em>,  <em>z</em> ∣ <em>x</em><sup>2</sup>,  <em>y</em><sup>2</sup>,  (<em>x</em><em>y</em>)<sup>2</sup>,  <em>z</em><sup>2</sup>,  (<em>x</em><em>z</em>)<sup>5</sup>,  (<em>y</em><em>z</em>)<sup>5</sup>, </span> <span class="math">(<em>x</em><em>y</em><em>z</em>)<sup>5</sup> &gt; </span>. It is known that <span class="math"><em>G</em><sup>(5, 5, 5)</sup></span> is isomorphic to the projective special linear group <span class="math"><em>L</em><sub>2</sub>(11)</span> which is simple, so that <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> is isomorphic to <span class="math"><em>L</em><sub>2</sub>(11)</span>. It was proved by S. Norton that (up to conjugacy) <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> is the unique <span class="math">2<em>A</em></span>-generated <span class="math"><em>L</em><sub>2</sub>(11)</span>-subgroup of <span class="math">M</span> and that <span class="math"><em>K</em> = <em>C</em><sub>M</sub>(<em>G</em>)</span> is isomorphic to the Mathieu group <span class="math"><em>M</em><sub>12</sub></span>. For any pair <span class="math">{<em>t</em>,  <em>s</em>}</span> of <span class="math">2<em>A</em></span>-involutions, the pair of Majorana axes <span class="math">{<em>a</em><sub><em>t</em></sub>,  <em>a</em><sub><em>s</em></sub>}</span> generates the dihedral subalgebra <span class="math"> &lt;&lt; <em>a</em><sub><em>t</em></sub>, <em>a</em><sub><em>s</em></sub> &gt;&gt; </span> of <span class="math"><em>V</em><sub><em>M</em></sub></span>, whose structure has been described in . In particular, the subalgebra <span class="math"> &lt;&lt; <em>a</em><sub><em>t</em></sub>, <em>a</em><sub><em>s</em></sub> &gt;&gt; </span> contains the Majorana axis <span class="math"><em>a</em><sub><em>t</em><em>s</em><em>t</em></sub></span> by the conjugacy property of dihedral subalgebras. Hence from the structure of its dihedral subalgebras, <span class="math"><em>V</em></span> coincides with the subalgebra of <span class="math"><em>V</em><sub>M</sub></span> generated by the set of Majorana axes <span class="math">{<em>a</em><sub><em>t</em></sub> ∣ <em>t</em> ∈ <em>T</em>}</span>, indexed by the <span class="math">55</span> elements of the unique conjugacy class <span class="math"><em>T</em></span> of involutions of <span class="math"><em>G</em> ≅ <em>L</em><sub>2</sub>(11)</span>. We prove that <span class="math"><em>V</em></span> is <span class="math">101</span>-dimensional, linearly spanned by the set <span class="math">{ <em>a</em><sub><em>t</em></sub> ⋅ <em>a</em><sub><em>s</em></sub> ∣ <em>s</em>,  <em>t</em> ∈ <em>T</em> }</span>, and with <span class="math"><em>C</em><sub><em>V</em><sub>M</sub></sub>(<em>K</em>) = <em>V</em> ⊕ <em>ι</em><sub>M</sub></span>, where <span class="math"><em>ι</em><sub>M</sub></span> is the identity of <span class="math"><em>V</em><sub>M</sub></span>. Lastly we present a recent result of Á. Seress proving that <span class="math"><em>V</em></span> is equal to the algebra of the unique Majorana representation of <span class="math"><em>L</em><sub>2</sub>(11)</span>.</p>	string

263	en_US	title	Poly-antimatroid polyhedra	string
263	en_US	cleanTitle	Polyantimatroid polyhedra	string
263	en_US	abstract	<p>The notion of “antimatroid with repetition” was conceived by Bjorner, Lovasz and Shor in 1991 as an extension of the notion of antimatroid in the framework of non-simple languages. Further they were investigated by the name of “poly-antimatroids” (Nakamura, 2005, Kempner &amp; Levit, 2007), where the set system approach was used. If the underlying set of a poly-antimatroid consists of <span class="math"><em>n</em></span> elements, then the poly-antimatroid may be represented as a subset of the integer lattice <span class="math">Z<sup><em>n</em></sup></span>. We concentrate on geometrical properties of two-dimensional (<span class="math"><em>n</em> = 2</span>) poly-antimatroids - poly-antimatroid polygons, and prove that these polygons are parallelogram polyominoes. We also show that each two-dimensional poly-antimatroid is a poset poly-antimatroid, i.e., it is closed under intersection.</p><p>The convex dimension <span class="math"><em>c</em><em>d</em><em>i</em><em>m</em>(<em>S</em>)</span> of a poly-antimatroid <span class="math"><em>S</em></span> is the minimum number of maximal chains needed to realize <span class="math"><em>S</em></span>. While the convex dimension of an <span class="math"><em>n</em></span>-dimensional poly-antimatroid may be arbitrarily large, we prove that the convex dimension of an <span class="math"><em>n</em></span>-dimensional poset poly-antimatroid is equal to <span class="math"><em>n</em></span>.</p>	string
263	en_US	discipline		string
263	en_US	subjectClass	05B35	string
263	en_US	subject	antimatroid, polyhedron, convex dimension, lattice animal, polyomino	string
263	en_US	sponsor		string
264	en_US	title	Generalized network descriptors	string
264	en_US	cleanTitle	Generalized network descriptors	string
264	en_US	abstract	Transmission and betweenness centrality are key concepts in communication networks theory. Based on this concept, new concepts of networkness and network surplus have<br />recently been defined. However, all these four concepts include unrealistic assumption about equal communication between vertices. Here, we propose more realistic assumption<br />that the amount of communication of vertices decreases as their distance increases. We assume that amount of communication between vertices u and v is proportional to $d(u,v)^\\lambda$<br />where $\\lambda &lt; 0$. Taking this into account generalized versions of these four descriptors are defined. Extremal values of these descriptors are analysed.	string
264	en_US	discipline	Mathematics	string
264	en_US	subjectClass	05C35, 05C12	string
264	en_US	subject	Betweenness, transmission, networkness, network surplus, complex networks	string

269	en_US	abstract	<p>The revised Szeged index is a molecular structure descriptor equal to the sum of products <span class="math">[<em>n</em><sub><em>u</em></sub>(<em>e</em>) + <em>n</em><sub>0</sub>(<em>e</em>) / 2] × [<em>n</em><sub><em>v</em></sub>(<em>e</em>) + <em>n</em><sub>0</sub>(<em>e</em>) / 2]</span> over all edges <span class="math"><em>e</em> = <em>u</em><em>v</em></span> of the molecular graph <span class="math"><em>G</em></span>, where <span class="math"><em>n</em><sub>0</sub>(<em>e</em>)</span> is the number of vertices equidistant from <span class="math"><em>u</em></span> and <span class="math"><em>v</em></span>, <span class="math"><em>n</em><sub><em>u</em></sub>(<em>e</em>)</span> is the number of vertices whose distance to vertex <span class="math"><em>u</em></span> is smaller than the distance to vertex <span class="math"><em>v</em></span> and <span class="math"><em>n</em><sub><em>v</em></sub>(<em>e</em>)</span> is defined analogously. In this paper, new formula for computing this molecular descriptor is presented by which it is possible to reprove most of results given in [M. Aouchiche and P. Hansen, On a conjecture about the Szeged index,<em> European J. Combin.</em> <strong>31</strong> (2010), 1662–1666]. We also present an edge version of this graph invariant. At the end of the paper an open question is presented.</p>	string

270	en_US	title	Constructions for large spatial point-line (<em>n</em><sub><em>k</em></sub>) congurations	string
270	en_US	cleanTitle	Constructions for large spatial pointline <em>n</em><sub><em>k</em></sub> congurations	string
270	en_US	abstract	Highly symmetric figures, such as regular polytopes, can serve as a scaffolding on which spatial <span class="math">(<em>n</em><sub><em>k</em></sub>)</span> point-line configurations can be built. We give several constructions using this method in dimension 3 and 4. We also explore possible constructions of point-line configurations obtained as Cartesian products of smaller ones. Using suitable powers of well-chosen configurations, we obtain infinite series of <span class="math">(<em>n</em><sub><em>k</em></sub>)</span> configurations for which both <span class="math"><em>n</em></span> and <span class="math"><em>k</em></span> are arbitrarily large. We also combine the method of polytopal scaffolding and the method of powers to construct further examples. Finally, we formulate an incidence statement concerning a <span class="math">(100<sub>4</sub>)</span> configuration in 3-space derived from the product of two complete pentalaterals; it is posed as a conjecture.	string

271	en_US	title	Sharp spectral inequalities for connected bipartite graphs with maximal Q-index	string
271	en_US	cleanTitle	Sharp spectral inequalities for connected bipartite graphs with maximal Qindex	string
271	en_US	abstract	The <span class="math"><em>Q</em></span>-index of a simple graph is the largest eigenvalue of its signless Laplacian. As for the adjacency spectrum, we will show that in the set of connected bipartite graphs with fixed order and size, the bipartite graphs with maximal <span class="math"><em>Q</em></span>-index are the double nested graphs. We provide a sequence of (in)equalities regarding the principal eigenvector of the signless Laplacian of double nested graphs and apply these results to obtain some lower and upper bounds for their <span class="math"><em>Q</em></span>-index. In the end, we give some computational results in order to compare these bounds.	string

275	en_US	title	Interlacing–extremal graphs	string
275	en_US	cleanTitle	Interlacing–extremal graphs	string
275	en_US	abstract	<p>A graph <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> is <em>singular</em> if the zero-one adjacency matrix has the eigenvalue zero. The multiplicity of the eigenvalue zero is called the <em>nullity</em> of <span class="math"><em>G</em></span>. For two vertices <span class="math"><em>y</em></span> and <span class="math"><em>z</em></span> of <span class="math"><em>G</em></span>, we call <span class="math">(<em>G</em>, <em>y</em>, <em>z</em>)</span> a <em>device</em> with respect to <span class="math"><em>y</em></span> and <span class="math"><em>z</em></span>. The nullities of <span class="math"><em>G</em></span>, <span class="math"><em>G</em> − <em>y</em>,  <em>G</em> − <em>z</em></span> and <span class="math"><em>G</em> − <em>y</em> − <em>z</em></span> classify devices into different <em>kinds</em>. We identify two particular classes of graphs that correspond to distinct kinds. In the first, the devices have the minimum allowed value for the nullity of <span class="math"><em>G</em> − <em>y</em> − <em>z</em></span> relative to that of <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> for all pairs of distinct vertices <span class="math"><em>y</em></span> and <span class="math"><em>z</em></span> of <span class="math"><em>G</em></span>. In the second, the nullity of <span class="math"><em>G</em> − <em>y</em></span> reaches the maximum possible for all vertices <span class="math"><em>y</em></span> in a graph <span class="math"><em>G</em></span>. We focus on the non–singular devices of the second kind.</p>	string

276	en_US	abstract	<p>A simple undirected graph is said to be <em>semisymmetric</em> if it is regular and edge-transitive but not vertex-transitive. Every semisymmetric graph is a bipartite graph with two parts of equal size. Let <span class="math"><em>p</em></span> be a prime. In this paper, a class of semisymmetric graphs of order <span class="math">2<em>p</em><sup>3</sup></span> are determined. This work is a partial result for our long term goal to classify all semisymmetric graphs of order <span class="math">2<em>p</em><sup>3</sup></span>.</p>	string

283	en_US	title	On Zero Forcing Number of Functigraphs	string
283	en_US	cleanTitle	On Zero Forcing Number of Functigraphs	string
283	en_US	abstract	\\emph{Zero forcing number}, $Z(G)$, of a graph $G$ is the minimum cardinality of a set $S$ of black vertices (whereas vertices in $V(G)\\!\\setminus\\!S$ are colored white) such that $V(G)$ is turned black after finitely many applications of ``the color-change rule": a white vertex is converted black if it is the only white neighbor of a black vertex. Let $G_1$ and $G_2$ be disjoint copies of a graph $G$ and let $f: V(G_1) \\rightarrow V(G_2)$ be a function. Then a \\emph{functigraph} $C(G, f)=(V, E)$ has the vertex set $V=V(G_1) \\cup V(G_2)$ and the edge set $E=E(G_1) \\cup E(G_2) \\cup \\{uv \\mid v=f(u)\\}$. We study how zero forcing number behaves in passing from $G$ to $C(G,f)$ by first showing that $1+ \\delta(G) \\le Z(C(G, f)) \\le 2n-2$, if $G$ is a connected graph of order $n \\ge 3$ and $f$ is any function; here $\\delta(G)$ is the minimum degree of $G$. We further investigate the zero forcing number of functigraphs on complete graphs, on cycles, and on paths.	string
283	en_US	discipline	graph theory, combinatorics	string
283	en_US	subjectClass	05C50, 05C38	string
283	en_US	subject	zero forcing set, zero forcing number, functigraph, complete graph, cycle, path	string

282	en_US	title	A note on domination and independence-domination numbers of graphs	string
282	en_US	cleanTitle	A note on domination and independencedomination numbers of graphs	string
282	en_US	abstract	Vizing's conjecture is true for graphs <em>G</em> satisfying <em>γ</em><sup><em>i</em></sup>(<em>G</em>) = <em>γ</em>(<em>G</em>), where <em>γ</em>(<em>G</em>) is the <em>domination number</em> of a graph <em>G</em> and <em>γ</em><sup><em>i</em></sup>(<em>G</em>) is the <em>independence-domination number</em> of <em>G</em>, that is, the maximum, over all independent sets <em>I</em> in <em>G</em>, of the minimum number of vertices needed to dominate <em>I</em>. The equality <em>γ</em><sup><em>i</em></sup>(<em>G</em>) = <em>γ</em>(<em>G</em>) is known to hold for all chordal graphs and for chordless cycles of length 0 (mod 3). We prove some results related to graphs for which the above equality holds. More specifically, we show that the problems of determining whether <em>γ</em><sup><em>i</em></sup>(<em>G</em>) = <em>γ</em>(<em>G</em>) = 2 and of verifying whether <em>γ</em><sup><em>i</em></sup>(<em>G</em>) ≥ 2 are NP-complete, even if <em>G</em> is weakly chordal. We also initiate the study of the equality <em>γ</em><sup><em>i</em></sup> = <em>γ</em> in the context of hereditary graph classes and exhibit two infinite families of graphs for which <em>γ</em><sup><em>i</em></sup> &lt; <em>γ</em>.	string

286	en_US	title	Markov chain algorithms for generating sets uniformly at random	string
286	en_US	cleanTitle	Markov chain algorithms for generating sets uniformly at random	string
286	en_US	abstract	In this paper we tackle the problem of generating uniformly at random two representative types of sets with <em>n</em> elements: transitive sets and weakly transitive sets, that is, transitive sets with atoms. A set is said to be <em>transitive</em> if any of its elements is also a subset of it; a set is <em>weakly transitive</em> if any of its elements, unless disjoint from it, is also a subset of it. We interpret such sets as (weakly) extensional acyclic digraphs—that is, acyclic digraphs whose (non-sink) vertices have pairwise different out-neighborhoods—and employ a Markov chain technique already given for acyclic digraphs. We thus propose Markov chain-based algorithms for generating uniformly at random (weakly) extensional acyclic digraphs with a given number of vertices. The Markov chain is then refined to generate such digraphs which are also simply connected, and digraphs in which the number of arcs is fixed.	string
286	en_US	discipline	Discrete Mathematics, Computer Science	string
286	en_US	subjectClass	03E75, 05C81, 05C20	string
286	en_US	subject	Extensional digraph, transitive set, set theory, random generation, Markov chain.	string

287	en_US	abstract	<p>In this paper, we show that all fat Hoffman graphs with smallest eigenvalue at least <span class="math"> − 1 − <em>τ</em></span>, where <span class="math"><em>τ</em></span> is the golden ratio, can be described by a finite set of fat <span class="math">(− 1 − <em>τ</em>)</span>-irreducible Hoffman graphs. In the terminology of Woo and Neumaier, we mean that every fat Hoffman graph with smallest eigenvalue at least <span class="math"> − 1 − <em>τ</em></span> is an <span class="math">H</span>-line graph, where <span class="math">H</span> is the set of isomorphism classes of maximal fat <span class="math">(− 1 − <em>τ</em>)</span>-irreducible Hoffman graphs. It turns out that there are <span class="math">37</span> fat <span class="math">(− 1 − <em>τ</em>)</span>-irreducible Hoffman graphs, up to isomorphism.</p>	string

294	en_US	abstract	<p>Let <span class="math">Γ </span> denote a finite digraph and let <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> be a subgroup of its automorphism group. A directed cycle <span class="math"><em>C</em></span> of <span class="math">Γ </span> is called <span class="math"><em>G</em></span>-<em>consistent</em> whenever there is an element of <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> whose restriction to <span class="math"><em>C</em></span> is the <span class="math">1</span>-step rotation of <span class="math"><em>C</em></span>. 295	en_US	abstract	We classify those 2-groups <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> which factorise as a product of two disjoint cyclic subgroups <span class="math"><em>A</em></span> and <span class="math"><em>B</em></span>, transposed by an automorphism of order <span class="math">2</span>. 298	en_US	title	The Algorithmic Complexity of $k$-Domatic Partition of Graphs	string
298	en_US	cleanTitle	The Algorithmic Complexity of kDomatic Partition of Graphs	string
298	en_US	abstract	Let $G=(V,E)$ be a simple undirected graph, and $k$ be a positiveinteger. A \\emph{$k$-dominating set} of $G$ is a set of vertices$S\\subseteq V$ satisfying that every vertex in $V\\setminus S$ isadjacent to at least $k$ vertices in $S$. A \\emph{$k$-domaticpartition} of $G$ is a partition of $V$ into $k$-dominating sets.The \\emph{$k$-domatic number} of $G$ is the maximum number of$k$-dominating sets contained in a $k$-domatic partition of $G$. Inthis paper we study the $k$-domatic number from both algorithmiccomplexity and graph theoretic points of view. We prove that it is\\NP-complete to decide whether the $k$-domatic number of a bipartitegraph is at least 3, and present a polynomial time algorithm that   approximates the $k$-domatic number of a graph of order $n$ within afactor of $(\\frac{1}{k}+o(1))\\ln n$, generalizing the $(1+o(1))\\lnn$ approximation for the 1-domatic number given in \\cite{fhks02}. Inaddition, we determine the exact values of the $k$-domatic number ofsome particular classes of graphs.	string

309	en_US	title	GCD-graphs and NEPS of complete graphs	string
309	en_US	cleanTitle	GCDgraphs and NEPS of complete graphs	string
309	en_US	abstract	A gcd-graph is a Cayley graph over a finite abelian group defined by greatest common divisors. Such graphs are known to have integral spectrum. A non-complete extended p-sum, or NEPS in short, is well-known general graph product. We show that the class of gcd-graphs and the class of NEPS of complete graphs coincide. Thus, a relation between the algebraically defined Cayley graphs and the combinatorially defined NEPS of complete graphs is established. We use this link to show that gcd-graphs have a particularly simple eigenspace structure, to be precise, that every eigenspace of the adjacency matrix of a gcd-graph has a basis with entries <span class="math"> − 1, 0, 1</span> only.	string

315	en_US	title	On the automorphism groups of almost all circulant graphs and digraphs	string
315	en_US	cleanTitle	On the automorphism groups of almost all circulant graphs and digraphs	string
315	en_US	abstract	We attempt to determine the structure of the automorphism group of a generic circulant graph. We first show that almost all circulant graphs have automorphism groups as small as possible. The second author has conjectured that almost all of the remaining circulant (di)graphs (those whose automorphism group is not as small as possible) are normal circulant (di)graphs. We show this conjecture is not true in general, but is true if we consider only those circulant (di)graphs whose order is in a "large" subset of integers. We note that all non-normal circulant (di)graphs can be classified into two natural classes (generalized wreath products, and deleted wreath type), and show that neither of these classes contains almost every non-normal circulant digraph.	string

320	en_US	title	Fast recognition of direct and strong products	string
320	en_US	cleanTitle	Fast recognition of direct and strong products	string
320	en_US	abstract	This note describes fast algorithms for computing the prime factors of connected, nonbipartite graphs with respect to the direct product, and of connected graphs with respect to the strong product. The complexities are <em>O</em>(<em>m</em> min(<em>n</em><sup>2</sup>; Δ<sup>3</sup>)) for the direct product, and <em>O</em>(<em>m</em> <em>a</em>(<em>G</em>) Δ) for the strong, where <em>n</em> is the order of the graph <em>G</em> to be factored, <em>m</em> its size, <em>a</em>(<em>G</em>) its arboricity, and Δ its maximum degree. That is, the complexities are linear in <em>m</em> for fixed Δ.	string

328	en_US	abstract	<p>Let <span class="math"><em>S</em></span> be a closed Riemann surface and let <span class="math"><em>β</em>: <em>S</em> →  ̂<strong>C</strong></span> be a regular branched holomorphic covering, with an abelian group as deck group, whose branch values are contained in the set <span class="math">{∞, 0, 1}</span>. Three dessins d’enfants are provided by <span class="math"><em>β</em><sup> − 1</sup>([0, 1])</span>, <span class="math"><em>β</em><sup> − 1</sup>([1, ∞])</span> and <span class="math"><em>β</em><sup> − 1</sup>([0, ∞])</span>. 329	en_US	title	Matrices and their Kirchhoff graphs	string
329	en_US	cleanTitle	Matrices and their Kirchhoff graphs	string
329	en_US	abstract	The fundamental relationship between matrices over the rational numbers and a newly defined type of graph, a Kirchhoff graph, is established. For a given matrix, a Kirchhoff graph represents the orthogonal complementarity of the null and row spaces of that matrix. A number of basic results are proven, and then a relatively complicated Kirchhoff graph is constructed for a matrix that is the transpose of the stoichiometric matrix for a reaction network for the production of sodium hydroxide from salt. A Kirchhoff graph for a reaction network is a circuit diagram for that reaction network. Finally it is conjectured that there is at least one Kirchhoff graph for any matrix with rational elements, and a process for constructing an incidence matrix for a Kirchhoff graph from a given matrix is discussed.	string

329	en_US	subject	Kirchhoff graphs, fundamental theorem of linear algebra, reaction networks.	string

334	en_US	title	Distinguishing graphs with infinite motion and nonlinear growth	string
334	en_US	cleanTitle	Distinguishing graphs with infinite motion and nonlinear growth	string
334	en_US	abstract	<p>The distinguishing number <span class="math">D(<em>G</em>)</span> of a graph <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> is the least cardinal <span class="math"><em>d</em></span> such that <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> has a labeling with <span class="math"><em>d</em></span> labels which is only preserved by the trivial automorphism. We show that the distinguishing number of infinite, locally finite, connected graphs <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> with infinite motion and growth <span class="math"><em>o</em>(<em>n</em><sup>2</sup> / log<sub>2</sub><em>n</em>)</span> is either <span class="math">1</span> or <span class="math">2</span>, which proves the Infinite Motion Conjecture of Tom Tucker for this type of graphs. The same holds true for graphs with countably many ends that do not grow too fast. We also show that graphs <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> of arbitrary cardinality are <span class="math">2</span>-distinguishable if every nontrivial automorphism moves at least uncountably many vertices <span class="math">m(<em>G</em>)</span>, where <span class="math">m(<em>G</em>) ≥ ∣Aut(<em>G</em>)∣</span>. This extends a result of Imrich et al. to graphs with automorphism groups of arbitrary cardinality.</p>	string

335	en_US	title	Relations between graphs	string
335	en_US	cleanTitle	Relations between graphs	string
335	en_US	abstract	<p>Given two graphs <span class="math"><em>G</em> = (<em>V</em><sub><em>G</em></sub>, <em>E</em><sub><em>G</em></sub>)</span> and <span class="math"><em>H</em> = (<em>V</em><sub><em>H</em></sub>, <em>E</em><sub><em>H</em></sub>)</span>, we ask under which conditions there is a relation <span class="math"><em>R</em> ⊆ <em>V</em><sub><em>G</em></sub> × <em>V</em><sub><em>H</em></sub></span> that generates the edges of <span class="math"><em>H</em></span> given the structure of the graph <span class="math"><em>G</em></span>. This construction can be seen as a form of multihomomorphism. It generalizes surjective homomorphisms of graphs and naturally leads to notions of R-retractions, R-cores, and R-cocores of graphs. Both R-cores and R-cocores of graphs are unique up to isomorphism and can be computed in polynomial time.</p>	string

340	en_US	abstract	 The Harary index is defined as the sum of reciprocals of distances between all pairs of vertices of a connected graph. 341	en_US	title	Comparing the irregularity and the total irregularity of graphs	string
341	en_US	cleanTitle	Comparing the irregularity and the total irregularity of graphs	string
341	en_US	abstract	<p>Albertson has defined the <span><em>irregularity</em></span> of a simple undirected graph <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> as <span class="math">irr(<em>G</em>) = ∑ <sub><em>u</em><em>v</em> ∈ <em>E</em>(<em>G</em>)</sub>∣<em>d</em><sub><em>G</em></sub>(<em>u</em>) − <em>d</em><sub><em>G</em></sub>(<em>v</em>)∣, </span> where <span class="math"><em>d</em><sub><em>G</em></sub>(<em>u</em>)</span> denotes the degree of a vertex <span class="math"><em>u</em> ∈ <em>V</em>(<em>G</em>)</span>. 343	en_US	title	Facial parity edge coloring vs. odd subgraphs	string
343	en_US	cleanTitle	Facial parity edge coloring vs odd subgraphs	string
343	en_US	abstract	A \\textit{facial parity edge coloring} of a connected bridgeless plane graph is an edge coloring where <br /> no two consecutive edges of a facial walk of any face receive the same color. Additionally, for every face<br /> $f$ and every color $c$ either no edge or an odd number of edges incident to $f$ are colored with $c$.   <br /> Czap, Jendrol' and Kardoš showed that 92 colors suffice to color any $2$-edge connected planar<br /> graph. We improve this bound to 24 colors using the concept of odd subgraphs. Moreover, if a plane<br /> graph is $3$-edge connected, 16 colors suffice.	string

344	en_US	title	On Strong Metric Dimension of Permutation Graphs	string
344	en_US	cleanTitle	On Strong Metric Dimension of Permutation Graphs	string
344	en_US	abstract	A vertex $x$ in a graph $G$ \\emph{strongly resolves} a pair of vertices $v,w$ if there exists a shortest $x-w$ path containing $v$ or a shortest $x-v$ path containing $w$ in $G$. A set of vertices $S \\subseteq V(G)$ is a \\emph{strong resolving set} of $G$ if every pair of distinct vertices of $G$ is strongly resolved by some vertex in $S$. The \\emph{strong metric dimension} $sdim(G)$ of a graph $G$ is the minimum cardinality over all strong resolving sets of $G$. Let $G_1$ and $G_2$ be disjoint copies of a graph $G$ and let $\\sigma: V(G_1) \\rightarrow V(G_2)$ be a permutation. Then a permutation graph $G_{\\sigma}=(V,E)$ has the vertex set $V=V(G_1) \\cup V(G_2)$ and the edge set $E=E(G_1) \\cup E(G_2) \\cup \\{uv \\mid v=\\sigma(u)\\}$. We show that $2 \\le sdim(G_{\\sigma}) \\le 2n-2$, if $G$ is a connected graph of order $n \\ge 3$; we also give an example showing that there does not exist a function $g$ such that $g(sdim(G))&gt;sdim(G_{\\sigma})$ for every pair $(G, \\sigma)$. We prove that $sdim(G_{\\sigma_0}) \\le 2 sdim(G)$ for $\\sigma_0$ the identity map. Further, we characterize permutation graphs $G_{\\sigma}$ satisfying $sdim(G_{\\sigma})$ equals $2n-2$ or $2n-3$ when $G$ is a complete $k$-partite graph, a cycle, or a path on $n$ vertices.	string
344	en_US	discipline	Mathematics	string
344	en_US	subjectClass	05C12; 05C38; 05D99	string
344	en_US	subject	distance; strong resolving set; strong metric dimension; permutation graph; generalized prism; complete k-partite graph; cycle; path	string

345	en_US	title	Computers in Scientific Discovery 6 (CSD6)	string
