345	en_US	sponsor		string
346	en_US	title	Systematic celestial 4-configurations	string
346	en_US	cleanTitle	Systematic celestial 4configurations	string
346	en_US	abstract	Celestial 4-configurations are a class of highly symmetric geometric configurations of points and lines in the plane in which 4 points lie on each line and 4 lines pass through each point (that is, they are (<em>n</em><sub>4</sub>) configurations). The set of isometries of the plane that map a configuration to itself (that is, the <em>symmetries</em> of the configuration) partition the points into orbits, called the <em>symmetry classes of points</em>, and likewise the symmetries of the configuration partition the lines into orbits as well, forming the set of symmetry classes of lines. Celestial 4-configurations have the property that two lines from each of two symmetry classes of lines pass through each point, and two points from each of two symmetry classes of points lie on each line; a celestial 4-configuration with <em>k</em> symmetry classes is called <em>k</em>-celestial. Celestial configurations may be classified as being <em>trivial</em>, <em>systematic</em>, or <em>sporadic</em>. Previously, three non-trivial classes of 3-celestial 4-configurations were known. This paper presents a number of new systematic families of celestial 4-configurations, including 16 new 3-celestial families, four 4-celestial families, and three classes of <em>h</em>-celestial configurations for infinitely many values of <em>h</em>, although it does not provide a complete classification.	string

346	en_US	subject	Configurations, incidence geometry	string
346	en_US	sponsor	Ursinus College Summer Fellows Program	string

352	en_US	abstract	<span>For a graph </span><span class="math"><em>G</em></span><span>, </span><span class="math"><em>κ</em>(<em>G</em>)</span><span> denotes its connectivity. A graph </span><span class="math"><em>G</em></span><span> is </span><span><em>super connected</em></span><span>, or simply </span><span><em>super-<span class="math"><em>κ</em></span></em></span><span>, if every minimum separating set is the neighborhood of a vertex of </span><span class="math"><em>G</em></span><span>, that is, every minimum separating set isolates a vertex. The </span><span><em>direct product</em></span><span> </span><span class="math"><em>G</em><sub>1</sub> × <em>G</em><sub>2</sub></span><span> of two graphs </span><span class="math"><em>G</em><sub>1</sub></span><span> and </span><span class="math"><em>G</em><sub>2</sub></span><span> is a graph with vertex set </span><span class="math"><em>V</em>(<em>G</em><sub>1</sub> × <em>G</em><sub>2</sub>) = <em>V</em>(<em>G</em><sub>1</sub>) × <em>V</em>(<em>G</em><sub>2</sub>)</span><span> and edge set </span><span class="math"><em>E</em>(<em>G</em><sub>1</sub> × <em>G</em><sub>2</sub>) = {(<em>u</em><sub>1</sub>, <em>v</em><sub>1</sub>)(<em>u</em><sub>2</sub>, <em>v</em><sub>2</sub>) ∣ <em>u</em><sub>1</sub><em>u</em><sub>2</sub> ∈ <em>E</em>(<em>G</em><sub>1</sub>), <em>v</em><sub>1</sub><em>v</em><sub>2</sub> ∈ <em>E</em>(<em>G</em><sub>2</sub>)}</span><span>. In this paper, we show that </span><span class="math">Γ </span><span> is not super-</span><span class="math"><em>κ</em></span><span> if and only if either </span><span class="math"><em>κ</em>(Γ ) = <em>n</em><em>κ</em>(<em>G</em>)</span><span>, or </span><span class="math">Γ  ≅ <em>K</em><sub>ℓ, ℓ</sub> × <em>K</em><sub>3</sub>(ℓ &gt; 0)</span><span>.</span>	string

356	en_US	title	Maximum genus, connectivity, and Nebeský's Theorem	string
356	en_US	cleanTitle	Maximum genus connectivity and Nebeský's Theorem	string
356	en_US	abstract	We prove lower bounds on the maximum genus of a graph in terms of its connectivity and Betti number (cycle rank). These bounds are tight for all possible values of edge-connectivity and vertex-connectivity and for both simple and non-simple graphs. The use of Nebeský's characterization of maximum genus gives us both shorter proofs and a description of extremal graphs. An additional application of our method shows that the maximum genus is almost additive over the edge cuts.	string

357	en_US	abstract	<p>Every equivelar abstract polytope of type <span class="math">{<em>p</em><sub>1</sub>, …, <em>p</em><sub><em>n</em> − 1</sub>}</span> has at least <span class="math">2<em>p</em><sub>1</sub>⋯<em>p</em><sub><em>n</em> − 1</sub></span> flags. In this paper, we study polytopes that attain this lower bound, called <em>tight polytopes</em>. Using properties of flat polytopes, we are able to give a complete local characterization of when a polytope is tight. We then show a way to construct tight polyhedra of type <span class="math">{<em>p</em>, <em>q</em>}</span> when <span class="math"><em>p</em></span> and <span class="math"><em>q</em></span> are not both odd, and a way to construct regular tight polytopes of type <span class="math">{2<em>k</em><sub>1</sub>, …, 2<em>k</em><sub><em>n</em> − 1</sub>}</span>.</p>	string

358	en_US	abstract	   Let $a$, $b$ and $k$ be nonnegative integers with<br />$1\\leq a\\leq b$, and let $G$ be a graph of order $n$ with $n\\geq<br />\\frac{(a+b)(a+b-3)+1}{a}+k$. A graph $G$ is called all fractional<br />$(a,b,k)$-critical if after deleting any $k$ vertices of $G$ the<br />remaining graph of $G$ has all fractional $[a,b]$-factors. In this<br />paper, it is proved that $G$ is all fractional $(a,b,k)$-critical<br />if $G$ satisfies $|N_G(X)|&gt;\\frac{(b-1)n+|X|+ak-1}{a+b-1}$ for<br />every non-empty independent subset $X$ of $V(G)$ and<br />$\\delta(G)&gt;\\frac{(b-1)n+a+b+ak-2}{a+b-1}$. Furthermore, it is<br />shown that the result is sharp in some sense.	string

359	en_US	abstract	<p>We call a convex polytope <span class="math"><em>P</em></span> of dimension 3 <em>admissible</em> if it has the following two properties: (1) for each vertex of <span class="math"><em>P</em></span> the set of its first-neighbours is coplanar; (2) all planes determined by the first-neighbours are distinct. We investigate the combinatorial nature of the <span class="math"><em>V</em></span>-construction and use it on unit-distance graphs to construct novel isometric point-circle configurations. 366	en_US	title	Embeddings of graphs of fixed treewidth and bounded degree	string
366	en_US	cleanTitle	Embeddings of graphs of fixed treewidth and bounded degree	string
366	en_US	abstract	Let <em><strong><span class="math">F</span></strong></em> be any family of graphs of fixed treewidth and bounded degree. We construct a quadratic-time algorithm for calculating the genus distribution of the graphs in <em><strong>F</strong></em>. Within a post-order traversal of the decomposition tree, the algorithm involves a full-powered upgrading of <em>production rules</em> and <em>root-popping</em>. This algorithm for calculating genus distributions in quadratic time complements an algorithm of Kawarabayashi, Mohar, and Reed for calculating the minimum genus of a graph of bounded treewidth in linear time.	string

368	en_US	abstract	A facial parity edge coloring of a 2-edge connected plane graph is an edge coloringwhere no two consecutive edges of a facial walk of any face receive the same color.Additionally, for every face f and every color c either no edge or an odd number ofedges incident to f are colored with c. 370	en_US	title	The connected vertex detour monophonic number of a graph	string
370	en_US	cleanTitle	The connected vertex detour monophonic number of a graph	string
370	en_US	abstract	<p>For any vertex $x$ in a connected graph $G$ of order $n \\geq 2$, a set $S \\subseteq V(G)$ is an $x$-detour monophonic set<br />of $G$ if each vertex $v \\in V(G)$ lies on an $x$-$y$ detour <br />monophonic path for some element $y$ in $S$. The minimum cardinality of an <br />$x$-detour monophonic set of $G$ is the $x$-detour <br />monophonic number of $G$, denoted by $dm_x(G)$. A connected $x$-detour monophonic set of $G$<br />is an $x$-detour monophonic set $S$ such that the subgraph induced by $S$ is<br />connected. The minimum cardinality of a connected $x$-detour monophonic <br />set of $G$ is the connected $x$-detour monophonic number of $G$, denoted by <br />$cdm_x(G)$. We determine bounds for it and find the same for some special <br />classes of graphs. For positive integers $r, d$ and $k$ with $2 \\leq r \\leq d$ and $k \\geq 2$, there exists a connected graph $G$ with <br />monophonic radius $r$, monophonic diameter $d$ and connected $x$-detour monophonic number $k$<br /> for some vertex $x$ in $G$. Also, it is shown that for positive integers $j, k, l$ and $n$ with $2 \\leq j \\leq k \\leq l \\leq n-4$, there is a connected graph $G$ of order $n$ with $m_x(G) = j, dm_x(G) = k$ and $cdm_x(G) = l$ for some vertex $x$ in $G$.</p>	string

373	en_US	title	Sectional split extensions arising from lifts of groups	string
373	en_US	cleanTitle	Sectional split extensions arising from lifts of groups	string
373	en_US	abstract	<p>Covering techniques have recently emerged as an effective tool used for classification of several infinite families of connected symmetric graphs. One commonly encountered technique is based on the concept of lifting groups of automorphisms along regular covering projections <span class="math">℘: <span>˜</span><em>X</em> → <em>X</em></span>. Efficient computational methods are known for regular covers with cyclic or elementary abelian group of covering transformations <span class="math">CT(℘)</span>.</p><p>In this paper we consider the lifting problem with an additional condition on how a group should lift: given a connected graph <span class="math"><em>X</em></span> and a group <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> of its automorphisms, find all connected regular covering projections <span class="math">℘: <span>˜</span><em>X</em> → <em>X</em></span> along which <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> lifts as a sectional split extension. By this we mean that there exists a complement <span>ˉ</span><span class="math"><em>G</em></span> of <span class="math">CT(℘)</span> within the lifted group <span>˜</span><span class="math"><em>G</em></span> such that <span>ˉ</span><span class="math"><em>G</em></span> has an orbit intersecting each fibre in at most one vertex. As an application, all connected elementary abelian regular coverings of the complete graph <span class="math"><em>K</em><sub>4</sub></span> along which a cyclic group of order <span class="math">4</span> lifts as a sectional split extension are constructed.</p>	string

381	en_US	title	Genus distributions of iterated 3-wheels and 3-prisms	string

381	en_US	abstract	<p>The <em>iterated 3-prism</em> <span class="math"><em>P</em><em>r</em><sub>3</sub><sup><em>n</em></sup></span> is the cartesian product <span class="math"><em>C</em><sub>3</sub>□ <em>P</em><sub><em>n</em></sub></span> of a 3-cycle and an path. At each end of the iterated 3-prism, there is a 3-cycle whose vertices are 3-valent in <span class="math"><em>C</em><sub>3</sub>□ <em>P</em><sub><em>n</em></sub></span>. The <em>iterated 3-wheel</em> <span class="math"><em>W</em><sub>3</sub><sup><em>n</em></sup></span> is obtained by contracting one of these 3-cycles in <span class="math"><em>C</em><sub>3</sub>□ <em>P</em><sub><em>n</em> + 1</sub></span> to a single vertex. Using <em>rooted-graphs</em>, we derive simultaneous recursions for the <em>partitioned genus distributions</em> of <span class="math"><em>W</em><sub>3</sub><sup><em>n</em></sup></span> and a formula for the genus distribution of the graphs <span class="math"><em>P</em><em>r</em><sub>3</sub><sup><em>n</em></sup></span>. A seemingly straightforward way to construct either the sequence of iterated prisms <span class="math"><em>P</em><em>r</em><sub>3</sub><sup><em>n</em></sup></span> or the sequence of iterated wheels <span class="math"><em>W</em><sub>3</sub><sup><em>n</em></sup></span>, would be by iterative amalgamation of a copy of <span class="math"><em>C</em><sub>3</sub>□ <em>K</em><sub>2</sub></span>, such that a copy of <span class="math"><em>C</em><sub>3</sub></span> contained in it is matched to the “newest” copy of <span class="math"><em>C</em><sub>3</sub></span> in the growing graph. Calculating genus distributions for the sequences would then involve an excessively large set of simultaneous recurrences. To avoid this, we propose a method of iterative surgery, under which the same vertex is considered a root-vertex in all graphs of the sequence, and in which the successive calculations of genus distributions require only four simultaneous recurrences. We also prove that the genus distribution of <span class="math"><em>P</em><em>r</em><sub>3</sub><sup><em>n</em></sup></span> not only dominates the genus distribution of <span class="math"><em>W</em><sub>3</sub><sup><em>n</em> − 1</sup></span>, but is also dominated by the genus distribution of <span class="math"><em>W</em><sub>3</sub><sup><em>n</em></sup></span>.</p>	string

385	en_US	title	The Resolving Partition Polynomial of a Graph	string
385	en_US	cleanTitle	The Resolving Partition Polynomial of a Graph	string
385	en_US	abstract	For a vertex $u$ of $G$ and a subset $S$ of $V(G)$, the distancebetween $u$ and $S$ is the number $min_{s \\in S}d(u,s)$. A$k$-partition $\\Pi$ $=$ $\\{S_1, S_2, \\ldots, S_k\\}$ of $V(G)$ iscalled a resolving partition if for every two distinct vertices $u,v\\in V(G)$, there is a set $S_i$ in $\\Pi$ such that $d(u,S_i) \\neqd(v,S_i)$. The minimum $k$ for which there is a resolving$k$-partition of $V(G)$ is called the partition dimension of $G$,denoted by $pd(G)$. The resolving partition polynomial of $G$ is thepolynomial $\\mathcal{P}(G,x) = \\sum_{i = pd(G)}^n \\rho_{i} x^i$,where $\\rho_{i}$ is the number of resolving partitions of $V(G)$ ofcardinality $i$. A root of $\\mathcal{P}(G,x)$ is called a resolvingpartition root. Two graphs $G$ and $H$ are said to be$\\mathcal{\\mathcal{P}}$-equivalent, written as $G\\sim^{\\mathcal{\\mathcal{P}}} H$, if $\\mathcal{P}(G,x) =\\mathcal{P}(H,x)$. The $\\mathcal{\\mathcal{P}}$-equivalence class of$G$ is $[G] = \\{H\\ :\\ H \\sim^{\\mathcal{\\mathcal{P}}} G\\}$. A graph$G$ is said to be $\\mathcal{\\mathcal{P}}$-unique if $[G] = \\{G\\}$.The connected resolving partition polynomial of $G$ is thepolynomial $C_{\\mathcal{P}}(G,x) = \\sum_{i = cpd(G)}^{n} c_{i} x^i,$where $c_{i}$ is the number of connected resolving partitions of$V(G)$ of cardinality $i$ and $cpd(G)$ is the connected partitiondimension of $G$. In this paper, we study some properties of theresolving partition polynomial and find resolving partitionpolynomials and connected resolving partition polynomials of somewell-known families of graphs. We also find the resolving partitionpolynomials and connected resolving partition polynomials of thefamilies of graphs having partition dimension $n-1$. Further, wecompute equivalence classes of the graphs with partition dimension$2$, $n$ and $n-1$.	string

394	en_US	title	On the game chromatic number of the splitting graph of cycle	string
394	en_US	cleanTitle	On the game chromatic number of the splitting graph of cycle	string
394	en_US	abstract	Given a graph $G$ and an integer $k$, two players take turns coloring the vertices of $G$ one by one using $k$ colors so that neighboring vertices get different colors. The first player wins iff at the end of the game all the vertices of $G$ are colored. The game chromatic number $\\chi_g (G)$ is the minimum $k$ for which the first player has a winning strategy. In this study, we prove that the game chromatic number of the splitting<br />graph of $n$-cycle for $n\\geq 5$ is $4$.	string

395	en_US	title	The Resolving Share in graphs	string
395	en_US	cleanTitle	The Resolving Share in graphs	string
395	en_US	abstract	Consider a robot which is navigating in a space modeled by a graph,and which wants to know its location. There is neither the conceptof direction nor that of visibility. But it is assumed that it cansense the distances to a set of landmarks. Then there is a problemof computing the minimum number of landmarks required, and wherethey should be placed, such that the robot can always uniquelydetermine its location. Consider a chemical structure modeled by ametagraph $H$ whose vertices are the graphs corresponding tochemical compounds such that the distance between some pairs ofgraphs is one. Then there is a problem of computing the minimumnumber of vertices of $H$ required such that distinct chemicalcompounds have distinct representations. Both the problems,mentioned above, are actually the classical problems about metricspace. A minimum set of landmarks which uniquely determine therobot’s position and a minimum set of vertices of the graph $H$which uniquely determine the presentation of distinct chemicalcompounds is called a metric basis and the cardinality of a metricbasis is called the metric dimension (formally defined in theintroduction). Now, an interesting question one can ask that howmuch a landmark form a set of minimum landmarks play its role indetermining the unique position of robot? How much a vertex from aminimum set of vertices in the graph $H$ participate in determiningthe presentation of chemical compounds? That is, in a graph $G$, howmuch a vertex of a metric basis of $G$ participate in resolving thegraph $G$? To answer this question, in this paper, we introduce theconcept of resolving share of each element of a metric basis of $G$.We also define a parameter, called the resolving percentage, byusing the concept of resolving share, which is helpful indetermining the measure of the amount of resolving done by theelements of metric basis in $G$.	string

395	en_US	subjectClass	05C12	string
395	en_US	subject	resolving set, metric dimension, diameter, resolving share, resolving percentage	string
395	en_US	sponsor	This research of the authors was supported by the Higher Education Commission of Pakistan	string

405	en_US	abstract	The metric dimension of a graph $G$ is the least number of vertices<br />in $G$ chosen in such a way that each vertex of $G$ can be<br />determined uniquely by its distances to the chosen vertices. The<br />metric dimension of $G$ is said to be constant if it does not<br />increase with increase in the number of vertices of $G$, otherwise<br />it is said to be unbounded. In this paper, we consider two families<br />of circulant graphs: one in the context of constant metric dimension<br />and the other in the perspective of unbounded metric dimension to<br />counter the popular belief that every family of circulant graphs has<br />constant metric dimension.	string

406	en_US	abstract	Given any equivelar map on the torus, it is natural to consider its covering maps. In this paper, we prove that each equivelar map on the torus has a unique minimal toroidal rotary cover and also a unique minimal toroidal regular cover. 409	en_US	title	signed total k-independence in graphs	string
409	en_US	cleanTitle	signed total kindependence in graphs	string
409	en_US	abstract	Let $k\\ge 2$ be an integer. A function $f:V(G)\\rightarrow\\{-1,1\\}$ defined on the vertex set $V(G)$ <br />of a graph $G$ is a signed total $k$-independence function if the sum of its function values<br />over any neighborhood is at most $k-1$. That is, $\\sum_{x\\in N(v)}f(x)\\le k-1$ for every<br />$v\\in V(G)$, where $N(v)$ consists of every vertex adjacent to $v$.<br />The weight of a signed total $k$-independence function $f$ is $w(f)=\\sum_{v\\in V(G)}f(v)$. The maximum <br />of weights $w(f)$, taken over all signed total $k$-independence functions $f$ on $G$, is the signed <br />total $k$-independence number $\\alpha_{st}^k(G)$ of $G$.<br /><br />In this work, we mainly present upper bounds on $\\alpha_{st}^k(G)$, as for example<br />$\\alpha_{st}^k(G)\\le n-2\\lfloor(\\Delta(G)+2-k)/2\\rfloor$, and we prove the Nordhaus-Gaddum type inequality<br />$\\alpha_{st}^k(G)+\\alpha_{st}^k(\\overline G)\\le n+2k-3$, where $n$ is the order, $\\Delta(G)$ the maximum <br />degree and $\\overline G$ the complement of the graph $G$. Some of our results imply well-known bounds <br />on the signed total 2-independence number.	string

412	en_US	abstract	In this work, we derive some algebraic identities on Pell numbers which are the numbers given by $P_{n}=2P_{n-1}+P_{n-2}$ for $n\\geq 2$ with initial values $P_{0}=0,P_{1}=1$ and also generalized Pell numbers $a_{n},U_{n}$ and $V_{n}$. 425	en_US	title	Optimum Routing in Wireless Nanosensor Networks by a Game Theory Approach	string
425	en_US	cleanTitle	Optimum Routing in Wireless Nanosensor Networks by a Game Theory Approach	string
425	en_US	abstract	<p class="papertitle">In this paper, we investigate a moving-Optimum Routing problem with nanosensor networks. Each nanosensor node has a sensor to observe the target and a processor to estimate the target position. It also has wireless communication capability but with limited range and can only communicate with neighbors. The moving target is assumed to be an intelligent agent, which is “smart” enough to escape from the detection by maximizing the estimation error. This adversary behavior makes the Optimum Routing problem more difficult. In this paper, a “Game Theory” approach for finding an optimum routing in a “Wireless Nanosensor Network” is discussed. WSN is one of the most interesting research fields in the communication networks, and is the center of attention in recent years. We formulate this target estimation problem as a zero-sum game in this paper and use a minimax filter to estimate the target position. The minimax filter is a robust filter that minimizes the estimation error by considering the worst case noise. In our model, a pricing and payment technique is presented to obtain an optimum routing in a WSN by considering reliability, energy and traffic load. The proposed algorithm is able to find a path which improves network lifetime, load distribution and path reliability. The distributed computation is implemented via modeling the information received from neighbors as measurements in the minimax filter. The simulation results show that the Optimum Routing algorithm proposed in this paper provides a satisfactory result.</p> <p><em> </em></p>	string
417	en_US	title	Optimum Routing in Wireless Nanosensor Networks by a Game Theory Approach	string
417	en_US	cleanTitle	Optimum Routing in Wireless Nanosensor Networks by a Game Theory Approach	string
417	en_US	abstract	<p>In this paper, we investigate a moving-Optimum Routing problem with nanosensor networks. Each nanosensor node has a sensor to observe the target and a processor to estimate the target position. It also has wireless communication capability but with limited range and can only communicate with neighbors. The moving target is assumed to be an intelligent agent, which is “smart” enough to escape from the detection by maximizing the estimation error. This adversary behavior makes the Optimum Routing problem more difficult.In this paper, a “Game Theory” approach for finding an optimum routing in a “Wireless Nanosensor Network” is discussed. WSN is one of the most interesting research fields in the communication networks, and is the center of attention in recent years<strong>.</strong> We formulate this target estimation problem as a zero-sum game in this paper and use a minimax filter to estimate the target position. The minimax filter is a robust filter that minimizes the estimation error by considering the worst case noise.In our model, a pricing and payment technique is presented to obtain an optimum routing in a WSN by considering reliability, energy and traffic load. The proposed algorithm is able to find a path which improves network lifetime, load distribution and path reliability. The distributed computation is implemented via modeling the information received from neighbors as measurements in the minimax filter. The simulation results show that the Optimum Routing algorithm proposed in this paper provides a satisfactory result.</p>	string

418	en_US	title	Equitable Colorings of Corona Multiproducts of Graphs	string
418	en_US	cleanTitle	Equitable Colorings of Corona Multiproducts of Graphs	string
418	en_US	abstract	A graph is equitably k-colorable if its vertices can be partitioned into k<br />independent sets in such a way that the number of vertices in any two sets<br />differ by at most one. The smallest k for which such a coloring exists is known as the equitable chromatic number of G and denoted \\chi_=(G). It is known that this problem is NP-hard in general case and remains so for corona graphs. In [12] Lin i Chang studied equitable coloring of Cartesian products of graphs. In this paper we consider the same model of coloring in the case of corona products of graphs. In particular, we obtain some results regarding the equitable chromatic number for l-corona product G l H, where G is an equitably 3- or 4-colorable graph and H is an r-partite graph, a path, a cycle or a complete graph. Our proofs are constructive in that they lead to polynomial algorithms for equitable coloring of such graph products provided that there is given an equitable coloring of G. Moreover, we confirm Equitable Coloring Conjecture for corona products of such graphs. This paper extends our results from [8].	string
418	en_US	discipline	Combinatorics; Graph Theory	string
418	en_US	subjectClass	05C15; 05C76;	string
418	en_US	subject	corona graph, equitable chromatic number, equitable coloring conjecture, equitable graph coloring, NP-completeness, polynomial algorithm, multiproduct of graphs	string
418	en_US	sponsor	Narodowe Centrum Nauki	string
419	en_US	title	Partial product of graphs and Vizing's conjecture	string
419	en_US	cleanTitle	Partial product of graphs and Vizing's conjecture	string
419	en_US	abstract	<p>Let <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> and <span class="math"><em>H</em></span> be two graphs with vertex sets <span class="math"><em>V</em><sub>1</sub> = {<em>u</em><sub>1</sub>, . . . , <em>u</em><sub><em>n</em><sub>1</sub></sub>}</span> and <span class="math"><em>V</em><sub>2</sub> = {<em>v</em><sub>1</sub>, . . . , <em>v</em><sub><em>n</em><sub>2</sub></sub>}</span>, respectively. If <span class="math"><em>S</em> ⊂ <em>V</em><sub>2</sub></span>, then the partial Cartesian product of <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> and <span class="math"><em>H</em></span> with respect to <span class="math"><em>S</em></span> is the graph <span class="math"><em>G</em>□<sub><em>S</em></sub><em>H</em> = (<em>V</em>, <em>E</em>)</span>, where <span class="math"><em>V</em> = <em>V</em><sub>1</sub> × <em>V</em><sub>2</sub></span> and two vertices <span class="math">(<em>u</em><sub><em>i</em></sub>, <em>v</em><sub><em>j</em></sub>)</span> and <span class="math">(<em>u</em><sub><em>k</em></sub>, <em>v</em><sub><em>l</em></sub>)</span> are adjacent in <span class="math"><em>G</em>□<sub><em>S</em></sub><em>H</em></span> if and only if either (<span class="math"><em>u</em><sub><em>i</em></sub> = <em>u</em><sub><em>k</em></sub></span> and <span class="math"><em>v</em><sub><em>j</em></sub> ∼ <em>v</em><sub><em>l</em></sub></span>) or (<span class="math"><em>u</em><sub><em>i</em></sub> ∼ <em>u</em><sub><em>k</em></sub></span> and <span class="math"><em>v</em><sub><em>j</em></sub> = <em>v</em><sub><em>l</em></sub> ∈ <em>S</em></span>). If <span class="math"><em>A</em> ⊂ <em>V</em><sub>1</sub></span> and <span class="math"><em>B</em> ⊂ <em>V</em><sub>2</sub></span>, then the restricted partial strong product of <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> and <span class="math"><em>H</em></span> with respect to <span class="math"><em>A</em></span> and <span class="math"><em>B</em></span> is the graph <span class="math"><em>G</em><sub><em>A</em></sub>\\boxtimes<sub><em>B</em></sub> <em>H</em> = (<em>V</em>, <em>E</em>)</span>, where <span <em>B</em></span>, <span class="math"><em>v</em><sub><em>l</em></sub> ∈ <em>B</em></span>, <span class="math"><em>u</em><sub><em>i</em></sub> ∼ <em>u</em><sub><em>k</em></sub></span> and <span In this article we obtain Vizing-like results for the domination number and the independence domination number of the partial Cartesian product of graphs. Moreover we study the domination number of the restricted partial strong product of graphs.</p>	string

420	en_US	title	Laceable knights	string
420	en_US	cleanTitle	Laceable knights	string
420	en_US	abstract	<p>A bipartite graph is <em>Hamilton-laceable</em> if for any two vertices in different parts there is a Hamiltonian path from one to the other. Using two main ideas (an algorithm for finding Hamiltonian paths and a decomposition lemma to move from smaller cases to larger) we show that the graph of knight<span>’</span>s moves on an <span class="math"><em>m</em> × <em>n</em></span> board is Hamilton-laceable iff <span class="math"><em>m</em> ≥ 6</span>, <span class="math"><em>n</em> ≥ 6</span>, and one of <span class="math"><em>m</em>, <em>n</em></span> is even. We show how the algorithm leads to new conjectures about Hamiltonian paths for various families, such as generalized Petersen graphs, <span class="math"><em>I</em></span>-graphs, and cubic symmetric graphs.</p>	string

424	en_US	title	$k$-colored kernels in semicomplete multipartite digraphs	string
424	en_US	cleanTitle	kcolored kernels in semicomplete multipartite digraphs	string
424	en_US	abstract	An $m$-colored digraph $D$ has $k$-colored kernel if there exists asubset $K $ of its vertices such that for every vertex $v\\notin K$there exists an atmost $k$-colored directed path from $v$ to a vertex of $K$ and for every $%u,v\\in K$ there does not exist an at most $k$-colored directed pathbetween them. Let $\\overrightarrow{C}_{n}$ be the directed cycle of length $n$. We defined the digraphs $%\\overrightarrow{C}_{3}\\uparrow \\overrightarrow{C}_{3}$ (resp. $%\\overrightarrow{C}_{4}\\uparrow \\uparrow \\overrightarrow{C}_{4}$) as twodirected cycles $\\overrightarrow{C}_{3}$ (resp.$\\overrightarrow{C}_{4}$) joined by an arc (resp. by two consecutivearcs).In this paper we prove that an $m$-coloredsemicomplete $r$-partite digraph $D$ has a $k$-colored kernelprovided that $r\\geq 3$ and \\\\\\hspace*{15pt}(i) $k\\geq 4$, \\\\\\hspace*{10pt} (ii) $k=3$ and every $\\overrightarrow{C}_{4}$ contained in $D$ is atmost $2$-colored and, either every $\\overrightarrow{C}_{5}$contained in $D$ is at most $3$-colored or every$\\overrightarrow{C}_{3}\\uparrow \\overrightarrow{C}_{3}$ contained in$D$ is at most $2$-colored, \\\\\\hspace*{10pt}(iii) $k=2$ and every $\\overrightarrow{C}_{3}$ and $\\overrightarrow{C}%_{4}$ contained in $D$ is monochromatic. \\\\If $D$ is an $m$-colored semicomplete bipartite digraph and $k=2$(resp. $k=3 $) and every $\\overrightarrow{C}_{4} \\uparrow \\uparrow \\overrightarrow{C}_{4}$contained in $D$ is at most $2$-colored (resp. $3$-colored), then $D$ has a $%2$-colored (resp. $3$-colored) kernel. Using these and previousresults, we obtain conditions for the existence of $k$-coloredkernels in $m$-colored semicomplete $r$-partite digraphs for every$k\\geq 2$ and $r\\geq 2$.	string

426	en_US	title	Vertex-Neighbor-Scattering Number of Bipartite Graphs	string
426	en_US	cleanTitle	VertexNeighborScattering Number of Bipartite Graphs	string
426	en_US	abstract	Let G be a connected noncomplete graph. A set of vertices<br />S\\subseteq V(G) is called subverted from G if each of the<br />vertices in S and the neighbor of S in G are deleted from G.<br />By G/S we denote the survival subgraph that remains after S is subverted from G. A vertex set S is called a cut-strategy of G if G/S is disconnected, a clique, or \\emptyset. The<br />vertex-neighbor-scattering number of G is defined by<br />VNS(G)=max{\\omega(G/S)-|S|}, where S is any cut-strategy of G, and \\omega(G/S) is the number of  components of G/S. It is known that this parameter can be used to measure the vulnerability of spy networks and the computing problem<br />of the parameter is $NP$-complete. In this paper we discuss the vertex-neighbor-scattering number of bipartite graphs. The NP-completeness of the computing problem of this parameter is proven, and some upper and lower bounds of the parameter are also given.	string

428	en_US	title	Distinguishing partitions of complete multipartite graphs	string

428	en_US	abstract	<span>A </span><em>distinguishing partition</em><span> of a set </span><span class="math"><em>X</em></span><span> with automorphism group </span><span class="math">aut(<em>X</em>)</span><span> is a partition of </span><span class="math"><em>X</em></span><span> that is fixed by no nontrivial element of </span><span class="math">aut(<em>X</em>)</span><span>. In the event that </span><span class="math"><em>X</em></span><span> is a complete multipartite graph with its automorphism group, the existence of a distinguishing partition is equivalent to the existence of an asymmetric hypergraph with prescribed edge sizes. An asymptotic result is proven on the existence of a distinguishing partition when </span><span class="math"><em>X</em></span><span> is a complete multipartite graph with </span><span class="math"><em>m</em><sub>1</sub></span><span> parts of size </span><span class="math"><em>n</em><sub>1</sub></span><span> and </span><span class="math"><em>m</em><sub>2</sub></span><span> parts of size </span><span class="math"><em>n</em><sub>2</sub></span><span> for small </span><span class="math"><em>n</em><sub>1</sub></span><span>, </span><span class="math"><em>m</em><sub>2</sub></span><span> and large </span><span class="math"><em>m</em><sub>1</sub></span><span>, </span><span class="math"><em>n</em><sub>2</sub></span><span>. A key tool in making the estimate is counting the number of trees of particular classes.</span>	string

432	en_US	title	Group distance magic labeling of direct product of graphs	string
432	en_US	cleanTitle	Group distance magic labeling of direct product of graphs	string
432	en_US	abstract	<p>Let <span class="math"><em>G</em> = (<em>V</em>, <em>E</em>)</span> be a graph and <span class="math">Γ </span> an Abelian group, both of order <span class="math"><em>n</em></span>. A group distance magic labeling of <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> is a bijection <span class="math">ℓ: <em>V</em> → Γ </span> for which there exists <span class="math"><em>μ</em> ∈ Γ </span> such that <span class="math">∑ <sub><em>x</em> ∈ <em>N</em>(<em>v</em>)</sub>ℓ(<em>x</em>) = <em>μ</em></span> for all <span class="math"><em>v</em> ∈ <em>V</em></span>, where <span class="math"><em>N</em>(<em>v</em>)</span> is the neighborhood of <span class="math"><em>v</em></span>. In this paper we consider group distance magic labelings of direct product of graphs. We show that if <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> is an <span class="math"><em>r</em></span> -regular graph of order <span class="math"><em>n</em></span> and <span class="math"><em>m</em> = 4</span> or <span class="math"><em>m</em> = 8</span> and <span class="math"><em>r</em></span> is even, then the direct product <span class="math"><em>C</em><sub><em>m</em></sub> × <em>G</em></span> is <span class="math">Γ </span>-distance magic for every Abelian group of order <span class="math"><em>m</em><em>n</em></span>. We also prove that <span class="math"><em>C</em><sub><em>m</em></sub> × <em>C</em><sub><em>n</em></sub></span> is <span class="math">Z<sub><em>m</em><em>n</em></sub></span>-distance magic if and only if <span class="math"><em>m</em> ∈ {4, 8}</span> or <span class="math"><em>n</em> ∈ {4, 8}</span> or <span class="math"><em>m</em>, <em>n</em> ≡ 0 mod 4</span>. It is also shown that if <span class="math"><em>m</em>, <em>n</em> not≡ 0 mod 4</span> then <span class="math"><em>C</em><sub><em>m</em></sub> × <em>C</em><sub><em>n</em></sub></span> is not <span class="math">Γ </span>-distance magic for any Abelian group <span class="math">Γ </span> of order <span class="math"><em>m</em><em>n</em></span>.</p>	string

692	en_US	title	Unstable Graphs: A Fresh Outlook via TF-Automorphisms	string
692	en_US	cleanTitle	Unstable Graphs: A Fresh Outlook via TFAutomorphisms	string
692	en_US	abstract	<pre><!--StartFragment-->In this paper, we first establish the very close link between stability of graphs, a concept first introduced by Maru{<span>\\v</span>{s}}i{<span>\\v</span>{c}}, Scapellato and Zagaglia Salvi and studied most notably by Surowski and Wilson, and two-fold automorphisms. The concept of two-fold isomorphisms, as far as we know, first appeared in Zelinka's work on isotopies of digraphs and later studied formally by the authors with a greater emphasis on undirected graphs.  We then turn our attention to the stability of graphs which have every edge on a triangle, but with the fresh outlook provided by TF-automorphisms. Amongst such graphs are strongly regular graphs with certain parameters. The advantages of this fresh outlook are highlighted when we ultimately present a method of constructing and generating unstable graphs with large diameter having every edge lying on a triangle. This was a rather surprising outcome. <!--EndFragment--></pre>	string

695	en_US	title	Maximum generalized local connectivities of cubic Cayley graphs on Abelian groups	string
695	en_US	cleanTitle	Maximum generalized local connectivities of cubic Cayley graphs on Abelian groups	string
695	en_US	abstract	For a set $S$ of $k$ vertices of $G$, let $\\kappa(S)$ denote the<br />maximum number $\\ell$ of pairwise edge-disjoint trees $T_1, T_2,<br />\\ldots, T_{\\ell}$ in $G$ such that $V(T_i) \\cap V(T_j)=S$ for $1<br />\\leq i \\neq j \\leq \\ell$ and $\\lambda(S)$ denote the maximum number<br />$\\ell$ of pairwise edge-disjoint trees $T_1, T_2, \\ldots, T_{\\ell}$<br />in $G$ such that $S \\subseteq V(T_i)$ for $1\\leq i\\leq \\ell$.<br />Similar to the classical maximum local connectivity, H. Li et al.<br />introduced the parameter<br />$\\overline{\\kappa}_k(G)=\\max\\{\\kappa(S)|S\\subseteq V(G),|S|=k\\}$,<br />which is called the maximum generalized local connectivity of $G$.<br />The maximum generalized local edge-connectivity of $G$ which was<br />introduced by X. Li et al. is defined as<br />$\\overline{\\lambda}_k(G)=\\max\\{\\lambda(S)|S\\subseteq V(G),|S|=k\\}$.<br />In this note, we investigate the maximum generalized local<br />connectivity and edge-connectivity of a cubic connected Cayley graph<br />$G$ on an Abelian group. We determine the precise values for<br />$\\overline{\\kappa}_3(G)$ and $\\overline{\\lambda}_3(G)$ and get a<br />result of $\\overline{\\kappa}_k(G)$ and $\\overline{\\lambda}_k(G)$ for<br />a general $k$.	string

433	en_US	abstract	A subset $S\\subseteq V$ is a dominating set of $G=(V,E)$ if each vertex in $V\\backslash S$ is adjacent to at least one  vertex in $S$. The domination number of $G$ is the cardinality of a minimum  dominating set of $G$. Graph<br />domination numbers and algorithms for finding them have been investigated for numerous classes of graphs, usually for graphs that have some kind of tree-like structure. In this paper, we determine that the exact domination number of generalized Petersen graph $P(n,k)$  with $n=2k$  and $n=2k+2$.<br />\\begin{center}$\\gamma(P(n,k))=<br />\\lceil\\frac{2n}{3}\\rceil$ $for$ $n=2k$; \\end{center}\\[<br />\\gamma(P(n,k))=\\left\\{<br />\\begin{array}{ll}<br />\\frac{n}{2} &amp; if\\;k\\;is\\;odd  \\\\<br />\\frac{n}{2}+1 &amp; if\\;k\\;is\\;even<br />\\end{array}<br />\\right. for\\;n=2k+2.<br />\\]	string

434	en_US	title	The anti-symmetric solution for the mixed-type Lyapunov matrix equation by parameter iterative method	string
434	en_US	cleanTitle	The antisymmetric solution for the mixedtype Lyapunov matrix equation by parameter iterative method	string
434	en_US	abstract	Lyapunov matrix equations (LMEs) have play a fundamental role in numerous problems in control, communication systems theory and power systems. As one of LMEs,  mixed-type Lyapunov matrix equation (MTLME ) also has a wide range of applications in practice. In this paper, the anti-symmetric solution of the MTLME $A^{T}X+XA+B^{T}XB=C$ is solved by using an iterative algorithm with a parameter. The steps and the conditions of convergence for this algorithm are given. Choice of the parameter is discussed. Finally, the results are illustrated by numerical example.	string

435	en_US	abstract	A signed graph (or sigraph in short) is an ordered pair S = (Su, ), where Su isa graph G = (V,E) and  : E ! {+, −} is a function from the edge set E ofSu into the set {+, −}. The canonical marking on S is defined as: for each vertexv 2 V (S), μ(v) =Yej2Ev(ej), where Ev is the set of edges ej incident at v in S.If S is canonically marked, then a cycle Z in S is said to be canonically consistentif it contains an even number of negative vertices and the given sigraph S is calledcanonically consistent if every cycle in it is canonically consistent. In this paper, wecharacterize canonically consistent semi-total line sigraphs and canonically consistentsemi-total point sigraphs.	string

436	en_US	title	Subdivision into i-packings and S-packing chromatic number of some lattices	string
436	en_US	cleanTitle	Subdivision into ipackings and Spacking chromatic number of some lattices	string
436	en_US	abstract	<p>An i-packing in a graph G is a set of vertices at pairwise distance greater than i. For a nondecreasing sequence of integers S=(s_1,s_2,...), the S-packing chromatic number of a graph G is the least integer k such that there exists a coloring of G into k colors where each set of vertices colored i, i=1,..., k, is an s_i-packing.</p><p>This paper describes various subdivisions of an i-packing into j-packings (j&gt;i) for the hexagonal, square and triangular lattices. These results allow us to bound the S-packing chromatic number for these graphs, with more precise bounds and exact values for sequences S=(s_i, i in N*), s_i = d+ [(i-1)/n].<br /><br /></p>	string

439	en_US	title	The Extremal Function for Two Disjoint Specified Subgraphs	string
439	en_US	cleanTitle	The Extremal Function for Two Disjoint Specified Subgraphs	string
439	en_US	abstract	A theta graph is the union of three internally disjoint paths that have the same two distinct end vertices. We show that every graph of order $n\\geq 9$ and size at least $\\lfloor\\frac{7n-13}{2}\\rfloor$ contains two disjoint theta graphs. We also show that every 2-edge-connected graph of order $n\\geq 6$ and size at least $3n-5$ contains two disjoint cycles, such that any specified vertex with degree at least three belongs to one of them. The lower bound on size in both are sharp in general.	string

444	en_US	title	Signed mixed dominating functions in complete bipartite graphs	string
444	en_US	cleanTitle	Signed mixed dominating functions in complete bipartite graphs	string
444	en_US	abstract	Let $G=(V,E)$ be a simple graph with vertex set $V$ and  edge set $E$. A {\\em signed mixed dominating function} of $G$ is a function $f$: $V\\cup E\\rightarrow \\{-1,1\\}$ such that $\\sum_{y\\in N_m(x)\\cup\\{x\\}}f(y)\\ge 1$ for every element $x\\in V\\cup E$, where $N_m(x)$ is the set of elements of $V\\cup E$ adjacent or incident to $x$. The weight of $f$ is $w(f)=\\sum_{x\\in V\\cup E}f(x)$. The {\\em signed mixed domination number} $\\gamma_s^*(G)$ of $G$ is the minimum weight of a signed mixed dominating function of $G$. In this paper we determine the signed mixed domination numbers of complete bipartite graphs by  constructing its minimum signed mixed dominating functions.	string

447	en_US	abstract	<p>We present some results for convergence properties of a system of non linear rational difference equations subject to multi –point exception handling. The obtained results are applied to the analysis of exception handling techniques which is associated with error identification and noise reduction in non linear filters like Extended Kalman Filter associated with non linear difference equations. 450	en_US	title	Cycle construction and geodesic cycles with application to the hypercube	string
450	en_US	cleanTitle	Cycle construction and geodesic cycles with application to the hypercube	string
450	en_US	abstract	Construction of cycles in a graph is investigated, where cycles from particular subsets (such as bases) are added together so that each partial sum is also a cycle or each new cycle intersects the sum of the preceding terms in a nontrivial path. Starting with the geodesic cycles, a hierarchical construction is given. For the hypercube graph, geodesic cycles are characterized, and it is shown how hypercube geodesic cycles can be constructed in two steps from a special basis. Applications are given to inferring commutativity of a diagram in a groupoid from commutativity of some of its cycles.	string

457	en_US	cleanTitle	Super edge magic total labeling of C_n \\triangle S_{m_i}  graph	string
457	en_US	abstract	Let $C_n$ be a~cycle with vertices $v_1,v_2, \\dots, v_n$ and $S_{m_i}$, $i=1,2,\\dots, n$, be a~star with the central vertex $u_i$ and leaves $u_j^i$, $1\\le j \\le m_i$. If the star $S_{m_i}$ is adjoined to each vertex $v_i$, $i=1,2, \\dots, n$, by identifying $v_i$ and $u_i$ for $i=1,2, \\dots, n$, we obtained a~unicyclic graph denoted by $C_n \\triangle S_{m_i}$.<br /><br />An edge magic total labeling  $\\phi:V(G)\\cup E(G)\\rightarrow \\{1, 2, \\dots, |V(G)|+ |E(G)|\\}$ of a graph $G=(V,E)$ is a bijective function of vertices and edgesof $G$  in such a way that for all edges $uv\\in E(G),$ $\\phi(u)+\\phi(uv)+\\phi(v)=k$,  where $k$ is called the magic constant or sometimes the valence of $\\phi$. An edge magic total labeling $\\phi$ is called super edge magic total if $\\phi(V(G))=\\{1, 2, \\dots, |V(G)|\\}$. We have determined the super edge magicness of the graphs $C_n \\triangle S_{m_i}$ for  $n\\ge 3$ odd, $m_i \\ge 1$ and  $n \\ge 3$ even, $m=m_i\\ge 1.$	string

458	en_US	abstract	The Kirchhoff index <em>Kf</em>(<em>G</em>) of a graph <em>G</em> is the sum of resistance distances between all pairs of vertices in <em>G</em>. In this paper, we obtain exact formulas for the expected values of the Kirchhoff indices of the random polyphenyl and spiro chains, which are graphs of a class of unbranched multispiro molecules and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons. Moreover, we obtain a relation between the expected values of the Kirchhoff indices of a random polyphenyl and its random hexagonal squeeze, and the average values for the Kirchhoff indices of all polyphenyl chains and all spiro chains with <em>n</em> hexagons, respectively.	string

467	en_US	abstract	In this paper, a relation between graph distance matrices and Euclidean distance matrices (EDM) is considered. 473	en_US	title	SPLITTING GROUPS WITH BASIS PROPERTY	string

473	en_US	abstract	A ¯nite group G is called splitting or splitable if it is a union of<br />some collection of its proper subgroups intersecting pairwise at the identity.<br />A special kind of splitting is known to be normal splitting. Also, a group G<br />is said to have the basis property if for each subgroup H · G, H has a basis<br />(minimal generating set), and any two bases have the same cardinality. In this<br />work, I discuss a relation between classes of ¯nite groups that possess both<br />normal splitting and the basis property. This article shows mainly that any<br />non p-group with basis property is normal splitting. However, the converse<br />is not true in general. A counterexample is given. It is well known that any<br />p-group has basis property [8]. I demonstrate some types of p-groups which<br />are splitting as well.	string

478	en_US	title	Sparse line deletion constructions for symmetric 4-configurations	string
478	en_US	cleanTitle	Sparse line deletion constructions for symmetric 4configurations	string
478	en_US	abstract	<span>A </span><em>4-configuration</em><span> is a collection of points and lines in the Euclidean plane such that each point lies on four lines and each line passes through four points. In this paper we introduce a new family of these objects. Our construction generalizes a 2010 result of Berman and Grünbaum in which suitable 4-configurations from the well-understood </span><em>celestial</em><span> family are altered to yield new configurations with reduced geometric symmetry groups. The construction introduced in 2010 removes every other line of a symmetry class from the celestial configuration; here we we give conditions under which every </span><span class="math"><em>p</em></span><span>-th line can be removed, for </span><span class="math"><em>p</em> ∈ {2, 3, 4, ⋯}</span><span>. The geometric symmetry groups of the new configurations we obtain are of correspondingly smaller index as subgroups of the symmetry group of the underlying celestial configuration. These </span><em>sparse</em><span> constructions can also be repeated and combined to yield a rich variety of previously unknown 4-configurations. In particular, we can begin with a configuration with very high geometric symmetry—the dihedral symmetry of an </span><span class="math"><em>m</em></span><span>-gon for </span><span class="math"><em>m</em></span><span> quite large—and produce a configuration whose only geometric symmetry is </span><span class="math">180<sup> ∘ </sup></span><span> rotation.</span>	string

479	en_US	title	Some Results on the Total Graph of $\\mathbb{Z}_n$	string
479	en_US	cleanTitle	Some Results on the Total Graph of \\mathbb{Z}_n	string
479	en_US	abstract	Suppose that $R$ is a commutative ring with identity and $Z(R)$ is the set of<br />zero-divisors of $R$. The total graph of $R$, denoted by $\\Gamma(R)$, is a graph whose vertices are elements of $R$ and<br />two distinct vertices $x$ and $y$ are adjacent if and only if<br />$x+y\\in Z(R)$. In this paper, we study the total graph of $\\mathbb{Z}_n$, the ring of integers modulo $n$. For instance, for every positive integer $n$, it is shown that the graph $\\Gamma(\\mathbb{Z}_n)$ is  weakly perfect. Among other results, we prove that $\\Gamma(\\mathbb{Z}_n)$ is a class 1 graph. Furthermore, some results on the independence number, domination number and planarity of $\\Gamma(\\mathbb{Z}_n)$ are given.	string

480	en_US	title	Study of various Routing Metric In Wireless Mesh Network and comparison according to various tuning parameters	string
480	en_US	cleanTitle	Study of various Routing Metric In Wireless Mesh Network and comparison according to various tuning parameters	string
480	en_US	abstract	<p><strong>Routing metric implementation is very important for acquiring good performance in wireless mesh network (WMN). Various routing metrics such as Expected Transmission Count (ETX), Expected Transmission Time (ETT), Weighted Cumulative Expected Transmission Time (WCETT), Weighted Cumulative Consecutive Expected Transmission Time (WCCETT) were proposed in multi-channel multi-hop wireless mesh networks. In this paper we proposed a new routing metric called modified Weighted Cumulative Consecutive Expected Transmission Time (mWCCETT) with respect to the selection of less interference path in wireless mesh network. The theoretic analysis and calculations verify that mWCCETT performs better than other routing metrics.</strong></p>	string

483	en_US	title	Hamming distance between vertices and Hamming index of graphs	string
483	en_US	cleanTitle	Hamming distance between vertices and Hamming index of graphs	string
483	en_US	abstract	Let $A(G)$ be the adjacency matrix of a graph $G$. the rows of $A(G)$ corresponding to a vertex $v$ of $G$, denoted by $s(v)$ is the string which belongs to $Z_2^n$, a set of $n$-tuples. The Hamming distance between the vertices $u$ and $v$ is the number of positions in which $s(u)$ and $s(v)$ differ. The Hamming index of a graph $G$ is the sum of the Hamming distances between all pairs of vertices of $G$. In this paper we obtain the Hamming distances between the vertices and also the Hamming index of graphs.	string

484	en_US	title	Independent sets of some graphs associated to commutative rings	string
484	en_US	cleanTitle	Independent sets of some graphs associated to commutative rings	string
484	en_US	abstract	Let $G=(V,E)$ be a simple graph. A set $S\\subseteq V$ is<br />independent set of $G$,  if no two vertices of $S$ are adjacent. The  independence number $\\alpha(G)$ is the size of a maximum independent set in the graph. Let $R$ be a commutative ring with nonzero identity and  $I$ an ideal of<br />$R$. The zero-divisor graph of $R$, denoted by $\\Gamma(R)$, is an undirected graph whose vertices are the nonzero zero-divisors of $R$ and two distinct vertices $x$ and $y$ are adjacent if and only if $xy = 0$. Also the ideal-based zero-divisor graph of $R$, denoted by $\\Gamma_I(R)$, is the graph which vertices are the set $\\{x\\in R\\backslash I | xy\\in I  \\quad\\mbox{for some} \\quad  y\\in R\\backslash I\\}$  and two distinct vertices $x$ and $y$ are adjacent if and only if $xy \\in I$. In this paper we study the independent sets and the independence number of  $\\Gamma(R)$ and $\\Gamma_I(R)$.	string

485	en_US	abstract	The harmonic index $H(G)$ of a graph $G$ is defined as the sum of weights $\\frac{2}{d(u)+d(v)}$ of all edges $uv$ of $G$, where $d(u)$ denotes the degree of a vertex $u$ in $G$. In this paper, we first present a sharp lower bound on the harmonic index of acyclic conjugated graphs (trees with a perfect matching).  A sharp lowerbound on the harmonic index of acyclic graphs is also given in terms of the order and given size of matching.	string

491	en_US	abstract	<span>The Kneser graph </span><span class="math">KG<sub><em>n</em>, <em>k</em></sub></span><span> has one vertex for each </span><span class="math"><em>k</em></span><span>-subset of an </span><span class="math"><em>n</em></span><span>-set and edges between vertices whenever the corresponding subsets are disjoint. 496	en_US	title	Edmonds maps on Fricke-Macbeath curve	string
496	en_US	cleanTitle	Edmonds maps on FrickeMacbeath curve	string
496	en_US	abstract	<span>In 1985, L. D. James and G. A. Jones proved that the complete graph </span><span class="math"><em>K</em><sub><em>n</em></sub></span><span> defines a clean dessin d’enfant (the bipartite graph is given by taking as the black vertices the vertices of </span><span class="math"><em>K</em><sub><em>n</em></sub></span><span> and the white vertices as middle points of edges) if and only if </span><span class="math"><em>n</em> = <em>p</em><sup><em>e</em></sup></span><span>, where </span><span class="math"><em>p</em></span><span> is a prime. Later, in 2010, G. A. Jones, M. Streit and J. Wolfart computed the minimal field of definition of them. The minimal genus </span><span class="math"><em>g</em> &gt; 1</span><span> of these types of clean dessins d’enfant is </span><span class="math"><em>g</em> = 7</span><span>, obtained for </span><span class="math"><em>p</em> = 2</span><span> and </span><span class="math"><em>e</em> = 3</span><span>. In that case, there are exactly two such clean dessins d’enfant (previously known as Edmonds maps), both of them defining the Fricke-Macbeath curve (the only Hurwitz curve of genus </span><span class="math">7</span><span>) and both forming a chiral pair. The uniqueness of the Fricke-Macbeath curve asserts that it is definable over </span><span class="math"><strong>Q</strong></span><span>, but both Edmonds maps cannot be defined over </span><span class="math"><strong>Q</strong></span><span>; in fact they have as minimal field of definition the quadratic field </span><span class="math"><strong>Q</strong>(sqrt( − 7))</span><span>. It seems that no explicit models for the Edmonds maps over </span><span class="math"><strong>Q</strong>(sqrt( − 7))</span><span> are written in the literature. In this paper we start with an explicit model </span><span class="math"><em>X</em></span><span> for the Fricke-Macbeath curve provided by Macbeath, which is defined over </span><span class="math"><strong>Q</strong>(<em>e</em><sup>2<em>π</em><em>i</em> / 7</sup>)</span><span>, and we construct an explicit birational isomorphism</span><span class="math"><em>L</em>: <em>X</em> → <em>Z</em></span><span>, where </span><span class="math"><em>Z</em></span><span> is defined over </span><span class="math"><strong>Q</strong>(sqrt( − 7))</span><span>, so that both Edmonds maps are also defined over that field.</span>	string

502	en_US	title	Quartic integral Cayley graphs	string
502	en_US	cleanTitle	Quartic integral Cayley graphs	string
502	en_US	abstract	We give exhaustive lists of connected 4-regular integral Cayley graphs and connected 4-regular integral arc-transitive graphs. An integral graph is a graph for which all eigenvalues are integers. A Cayley graph Cay(Γ, S) for a given group Γ and connection set S ⊂ Γ is the graph with vertex set Γ and with a connected to b if and only if ba−1 ∈ S. Up to isomorphism, we find that there are 32 connected quartic integral Cayley graphs; 17 of which are bipartite. Many of these can be realized in a number of different ways by using non-isomorphic choices for Γ and/or S. A graph is arc-transitive if its automorphism group acts transitively upon ordered pairs of adjacent vertices. Up to isomorphism, there are 27 quartic integral graphs that are arc-transitive. Of these 27 graphs, 16 are bipartite and 16 are Cayley graphs. By taking quotients of our Cayley or arc-transitive graphs we also find a number of other quartic integral graphs. Overall, we find 9 new spectra that can be realised by bipartite quartic integral graphs.	string

507	en_US	abstract	Given any graph $G$, its square graph $G^2$ is a graph with vertex set $V(G)$ and two vertices are adjacent whenever they are at distance $1$ or $2$ in $G$. Similarly, $G^k$ is defined. Dominating parameter of power of a graph has not been deeply studied yet. In this paper, inspired of dominating set for $G$, we study dominating set of $G^2$ in terms of dominating set and diameter of $G$, and characterize the domination number of $G^k$ for $k\\ge 2$, indeed we obtain the exact value of domination number of some square of graphs. 508	en_US	title	Augmented down-up algebras and uniform posets	string
508	en_US	cleanTitle	Augmented downup algebras and uniform posets	string
508	en_US	abstract	<p>Motivated by the structure of the uniform posets we introduce the notion of an augmented down-up (or ADU) algebra. We discuss how ADU algebras are related to the down-up algebras defined by Benkart and Roby. For each ADU algebra we give two presentations by generators and relations. We also display a <span class="math"><strong>Z</strong></span>-grading and a linear basis. In addition we show that the center is isomorphic to a polynomial algebra in two variables. We display seven families of uniform posets and show that each gives an ADU algebra module in a natural way. The main inspiration for the ADU algebra concept comes from the second author’s thesis concerning a type of uniform poset constructed using a dual polar graph.</p>	string

512	en_US	title	On the f-chromatic class of a multi-wheel graph	string
512	en_US	cleanTitle	On the fchromatic class of a multiwheel graph	string
512	en_US	abstract	<p>An $f$-coloring of a graph $G$ is an edge-coloring<br />of $G$ such that each color appears at each vertex $v\\in V(G)$ at most $f(v)$ times. The minimum number of colors needed to $f$-color $G$ is called the $f$-chromatic index of $G$. Any graph $G$ has<br />$f$-chromatic index equal to $\\Delta_{f}(G)$ or $\\Delta_{f}(G)+1$, where $\\Delta_{f}(G)=\\max_{v\\in V(G)}\\{\\lceil{d(v)}/{f(v)}\\rceil\\}$. A multi-wheel graph is a graph obtained from $s$ cycles $C_{n_1},C_{n_2},\\ldots,C_{n_s}$ $(s\\geq 1)$ by adding a new vertex, say $w$, and edges joining $w$ to all the vertices of the $s$ cycles. In this article, the classification problem of multi-wheel graphs on $f$-colorings is solved completely. As a consequence, we<br />solve a conjecture posed by Yu et al. in 2006 and prove that it is not always true.</p>	string
512	en_US	discipline	Graph theory	string

513	en_US	title	The clone cover	string
513	en_US	cleanTitle	The clone cover	string
513	en_US	abstract	<p>Each finite graph on <span class="math"><em>n</em></span> vertices determines a special <span class="math">(<em>n</em> − 1)</span>-fold covering graph that we call the <em>clone cover</em>. Several equivalent definitions and basic properties about this remarkable construction are presented. In particular, we show that for <span class="math"><em>k</em> ≥ 2</span>, the clone cover of a <span class="math"><em>k</em></span>-connected graph is <span class="math"><em>k</em></span>-connected, the clone cover of a planar graph is planar and the clone cover of a hamiltonian graph is hamiltonian. As for symmetry properties, in most cases we also understand the structure of the automorphism groups of these covers. A particularly nice property is that every automorphism of the base graph lifts to an automorphism of its clone cover. We also show that the covering projection from the clone cover onto its corresponding <span class="math">2</span>-connected base graph is never a regular covering, except when the base graph is a cycle.</p>	string

516	en_US	abstract	<p><span>An injective coloring of a graph is a vertex coloring where two vertices receive distinct colors if they have a common neighbor. Chen, Hahn, Raspaud, and Wang </span><span>conjectured that every planar graph with maximum degree </span><span class="math">Δ  ≥ 3</span><span> admits an injective coloring with at most </span><span class="math">⌈3Δ  / 2⌉</span><span> colors. 520	en_US	title	Fast recognition of partial star products and quasi cartesian products	string
520	en_US	cleanTitle	Fast recognition of partial star products and quasi cartesian products	string
520	en_US	abstract	<p>This paper is concerned with the fast computation of a relation d on the edge set of connected graphs that plays a decisive role in the recognition of approximate Cartesian products, the weak reconstruction of Cartesian products, and the recognition of Cartesian graph bundles with a triangle free basis.</p><p>A special case of d is the relation <span class="math"><em>δ</em><sup>*</sup></span>, whose convex closure yields the product relation <span class="math"><em>σ</em></span> that induces the prime factor decomposition of connected graphs with respect to the Cartesian product. For the construction of d so-called Partial Star Products are of particular interest. Several special data structures are used that allow to compute Partial Star Products in constant time. These computations are tuned to the recognition of approximate graph products, but also lead to a linear time algorithm for the computation of <span class="math"><em>δ</em><sup>*</sup></span> for graphs with maximum bounded degree.</p><p>Furthermore, we define <em>quasi Cartesian products</em> as graphs with non-trivial <span class="math"><em>δ</em><sup>*</sup></span>. We provide several examples, and show that quasi Cartesian products can be recognized in linear time for graphs with bounded maximum degree. Finally, we note that quasi products can be recognized in sublinear time with a parallelized algorithm.</p>	string

518	en_US	title	Rational sums of hermitian squares of free noncommutative polynomials	string
518	en_US	cleanTitle	Rational sums of hermitian squares of free noncommutative polynomials	string
518	en_US	abstract	In this paper we consider polynomials in noncommuting variables that admit sum of hermitian squares and commutators decompositions. We recall algorithms for finding decompositions of this type that are based on semidefinite programming. The main part of the article investigates how to find such decomposition with <em>rational coefficients</em> if the original polynomial has rational coefficients. We show that the numerical evidence, obtained by the Gram matrix method and semidefinite programming, which is usually an almost feasible point, can be frequently tweaked to obtain an <em>exact certificate</em> using rational numbers. In the presence of Slater points, the Peyrl-Parrilo rounding and projecting method applies. On the other hand, in the absence of strict feasibility, a variant of the facial reduction is proposed to reduce the size of the semidefinite program and to enforce the existence of Slater points. All these methods are implemented in our open source computer algebra package NCSOStools. Throughout the paper many worked out examples are presented to illustrate our results.	string
518	en_US	discipline		string
518	en_US	subjectClass	13J30, 90C22, 08B20, 11E25, 90C90	string
518	en_US	subject	Sum of squares, semidefinite programming, noncommutative polynomial, Matlab toolbox, commutator, cyclic equivalence, free positivity, real algebraic geometry, Motzkin polynomial, Bessis- Moussa-Villani (BMV) conjecture, NCSOStools.	string

521	en_US	title	Reachability relations, transitive digraphs and groups	string
521	en_US	cleanTitle	Reachability relations transitive digraphs and groups	string
521	en_US	abstract	<div class="page" title="Page 3"><div class="layoutArea"><div class="column"><p>In A. Malnič, D. Marušič, N. Seifter, P. Šparl and B. Zgrablič, Reachability relations in digraphs, <em>Europ. J. Combin.</em> <strong>29 </strong>(2008), 1566–1581, it was shown that properties of digraphs such as growth, property <strong>Z</strong>, and number of ends are reflected by the properties of certain reachability relations defined on the vertices of the corresponding digraphs.<br />In this paper we study these relations in connection with certain properties of automorphism groups of transitive digraphs. In particular, one of the main results shows that if a transitive digraph admits a nilpotent subgroup of automorphisms with finitely many orbits, then its nilpotency class and the number of orbits are closely related to particular properties of reachability relations defined on the digraphs in question.<br />The obtained results have interesting implications for Cayley digraphs of certain types of groups such as torsion-free groups of polynomial growth.</p><p> </p></div></div></div>	string

522	en_US	abstract	Abstract. Let G be a connected graph with vertex set V (G) and<br />edge set E(G). 524	en_US	title	On a Conjecture on Unimodal Sequences	string
524	en_US	cleanTitle	On a Conjecture on Unimodal Sequences	string
524	en_US	abstract	Wang and Yeh proved that if P(x) is a polynomial with non- negative and nondecreasing coefficients, then P(x + d) is unimodal for any d &gt; 0. A mode of a unimodal polynomial f(x) = a0 + a1x + · · · + amxm is an index k such that ak is the maximum coefficient. Suppose that M(P, d) is the smallest mode of P(x + d), and M(P, d) the greatest<br />mode. Wang and Yeh conjectured that if d2 &gt; d1 &gt; 0, then M(P, d1)  M(P, d2) and M(P, d1)  M(P, d2). This conjecture has already been proved in [7] but we give a different proof of this conjecture. We also show that if {dj : 0  j  m} is a unimodal sequence, then there is a polynomial p(x) = Pm i=0 aixi with nonnegative and non- decreasing<br />coefficients such that p(x + n) = Pm j=0 djxj , where n is a positive integer number. Furthermore, we define the almost unimodal sequences and prove that under some conditions the polynomial p(xk +d) for any positive real number d and integer number k  2, is almost unimodal.<br />.	string

526	en_US	title	Note on the independent Roman domination number of a graph	string
526	en_US	cleanTitle	Note on the independent Roman domination number of a graph	string
526	en_US	abstract	A Roman dominating function (RDF) on a graph $G$ is a function $%<br />f:V(G)\\rightarrow \\{0,1,2\\}$ satisfying the condition that every<br />vertex $u$ for which $f(u)=0$ is adjacent to at least one vertex<br />$v$ for which $f(v)=2$. The weight of a Roman dominating function is the value $f(V(G))=\\sum_{u%<br />\\in V(G)}f(u)$. The Roman domination number, $\\gamma_{R}(G)$, of<br />$G$ is the minimum weight of a Roman dominating function on $G$.<br />An RDF $f=(V_0, V_1, V_2)$ is called an independent Roman<br />dominating function if the set $V_1 \\cup V_2$ is an independent<br />set. The independent Roman domination number, $i_{R}(G)$, of $G$<br />is the minimum weight of an independent RDF on $G$. In this<br />paper, we improve some previous bounds on the independent Roman<br />domination number of a graph.	string

527	en_US	title	Polarity graphs revisited	string
527	en_US	cleanTitle	Polarity graphs revisited	string
527	en_US	abstract	<p>Polarity graphs, also known as Brown graphs, and their minor modifications are the largest currently known graphs of diameter <span class="math">2</span> and a given maximum degree <span class="math"><em>d</em></span> such that <span class="math"><em>d</em> − 1</span> is a prime power larger than <span class="math">5</span>. In view of the recent interest in the degree-diameter problem restricted to vertex-transitive and Cayley graphs we investigate ways of turning the (non-regular) polarity graphs to large <span><em>vertex-transitive</em></span> graphs of diameter <span class="math">2</span> and given degree.</p><p>We review certain properties of polarity graphs, giving new and shorter proofs. Then we show that polarity graphs of maximum even degree <span class="math"><em>d</em></span> cannot be spanning subgraphs of vertex-transitive graphs of degree at most <span class="math"><em>d</em> + 2</span>. If <span class="math"><em>d</em> − 1</span> is a power of <span class="math">2</span>, there are two large vertex-transitive induced subgraphs of the corresponding polarity graph, one of degree <span class="math"><em>d</em> − 1</span> and the other of degree <span class="math"><em>d</em> − 2</span>. We show that the subgraphs of degree <span class="math"><em>d</em> − 1</span> cannot be extended to vertex-transitive graphs of diameter <span class="math">2</span> by adding a relatively small non-edge orbital. On the positive side, we prove that the subgraphs of degree <span class="math"><em>d</em> − 2</span> can be extended to the largest currently known Cayley graphs of given degree and diameter <span class="math">2</span> found by Šiagiová and the second author [<em>J. Combin. Theory Ser. B</em> <strong>102</strong> (2012), 470–473].</p>	string

529	en_US	title	The Zagreb indices of bipartite graphs with more edges	string
529	en_US	cleanTitle	The Zagreb indices of bipartite graphs with more edges	string
529	en_US	abstract	For a (molecular) graph, the first and second  Zagreb indices ($M_1$ and $M_2$) are two well-known topological indices, first introduced in 1972 by Gutman and Trinajsti\\'{c}. The first Zagreb index $M_1$ is equal to the sum of the squares of the degree of the vertices, and the second Zagreb index $M_2$ is equal to the sum of the products of the degrees of pairs of adjacent vertices. Let ${\\cal{K}}_{n_1,n_2}^p$ with $n_1\\leq n_2$, $n_1+n_2=n$ and $p&lt;n_1$ be the set of bipartite graphs obtained by deleting $p$ edges from complete bipartite graph $K_{n_1,n_2}$.<br />In this paper, we determine  sharp upper and lower bounds on Zagreb indices of graphs from ${\\cal{K}}_{n_1,n_2}^p$ and characterized the corresponding extremal graphs at which the upper and lower bounds on Zagreb indices are attained. As a corollary, we can determine the extremal graph from ${\\cal{K}}_{n_1,n_2}^p$ with respect to Zagreb coindices. Moreover a problem has been proposed on the first and second Zagreb indices.	string

530	en_US	abstract	<p>We give the general form of the Tutte polynomial of a fam-<br />ily of positive-signed connected planar graphs. Then we give general formulas of the Jones polynomial of some very interesting families of alternating knots and links that correspond to these planar graphs as a specialization of the Tutte olynomial. 532	en_US	abstract	<p>The Merrifield-Simmons index of a graph $G$, denoted by<br />$i(G)$, is defined to be the total number of independent sets in<br />$G$, including the empty set. A connected graph is called a<br />unicyclic graph, if it possesses equal number of vertices and edges. In this paper, we characterize the maximal unicyclic graph w.r.t. $i(G)$ within all unicyclic graphs with given order and number of cut vertices. 534	en_US	title	Unstable graphs: A fresh outlook via TF-automorphisms	string
534	en_US	cleanTitle	Unstable graphs: A fresh outlook via TFautomorphisms	string
534	en_US	abstract	In this paper, we first establish the very close link between stability of graphs, a concept first introduced by Marušič, Scapellato and Zagaglia Salvi and studied most notably by Surowski and Wilson, and two-fold automorphisms. The concept of two-fold isomorphisms, as far as we know, first appeared in Zelinka’s work on isotopies of digraphs and later studied formally by the authors with a greater emphasis on undirected graphs. We then turn our attention to the stability of graphs which have every edge on a triangle, but with the fresh outlook provided by TF-automorphisms. Amongst such graphs are strongly regular graphs with certain parameters. The advantages of this fresh outlook are highlighted when we ultimately present a method of constructing and generating unstable graphs with large diameter having every edge lying on a triangle. This was a rather surprising outcome.	string

536	en_US	cleanTitle	The kmetric dimension of a graph	string
536	en_US	abstract	<span style="color: #000000;">As a generalization of the concept of metric basis, this article introduces the notion of </span><span style="color: #008000;">$k$</span><span style="color: #000000;">-metric basis in graphs. Given a connected graph </span><span style="color: #008000;">$G=(V,E)$</span><span style="color: #000000;">, a set </span><span style="color: #008000;">$S\\subseteq V$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> is said to be a </span><span style="color: #008000;">$k$</span><span style="color: #000000;">-metric generator for </span><span style="color: #008000;">$G$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> if the elements of any pair of vertices of </span><span style="color: #008000;">$G$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> are distinguished by at least </span><span style="color: #008000;">$k$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> elements of </span><span style="color: #008000;">$S$</span><span style="color: #000000;">, {</span><span style="color: #800000;">\\em</span><span style="color: #000000;"> i.e.}, for any two different vertices </span><span style="color: #008000;">$u,v\\in V$</span><span style="color: #000000;">, there exist at least </span><span style="color: #008000;">$k$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> vertices </span><span style="color: #008000;">$w_1,w_2,...,w_k\\in S$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> such that </span><span style="color: #008000;">$d_G(u,w_i)\\ne d_G(v,w_i)$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> for every </span><span style="color: #008000;">$i\\in \\{1,...,k\\}$</span><span style="color: #000000;">. A metric generator of minimum cardinality is called a </span><span style="color: #008000;">$k$</span><span style="color: #000000;">-metric basis and its cardinality the </span><span style="color: #008000;">$k$</span><span style="color: #000000;">-metric dimension of </span><span style="color: #008000;">$G$</span><span style="color: #000000;">. A connected graph </span><span style="color: #008000;">$G$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> is </span><span style="color: #800000;">\\emph</span><span style="color: #000000;">{</span><span style="color: #008000;">$k$</span><span style="color: #000000;">-metric dimensional} if </span><span style="color: #008000;">$k$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> is the largest integer such that there exists a </span><span style="color: #008000;">$k$</span><span style="color: #000000;">-metric basis for </span><span style="color: #008000;">$G$</span><span style="color: #000000;">. We give a necessary and sufficient condition for a graph to be </span><span style="color: #008000;">$k$</span><span style="color: #000000;">-metric dimensional and we obtain several results on the </span><span style="color: #008000;">$k$</span><span style="color: #000000;">-metric dimension.</span>	string

538	en_US	title	Iterated claws have real-rooted genus polynomials	string
538	en_US	cleanTitle	Iterated claws have realrooted genus polynomials	string
538	en_US	abstract	<p>We prove that the genus polynomials of the graphs called <em>iterated claws</em> are real-rooted. This continues our work directed toward the 25-year-old conjecture that the genus distribution of every graph is log-concave. We have previously established log-concavity for sequences of graphs constructed by iterative vertex-amalgamation or iterative edge-amalgamation of graphs that satisfy a commonly observable condition on their partitioned genus distributions, even though it had been proved previously that iterative amalgamation does not always preserve real-rootedness of the genus polynomial of the iterated graph. In this paper, the iterated topological operation is adding a claw, rather than vertex- or edge-amalgamation. Our analysis here illustrates some advantages of employing a matrix representation of the transposition of a set of productions.</p>	string

541	en_US	title	Chamfering operation on k-orbit maps	string
541	en_US	cleanTitle	Chamfering operation on korbit maps	string
541	en_US	abstract	A map, as a 2-cell embedding of a graph on a closed surface, is called a <em>k</em>-orbit map if the group of automorphisms (or symmetries) of the map partitions its set of flags into k orbits. Orbanić, Pellicer and Weiss studied the effects of operations as medial and truncation on <em>k</em>-orbit maps. In this paper we study the possible symmetry types of maps that result from other maps after applying the chamfering operation and we give the number of possible flag-orbits that has the chamfering map of a <em>k</em>-orbit map, even if we repeat this operation <em>t</em> times.	string

548	en_US	title	Star coloring of Cartesian product of paths and cycles	string
548	en_US	cleanTitle	Star coloring of Cartesian product of paths and cycles	string
548	en_US	abstract	A star coloring of an undirected graph $G$ is a proper vertex coloring of $G$ such that any path on four vertices in $G$ is not bicolored.<br />The star chromatic number  $\\chi_s(G)$ of an undirected graph $G$ is the smallest integer $k$ for which $G$ admits a star coloring with $k$ colors.<br />In this paper,   the star chromatic numbers for some infinite subgraphs of Cartesian product of paths and cycles  are<br />established. In particular, we show that  $\\chi_s(P_{i} \\Box C_j) = 5$ for $i,j \\geq 4$ and $\\chi_s(C_{i} \\Box C_j) = 5$ for $i,j \\geq 30$.<br />We also determine the  star chromatic number of Cartesian product of three paths, and show that $\\chi_s(C_{3} \\Box C_3 \\Box C_k) = 7$ for $k \\geq 3$,<br />$\\chi_s(C_{4i} \\Box C_{4j} \\Box C_{4k}  \\Box C_{4\\ell}) \\leq 9$ for $i,j,k,\\ell \\geq 1$ and the star chromatic numbers of $d$-dimensional hypercubes with $d$ at most 6 are given.	string
