549	en_US	title	Advanced Clever Greedy: A New, Better and Faster Approximation algorithm for the Minimum vertex cover	string
549	en_US	cleanTitle	Advanced Clever Greedy: A New Better and Faster Approximation algorithm for the Minimum vertex cover	string
549	en_US	abstract	<p align="left">Minimum Vertex cover (MVC) is a well-known NP-Complete problem and due to its</p><p align="left">applications in solving a large number of real world problems, various approximation methods</p><p align="left">have been developed by researchers for solving it. In this article, we have provided a</p><p align="left">detailed literature review of existing well-known approximation algorithms and have also</p><p align="left">proposed a new and fast polynomial time algorithm for the approximation of MVC. The</p><p align="left">algorithm’s design is based on the optimized analysis of the relationships between different</p><p align="left">vertices. In our approach, we divide the vertices into two disjoint sets and then identify</p><p align="left">those nodes that have a high probability of emerging as candidates for MVC. Extensive empirical</p><p align="left">evaluation has been carried out for the proposed algorithm using the best available</p><p align="left">benchmarks. We have compared our approach with the other well-known Approximation</p><p align="left">Algorithms for the MVC and have taken into account both computational complexity and</p><p align="left">Approximation ratio factors. Our algorithm outperforms the other well-known approximation</p><p align="left">algorithms and the worst approximation ratio received after applying different benchmarks</p><p align="left">is 1.0256. We have also applied our algorithm for finding the approximate solutions</p><p align="left">to the maximum clique and maximum independent set on different benchmarks and have</p><p>provided the results</p>	string

550	en_US	abstract	<div class="column"><p><span>By a graph we mean a finite connected multigraph without bridges. The genus of a graph is the dimension of its homology group. Two graphs are isospectral is they share the same Laplacian spectrum. We prove that two genus two graphs are isospectral if and only if they are isomorphic. 557	en_US	abstract	<p>We present some new discoveries about graphs that are half-arc-transitive (that is, vertex- and edge-transitive but not arc-transitive). These include the recent discovery of the smallest half-arc-transitive 4-valent graph with vertex-stabiliser of order 4, and the smallest with vertex-stabiliser of order 8, two new half-arc-transitive 4-valent graphs with dihedral vertex-stabiliser <em>D</em><sub>4</sub> (of order 8), and the first known half-arc-transitive 4-valent graph with vertex-stabiliser of order 16 that is neither abelian nor dihedral. 558	en_US	title	Linear completely recursive (LCR) sequences	string
558	en_US	cleanTitle	Linear completely recursive LCR sequences	string
558	en_US	abstract	Linear recursive sequences such as the Fibonacci sequence have been known and studied for centuries.  There is an extensive literature on them, yet almost all of it concerns sequences that use only a fixed number $N$ of the previous sequence members.  Here, linear sequences that are recursive back to the very first sequence item are discussed; they are referred to as \\emph{linear completely recursive} (LCR) sequences.  Many of them converge, so theorems showing some necessary and sufficient conditions for convergence are proven.  For divergent sequences, a method for converting them into a product of a growth function and a convergent LCR sequence is shown, followed by asymptotic results when combining multiple sequences.  The discussion closes with a set of examples using LCR sequences to solve various problems, often in ways that are easier than the traditional methods.	string

561	en_US	title	What can Wikipedia and Google tell us about stock prices under different market regimes?	string
561	en_US	cleanTitle	What can Wikipedia and Google tell us about stock prices under different market regimes	string
561	en_US	abstract	<p>In less than five years a surprisingly high level of attention has built up in the possible connection between internet search data and stock prices. It is the main aim of this paper to point out how this connection may depend heavily on different regimes of the market, i.e. the bear market vs. the bull market. We consider three types of internet search data (relative Google search frequencies of company tickers, relative Google search frequencies of company names and page visits of Wikipedia articles about individual companies) and a substantial sample of companies which are members of the S&amp;P 500 index. We discover two inverse patterns in stock prices: in the bear market what we propose to term a "merry frown" and in bull market a "sour smile", both clearly seen especially for the Wikipedia data. We propose market neutral strategies that exploit these new patterns and yield up to 17% in average annual return during our sample period from 2008 to 2013.</p>	string

564	en_US	abstract	A graph is 1-planar if it can be drawn in the plane such that every edge crosses at most one other edge. A connected graph H is strongly light in a family of graphs G, if there exists a constant lambda, such that every graph G in G contains a subgraph K isomorphic to H with deg_G (v) &lt;= lambda for all v in V(K). In this paper, we present some strongly light subgraphs in the family of 1-planar graphs with minimum degree 7.	string

566	en_US	abstract	We use a similar techique as in M. Kosters, The subset problem for finite abelian groups, <em>J. Combin. Theory Ser. 572	en_US	abstract	\\begin{abstract} The group $\\overline{G} = 2^6{:}A_8$ is an inertia factor group of $2^8{:}O_8^+(2)$. In the first method, we use combinatorics and the natural action of $A_8$ on $W\\cong 2^6$. In the second method, we use a computational method to construct $\\overline{G}=N{:}A_8$ inside $O_8^+(2)$. 574	en_US	title	Packing and covering the balanced complete bipartite multigraph with cycles and stars	string
574	en_US	cleanTitle	Packing and covering the balanced complete bipartite multigraph with cycles and stars	string
574	en_US	abstract	Let $C_k$ denote a cycle of length $k$ and let $S_k$ denote a star with $k$ edges. For multigraphs $F$, $G$ and $H$, an $(F,G)$-decomposition of $H$ is an edge decomposition of $H$ into copies of $F$ and $G$ using at least one of each. For $L\\subseteq H$ and $R\\subseteq rH$, an $(F,G)$-packing (resp. $(F,G)$-covering) of $H$ with leave $L$ (resp. padding $R$) is an $(F,G)$-decomposition of $H-E(L)$ (resp. H+E(R)). An $(F,G)$-packing (resp. $(F,G)$-covering) of $H$ with the largest (resp. smallest) cardinality is a maximum $(F,G)$-packing (resp. minimum $(F,G)$-covering), and its cardinality is referred to as the $(F,G)$-packing number (resp. $(F,G)$-covering number) of $H$. In this paper, we determine the packing number and the covering number of $\\lambda K_{n,n}$ with $C_k$'s and $S_k$'s for any $\\lambda$, $n$ and $k$, and give the complete solution of the maximum packing and the minimum covering of $\\lambda K_{n,n}$ with $4$-cycles and $4$-stars for any $\\lambda$ and $n$ with all possible leaves and paddings.	string

576	en_US	title	Odd edge coloring of graphs	string
576	en_US	cleanTitle	Odd edge coloring of graphs	string
576	en_US	abstract	<p>An edge coloring of a graph G is said to be an odd edge coloring if for each vertex v of G and each color c, the vertex v uses the color c an odd number of times or does not use it at all. In [5], Pyber proved that 4 colors suffice for an odd edge coloring of any simple graph. Recently, some results on this type of colorings of (multi)graphs were successfully applied in solving a problem of facial parity edge coloring [3, 2]. In this paper we present additional results, namely we prove that 6 colors suffice for an odd edge coloring of any loopless connected (multi)graph, provide examples showing that this upper bound is sharp and characterize the family of loopless connected (multi)graphs for which the bound 6 is achieved. We also pose several open problems.</p>	string

583	en_US	abstract	<p>A signed graph (or sigraph in short) is an ordered pair S = (G, ), where G is a<br />graph G = (V,E) and  : E ! {+, −} is a function from the edge set E of G into the<br />set {+, −}. For a positive integer n &gt; 1, the unitary addition Cayley graph Gn is the<br />graph whose vertex set is Zn, the integers modulo n and if Un denotes set of all units of<br />the ring Zn, then two vertices a, b are adjacent if and only if a+b 2 Un. Four different<br />unitary addition Cayley sigraph on unitary addition Cayley graph Gn denoted by _n ,<br />^n , n and ¯_n have been defined (see [47]), by assigning the signs to the edges of<br />Gn by a certain rule. In this paper, we have obtained a characterization of balanced<br />and clusterable unitary addition Cayley ring sigraph n . 584	en_US	title	Alternating plane graphs	string
584	en_US	cleanTitle	Alternating plane graphs	string
584	en_US	abstract	<p>A plane graph is called alternating if all adjacent vertices have different degrees, and all neighboring faces as well. Alternating plane graphs were introduced in 2008. This paper presents the previous research on alternating plane graphs.</p><p>There are two smallest alternating plane graphs, having 17 vertices and 17 faces each. There is no alternating plane graph with 18 vertices, but alternating plane graphs exist for all cardinalities from 19 on. From a small set of initial building blocks, alternating plane graphs can be constructed for all large cardinalities. Many of the small alternating plane graphs have been found with extensive computer help.</p><p>Theoretical results on alternating plane graphs are included where all degrees have to be from the set {3,4,5}. In addition, several classes of “weak alternating plane graphs” (with vertices of degree 2) are presented.</p>	string

588	en_US	title	A note on the $3$-rainbow index of complete bipartite graphs	string
588	en_US	cleanTitle	A note on the 3rainbow index of complete bipartite graphs	string
588	en_US	abstract	A tree $T$, in an edge-colored  graph $G$, is called {\\em a rainbow tree} if no two edges of $T$ are assigned the same color. For a vertex<br />subset $S\\in V(G)$, a tree that connects $S$ in $G$ is called an $S$-tree. A  {\\em $k$-rainbow coloring } of $G$ is an edge coloring of $G$ having the property that for every set $S$ of $k$ vertices of $G$, there exists a rainbow $S$-tree $T$ in $G$. The minimum number of colors needed in a $k$-rainbow coloring of $G$ is the {\\em $k$-rainbow  index of $G$}, denoted by $rx_k(G)$.  It is NP-hard to compute  the $rx_k(G)$ for the general graphs $G$. We consider the 3-rainbow index of complete bipartite graphs $K_{s,t}$. For $3\\leq s\\leq t$, we have determined the tight bounds of $rx_3(K_{s,t})$. In this paper,  we continue the study. For $2=s\\leq t$, we develop a converse idea and apply with the model of chessboard to study the problem. And we obtain the exact value of $rx_3(K_{s,t})$ with $2=s\\leq t$.	string

591	en_US	title	On global location-domination in graphs	string
591	en_US	cleanTitle	On global locationdomination in graphs	string
591	en_US	abstract	<p>A dominating set S of a graph G is called locating-dominating, LD-set for short, if every vertex v not in S is uniquely determined by the set of neighbors of v belonging to S. Locating-dominating sets of minimum cardinality are called LD-codes and the cardinality of an LD-code is the location-domination number lambda(G). An LD-set S of a graph G is  global if it is an LD-set of both G and its complement G'. The global location-domination number lambda g(G) is introduced as  the minimum cardinality of a global LD-set of G.</p><p>In this paper, some general relations between  LD-codes and the location-domination number in a graph and its complement are presented first. <br />Next, a number of basic properties involving the global location-domination number are showed. Finally, both parameters are studied in-depth for the family of block-cactus graphs.</p>	string

592	en_US	cleanTitle	Minimal Faithful UpperTriangular Matrix Representations for Solvable Lie Algebras	string
592	en_US	abstract	<p>A well-known result on Lie Theory states that every finite-dimensional complex solvable Lie algebra can be represented as a matrix Lie algebra, with upper-triangular square matrices as elements. However, this result does not specify which is the minimal order of the matrices involved in such representations. Hence, the main goal of this paper is to revisit and implement a method to compute both that minimal order and a matrix representative for a given solvable Lie algebra. As application of this procedure, we compute representatives for each solvable Lie algebra with dimension less than 6.</p>	string

598	en_US	title	A LEFT TOPOLOGICAL MONOID ASSOCIATED TO A TOPOLOGICAL GROUPOID	string
598	en_US	cleanTitle	A LEFT TOPOLOGICAL MONOID ASSOCIATED TO A TOPOLOGICAL GROUPOID	string
598	en_US	abstract	<p> A monoid  $S_G$ is related to a topological groupoid $G$, which precisely consists of the continuous functions $f:G\\rightarrow G$ such that the graph of $f$ is a subset of $G^2$, the set of all composable pairs.  The monoid $S_G$  with the compact- open topology  is a left topological monoid.<br />        The group of units of $S_G$ which is denoted by $H(d)$ is characterized. It is shown that $S_G$ acts on the left of $G$. By using this action each element $f\\in S_G$ is represented by a linear operator $L_f$ on $C(G)$, the set of all complex continuous function on $G$. Also by this representation $H(d)$ is embedded in the group of all invertible linear operators on $C(G)$.</p><p> </p>	string

599	en_US	title	Cayley graphs of order 3p where p is an odd prime	string
599	en_US	cleanTitle	Cayley graphs of order 3p where p is an odd prime	string
599	en_US	abstract	<p>In this article we will determine all the tetravalent Cayley graphs of order 3p, where p is a prime number. We also study the edge and arc transitivity of those graphs.</p><p>Our main result in this paper is the following:</p><p><strong> Main Theorem</strong>: Let G be a non-abelian group of order3p, p an odd prime. If p≠7, then up to equivalence there are two inverse closed subsets S and T of G, 1∉S and 1∉T of size 4 and in both cases Cay(G,S) and Cay(G,T) are normal Cayley graphs. If p=7, then there are two tetravalent Cayley graphs Cay(G,S), where S=S^(-1)and 1∉S, such that one of them is normal and the other is non-normal.</p>	string

600	en_US	title	Levels in bargraphs	string
600	en_US	cleanTitle	Levels in bargraphs	string
600	en_US	abstract	Bargraphs are lattice paths in N_0^2, which start at the origin and terminate immediately upon return to the x-axis. The allowed steps are the up step (0,1), the down step (0,-1) and the horizontal step (1,0). The first step is an up step and the horizontal steps must all lie above the x-axis. An up step cannot follow a down step and vice versa. In this paper we consider levels, which are maximal sequences of two or more adjacent horizontal steps. We find the generating functions that count the total number of levels, the leftmost x-coordinate and the height of the first level and obtain the generating function for the mean of these parameters. Finally, we obtain the asymptotics of these means as the length of the path tends to infinity.	string

612	en_US	abstract	<p>A simple graph $G$ is called a compact graph if $G$ contains no isolated<br />vertices and for each pair $x, y$ of non-adjacent vertices of $G$, there is a vertex $z$ with $N(x)\\cup N(y)\\subseteq N(z)$, where $N(v)$ is<br />the neighborhood of $v$, for every vertex $v$ of $G$. 613	en_US	title	On D-equivalence class of friendship graphs	string
613	en_US	cleanTitle	On Dequivalence class of friendship graphs	string
613	en_US	abstract	Let $G$ be a simple graph of order $n$.<br />The domination polynomial of $G$ is the polynomial<br />$D(G, x)=\\sum_{i=\\gamma(G)}^{n} d(G,i) x^{i}$,<br />where $d(G,i)$ is the number of dominating sets of $G$ of size $i$ and $\\gamma(G)$ is the domination number of $G$. A root of $D(G, x)$ is called a domination root of $G$. Two graphs $G$ and $H$ are said to be $\\mathcal{D}$-equivalent,<br />written $G \\sim  H$, if $D(G, x) = D(H, x)$. The $\\mathcal{D}$-equivalence class of $G$ is<br />$[G] = \\{H : H\\sim G\\}.$<br /> A graph $G$ is said to be $\\mathcal{D}$-unique, if $[G] = \\{G\\}$.<br />Let $n$ be any positive integer and  $F_n$ be Dutch-Windmill,  or friendship graph with<br />$2n + 1$ vertices and $3n$ edges. We prove that for every $n$, $F_n$ is not $\\mathcal{D}$-unique.  Also we<br />study the domination roots of $F_n$ and some families of graphs related to $F_n$.	string

615	en_US	title	On the strong metric dimension of Cartesian sum graphs	string
615	en_US	cleanTitle	On the strong metric dimension of Cartesian sum graphs	string
615	en_US	abstract	A vertex $w$ of a connected graph $G$ strongly resolves two vertices $u,v\\in V(G)$, if there exists some shortest $u-w$ path containing $v$ or some shortest $v-w$ path containing $u$. A set $S$ of vertices is a strong metric generator for $G$ if every pair of vertices of $G$ is strongly resolved by some vertex of $S$. The smallest cardinality of a strong metric generator for $G$ is called the strong metric dimension of $G$. In this paper we obtain several tight bounds or closed formulaes for the strong metric dimension of the Cartesian sum of graphs in terms of the strong metric dimension, clique number or twins-free clique number of its factor graphs.	string

617	en_US	title	Irreducibility of configurations	string
617	en_US	cleanTitle	Irreducibility of configurations	string
617	en_US	abstract	<p>In a paper from 1886, Martinetti enumerated small v_3-configurations. One of his tools was a construction that permits to produce a (v+1)_3-configuration from a v_3-configuration. He called configurations that were not constructible in this way irreducible configurations. According to his definition, the irreducible configurations are Pappus' configuration and four infinite families of configurations. In 2005, Boben defined a simpler and more general definition of irreducibility, for which only two v_3-configurations, the Fano plane and Pappus' configuration, remained irreducible. The present article gives a generalization of Boben's reduction for both balanced and unbalanced (v_r,b_k)-configurations, and proves several general results on augmentability and reducibility. Motivation for this work is found, for example, in the counting and enumeration of configurations.</p>	string

622	en_US	abstract	For a simple graph G=(V,E), a vertex labeling  $\\phi: V  \\rightarrow \\{1, 2,\\dots k\\}$ is called $k$-labeling. The weight of an edge $xy$ in $G$, denoted by $w_\\phi(xy)$, is the sum of the labels of end vertices $x$ and $y$, i.e $w_\\phi(xy)=\\phi(x)+\\phi(y)$.  A vertex  $k$-labeling is defined to be an edge irregular $k$-labeling of the graph $G$ if for every two different edges $e$ and $f$ there is  $w_\\phi(e) \\ne w_\\phi(f)$. The minimum $k$ for which the graph $G$ has an edge irregular $k$-labeling is called the edge irregularity strength of $G$, denoted by $es(G)$.<br /><br />In this paper, we estimate the bounds of the edge irregularity strength and determine the exact value for several families of graphs.	string

626	en_US	title	Regular embeddings of cycles with multiple edges revisited	string
626	en_US	cleanTitle	Regular embeddings of cycles with multiple edges revisited	string
626	en_US	abstract	<div class="page" title="Page 1"><div class="layoutArea"><div class="column"><p>Regular embeddings of cycles with multiple edges have been reappearing in the literature for quite some time, both in and outside topological graph theory. The present paper aims to draw a complete picture of these maps by providing a detailed description, classification, and enumeration of regular embeddings of cycles with multiple edges on both orientable and non-orientable surfaces. Most of the results have been known in one form or another, but here they are presented from a unique viewpoint based on finite group theory. Our approach brings additional information about both the maps and their automorphism groups, and also gives extra insight into their relationships.</p></div></div></div>	string

627	en_US	title	On the spread of influence in graphs with probabilistic thresholds	string
627	en_US	cleanTitle	On the spread of influence in graphs with probabilistic thresholds	string
627	en_US	abstract	Let $G$ be a graph and ${\\mathcal{\\tau}}$ be an assignment of non-negative thresholds to the vertices of $G$. A subset of vertices, $D$, is said to be an irreversible dynamic monopoly of $(G, \\tau)$ if the vertices of $G$ can be partitioned into subsets $D_0, D_1, \\ldots, D_k$ such that $D_0=D$ and for all $i\\in \\{0, \\ldots, k-1\\}$, each vertex $v$ in $D_{i+1}$ has at least $\\tau(v)$ neighbors in $D_0\\cup \\ldots \\cup D_i$. Dynamic monopolies are in fact modeling the spread of influence or propagation of opinion in social networks, where the graph $G$ represents the underlying network. The smallest cardinality of any dynamic monopoly of $(G,\\tau)$ is denoted by $dyn_{\\tau}(G)$. In this paper we assume that the threshold of each vertex $v$ of the network is a random variable $X_v$ such that $0\\leq X_v \\leq deg_G(v)+1$. Let $X=(X_v)_{v\\in G}$. Given $(G,X)$, the probabilistic version of $dyn_{\\tau}(G)$ is defined and denoted by $dyn_X(G)$. We first obtain a concentration result for $dyn_X(G)$ around its mean value. Next, an upper bound for $\\Bbb{E}(dyn_X(G))$ and using the previous concentration result, another upper bound for $dyn_X(G)$ are obtained. We show the sharpness of these bounds.<br />In the rest of the paper we obtain some lower bounds for the size of dynamic monopolies in $(G,X)$ in terms of $|G|$ and ${\\sum}_{v\\in G} \\Bbb{E}(X(v))/|G|$. In particular, let $\\{(G_{n},X_n)\\}_{n=1}^{\\infty}$ be any sequence of graphs with probabilistic thresholds such that $|G_n|=n$. We obtain the least conditions under which there exists some positive constant $\\lambda$ such that $dyn_{X_n}(G_{n})\\geq \\lambda n$, with high probability.	string
627	en_US	discipline		string
627	en_US	subjectClass		string
627	en_US	subject		string
627	en_US	sponsor		string
628	en_US	title	Component factors of the Cartesian product of graphs	string
628	en_US	cleanTitle	Component factors of the Cartesian product of graphs	string
628	en_US	abstract	Let A be a family of connected graphs. A spanning subgraph H of<br />G is called an A-factor (component factor) of G if each component of H<br />is in A. In this paper, we study the component factors of the Cartesian<br />product of graphs. Here, we take A = {K1,n,C4} and show that every<br />connected graph G ∼=<br />H1H2 has a {K1,n,C4}-factor where n 6 t and t is<br />the maximum degree of an induced subgraph K1,t in H1 or H2. Also, we<br />characterize graphs G ∼=<br />H1H2 having a C4-factor.	string
628	en_US	discipline		string
628	en_US	subjectClass	05C76	string
628	en_US	subject	Component factors, Cartesian Product	string
628	en_US	sponsor		string
630	en_US	title	Strong Permutations and Triangle Labelings	string
630	en_US	cleanTitle	Strong Permutations and Triangle Labelings	string
630	en_US	abstract	A permutation $\\sigma$ on an integer interval $\\{a,a+1,\\cdots,a+m-1\\}$ is called strong if either $\\{\\sigma(i)-i\\}_{i=a}^{a+m-1}$ or $\\{\\sigma(i)+i\\}_{i=a}^{a+m-1}$ has maximal number of elements. Well-known instances of strong permutations are complete and additive permutations. For any integer $c&gt;0$, a $c$-Erd\\"{o}sian triangle labeling $\\phi$ of the graph $GT_m=(V_m,E_m)$ consisting $m$ disjoint triangles is a bijective map $\\phi:V_m\\cup E_m\\to\\{c,c+1,\\dots,c+6m-1\\}$ with the property that $\\phi(x)+\\phi(y)=\\phi(xy)$ for any vertices $x,y\\in V_m$ forming the edge $xy\\in E_m$. In this article, the connection of strong permutations to $c$-Erd\\"{o}sian triangle labelings is exhibited, where some classes of $c$-Erd\\"{o}sian triangle labelings are shown arising from strong permutations and, conversely, some of these permutations are characterized through the $c$-Erd\\"{o}sian triangle labelings.	string
630	en_US	discipline	Mathematics; Combinatorics; Labelings	string
630	en_US	subjectClass	05A05, 05C78	string
630	en_US	subject	strong permutation, graph labeling, magic labeling	string

631	en_US	title	Arc-transitive abelian regular covering graphs	string
631	en_US	cleanTitle	Arctransitive abelian regular covering graphs	string
631	en_US	abstract	<div class="page" title="Page 1"><div class="layoutArea"><div class="column"><p><span>A lot of attention has been paid recently to the construction of symmetric covers of symmetric graphs. After a new approach given by Conder and the author [M. Conder and J. Ma, Arc-transitive abelian regular covers of cubic graphs, </span><span>J. Algebra</span><span>, 387 (2013) 215–242], the group of covering transformations can be extended to more general abelian groups rather than cyclic or elementary abelian groups. In this paper, by using the Conder-Ma approach, we investigate the symmetric covers of 4-valent symmetric graphs. As an application, all the arc-transitive abelian regular covers of the 4-valent complete graph $</span><span>K_</span><span>5$ </span><span>which can be obtained by lifting the arc-transitive subgroups of automorphisms $</span><span>A_</span><span>5$ </span><span>and AGL(1</span><span>, </span><span>5) are classified. </span></p></div></div></div>	string

634	en_US	title	On real forms of a Belyi action of alternating groups	string
634	en_US	cleanTitle	On real forms of a Belyi action of alternating groups	string
634	en_US	abstract	<p>In virtue of the Belyi Theorem a complex algebraic curve can be defined over the algebraic numbers if and only if the<br />corresponding Riemann surface can be uniformized by a subgroup of a Fuchsian triangle group. Such surfaces are<br />known as Belyi surfaces. Here we study certain natural actions of the alternating groups ${\\rm A}_n$ on them.<br />We show that they are symmetric and we calculate the number of connected components, called<br />ovals, of the corresponding real forms. It will be obvious that all symmetries with ovals are conjugate and we<br />shall calculate the number of purely imaginary real forms both in case of ${\\rm A}_n$ considered here and ${\\rm S}_n$<br />considered in an earlier paper of the last three authors.</p>	string

636	en_US	title	The linear arboricity of planar graphs with 7-cycles containing at most two chords	string
636	en_US	cleanTitle	The linear arboricity of planar graphs with 7cycles containing at most two chords	string
636	en_US	abstract	The linear arboricity $la(G)$ of a graph $G$ is the minimum number of linear forests which partition the edges of $G$. In this paper, it is proved that if $G$ is a planar graph with maximum degree $\\Delta\\geq7$ and every 7-cycle of $G$ contains at most two chords, then $la(G)=\\lceil\\frac{\\Delta(G)}{2}\\rceil$.	string

637	en_US	title	On strong metric dimension of lexicographic product of graphs	string
637	en_US	cleanTitle	On strong metric dimension of lexicographic product of graphs	string
637	en_US	abstract	<p>A vertex $w$ \\textit{strongly resolves} a pair of vertices $u$ and $v$ of $G$ if there exists a shortest $(u,w)$ path containing $v$ or a shortest $(v,w)$ path containing $u$. \\ A set of vertices $W$ \\textit{strongly resolves} a graph $G$ if every pair of vertices of $G$ is strongly resolved by some vertices of $W$. \\ The minimum cardinality of a strong resolving set of $G$ is called the \\textit{strong metric dimension} of $G$. \\ The \\textit{lexicographic product} of graph $G$ and $H$, which is denoted by $G\\circ H$, is the graph with vertex set $V\\left( G\\right) \\times V\\left( H\\right) =\\left\\{ \\left( a,v\\right) |a\\in V\\left( G\\right) ,v\\in V\\left( H\\right) \\right\\} $, where $\\left( a,v\\right) $ is adjacent to $\\left( b,w\\right) $ whenever $ab\\in E\\left( G\\right) $, or $a=b$ and $vw\\in E\\left( H\\right) $. \\ In this paper, we determine the general bound of the strong metric dimension of a lexicographic product of a connected graph $G$ and an arbitrary graph $H$. \\ We also prove that the bound is sharp.</p>	string
637	en_US	discipline	Graph Theory; Combinatorics	string

637	en_US	subject	lexicographic product; strong basis; strong metric dimension; strong resolving set	string

638	en_US	title	On the isomorphisms of bi-Cayley graphs	string
638	en_US	cleanTitle	On the isomorphisms of biCayley graphs	string
638	en_US	abstract	‎For a finite group $G$ and a subset $S\\subseteq G$‎, ‎the bi-Cayley graph $\\BCay(G,S)$ of $G$ with ‎respect to $S$ is an undirected graph with ‎vertex set $G\\times\\{1,2\\}$ and edge set $\\{\\{(x,1),(sx,2)\\}\\mid x\\in G‎, ‎\\ s\\in S\\}$‎. ‎A ‎bi-Cayley graph $\\BCay(G,S)$ is called a BCI-graph if for any bi-Cayley graph $\\BCay(G,T)$‎, ‎whenever ‎$\\BCay(G,S)\\cong \\BCay(G,T)$ we have $T=gS^\\alpha$ for some $g\\in G$ and $\\alpha\\in\\Aut(G)$‎. ‎In \\cite{koike} a Babai's type theorem for bi-Cayley graphs of finite cyclic groups is proved‎. ‎In this paper‎, ‎we extend this result to arbitrary groups‎. ‎Also we prove that every group of prime ‎order is a BCI-group and in a BCI-group $G$‎, ‎for each prime $p&gt;3$ dividing the order of $G$ each Sylow $p$-subgroup is elementary abelian‎.	string

639	en_US	title	Complete graphs with zero diagonal inverse	string
639	en_US	cleanTitle	Complete graphs with zero diagonal inverse	string
639	en_US	abstract	If the inverse of a non-singular real symmetric matrix that represents an edge-weighted graph with no loops has zero diagonal, then the inverse itself is the matrix of a loopless graph. Here we show that such graphs having non--zero weight on each edge always exist if their number of vertices is at least 6.	string

640	en_US	title	Associated Lah numbers and r-Stirling numbers	string
640	en_US	cleanTitle	Associated Lah numbers and rStirling numbers	string
640	en_US	abstract	<p>We introduce the associated Lah numbers. Some recurrence relations and convolution identities are established. An extension of the associated Stirling and Lah numbers to the r-Stirling and r-Lah numbers are also given. For all these sequences we give combinatorial interpretation, generating functions, recurrence relations, convolution identities. In the sequel, we develop a section on nested sums related to binomial coecient.</p>	string

642	en_US	title	Quasi-configurations: Building blocks for point-line configurations	string
642	en_US	cleanTitle	Quasiconfigurations: Building blocks for pointline configurations	string
642	en_US	abstract	We study point-line incidence structures and their properties in the projective plane. Our motivation is the problem of the existence of (n_4) configurations, still open for few remaining values of n. Our approach is based on quasi-configurations: point-line incidence structures where each point is incident to at least 3 lines and each line is incident to at least 3 points. We investigate the existence problem for these quasi-configurations, with a particular attention to 3|4-configurations where each element is 3- or 4-valent. We use these quasi-configurations to construct the first (37_4) and (43_4) configurations. The existence problem of finding (22_4), (23_4), and (26_4) configurations remains open.	string

644	en_US	title	Unilateral and equitransitive tilings by squares of four sizes	string
644	en_US	cleanTitle	Unilateral and equitransitive tilings by squares of four sizes	string
644	en_US	abstract	D. Schattschneider proved that there are exactly eight unilateral and equitransitive tilings of the plane by squares of three distinct sizes. This article extends Schattschneider’s methods to determine a classification of all such tilings by squares of four different sizes. It is determined that there are exactly 39 unilateral and equitransitive tilings by squares of four different sizes.	string

649	en_US	title	Application of Simple Graph in Four Color Theorem	string
649	en_US	cleanTitle	Application of Simple Graph in Four Color Theorem	string
649	en_US	abstract	<p>The relationship between the regions in the planar map <em>(genus 0 space) </em>is studied by analysing the edges of the simple graph in two-dimensional space with geometrical constraint lines. It is found that the maximum number of vertices placed on the geometrical constraint lines of two-dimensional space that can form a complete graph is two or three. Therefore for an arbitrary region of the planar map, the number of its bordering regions that are in turn connected (share borders) to each other can only be two or three. This implies that four colors are sufficient to color any planar maps <em>(genus 0 space)</em>.<strong> </strong></p>	string
649	en_US	discipline	Graphs	string

650	en_US	title	On gamma-hyperellipticity of graphs	string
650	en_US	cleanTitle	On gammahyperellipticity of graphs	string
650	en_US	abstract	<p>The basic objects of research in this paper are graphs and their branched coverings. By a graph, we mean a finite connected multigraph. The genus of a graph is defined as the rank of the first homology group. A graph is said to be gamma-hyperelliptic if it is a two fold branched covering of a genus gamma graph. The corresponding covering involution is called gamma-hyperelliptic.</p><p>The aim of the paper is to provide a few criteria for the involution tau acting on a graph X of genus g to be gamma-hyperelliptic. If tau has at least one fixed point then the first criterium states that there is a basis in the homology group H_1(X) whose elements are either invertible or split into gamma interchangeable pairs under the action of tau_*. The second criterium is given by the formula tr_{H_1(X)}, (tau_*) = 2 gamma - g. Similar results are also obtained in the case when tau acts fixed point free.</p>	string

652	en_US	abstract	<!--[if gte mso 9]><xml>\\r\\n <o:OfficeDocumentSettings>\\r\\n  <o:RelyOnVML/>\\r\\n  <o:AllowPNG/>\\r\\n </o:OfficeDocumentSettings>\\r\\n</xml><![endif]--><p class="MsoNormal" style="margin-bottom: .0001pt; text-align: justify; line-height: 200%;"><span style="font-size: 12.0pt; line-height: 200%; font-family: 'Times New Roman','serif'; mso-fareast-font-family: 'Times New Roman'; mso-ansi-language: EN-MY; mso-fareast-language: EN-MY;" lang="EN-MY">The relationship between the regions in the planar map <em style="mso-bidi-font-style: normal;">(genus 0 space) </em>is studied by analysing the edges of the simple graph in two-dimensional space with geometrical constraint lines. 653	en_US	title	Polynomial reconstruction of the matching~polynomial	string
653	en_US	cleanTitle	Polynomial reconstruction of the matching~polynomial	string
653	en_US	abstract	<span style="color: #000000;">The matching polynomial of a graph is the generating function of the numbers of its </span><span style="text-decoration: underline; color: #000000;">matchings</span><span style="color: #000000;"> with respect to their cardinality. A graph polynomial is polynomial </span><span style="text-decoration: underline; color: #000000;">reconstructible</span><span style="color: #000000;">, if its value for a graph can be determined from its values for the vertex-deleted </span><span style="text-decoration: underline; color: #000000;">subgraphs</span><span style="color: #000000;"> of the same graph. This note discusses the polynomial </span><span style="text-decoration: underline; color: #000000;">reconstructibility</span><span style="color: #000000;"> of the matching polynomial. We collect previous results, prove it for graphs with pendant edges and disprove it for some graphs.</span>	string

655	en_US	title	A Solutions for Boundary Value Problem for Fractional Differential Inclusions With Negatively Perturbed Term	string
655	en_US	cleanTitle	A Solutions for Boundary Value Problem for Fractional Differential Inclusions With Negatively Perturbed Term	string
655	en_US	abstract	In this paper, we investigate the existence of solution for<br />boundary value problem with fractional differential<br />inclusions with negatively perturbed term<br />involving the standard Riemann-Liouville<br />fractional derivative of order $\\alpha\\in (1,2]$ .	string
655	en_US	discipline		string

657	en_US	title	Classification of the regular oriented hypermaps with prime number of hyperfaces	string
657	en_US	cleanTitle	Classification of the regular oriented hypermaps with prime number of hyperfaces	string
657	en_US	abstract	<p>Regular oriented hypermaps are triples <em>(G;a,b)</em> consisting of a finite 2-generated group <em>G</em> and a pair <em>a</em>, <em>b</em> of generators of <em>G</em>, where the left cosets of &lt;<em>a</em>&gt;, &lt;<em>b</em>&gt; and &lt;<em>ab</em>&gt; describe respectively the hyperfaces, hypervertices and hyperedges. They generalise regular oriented maps (triples with <em>ab</em> of order 2) and describe cellular embeddings of regular hypergraphs on orientable surfaces. <br />Previously, we have classified the regular oriented hypermaps with a prime number of hyperfaces and with no non-trivial regular proper quotients with the same number of hyperfaces (i.e. primer hypermaps with prime number of hyperfaces), which generalises the classification of regular oriented maps with prime number of faces and underlying simple graph. Now we classify the regular oriented hypermaps with a prime number of hyperfaces. As a result of this classification, we conclude that the regular oriented hypermaps with prime <em>p</em> hyperfaces have metacyclic automorphism groups and the chiral ones have cyclic chirality groups; of these the "canonical metacyclic" (i.e. those for which &lt;<em>a</em>&gt; is normal in <em>G</em>) have chirality index a divisor of <em>n</em> (the hyperface valency) and the non "canonical metacyclic" have chirality index <em>p</em>. We end the paper by counting, for each positive integer <em>n</em> and each prime <em>p</em>, the number of regular oriented hypermaps with <em>p</em> hyperfaces of valency <em>n</em>.</p>	string

657	en_US	subjectClass	05E18, 05E15, 20B25, 05C25, 05C30	string
657	en_US	subject	Hypermaps, maps, hypergraphs, regularity, orientably regular, chirality	string
657	en_US	sponsor	CIDMA	string
658	en_US	title	ASYMPTOTIC AND NONOSCILLATORY BEHAVIOR OF SECOND ORDER NEUTRAL DELAY DIFFERENCE EQUATIONS	string
658	en_US	cleanTitle	ASYMPTOTIC AND NONOSCILLATORY BEHAVIOR OF SECOND ORDER NEUTRAL DELAY DIFFERENCE EQUATIONS	string
658	en_US	abstract	<p>This paper is concerned with the asymptotic behavior for nonoscillatory solutions of the second order neutral delay difference equations of the form </p><p>∆<sup>2</sup>(x<sub>n</sub>+p<sub>i</sub>x<sub>n-τi</sub>-q<sub>j</sub>x<sub>n-σj</sub>)+f(n,x<sub>n-l</sub>)=0. Examples are inserted to illustrate the results.</p>	string

661	en_US	title	Counting of even and odd restricted permutations	string
661	en_US	cleanTitle	Counting of even and odd restricted permutations	string
661	en_US	abstract	<p style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; margin: 0px;"><span>Let </span><span class="math"><em>p</em></span><span> be a </span><span><em>permutation</em></span><span> of the set </span><span class="math">N<sub><em>n</em></sub> = {1, 2, …, <em>n</em>}</span><span>. We introduce techniques for counting </span><span class="math"><em>N</em>(<em>n</em>; <em>k</em>; <em>r</em>; <em>I</em>; <em>π</em>)</span><span>, the number of even or odd restricted permutations of </span><span class="math">N<sub><em>n</em></sub></span><span> satisfying the conditions </span><span class="math"> − <em>k</em> ≤ <em>p</em>(<em>i</em>) − <em>i</em> ≤ <em>r</em></span><span> (for arbitrary natural numbers </span><span class="math"><em>k</em></span><span> and </span><span class="math"><em>r</em></span><span>) and </span><span class="math"><em>p</em>(<em>i</em>) − <em>i</em> ∉ <em>I</em></span><span> (for some set </span><span class="math"><em>I</em></span><span>) and </span><span class="math"><em>π</em> = 0</span><span> for even permutations and </span><span class="math"><em>π</em> = 1</span><span> for odd permutations.</span></p>	string

661	en_US	sponsor		string
664	en_US	title	Degree Monotone Paths	string
664	en_US	cleanTitle	Degree Monotone Paths	string
664	en_US	abstract	<p>We shall study degree monotone paths in graphs, a problem inspired by the celebrated theorem of Erd{\\H{o}}s-Szekeres concerning the longest monotone subsequence of a given sequence of numbers.</p><p> </p><p>A path P in a graph G is said to be a degree monotone path if the sequence of degrees of the vertices in P in the order they appear in P is monotonic.</p><p> </p><p> </p><p>In this paper we shall consider these three problem related to this parameter:</p><p>\\begin{enumerate}</p><p>\\item{ Find bounds on $mp(G)$ in terms of other parameters of $G$.}</p><p>\\item{Study $f(n,k)$ defined to be the maximum number of edges in a graph on $n$ vertices with $mp(G) &lt; k$.}</p><p>\\item{Estimate the minimum and the maximum over all graph $G$ on $n$ vertices of $mp(G)+mp(\\overline{G})$.}</p><p>\\end{enumerate}</p><p> </p><p>For the first problem our main tool will be the Gallai-Roy Theorem on directed paths and chromatic number. We shall also consider in some detail maximal planar and maximal outerplanar graphs in order to investigate the sharpness of the bounds obtained. For the second problem we establish a close link between $f(n,k)$ and the classical Turan numbers. For the third problem we establish some Nordhaus-Gaddum type of inequalities. We conclude by indicating some open problems which our results point to.</p><p> </p>	string
664	en_US	discipline	Combinatorics;Graph Theory	string
664	en_US	subjectClass	05C07; 05C38; 05C10; 05C35	string
664	en_US	subject	graphs; vertex degrees; paths; planarity	string
664	en_US	sponsor		string
665	en_US	title	On automorphism groups of graph truncations	string
665	en_US	cleanTitle	On automorphism groups of graph truncations	string
665	en_US	abstract	<span>It is well known that the Petersen graph, the Coxeter graph, as well as the graphs obtained from these two graphs by replacing each vertex with a triangle, are trivalent vertex-transitive graphs without Hamilton cycles, and are indeed the only known connected vertex-transitive graphs of valency at least two without Hamilton cycles. It is known by many that the replacement of a vertex with a triangle in a trivalent vertex-transitive graph results in a vertex-transitive graph if and only if the original graph is also arc-transitive. In this paper, we generalize this notion to </span><span class="math"><em>t</em></span><span>-regular graphs </span><span class="math">Γ </span><span> and replace each vertex with a complete graph </span><span class="math"><em>K</em><sub><em>t</em></sub></span><span> on </span><span class="math"><em>t</em></span><span> vertices. We determine necessary and sufficient conditions for </span><span class="math"><em>T</em>(Γ)</span><span> to be hamiltonian, show </span><span class="math">Aut(<em>T</em>(Γ)) ≅ Aut(Γ)</span><span>, as well as show that if </span><span class="math">Γ </span><span> is vertex-transitive, then </span><span class="math"><em>T</em>(Γ )</span><span> is vertex-transitive if and only if </span><span class="math">Γ </span><span> is arc-transitive. Finally, in the case where </span><span class="math"><em>t</em></span><span> is prime we determine necessary and sufficient conditions for </span><span class="math"><em>T</em>(Γ)</span><span> to be isomorphic to a Cayley graph as well as an additional necessary and sufficient condition for </span><span class="math"><em>T</em>(Γ)</span><span> to be vertex-transitive.</span>	string

666	en_US	discipline		string

666	en_US	sponsor	nil	string
667	en_US	title	The equalization scheme of the residual voluntary health insurance in Slovenia	string
667	en_US	cleanTitle	The equalization scheme of the residual voluntary health insurance in Slovenia	string
667	en_US	abstract	<p>Residual voluntary health insurance in Slovenia covers the difference between the (recognised) value of the health service and the part of this value that is payed by the compulsory health insurance. From the inception of compulsory health insurance in 1992, residual voluntary health insurance has open enrolment. From 2006 community rating applied, as well as an equalization scheme with which the differences in health services expenses, arising from the different structures of the insurees of the single insurance undertakings regarding age and gender, shall be equalized. The equalization scheme of the residual voluntary health insurance in Slovenia is presented, along with a detailed explanation of the formulae required for the computation.</p>	string

669	en_US	title	Symmetric (45,12,3) designs with nontrivial automorphisms	string
669	en_US	cleanTitle	Symmetric 45123 designs with nontrivial automorphisms	string
669	en_US	abstract	We show that there are exactly 4285 symmetric (45,12,3) designs that admit nontrivial automorphisms.<br />Among them there are 1161 self-dual designs and 1562 pairs of mutually dual designs. <br />We describe the full automorphism groups of these designs and analyze their ternary codes.<br />R. Mathon and E. Spence have constructed 1136 symmetric (45,12,3) designs with trivial automorphism group,<br />which means that there are at least 5421 symmetric (45,12,3) designs.<br />Further, we discuss trigeodetic graphs obtained from the symmetric (45,12,3) designs.<br />We prove that k-geodetic graphs constructed from mutually non-isomorphic designs<br />are mutually non-isomorphic, hence there are at least 5421 mutually non-isomorphis trigeodetic graphs <br />obtained from symmetric (45,12,3) designs.	string

670	en_US	title	On the split structure of lifted groups	string
670	en_US	cleanTitle	On the split structure of lifted groups	string
670	en_US	abstract	<p>Let wp: tildeX -&gt; X be a regular covering projection of connected graphs with the  group of covering transformations CT_wp being abelian. Assuming that a  group of automorphisms G &lt;= Aut (X) lifts along wp to a group tildeG &lt;= Aut(tildeX), the problem whether the corresponding exact sequence id -&gt; CT_wp -&gt; tildeG -&gt; G -&gt; id splits is analyzed in detail in terms of a Cayley voltage assignment that reconstructs the projection up to equivalence.</p><p>In the above combinatorial setting the extension is given only implicitly: <br />neither tildeG nor the action G -&gt; Aut CT_wp nor a 2-cocycle GxG -&gt; CT_wp, are given. Explicitly constructing the cover tildeX together with  CT_wp and  tildeG as permutation groups on tildeX is time and space consuming whenever CT_wp is large; thus, using the implemented  algorithms (for instance, HasComplement in Magma) is far from optimal. Instead,  we show that the minimal required information about the action and the 2-cocycle can  be effectively decoded directly from voltages (without explicitly constructing the cover and the lifted group); one could then use the standard method by reducing the problem to solving a linear system of equations over the integers. However, along these lines we here take a slightly different approach which  even  does not require any knowledge of cohomology. Time and space complexity are formally analyzed whenever CT_wp is elementary abelian.</p>	string

671	en_US	title	Numerical Solution of Singularly Perturbed Two-Parameters DDE using Numerical Integration Method	string
671	en_US	cleanTitle	Numerical Solution of Singularly Perturbed TwoParameters DDE using Numerical Integration Method	string
671	en_US	abstract	<p><strong>Abstract: </strong>In this paper, we present numerical integration methods to solve singularly perturbed Two-Parameter delay differential equations (DDEs) of second-order in which the highest order derivative has multiplied by a small parameter <em>e</em>  and both the convection and reaction terms are with negative and positive shift. In this method, we approximate the terms containing negative and positive shifts using the Taylor series expansion. We employ the Taylor and Simpson numerical integration, which has solved easily by discrete invariant imbedding algorithm. Several test examples are considered by taking various values for the delay, advance and perturbation parameters.</p>	string

672	en_US	title	The Nordhaus-Gaddum-type inequality for the Wiener polarity index	string
672	en_US	cleanTitle	The NordhausGaddumtype inequality for the Wiener polarity index	string
672	en_US	abstract	The Wiener polarity index $W_{p}(G)$ of a graph $G$ is the number of<br />unordered pairs of vertices \\{$u$,$v$\\} of $G$ such that the<br />distance between $u$ and $v$ is 3. In this paper, we study the Nordhaus-Gaddum-type inequality for the Wiener polarity index of<br />a graph $G$ with order $n$. We firstly consider a<br />crucial case for  $diam(G)=3$ and<br />$diam(\\bar{G})=3$. And we get that  $2\\leq<br />W_{p}(G)+W_{p}(\\bar{G})\\leq \\Big\\lceil\\dfrac{n}{2} \\Big\\rceil<br />\\Big\\lfloor\\dfrac{n}{2} \\Big\\rfloor-n+2$. Moreover, the bounds are best possible,<br />and the corresponding extremal graphs<br />are also presented. Then<br />we generalize the results to all connected simple graphs. Furthermore, we discuss the  Nordhaus-Gaddum-type inequality<br />for trees and unicyclic graphs,<br />respectively.	string

673	en_US	title	On the inertia of weighted (k - 1)-cyclic graphs	string
673	en_US	cleanTitle	On the inertia of weighted k  1cyclic graphs	string
673	en_US	abstract	<p>Let <span class="math"><em>G</em><sub><em>w</em></sub></span> be a weighted graph. The inertia of <span class="math"><em>G</em><sub><em>w</em></sub></span> is the triple <span class="math">In(<em>G</em><sub><em>w</em></sub>) = (<em>i</em><sub> + </sub>(<em>G</em><sub><em>w</em></sub>), <em>i</em><sub> − </sub>(<em>G</em><sub><em>w</em></sub>), <em>i</em><sub>0</sub>(<em>G</em><sub><em>w</em></sub>))</span>, where <span class="math"><em>i</em><sub> + </sub>(<em>G</em><sub><em>w</em></sub>), <em>i</em><sub> − </sub>(<em>G</em><sub><em>w</em></sub>), <em>i</em><sub>0</sub>(<em>G</em><sub><em>w</em></sub>)</span> are, respectively, the number of the positive, negative and zero eigenvalues of the adjacency matrix <span class="math"><em>A</em>(<em>G</em><sub><em>w</em></sub>)</span> of <span class="math"><em>G</em><sub><em>w</em></sub></span> including their multiplicities. A simple <span class="math"><em>n</em></span>-vertex connected graph is called a <span class="math">(<em>k</em> − 1)</span>-cyclic graph provided that its number of edges equals <span class="math"><em>n</em> + <em>k</em> − 2</span>. Let <span class="math"><em>θ</em>(<em>r</em><sub>1</sub>, <em>r</em><sub>2</sub>, …, <em>r</em><sub><em>k</em></sub>)<sub><em>w</em></sub></span> be an <span class="math"><em>n</em></span>-vertex simple weighted graph obtained from <span class="math"><em>k</em></span> weighted paths <span class="math">(<em>P</em><sub><em>r</em><sub>1</sub></sub>)<sub><em>w</em></sub>, (<em>P</em><sub><em>r</em><sub>2</sub></sub>)<sub><em>w</em></sub>, …, (<em>P</em><sub><em>r</em><sub><em>k</em></sub></sub>)<sub><em>w</em></sub></span> by identifying their initial vertices and terminal vertices, respectively. Set <span class="math">Θ <sub><em>k</em></sub>:  = {<em>θ</em>(<em>r</em><sub>1</sub>, <em>r</em><sub>2</sub>, …, <em>r</em><sub><em>k</em></sub>)<sub><em>w</em></sub>: <em>r</em><sub>1</sub> + <em>r</em><sub>2</sub> + ⋯ + <em>r</em><sub><em>k</em></sub> = <em>n</em> + 2<em>k</em> − 2}. </span> The inertia of the weighted graph <span class="math"><em>θ</em>(<em>r</em><sub>1</sub>, <em>r</em><sub>2</sub>, …, <em>r</em><sub><em>k</em></sub>)<sub><em>w</em></sub></span> is studied. Also, the weighted <span class="math">(<em>k</em> − 1)</span>-cyclic graphs that contain <span class="math"><em>θ</em>(<em>r</em><sub>1</sub>, <em>r</em><sub>2</sub>, …, <em>r</em><sub><em>k</em></sub>)<sub><em>w</em></sub></span> as an induced subgraph are studied. We characterize those graphs among <span class="math">Θ <sub><em>k</em></sub></span> that have extreme inertia. The results generalize the corresponding results obtained in [X.Z. Tan, B.L. Liu, The nullity of <span class="math">(<em>k</em> − 1)</span>-cyclic graphs, Linear Algebra Appl. 438 (2013) 3144-3153] and [G.H. Yu et al., The inertia of weighted unicyclic graphs, Linear Algebra Appl. 448 (2014) 130-152].</p>	string

676	en_US	title	A note on nowhere-zero 3-ﬂows and Z_3-connectivity	string
676	en_US	cleanTitle	A note on nowherezero 3ﬂows and Z_3connectivity	string
676	en_US	abstract	There are many major open problems in integer flow theory, such as Tutte's 3-flow conjecture that every 4-edge-connected graph admits a nowhere-zero 3-flow, Jaeger et al.'s conjecture that every 5-edge-connected graph is Z_3-connected and Kochol's conjecture that every bridgeless graph with at most three 3-edge-cuts admits a nowhere-zero 3-flow (an equivalent version of 3-flow conjecture). Thomassen proved that every 8-edge-connected graph is Z_3-connected and therefore admits a nowhere-zero 3-flow. Furthermore, Lovasz, Thomassen, Wu and Zhang improved Thomassen's result to 6-edge-connected graphs. In this paper, we prove that: (1) Every 4-edge-connected graph with at most seven 5-edge-cuts admits a nowhere-zero 3-flow. (2) Every bridgeless graph containing no 5-edge-cuts but at most three 3-edge-cuts admits a nowhere-zero 3-flow. (3) Every 5-edge-connected graph with at most five 5-edge-cuts is Z_3-connected. Our main theorems are partial results to Tutte's 3-flow conjecture, Kochol's conjecture and Jaeger et al.'s conjecture, respectively.	string

677	en_US	title	Isomorphisms of finite semi-Cayley graphs	string
677	en_US	cleanTitle	Isomorphisms of finite semiCayley graphs	string
677	en_US	abstract	‎A semi-Cayley graph (also called bi-Cayley graph by some authors) over a finite group $G$ is a simple graph‎<p style="margin: 0px; text-indent: 0px; -qt-block-indent: 0; -qt-user-state: 0;">‎whose its automorphism group has a semiregular subgroup isomorphic to $G$ with two orbits (of equal size)‎.</p><p style="margin: 0px; text-indent: 0px; -qt-block-indent: 0; -qt-user-state: 0;">‎In this paper we introduce the concept of isomorphism‎</p><p style="margin: 0px; text-indent: 0px; -qt-block-indent: 0; -qt-user-state: 0;">‎for semi-Cayley graphs‎. ‎A Cayley graph $\\Gamma$ of $G$ is called a CI-graph if its isomorphic‎</p><p style="margin: 0px; text-indent: 0px; -qt-block-indent: 0; -qt-user-state: 0;">‎images are induced by automorphisms of $G$‎. ‎By a well-known result of Babai \\cite{babai}‎,</p><p style="margin: 0px; text-indent: 0px; -qt-block-indent: 0; -qt-user-state: 0;">‎a Cayley graph $\\Gamma$ of a finite group $G$ is a CI-graph‎</p><p style="margin: 0px; text-indent: 0px; -qt-block-indent: 0; -qt-user-state: 0;">‎if and only if all regular subgroups of $\\Aut(\\Gamma)$ isomorphic to $G$ are conjugate in $\\Aut(\\Gamma)$‎.</p><p style="margin: 0px; text-indent: 0px; -qt-block-indent: 0; -qt-user-state: 0;">‎In this paper‎, ‎analogous to CI-graphs‎, ‎we introduce \\textit{SCI-graphs} and prove a Babai's type theorem for semi-Cayley graphs‎. ‎We prove that every semi-Cayley graph of a finite group $G$ is a SCI-graph if and only if $G$ is cyclic of order 3‎. ‎Also‎, ‎we study the isomorphism problem of a special class of semi-Cayley graphs‎.</p>	string

678	en_US	title	New type of difference sequence space of Fibonacci numbers	string
678	en_US	cleanTitle	New type of difference sequence space of Fibonacci numbers	string
678	en_US	abstract	<p>The aim of the present paper is to introduce a new band matrix $\\bar{H}_u$ and define the sequence space<br />$$l_p(\\bar{H}_u)=\\left\\{ \\sum_{k}\\left|\\frac{f_{k}}{f_{k+1}}u_kx_k - \\frac{f_{k}}{f_{k+1}}u_{k-1}x_{k-1} \\right|^{p}&lt;\\infty, ~~ 1\\le p \\le\\infty \\right\\},$$<br />where $f_k$ is the $kth$ Fibonacci number for every $k \\in \\mathbf{N}$. 679	en_US	title	Embeddings of generalized Latin squares in finite groups	string
679	en_US	cleanTitle	Embeddings of generalized Latin squares in finite groups	string
679	en_US	abstract	<p>Let $n$ be a positive integer. A generalized Latin square of order $n$ is an $n \\times n$ matrix such that the elements in each row  and each column are distinct. The square is said to be commutative if the $n\\times n$ matrix is symmetric. Given $n\\ge 2$, we show that for any $m\\in \\{n, \\dots, \\frac {n(n+1)}2\\}$, there exists a commutative generalized Latin square of order $n$ with $m$ distinct elements which is embeddable in a finite group. We also show that the corresponding result holds in the non-commutative case for $n\\ge 2$ and $m\\in \\{n, \\dots, n\\sp 2\\}$.</p>	string

680	en_US	cleanTitle	Gray Code Numbers of Complete Bipartite Graphs	string
680	en_US	abstract	Let $H$ be a graph, and $k\\geq \\chi(H)$ an integer.<br />We say that $H$ has a {\\em Gray code of $k$-colourings}<br />if and only if it is possible to list all its<br />$k$-colourings in such a way that consecutive colourings<br />(including the last and the first) agree on all vertices<br />of $H$ except one.<br />The Gray code number of $H$ is the least integer $k_0(H)$<br />such that $H$ has a Gray code of its $k$-colourings<br />for all $k\\geq k_0(H)$.<br />For complete bipartite graphs, we prove that<br />$k_0(K_{\\ell,r})=3$ when both $\\ell$ and $r$ are odd, and<br />$k_0(K_{\\ell,r})=4$ otherwise.	string

682	en_US	abstract	<p>Digraphs are considered by means of eigenvalues of the matrix <span class="math"><em>A</em><em>A</em><sup><em>T</em></sup></span>, and similarly <span class="math"><em>A</em><sup><em>T</em></sup><em>A</em></span>, where <span class="math"><em>A</em></span> is the adjacency matrix of a digraph. 684	en_US	title	Residual voluntary health insurance in Slovenia and protection of competition	string
684	en_US	cleanTitle	Residual voluntary health insurance in Slovenia and protection of competition	string
684	en_US	abstract	In an oligopolic competitive health insurance market,<br />where all insurance undertakings sell <br />a unique and homogeneous health insurance product<br />under community rating,<br />the introduction of claims equalisation <br />determines a specific Bertrand competition.<br />A non-market initial advantage of the dominant insurance undertaking,<br />gained through state intervention, can result in <br />self-reinforcing market dominance,<br />leading to the withdrawal of the smallest firm and final monopoly.<br />As a prevention, specific measures of protection of competition are required.<br />An example of such a market condition is given by means of residual voluntary health insurance in Slovenia,<br />where an equalisation scheme in the form of claims equalisation applies, <br />and the dominant insurance undertaking <br />received its initial insurance contracts free of charge from a public institution,<br />whilst the other two private insurance undertakings had to pay the acquirement of every of their<br />insurees.	string

685	en_US	title	A new theoretical bound to approximate connected dominating set in unit disk graph	string
685	en_US	cleanTitle	A new theoretical bound to approximate connected dominating set in unit disk graph	string
685	en_US	abstract	A graph $G = (V,E)$ is called a unit disk graph if the inequality $d(u,v)\\leq 1$  is equivalence of existence an edge between two nodes $u$ and $v$. The unit disk graph is a mathematical model for wireless sensor networks when all sensors have the same communication radius. Minimum connected dominating set and maximal independent set of vertices, that is also a dominating set, are two mathematical tools in this area. The size of the maximum independent set $(MIS)$ in a graph $G$ is called the independence number, denoted by $\\alpha(G)$. The size of the minimum connected dominating set $(MCDS)$ in $G$ is called the connected domination number, denoted by $\\gamma_{c}(G)$. The ratio to compare $\\alpha(G)$ with $\\gamma_{c}(G)$ becomes a theoretical upper bound for approximation algorithms to compute connected dominating set. We improve the upper bound by showing $\\alpha(G)\\leq 3.398 \\gamma_{c}(G)+4.763$, which may be the best upper bound.	string
685	en_US	discipline		string
685	en_US	subjectClass	05C69	string
685	en_US	subject	Unit disk graph, connected domination number, independence number	string
685	en_US	sponsor		string
686	en_US	title	Computing Unique Maximum Matchings in O(m) time for König-Egerváry Graphs and Unicyclic Graphs	string
686	en_US	cleanTitle	Computing Unique Maximum Matchings in Om time for KönigEgerváry Graphs and Unicyclic Graphs	string
686	en_US	abstract	<p>Let α(G) denote the maximum size of an independent set of vertices and μ(G) be the cardinality of a maximum matching in a graph G. A matching saturating all the vertices is a perfect matching. If α(G)+μ(G)=|V(G)|, then G is called a König-Egerváry graph. A graph is unicyclic if it has a unique cycle. <br />It is known that a maximum matching can be found in O(m∙√n) time for a graph with n vertices and m edges. In 2010 Bartha conjectured that a unique perfect matching, if it exists, can be found in O(m) time. <br />In this paper we validate this conjecture for König-Egerváry graphs and unicylic graphs. We propose a variation of Karp-Sipser leaf-removal algorithm, which ends with an empty graph if and only if the original graph is a König-Egerváry graph with a unique perfect matching (obtained as an output as well). <br />We also show that a unicyclic non-bipartite graph G may have at most one perfect matching, and this is the case where G is a König-Egerváry graph.</p>	string
686	en_US	discipline	Combinatorics; Graph Theory	string
686	en_US	subjectClass	05C70; 05C85	string
686	en_US	subject	unique perfect matching; König-Egerváry graph; unicyclic graph; Karp-Sipser leaf-removal algorithm; core	string

687	en_US	title	Equitable coloring of corona products of cubic graphs is harder than ordinary coloring	string
687	en_US	cleanTitle	Equitable coloring of corona products of cubic graphs is harder than ordinary coloring	string
687	en_US	abstract	<p>A graph is equitably <span class="math"><em>k</em></span>-colorable if its vertices can be partitioned into <span class="math"><em>k</em></span> independent sets in such a way that the number of vertices in any two sets differ by at most one. The smallest <span class="math"><em>k</em></span> for which such a coloring exists is known as the <em>equitable chromatic number</em> of <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> and it is denoted by <span class="math"><em>χ</em><sub> = </sub>(<em>G</em>)</span>. In this paper the problem of determinig <span class="math"><em>χ</em><sub> = </sub></span> for coronas of cubic graphs is studied. Although the problem of ordinary coloring of coronas of cubic graphs is solvable in polynomial time, the problem of equitable coloring becomes NP-hard for these graphs. We provide polynomially solvable cases of coronas of cubic graphs and prove the NP-hardness in a general case. As a by-product we obtain a simple linear time algorithm for equitable coloring of such graphs which uses <span class="math"><em>χ</em><sub> = </sub>(<em>G</em>)</span> or <span class="math"><em>χ</em><sub> = </sub>(<em>G</em>) + 1</span> colors. Our algorithm is best possible, unless P=NP. Consequently, cubical coronas seem to be the only known class of graphs for which equitable coloring is harder than ordinary coloring.</p>	string

688	en_US	title	Dominance in a Cayley digraph and in its reverse	string
688	en_US	cleanTitle	Dominance in a Cayley digraph and in its reverse	string
688	en_US	abstract	<pre class="western">Let $D$ be a digraph.\\r\\nIts reverse digraph, $D^{-1}$, is obtained by reversing all arcs of $D$.\\r\\nWe show that the domination numbers of $D$ and $D^{-1}$ can be different\\r\\neven if $D$ is a Cayley digraph.\\r\\nThe smallest groups admitting Cayley digraphs with this property are the\\r\\nalternating group $\\Alt_4$ and the dihedral group $\\Dih_6$, both on $12$\\r\\nelements.\\r\\nThen, for each $n\\ge 6$ we find a Cayley digraph $D$ on the dihedral group\\r\\n$\\Dih_n$ such that the domination numbers of $D$ and $D^{-1}$ are different\\r\\nthough $D$ has an efficient dominating set.\\r\\nAnalogous results are obtained also for the total domination number.\\r\\nSince $D$ and $D^{-1}$ cannot be isomorphic if the (total) domination\\r\\nnumbers of $D$ and $D^{-1}$ are different, our approach can be used to\\r\\nidentify Cayley digraphs $D$ for which $D$ and $D^{-1}$ are not isomorphic.</pre>	string

689	en_US	title	Note on the Erd{\\H o}s-Faber-Lov{\\' a}sz Conjecture and commutative quasigroups.	string
689	en_US	cleanTitle	Note on the Erd{\\H o}sFaberLov{ a}sz Conjecture and commutative quasigroups	string
689	en_US	abstract	<pre><!--StartFragment-->A <span>\\emph</span>{decomposition} of a simple graph <span>$G$</span> is a pair <span>$(G,\\mathcal{D})$</span> where <span>$\\mathcal{D}$</span> is a set of subgraphs of <span>$G$</span>, which partitions the edges of <span>$G$</span> in the sense that every edge of <span>$G$</span> belongs to exactly one subgraph in <span>$\\mathcal{D}$</span>. If the elements of <span>$\\mathcal{D}$</span> are induced subgraphs then the decomposition is denoted by <span>$[G,\\mathcal{D}]$</span>.</pre><pre> </pre><pre>A <span>$k$</span>-<span>$\\mathcal{D}$</span>-<span>\\emph</span>{coloring} of a decomposition <span>$(G,\\mathcal{D})$</span> is a surjective function that assigns to the edges of <span>$G$</span> a color from a <span>$k$</span>-set of colors, such that all edges of <span>$H\\in \\mathcal{D}$</span> have the same color, and if <span>$H_1,H_2\\in\\mathcal{D}$</span> with <span>$V(H_1)\\cap V(H_2)\\neq\\emptyset$</span>, then <span>$E(H_1)$</span> and <span>$E(H_2)$</span> have different colors. The <span>\\emph</span>{chromatic index} <span>$\\chi'((G,\\mathcal{D}))$</span> of a decomposition <span>$(G,\\mathcal{D})$</span> is the smallest number <span>$k$</span> for which there exists a <span>$k$</span>-<span>$\\mathcal{D}$</span>-coloring of <span>$(G,\\mathcal{D})$</span>.</pre><pre> </pre><pre>The well-known Erd{<span>\\H</span> o}s-Faber-Lov{<span>\\'a</span>}sz Conjecture states that any decomposition <span>$[K_n,\\mathcal{D}]$</span> satisfies <span>$\\chi'([K_n,\\mathcal{D}])\\leq n$</span>. We use commutative quasigroups to give a new family of decompositions that satisfy the conjecture.<!--EndFragment--></pre>	string

699	en_US	title	Testing whether the lifted group splits	string
699	en_US	cleanTitle	Testing whether the lifted group splits	string
699	en_US	abstract	<p>Let a group of automorphisms lift along a regular covering projection of connected graphs given combinatorially by means of voltages. The data that determine the lifted group and its action are then conveniently encoded in terms of voltages as well. Along these lines, an algorithm for testing whether the lifted group is a split extension of the group of covering transformations has recently been proposed in the case when the group of covering transformations is solvable. It consists of decomposing the covering into a series of coverings with elementary abelian groups of covering transformations, and inductively solving the problem at every elementary abelian step. Although the explicit construction of the lifted group is not needed, it still involves time and space consuming constructions of certain subgroups in the lifted group at every step except at the final one.</p><p>In this paper, an improved version that completely avoids such constructions is presented. From voltage distribution we first compute the weak action and the factor set that determine the lifted group, and we then carry out the test by extracting the necessary information only from the corresponding weak actions and factor sets at every step. An experimental comparison is made against the previous version.</p>	string

700	en_US	cleanTitle	Coupon Coloring of Some Special Graphs	string
700	en_US	abstract	<p>Let $G$ be a graph without isolated vertices. A \\emph{$k$-coupon coloring} of $G$ is a $k$-coloring of $G$ such that the neighborhood of every vertex of $G$ contains vertices of all colors from $[k] := \\{1, 2, \\cdots, k\\}$. The \\emph{coupon coloring number} $\\chi_c(G)$ of $G$ is the maximum $k$ for which a $k$-coupon coloring exists. In this paper, we mainly study the coupon coloring of some special graphs such as complete graphs, complete $k$-partite graphs, wheels, cycles, unicyclic graphs, bicyclic graphs and generalised $\\Theta$-graphs. Moreover, we determine the coupon coloring numbers of all above graphs.</p>	string

703	en_US	abstract	The classification of the dihedral folding tessellations of the sphere and the plane whose prototiles are a kite and an equilateral triangle were obtained in [C. Avelino and A. Avelino and A. Santos, Spherical Folding Tessellations by Kites and Isosceles Triangles: a case of adjacency, Mathematical Communications, 19 (2014), 1–28.; C. Avelino and A. Santos, Spherical Folding Tessellations by Kites and Isosceles Triangles II, International Journal of Pure and Applied Mathematics, 85 (2013), 45–67.; C.Avelino and A.Santos, Spherical Folding Tessellations by Kites and Isosceles Triangles III, submitted.]. 705	en_US	title	On convergence of binomial means, and an application to finite Markov chains	string
705	en_US	cleanTitle	On convergence of binomial means and an application to finite Markov chains	string
705	en_US	abstract	<p>For a sequence <span class="math">{<em>a</em><sub><em>n</em></sub>}<sub><em>n</em> ≥ 0</sub></span> of real numbers, we define the sequence of its arithmetic means <span class="math">{<em>a</em><sub><em>n</em></sub><sup> * </sup>}<sub><em>n</em> ≥ 0</sub></span> as the sequence of averages of the first <span class="math"><em>n</em></span> elements of <span class="math">{<em>a</em><sub><em>n</em></sub>}<sub><em>n</em> ≥ 0</sub></span>. For a parameter <span class="math">0 &lt; <em>p</em> &lt; 1</span>, we define the sequence of <span class="math"><em>p</em></span>-binomial means <span class="math">{<em>a</em><sub><em>n</em></sub><sup><em>p</em></sup>}<sub><em>n</em> ≥ 0</sub></span> of the sequence <span class="math">{<em>a</em><sub><em>n</em></sub>}<sub><em>n</em> ≥ 0</sub></span> as the sequence of <span class="math"><em>p</em></span>-binomially weighted averages of the first <span class="math"><em>n</em></span> elements of <span class="math">{<em>a</em><sub><em>n</em></sub>}<sub><em>n</em> ≥ 0</sub></span>. We compare the convergence of sequences <span class="math">{<em>a</em><sub><em>n</em></sub>}<sub><em>n</em> ≥ 0</sub></span>, <span class="math">{<em>a</em><sub><em>n</em></sub><sup> * </sup>}<sub><em>n</em> ≥ 0</sub></span> and <span class="math">{<em>a</em><sub><em>n</em></sub><sup><em>p</em></sup>}<sub><em>n</em> ≥ 0</sub></span> for various <span class="math">0 &lt; <em>p</em> &lt; 1</span>, , we analyze when the convergence of one sequence implies the convergence of the other.</p><p>While the sequence <span class="math">{<em>a</em><sub><em>n</em></sub><sup> * </sup>}<sub><em>n</em> ≥ 0</sub></span>, known also as the sequence of Cesàro means of a sequence, is well studied in the literature, the results about <span class="math">{<em>a</em><sub><em>n</em></sub><sup><em>p</em></sup>}<sub><em>n</em> ≥ 0</sub></span> are hard to find. Our main result shows that, if <span class="math">{<em>a</em><sub><em>n</em></sub>}<sub><em>n</em> ≥ 0</sub></span> is a sequence of non-negative real numbers such that <span class="math">{<em>a</em><sub><em>n</em></sub><sup><em>p</em></sup>}<sub><em>n</em> ≥ 0</sub></span> converges to <span class="math"><em>a</em> ∈ <strong>R</strong> ∪ {∞}</span> for some <span class="math">0 &lt; <em>p</em> &lt; 1</span>, then <span class="math">{<em>a</em><sub><em>n</em></sub><sup> * </sup>}<sub><em>n</em> ≥ 0</sub></span> also converges to <span class="math"><em>a</em></span>. We give an application of this result to finite Markov chains.</p>	string

706	en_US	title	Squashing maximum packings of 6-cycles into maximum packings of triples	string
706	en_US	cleanTitle	Squashing maximum packings of 6cycles into maximum packings of triples	string
706	en_US	abstract	<p><span>A </span><span class="math">6</span><span>-cycle is said to be squashed if we identify a pair of opposite vertices and name one of them with the other (and thereby turning the </span><span class="math">6</span><span>-cycle into a pair of triples with a common vertex). The squashing problem for </span><span class="math">6</span><span>-cycle systems was introduced by C. C. Lindner, M. Meszka and A. Rosa and completely solved by determining the spectrum. In this paper, by employing PBD and GDD-constructions and filling techniques, we extend this result by squashing maximum packings of </span><span class="math"><em>K</em><sub><em>n</em></sub></span><span> with </span><span class="math">6</span><span>-cycles into maximum packings of </span><span class="math"><em>K</em><sub><em>n</em></sub></span><span> with triples. More specifically, we establish that for each </span><span class="math"><em>n</em> ≥ 6</span><span>, there is a max packing of </span><span class="math"><em>K</em><sub><em>n</em></sub></span><span> with </span><span class="math">6</span><span>-cycles that can be squashed into a maximum packing of </span><span class="math"><em>K</em><sub><em>n</em></sub></span><span> with triples.</span></p>	string

707	en_US	abstract	<p><span style="font-family: Times New Roman;"><span style="font-size: medium;">Recently, an extension of Motzkin-Straus theorem was proved for non-uniform hypergraphs whose edges contain 1 or 2 vertices in \\cite</span><span style="font-size: medium;">{PPTZ}</span><span style="font-size: medium;">. It would be interesting if similar results hold for other non-uniform hypergraphs. In this paper, we establish some connections between</span><span style="font-size: medium;">  </span><span style="font-size: medium;">the maximum value of a class of polynomial</span><span style="font-size: medium;">  </span><span style="font-size: medium;">functions over the standard simplex of the Euclidean space and the clique number of non-uniform hypergraphs whose edges contain 1, or 2, and more vertices. 710	en_US	abstract	In this paper we define a family of polynomials closely related to the modified $R$-polynomials and begin work toward a classification of the polynomials by using a combinatorial interpretation involving subwords of the maximal element in the Bruhat order. We state several properties of these polynomials and symmetries which they satisfy that were discovered while pursuing a resolution to this problem.	string

711	en_US	abstract	<p>For a graph <em>G </em>= (<em>V </em>(<em>G</em>), <em>E</em> (<em>G</em>)), an edge labeling function <em>f</em>: <em>E</em> (<em>G</em>) → {0,1, ..., <em>k </em>- 1} where <em>k </em>is an integer, 2<em> </em>≤<em> k ≤</em><strong> </strong><strong>|</strong><em>E</em>(<em>G</em>)<strong>|</strong>, induces a vertex labeling function <em>f </em>*: <em>V </em>(<em>G</em>) → {0,1, ..., <em>k </em>- 1} such that <em>f </em>*(<em>v</em>) is the product of the labels of the edges incident to <em>v </em>(mod <em>k</em>). In this paper, we introduce this concept and investigate 3-TEPC labeling of some graphs.</p><p> </p>	string

713	en_US	title	Weak-parity edge-colorings of graphs	string
713	en_US	cleanTitle	Weakparity edgecolorings of graphs	string
713	en_US	abstract	<p>An edge-coloring of a graph $G$ is said to be a weak-odd edge-coloring if each non-isolated vertex of $G$ uses at least one color odd number of times on its incident edges.<br />Similarly, whenever each vertex of degree at least 2 in $G$ uses at least one color even number of times on its incident edges, we speak of a weak-even edge-coloring of $G$.<br />The weak-odd (resp. weak-even) chromatic index $\\chi_{\\textrm{wo}}'(G)$ (resp. $\\chi_{\\textrm{we}}'(G)$), is defined to be the minimum number of colors needed for a<br />weak-odd (resp. weak-even) edge-coloring of $G$. In this paper, we prove that $3$ (resp. $2$) colors suffice for a weak-odd (resp. weak-even) edge-coloring of<br />any graph without trivial nonempty components, and characterize connected graphs according to the value of their weak-odd (resp. weak-even) chromatic index. We also<br />introduce the concept of vertex signature $\\pi$ of a graph $G$ and the related general notion of weak-parity edge-coloring of $(G,\\pi)$. We characterize the pairs $(G,\\pi)$,<br />consisting of a connected graph $G$ and an associated vertex signature $\\pi$, which admit weak-parity edge-colorings, and furthermore prove that $3$ colors suffice for any such pair.</p>	string

714	en_US	title	Labeling  $Mycielski$  Graphs with Distance Constraints	string
714	en_US	cleanTitle	Labeling  Mycielski  Graphs with Distance Constraints	string
714	en_US	abstract	<p>An $L(2,1)$-labeling of a graph $G$ is a function $f$ from the<br />vertex set $V(G)$ to the set of all nonnegative integers such that<br />$\\vert f(x) - f(y)\\vert \\ge 2$ if $d(x,y) = 1$ and $\\vert f(x) -<br />f(y)\\vert \\ge 1$ if $d(x,y) = 2$, where $d(x,y)$ denotes the<br />distance between $x$ and $y$ in $G$. The $L(2,1)  $-labeling<br />number $\\lambda (G)$ of $G$ is the smallest number $k$ such that<br />$G$ has an $L(2,1)  $-labeling    $f$ with $\\max \\{f(v):v \\in V(G)\\} =<br />k$.   In this paper,       we  first determine the  exact value for the   $L(2,1)  $-labeling<br />number of  a   class of $Mycielski$  graphs $\\mu(K_n)      $.  We then determine the  exact value or provide both lower and upper bounds  for  the   $L(2,1)  $-labeling<br />number  of  any   Mycielski graphs<br />$\\mu^t(K_n)$ for $t \\geq 2$. We finally   provide both lower and upper bounds  for  the   $L(2,1)  $-labeling<br />number  of  any  $Mycielski$  graphs  $\\mu^t(G)$.</p>	string

715	en_US	abstract	We extend the definition of the Cartesian product to graphs with loops and show that the Sabidussi–Vizing unique factorization theorem for connected finite simple graphs still holds in this context for all connected finite graphs with at least one unlooped vertex. 718	en_US	title	An extension of total graph over a module	string
718	en_US	cleanTitle	An extension of total graph over a module	string
718	en_US	abstract	Let $R$ be a commutative ring with nonzero identity and $U(R)$ its multiplicative group of units. Suppose that $c\\in U(R)$ such that $c^{-1}=c$. Also, let $M$ be an R-module where the collection of prime submodules is non-empty and let  $N_{\\Lambda}$ be an arbitrary union of prime submodules. We define the extended total graph of $M$ as a simple graph $T\\Gamma_{c}(M,N_{\\Lambda})$ with vertex set $M$, and two distinct elements $x,y\\in M$ are adjacent if and only if $x+cy\\in N_{\\Lambda}$. This graph provides an extension of the total graph of a commutative ring and total graph of a module. In this paper,  we will study some graph theoretic results of $T\\Gamma_{c}(M,N_{\\Lambda})$. We also show that if $M\\neq M(L)$ for some proper submodule $L$ of $M$, then $M(L)$ is a union of prime submodules of $M$ where $M(L)=\\{m\\in M\\vert rm\\in L$ for some $r\\in R\\setminus(L:_{R}M)\\}$.	string
