719	en_US	title	Graph structure of commuting functions	string
719	en_US	cleanTitle	Graph structure of commuting functions	string
719	en_US	abstract	The problem of finding graph structure of functions commuting with<br />a given function in terms of their functional graphs is<br />considered. Structure of functional graphs of commuting functions<br />is described. The problem is reduced to describing graph<br />homomorphisms of weakly connected components of functional graphs.<br />Four subcases with finite sets are considered: permutations<br />commuting with permutation, permutations commuting with a<br />function, functions commuting with a permutation and functions<br />commuting with a function.  For finite sets the number of<br />functions commuting with a given one and functions with extremal<br />properties are found. Results for finite sets are generalized to<br />the case of arbitrary sets where there are additional types of<br />functional graph components.	string

721	en_US	title	Weak total resolving sets in graphs	string
721	en_US	cleanTitle	Weak total resolving sets in graphs	string
721	en_US	abstract	A set $W$ of vertices of $G$ is said to be a weak total resolving set for $G$ if $W$ is a resolving set for $G$ as well as for each $w\\in W$, there is at least one element in $W-\\{w\\}$ that resolves $w$ and $v$ for every $v\\in V(G)- W$. Weak total metric dimension of $G$ is the smallest order of a weak total resolving set for $G$. This paper includes the investigation of weak total metric dimension of trees. Also, weak total resolving number of a graph as well as randomly weak total $k$-dimensional graphs are defined and studied in this paper. Moreover, some characterizations and realizations regarding weak total resolving number and weak total metric dimension are given.	string

722	en_US	title	The number of edges of the edge polytope of a finite simple graph	string
722	en_US	cleanTitle	The number of edges of the edge polytope of a finite simple graph	string
722	en_US	abstract	<p>Let <span class="math"><em>d</em> ≥ 3</span> be an integer. It is known that the number of edges of the edge polytope of the complete graph with <span class="math"><em>d</em></span> vertices is <span class="math"><em>d</em>(<em>d</em> − 1)(<em>d</em> − 2) / 2</span>. In this paper, we study the maximum possible number <span class="math"><em>μ</em><sub><em>d</em></sub></span> of edges of the edge polytope arising from finite simple graphs with <span class="math"><em>d</em></span> vertices. We show that <span class="math"><em>μ</em><sub><em>d</em></sub> = <em>d</em>(<em>d</em> − 1)(<em>d</em> − 2) / 2</span> if and only if <span class="math">3 ≤ <em>d</em> ≤ 14</span>. In addition, we study the asymptotic behavior of <span class="math"><em>μ</em><sub><em>d</em></sub></span>. Tran–Ziegler gave a lower bound for <span class="math"><em>μ</em><sub><em>d</em></sub></span> by constructing a random graph. We succeeded in improving this bound by constructing both a non-random graph and a random graph whose complement is bipartite.</p>	string

724	en_US	abstract	Let $G$ be an undirected connected graph with $n$, $n\\ge 3$, vertices and $m$ edges, and let $\\mu_1\\ge \\mu_2 \\ge \\cdots \\ge \\mu_{n-1}&gt;\\mu_n =0$ and $\\rho_1\\ge \\rho_2\\ge \\cdots \\ge \\rho_{n-1} &gt;\\rho_n =0$ be Laplacian and normalized Laplacian eigenvalues of $G$, respectively. 734	en_US	title	On the Balanced Case of the Brualdi-Shen Conjecture on 4-Cycle Decompositions of Eulerian Bipartite Tournaments	string
734	en_US	cleanTitle	On the Balanced Case of the BrualdiShen Conjecture on 4Cycle Decompositions of Eulerian Bipartite Tournaments	string
734	en_US	abstract	The Brualdi-Shen Conjecture on Eulerian Bipartite Tournaments states that any such graph can be decomposed into oriented $4$-$cycles$. In this article we prove the balanced case of the mentioned conjecture. We show that for any $2n\\times \\2n$ bipartite graph $G=(U\\cup V,E)$ in which each vertex has $n$-neighbors with biadjacency matrix $M$ (or its transpose) there is a proper edge coloring of a column permutation of $M$ denoted $M^{\\sigma}$ in which the nonzero entries of each of the $first$ $n$-columns are colored with elements from the set $\\{n+1, n+2,\\ldots, 2n\\}$ and the nonzero entries of each of the $last$ $n$-columns are colored with elements from the set $\\{1, 2,\\ldots, n\\}$ and if the nonzero entry $M^{\\sigma}_{r,j}$ is colored with color $i$ then $M^{\\sigma}_{r,i}$ must be a zero entry. Such a coloring will induce an oriented $4$-$cycle$ decomposition of the bipartite tournament corresponding to $M$. We achieve this by constructing an euler tour on the bipartite tournament which avoids traversing both pair of edges of any two internally disjoint $s$-$t$ $2$-$paths$ consecutively, where $s$ and $t$ belong to $V$.	string

737	en_US	abstract	<p>The psi function $\\psi(x)$ is defined by $\\psi(x)=\\frac{\\Gamma'(x)}{\\Gamma(x)}$ and $\\psi^{(i)}(x)$ for $i\\in\\mathbb{N}$ denote polygamma functions, where $\\Gamma(x)$ is the gamma function. In the paper, we prove that the function<br />$$<br />[\\psi'(x)]^2+\\psi''(x)-\\frac{x^2+\\lambda x+12}{12x^4(x+1)^2}<br />$$<br />is completely monotonic on $(0,\\infty)$ if and only if $\\lambda\\le0$, and so is its negative if and only if $\\lambda\\ge4$. 738	en_US	title	Convex-Arc Drawings of Pseudolines	string
738	en_US	cleanTitle	ConvexArc Drawings of Pseudolines	string
738	en_US	abstract	<p>A weak pseudoline arrangement is a topological generalization of a line arrangement, consisting of curves topologically equivalent to lines that cross each other at most once. We consider arrangements that are outerplanar—each crossing is incident to an unbounded face—and simple—each crossing point is the crossing of only two curves. We show that these arrangements may be represented by the chords of a circle, by convex polygonal chains with only two bends, or by hyperbolic lines. Simple but non-outerplanar arrangements may be represented by convex polygonal chains or convex smooth curves of linear complexity.</p>	string

746	en_US	title	The JLS model with ARMA/GARCH errors	string
746	en_US	cleanTitle	The JLS model with ARMA/GARCH errors	string
746	en_US	abstract	<p>Prior to crashes, the stock index price time series is characterised by the Log-Periodic Power Law (LPPL) equation of the Johansen–Ledoit–Sornette (JLS) model, which leads to a critical point indicating a change to a new market regime. In this paper, we describe the hierarchical diamond lattice, upon which the JLS model is derived, using the diamond lattice operation <span class="math"><em>D</em><sub><em>i</em></sub></span> and derive the recursion for the coefficients of the growth function in a diamond lattice rooted at the main root vertex <span class="math"><em>r</em><sub><em>m</em></sub></span>. Further, to verify the adequacy of the JLS model, we analyse the model’s residuals and propose its generalization, using the ARMA/GARCH error model. We determine the ARMA/GARCH orders using the extended autocorrelation function (EACF) method and compare the results with those of the Akaike and Bayesian Information Criteria. Using the data for 33 major world stock indices we show, that proposed generalization of the JLS model in general performs better in predicting the market regime changes and has also the ability to recognise false bubble identification, indicated by the JLS model.</p>	string

751	en_US	cleanTitle	Distinguishing  graphs by total colourings	string
751	en_US	abstract	<p>We introduce the <span><em>total distinguishing number</em></span> <span class="math"><em>D</em>ʺ(<em>G</em>)</span> of a graph <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> as the least number <span class="math"><em>d</em></span> such that <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> has a total colouring (not necessarily proper) with <span class="math"><em>d</em></span> colours that is only preserved by the trivial automorphism. This is an analog to the notion of the distinguishing number <span class="math"><em>D</em>(<em>G</em>)</span>, and the distinguishing index <span class="math"><em>D</em>ʹ(<em>G</em>)</span>, which are defined for colourings of vertices and edges, respectively. We obtain a general sharp upper bound: <span class="math"><em>D</em>ʺ(<em>G</em>) ≤ ⌈√Δ (<em>G</em>)⌉</span> for every connected graph <span class="math"><em>G</em></span>.</p><p>We also introduce the <span><em>total distinguishing chromatic number</em></span> <span class="math"><em>χ</em>ʺ<sub><em>D</em></sub>(<em>G</em>)</span> similarly defined for proper total colourings of a graph <span class="math"><em>G</em></span>. We prove that <span class="math"><em>χ</em>ʺ<sub><em>D</em></sub>(<em>G</em>) ≤ <em>χ</em>ʺ(<em>G</em>) + 1</span> for every connected graph <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> with the total chromatic number <span class="math"><em>χ</em>ʺ(<em>G</em>)</span>. Moreover, if <span class="math"><em>χ</em>ʺ(<em>G</em>) ≥ Δ (<em>G</em>) + 2</span>, then <span class="math"><em>χ</em>ʺ<sub><em>D</em></sub>(<em>G</em>) = <em>χ</em>ʺ(<em>G</em>)</span>. We prove these results by setting sharp upper bounds for the minimal number of colours in a proper total colouring such that each vertex has a distinct set of colour walks emanating from it.</p>	string
751	en_US	coverPageAltText		string
751	en_US	discipline	Mathematics	string

758	en_US	title	One-point extensions in n_3 configurations	string
758	en_US	cleanTitle	Onepoint extensions in n_3 configurations	string
758	en_US	abstract	<p>Given an <span class="math"><em>n</em><sub>3</sub></span> configuration, a 1-point extension is a technique that constructs an <span class="math">(<em>n</em> + 1)<sub>3</sub></span> configuration from it. It is proved that all <span class="math">(<em>n</em> + 1)<sub>3</sub></span> configurations can be constructed from an <span class="math"><em>n</em><sub>3</sub></span> configuration using a 1-point extension, except for the Fano, Pappus, and Desargues configurations, and a family of Fano-type configurations. A 3-point extension is also described. A 3-point extension of the Fano configuration produces the Desargues and anti-Pappian configurations.</p><p>The significance of the 1-point extension is that it can frequently be used to construct real and/or rational coordinatizations in the plane of an <span class="math">(<em>n</em> + 1)<sub>3</sub></span> configuration, whenever it is geometric, and the corresponding <span class="math"><em>n</em><sub>3</sub></span> configuration is also geometric.</p>	string

763	en_US	abstract	<div><p>An edge colored graph is rainbow connected if any two vertices are connected by a path whose edges have distinct colors.<br />The rainbow connection number, $rc$-number for short, of a graph $\\Gamma$, is the smallest number of colors that are needed in order to make $\\Gamma$ rainbow connected.<br />In this paper, we give a method to bound the $rc$-numbers of graphs with certain structural properties.<br />Using this method, we investigate the $rc$-numbers of Cayley graphs, especially, those defined on abelian groups and on dihedral groups.</p></div>	string

771	en_US	title	On colour-preserving automorphisms of Cayley graphs	string
771	en_US	cleanTitle	On colourpreserving automorphisms of Cayley graphs	string
771	en_US	abstract	We study the automorphisms of a Cayley graph that preserve its natural edge-colouring. More precisely, we are interested in groups <em>G</em>, such that every such automorphism of every connected Cayley graph on <em>G</em> has a very simple form: the composition of a left-translation and a group automorphism. We find classes of groups that have the property, and we determine the orders of all groups that do not have the property. We also have analogous results for automorphisms that permute the colours, rather than preserving them.	string

777	en_US	abstract	<p>The field of graph theory is rich in its theoretical development as well as in  application areas such as drug modeling, communication networks and so on. One of the well-investigated notions in graph theory is the distance and the detour distance between vertices in a graph, especially when a graph is used in modeling real world problems. This notion of distance and detour distance give  rise to the introduction of other concepts such as the Wiener Index and Detour Index which are the popular topological indices. From these indices Reverse Wiener Index and Reverse Detour Index are defined using the diameter and Detour diameter of a graph. In this paper , the Wiener Detour distance matrix is defined and using that matrix, the Reverse Harary Wiener index, Reverse Harary Detour  index, Reverse Harary Circular  index, Reverse Reciprocal Wiener index, Reverse Reciprocal Detour index, Reverse Reciprocal Circular index, Reverse Hyper Wiener index, Reverse Hyper Detour  index, Reverse Hyper Circular  index, Reverse Gutman wiener index, Reverse Gutman Detour  index and Reverse Gutman circular index are defined using the diameter and Detour diameter of a graph and the above indices have been estimated for the corona of graphs C<sub>3  </sub>ͦ P<sub>n</sub> , Helm graph H<sub>n</sub> &amp; Two fold wheel graph W<sub>2,n</sub>.</p>	string

783	en_US	abstract	<p>The number of independent sets is equivalent to the partition function of the hard-core lattice gas model with nearest-neighbor exclusion and unit activity. In this article, we mainly study the number of independent sets <span class="math"><em>i</em>(<em>H</em><sub><em>n</em></sub>)</span> on the Tower of Hanoi graph <span class="math"><em>H</em><sub><em>n</em></sub></span> at stage <span class="math"><em>n</em></span>, and derive the recursion relations for the numbers of independent sets. Upper and lower bounds for the asymptotic growth constant <span class="math"><em>μ</em></span> on the Towers of Hanoi graphs are derived in terms of the numbers at a certain stage, where <span class="math"><em>μ</em> = lim<sub><em>v</em> → ∞</sub>(ln<em>i</em>(<em>G</em>)) / <em>v</em>(<em>G</em>)</span> and <span class="math"><em>v</em>(<em>G</em>)</span> is the number of vertices in a graph <span class="math"><em>G</em></span>. Furthermore, we also consider the number of independent sets on the Sierpiński graphs which contain the Towers of Hanoi graphs as a special case.</p>	string

784	en_US	title	Reverse vertex degree and reverse Zagreb indices	string
784	en_US	cleanTitle	Reverse vertex degree and reverse Zagreb indices	string
784	en_US	abstract	Firstly, we define the reverse vertex degree of a vertex $v$ of a simple connected graph $G$ such as; $c_v=\\Delta-{d_v}+1$ where $\\Delta$  denotes the largest of all degrees of vertices of $G$ and $d_v$ denotes  the number of edges incident to $v$. Secondly, in relation to reverse vertex degree, we define four novel graph invariants:  Total reverse vertex degree,  first  reverse Zagreb alpha index, first reverse Zagreb beta  index  and second reverse Zagreb index of a simple connected graph.  We characterize extremal trees and graphs with respect to total reverse vertex degree and first  reverse Zagreb alpha index. To find  maximum graphs with respect to first reverse Zagreb beta index and second reverse Zagreb index are remained open questions.	string

787	en_US	title	Geometric point-circle pentagonal geometries from Moore graphs	string
787	en_US	cleanTitle	Geometric pointcircle pentagonal geometries from Moore graphs	string
787	en_US	abstract	<p>We construct isometric point-circle configurations on surfaces from uniform maps. This gives one geometric realisation in terms of points and circles of the Desargues configuration in the real projective plane, and three distinct geometric realisations of the pentagonal geometry with seven points on each line and seven lines through each point on three distinct dianalytic surfaces of genus 57. We also give a geometric realisation of the latter pentagonal geometry in terms of points and hyperspheres in 24 dimensional Euclidean space. <br />From these, we also obtain geometric realisations in terms of points and circles (or hyperspheres) of pentagonal geometries with k circles (hyperspheres) through each point and k-1 points on each circle (hypersphere).</p>	string

788	en_US	title	Search for the end of a path in the d-dimensional grid and in other graphs	string
788	en_US	cleanTitle	Search for the end of a path in the ddimensional grid and in other graphs	string
788	en_US	abstract	<p>We consider the worst-case query complexity of some variants of certain <strong>PPAD</strong>-complete search problems. Suppose we are given a graph <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> and a vertex <span class="math"><em>s</em> ∈ <em>V</em>(<em>G</em>)</span>. We denote the directed graph obtained from <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> by directing all edges in both directions by <span class="math"><em>G</em>ʹ</span>. <span class="math"><em>D</em></span> is a directed subgraph of <span class="math"><em>G</em>ʹ</span> which is unknown to us, except that it consists of vertex-disjoint directed paths and cycles and one of the paths originates in <span class="math"><em>s</em></span>. Our goal is to find an endvertex of a path by using as few queries as possible. A query specifies a vertex <span class="math"><em>v</em> ∈ <em>V</em>(<em>G</em>)</span>, and the answer is the set of the edges of <span class="math"><em>D</em></span> incident to <span class="math"><em>v</em></span>, together with their directions.</p><p>We also show lower bounds for the special case when <span class="math"><em>D</em></span> consists of a single path. Our proofs use the theory of graph separators. Finally, we consider the case when the graph <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> is a grid graph. In this case, using the connection with separators, we give asymptotically tight bounds as a function of the size of the grid, if the dimension of the grid is considered as fixed. In order to do this, we prove a separator theorem about grid graphs, which is interesting on its own right.</p>	string

789	en_US	title	On Alexandroff Shadow Spaces	string
789	en_US	cleanTitle	On Alexandroff Shadow Spaces	string
789	en_US	abstract	Each Alexandroff<br />space $X$ has a corresponding shadow space $[X]$ which is $T_0$ Alexandroff<br />space. In this paper, we study Alexandroff spaces and their properties via their shadow<br />spaces. The definitions and the concepts such as Artinian, Noetherian,<br />maximal points and minimal points, that are defined on $T_0$ Alexandroff<br />space carry over to any Alexandroff space. We prove that an Alexandroff<br />space $X$ is connected (compact) iff its shadow space $[X]$ is connected<br />(compact). Moreover, $X$ need not be scattered or $\\alpha $-scattered.<br />We give a study of preopen, semi-open, and $\\alpha$-open sets on<br />$X$.<br /><br />	string

790	en_US	abstract	In this paper, we prove the following theorem:<br />If a graph X is a degree 2 (unramified) covering of a hyperelliptic graph of genus g &gt;= 2, then X is gamma-hyperelliptic for some gamma &lt;= [(g-1)/2]. This is a discrete analogue of the corresponding theorem for Riemann surfaces. The Bass-Serre theory of coverings of graphs of groups is employed to get the main result.	string

797	en_US	abstract	The construction of a cycle in a graph can be realized by<br />iteratively adding cycles of a cycle basis.  The construction of<br />each elementary cycle is only possible if this cycle basis is<br />robust.  In the last years, different classes of robust cycle bases<br />have been established.  We compare these classes and show that they<br />are completely unrelated.  More precisely, we draw a Venn diagram<br />which displays the obvious containedness relations and show that<br />each of its regions is not empty.	string

805	en_US	title	Classification of convex polyhedra by their rotational orbit Euler characteristic	string
805	en_US	cleanTitle	Classification of convex polyhedra by their rotational orbit Euler characteristic	string
805	en_US	abstract	<p>Let <span class="math"><strong>P</strong></span> be a polyhedron whose boundary consists of flat polygonal faces on some compact surface <span class="math"><em>S</em>(<strong>P</strong>)</span> (not necessarily homeomorphic to the sphere <span class="math"><em>S</em><sup>2</sup></span>). Let <span class="math"><em>v</em><em>o</em><sub><em>R</em></sub>(<strong>P</strong>), <em>e</em><em>o</em><sub><em>R</em></sub>(<strong>P</strong>), </span> <span class="math"><em>f</em><em>o</em><sub><em>R</em></sub>(<strong>P</strong>)</span> be the numbers of rotational orbits of vertices, edges and faces, respectively, determined by the group <span class="math"><em>G</em> = <em>G</em><sub><em>R</em></sub>(<em>P</em>)</span> of all the rotations of the Euclidean space <span class="math"><em>E</em><sup>3</sup></span> preserving <span class="math"><strong>P</strong></span>. We define the <em>rotational orbit Euler characteristic</em> of <span class="math"><strong>P</strong></span> as the number <span class="math"><em>E</em><em>o</em><sub><em>R</em></sub>(<strong>P</strong>) = <em>v</em><em>o</em><sub><em>R</em></sub>(<strong>P</strong>) − <em>e</em><em>o</em><sub><em>R</em></sub>(<strong>P</strong>) + <em>f</em><em>o</em><sub><em>R</em></sub>(<strong>P</strong>)</span>.</p><p>Using the Burnside lemma we obtain the lower and the upper bound for <span class="math"><em>E</em><em>o</em><sub><em>R</em></sub>(<strong>P</strong>)</span> in terms of the genus of the surface <span class="math"><em>S</em>(<em>P</em>)</span>. We prove that <span class="math"><em>E</em><em>o</em><sub><em>R</em></sub> ∈ {2, 1, 0,  − 1}</span> for any convex polyhedron <span class="math"><strong>P</strong></span>. In the non-convex case <span class="math"><em>E</em><em>o</em><sub><em>R</em></sub></span> may be arbitrarily large or small.</p>	string

806	en_US	title	Finite actions on the 2-sphere, the projective plane and I-bundles over the projective plane	string
806	en_US	cleanTitle	Finite actions on the 2sphere the projective plane and Ibundles over the projective plane	string
806	en_US	abstract	<p>In this paper, we consider the finite groups which act on the <span class="math inline">2</span>-sphere <span class="math inline"><strong>S</strong><sup>2</sup></span> and the projective plane <span class="math inline"><strong>P</strong><sup>2</sup></span>, and show how to visualize these actions which are explicitly defined. We obtain their quotient types by distinguishing a fundamental domain for each action and identifying its boundary. If <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> is an action on <span class="math inline"><strong>P</strong><sup>2</sup></span>, then <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> is isomorphic to one of the following groups: <span class="math inline"><strong>S</strong><sub>4</sub></span>, <span class="math inline"><strong>A</strong><sub>5</sub></span>, <span class="math inline"><strong>A</strong><sub>4</sub></span>, <span class="math inline"><strong>Z</strong><sub><em>m</em></sub></span> or <span class="math inline">Dih(<strong>Z</strong><sub><em>m</em></sub>)</span>. For each group, there is only one equivalence class (conjugation), and <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> leaves an orientation reversing loop invariant if and only if <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> is isomorphic to either <span class="math inline"><strong>Z</strong><sub><em>m</em></sub></span> or <span class="math inline">Dih(<strong>Z</strong><sub><em>m</em></sub>)</span>. Using these preliminary results, we classify and enumerate the finite groups, up to equivalence, which act on <span class="math inline"><strong>P</strong><sup>2</sup> × <em>I</em></span> and the twisted I-bundle over <span class="math inline"><strong>P</strong><sup>2</sup></span>. As an example, if <span class="math inline"><em>m</em> &gt; 2</span> is an even integer and <span class="math inline"><em>m</em>/2</span> is odd, there are three equivalence classes of orientation reversing <span class="math inline">Dih(<strong>Z</strong><sub><em>m</em></sub>)</span>-actions on the twisted I-bundle over <span class="math inline"><strong>P</strong><sup>2</sup></span>. However if <span class="math inline"><em>m</em>/2</span> is even, then there are two equivalence classes.</p>	string

810	en_US	title	Spectral centrality measures in temporal networks	string
810	en_US	cleanTitle	Spectral centrality measures in temporal networks	string
810	en_US	abstract	In our previous article we defined temporal quantities used for the description of temporal networks with zero latency and we showed that some centrality measures (e.g. degree, betweenness, closeness) can be extended to the case of temporal networks. In this article we broaden the scope of centrality measures in temporal networks to centrality measures derived from the eigenvectors of network matrices, namely the eigenvector in-centrality, the eigenvector out-centrality, the Katz centrality, the Bonacich a and (a,b)-centrality, the HITS algorithm (also known as Hubs and Authorities) introduced by Kleinberg, and the PageRank algorithm defined by Page and Brin.<br />We extended our Python library TQ (Temporal Quantities) to include the algorithms from our research. The library is available online. The procedures will also be added to the user friendly program called Ianus. We tested the proposed algorithms on Franzosi’s violence network and on Corman’s Reuter terror news network and show the results.	string

812	en_US	cleanTitle	On domination and packing in graphs with emphasis on trees	string
812	en_US	abstract	We investigate (lower) packing and (lower) open packing numbers in graphs. We bound these two parameters from below in terms of order, maximum degree and the number of support vertices. These sharp lower bounds can be applied for trees, appropriately. Also, we prove the new upper bound $‎\\gamma(T)‎\\leq(n-\\ell+2s)/3‎‎$ for every tree $T$ of order $n$ with $\\ell$ leaves and $s$ support vertices and conclude $‎\\gamma‎_{t}(T)‎‎‎\\leq (n+s)/2‎$ as an immediate result, that was first proved by Chellali and Haynes \\cite{ch}.	string

814	en_US	title	The Structure of SP5-free graphs	string
814	en_US	cleanTitle	The Structure of SP5free graphs	string
814	en_US	abstract	<pre> A <span>P5</span> is a chain induced by five vertices a,b,c,d,e and four edges ab, bc, cd, de. A graph is S<span>P5</span>-free, if for any subgraph<span> H of G</span> any vertex of H is a split vertex. A split vertex is a vertex whose neighborhood can be partitioned into a clique and a stable set. Modular decomposition is a technique that applies to graphs [5]. The classical combinatorial optimization problems are in general NP-complete, Computing the modular decomposition tree(when the primes graphs appearing on the tree nodes have better properties)is an important preprocessing step to solve a large number of combinatorial optimization problems [3, 4, 8]. Using some results on the primes graphs [10], we establishes in this work a characterization of primes graphs that appears in the modular decomposition tree of S<span>P5</span>-free graphs.</pre>	string

815	en_US	title	Eccentricity of Networks with Structural Constraints	string
815	en_US	cleanTitle	Eccentricity of Networks with Structural Constraints	string
815	en_US	abstract	<p>The eccentricity of a node $v$ in a network is the maximum distance from $v$<br /> to any other node. In social networks, the reciprocal of eccentricity is<br /> used as a measure of importance of nodes in the network. Our work focuses on<br /> networks with prescribed structural properties, such as the number of nodes,<br /> the number of edges or the maximum degree. Specifically, we determine the<br /> maximum value of eccentricity centralization and (some) optimal networks for<br /> the families of bipartite networks with given partition sizes, networks with<br /> fixed maximum degree and fixed number of edges, tree networks with fixed<br /> maximum degree and fixed number of vertices, and networks with fixed number<br /> of nodes or edges. As a by-product, we introduce and study a new way of<br /> enumerating the nodes of a tree, which might be of independent interest.</p>	string

822	en_US	cleanTitle	Wiener Index of Some Total Graphs	string
822	en_US	abstract	<p>The total graph T(G) of a graph G = (V;E) is that graph whose vertex set is V [E,<br />and two vertices x; y are adjacent in T(G) in case one of the following holds:<br />(i) x; y 2 V (G) and x is adjacent to y in G, or<br />(ii) x; y 2 E(G) and x, y are adjacent in G, or<br />(iii) x 2 V (G), y 2 E(G), and x, y are incident in G.<br />For a graph G = (V;E), the graph G:Sm is obtained by identifying each vertex<br />of G by a root vertex of Sm and the graph Sm:G is obtained by identifying each<br />vertex of Sm except root vertex by any vertex of G, where Sm is a star graph with<br />m vertices. In this article, we consider G as the complete graph Kn with n vertices<br />and nd out the Wiener index of the total graphs of Kn:Sm and Sn:Km.</p>	string

824	en_US	title	A Circle without Pi	string
824	en_US	cleanTitle	A Circle without Pi	string
824	en_US	abstract	This paper provides the proof of invalidity of the most fundamental constant known to mankind. Imagining a circle without "\\pi" is simply unthinkable but it’s going to be a reality very soon. "\\pi" is not a true circle constant. This paper explores this idea and proposes a new constant in the process which gives the correct measure of a circle. It is given by "\\tau". As a result, it redefines the area of the circle. The circle area currently accounted is wrong and therefore needs correction. This has serious implications for science. I have also discovered the fundamental geometrical ratio b/w a circle and a square in which it’s inscribed and have also discovered a new circle formula. This paper makes this strong case with less ambiguity.	string

825	en_US	cleanTitle	Automorphism group of the balanced hypercube	string
825	en_US	abstract	<p>Huang and Wu in [IEEE Transactions on Computers 46 (1997), pp. 484–490] introduced the balanced hypercube <span class="math"><em>B</em><em>H</em><sub><em>n</em></sub></span> as an interconnection network topology for computing systems. In this paper, we completely determine the full automorphism group of the balanced hypercube. Applying this, we first show that the <span class="math"><em>n</em></span>-dimensional balanced hypercube <span class="math"><em>B</em><em>H</em><sub><em>n</em></sub></span> is arc-transitive but not <span class="math">2</span>-arc-transitive whenever <span class="math"><em>n</em> ≥ 2</span>. Then, we show that <span class="math"><em>B</em><em>H</em><sub><em>n</em></sub></span> is a lexicographic product of an <span class="math"><em>n</em></span>-valent graph <span class="math"><em>X</em><sub><em>n</em></sub></span> and the null graph with two vertices, where <span class="math"><em>X</em><sub><em>n</em></sub></span> is a <span class="math">Z<sub>2</sub><sup><em>n</em> − 1</sup></span>-regular cover of the <span class="math"><em>n</em></span>-dimensional hypercube <span class="math"><em>Q</em><sub><em>n</em></sub></span>.</p>	string

826	en_US	title	On statistically sequentially covering maps	string
826	en_US	cleanTitle	On statistically sequentially covering maps	string
826	en_US	abstract	A mapping $f: X \\rightarrow Y $ is statistically sequence covering map if whenever a sequence $\\lbrace y_n \\rbrace$  convergent to $y$ in $Y,$ there is a  sequence $\\lbrace x_n \\rbrace$ statistically converges to $x$ in $X$ with each $x_n \\in f^{-1}(y_n) $ and $ x \\in f^{-1}(y).$ In this paper, we introduce the concept of statistically sequence covering map which is a generalization of sequence covering map and discuss the relation with covering maps by some examples. Using this concept, we prove that every closed and statistically sequence-covering image of a metric space is metrizable. Also, we give characterizations of statistically sequence covering compact images of spaces with a weaker metric topology.	string

830	en_US	title	Iterated Symmetric Three Players Prisoner's Dilemma Game	string
830	en_US	cleanTitle	Iterated Symmetric Three Players Prisoner's Dilemma Game	string
830	en_US	abstract	Most game theory research on the Prisoner's Dilemma has focused on two player games, but it is possible to create a Prisoner's Dilemma involving three or even more players. In this paper, we discuss a Prisoner's Dilemma game involving three players which is infinitely iterated "iterated three player Prisoner's Dilemma game (I3PD)". The all possible strategies which depend on the previous outcomes are presented by finite state of automata, and we compute the all payoff values for these strategies. Four different new strategies are presented in order to discuss the general Tit-For-Tat concept in details. In the appendix section, we designed an algorithm and implemented it using the Java programming language to make these calculations.	string

834	en_US	title	Mathematical aspects of fullerenes	string
834	en_US	cleanTitle	Mathematical aspects of fullerenes	string
834	en_US	abstract	Fullerene graphs are cubic, 3-connected, planar graphs with exactly 12 pentagonal faces, while all other faces are hexagons. Fullerene graphs are mathematical models of fullerene molecules, i.e., molecules comprised only by carbon atoms different than graphites and diamonds. We give a survey on fullerene graphs from our perspective, which could be also considered as an introduction to this topic. Different types of fullerene graphs are considered, their symmetries, and construction methods. We give an overview of some graph invariants that can possibly correlate with the fullerene molecule stability, such as: the bipartite edge frustration, the independence number, the saturation number, the number of perfect matchings, etc.	string

839	en_US	abstract	\\noindent \\textbf{Abstract}. Given the binomial transforms $\\{ b_{n} \\} $ and $\\{ \\, c_{n} \\} $of the sequences $\\left\\{a_{n} \\right\\}$and $\\{ {\\kern 1pt} {\\kern 1pt} d_{n} \\} $ correspondingly, we compute the binomial transform of the sequence $\\{ \\, a_{n} {\\kern 1pt} c_{n} \\} $in terms of $\\{ b_{n} \\} $ and $\\{ \\, d_{n} \\} $. In particular, we compute the binomial transform of the sequences $\\left\\{n(n-1)...(n-m+1)\\, a_{n} \\right\\}$ and $\\{ \\, a_{k} {\\kern 1pt} x^{k} \\} $ in terms of $\\left\\{b_{n} \\right\\}$. 844	en_US	title	A characterization of plane Gauss paragraphs	string
844	en_US	cleanTitle	A characterization of plane Gauss paragraphs	string
844	en_US	abstract	<p>Gauss first studied representations of self-intersecting curves in the plane using only lists of their crossings in the sequence as they occur when traversing a curve, i.e., representations using Gauss words. The characterisation of words that are Gauss words has been elusive for a long time, and only in recent decades have some good characterizations been established. Together with these, the interest in Gauss paragraphs, i.e., representations of sets of curves by sets of words listing their sequences of crossings, has came to light, and we are unaware of a (good) characterization of abstract sets of words that are Gauss paragraphs. We establish such a characterization and we show that characterizing Gauss paragraphs is algorithmically equivalent to characterizing Gauss words, as there exists a word <span class="math"><em>W</em></span> that can be obtained from a set of words <span class="math"><em>P</em></span> in linear time, such that <span class="math"><em>P</em></span> is a Gauss paragraph if and only if <span class="math"><em>W</em></span> is a Gauss word.</p>	string
844	en_US	discipline	geometric and topological aspects of graph theory	string

845	en_US	title	New bounds for the sum of powers of normalized Laplacian eigenvalues of graphs	string
845	en_US	cleanTitle	New bounds for the sum of powers of normalized Laplacian eigenvalues of graphs	string
845	en_US	abstract	<p>For a simple and connected graph, a new graph invariant <span class="math"><em>s</em><sub><em>α</em></sub><sup> * </sup>(<em>G</em>)</span>, defined as the sum of <span class="math"><em>α</em></span> powers of the eigenvalues of the normalized Laplacian matrix, has been introduced by Bozkurt and Bozkurt (2012). Lower and upper bounds for this index have been proposed by the authors. In this paper, we localize the eigenvalues of the normalized Laplacian matrix by adapting a theoretical method, proposed in Bianchi and Torriero (2000), based on majorization techniques. Through this approach we derive upper and lower bounds of <span class="math"><em>s</em><sub><em>α</em></sub><sup> * </sup>(<em>G</em>)</span>. Some numerical examples show how sharper results can be obtained with respect to those existing in literature.</p>	string

848	en_US	title	<em>χ</em><sub><em>D</em></sub>(<em>G</em>), |Aut(<em>G</em>)|, and a variant of the Motion Lemma	string
848	en_US	cleanTitle	<em>χ</em><sub><em>D</em></sub><em>G</em> |Aut<em>G</em>| and a variant of the Motion Lemma	string
848	en_US	abstract	<p>The <em>Distinguishing Chromatic Number</em> of a graph <span class="math"><em>G</em></span>, denoted <span class="math"><em>χ</em><sub><em>D</em></sub>(<em>G</em>)</span>, was first defined in K. L. Collins and A. N. Trenk, The distinguishing chromatic number, Electron. J. Combin. 13 (2006), #R16, as the minimum number of colors needed to properly color <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> such that no non-trivial automorphism <span class="math"><em>ϕ</em></span> of the graph <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> fixes each color class of <span class="math"><em>G</em></span>. In this paper,</p><ol><li><p>We prove a lemma that may be considered a variant of the Motion lemma of A. Russell and R. Sundaram, A note on the asympotics and computational complexity of graph distinguishability, Electron. J. Combin. 5 (1998), #R23, and use this to give examples of several families of graphs which satisfy <span class="math"><em>χ</em><sub><em>D</em></sub>(<em>G</em>) = <em>χ</em>(<em>G</em>) + 1</span>.</p></li><li><p>We give an example of families of graphs that admit large automorphism groups in which every proper coloring is distinguishing. We also describe families of graphs with (relatively) very small automorphism groups which satisfy <span class="math"><em>χ</em><sub><em>D</em></sub>(<em>G</em>) = <em>χ</em>(<em>G</em>) + 1</span>, for arbitrarily large values of <span class="math"><em>χ</em>(<em>G</em>)</span>.</p></li><li><p>We describe non-trivial families of bipartite graphs that satisfy <span class="math"><em>χ</em><sub><em>D</em></sub>(<em>G</em>) &gt; <em>r</em></span> for any positive integer <span class="math"><em>r</em></span>.</p></li></ol>	string

850	en_US	abstract	<div class="page" title="Page 1"><div class="layoutArea"><div class="column"><p><span style="font-size: 11.000000pt; font-family: 'CMR10';">Bisectors of line segments are quite simple geometrical objects. Despite their sim- plicity, they have many surprising and useful properties. As metric objects, the shape of bisectors depends upon the metric considered. If </span><span style="font-size: 11.000000pt; font-family: 'CMMI10';">p</span><span style="font-size: 11.000000pt; font-family: 'CMR10';">-norms are used as metrics in the plane, the corresponding </span><span style="font-size: 11.000000pt; font-family: 'CMMI10';">p</span><span style="font-size: 11.000000pt; font-family: 'CMR10';">-bisectors of a fixed line segment appear to be different curves (or regions!) blue among the various </span><span style="font-size: 11.000000pt; font-family: 'CMMI10';">p </span><span style="font-size: 11.000000pt; font-family: 'CMR10';">and in fact they are. However, the picture suggests more: it shows that all </span><span style="font-size: 11.000000pt; font-family: 'CMMI10';">p</span><span style="font-size: 11.000000pt; font-family: 'CMR10';">-bisectors must have three (and only three) points in common. There was no proof of this picture in previous literature, so we provide one here together with a handful of amusing facts about bisectors. </span></p></div></div></div>	string

851	en_US	abstract	<p>A matching <em>M</em> in a graph <em>G</em> is maximal if it cannot be extended to a larger matching in <em>G</em>. 854	en_US	abstract	<div>The edge version of classical Zagreb indices $M_1^2(G)$ and $M_2^1(G)$ are known as reformulated Zagreb indices denoted by $EM_1^2(G)$ and $EM_2^1(G)$. In this paper we  analyze the upper and lower bounds for the first and second general reformulated Zagreb indices $EM_1^\\alpha(G)$ and $EM_2^\\alpha(G).$ The AutographiX \\cite{conjecture} conjectured ${{M_1^2(G)} \\mathord{\\left/</div><div> {\\vphantom {{M_1^2(G)} n}} \\right. \\kern-\\nulldelimiterspace} n} \\le {{M_2^1(G)} \\mathord{\\left/ {\\vphantom {{M_2^1(G)} m}} \\right. \\kern-\\nulldelimiterspace} m}$ for simple connected graphs with $n$ vertices and $m$ edges. 856	en_US	title	Cycle bases of reduced powers of graphs	string
856	en_US	cleanTitle	Cycle bases of reduced powers of graphs	string
856	en_US	abstract	<p>We define what appears to be a new construction. Given a graph <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> and a positive integer <span class="math"><em>k</em></span>, the <span><em>reduced <span class="math"><em>k</em></span>th power of</em></span> <span class="math"><em>G</em></span>, denoted <span class="math"><em>G</em><sup>(<em>k</em>)</sup></span>, is the configuration space in which <span class="math"><em>k</em></span> indistinguishable tokens are placed on the vertices of <span class="math"><em>G</em></span>, so that any vertex can hold up to <span class="math"><em>k</em></span> tokens. Two configurations are adjacent if one can be transformed to the other by moving a single token along an edge to an adjacent vertex. We present propositions related to the structural properties of reduced graph powers and, most significantly, provide a construction of minimum cycle bases of <span class="math"><em>G</em><sup>(<em>k</em>)</sup></span>.</p><p>The minimum cycle basis construction is an interesting combinatorial problem that is also useful in applications involving configuration spaces. For example, if <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> is the state-transition graph of a Markov chain model of a stochastic automaton, the reduced power <span class="math"><em>G</em><sup>(<em>k</em>)</sup></span> is the state-transition graph for <span class="math"><em>k</em></span> identical (but not necessarily independent) automata. We show how the minimum cycle basis construction of <span class="math"><em>G</em><sup>(<em>k</em>)</sup></span> may be used to confirm that state-dependent coupling of automata does not violate the principle of microscopic reversibility, as required in physical and chemical applications.</p>	string

Moreover, we prove that these spaces are linearly isomorphic to the spaces $l_{\\infty},\\; c_{0}$ and $c$. We also make an effort to establish  some inclusion relations between these spaces. 858	en_US	title	Two characterizations of simple circulant tournaments	string
858	en_US	cleanTitle	Two characterizations of simple circulant tournaments	string
858	en_US	abstract	<p>The \\textit{acyclic disconnection} $\\overrightarrow{\\omega }(D)$<br />(resp. the\\textit{directed triangle free disconnection } $\\overrightarrow{\\omega }_{3}(D)$) of a digraph $D$ is defined as the maximum possible number<br />of connected components of the underlying graph of $D\\setminus<br />A(D^{\\ast })$ where $D^{\\ast }$ is an acyclic (resp. a directed<br />triangle free) subdigraph of $D$. We say that $\\pi $ is an \\textit{externally acyclic }(resp. a\\textit{\\ }$\\overrightarrow{C}_{3}$\\textit{-free})\\textit{\\ partition }ifthe set ofexternal arcs of $D$ (an arc $(u,v)$ of $D$ is said to be \\textit{external } if\\textit{\\ }$u$ and $v$ belong to different equivalence classes of $\\pi $) induces an acyclic subdigraph (resp. a<br />$\\overrightarrow{C}_{3}$-free subdigraph) of $D.$ A digraph $D$ is said to be $\\overrightarrow{\\omega }$ \\textit{-keen }(resp. $\\overrightarrow{\\omega<br />}_{3}$\\textit{-keen})\\textit{\\ }if there exists an optimal<br />externally acyclic (resp. $\\overrightarrow{C}_{3} $-free) partition<br />$\\pi $ of $V(D)$ having exactly one equivalence class of<br />cardinality one and no externally acyclic (resp. $\\overrightarrow{C}_{3}$%<br />-free) partition leaves more than one such a class. In this paper,<br />we generalize some previous results and solve some problems<br />posed by V. Neumann-Lara (The acyclic disconnection of a digraph,<br />Discrete Math. 197/198 (1999), 617-632). Let<br />$\\overrightarrow{C}_{2n+1}(J)$ be a circulant<br />tournament. We prove that $\\overrightarrow{C}_{2n+1}(J)$ is $\\overrightarrow{%<br />\\omega }$-keen and $\\overrightarrow{\\omega _{3}}$-keen, respectively, and $%<br />\\overrightarrow{\\omega }(\\overrightarrow{C}_{2n+1}(J))=\\overrightarrow{%<br />\\omega }_{3}(\\overrightarrow{C}_{2n+1}(J))=2$ for every $\\overrightarrow{C}%<br />_{2n+1}(J)$. Finally, it is showed that $\\overrightarrow{\\omega }_{3}(%<br />\\overrightarrow{C}_{2n+1}(J))=2$, $\\overrightarrow{C}_{2n+1}(J)$ is<br />simple and $J$ is aperiodic are equivalent propositions. The proofs<br />of the results are essentially based on classic results for abelian<br />groups of additive number theory.</p>	string

862	en_US	title	Growth of face-homogeneous tessellations	string
862	en_US	cleanTitle	Growth of facehomogeneous tessellations	string
862	en_US	abstract	A tessellation of the plane is <em>face-homogeneous</em> if for some integer <span class="math inline"><em>k</em> ≥ 3</span> there exists a cyclic sequence <span class="math inline"><em>σ</em> = [<em>p</em><sub>0</sub>, <em>p</em><sub>1</sub>, …, <em>p</em><sub><em>k</em> − 1</sub>]</span> of integers <span class="math inline">≥ 3</span> such that, for every face <span class="math inline"><em>f</em></span> of the tessellation, the valences of the vertices incident with <span class="math inline"><em>f</em></span> are given by the terms of <span class="math inline"><em>σ</em></span> in either clockwise or counter-clockwise order. When a given cyclic sequence <span class="math inline"><em>σ</em></span> is realizable in this way, it may determine a unique tessellation (up to isomorphism), in which case <span class="math inline"><em>σ</em></span> is called <em>monomorphic</em>, or it may be the valence sequence of two or more non-isomorphic tessellations (<em>polymorphic</em>). A tessellation whose faces are uniformly bounded in the hyperbolic plane but not uniformly bounded in the Euclidean plane is called a <span><em>hyperbolic tessellation</em></span>. Such tessellations are well-known to have exponential growth. We seek the face-homogeneous hyperbolic tessellation(s) of slowest growth rate and show that the least growth rate of such monomorphic tessellations is the “golden mean,” <span class="math inline">γ = (1+√5)/2</span>, attained by the sequences <span class="math inline">[4, 6, 14]</span> and <span class="math inline">[3, 4, 7, 4]</span>. A polymorphic sequence may yield non-isomorphic tessellations with different growth rates. However, all such tessellations found thus far grow at rates greater than <span class="math inline"><em>γ</em></span>.	string
862	en_US	discipline	Mathematics	string

863	en_US	title	Relative edge betweenness centrality	string
863	en_US	cleanTitle	Relative edge betweenness centrality	string
863	en_US	abstract	<p>We introduce a new edge centrality measure - relative edge betweenness <span class="math"><em>γ</em>(<em>u</em><em>v</em>) = <em>b</em>(<em>u</em><em>v</em>) /<span>√</span>(<em>c</em>(<em>u</em>)<em>c</em>(<em>v</em>))</span>, where <span class="math"><em>b</em>(<em>u</em><em>v</em>)</span> is the standard edge betweenness and <span class="math"><em>c</em>(<em>u</em>)</span> is the adjusted vertex betweenness. In this alternative definition, the importance of an edge is normalized with respect to the importance of its end-vertices. This gives a better presentation of the “local” importance of an edge, i.e. its importance in the near neighborhood. We present sharp upper and lower bounds on this invariant together with the characterization of graphs attaining these bounds. In addition, we discuss the bounds for various interesting graph families, and state several open problems.</p>	string

867	en_US	title	Crosscap number distributions of cubic outerplanar graphs	string
867	en_US	cleanTitle	Crosscap number distributions of cubic outerplanar graphs	string
867	en_US	abstract	The \\mdef{genus distribution} and \\mdef{crosscap number distribution} are defined to be the sequence $\\{a_i(G)|i \\geq0\\}$ and $\\{b_j(G)|j \\geq 1\\}$ respectively, where $a_i(G)$ and $b_j(G)$ are the number of embeddings into orientable surface $S_i$ and non-orientable surface $N_j$ respectively.  Gross  developed a quadratic-time for calculating genus distributions of cubic outerplanar graphs [J. Graph Algorithms and Applications, 15 (2011), 295-316].  By using a different approach, a recursive formula for the total embedding distributions of all \\mdef{cubic outerplanar graphs} is obtained.  Furthermore, we present a $O\\left(n(h+\\Delta)\\right)$-time algorithm for computing genus distribution and crosscap number distributions of any cubic outerplanar graph based on the recursive formula, where $h$ and $\\Delta$ are the \\mdef{height} and \\mdef{maximum degree} of the characteristic tree, respectively. The main idea of the algorithm is that we encode total embedding distributions of cubic outerplanar graphs as a preorder traverse of the characteristic tree. In addition, the explicit formulas for embeddings of cubic outerplanar graphs into plane, torus, projective plane and Klein bottle are also given. With a computer program, we also verified the genus distributions of all cubic outerplanar graphs are log-concave whose vertices less that $33,$ this provide further evidence that support the conjecture that the genus distribution of a graph is log-concave.	string

868	en_US	abstract	The actions of the Picard group PSL(2,O₁), where O₁ is the ring of Gaussian integers, on projective lines over the finite fields PL(Fp), yield worthwhile results. In this work, we are interested in parameterizing the actions of Πη=PSL(2,O₁)_[A,B]^η on PL(Fp). We consider a class of primes p≡1(mod8) to investigate the behavior of the action of Π₃ on PL(Fp). Furthermore, we conclude that for p≡1(mod8) there is a natural homomorphism induced from Π₃ to PL(Fp) which evolves S₄ as a homomorphic image of PSL(2,O₁). Moreover, we develop a formula to count the total number of orbits for the actions of Π₃ on PL(Fp).	string

873	en_US	abstract	<p>A total-colored graph $G$ is total rainbow connected if any two<br />vertices are connected by a path whose edges and inner vertices have<br />distinct colors. 876	en_US	title	Lifting symmetric pictures to polyhedral scenes	string
876	en_US	cleanTitle	Lifting symmetric pictures to polyhedral scenes	string
876	en_US	abstract	<p>Scene analysis is concerned with the reconstruction of <span class="math"><em>d</em></span>-dimensional objects, such as polyhedral surfaces, from <span class="math">(<em>d</em> − 1)</span>-dimensional pictures (i.e., projections of the objects onto a hyperplane). In this paper we study the impact of symmetry on the lifting properties of pictures. We first use methods from group representation theory to show that the lifting matrix of a symmetric picture can be transformed into a block-diagonalized form. Using this result we then derive new symmetry-extended counting conditions for a picture with a non-trivial symmetry group in an arbitrary dimension to be minimally flat (i.e., ‘non-liftable’). These conditions imply very simply stated restrictions on the number of those structural components of the picture that are fixed by the various symmetry operations of the picture. We then also transfer lifting results for symmetric pictures from Euclidean <span class="math">(<em>d</em> − 1)</span>-space to Euclidean <span class="math"><em>d</em></span>-space via the technique of coning. Finally, we offer some conjectures regarding sufficient conditions for a picture realized generically for a symmetry group to be minimally flat.</p>	string

877	en_US	cleanTitle	On Atombond Connectivity Index and Diameter of Unicyclic Graphs	string
877	en_US	abstract	The atom-bond connectivity index of a graph $G$ is $ABC(G) = \\sum\\limits_{uv \\in E(G)} {\\sqrt {\\frac{{d(u)  + d(v)  - 2}}{{d(u)  \\cdot d(v) }}} } $<br />where $d(u)$ stands for the degree of a vertex $u$ in $G$. It is interesting to study the relationship between<br />the atom-bond connectivity index and the diameter since the  atom-bond connectivity index depends on degree of vertices <br />whereas the diameter depends on distance. In this paper, we discuss the relations between the atom-bond connectivity index and diameter of unicyclic graphs. Let $v$ be one of the terminal vertices in a diametrical path of $G$ and $u$ be a neighbor of $v$. If $N(u)$ just has one vertex of degree at least 2 and $D(G - v) = D(G)- 1$, $ABC(G) - D(G) \\le \\left( {\\sqrt {\\frac{1}{2}}  - 1} \\right)n + 2$, where equality holds if $G = C_3  + P_{n - 3}$. Otherwise, $ABC(G) - D(G) &gt; \\left( {\\sqrt {\\frac{1}{2}}  - 1} \\right)n + 2$.	string

886	en_US	abstract	<p>A signed graph (or sigraph, in short) is an ordered pair S = (Su, ), where Su<br />is a graph G = (V,E), called the underlying graph of S and  : E ! {+, −} is a<br />function from the edge set E of Su into the set {+, −}, called the signature of S.<br />A sigraph is also denoted as S = (V,E, ). 887	en_US	title	Involutes of polygons of constant width in Minkowski planes	string
887	en_US	cleanTitle	Involutes of polygons of constant width in Minkowski planes	string
887	en_US	abstract	Consider a convex polygon <em>P</em> in the plane, and denote by <em>U</em> a homothetical copy of the vector sum of <em>P</em> and -<em>P</em>. Then the polygon <em>U</em>, as unit ball, induces a norm such that, with respect to this norm, P has constant Minkowskian width. We define notions like Minkowskian curvature, evolutes and involutes for polygons of constant <em>U</em>-width, and we prove that many properties of the smooth case, which is already completely studied, are preserved. The iteration of involutes generates a pair of sequences of polygons of constant width with respect to the Minkowski norm and its dual norm, respectively. We prove that these sequences are converging to symmetric polygons with the same center, which can be regarded as a central point of the polygon <em>P</em>.	string

888	en_US	title	Equitable coloring of Cartesian product of generalized Peterson graphs with complete bipartite graphs	string
888	en_US	cleanTitle	Equitable coloring of Cartesian product of generalized Peterson graphs with complete bipartite graphs	string
888	en_US	abstract	A graph $G$ is said to be equitably $k$-colorable if the vertex set of $G$ can be divided into $k$<br /> independent sets for which any two sets differ in size at most one.  The equitable chromatic number of $G$, $\\chi_{=}(G)$, is the minimum $k$ for which $G$ is equitably $k$-colorable.<br /> The equitable chromatic threshold of $G$, $\\chi_{=}^{\\ast}(G)$, is the minimum $k$ for which $G$ is<br /> equitably $k'$-colorable for all $k'\\geq k$. In this paper, the exact values of $\\chi_{=}^{\\ast}(P_{n',2}\\Box K_{m,n})$ and $\\chi_{=}(P_{n',2}\\Box K_{m,n})$ are obtained except that $3\\leq\\chi_{=}^{\\ast}(P_{5,2}\\Box K_{m,n})=\\chi_{=}(P_{5,2}\\Box K_{m,n})\\leq4$ when $m+n&gt;3min\\{m,n\\}+2$ or $m+n&lt;3min\\{m,n\\}-2$.	string

889	en_US	title	On the spectral determination of Kite graphs	string
889	en_US	cleanTitle	On the spectral determination of Kite graphs	string
889	en_US	abstract	The \\textit{Kite graph}, denoted by $Kite_{p,q}$  is obtained by appending a complete graph $K_{p}$ to a pendant vertex of a path $P_{q}$. In this paper, firstly we show that no two non-isomorphic kite graphs are cospectral w.r.t adjacency matrix. Let $G$ be a graph which is cospectral with $Kite_{p,q}$  and the clique number of $G$ is denoted by $w(G)$. Then, it is shown that $w(G)\\geq p-2q+1$. Also, we prove that $Kite_{p,2}$  graphs are determined by their adjacency spectrum.	string

891	en_US	title	Domination game on paths and cycles	string
891	en_US	cleanTitle	Domination game on paths and cycles	string
891	en_US	abstract	<p>Domination game is a game on a simple graph played by two players, Dominator and Staller, who are alternating in taking turns. In each turn a player chooses a vertex in such a way that at least one new vertex gets dominated by this move. The game ends when all vertices are dominated, and thus no legal move is possible. As the names of the players suggest, Dominator tries to finish the game as fast as possible, while Staller wants to prolong its end as long as she can. By <span class="math"><em>γ</em><sub><em>g</em></sub></span> (<span class="math"><em>γ</em><sub><em>g</em></sub>ʹ</span>) we denote the total number of moves in the game when Dominator (resp. Staller) starts, and both players play according to their optimal strategies. In a manuscript from 2012, Kinnersley et al. determined <span class="math"><em>γ</em><sub><em>g</em></sub></span> and <span class="math"><em>γ</em><sub><em>g</em></sub>ʹ</span> for paths and cycles, but have not yet published this very important result. In this paper we give an alternative proof for these formulas. Our approach also explicitly describes optimal strategies for both players.</p>	string
891	en_US	discipline	discrete mathematics; graph theory; domination	string

891	en_US	subject	Domination game, game domination number, paths, cycles	string

892	en_US	title	The bipartite vertex frustration of line graphs	string
892	en_US	cleanTitle	The bipartite vertex frustration of line graphs	string
892	en_US	abstract	The bipartite vertex (resp. edge) frustration of a graph $G$, denoted by $\\psi(G)$ (resp. $\\varphi(G)$), is the smallest number of vertices (resp. edges) that have to be deleted from $G$ to obtain a bipartite subgraph of $G$. A sharp lower bound of the bipartite vertex frustration of the line graph $L(G)$ of every graph $G$ is given. In addition, the exact value of $\\psi(L(G))$ is calculated when $G$ is a forest.	string

894	en_US	title	Parity Domination in Direct and Strong Products of Graphs	string
894	en_US	cleanTitle	Parity Domination in Direct and Strong Products of Graphs	string
894	en_US	abstract	An odd open dominating set of a graph is a subset of the graph's vertices with the property that the open neighborhood of each vertex in the graph contains an odd number of vertices in the subset.  An odd closed $r$-dominating set is a subset of the graph's vertices with the property that the closed $r$-ball centered at each vertex in the graph contains an odd number of vertices in the subset. In this paper we show that the $n$-fold direct product of simple graphs has an odd open dominating set if and only if each factor has an odd open dominating set.  Secondly, we show that the $n$-fold strong product of simple graphs has an odd closed $r$-dominating set if and only if each factor has an odd closed $r$-dominating set.	string

895	en_US	title	ADJACENCY AND SHIFT-TRANSITIVITY IN GRAPH PRODUCTS	string
895	en_US	cleanTitle	ADJACENCY AND SHIFTTRANSITIVITY IN GRAPH PRODUCTS	string
895	en_US	abstract	Let $\\Gamma$ be a finite simple graph with automorphism group $\\Aut(\\Gamma).$<br />An automorphism $\\sigma$ of $\\Gamma$ is said to be an adjacency automorphism, if for every vertex<br />$x\\in V(\\Gamma)$, either $\\sigma x=x$ or $\\sigma x$ is adjacent to<br />$x$ in $\\Gamma$. A shift is an adjacency automorphism fixing no vertices. The graph<br />$\\Gamma$ is (shift) adjacency-transitive if for every pair of vertices $x, x'\\in V(\\Gamma)$,<br />there exists a sequence of (shift) adjacency automorphisms $\\sigma_{1},\\sigma_{2},...\\sigma_{k}\\in\\Aut(\\Gamma)$<br />such that $\\sigma_{1}\\sigma_{2}...\\sigma_{k}x=x'$. If, in addition, for every pair of<br />adjacent vertices $x, x'\\in V(\\Gamma)$ there exists an (shift) adjacency automorphism say<br />$\\sigma\\in \\Aut(\\Gamma)$ sending $x$ to $x'$, then $\\Gamma$ is strongly (shift) adjacency-transitive.<br />If for every pair of adjacent vertices $x, x'\\in V(\\Gamma)$ there exists exactly one shift $\\sigma\\in\\Aut(\\Gamma)$<br />sending $x$ to $x'$, then $\\Gamma$ is uniquely shift-transitive. In this paper, we investigate these concepts in<br />some standard graph products.	string

896	en_US	abstract	<p>A Langford sequence of order <span class="math"><em>m</em></span> and defect <span class="math"><em>d</em></span> can be identified with a labeling of the vertices of a path of order <span class="math">2<em>m</em></span> in which each label from <span class="math"><em>d</em></span> up to <span class="math"><em>d</em> + <em>m</em> − 1</span> appears twice and in which the vertices that have been labeled with <span class="math"><em>k</em></span> are at distance <span class="math"><em>k</em></span>. We study these labelings for some well known families of graphs. We also study the existence of these labelings in general. Finally, given a sequence or a set of nonnegative integers, we study the existence of graphs that can be labeled according to this sequence or set.</p>	string

910	en_US	abstract	We discuss functions from the edges and vertices of a directed graph to an Abelian group. A function is called balanced if the sum of its values along any cycle is zero. 918	en_US	abstract	A variation of the classical <span>Wiener</span> index, the modified <span>Wiener</span> index, that was introduced in 1991 by <span>Graovac</span> and <span>Pisanski</span>, takes into account the symmetries of a given graph. 921	en_US	title	A novel characterization of cubic Hamiltonian graphs via the associated quartic graphs	string
921	en_US	cleanTitle	A novel characterization of cubic Hamiltonian graphs via the associated quartic graphs	string
921	en_US	abstract	<p>We give a necessary and sufficient condition for a cubic graph to be Hamiltonian by analyzing Eulerian tours in certain spanning subgraphs of the quartic graph associated with the cubic graph by <span class="math">1</span>-factor contraction. This correspondence is most useful in the case when it induces a blue and red <span class="math">2</span>-factorization of the associated quartic graph. We use this condition to characterize the Hamiltonian <span class="math"><em>I</em></span>-graphs, a further generalization of generalized Petersen graphs. The characterization of Hamiltonian <span class="math"><em>I</em></span>-graphs follows from the fact that one can choose a <span class="math">1</span>-factor in any <span class="math"><em>I</em></span>-graph in such a way that the corresponding associated quartic graph is a graph bundle having a cycle graph as base graph and a fiber and the fundamental factorization of graph bundles playing the role of blue and red factorization. The techniques that we develop allow us to represent Cayley multigraphs of degree <span class="math">4</span>, that are associated to abelian groups, as graph bundles. Moreover, we can find a family of connected cubic (multi)graphs that contains the family of connected <span class="math"><em>I</em></span>-graphs as a subfamily.</p>	string

924	en_US	abstract	<p>A distance spectrum of a graph is a set of eigenvalues of its distance matrix. A distance energy, which is a useful molecular descriptor in QSPR modelling, is the sum of absolute values of distance eigenvalues. In the paper we consider <em>H</em>-join on graphs, where <em>H</em> is an arbitrary graph. In terms of distance matrix, we determine the <em>D</em>-spectra of graphs obtained by this operation on distance regular graphs of diameter at most 2. 925	en_US	title	On the reliability of generalized Petersen graphs	string
925	en_US	cleanTitle	On the reliability of generalized Petersen graphs	string
925	en_US	abstract	The connectivity (edge connectivity) of a connected graph $G$ is the minimum number of vertices (edges) that need to be deleted from $G$ in order to create a disconnected or a trivial graph. If at least one of the components of the disconnected graph is an isolated vertex, then the graph is said to be super--connected (resp. super edge--connected). In this case, a related and natural question is to ask what the minimum number of vertices (edges) that need to be deleted from $G$ in order not to create an isolated vertex is. If such a set of vertices (edges) exists, it is called a super vertex--cut of $G$ (resp. super edge--cut of $G$) and its cardinality gives the super--connectivity (resp. super edge--connectivity) of $G$. In this article we examine the super--connectivity and super edge--connectivity of the class of generalized Petersen graphs $GP[n,k]$, and determine when the graphs in this class are super--connected and super edge--connected. We also show that the generalized Petersen graphs $ GP[n,k] $ have super--connectivity and super edge--connectivity equal to four, when $ n\\notin\\{2k,3k\\} $. These results are of interest especially in the study of reliability and fault tolerance of interconnection networks, since the graphs in this class are good candidates for such networks.	string
925	en_US	discipline	Mathematics; Graph Theory	string
925	en_US	subjectClass	MSC 05C40; MSC 94C15	string
925	en_US	subject	Super connectivity; Super edge--connectivity; Generalized Petersen graph; Networks	string
925	en_US	sponsor		string

933	en_US	abstract	In this paper, we build on the work of Alspach, Chen, and Dean.  Proving the hamiltonicity of the Cayley graph of the dihedral group reduces to showing certain graphs, called <em>honeycomb toriodal graphs </em>are <em>hamilton laceable.</em>  In this paper, we examine the unsolved case of this problem, where the order of the graph is 2 mod 4.  We first show that the hamilton-laceability of these graphs reduces to the degenerate case, and then we show that when n is at least 4s^2, (where the graphs has 2n vertices), these graphs are hamilton-laceable.  Here <em>s </em>is the so-called <em>shift</em> parameter.	string

937	en_US	title	An infinite class of movable 5-configurations	string
937	en_US	cleanTitle	An infinite class of movable 5configurations	string
937	en_US	abstract	<p>A geometric <span class="math">5</span>-configuration is a collection of points and straight lines, typically in the Euclidean plane, in which every point has <span class="math">5</span> lines passing through it and every line has <span class="math">5</span> points lying on it; that is, it is an <span class="math">(<em>n</em><sub>5</sub>)</span> configuration for some number <span class="math"><em>n</em></span> of points and lines. Using reduced Levi graphs and two elementary geometric lemmas, we develop a construction that produces infinitely many new 5-configurations which are movable; in particular, we produce infinitely many 5-configurations with one continuous degree of freedom, and we produce 5-configurations with <span class="math"><em>k</em> − 2</span> continuous degrees of freedom for all odd <span class="math"><em>k</em> &gt; 2</span>.</p>	string

938	en_US	title	On <i>t</i>-fold covers of coherent configurations	string
938	en_US	cleanTitle	On <i>t</i>fold covers of coherent configurations	string
938	en_US	abstract	We introduce the covering configuration induced by a regular weight defined on a coherent configuration. This construction generalizes the well-known equivalence of regular two-graphs and antipodal double covers of complete graphs. It also recovers, as special cases, the rank 6 association schemes connected with regular 3-graphs, and certain extended Q-bipartite doubles of cometric association schemes. We articulate sufficient conditions on the parameters of a coherent configuration for it to arise as a covering configuration.	string

939	en_US	title	Calculating genus polynomials via string operations and matrices	string
939	en_US	cleanTitle	Calculating genus polynomials via string operations and matrices	string
939	en_US	abstract	<p>To calculate the genus polynomials for a recursively specifiable sequence of graphs, the set of cellular imbeddings in oriented surfaces for each of the graphs is usually partitioned into <em>imbedding-types</em>. The effects of a recursively applied graph operation <span class="math inline"><em>τ</em></span> on each imbedding-type are represented by a <em>production matrix</em>. When the operation <span class="math inline"><em>τ</em></span> amounts to constructing the next member of the sequence by attaching a copy of a fixed graph <span class="math inline"><em>H</em></span> to the previous member, Stahl called the resulting sequence of graphs an <em><span class="math inline"><em>H</em></span>-linear family</em>. We demonstrate herein how representing the imbedding types by strings and the operation <span class="math inline"><em>τ</em></span> by <em>string operations</em> enables us to automate the calculation of the production matrices, a task requiring time proportional to the square of the number of imbedding-types.</p>	string
939	en_US	discipline	Graph theory, topological graph theory	string
939	en_US	subjectClass	05A15, 05A20, 05C10	string
939	en_US	subject	Graph imbedding, genus polynomial, production matrix, transfer matrix method	string

In this paper, we fully and partially characterize the 2-adic valuations of T_n(4) and T_n(5), respectively. 946	en_US	title	The nullity of bicyclic graphs in terms of their matching number	string
946	en_US	cleanTitle	The nullity of bicyclic graphs in terms of their matching number	string
946	en_US	abstract	<p>Let G be a graph with n(G) vertices and m(G) be its matching number. The<br />nullity of G, denoted by η(G), is the multiplicity of the eigenvalue zero of adjacency matrix of<br />G. It is well known that if G is a tree, then η(G) = n(G) − 2m(G). J.M. Guo et al.[Jiming<br />Guo, Weigen Yan, Yeongnan Yeh, On the nullity and the matching number of unicyclic<br />graphs, Linear Alg.Appl. 431(2009) 1293-1301] proved that if G is a unicyclic graph, then<br />η(G) equals n(G) − 2m(G) − 1, n(G) − 2m(G), or n(G) − 2m(G) + 2. In this paper, we<br />proved that if G is a bicyclic graph, then η(G) equals n(G) − 2m(G), n(G) − 2m(G) ± 1,<br />n(G)−2m(G)±2 or n(G)−2m(G)+4. We also give the characterization of these six types<br />of bicyclic graphs corresponding to each nullity.</p>	string

It<br />is well known that if G is a tree, then η(G) = n(G)−2m(G). J.M. Guo et al.[Jiming Guo,<br />Weigen Yan, Yeongnan Yeh, On the nullity and the matching number of unicyclic graphs,<br />Linear Alg.Appl. 431(2009) 1293-1301] proved that if G is a unicyclic graph, then η(G)<br />equals n(G) − 2m(G) − 1, n(G) − 2m(G), or n(G) − 2m(G) + 2. 948	en_US	title	The bipartite-splittance of a bipartite graph	string
948	en_US	cleanTitle	The bipartitesplittance of a bipartite graph	string
948	en_US	abstract	A {\\it bipartite-split graph} is a<br />bipartite graph whose vertex set can be partitioned into a complete<br />bipartite set and an independent set. The {\\it bipartite-splittance}<br />of an arbitrary bipartite graph is the minimum number of edges to be<br />added or removed in order to produce a bipartite-split graph. In<br />this paper, we show that the bipartite-splittance of a bipartite<br />graph depends only on the degree sequence pair of the bipartite<br />graph, and an easily computable formula for it is derived. As a<br />corollary, a<br />simple characterization of the degree sequence pair of bipartite-split graphs is also given.	string

957	en_US	abstract	<p>An edge-coloring of a graph <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> is said to be odd if for each vertex <span class="math"><em>v</em></span> of <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> and each color <span class="math"><em>c</em></span>, the vertex <span class="math"><em>v</em></span> either uses the color <span class="math"><em>c</em></span> an odd number of times or does not use it at all. In this paper, we consider loopless subcubic graphs, and give a complete characterization in terms of the value of their odd chromatic index.</p>	string

964	en_US	abstract	<p>A graph is called <span><em>half-arc-transitive</em></span> if its full automorphism group acts transitively on vertices and edges, but not on arcs. It is well known that for any prime <span class="math"><em>p</em></span> there is no half-arc-transitive graph of order <span class="math"><em>p</em></span> or <span class="math"><em>p</em><sup>2</sup></span>. 967	en_US	title	THE AVERAGE BINDING NUMBER OF A GRAPH	string
967	en_US	cleanTitle	THE AVERAGE BINDING NUMBER OF A GRAPH	string
967	en_US	abstract	<p>The binding number of a graph is a measure of the vulnerability<br />of a graph. In this paper we investigate a refinement that<br />involves the average of a local version of the parameter. If $v$<br />is a vertex in a connected graph $G$, then $bind_v(G) =<br />\\min_{S_v\\in F(G)}\\{\\frac{|N(S_v)|}{|S_v|}\\},$ where $F(G) =<br />\\{v\\in V(G), S_v \\subset V(G) : S_v\\neq\\emptyset, N(S_v)\\neq<br />V(G)\\}$. The average binding number of \\textit{G} denoted by<br />$bind_{av}(G)$, is defined as $ bind_{av}(G)=\\frac{\\Sigma_{v\\in<br />V(G)} bind_v(G)}{n}, $ where $n$ will denote the number of<br />vertices in graph $G$ and $\\Sigma_{v\\in V(G)} bind_v(G)$ will<br />denote the sum over all vertices of \\textit{G}. Like the binding<br />number itself, this is a measure of the vulnerability of a graph,<br />but it is more sensitive. This paper, the average binding number<br />of some special graphs are obtained and some bounds of the average<br />binding number are given. Moreover some results about the average<br />binding number of graphs obtained by graph operations are given.</p>	string

968	en_US	title	Disjoint cliques in claw-free graphs	string
968	en_US	cleanTitle	Disjoint cliques in clawfree graphs	string
968	en_US	abstract	A graph is said to be claw-free if it does not contain an induced subgraph isomorphic to $K_{1,3}$. Let $s$ and $k$ be two integers with $0\\leq s\\leq k$ and let $G$ be a claw-free graph of order $n$. In this paper, we investigate clique partition problems in claw-free graphs. It is proved that if $n\\geq 3s+4(k-s)$ and $d(x)+d(y)\\geq n-2s+2k+1$ for any pair of non-adjacent vertices $x,y$ of $G$, then $G$ contains $s$ disjoint $K_3$s and $k-s$ disjoint $K_4$s such that all of them are disjoint. Moreover, the degree condition is sharp.	string
968	en_US	discipline	Mathematics;Combinatorics	string

969	en_US	title	Large circulant graphs of fixed diameter and arbitrary degree	string
969	en_US	cleanTitle	Large circulant graphs of fixed diameter and arbitrary degree	string
969	en_US	abstract	<p>We consider the degree-diameter problem for undirected and directed circulant graphs. To date, attempts to generate families of large circulant graphs of arbitrary degree for a given diameter have concentrated mainly on the diameter 2 case. We present a direct product construction yielding improved bounds for small diameters and introduce a new general technique for “stitching” together circulant graphs which enables us to improve the current best known asymptotic orders for every diameter. As an application, we use our constructions in the directed case to obtain upper bounds on the minimum size of a subset <span class="math"><em>A</em></span> of a cyclic group of order <span class="math"><em>n</em></span> such that the <span class="math"><em>k</em></span>-fold sumset <span class="math"><em>k</em><em>A</em></span> is equal to the whole group. We also present a revised table of largest known circulant graphs of small degree and diameter.</p>	string

970	en_US	title	The cycle index of the automorphism group of $\\mathbb{Z}_n$	string
970	en_US	cleanTitle	The cycle index of the automorphism group of \\mathbb{Z}_n	string
970	en_US	abstract	<pre><!--StartFragment-->We consider the group action of the <span>automorphism</span> group <span>$\\I_n=\\aut(\\Zz_n)$</span> on the set <span>$\\Zz_n$</span>, that is the set of residue classes modulo <span>$n$</span>. Clearly, this group action provides a representation of <span>$\\I_n$</span> as a permutation group acting on <span>$n$</span> points. One problem to be solved regarding this group action is to find its cycle index. Once it is found, there appears a vast class of related <span>enumerative</span> and computational problems with interesting applications. We provided the cycle index of specified group action in two ways. One of them is more abstract and hence compact, while another one is basically procedure of composing the cycle index from some <span>\\textit</span>{building blocks}. However, those <span>\\textit</span>{building blocks} are also well explained and finally presented in very detailed fashion.  <!--EndFragment--></pre>	string

974	en_US	title	Padovan-Type Sequences via Hurwitz Matrices	string
974	en_US	cleanTitle	PadovanType Sequences via Hurwitz Matrices	string
974	en_US	abstract	In this paper, we define the recurrence sequences by using the Hurwitz matrices which are obtained from the characteristic polynomials of the Padovan, the Pell-Padovan and the Jacobsthal-Padovan sequences and then, we obtain miscellaneous properties of these sequences. Also, we study these sequences modulo m and we obtain the cyclic groups which are generated by the generating matrices when read modulo m. Then we derive the relationships among the orders of the obtained cyclic groups and the periods of the defined sequences according to modulo m.  Furthermore, we extend the PadovanHurwitz, the Pell-Padovan-Hurwitz sequences to groups. Finally, we obtain the lengths of the periods of the extended sequences in the semidihedral group 2mSD and the modular maximal-cyclic group M _(2) Mm for 4 m as applications of the results obtained.	string

975	en_US	abstract	<p>In this paper we introduce the notion of fundamental groupoid of a digraph<br />and prove its basic properties. 976	en_US	title	An algebraic proof of the Erdős-Ko-Rado theorem for intersecting families of perfect matchings	string
976	en_US	cleanTitle	An algebraic proof of the ErdősKoRado theorem for intersecting families of perfect matchings	string
976	en_US	abstract	<p>In this paper we give a proof that the largest set of perfect matchings, in which any two contain a common edge, is the set of all perfect matchings that contain a fixed edge. This is a version of the famous Erdős-Ko-Rado theorem for perfect matchings. The proof given in this paper is algebraic, we first determine the least eigenvalue of the perfect matching derangement graph and then use properties of the perfect matching polytope to prove the result.</p>	string
