979	en_US	title	A hypothetical algorithm which computes an upper bound for the heights of solutions of a Diophantine equation whose solution set is finite	string
979	en_US	cleanTitle	A hypothetical algorithm which computes an upper bound for the heights of solutions of a Diophantine equation whose solution set is finite	string
979	en_US	abstract	Let f(n)=1 if n=1, 2^(2^(n-2)) if n \\in {2,3,4,5}, (2+2^(2^(n-4)))^(2^(n-4)) if n \\in {6,7,8,...}. We conjecture that if a system T \\subseteq {x_i+1=x_k, x_i \\cdot x_j=x_k: i,j,k \\in {1,...,n}} has only finitely many solutions in integers x_1,...,x_n, then each such solution (x_1,...,x_n) satisfies |x_1|,...,|x_n| \\leq f(n). We prove that the function f cannot be decreased and the conjecture implies that there is an algorithm which takes as input a Diophantine equation, returns an integer, and this integer is greater than the heights of integer (non-negative integer, positive integer, rational) solutions, if the solution set is finite. We show that the conjecture and Matiyasevich's conjecture on finite-fold Diophantine representations are jointly inconsistent.	string

981	en_US	abstract	<p>The distinguishing index of a graph <span class="math"><em>G</em></span>, denoted by <span class="math"><em>D</em>ʹ(<em>G</em>)</span>, is the least number of colours in an edge colouring of <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> not preserved by any non-trivial automorphism. We characterize all connected graphs <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> with <span class="math"><em>D</em>ʹ(<em>G</em>) ≥ Δ (<em>G</em>)</span>. We show that <span class="math"><em>D</em>ʹ(<em>G</em>) ≤ 2</span> if <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> is a traceable graph of order at least seven, and <span class="math"><em>D</em>ʹ(<em>G</em>) ≤ 3</span> if <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> is either claw-free or <span class="math">3</span>-connected and planar. 982	en_US	title	Congruent triangles in arrangements of lines	string
982	en_US	cleanTitle	Congruent triangles in arrangements of lines	string
982	en_US	abstract	We study the maximum number of congruent triangles in finite arrangements of <span class="math inline">ℓ</span> lines in the Euclidean plane. Denote this number by <span class="math inline"><em>f</em>(ℓ)</span>. We show that <span class="math inline"><em>f</em>(5) = 5</span> and that the construction realizing this maximum is unique, <span class="math inline"><em>f</em>(6) = 8</span>, and <span class="math inline"><em>f</em>(7) = 14</span>. We also discuss for which integers <span class="math inline"><em>c</em></span> there exist arrangements on <span class="math inline">ℓ</span> lines with exactly <span class="math inline"><em>c</em></span> congruent triangles. In parallel, we treat the case when the triangles are faces of the plane graph associated to the arrangement (i.e. the interior of the triangle has empty intersection with every line in the arrangement). Lastly, we formulate four conjectures.	string

984	en_US	title	A conjecture on rational arithmetic which implies that there is an algorithm which decides whether or not a Diophantine equation has a rational solution	string
984	en_US	cleanTitle	A conjecture on rational arithmetic which implies that there is an algorithm which decides whether or not a Diophantine equation has a rational solution	string
984	en_US	abstract	The height of a rational number p/q is defined by max(|p|,|q|) provided p/q is written in lowest terms. The height of a rational tuple (x_1,...,x_n) is defined as the maximum of n and the heights of the numbers x_1,...,x_n. Let h:\\bigcup_{n=1}^\\infty Q^n \\to N\\{0} denote the height function. We conjecture that \\forall x_1,...,x_n \\in Q \\exists y_1,...,y_n \\in Q (n=1 ==&gt; h(y_1,...,y_n)=1) \\wedge (n \\geq 2 ==&gt; h(y_1,...,y_n) \\leq 2^(2^(n-2))) \\wedge \\forall i,j,k \\in {1,...,n} ((x_i+1=x_k ==&gt; y_i+1=y_k) \\wedge (x_i \\cdot x_j=x_k ==&gt; y_i \\cdot y_j=y_k)). We prove that the conjecture implies that there is an algorithm which decides whether or not a Diophantine equation has a rational solution.	string

990	en_US	cleanTitle	Nonuniform trichotomies and arbitrary growth rates	string
990	en_US	abstract	For a nonautonomous dynamics defined by a sequence of matrices, we consider the notion of a nonuniform exponential trichotomy for an arbitrary growth rate (this means that there may exist contracting, expanding and neutral directions with an arbitrary fixed growth rate). The purpose of our work is two-fold: to use a regularity coefficient in order to show that these trichotomies occur naturally and to provide several alternative characterizations of those for which the nonuniform part is arbitrarily small. This includes characterizations in terms of the growth rate of volumes and of the Lyapunov exponents of the dynamics and its adjoint. We also obtain sharp lower and upper bounds for the regularity coefficient.	string

992	en_US	abstract	Continuing the previous research, we consider trees with given number of vertices and minimal spectral gap. We provide theoretical results concerning double comets and putative trees that minimize the spectral gap. We also compare the spectral gap of regular graphs and paths. Finally, a sequence of inequalities that involve the same invariant is obtained.	string

996	en_US	title	On the distribution of subtree orders of a tree	string
996	en_US	cleanTitle	On the distribution of subtree orders of a tree	string
996	en_US	abstract	We investigate the distribution of the number of vertices of a randomly chosen subtree of a tree. Specifically, it is proven that this distribution is close to a Gaussian distribution in an explicitly quantifiable way if the tree has sufficiently many leaves and no long branchless paths. We also show that the conditions are satisfied asymptotically almost surely for random trees. If the conditions are violated, however, we exhibit by means of explicit counterexamples that many other (non-Gaussian) distributions can occur in the limit. These examples also show that our conditions are essentially best possible.	string

1859	en_US	cleanTitle	Regular and biregular planar cages	string
1859	en_US	abstract	<p>We study the \\textit{Cage Problem} for regular and biregular planar<br /> graphs. A $(k,g)$-\\textit{graph} is a $k$-regular graph with girth $g$. A $(k,g)$-\\textit{cage} is a $(k,g)$-graph of minimum order. It is not difficult to conclude that the \\textit{regular<br /> planar cages} are the \\textit{Platonic Solids}. A $(\\{r,m\\};g)$-\\textit{graph} is a graph of girth $g$ whose vertices have<br />degrees $r$ and $m.$ A $(\\{r,m\\};g)$-\\textit{cage} is a $(\\{r,m\\};g)$-graph of minimum order. In this case we determine the triplets of values $(\\{r,m\\};g)$ for which there exist planar $(\\{r,m\\};g)$--graphs, for all those values we construct examples. Furthermore, for many triplets $(\\{r,m\\};g)$ we build the $(\\{r,m\\};g)$-cages.</p>	string

The problem of establishing the set of values of <span class="math"><em>v</em></span> for which there exists an <span class="math"><em>f</em></span>-pyramidal Steiner triple system of order <span class="math"><em>v</em></span> has been deeply investigated in the case <span class="math"><em>f</em> = 1</span> but it remains open for a special class of values of <span class="math"><em>v</em></span>. 1000	en_US	title	Resonance graphs of fullerenes	string
1000	en_US	cleanTitle	Resonance graphs of fullerenes	string
1000	en_US	abstract	<p>A fullerene <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> is a <span class="math">3</span>-regular plane graph consisting only of pentagonal and hexagonal faces. The resonance graph <span class="math"><em>R</em>(<em>G</em>)</span> of <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> reflects the structure of its perfect matchings. The Zhang-Zhang polynomial of a fullerene is a counting polynomial of resonant structures called Clar covers. The cube polynomial is a counting polynomial of induced hypercubes in a graph.</p><p>In the present paper we show that the resonance graph of every fullerene is bipartite and each connected component has girth <span class="math">4</span> or is a path. Also, the equivalence of the Zhang-Zhang polynomial of a fullerene and the cube polynomial of its resonance graph is established. Furthermore, it is shown that every subgraph of the resonance graph isomorphic to a hypercube is an induced subgraph in the resonance graph. For benzenoid systems and tubulenes each connected component of the resonance graph is the covering graph of a distributive lattice; for fullerenes this is not true, as we show with an example.</p>	string

1001	en_US	title	On the Rational Function Solutions of Functional Equations Arising from Multiplication of Quantum Integers	string
1001	en_US	cleanTitle	On the Rational Function Solutions of Functional Equations Arising from Multiplication of Quantum Integers	string
1001	en_US	abstract	We prove results concerning rational function solutions of the functional equations arising from multiplication of quantum integers and thus resolve some problems raised by Melvyn Nathanson. First, we show that the rational function solutions contain more structure than the polynomial solutions in an essential way, namely the non-cyclotomic part of the former is no longer necessarily trivial, which allows us to resolve a problem on the associated Grothendieck group $K(\\Upsilon_{P})$ of the collection of all polynomial solutions $\\Upsilon_{P}$ with fields of coefficients of characteristic zero and support base $P$. Second, we show that, contrary to the polynomial solution<br /> case, there exists at least one (infinitely many) rational function solution, with support base $P$ containing all primes, which are not constructible from quantum integers. Third, we show that even in the case where the non-cyclotomic part is trivial, rational function solutions are different from polynomial solutions in<br />that there still exist infinitely many rational function solutions to these functional equations with support base $P$ containing all primes and which are not constructible from quantum integers.	string

1005	en_US	title	General and acyclic sum-list-colourings of graphs	string
1005	en_US	cleanTitle	General and acyclic sumlistcolourings of graphs	string
1005	en_US	abstract	Let ${\\mathcal P}$ be a %n induced hereditary<br /> class of graphs that is closed with respect to taking  induced subgraphs. Next let $G$ be a graph and ${\\bf L}$ be  a collection $\\{L(v)\\}_{v\\in V(G)}$ of nonempty sets each of which consists of positive integers. A graph $G$ is $({\\bf L},{\\mathcal P})$-{\\it choosable} if there exists a mapping $c: V(G) \\to \\mathbb{N}$, such that<br />\\begin{enumerate}<br />\\item for each $v \\in V(G)$ it holds $c(v) \\in L(v)$; and <br />\\item for each $ i\\in \\mathbb{N}$ the graph induced in $G$ by all the vertices in the set $c^{-1}(i)$ belongs to $\\mathcal{P}$.<br />\\end{enumerate}<br /><br />Let $f: V(G)\\to \\mathbb{N}$ be a function which assigns list sizes to the vertices of $G$. A graph $G$ is $(f,{\\mathcal P})$-{\\it choosable} if for every  ${\\bf L}$ whose sizes are specified by $f$ (it means $|L(v)|=f(v)$ for each $v\\in V(G)$ with ${\\bf L}=\\{L(v)\\}_{v\\in V(G)}$) the graph $G$ is $({\\bf L},{\\mathcal P})$-choosable.<br /><br />The ${\\mathcal P}${\\it -sum-choice-number} of a graph $G$ is the minimum of the sum $\\sum_{v\\in V(G)}f(v)$ of sizes in $f$ over all $f$ such that $G$ is $(f,{\\mathcal P})$-choosable. For the class ${\\mathcal P}$ of edgeless graphs, this invariant is known in the literature as the sum-choice-number of a graph.<br /><br />In the paper we estimate the ${\\mathcal P}$-sum-choice-number of a graph in terms of hypergraph theory notions and in terms of the sum-choice-number of another graph. We pay special attention to the class ${\\mathcal D}_1$ of acyclic graphs showing the improvement of the general upper bounds on the ${\\mathcal P}$-sum-choice-number for ${\\mathcal P}={\\mathcal D}_1$  in the classes of all graphs, $k$-degenerate graphs, planar graphs, bipartite graphs. We give wide discussion on complete graphs and complete bipartite graphs proving exact values or some narrow estimations of their ${\\mathcal D}_1$-sum-choice-numbers. Several supporting results presented in the paper can be used as tools for other research in this field.	string
1005	en_US	discipline	graph theory	string
1005	en_US	subjectClass	05C07; 05C15; 05C30; 05C38	string
1005	en_US	subject	Sum-list chromatic number; acyclic colourings; bipartite graphs; induced hereditary graph classes	string
1005	en_US	sponsor		string
1006	en_US	abstract	<p>Given a nontrivial Cartesian product <em>G</em> one can reconstruct <em>G</em> from any of its vertex deleted subgraphs G \\ x. In other words, Cartesian products are weakly reconstructable. Hagauer and Žerovnik showed that the complexity of the weak reconstruction of Cartesian products is <em>O(mn(\\Delta^2+m))</em>, where <em>m</em> is the size of <em>G</em>, <em>n</em> its order, and \\Delta its maximum degree. The core of this paper is a new algorithm of complexity <em>O(\\Delta^2(\\Delta^2+m))</em> for the solution of this problem.</p>	string

1012	en_US	abstract	<p>Let $a,b,r$ be nonnegative integers with $1\\leq a\\leq b$ and $r\\geq 2$.<br />Let $G$ be a graph of order $n$ with $n&gt;\\frac{(a+2b)(r(a+b)-2)}{b}$. 1013	en_US	title	Uniformly dissociated graphs	string
1013	en_US	cleanTitle	Uniformly dissociated graphs	string
1013	en_US	abstract	<p>A set <span class="math"><em>D</em></span> of vertices in a graph <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> is called a dissociation set if every vertex in <span class="math"><em>D</em></span> has at most one neighbor in <span class="math"><em>D</em></span>. We call a graph <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> uniformly dissociated if all maximal dissociation sets are of the same cardinality. Characterizations of uniformly dissociated graphs with small cardinalities of dissociation sets are proven; in particular, the graphs in which all maximal dissociation sets are of cardinality 2 are the complete graphs on at least two vertices from which possibly a matching is removed, while the graphs in which all maximal dissociation sets are of cardinality 3 are the complements of the <span class="math"><em>K</em><sub>4</sub></span>-free geodetic graphs with diameter 2. A general construction by which any graph can be embedded as an induced subgraph of a uniformly dissociated graph is also presented. In the main result we characterize uniformly dissociated graphs with girth at least 7 to be either isomorphic to <span class="math"><em>C</em><sub>7</sub></span>, or obtainable from an arbitrary graph <span class="math"><em>H</em></span> with girth at least 7 by identifying each vertex of <span class="math"><em>H</em></span> with a leaf of a copy of <span class="math"><em>P</em><sub>3</sub></span>.</p>	string

1348	en_US	abstract	In this paper we show that the relative normalised size with respect to a number field <strong>K</strong> of an algebraic integer <em>α</em> ≠ -1, 0, 1 is greater than 1 provided that the number of real embeddings <em>s</em> of <strong>K</strong> satisfies <em>s</em> <span>≥</span> 0.828<em>n</em>, where <em>n</em> = [<strong>K</strong> : <strong>Q</strong>]. 1015	en_US	title	Game distinguishing numbers of Cartesian products	string
1015	en_US	cleanTitle	Game distinguishing numbers of Cartesian products	string
1015	en_US	abstract	<p>The distinguishing number of a graph <span class="math"><em>H</em></span> is a symmetry related graph invariant whose study started two decades ago. The distinguishing number <span class="math"><em>D</em>(<em>H</em>)</span> is the least integer <span class="math"><em>d</em></span> such that <span class="math"><em>H</em></span> has a distinguishing <span class="math"><em>d</em></span>-coloring. A distinguishing <span class="math"><em>d</em></span>-coloring is a coloring <span class="math"><em>c</em>: <em>V</em>(<em>H</em>) → {1, …, <em>d</em>}</span> invariant only under the trivial automorphism. In this paper, we continue the study of a game variant of this parameter, recently introduced. The distinguishing game is a game with two players, Gentle and Rascal, with antagonistic goals. This game is played on a graph <span class="math"><em>H</em></span> with a fixed set of <span class="math"><em>d</em> ∈ N</span> colors. Alternately, the two players choose a vertex of <span class="math"><em>H</em></span> and color it with one of the <span class="math"><em>d</em></span> colors. The game ends when all the vertices have been colored. Then Gentle wins if the <span class="math"><em>d</em></span>-coloring is distinguishing and Rascal wins otherwise. This game defines two new invariants, which are the minimum numbers of colors needed to ensure that Gentle has a winning strategy, depending who starts the game. The invariant could be infinite. In this paper, we focus on the Cartesian product, a graph operation well studied in the classical case. We give sufficient conditions on the order of two connected factors <span class="math"><em>H</em></span> and <span class="math"><em>F</em></span> that are relatively prime, which ensure that one of the game distinguishing numbers of the Cartesian product <span class="math"><em>H</em>▫<em>F</em></span> is finite. If <span class="math"><em>H</em></span> is a so-called involutive graph, we give an upper bound of order <span class="math"><em>D</em><sup>2</sup>(<em>H</em>)</span> for one of the game distinguishing numbers of <span class="math"><em>H</em>▫<em>F</em></span>. Finally, using in part the previous result, we compute the exact value of these invariants for Cartesian products of relatively prime cycles. It turns out that the value is either infinite or equal to <span class="math">2</span>, depending on the parity of the product order.</p>	string

1017	en_US	cleanTitle	ℱWORM colorings of some 2trees: partition vectors	string
1017	en_US	abstract	<p>Suppose <span class="math inline">ℱ = {<em>F</em><sub>1</sub>, …, <em>F</em><sub><em>t</em></sub>}</span> is a collection of distinct subgraphs of a graph <span class="math inline"><em>G</em> = (<em>V</em>, <em>E</em>)</span>. An <span><em><span class="math inline">ℱ</span>-WORM</em></span> coloring of <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> is the coloring of its vertices such that no copy of each subgraph <span class="math inline"><em>F</em><sub><em>i</em></sub> ∈ ℱ</span> is monochrome or rainbow. This generalizes the notion of <span class="math inline"><em>F</em></span>-WORM coloring that was introduced recently by W. Goddard, K. Wash, and H. Xu. A (restricted) partition vector <span class="math inline">(<em>ζ</em><sub><em>α</em></sub>, …, <em>ζ</em><sub><em>β</em></sub>)</span> is a sequence whose terms <span class="math inline"><em>ζ</em><sub><em>r</em></sub></span> are the number of <span class="math inline">ℱ</span>-WORM colorings using exactly <span class="math inline"><em>r</em></span> colors, with <span class="math inline"><em>α</em> ≤ <em>r</em> ≤ <em>β</em></span>. The partition vectors of complete graphs and those of some <span class="math inline">2</span>-trees are discussed. We show that, although <span class="math inline">2</span>-trees admit the same partition vector in classic proper vertex colorings which forbid monochrome <span class="math inline"><em>K</em><sub>2</sub></span>, their partition vectors in <span class="math inline"><em>K</em><sub>3</sub></span>-WORM colorings are different.</p>	string

1020	en_US	abstract	<p>Let <span class="math"><em>n</em></span> be a positive integer, <span class="math"><em>q</em></span> be a prime power, and <span class="math"><em>V</em></span> be a vector space of dimension <span class="math"><em>n</em></span> over <span class="math"><em>F</em><sub><em>q</em></sub></span>. 1021	en_US	title	On ±1 eigenvectors of graphs	string
1021	en_US	cleanTitle	On ±1 eigenvectors of graphs	string
1021	en_US	abstract	<p>While discussing his spectral bound on the independence number of a graph, Herbert Wilf asked back in 1986 what kind of a graph admits an eigenvector consisting solely of <span class="math"> ± 1</span> entries? We prove that Wilf’s problem is NP-complete, but also that the set of graphs having a <span class="math"> ± 1</span> eigenvector is quite rich, being closed under a number of different graph compositions.</p>	string

1023	en_US	title	New results on super edge magic deficiency of kite graphs	string
1023	en_US	cleanTitle	New results on super edge magic deficiency of kite graphs	string
1023	en_US	abstract	<p>An \\emph{edge magic labeling} of a graph $G$ is a bijection<br />$\\lambda:V(G)\\cup E(G)\\rightarrow \\{1, 2, \\dots ,|V(G)|+|E(G)| \\}$ such that $\\lambda(u)+\\lambda(uv)+\\lambda(v)$ is constant, for every edge $uv\\in<br />E(G).$ The concept of edge magic deficiency was introduce by Kotzig and Rosa’s. Motivated by this concept Figueroa-Centeno,<br />Ichishima and Muntaner-Batle defined a similar concept for super edge magic<br />total labelings. The \\emph{super edge magic deficiency} of a graph $G,$ which is denoted by<br />$\\mu_s(G),$ is the minimum nonnegative integer $n$ such that $G\\cup nK_1,$ has a super edge magic<br />total labeling or it is equal to $+\\infty$ if there exists no such $n.$ In this paper, we study the super edge magic deficiency of kite graphs.</p>	string

1024	en_US	title	Almost-bipartite {\\it Q}-polynomial distance-regular graphs and uniform posets	string
1024	en_US	cleanTitle	Almostbipartite {\\it Q}polynomial distanceregular graphs and uniform posets	string
1024	en_US	abstract	<p>Let $\\Gamma=(X,\\mathcal{R})$ be one of the $(2D+1)$-gon, the folded $(2D+1)$-cube and the Odd graph on a set of cardinality $2D+1$ with diameter $D \\geq 3$. It is known that $\\Gamma$ is an almost-bipartite {\\it Q}-polynomial distance-regular graph.<br />We first characterize the {\\it Q}-polynomial structures of the folded $(2D+1)$-cube by using the theory of Leonard pairs. Next, fix $ x \\in X $ and define a partial order $\\leq$ on $X$ as<br />follows. For $y,z \\in X $ let $y \\leq z$ whenever $\\partial(x, y)+ \\partial(y, z) = \\partial(x, z)$, where $\\partial$ denotes<br />the path-length distance function. Then the partition $\\{\\Gamma_i(x)\\}^D_{i=0}$ of $X$ is a grading of the poset $(X,\\leq)$. Let $R$ (resp. $L$) denote the corresponding raising matrix (resp. lowering matrix). Then we show that there exists a certain linear dependency among $RL^2,\\ LRL,\\ L^2R\\ {\\rm and}\\ L$ for each given {\\it Q}-polynomial structure of $\\Gamma$. We call this dependency an $R/L$ dependency structure. Finally, we determine whether the above $R/L$ dependency structure gives this<br />poset a uniform structure or strongly uniform structure.</p>	string

1027	en_US	abstract	We continue our research in the enumeration of Hamiltonian cycles<br />(HC) on thin cylinder grid graphs by studying a triangular variant<br />of the problem.  There are two types of HCs, distinguished by<br />whether they wrap around the cylinder.  Using two<br />characterizations of these HCs, we prove that, for fixed $m$, the<br />number of HCs of both types obey some linear recurrence relations<br />for fixed $m$. For small $m$, computational results reveal that<br />the two numbers are asymptotically the same.  We conjecture that<br />this is true for all $m$.	string

1030	en_US	title	No chemical graph on more than two vertices is nuciferous	string
1030	en_US	cleanTitle	No chemical graph on more than two vertices is nuciferous	string
1030	en_US	abstract	<p>A simple graph is nuciferous if its 0–1 adjacency matrix is nonsingular and if its inverse has zero entries on its main diagonal and a non–zero entry at each off–diagonal position. A nuciferous graph is a molecular graph that represents an ipso omni–insulating but distinct omni–conducting molecule. It has been conjectured in 2012 that only <span class="math"><em>K</em><sub>2</sub></span>, the complete graph on two vertices, is nuciferous. We show that this conjecture is true for chemical graphs, that is, graphs whose vertex degree is at most three.</p>	string

1032	en_US	title	Weakly convex and convex domination numbers for generalized Petersen graphs and grid graphs	string
1032	en_US	cleanTitle	Weakly convex and convex domination numbers for generalized Petersen graphs and grid graphs	string
1032	en_US	abstract	<p>In this paper we consider the weakly convex domination and convex domination numbers for two classes of graphs: generalized Petersen graphs and grid graphs.<br />For a given generalized Petersen graph $GP(n,k)$, we prove that if $k=1$ and $n\\geq 4$, both weakly convex domination number $\\gamma_{wcon}(G(n,k))$ and convex domination number $\\gamma_{con}(G(n,k))$ are equal to $n$. For $k\\geq 2$ and $n\\geq 13$, $\\gamma_{wcon}(G(n,k))=\\gamma_{con}(G(n,k))=2n$, which is the order of $G(n,k)$. Special cases for smaller graphs are solved by the total enumeration method.<br />For a grid graph $G_{m,n},\\ m\\leq n$, we prove that if $m=2$ and $n\\neq 3$ or $m=3$, $\\gamma_{wcon}(G_{m,n})=\\gamma_{con}(G_{m,n})=n$, while if $m \\geq 4$, $\\gamma_{wcon}(G_{m,n})=(m-2)(n-2)+4$ and $\\gamma_{con}(G_{m,n})=(m-2)n$.</p>	string

1038	en_US	abstract	In this paper, we introduce the conjugate element graph over $ \\mathbb Z_n$, denoted by $CG(\\mathbb Z_n)$, which is defined as follows: it is a simple undirected graph $(V, E)$ where $V=\\mathbb Z_n$ and for vertices $\\bar a, \\bar b$, $\\bar a \\bar b \\in E$ if and only if there exist prime elements (not necessarily distinct) $\\bar p, \\bar q$ in $\\mathbb Z_n$ such that $\\bar a=\\bar p+\\bar q$ and $\\bar b=\\bar p-\\bar q$. We look at the various graph-theoretical properties of $CG(\\mathbb Z_n)$. Connectedness, degrees and other structures of the graph $CG(\\mathbb Z_n)$ are considered. The values of $n$ for which $CG(\\mathbb Z_n)$ is regular, acyclic etc., are also found.	string

1044	en_US	title	Improved bounds for hypohamiltonian graphs	string
1044	en_US	cleanTitle	Improved bounds for hypohamiltonian graphs	string
1044	en_US	abstract	<p>A graph <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> is <em>hypohamiltonian</em> if <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> is non-hamiltonian and <span class="math"><em>G</em> − <em>v</em></span> is hamiltonian for every <span class="math"><em>v</em> ∈ <em>V</em>(<em>G</em>)</span>. In the following, every graph is assumed to be hypohamiltonian. Aldred, Wormald, and McKay gave a list of all graphs of order at most 17. In this article, we present an algorithm to generate all graphs of a given order and apply it to prove that there exist exactly 14 graphs of order 18 and 34 graphs of order 19. We also extend their results in the cubic case. Furthermore, we show that (i) the smallest graph of girth 6 has order 25, (ii) the smallest planar graph has order at least 23, (iii) the smallest cubic planar graph has order at least 54, and (iv) the smallest cubic planar graph of girth 5 with non-trivial automorphism group has order 78.</p>	string

1051	en_US	title	Algebraic and geometric properties of the  terminal  set in  lattice walks with steps of equal length	string
1051	en_US	cleanTitle	Algebraic and geometric properties of the  terminal  set in  lattice walks with steps of equal length	string
1051	en_US	abstract	A lattice walk with all steps having the same length $d$ is called a $d$-walk. Denote by ${\\cal T}_d$  the terminal set, that is, the set of all lattice points which can be reached from the origin by means of a $d$-walk. We examine some geometric and algebraic properties of the terminal set.  We observe, among others things, that $({\\cal T}_d,+)$ is a normal subgroup of the group $(\\zz^N,+)$. This observation gives us a natural motivation to ask questions about the  quotient $\\zz^N/{\\cal T}_d$ which is the main object examined in this note.<br />To establish some of our results we use several consequences of Fermat's theorem about representations  of prime numbers of the form $4k+1$ as the sum of two squares. One of the consequences is the  fact, observed by Sierpinski, that every natural power of such a prime number has exactly one relatively prime representation. We provide explicit formulas for the relatively prime integers in this  representation.	string

1053	en_US	title	A note on asymptotical Efficiency of the Goodness of Fit Tests Based on disjoint k-spacings.	string
1053	en_US	cleanTitle	A note on asymptotical Efficiency of the Goodness of Fit Tests Based on disjoint kspacings	string
1053	en_US	abstract	The Pitman's asymptotic efficiencies (AE) of the goodness-of-t tests based on higher-order non-overlapping spacings have been considered in the literature. Different authors have studied the Pitman's as well as Bahadur approximate efficiency of the logarithm statistics based on k- spacings where k isfixed number. This paper considers the case where k may tends to infinity as n approaches infinity. This certainly compliments the results available in the literature and provides more general results. In this paper we show that logarithm statistics based on higher ordered spacings has higher efficiency in Pitman's sense compared to their counterparts based on simple spacings. It is also shown that the Kallenberg's intermediate AE of such test coincides with its Pitman's AE, the power of the tests are also discussed.	string

1054	en_US	title	On zero sum-partition of Abelian groups into three sets and group distance magic labeling	string
1054	en_US	cleanTitle	On zero sumpartition of Abelian groups into three sets and group distance magic labeling	string
1054	en_US	abstract	<p>We say that a finite Abelian group <span class="math">Γ </span> has the <em>constant-sum-partition property into <span class="math"><em>t</em></span> sets</em> (CSP<span class="math">(<em>t</em>)</span>-property) if for every partition <span class="math"><em>n</em> = <em>r</em><sub>1</sub> + <em>r</em><sub>2</sub> + … + <em>r</em><sub><em>t</em></sub></span> of <span class="math"><em>n</em></span>, with <span class="math"><em>r</em><sub><em>i</em></sub> ≥ 2</span> for <span class="math">2 ≤ <em>i</em> ≤ <em>t</em></span>, there is a partition of <span class="math">Γ </span> into pairwise disjoint subsets <span class="math"><em>A</em><sub>1</sub>, <em>A</em><sub>2</sub>, …, <em>A</em><sub><em>t</em></sub></span>, such that <span class="math">∣<em>A</em><sub><em>i</em></sub>∣ = <em>r</em><sub><em>i</em></sub></span> and for some <span class="math"><em>ν</em> ∈ Γ </span>, <span class="math">∑ <sub><em>a</em> ∈ <em>A</em><sub><em>i</em></sub></sub><em>a</em> = <em>ν</em></span> for <span class="math">1 ≤ <em>i</em> ≤ <em>t</em></span>. For <span class="math"><em>ν</em> = <em>g</em><sub>0</sub></span> (where <span class="math"><em>g</em><sub>0</sub></span> is the identity element of <span class="math">Γ </span>) we say that <span class="math">Γ </span> has <em>zero-sum-partition property into <span class="math"><em>t</em></span> sets</em> (ZSP<span class="math">(<em>t</em>)</span>-property).</p><p>A <span class="math">Γ </span><em>-distance magic labeling</em> of a graph <span class="math"><em>G</em> = (<em>V</em>, <em>E</em>)</span> with <span class="math">∣<em>V</em>∣ = <em>n</em></span> is a bijection <span class="math">ℓ</span> from <span class="math"><em>V</em></span> to an Abelian group <span class="math">Γ </span> of order <span class="math"><em>n</em></span> such that the weight <span class="math"><em>w</em>(<em>x</em>) = ∑ <sub><em>y</em> ∈ <em>N</em>(<em>x</em>)</sub>ℓ(<em>y</em>)</span> of every vertex <span class="math"><em>x</em> ∈ <em>V</em></span> is equal to the same element <span class="math"><em>μ</em> ∈ Γ </span>, called the <em>magic constant</em>. A graph <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> is called a <em>group distance magic graph</em> if there exists a <span class="math">Γ </span>-distance magic labeling for every Abelian group <span class="math">Γ </span> of order <span class="math">∣<em>V</em>(<em>G</em>)∣</span>.</p><p>In this paper we study the CSP<span class="math">(3)</span>-property of <span class="math">Γ </span>, and apply the results to the study of group distance magic complete tripartite graphs.</p>	string

1059	en_US	title	Coordinatizing <i>n</i><sub>3</sub> configurations	string
1059	en_US	cleanTitle	Coordinatizing <i>n</i><sub>3</sub> configurations	string
1059	en_US	abstract	Given an <span class="math inline"><em>n</em><sub>3</sub></span> configuration, a one-point extension is a technique that constructs <span class="math inline">(<em>n</em> + 1)<sub>3</sub></span> configurations from it. A configuration is <em>geometric</em> if it can be realized by a collection of points and straight lines in the plane. Given a geometric <span class="math inline"><em>n</em><sub>3</sub></span> configuration with a planar coordinatization of its points and lines, a method is presented that uses a one-point extension to produce <span class="math inline">(<em>n</em> + 1)<sub>3</sub></span> configurations from it, and then constructs geometric realizations of the <span class="math inline">(<em>n</em> + 1)<sub>3</sub></span> configurations. It is shown that this can be done using only a homogeneous <span><em>cubic</em></span> polynomial in just <span><em>three</em></span> variables, <span><em>independent</em></span> of <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span>. This transforms a computationally intractable problem into a computationally practical one.	string

1060	en_US	title	Pursuit-evasion in a two-dimensional domain	string
1060	en_US	cleanTitle	Pursuitevasion in a twodimensional domain	string
1060	en_US	abstract	In a pursuit-evasion game, a team of pursuers attempt to capture an evader. The players alternate turns, move with equal speed, and have full information about the state of the game. We consider the most restrictive capture condition: a pursuer must become colocated with the evader to win the game. We prove two general results about this adversarial motion planning problem in geometric spaces. First, we show that one pursuer has a winning strategy in any compact CAT(0) space. This complements a result of Alexander, Bishop and Ghrist, who provide a winning strategy for a game with positive capture radius. Second, we consider the game played in a compact domain in Euclidean two-space with piecewise analytic boundary and arbitrary Euler characteristic. We show that three pursuers always have a winning strategy by extending recent work of Bhadauria, Klein, Isler and Suri from polygonal environments to our more general setting.	string

1065	en_US	abstract	‎Let $R$ be a commutative ring with $1\\neq0$ and $U(R)$ be the set of unit elements‎. ‎Let $M$ be an R-module and $T(M)$ the set of torsion elements‎. ‎In this paper‎, ‎we introduce and investigate the $torsion-unitary$ $Cayley$ $graph$ of $M$‎, ‎denoted by $\\Upsilon_{R}(M)$‎. ‎It is a simple graph with vertex set $M\\times R$‎, ‎and two elements $(m,r)‎, ‎(n,s)\\in M\\times R$ are adjacent if and only if $(m,r)-(n,s)\\in T(M)\\times U(R)$‎. ‎‏‎We observe that ‎$\\Upsilon_{R}(-)$ acts as a functor on the category of modules‎. ‎We also introduce the exact sequence of Cayley graphs and determine the properties of functor $\\Upsilon_{R}(-)$‎.	string

1067	en_US	abstract	<p>Uniformly finite homology is a coarse homology theory, defined via<br /> chains that satisfy a uniform boundedness condition. 1073	en_US	title	On factorable bigraphic pairs	string
1073	en_US	cleanTitle	On factorable bigraphic pairs	string
1073	en_US	abstract	<p>Let $S=(a_1,\\ldots,a_m;b_1,\\ldots,b_n)$,<br />where $a_1,\\ldots,a_m$ and $b_1,\\ldots,b_n$ are two sequences of<br />nonnegative integers. We say that $S$ is a {\\it bigraphic pair} if<br />there exists a simple bipartite graph $G$ with partite sets<br />$\\{x_1,x_2,\\ldots,x_m\\}$ and $\\{y_1,y_2,\\ldots,y_n\\}$ such that<br />$d_G(x_i)=a_i$ for $1\\le i\\le m$ and $d_G(y_j)=b_j$ for $1\\le j\\le<br />n$. In this case, we say that $G$ is a {\\it realization} of $S$.<br />Analogous to Kundu's $k$-factor theorem, we show that if<br />$(a_1,a_2,\\ldots,a_m;b_1,b_2,\\ldots,b_n)$ and<br />$(a_1-e_1,a_2-e_2,\\ldots,a_m-e_m;b_1-f_1,b_2-f_2,\\ldots,b_n-f_n)$ be<br />two bigraphic pairs satisfying $k\\le f_i\\le k+1$, $1\\le i\\le n$ (or<br />$k\\le e_i\\le k+1$, $1\\le i\\le m$), for some $k\\ge 0$, then<br />$(a_1,a_2,\\ldots,a_m;b_1,b_2,\\ldots,b_n)$ has a realization<br />containing a $(e_1,e_2,\\ldots,e_m;f_1,f_2,\\ldots,f_n)$-factor. For<br />$m=n$, we also give a necessary and sufficient condition for a<br />$(k^n;k^n)$-factorable bigraphic pair to be connected<br />$(k^n;k^n)$-factorable when $k\\ge 2$. This implies a<br />characterization of bigraphic pairs with a realization<br />containing a hamiltonian cycle.</p>	string

1074	en_US	abstract	<p>When the policy decisions related to pay, perquisites and targets are announced in any organization the exit of personnel takes place. Once the exit of personnel   takes place in real situation, the recruitment cannot be implemented immediately. Because the recruitment involves time and expense recruitment cannot be recommended. Thus additional loss of manpower for frequent recruitment cross the level called as known as threshold then the recruitment is made. When the shock model approach is applied, various stochastic   models with bivariate policy of recruitment are followed. In  this paper, the explicit expression for the long - run average cost per unit time is derived  when (i) survival  time  process  is  a geometric process and  (ii)    the threshold for the loss of manpower contains   two components namely the level of wastage which can be allowed and the manpower due to extra time  work. Numerical illustrations are additionally provided.</p>	string

1078	en_US	title	On The Fixed Number of Graphs	string
1078	en_US	cleanTitle	On The Fixed Number of Graphs	string
1078	en_US	abstract	<p>An automorphism on a graph $G$ is a bijective mapping on the vertex<br />set $V(G)$, which preserves the relation of adjacency between any<br />two vertices of $G$. An automorphism $g$ fixes a vertex $v$ if $g$<br />maps $v$ onto itself. The stabilizer of a set $S$ of vertices is the<br />set of all automorphisms that fix vertices of $S$. A set $F$ is<br />called fixing set of $G$, if its stabilizer is trivial. The fixing<br />number of a graph is the cardinality of a smallest fixing set. The<br />fixed number of a graph $G$ is the minimum $k$, such that every<br />$k$-set of vertices of $G$ is a fixing set of $G$. A graph $G$ is<br />called a $k$-fixed graph if its fixing number and the fixed number<br />are both $k$. In this paper, we study the fixed number of a graph<br />and give construction of a graph of higher fixed number from graph<br />with lower fixed number. We find bound on $k$ in terms of diameter<br />$d$ of a distance-transitive $k$-fixed graph.</p>	string

1083	en_US	abstract	<p>An NMNR-coloring of a hypergraph is a coloring of vertices such that in every hyperedge at least two vertices are colored with distinct colors, and at least two vertices are colored with the same color. We prove that every <span class="math">3</span>-uniform <span class="math">3</span>-regular hypergraph admits an NMNR-coloring with at most <span class="math">3</span> colors. 1087	en_US	title	Distinguishing number and distinguishing index of natural and fractional powers of graphs	string
1087	en_US	cleanTitle	Distinguishing number and distinguishing index of natural and fractional powers of graphs	string
1087	en_US	abstract	The distinguishing number (index) $D(G)$ ($D'(G)$) of a graph $G$ is the least integer $d$<br />such that $G$ has an vertex labeling (edge labeling)  with $d$ labels  that is preserved only by a trivial<br />automorphism. For any $n \\in \\mathbb{N}$, the $n$-subdivision of $G$ is a simple graph $G^{\\frac{1}{n}}$ which is constructed by replacing each edge of $G$ with a path of length $n$.  The $m^{th}$ power of $G$, is a graph with same set of vertices of $G$ and an edge between two vertices if and only if there is a path of length at most $m$ between them.    <br />    The fractional power of $G$, denoted by $G^{\\frac{m}{n}}$ is  $m^{th}$ power of the $n$-subdivision of $G$ or $n$-subdivision of $m$-th power of $G$. In this paper we study the distinguishing number and distinguishing index of natural and fractional powers of $G$. We show that  the natural powers more than two of a graph  distinguished by three edge labels. Also we show that for a connected graph $G$ of order $n \\geqslant 3$ with maximum degree $\\Delta (G)$,  $D(G^{\\frac{1}{k}})\\leqslant min\\{s: 2^k+\\sum^s_{n=3}n^{k-1}\\geqslant \\Delta (G)\\}$ and for $m\\geqslant 3$, $D'(G^{\\frac{m}{k}})\\leqslant 3$.	string

1090	en_US	title	On the metric dimension of wheels with consecutive missing spokes	string
1090	en_US	cleanTitle	On the metric dimension of wheels with consecutive missing spokes	string
1090	en_US	abstract	<p>If $G$ is a connected graph, the \\emph{distance} $d(u, v)$ between<br />two vertices $u, v \\in V(G)$ is the length of a shortest path<br />between them. Let $W = \\{w_1,w_2, \\dots ,w_k\\}$ be an ordered set of<br />vertices of $G$ and let $v$ be a vertex of $G$. The<br />\\emph{representation} $r(v|W)$ of $v$ with respect to $W$ is the<br />k-tuple $(d(v,w_1), d(v,w_2), \\dots , d(v,w_k))$. $W$ is called a<br />{\\it resolving set} or a {\\it locating set} if every vertex of $G$<br />is uniquely identified by its distances from the vertices of $W$, or<br />equivalently, if distinct vertices of $G$ have distinct<br />representations with respect to $W$. A resolving set of minimum<br />cardinality is called a \\emph{metric basis} for $G$ and this<br />cardinality is the {\\it metric dimension} of $G$,<br />denoted by $\\beta(G)$.\\\\<br />Metric dimension is a generalization of affine dimension to<br />arbitrary metric spaces (provided a resolving set exists).\\\\<br />The metric dimension of some wheel related graphs are studied recently in [H. M. A. Siddiqui, M. Imran, Appl. Math. Comput. $244(2014), 624-632$].<br />In this paper, we study the metric dimension of wheels with $k$<br />consecutive missing spokes denoted by $W_{n,k}$. We compute the exact value of metric dimension of<br />$W_{n,k}$ which shows that wheels with consecutive missing spokes have<br />unbounded metric dimension. It is natural to ask for characterization of graphs with unbounded metric dimension.<br />The exchange property for resolving set of $W_{n,k}$ has also been studied in<br />this paper and it is shown that exchange property of the bases<br />in a vector space does not hold for minimal resolving sets of wheels with $k$-consecutive missing spokes denoted by $W(n,k)$.</p>	string

1098	en_US	abstract	Cavenagh and Wanless recently proved that, for sufficiently large odd <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span>, the number of transversals in the Latin square formed from the addition table for integers modulo <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span> is greater than <span class="math inline">(3.246)<sup><em>n</em></sup></span>. 1099	en_US	cleanTitle	POLYNOMIALS ASSOCIATED WITH THE FRAGMENTS OF COSET DIAGRAMS	string
1099	en_US	abstract	The coset diagrams for PSL(2,ℤ) are composed of fragments, and the fragments are further composed of circuits. Mushtaq has found that, the condition for the existence of a fragment in coset diagram is a polynomial f in ℤ[z]. Higman has conjectured that, the polynomials related to the fragments are monic and for a fixed degree, there are finite number of such polynomials. In this paper, we consider a family Ω of fragments such that each fragment in Ω contains one vertex fixed by a pair of words (xy)^{q₁}(xy⁻¹)^{q₂},(xy⁻¹)^{s₁}(xy)^{s₂}, where s₁,s₂,q₁,q₂∈ℤ⁺, and prove Higman's conjecture for the polynomials obtained from Ω.	string

1100	en_US	abstract	<p>In this note we show that there are no real configurations of <span class="math"><em>d</em> ≥ 4</span> lines in the projective plane such that the associated Kummer covers of order <span class="math">3<sup><em>d</em> − 1</sup></span> are ball-quotients and there are no configurations of <span class="math"><em>d</em> ≥ 4</span> lines such that the Kummer covers of order <span class="math">4<sup><em>d</em> − 1</sup></span> are ball-quotients. Moreover, we show that there exists only one configuration of real lines such that the associated Kummer cover of order <span class="math">5<sup><em>d</em> − 1</sup></span> is a ball-quotient. In the second part we consider the so-called topological <span class="math">(<em>n</em><sub><em>k</em></sub>)</span>-configurations and we show, using Shnurnikov’s inequality, that for <span class="math"><em>n</em> &lt; 27</span> there do not exist <span class="math">(<em>n</em><sub>5</sub>)</span>-configurations and and for <span class="math"><em>n</em> &lt; 41</span> there do not exist <span class="math">(<em>n</em><sub>6</sub>)</span>-configurations.</p>	string

1386	en_US	title	Minor totals of natural sequence: some properties and application to growth modeling	string
1386	en_US	cleanTitle	Minor totals of natural sequence: some properties and application to growth modeling	string
1386	en_US	abstract	<p>Minor totals of natural sequence were shown to possess some<br />properties in respect to their units digits. Depending on numeral<br />system applied the units digits may take any digit of the system or there may be exclusions. i.e. some system digits can never appear in the units digits of the minor totals. Natural sequence arithmetics may be applied to model multicellular organism growth. It can be shown that growth of an idealized organism may follow a power law in the form of the minor totals.</p>	string

1103	en_US	title	Efficient Domination and Perfect Packing in Cayley Graphs	string
1103	en_US	cleanTitle	Efficient Domination and Perfect Packing in Cayley Graphs	string
1103	en_US	abstract	Let $\\tau^d$ be a diameter-$d$ tree with vertex set $I_n=\\{1,2,\\ldots,n\\}$. Let $X_n^d$ be the Cayley graph of the symmetric group $S_n$ of permutations of $I_n$ with the edge transpositions of $\\tau^d$ as connection set. It is well known that $X_n^2$ has<br />an efficient dominating set, or E-set.<br />We prove that no $X_n^3$ has E-sets<br />by noting that a tree $\\tau^3$ has two vertices of degrees $r&gt;1$ and $s&gt;1$ with $r+s=n$. In fact, this yields that uniformly distributed 1-sphere packings of $X_n^3$ attain maximum vertex number $\\frac{n}{rs}|V(X_n^3)|&lt;|V(X_n^3)|$.<br />Moreover, for $r=s&gt;1$ a connected subgraph induced by $2^r$ of the $n\\choose r$ disjoint copies of $X_r^2\\square X_s^2$ of $X_n^3$ has a perfect 1-sphere packing extendible to a maximum nonuniformly distributed 1-sphere packing in $X_n^3$ that can be punctured to a maximum nonuniformly distributed 1-sphere packing for $r&gt;s&gt;1$.<br />In addition, we prove that no $X_n^d$ has an E-set if $d\\ge 3$ and $n$ is either 4 or a prime $&gt;4$. This was established for path graphs $\\tau^d$ by Buzaglo and Etzion, who pointed out a previous mistake in proof for the general case $n&gt;0$ and $d\\ge 3$, remedied now for $d=3$.	string

1107	en_US	abstract	<p>This paper studies the maximum number of edges of a Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG) with <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span> vertices in terms of it’s longest path <span class="math inline">ℓ</span>. We prove that in general this number is the Turán number <span class="math inline"><em>t</em>(<em>n</em>, <em>l</em> + 1)</span>, the maximum number of edges in a graph with <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span> vertices without a clique of size <span class="math inline">ℓ + 2</span>. 1109	en_US	title	Combinatorial configurations, quasiline arrangements, and systems of curves on surfaces	string
1109	en_US	cleanTitle	Combinatorial configurations quasiline arrangements and systems of curves on surfaces	string
1109	en_US	abstract	<p>It is well known that not every combinatorial configuration admits a geometric realization with points and lines. Moreover, some of them do not even admit realizations with pseudoline arrangements, i.e., they are not topological. In this paper we generalize the concept of topological configurations to a more general one (in a least possible way) such that every combinatorial configuration is realizable in this way.</p><p>In particular, we generalize the notion of a pseudoline arrangement to the notion of a quasiline arrangement by relaxing the condition that two pseudolines meet exactly once. We also generalize well-known tools from pseudoline arrangements such as sweeps and wiring diagrams. We introduce monotone quasiline arrangements as a subfamily of quasiline arrangements that can be represented with generalized wiring diagrams. We show that every incidence structure (and therefore also every combinatorial configuration) can be realized as a monotone quasiline arrangement in the real projective plane.</p><p>A quasiline arrangement with selected vertices belonging to an incidence structure can be viewed as a map on a closed surface. Such a map can be used to distinguish between two “distinct” realizations of an incidence structure as a quasiline arrangement.</p>	string

1110	en_US	title	The full metamorphosis of $\\lambda$-fold $K_4$-designs into $\\lambda$-fold $3$-star systems	string
1110	en_US	cleanTitle	The full metamorphosis of \\lambdafold K_4designs into \\lambdafold 3star systems	string
1110	en_US	abstract	Let $(X,B)$ be a $\\lambda$-fold $K_4$-design. If<br />a triangle is removed from each block of $B$ the resulting<br />collection of $3$-stars; $S$, is a partial $\\lambda$-fold $3$-star<br />system; $(X,S)$. If the edges belonging to the deleted triangles can be arranged into a collection of  $3$-stars $T^*$, then $(X,S\\cup T^*)$ is a $\\lambda$-fold  $3$-star system, called a metamorphosis of the $\\lambda$-fold $K_4$-design $(X,B)$ into a $\\lambda$-fold  $3$-star system. Label the elements of each block $b$ with $b_1,b_2,b_3$ and $b_4$ (in any manner). For each $i=1,2,3,4$ define a set of triangles $T_i$ and a set of stars $S_i$ as follows:<br />for each block $b=[b_1,b_2,b_3,b_4]$ belonging to $B$, partition $b$ into a star centered at $b_i$ and the triangle $b\\setminus b_i$, then place the star in $S_i$ and the triangle<br />in $T_i$. $(X,S_i)$ forms a partial $\\lambda$-fold  $3$-star system. Now if the edges belonging to the triangles in $T_i$ can be arranged into a collection of stars $T^*_i$ then $(X,S_i\\cup T^*_i)$ is a $\\lambda$-fold  $3$-star system and we say that $M_i=(X,S_i\\cup T^*_i)$ is the $i$th metamorphosis of $(X,B)$. The full metamorphosis of $(X,B)$ is the set of four metamorphoses $\\{M_1,M_2,M_3,M_4\\}$. The purpose of this<br />work is to give a complete solution of the following problem: For<br />which $n$ and $\\lambda$ does there exist a $\\lambda$-fold $K_4$-design having a full metamorphosis into<br />$\\lambda$-fold  $3$-star systems?	string

1112	en_US	title	Some polynomial algorithms for partitioning the neighborhood of the vertex in a graph	string
1112	en_US	cleanTitle	Some polynomial algorithms for partitioning the neighborhood of the vertex in a graph	string
1112	en_US	abstract	<p>The problem of partitioning the vertex set of a graph has been studied by many researchers in particular when the vertex set is partitioned into stable sets and cliques.<br />In this paper, we focus on the (k; l) partition graph (also called (k; l) graph) and its generalizations. A (k; l) partition of graph G is a partition of its vertex set into k stable sets and l clques.A vertex v in a graph G is called a (k; l) split vertex if its neighborhood in G admits a (k; l) partition. We say that G is a (k; l) split neighborhood graph (denoted SN(k; l) graph) if every induced subgraph of G contains a (k; l) split vertex. We give a polynomial algorithm for coloring any Perfect (k; l) partition graphs (G is perfect if the chromatic number is equal to maximum clique size for every induced subgraph H of G) and we investigate perfect and non perfect (k; l) split neighborhood graph for some values of k and l.</p>	string

1114	en_US	title	Optimal Barycentric Gegenbauer Quadrature	string
1114	en_US	cleanTitle	Optimal Barycentric Gegenbauer Quadrature	string
1114	en_US	abstract	The work reported in this article presents a high-order, stable, and efficient Gegenbauer pseudospectral method to solve numerically a wide variety of mathematical models. The proposed numerical scheme exploits the stability and the well-conditioning of the numerical integration operators to produce well-conditioned systems of algebraic equations, which can be solved easily using standard algebraic system solvers. The core of the work lies in the derivation of novel and stable optimal Gegenbauer quadratures based on the stable barycentric representation of Lagrange interpolating polynomials and the explicit barycentric weights for the Gegenbauer-Gauss (GG) points. A rigorous error and convergence analysis of the proposed quadratures is presented along with a detailed set of pseudocodes for the established computational algorithms. The proposed numerical scheme leads to a reduction in the computational cost and time complexity required for computing the numerical quadrature while sharing the same exponential order of accuracy achieved by \\cite{Elgindy2013}. The bulk of the work includes three numerical test examples to assess the efficiency and accuracy of the numerical scheme. The present method provides a strong addition to the arsenal of numerical pseudospectral methods, and can be extended to solve a wide range of problems arising in numerous applications.	string
1114	en_US	discipline		string
1114	en_US	subjectClass	65D30; 65D32; 65D05	string

1115	en_US	cleanTitle	Enumeration of hypermaps of a given genus	string
1115	en_US	abstract	This paper addresses the enumeration of rooted and unrooted hypermaps of a given genus. For rooted hypermaps the enumeration method consists of considering the more general family of multirooted hypermaps, in which darts other than the root dart are distinguished. We give functional equations for the generating series counting multirooted hypermaps of a given genus by number of darts, vertices, edges, faces and the degrees of the vertices containing the distinguished darts. We solve these equations to get parametric expressions of the generating functions of rooted hypermaps of low genus. We also count unrooted hypermaps of given genus by number of darts, vertices, hyperedges and faces.	string

1118	en_US	abstract	<p>The acyclic number <span class="math"><em>a</em>(<em>G</em>)</span> of a graph <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> is the maximum order of an induced forest in <span class="math"><em>G</em></span>. The purpose of this short paper is to propose a conjecture that <span class="math"><em>a</em>(<em>G</em>) ≥ (1 − 3/(2<em>g</em>))<em>n</em></span> holds for every planar graph <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> of girth <span class="math"><em>g</em></span> and order <span class="math"><em>n</em></span>, which captures three known conjectures on the topic. In addition, we give a construction showing that the constant <span class="math">3/2</span> from the conjecture cannot be decreased.</p>	string

1121	en_US	abstract	<p>An integer Heffter array <span class="math"><em>H</em>(<em>m</em>, <em>n</em>; <em>s</em>, <em>t</em>)</span> is an <span class="math"><em>m</em> × <em>n</em></span> partially filled matrix with entries from the set <span class="math">{ ± 1,  ± 2, …,  ± <em>m</em><em>s</em>}</span> such that <span><em>i)</em></span> each row contains <span class="math"><em>s</em></span> filled cells and each column contains <span class="math"><em>t</em></span> filled cells, <span><em>ii)</em></span> every row and column sums to 0 (in <strong><span class="math">Z</span></strong>), and <span><em>iii)</em></span> no two entries agree in absolute value. Heffter arrays are useful for embedding the complete graph <span class="math"><em>K</em><sub>2<em>m</em><em>s</em> + 1</sub></span> on an orientable surface in such a way that each edge lies between a face bounded by an <span class="math"><em>s</em></span>-cycle and a face bounded by a <span class="math"><em>t</em></span>-cycle. 1125	en_US	cleanTitle	A linear time algorithm for computing a minimum distance total kdominating set in interval graphs	string
1125	en_US	abstract	<pre>For a graph <span>$G=(V,E)$</span>, a <span>\\emph</span>{total dominating set} is a set <span>$D\\subseteq V$</span></pre><pre>such that every vertex <span>$v\\in V$</span> has a <span>neighbor</span> in <span>$D$</span>.  Given a graph $G=(V,E)$ and a fixed positive integer $k$, the \\emph{distance total $k$-dominating set} for $G$ is a set $TD\\subseteq V$ such that for every vertex in $v\\in V$, there exists a vertex $u\\in TD$ different from $v$ such that $d_G(u,v)\\leq k$, where $d_G(u,v)$ is the distance between $u$ and $v$ in $G$. In this paper, we give a linear time algorithm to compute a minimum distance total $k$-dominating set in interval graphs, an important subclass of chordal graphs.</pre>	string

1129	en_US	abstract	<p>When the condition of having three equal sides is imposed upon a (convex) spherical quadrangle, the four angles of that quadrangle cannot longer be freely chosen but must satisfy an identity. We derive two simple identities of this kind, one involving ratios of sines, and one involving ratios of tangents, and improve upon an earlier identity by Ueno and Agaoka.</p><p>The simple form of these identities enable us to further investigate the case in which all of the angles are rational multiples of <span class="math"><em>π</em></span> and produce a full classification, consisting of 7 infinite classes and 29 sporadic examples. 1135	en_US	title	PROPERTIES OF THE DOT PRODUCT GRAPH OF A COMMUTATIVE RING	string
1135	en_US	cleanTitle	PROPERTIES OF THE DOT PRODUCT GRAPH OF A COMMUTATIVE RING	string
1135	en_US	abstract	Let $R$ be a commutative ring with identity and $n\\geq1$ be an integer. Let $R^{n}=R\\times\\cdots\\times R~(n~times)$. The \\textit{total dot product} graph, denoted by $TD(R,n)$ is a simple graph with elements of $R^{n}-\\{(0,0,\\ldots,0)\\}$ as vertices, and two distinct vertices $\\mathbf{x}$ and $\\mathbf{y}$ are adjacent if and only if $\\mathbf{x} \\cdot \\mathbf{y}=0\\in R$, where $\\mathbf{x} \\cdot \\mathbf{y}$ denotes the dot product of $\\mathbf{x}$ and $\\mathbf{y}$. In this paper, we find the structure of $TD(R\\times S,n)$ with respect to the structure of $TD(R,n)$ and $TD(S,n)$. In addition, we find the degree of vertices of this graph. We determine when it is regular. Let $\\mathbb{F}$ be a finite field. It is shown that if $TD(\\mathbb{F},n)\\simeq TD(R,m)$, then $n=m$ and $R\\simeq\\mathbb{F}$. A number of results concerning the domination number are also presented. Furthermore, we give some results on the clique and the independence number of $TD(R,n)$. It is shown that the ring $R$ is finite if and only if its independence number is finite. Finally, we classify all planar graphs within this class.	string

1138	en_US	title	The ring of T-covariants	string
1138	en_US	cleanTitle	The ring of Tcovariants	string
1138	en_US	abstract	<p>Starting from the invariant theory of binary forms, we extend the classical notion of covariants and introduce the ring of T-covariants. This ring consists of maps deﬁned on a ring of polynomials in one variable which commute with all translation operators. We study this ring and we show some of its meaningful features. We state an analogue of the classical Hermite reciprocity law, and recover the Hilbert<br />series associated with a suitable double grading via elementary theory of partitions. Together with classical covariants of binary forms other remarkable mathematical notions, such as orthogonal polynomials and cumulants, turn out to have a natural and simple interpretation in this algebraic framework. As a consequence, a Heine integral representation for the cumulants of a random variable is obtained.</p>	string

1141	en_US	abstract	<p>We address a question of Cavenagh and Wanless asking: which finite abelian groups arise as the canonical group of a spherical latin bitrade? We prove the existence of an infinite family of finite abelian groups that do not arise as canonical groups of spherical latin bitrades. Using a connection between abelian sandpile groups of digraphs underlying directed Eulerian spherical embeddings, we go on to provide several, general, families of finite abelian groups that do arise as canonical groups. These families include:</p><ul><li><p>any abelian group in which each component of the Smith Normal Form has composite order;</p></li><li><p>any abelian group with Smith Normal Form <span class="math">Z<sub><em>p</em></sub><sup><em>n</em></sup> ⊕ (⨁ <sub><em>i</em> = 1</sub><sup><em>k</em></sup>Z<sub><em>p</em><em>a</em><sub><em>i</em></sub></sub>)</span>, where <span class="math">1 ≤ <em>k</em></span>, <span class="math">2 ≤ <em>a</em><sub>1</sub>, <em>a</em><sub>2</sub>, …, <em>a</em><sub><em>k</em></sub>, <em>p</em></span> and <span class="math"><em>n</em> ≤ 1 + 2∑ <sub><em>i</em> = 1</sub><sup><em>k</em></sup>(<em>a</em><sub><em>i</em></sub> − 1)</span>; and</p></li><li><p>with two exceptions and two potential exceptions any abelian group of rank two.</p></li></ul>	string

1142	en_US	title	A normal quotient analysis for some families of oriented four-valent graphs	string
1142	en_US	cleanTitle	A normal quotient analysis for some families of oriented fourvalent graphs	string
1142	en_US	abstract	<p>We analyse the normal quotient structure of several infinite families of finite connected edge-transitive, four-valent oriented graphs. These families were singled out by Marušič and others to illustrate various different internal structures for these graphs in terms of their alternating cycles (cycles in which consecutive edges have opposite orientations). Studying the normal quotients gives fresh insights into these oriented graphs: in particular we discovered some unexpected ‘cross-overs’ between these graph families when we formed normal quotients. We determine which of these oriented graphs are ‘basic’, in the sense that their only proper normal quotients are degenerate. Moreover, we show that the three types of edge-orientations studied are the only orientations, of the underlying undirected graphs in these families, which are invariant under a group action which is both vertex-transitive and edge-transitive.</p>	string
1142	en_US	discipline	Combinatorics; group theory	string

1143	en_US	title	Properties, proved and conjectured, of Keller, Mycielski, and queen graphs	string
1143	en_US	cleanTitle	Properties proved and conjectured of Keller Mycielski and queen graphs	string
1143	en_US	abstract	<p>We prove several results about three families of graphs. For queen graphs, defined from the usual moves of a chess queen, we find the edge-chromatic number in almost all cases. In the unproved case, we have a conjecture supported by a vast amount of computation, which involved the development of a new edge-coloring algorithm. The conjecture is that the edge-chromatic number is the maximum degree, except when simple arithmetic forces the edge-chromatic number to be one greater than the maximum degree. For Mycielski graphs, we strengthen an old result that the graphs are Hamiltonian by showing that they are Hamilton-connected (except <span class="math"><em>M</em><sub>3</sub></span>, which is a cycle). For Keller graphs <span class="math"><em>G</em><sub><em>d</em></sub></span>, we establish, in all cases, the exact value of the chromatic number, the edge-chromatic number, and the independence number; and we get the clique covering number in all cases except <span class="math">5 ≤ <em>d</em> ≤ 7</span>. We also investigate Hamiltonian decompositions of Keller graphs, obtaining them up to <span class="math"><em>G</em><sub>6</sub></span>.</p>	string

1146	en_US	title	Vertex-transitive graphs and their arc-types	string
1146	en_US	cleanTitle	Vertextransitive graphs and their arctypes	string
1146	en_US	abstract	<p>Let <span class="math"><em>X</em></span> be a finite vertex-transitive graph of valency <span class="math"><em>d</em></span>, and let <span class="math"><em>A</em></span> be the full automorphism group of <span class="math"><em>X</em></span>. Then the <span><em>arc-type</em></span> of <span class="math"><em>X</em></span> is defined in terms of the sizes of the orbits of the stabiliser <span class="math"><em>A</em><sub><em>v</em></sub></span> of a given vertex <span class="math"><em>v</em></span> on the set of arcs incident with <span class="math"><em>v</em></span>. Such an orbit is said to be <span><em>self-paired</em></span> if it is contained in an orbit <span class="math">Δ </span> of <span class="math"><em>A</em></span> on the set of all arcs of <span class="math"><em>X</em></span> such that <span class="math">Δ </span> is closed under arc-reversal. The arc-type of <span class="math"><em>X</em></span> is then the partition of <span class="math"><em>d</em></span> as the sum <span class="math"><em>n</em><sub>1</sub> + <em>n</em><sub>2</sub> + … + <em>n</em><sub><em>t</em></sub> + (<em>m</em><sub>1</sub> + <em>m</em><sub>1</sub>) + (<em>m</em><sub>2</sub> + <em>m</em><sub>2</sub>) + … + (<em>m</em><sub><em>s</em></sub> + <em>m</em><sub><em>s</em></sub>)</span>, where <span class="math"><em>n</em><sub>1</sub>, <em>n</em><sub>2</sub>, …, <em>n</em><sub><em>t</em></sub></span> are the sizes of the self-paired orbits, and <span class="math"><em>m</em><sub>1</sub>, <em>m</em><sub>1</sub>, <em>m</em><sub>2</sub>, <em>m</em><sub>2</sub>, …, <em>m</em><sub><em>s</em></sub>, <em>m</em><sub><em>s</em></sub></span> are the sizes of the non-self-paired orbits, in descending order. In this paper, we find the arc-types of several families of graphs. Also we show that the arc-type of a Cartesian product of two ‘relatively prime’ graphs is the natural sum of their arc-types. Then using these observations, we show that with the exception of <span class="math">1 + 1</span> and <span class="math">(1 + 1)</span>, every partition as defined above is <em>realisable</em>, in the sense that there exists at least one vertex-transitive graph with the given partition as its arc-type.</p>	string

1160	en_US	abstract	<p>A graph $G$ is equitably $k$-colorable if its vertices can be partitioned into $k$ independent sets in such a way that the number of vertices in any two sets differ by at most one. 1350	en_US	abstract	<p>One of the most useful strategies for proving Breaker’s win in Maker-Breaker Positional Games is to find a pairing strategy. In some cases there are no pairing strategies at all, in some cases there are unique or almost unique strategies. For the <span class="math inline"><em>k</em></span>-in-a-row game, the case <span class="math inline"><em>k</em> = 9</span> is the smallest (sharp) for which there exists a Breaker winning pairing (paving) strategy. One pairing strategy for this game was given by Hales and Jewett.</p><p>In this paper we show that there are other winning pairings for the <span class="math inline">9</span>-in-a-row game, all have a very symmetric torus structure. While describing these symmetries we prove that there are only a finite number of non-isomorphic pairings for the game (around <span class="math inline">200</span> thousand), which can be also listed up by a computer program. In addition, we prove that there are no “irregular”, non-symmetric pairings. At the end of the paper we also show a pairing strategy for a variant of the <span class="math inline">3</span>-dimensional <span class="math inline"><em>k</em></span>-in-a-row game.</p>	string

1166	en_US	title	Uniform hypergraphs and dominating sets of graphs	string
1166	en_US	cleanTitle	Uniform hypergraphs and dominating sets of graphs	string
1166	en_US	abstract	<p>A (simple) hypergraph is a family H of pairwise incomparable sets of a finite set $\\Omega$. We say that a hypergraph H is a <em>domination hypergraph </em>if there is at least a graph G such that the collection of minimal dominating sets of G is equal to H. Given a hypergraph H, we are interested in determining if it is a domination hypergraph and, <br />if this is not the case, we want to find domination hypergraphs in some sense close to it, the <em>domination completions</em> of H. Here we will focus on the family of hypergraphs containing all the subsets with the same cardinality, the <em>uniform hypergraphs</em> of maximum size. Specifically, we characterize those hypergraphs H in this family that are domination hypergraphs and, in any other case, we prove that the domination completions of H exist. In addition to this, in this case we demonstrate that the hypergraph H is completely determined by some of its domination completions; namely, we prove that H can be recovered from its minimal domination completions by using a suitable hypergraph operation.</p>	string

1167	en_US	abstract	<p class="p1">An equitable colouring of a balanced G-design (X,B) is a map φ∶B → C such that ∣b<span class="s1">i</span>(x)−b<span class="s1">j</span>(x)∣ ≤ 1 for any x ∈ X and i,j, with i ≠ j, being b<span class="s1">i</span>(x) the number of blocks containing the vertex x and coloured with the colour i. A c-colouring is a colouring in which exactly c colours are used. A c-colouring of type s is a colourings in which, for every vertex x, all the blocks containing x are coloured exactly with s colours. A bicolouring, tricolouring or quadricolouring is an equitable colouring with s = 2, s = 3 or s = 4. In this paper we consider systems of graphs consisting of a 4-cycle and a pendant edge. We call such a graph a 4-kite and we consider balanced 4-kite systems. In particular, we prove that c-bicolourings of balanced 4-kite systems exist if and only if c = 2, 3.</p>	string

1171	en_US	title	A Modified Effective Ant Colony Optimization for the Vehicle Routing Problem with Simultaneous Pickup and Delivery	string
1171	en_US	cleanTitle	A Modified Effective Ant Colony Optimization for the Vehicle Routing Problem with Simultaneous Pickup and Delivery	string
1171	en_US	abstract	<p>One of the most important extensions of the capacitated vehicle routing problem (CVRP) is the vehicle routing problem with simultaneous pickup and delivery (VRPSPD) where customers require simultaneous delivery and pick-up service. In this paper, we propose an effective ant colony optimization (EACO) which includes insert, swap and 2-Opt moves for solving VRPSPD that is different with common ant colony optimization (ACO). ACO is a meta-heuristic algorithm inspired by the foraging behavior of real ants. Artificial ants are used to build a solution for the problem by using the pheromone information from previously generated solutions. An extensive numerical experiment is performed on 68 benchmark problem instances involving up to 200 customers available in the literature. The computational result shows that EACO not only presented a very satisfying scalability, but also was competitive with other meta-heuristic algorithms such as tabu search, large neighborhood search, particle swarm optimization and genetic algorithm for solving VRPSPD problems.</p>	string

1172	en_US	title	On domination-type invariants of Fibonacci cubes and hypercubes	string
1172	en_US	cleanTitle	On dominationtype invariants of Fibonacci cubes and hypercubes	string
1172	en_US	abstract	The Fibonacci cube <span class="math inline">Γ<sub><em>n</em></sub></span> is the subgraph of the <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span>-dimensional cube <span class="math inline"><em>Q</em><sub><em>n</em></sub></span> induced by the vertices that contain no two consecutive 1s. Using integer linear programming, exact values are obtained for <span class="math inline">γ<sub><em>t</em></sub>(Γ<sub><em>n</em></sub>)</span>, <span class="math inline"><em>n</em> ≤ 12</span>. Consequently, <span class="math inline">γ<sub><em>t</em></sub>(Γ<sub><em>n</em></sub>) ≤ 2<em>F</em><sub><em>n</em> − 10</sub> + 21<em>F</em><sub><em>n</em> − 8</sub></span> holds for <span class="math inline"><em>n</em> ≥ 11</span>, where <span class="math inline"><em>F</em><sub><em>n</em></sub></span> are the Fibonacci numbers. It is proved that if <span class="math inline"><em>n</em> ≥ 9</span>, then <span class="math inline">γ<sub><em>t</em></sub>(Γ<sub><em>n</em></sub>) ≥ ⌈(<em>F</em><sub><em>n</em> + 2</sub>−11)/(<em>n</em>−3)⌉ − 1</span>. Using integer linear programming exact values for the 2-packing number, connected domination number, paired domination number, and signed domination number of small Fibonacci cubes and hypercubes are obtained. A conjecture on the total domination number of hypercubes asserting that <span class="math inline">γ<sub><em>t</em></sub>(<em>Q</em><sub><em>n</em></sub>)=2<sup><em>n</em> − 2</sup></span> holds for <span class="math inline"><em>n</em> ≥ 6</span> is also disproved in several ways.	string

1176	en_US	title	On hypohamiltonian snarks and a theorem of Fiorini	string
1176	en_US	cleanTitle	On hypohamiltonian snarks and a theorem of Fiorini	string
1176	en_US	abstract	In 2003, Cavicchioli et al. corrected an omission in the statement and proof of Fiorini’s theorem from 1983 on hypohamiltonian snarks. However, their version of this theorem contains an unattainable condition for certain cases. We discuss and extend the results of Fiorini and Cavicchioli et al. and present a version of this theorem which is more general in several ways. Using Fiorini’s erroneous result, Steffen had shown that hypohamiltonian snarks exist for some orders <span class="math inline"><em>n</em> ≥ 10</span> and each even <span class="math inline"><em>n</em> ≥ 92</span>. We rectify Steffen’s proof by providing a correct demonstration of a technical lemma on flower snarks, which might be of separate interest. We then strengthen Steffen’s theorem to the strongest possible form by determining all orders for which hypohamiltonian snarks exist. This also strengthens a result of Máčajová and Škoviera. Finally, we verify a conjecture of Steffen on hypohamiltonian snarks up to 36 vertices.	string

1183	en_US	title	The normalized  Laplacian, degree-Kirchhoff index and the spanning trees of linear pentagonal chains	string
1183	en_US	cleanTitle	The normalized  Laplacian degreeKirchhoff index and the spanning trees of linear pentagonal chains	string
1183	en_US	abstract	Let $W_n$ be a linear pentagonal chain with $2n$ pentagons. In this article, according to the decomposition theorem for the normalized  Laplacian polynomial of $W_n$, we obtain that the normalized Laplacian spectrum of $W_n$ consists of the eigenvalues of two special matrices: $\\mathcal {L}_A$ of order $3n+1$ and $\\mathcal {L}_S$ of order $2n+1$. Together with the relationship between the roots and coefficients of the characteristic polynomials of the above two matrices, explicit closed-form formulas for the degree-Kirchhoff index and the total number of spanning trees of $W_n$ are derived, respectively. Finally, it is interesting to find that the degree-Kirchhoff index of $W_n$ is approximately to one half of its Gutman index.	string

1184	en_US	abstract	<p>The Szeged index of a graph $G=(V,E)$ is defined as<br />$Sz(G)=\\sum_{e=uv\\in E}n_u(e)n_v(e),$<br />where $n_u(e)$ and $n_v(e)$ are,<br />respectively, the number of vertices of $G$ lying closer to vertex $u$ than to<br />vertex $v$ and the number of vertices of $G$ lying closer to vertex $v$ than to vertex $u$.<br />A cactus is a graph in which any two cycles have at most one common vertex. Let $\\mathcal{C}(n,k)$ denote the class of all cacti with order $n$ and $k$ cycles, and $\\mathcal{C}_n^t$ denote the class of all cacti with order $n$ and $t$ pendant vertices.<br />In this paper, a lower bound of the Szeged index<br />for cacti of order $n$ with $k$ cycles is determined, and all the graphs that achieve the lower bound are identified.<br />As well, the unique graph in $\\mathcal{C}_n^t$ with minimum Szeged index is characterized.</p>	string

1185	en_US	title	Uniquely identifying the edges of a graph: the edge metric dimension	string
1185	en_US	cleanTitle	Uniquely identifying the edges of a graph: the edge metric dimension	string
1185	en_US	abstract	Let $G=(V,E)$ be a connected graph, let $v\\in V$ be a vertex and let $e=uw\\in E$ be an edge. The distance between the vertex $v$ and the edge $e$ is given by $d_G(e,v)=\\min\\{d_G(u,v),d_G(w,v)\\}$. A vertex $w\\in V$ distinguishes two edges $e_1,e_2\\in E$ if $d_G(w,e_1)\\ne d_G(w,e_2)$. A set $S$ of vertices in a connected graph $G$ is an edge metric generator for $G$ if every two edges of $G$ are distinguished by some vertex of $S$. The smallest cardinality of an edge metric generator for $G$ is called the edge metric dimension and is denoted by $edim(G)$. In this article we introduce the concept of edge metric dimension and initiate the study of its mathematical properties. We make a comparison between the edge metric dimension and the standard metric dimension of graphs while presenting some realization results concerning the edge metric dimension and the standard metric dimension of graphs. We prove that computing the edge metric dimension of connected graphs is NP-hard and give some approximation results. Moreover, we present some bounds and closed formulae for the edge metric dimension of several classes of graphs.	string

1189	en_US	abstract	<p>A graph, with a group $G$ of its automorphisms, is said to be $(G,s)$-transitive, if $G$ is transitive on $s$-arcs but not on $(s+1)$-arcs of the graph. Let $X$ be a connected $(G,s)$-transitive graph, and let $G_v$ be the vertex stabilizer of a vertex $v\\in V(X)$ in $G$. In this paper, we determine the structure of the vertex stabilizer $G_v$ when $X$ has valency eight. In particular, $|G_v|$ has no upper bound when $s=1$. 1190	en_US	abstract	The enumeration of the regions formed when circle  is divided by secants drawn from points on the circle is one of the examples where the inductive reasoning fails as was pointed out by Leo Moser in the Mathematical Miscellany in 1949. The formula that gives the right number of regions can be deduced by combinatorics reasoning, by using the Euler's planar graph formula, etc. My contribution in the present work is to reformulate and solve such problem in terms of a  fourth order difference equation and to obtain the formula proposed by Leo Moser.<br /><br />	string

1191	en_US	title	Spectra of some partial joins of subdivision of two regular graphs	string

1191	en_US	abstract	The subdivision graph $S(G)$ of a graph $G$ is the graph obtained by inserting a new vertex into every edge of $G$. The set of all these new vertices is denoted by $I(G)$. For any two vertex-disjoint graphs $G_{1}$ and $G_{2}$, the \\textit{subdivision-vertex-vertex join} graph $S(G_{1})\\ddot{\\vee} S(G_{2})$, \\textit{subdivision-edge-edge join} graph $S(G_{1})\\overline{\\overline{\\vee}} S(G_{2})$, and \\textit{subdivision-edge-vertex join} graph $S(G_{1})\\overline{\\dot{\\vee}} S(G_{2})$ of $G_{1}$ and $G_{2}$ are obtained from $S(G_{1})$ and $S(G_{2})$ by joining each vertex of $V(G_{1})$ with every vertex of $V(G_{2})$, each vertex of $I(G_{1})$ with every vertex of $I(G_{2})$, and each vertex of $I(G_{1})$ with every vertex of $V(G_{2})$ respectively. In this paper, we determine the adjacency, Laplacian, signless Laplacian and normalized Laplacian spectra of all the above joins of a connected regular graph with an arbitrary regular graph in terms of the corresponding spectra of the original graphs.
