1192	en_US	abstract	An edge set $S$ of a connected graph $G$ is an called anti-Kekul\\'e set if $G-S$ is connected and has no perfect matchings, where $G-S$ denotes the subgraph obtained by deleting all edges in $S$ from $G$. The anti-Kekul\\'e number of a graph $G$, denoted by $ak(G)$, is the cardinality of a smallest anti-Kekul\\'e set of $G$. It is NP-complete to determine the anti-Kekul\\'e number of a graph. In this paper, we show that the anti-Kekul\\'{e} number of a 2-connected cubic graph is either 3 or 4, and the anti-Kekul\\'{e} number of a connected cubic bipartite graph is always equal to 4.<br />Furthermore, a polynomial time algorithm is given to find all smallest anti-Kekul\\'{e} sets of a connected cubic graph.	string

1199	en_US	abstract	<p>A vertex signature $\\pi$ of a finite graph $G$ is any mapping $V(G)\\to \\{0,1\\}$.<br /> An edge-coloring of $G$ is said to be \\textit{vertex-parity} for the pair $(G,\\pi)$ if for every vertex $v$ each color used on the edges incident to $v$<br /> appears in parity accordance with $\\pi$, i.e. an even or odd number of times depending on whether $\\pi(v)$ equals $0$ or $1$, respectively.<br /> The minimum number of colors for which $(G,\\pi)$ admits such an edge-coloring is denoted by $\\chi'_p(G,\\pi)$.<br /> We characterize the existence and prove that $\\chi'_p(G,\\pi)$ is at most $6$.<br /> Furthermore, we give a structural characterization of the equalities $\\chi'_p(G,\\pi)=5$ and $\\chi'_p(G,\\pi)=6$.</p>	string

1200	en_US	title	Invariant regions for some strongly coupled reaction-diffusion systems non-dissipative.	string
1200	en_US	cleanTitle	Invariant regions for some strongly coupled reactiondiffusion systems nondissipative	string
1200	en_US	abstract	<p>In this work we present some simple techniques concerning the construction of invariant regions for some strongly coupled reaction-diffusion systems non-dissipative with a full diffusion matrix and their applications to some chemical, biological and dynamics of populations models. For such systems, namely when they are described by more then two equations, we have not seen substantial research results in the front of global existence in time until recently. An inherent difficulty in systems of the type considered, is that the asymptotic sign condition in vector version</p><p> u⋅f(u)≤0,  for all u∈ℝ^{m}: |u|≥C ,   #(*)</p><p>(where C is a positive constant and f is the nonlinear term, representing the reaction), is not satisfied. Usually this condition plays a key role in the dissipation process, and thus if it is satisfied, often leads to the existence of a bounded invariant regions and then global existence for the system. In the case of systems formed with two equations and under the condition (*) satisfied for all u=(u₁,u₂)∈ℝ² (i.e. C=0) in the scalar version (i.e. u₁.f₁(u) and u₁.f₂(u) don't change sign, where f=(f₁,f₂)) many partial results have been obtained when the balance law is strict and recently for more general nonlinearities. In this work, in order to construct bounded invariant regions and obtain global existence, we shall alleviate the condition (*) to be satisfied in the direction of each eigenvector (with sufficiently large norm) associated to the diffusion matrix. This means that we don't impose to the reactions to satisfy the condition (*) in both the vector and the scalar version and not necessary on the whole space ℝ^{m}, in addition we don't impose any conditions on the growth of the nonlinearities.</p>	string
1200	en_US	discipline		string
1200	en_US	subjectClass	35K57, 35K45	string
1200	en_US	subject	Reaction diffusion systems, Invariant regions, Global existence.	string
1200	en_US	sponsor	Project supported by the Deanship of Scientific Research, Qassim University, KSA,  under the number (3388 ) during the academic year 1436 AH / 2015 AD.	string
1201	en_US	title	All One Relator Quotients of PSL(2,Z) with Fibonacci Sequence	string
1201	en_US	cleanTitle	All One Relator Quotients of PSL2Z with Fibonacci Sequence	string
1201	en_US	abstract	Marston Conder found the quotients of the modular group by inserting an extra relation in the existing relations of the group. The length of extra relation was considered a small finite integer. In this paper, we find all the quotients of PSL(2,Z) by inserting an extra relation of the form w(x,y), so that the length of this extra relation is any positive integer and powers of the generators x and y in w(x,y) are considered as Fibonacci sequence of numbers. Finally we make complete classification of all the quotients of the modular group on the basis of length of the additional relation.	string

1202	en_US	cleanTitle	Regular dessins d'enfants with field of moduli Q<sup><em>p</em></sup>√2	string
1202	en_US	abstract	<p>Herradon has recently provided an example of a regular dessin d’enfant whose field of moduli is the non-abelian extension <span class="math"><strong>Q</strong>(<sup>3</sup>√2)</span> answering in this way a question due to Conder, Jones, Streit and Wolfart. In this paper we observe that Herradon’s example belongs naturally to an infinite series of such kind of examples; for each prime integer <span class="math"><em>p</em> ≥ 3</span> we construct a regular dessin d’enfant whose field of moduli is the non-abelian extension <span class="math"><strong>Q</strong>(<sup><em>p</em></sup>√2)</span>; for <span class="math"><em>p</em> = 3</span> it coincides with Herradon’s example.</p>	string

1203	en_US	title	Some families of graphs with no nonzero  real domination roots	string
1203	en_US	cleanTitle	Some families of graphs with no nonzero  real domination roots	string
1203	en_US	abstract	Let G be a simple graph of order n. The domination polynomial of G is the polynomial $D(G, x)=\\sum_{i= \\gamma(G)}^n d(G, i) x^ i$, where d(G, i) is the number of dominating sets of G of size i and $\\gamma(G)$ is the domination number of G. A root of D(G, x) is called a domination root of G. In the study of the domination roots of graphs , this naturally raises the question: Which graphs have no nonzero real domination roots? In this paper we present some families of graphs whose have this property.	string

1204	en_US	title	Parallel Communicating Grammar Systems with Context-Free Components Are Turing Complete for Any Communication Model	string
1204	en_US	cleanTitle	Parallel Communicating Grammar Systems with ContextFree Components Are Turing Complete for Any Communication Model	string
1204	en_US	abstract	Parallel Communicating Grammar Systems (PCGS) were introduced as a language-theoretic treatment of concurrent systems. A PCGS extends the concept of a grammar to a structure that consists of several grammars working in parallel, communicating with each other, and so contributing to the generation of strings.  PCGS are usually more powerful than a single grammar of the same type; PCGS with context-free components (CF-PCGS) in particular were shown to be Turing complete.  However, this result only holds when a specific type of communication (which we call broadcast communication, as opposed to one-step communication) is used.  We expand the original construction that showed Turing completeness so that broadcast communication is eliminated at the expense of introducing a significant number of additional, helper component grammars.  We thus show that CF-PCGS with one-step communication are also Turing complete.  We introduce in the process several techniques that may be usable in other constructions and may be capable of removing broadcast communication in general.	string
1204	en_US	discipline	Computer Science; formal languages	string
1204	en_US	subjectClass	68Q45, 68Q10, 68Q42, 68Q15	string
1204	en_US	subject	formal languages; theory of computation; formal grammar; parallel communicating grammar system; Turing completeness	string
1204	en_US	sponsor		string
1205	en_US	title	Yet another coloring problem with applications: Spectrum graph coloring	string
1205	en_US	cleanTitle	Yet another coloring problem with applications: Spectrum graph coloring	string
1205	en_US	abstract	We introduce and explore a family vertex-coloring problems which, surprisingly enough, have not been considered before despite they naturally steam from the problem of WiFi channel assignment. Given a spectrum of colors, endowed with a matrix of interferences between each pair of colors, the Threshold Spectrum Coloring problem fixes the number of colors available and aims to minimize the interference threshold, i.e., the maximum of the interferences at the vertices. Conversely, the Chromatic Spectrum Coloring problem fixes a threshold and aims to minimize the number of colors for which respecting that threshold is possible. As theoretical results, we show that both problems are NP-hard and we prove upper bounds for the solutions to each problem, with potential applications to the design and planning of wireless network infrastructures. We complete the scene with experimental results, proposing a DSATUR-based heuristic and showing its good performance minimizing the maximum vertex interference in WiFi channel assignment.	string

1209	en_US	abstract	The construction of a cycle in a graph can be realized by<br />iteratively adding cycles of a cycle basis.  The construction of<br />each elementary cycle is only possible if this cycle basis is<br />robust.  In the last years, different classes of robust cycle bases<br />have been established.  We compare these classes and show that they<br />are completely unrelated.  More precisely, we draw a Venn diagram<br />which displays the obvious containedness relations and show that<br />each of its regions is not empty.  In addition, we continue the<br />comparison with fundamental cycle bases.	string

1213	en_US	title	Convolution identities for Tribonacci numbers	string
1213	en_US	cleanTitle	Convolution identities for Tribonacci numbers	string
1213	en_US	abstract	Many kinds of convolution identities have been considered about several numbers, including Bernoulli, Euler, Genocchi, Cauchy, Stirling, and Fibonacci numbers. The well-known basic result about Bernoulli numbers is due to Euler. The convolution identities have been studied. <br /><br />In this paper, we give convolution identities for Tribonacci numbers without binomial coefficients and with binomial coefficients. Convolution identities of Fiboancci numbers or Lucas numbers can be expressed in the form of linear combinations of Fibonacci numbers and Lucas numbers only. Fibonacci numbers and Lucas numbers are in pairs with different values. Covolution identities of Tribonacci numbers can be expressed in the linear combination of several Tribonacci numbers with different values.  Symmetric formulas are basic tools for these expressions.	string

1218	en_US	title	Maximum cuts of graphs with forbidden cycles	string
1218	en_US	cleanTitle	Maximum cuts of graphs with forbidden cycles	string
1218	en_US	abstract	<p>For a graph <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span>, let <span class="math inline"><em>f</em>(<em>G</em>)</span> denote the maximum number of edges in a bipartite subgraph of <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span>. For an integer <span class="math inline"><em>m</em> ≥ 1</span> and for a set <span class="math inline">ℋ</span> of graphs, let <span class="math inline"><em>f</em>(<em>m</em>, ℋ)</span> denote the minimum possible cardinality of <span class="math inline"><em>f</em>(<em>G</em>)</span>, as <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> ranges over all graphs on <span class="math inline"><em>m</em></span> edges that contain no member of <span class="math inline">ℋ</span> as a subgraph. In particular, for a given graph <span class="math inline"><em>H</em></span>, we simply write <span class="math inline"><em>f</em>(<em>m</em>, <em>H</em>)</span> for <span class="math inline"><em>f</em>(<em>m</em>, ℋ)</span> when <span class="math inline">ℋ = {<em>H</em>}</span>. Let <span class="math inline"><em>r</em> &gt; 4</span> be a fixed even integer. Alon et al. (2003) conjectured that there exists a positive constant <span class="math inline"><em>c</em>(<em>r</em>)</span> such that <span class="math inline"><em>f</em>(<em>m</em>, <em>C</em><sub><em>r</em> − 1</sub>) ≥ <em>m</em>/2 + <em>c</em>(<em>r</em>)<em>m</em><sup><em>r</em>/(<em>r</em> + 1)</sup></span> for all <span class="math inline"><em>m</em></span>. In the present article, we show that <span class="math inline"><em>f</em>(<em>m</em>, <em>C</em><sub><em>r</em> − 1</sub>) ≥ <em>m</em>/2 + <em>c</em>(<em>r</em>)(<em>m</em><sup><em>r</em></sup>log<sup>4</sup><em>m</em>)<sup>1/(<em>r</em> + 2)</sup></span> for some positive constant <span class="math inline"><em>c</em>(<em>r</em>)</span> and all <span class="math inline"><em>m</em></span>. For any fixed integer <span class="math inline"><em>s</em> ≥ 2</span>, we also study the function <span class="math inline"><em>f</em>(<em>m</em>, ℋ)</span> for <span class="math inline">ℋ = {<em>K</em><sub>2, <em>s</em></sub>, <em>C</em><sub>5</sub>}</span> and <span class="math inline">ℋ = {<em>C</em><sub>4</sub>, <em>C</em><sub>5</sub>, …, <em>C</em><sub><em>r</em> − 1</sub>}</span>, both of which improve the results of Alon et al.</p>	string

1226	en_US	title	Spectra and structural polynomials of graphs of relevance to the theory of molecular conduction	string
1226	en_US	cleanTitle	Spectra and structural polynomials of graphs of relevance to the theory of molecular conduction	string
1226	en_US	abstract	<p>In chemistry and physics, distortivity of <span class="math"><em>π</em></span>-systems (stabilisation of bond-alternated structures) is an important factor in the calculation of geometric, energetic, and electronic properties of molecules <span><em>via</em></span> graph theoretical methods. We use the spectra of paths and cycles with alternating vertex and edge weights to obtain the eigenvalues and eigenvectors for a class of linear and cyclic ladders with alternating rung and backbone edge weights. We derive characteristic polynomials and other structural polynomials formed from the cofactors of the characteristic matrix for these graphs. We also obtain spectra and structural polynomials for ladders with flipped weights and/or Möbius topology. In all cases, the structural polynomials for the composite graphs are expressed in terms of products of polynomials for graphs of half order. This form of the expressions allows global deductions about the transmission spectra of molecular devices in the graph-theoretical theory of ballistic molecular conduction.</p>	string

1227	en_US	title	On two conjectures of spectral graph theory	string
1227	en_US	cleanTitle	On two conjectures of spectral graph theory	string
1227	en_US	abstract	<p>Let $G=(V,\\,E)$ be a simple graph. Denote by $D(G)$ the diagonal matrix of its vertex degrees and by $A(G)$ its adjacency matrix.<br /> Then the Laplacian matrix and the signless Laplacian matrix of $G$ are $L(G)=D(G)-A(G)$ and $Q(G)=D(G)+A(G)$, respectively.<br /> Also denote by $\\lambda_1(G)$, $a(G)$, $q_1(G)$ and $\\delta(G)$ the largest eigenvalue of $A(G)$, the second smallest eigenvalue of<br /> $L(G)$, the largest eigenvalue of $Q(G)$ and the minimum degree of $G$, respectively.<br /> In this paper, we give partial proofs to the following two conjectures:</p><p><span style="font-size: 10px;">$(i)$ \\cite{AO,ACH} If $G$ is a connected graph, then $a(G)/\\delta(G)$ is minimum for graph composed of $2$ triangles linked with a path.\\par\\vspace{0.20cm}\\noindent</span></p><p>$(ii)$ \\cite{AH,CRS} If $G$ is a connected graph with $n\\geq 4$ vertices, then $q_1(G)-2\\,\\lambda_1(G)\\leq n-2\\,\\sqrt{n-1}$<br /> with equality holding if and only if $G\\cong K_{1,n-1}$.</p>	string

1228	en_US	title	Touching perfect matchings and halving lines	string
1228	en_US	cleanTitle	Touching perfect matchings and halving lines	string
1228	en_US	abstract	<p>Let <span class="math inline"><em>V</em></span> be a set of <span class="math inline">2<em>m</em></span> (<span class="math inline">1 ≤ <em>m</em> &lt; ∞</span>) points in the plane. Two segments <span class="math inline"><em>I</em>, <em>J</em></span> with endpoints in <span class="math inline"><em>V</em></span> <em>cross</em> if <span class="math inline">relint <em>I</em> ∩ relint <em>J</em></span> is a singleton. A (perfect) <em>cross-matching</em> <span class="math inline"><em>M</em></span> on <span class="math inline"><em>V</em></span> is a set of <span class="math inline"><em>m</em></span> segments with endpoints in <span class="math inline"><em>V</em></span> such that every two segments in <span class="math inline"><em>M</em></span> cross. A <em>halving line</em> of <span class="math inline"><em>V</em></span> is a line <span class="math inline"><em>l</em></span> spanned by two points of <span class="math inline"><em>V</em></span> such that each one of the two open half planes bounded by <span class="math inline"><em>l</em></span> contains fewer than <span class="math inline"><em>m</em></span> points of <span class="math inline"><em>V</em></span>. Pach and Solymosi proved that if <span class="math inline"><em>V</em></span> is in general position, then <span class="math inline"><em>V</em></span> admits a perfect cross-matching iff <span class="math inline"><em>V</em></span> has exactly <span class="math inline"><em>m</em></span> halving lines. The aim of this note is to extend this result to the general case (where <span class="math inline"><em>V</em></span> is unrestricted).</p>	string

1229	en_US	abstract	The first-fit chromatic number of a graph is the maximum possible number of colors used in a first-fit coloring of the graph. In this paper, we investigate the first-fit chromatic numbers of union of graphs, multipartite graphs and a graph which is a triangulation of a closed surface and also for a special class of bipartite graphs. In addition we give a crisp description on the computational aspects of the first fit chromatic number and indicated the scope for further applications. We also raise some open problems.	string

1231	en_US	abstract	The distinguishing number (index) $D(G)$ ($D'(G)$)  of a graph $G$ is the least integer $d$ such that $G$ has an vertex labeling (edge labeling)  with $d$ labels  that is preserved only by a trivial automorphism. The Kronecker product $G\\times H$ of two graphs $G$ and $H$ is the graph with vertex set $V (G)\\times V (H)$ and edge set $\\{\\{(u, x), (v, y)\\} | \\{u, v\\} \\in E(G) ~and ~\\{x, y\\} \\in  E(H)\\}$. 1233	en_US	abstract	<p>The concept of $k$-independent number is a natural generalization of<br />classical independence number. 1235	en_US	title	An adaptive algorithm for the Euclidean Steiner tree problem in d-space	string
1235	en_US	cleanTitle	An adaptive algorithm for the Euclidean Steiner tree problem in dspace	string
1235	en_US	abstract	We describe a technique to improve Smith’s branch-and-bound algorithm for the Euclidean Steiner tree problem in Rd. The algorithm relies on the enumeration and optimization of full Steiner topologies for corresponding subsets of regular points. We handle the case of two Steiner points colliding during the optimization process — that is when there is a small enough distance between them — to dynamically change the exploration of the branch-and-bound tree. To do so, we introduce a simple means of reorganizing a topology to another. This enables reaching better minima faster, thus allowing the branch-and-bound to be further pruned. We also correct a mistake in Smith’s program by computing a lower bound for a Steiner tree with a specified topology and using it as a pruning technique prior to optimization. Because Steiner points lie in the plane formed by their three neighbors, we can build planar equilateral points and use them to compute the lower bound, even in dimensions higher than two.	string

1240	en_US	title	Alphabet-almost-simple 2-neighbour-transitive codes	string
1240	en_US	cleanTitle	Alphabetalmostsimple 2neighbourtransitive codes	string
1240	en_US	abstract	Let <span class="math inline"><em>X</em></span> be a subgroup of the full automorphism group of the Hamming graph <span class="math inline"><em>H</em>(<em>m</em>, <em>q</em>)</span>, and <span class="math inline"><em>C</em></span> a subset of the vertices of the Hamming graph. We say that <span class="math inline"><em>C</em></span> is an <em><span class="math inline">(<em>X</em>, 2)</span>-neighbour-transitive code</em> if <span class="math inline"><em>X</em></span> is transitive on <span class="math inline"><em>C</em></span>, as well as <span class="math inline"><em>C</em><sub>1</sub></span> and <span class="math inline"><em>C</em><sub>2</sub></span>, the sets of vertices which are distance <span class="math inline">1</span> and <span class="math inline">2</span> from the code. It has been shown that, given an <span class="math inline">(<em>X</em>, 2)</span>-neighbour-transitive code <span class="math inline"><em>C</em></span>, there exists a subgroup of <span class="math inline"><em>X</em></span> with a <span class="math inline">2</span>-transitive action on the alphabet; this action is thus almost-simple or affine. This paper completes the classification of <span class="math inline">(<em>X</em>, 2)</span>-neighbour-transitive codes, with minimum distance at least <span class="math inline">5</span>, where the subgroup of <span class="math inline"><em>X</em></span> stabilising some entry has an almost-simple action on the alphabet in the stabilised entry. The main result of this paper states that the class of <span class="math inline">(<em>X</em>, 2)</span> neighbour-transitive codes with an almost-simple action on the alphabet and minimum distance at least <span class="math inline">3</span> consists of one infinite family of well known codes.	string

1241	en_US	title	Locating Chromatic Number of Powers of Paths and Cycles	string
1241	en_US	cleanTitle	Locating Chromatic Number of Powers of Paths and Cycles	string
1241	en_US	abstract	<p>Let $c$ be a proper $k$-coloring of a graph $G$. Let $\\pi=\\{R_1,R_2,...,R_k\\}$ be the partition of $V (G)$ induced by $c$,<br />where $R_i$ is partition class receiving color $i$. The color code $c_\\pi(v)$ of a vertex $v$ of $G$ is the ordered $k$-tuple $(d(v,R_1),<br />d(v,R_2),... , $ $d(v,R_k))$ where $d(v,R_i)$ is the minimum distance from $v$ to each other vertex<br />$u\\in R_i$ for $1\\leq i \\leq k$. If all vertices of $G$ have distinct color codes, then $c$ is called a<br />locating $k$-coloring of $G$. The locating-chromatic number of $G$, denoted by $\\chi_L(G)$, is the smallest $k$ such that $ G$ admits a locating coloring<br />with k colors. In this paper, we give a characterization of the locating chromatic number of powers of paths. Also, we find sharp upper and lower bounds for the locating chromatic number of powers of cycles.</p>	string
1241	en_US	sponsor		string
1242	en_US	title	Pebbling on the middle graph of a complete binary tree	string
1242	en_US	cleanTitle	Pebbling on the middle graph of a complete binary tree	string
1242	en_US	abstract	<p>Given a distribution of pebbles on the vertices of a connected graph $G$, a pebbling move is defined as the removal of two pebbles from some vertex and the placement of one of those pebbles at an adjacent vertex. The $t$-pebbling number, $f_t(G)$, of a connected graph $G$, is the smallest positive integer such that from every placement of $f_t(G)$ pebbles, $t$ pebbles can be moved to any specified vertex by a sequence of pebbling moves. A graph $G$ has the $2t$-pebbling property if for any distribution with more than $2f_t(G) - q$ pebbles, where $q$ is the number of vertices with at least one pebble, it is possible, using the sequence of pebbling moves, to put $2t$ pebbles on any vertex. In this paper, we determine the $t$-pebbling number for the middle graph of a complete binary tree $M(B_h)$ and we show that the middle graph of a complete binary tree $M(B_h)$ satisfies the $2t$-pebbling property.</p>	string

1248	en_US	title	Mixed Connectivity of Random Graphs	string
1248	en_US	cleanTitle	Mixed Connectivity of Random Graphs	string
1248	en_US	abstract	For positive integers $k$ and $\\lambda$, a graph $G$ is $(k,\\lambda)$-connected if it satisfies the following conditions: (1) $|V(G)|\\ge k+1$; (2) for any subset $S\\subseteq V(G)$ and any subset $L\\subseteq E(G)$ with $\\lambda|S|+|L|&lt;k\\lambda$,  G-(S\\cup<br />L)$ is connected.  For positive integers $k$ and $\\ell$, a graph $G$ with $|V(G)|\\ge k+\\ell+1$ is said to be $(k,\\ell)$-mixed-connected if for any subset $S\\subseteq V(G)$ and any subset $L\\subseteq E(G)$ with $|S|\\le k, |L|\\le \\ell$ and $|S|+|L|&lt;k+\\ell$, $G-(S\\cup L)$ is connected. In this paper, we establish sharp threshold functions for<br />the $(k,\\lambda)$-connectivity and $(k,\\ell)$-mixed-connectivity of random graphs, generalizing  the results of Erd\\H os and R\\'enyi (1959), and Stepanov (1970).  Furthermore, our argument can show that in the random graph process $\\tilde G = \\left( {{G_t}} \\right)_0^N $, $N=\\binom{n}{2}$,  the hitting times of minimum degree at least $k\\lambda$ and of $G_t$ being $(k,\\lambda)$-connected coincide with high probability, and also the hitting times of minimum degree at least $k+\\ell$ and of $G_t$ being $(k,\\ell)$-mixed-connected coincide with high probability.  These results are analogous to the work of Bollob\\'as and Thomassen (1986) on classic connectivity.	string

1250	en_US	abstract	<pre>The trace norm <span>$||A||_*$</span> of a matrix <span>$A$</span> is defined as the sum of its singular values. In this paper we address the following problem: among all orientations of a given tree, which has minimal and which has maximal trace norm? We show that the minimal trace norm is attained in sink-source orientations (i.e. every vertex is a sink or a source). In the case of trees with <span>nonadjacent</span> branching vertices, we show that the maximal trace norm is attained in balanced orientations (i.e. <span>$|d^+(u)-d^-(u)|\\leqslant 1$</span> for all vertices <span>$u$</span>). </pre>	string

1256	en_US	abstract	<p>Nowakowski and Rall [Associative graph products and their independence, domination and coloring numbers, Discussiones Mathematicae Graph Theory 16 (1996) 53-79.] observed that the domination number in ‎the lexicographic product of graphs G and H is multiplicative‎, that is, γ(G∙H)≤γ(G)γ(H). They also showed that γ_t(G∙H)≤γ_t(G). Where γ(G) and γ_t(G) are known as the domination number and the total domination number of G, respectively. In this paper, as an extension of Nowakowski and Rall's result, we show that if H is a graph with γ(H)=1, then γ(G∙H)=γ(G). Otherwise, if γ(H)≥2 and G has no isolated vertices, then γ(G∙H)=γ_t(G). Also for deleted lexicographic product of two graphs G and H, denoted  G∘H, we show that if G has no isolated vertices and H has at least two vertices, then γ(G∘H)≤min⁡{3γ(G),2γ_t(G)}. As an application of our result, we present formulae for domination and total domination number of open and closed fences.</p>	string

1257	en_US	title	On super edge magic deficiency of certain Toeplitz graphs	string
1257	en_US	cleanTitle	On super edge magic deficiency of certain Toeplitz graphs	string
1257	en_US	abstract	<p>A graph $G$ is called \\emph{edge-magic} if there exists a bijective function $\\phi:V(G)\\cup E(G)\\rightarrow \\{1, 2,\\dots , |V(G)|+|E(G)|\\}$ such that $\\phi(x)+\\phi(xy)+\\phi(y)=c(\\phi)$ is a constant for every edge $xy\\in<br />E(G)$, called the valence of $\\phi$. Moreover, $G$ is said to be \\emph{super edge-magic} if $\\phi(V(G))=\\{1,2,\\dots,|V(G)|\\}.$ The \\emph{super edge-magic deficiency} of a graph $G$, denoted by $\\mu_s(G),$ is the minimum nonnegative integer $n$ such that $G\\cup nK_1,$ has a super edge-magic labelings, if such integer does not exist we define $\\mu_s(G)$ to be $+\\infty.$ In this paper, we study the super edge-magic deficiency of some Toeplitz graphs.</p>	string

1259	en_US	title	Strong discrete Morse theory and simplicial L--S category: A discrete version of the Lusternik-Schnirelmann Theorem.	string
1259	en_US	cleanTitle	Strong discrete Morse theory and simplicial LS category: A discrete version of the LusternikSchnirelmann Theorem	string
1259	en_US	abstract	We prove a discrete version of the Lusternik--Schnirelmann theorem for discrete Morse functions and the recently introduced simplicial Lusternik--Schnirelmann category of a simplicial complex. To accomplish this, a new notion of critical object of a discrete Morse function is presented, which generalizes the usual concept of critical simplex (in the sense of R. Forman). We show that the non-existence of such critical objects guarantees the strong homotopy equivalence (in the Barmak and Minian's sense) between the corresponding sublevel complexes. Finally, we establish that the number of critical objects of a discrete Morse function defined on K is an upper bound for the non-normalized simplicial Lusternik--Schnirelmann category of K.	string

1262	en_US	title	Locating Chromatic Number of Powers of Paths and Cycles	string
1262	en_US	cleanTitle	Locating Chromatic Number of Powers of Paths and Cycles	string
1262	en_US	abstract	<p>Let $c$ be a proper $k$-coloring of a graph $G$. Let $\\pi=\\{R_1,R_2,...,R_k\\}$ be the partition of $V (G)$ induced by $c$,<br />where $R_i$ is partition class receiving color $i$. The color code $c_\\pi(v)$ of a vertex $v$ of $G$ is the ordered $k$-tuple $(d(v,R_1),<br />d(v,R_2),... , $ $d(v,R_k))$ where $d(v,R_i)$ is the minimum distance from $v$ to each other vertex<br />$u\\in R_i$ for $1\\leq i \\leq k$. If all vertices of $G$ have distinct color codes, then $c$ is called a<br />locating $k$-coloring of $G$. The locating-chromatic number of $G$, denoted by $\\chi_L(G)$, is the smallest $k$ such that $ G$ admits a locating coloring<br />with k colors. In this paper, we give a characterization of the locating chromatic number of powers of paths. Also, we find sharp upper and lower bounds for the locating chromatic number of powers of cycles.</p>	string

1264	en_US	abstract	<p>Mili\\v{c}evi\\'{c} et al. firstly introduced the reformulated Zagreb indices, which is<br />a natural generalization of classical Zagreb indices in chemical graph theory. A connected graph $G$ is called a cactus if and only if its every block is either a cycle or a edge.<br />Denote $\\mathscr{A}(n,r)$ the set of cacti of order $n$ with $r$ cycles.<br />Obviously, $\\mathscr{A}(n,0)$ is the set<br />of all trees and $\\mathscr{A}(n,1)$ is the set of all unicyclic graphs.<br />In the paper, we obtain some extremal properties of the first reformulated Zagreb index. 1245	en_US	title	Graph Reconstruction via Asymmetry	string
1245	en_US	cleanTitle	Graph Reconstruction via Asymmetry	string
1245	en_US	abstract	<p>Any graph which is not vertex transitive has a proper induced subgraph which is unique due to its structure or the way of its connection to the rest of the graph. The former is an anchor and the latter is a connective anchor, if it is distinguishable in the deck.</p><p>If a graph has an orbit (with at least three vertices) whose removal leaves an anchor, or it has two vertices whose removal leaves an anchor with the mentioned condition in the paper, then it is reconstructible. This simple statement is very efficient for the explanation of the reconstruction of a graph from its deck. For instance, the above fact explains the reconstruction of almost every graph, trees and small graphs from their deck.</p><p>Furthermore, the above result is enough to show that every graph with at least three vertices is reconstructible, provided that the two assumptions described in the paper, hold true.</p>	string

1266	en_US	abstract	We obtain some recurrence relationships among the partition vectors of the partial exponential Bell polynomials. On using such results, the n-th Adomian polynomial for any nonlinear operator can be expressed explicitly in terms of the partial exponential Bell polynomials. Some new identities for the partial exponential Bell polynomials are obtained by solving certain ordinary dierential equations using Adomian decomposition method. The corresponding results for the partial ordinary Bell polynomials are also discussed.	string

1426	en_US	abstract	<p>The generalized Oberwolfach problem <span class="math inline">OP<sub><em>t</em></sub>(2<em>w</em> + 1; <em>N</em><sub>1</sub>, <em>N</em><sub>2</sub>, …, <em>N</em><sub><em>t</em></sub>; <em>α</em><sub>1</sub>, <em>α</em><sub>2</sub>, …, <em>α</em><sub><em>t</em></sub>)</span> asks for a factorization of <span class="math inline"><em>K</em><sub>2<em>w</em> + 1</sub></span> into <span class="math inline"><em>α</em><sub><em>i</em></sub></span> <span class="math inline"><em>C</em><sub><em>N</em><sub><em>i</em></sub></sub></span>-factors (where a <span class="math inline"><em>C</em><sub><em>N</em><sub><em>i</em></sub></sub></span>-factor of <span class="math inline"><em>K</em><sub>2<em>w</em> + 1</sub></span> is a spanning subgraph whose components are cycles of length <span class="math inline"><em>N</em><sub><em>i</em></sub> ≥ 3</span>) for <span class="math inline"><em>i</em> = 1, 2, …, <em>t</em></span>. 1270	en_US	title	Vertex-transitive diameter two graphs	string
1270	en_US	cleanTitle	Vertextransitive diameter two graphs	string
1270	en_US	abstract	<p>We investigate the family of vertex-transitive graphs with diameter 2. Let $\\Gamma$ be such a graph. Suppose that its automorphism group is transitive on the set of ordered non-adjacent vertex pairs. Then either $\\Gamma$ is distance-transitive or $\\Gamma$ has girth at most $4$. Moreover, if $\\Gamma$ has valency $2$, then $\\Gamma\\cong C_4$ or $C_5$; and for any integer $n\\geq 3$, there exist infinitely many such $\\Gamma$ of valency $n$ such that its automorphism group is not transitive on the set of arcs. Also, we determine this family of graphs of valency less than $5$. Finally, the family of diameter 2 circulants is characterized.</p>	string

1277	en_US	title	Automorphism Groups of Geometrically Represented Graphs	string
1277	en_US	cleanTitle	Automorphism Groups of Geometrically Represented Graphs	string
1277	en_US	abstract	<p>We describe a technique to determine the automorphism group of a geometrically represented graph, by understanding the structure of the induced action on all geometric representations. Using this, we characterize automorphism groups of interval, permutation and circle graphs.  We combine techniques from group theory (products, homomorphisms, actions) with data structures from computer science (PQ-trees, split trees, modular trees) that encode all geometric representations.</p><p>We prove that interval graphs have the same automorphism groups as trees, and for a given interval graph, we construct a tree with the same automorphism group which answers a question of Hanlon [Trans. Amer. Math. Soc 272(2), 1982]. For permutation and circle graphs, we give Jordan-like inductive characterizations by semidirect and wreath products. We also prove that every abstract group can be realized by the automorphism group of a comparability graph/poset of the dimension at most four.</p>	string

1278	en_US	title	Global existence for some strongly coupled reaction-diffusion systems non-dissipative via invariant regions techniques.	string
1278	en_US	cleanTitle	Global existence for some strongly coupled reactiondiffusion systems nondissipative via invariant regions techniques	string
1278	en_US	abstract	<p>In this work, in order to prove global existence in time of solutions for some strongly coupled reaction-diffusion systems non-dissipative with a full diffusion matrix, we present some simple techniques based on the construction of invariant regions. Applications to some chemical, biological and dynamics of populations models are presented. For such systems, namely when they are described by more then two equations and with nonlinearities growth more than exponential, we have not seen substantial research results in the front of global existence in time until recently. An inherent difficulty in systems of the type considered, is that the asymptotic sign condition in vector version</p><p> u⋅f(u)≤0,  for all u∈ℝ^{m}: |u|≥C ,   #(*)</p><p>(where C is a positive constant and f is the nonlinear term, representing the reaction), is not satisfied. Usually this condition plays a key role in the dissipation process, and thus if it is satisfied, often leads to the existence of a bounded invariant regions and then global existence of the solutions for the system. In the case of systems formed with two equations and under the condition (*) satisfied for all u=(u₁,u₂)∈ℝ² (i.e. C=0) in the scalar version (i.e. u₁.f₁(u) and u₁.f₂(u) don't change sign, where f=(f₁,f₂)), many partial results have been obtained when the balance law is strict and recently for more general nonlinearities. In this work, in order to construct bounded invariant regions and obtain global existence, we shall alleviate the condition (*) to be satisfied in the direction of each eigenvector (with sufficiently large norm) associated to the diffusion matrix. This means that we don't impose to the reactions to satisfy the condition (*) in both the vector and the scalar versions and not necessary on the whole space ℝ^{m}. In addition we don't impose any conditions on the growth of the nonlinearities.</p>	string
1278	en_US	discipline		string
1278	en_US	subjectClass		string
1278	en_US	subject	Reaction diffusion systems, Invariant regions, Global existence.	string
1278	en_US	sponsor	Qassim University, Deanship of Scientific Research, KSA	string

The saturation number of <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> is the cardinality of any smallest maximal matching in <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span>. 1280	en_US	abstract	Let $G$ be a graph. Denote by $W(G)$ its Wiener index and denote by $L^i(G)$ its $i$-iterated line graph. Dobrynin and Mel'nikov proposed to estimate the extremal values for the ratio $R_k(G) = W(L^k(G))/W(G)$ for $k\\ge 1$. Motivated by this we study the ratio for higher~$k$'s. 1282	en_US	title	Characterizing all graphs with 2-exceptional edges	string
1282	en_US	cleanTitle	Characterizing all graphs with 2exceptional edges	string
1282	en_US	abstract	<p>Dirac and Shuster in 1954 exhibited a simple proof of Kuratowski theorem by showing that any <span class="math inline">1</span>-crossing-critical edge of <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> belongs to a Kuratowski subdivision of <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span>. In 1983, Širáň extended this result to any <span class="math inline">2</span>-crossing-critical edge <span class="math inline"><em>e</em></span> with endvertices <span class="math inline"><em>b</em></span> and <span class="math inline"><em>c</em></span> of a graph <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> with crossing number at least two, whenever no two blocks of <span class="math inline"><em>G</em> − <em>b</em> − <em>c</em></span> contain all its vertices. Calling an edge <span class="math inline"><em>f</em></span> of <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> <span class="math inline"><em>k</em></span>-<span><em>exceptional</em></span> whenever <span class="math inline"><em>f</em></span> is <span class="math inline"><em>k</em></span>-crossing-critical and it does not belong to any Kuratowski subgraph of <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span>, he showed that simple <span class="math inline">3</span>-connected graphs with <span class="math inline"><em>k</em></span>-exceptional edges exist for any <span class="math inline"><em>k</em> ≥ 6</span>, and they exist even for arbitrarily large difference of <span class="math inline"><em>c</em><em>r</em>(<em>G</em>) − <em>c</em><em>r</em>(<em>G</em> − <em>f</em>)</span>. In 1991, Kochol constructed such examples for any <span class="math inline"><em>k</em> ≥ 4</span>, and commented that Širáň’s result holds for any simple graph.</p><p>Examining the case when two blocks contain all the vertices of <span class="math inline"><em>G</em> − <em>b</em> − <em>c</em></span>, we show that graphs with <span class="math inline"><em>k</em></span>-exceptional edges exist for any <span class="math inline"><em>k</em> ≥ 2</span>, albeit not necessarily simple. We confirm that no such simple graphs with <span class="math inline">2</span>-exceptional edges exist by applying the techniques of the recent characterization of <span class="math inline">2</span>-crossing-critical graphs to explicitly describe the set of all graphs with <span class="math inline">2</span>-exceptional edges and noting they all contain parallel edges. In this context, the paper can be read as an accessible prelude to the characterization of <span class="math inline">2</span>-crossing-critical graphs.</p>	string

1285	en_US	cleanTitle	Inherited unitals in Moulton planes	string
1285	en_US	abstract	We prove that every Moulton plane of odd order—by duality every generalised André plane—contains a unital. We conjecture that such unitals are non-classical, that is, they are not isomorphic, as designs, to the Hermitian unital. We prove our conjecture for Moulton planes which differ from <span class="math inline">PG(2, <em>q</em><sup>2</sup>)</span> by a relatively small number of point-line incidences. Up to duality, our results extend previous analogous results—due to Barwick and Grüning—concerning inherited unitals in Hall planes.	string

1286	en_US	title	Bio-Mathematical model to determine the resonant frequencies of piezoelectric cylindrical transducers used in Biosensors by Rayleigh Ritz method	string
1286	en_US	cleanTitle	BioMathematical model to determine the resonant frequencies of piezoelectric cylindrical transducers used in Biosensors by Rayleigh Ritz method	string
1286	en_US	abstract	In Biosensors, one major component part is transducers which are made of smart materials like ferroelectric materials, piezoelectric materials and pyroelectric materials. In this paper, the resonant frequencies of hollow cylinder made of piezoelectric materials have been determined. The flexural vibration analysis of piezoelectric hollow cylinder has been made. The governing equations which include the stress, strain and electric field have been solved using the constitutive equations of piezoelectric by the finite element Rayleigh Ritz method. The numerical results have been carried out for PZT4 materials. The different dimensions of the hollow cylinders which are used in real life applications have been considered and the results are compared to obtain the optimum usability of these transducers. The frequency spectrum of PZT4 material under harmonic motion with different wave numbers has been obtained and the convergence analysis using residual error with Euclidean norm for different mesh size has been carried out.	string

1288	en_US	title	Contrast in Greyscales of Graphs	string
1288	en_US	cleanTitle	Contrast in Greyscales of Graphs	string
1288	en_US	abstract	<p> A  greyscale f of a graph G(V,E) is a mapping from V to the interval [0,1] such that {0, 1} \\subseteq Im(f). This function f induces another mapping $\\widehat{f}$ on E by assigning to each edge the non-negative difference of the values of f on its vertices. The  contrast vector cont(G,f) is defined as the vector $(\\widehat{f}(e_1),\\widehat{f}(e_2), \\ldots, \\widehat{f}(e_m))$ for all edges $e_i$ of G in such a way that $\\widehat{f}(e_i) \\leq \\widehat{f}(e_{i+1})$  for i= 1, 2, ..., m-1. The concept of   maximum contrast vector is  presented by using the lexicographical ordering in the set of contrast vectors of all possible greyscales defined on G and a greyscale that gives rise to  a maximum contrast vector is named  maximum contrast greyscale.</p><p>The relation between finding the maximum contrast vector for the graph G and the chromatic number of G is established.<br /> Thus the maximum contrast problem is an NP-complete problem.  <br />However, the set of values of any maximum contrast greyscale  for any graph is bounded by  a finite set which is given. Several <br />methods to compute the maximum contrast vector with some restrictions in are collected in this paper.</p>	string

1289	en_US	title	On the relationship between distinguishing number and distinguishing  index of a graph	string
1289	en_US	cleanTitle	On the relationship between distinguishing number and distinguishing  index of a graph	string
1289	en_US	abstract	The distinguishing number (index) $D(G)$ ($D'(G)$) of a graph $G$ is the least integer $d$ such that $G$ has an vertex labeling (edge labeling)  with $d$ labels  that is preserved only by a trivial automorphism. Motivated by a  theorem (Kalinowski and Pil\\'sniak, 2015) which state that for every graph of order $n \\geq 3$,  $D'(G) \\leq D(G) + 1$,  we characterize all finite simple connected graphs with $D'(G) = D(G) + 1$. Also, we describe all finite simple connected graphs with $D'(G) = D(G)$ and  $\\vert E(G)\\vert \\leq \\vert V(G)\\vert$.	string

1290	en_US	title	Saturation Numbers for Linear Forests $2P_4\\cup tP_2$	string

1290	en_US	abstract	<p>For a fixed graph $F$, a graph $G$ is $F$-saturated if it has no $F$ as a subgraph, but does contain $F$ after the addition of any new edge. The saturation number,$sat(n, F)$, is the minimum number of edges of a graph in the set of all $F$-saturated graphs with order $n$. In this<br />paper, we determine the saturation number $sat(n, 2P_4\\cup tP_2 )$ and characterize the extremal graphs for $n\\geq 6t + 22$.</p>	string

1291	en_US	title	On the size of maximally non-hamiltonian digraphs	string
1291	en_US	cleanTitle	On the size of maximally nonhamiltonian digraphs	string
1291	en_US	abstract	<p>A graph is called <em>maximally non-hamiltonian</em> if it is non-hamiltonian, yet for any two non-adjacent vertices there exists a hamiltonian path between them. In this paper, we naturally extend the concept to directed graphs and bound their size from below and above. Our results on the lower bound constitute our main contribution, while the upper bound can be obtained using a result of Lewin, but we give here a different proof. We describe digraphs attaining the upper bound, but whether our lower bound can be improved remains open.</p>	string

1292	en_US	abstract	For $n\\geq 5$ and  $2\\leq g\\leq n-3,$ consider the tree $P_{n-g,g}$ on $n$ vertices  which is obtained by adding $g$ pendant vertices to one degree $1$ vertex of the path $P_{n-g}$. We call the trees $P_{n-g,g}$ as path-star trees. We prove that over all trees on $n\\geq 5$ vertices, the distance between center and  subtree core and the distance between centroid and subtree core are maximized by some path-star trees. We also prove that the tree $P_{n-g_0,g_0}$ maximizes both the distances among all path-star trees on $n$ vertices, where $g_0$ is the smallest positive integer such that $2^{g_0}+g_0&gt;n-1.$	string

1293	en_US	title	Gradation in Greyscales of Graphs	string
1293	en_US	cleanTitle	Gradation in Greyscales of Graphs	string
1293	en_US	abstract	A \\textit{greyscale} $f$ of a graph $G(V,E)$ is a mapping on $V$ to the interval $[0,1]$ such that $f^{-1}(0)\\neq \\emptyset$ and $f^{-1}(1)\\neq \\emptyset$. Every greyscale induces a mapping $\\widehat{f}$ on $E$ by assigning to each edge the non-negative difference between the values of $f$ on its vertices. The \\textit{gradation vector} $grad(G,f)$ is defined as the vector $(\\widehat{f}(e_m), \\widehat{f}(e_{m-1}) , \\ldots , \\widehat{f}(e_1) )$, where all edges $e_i$ of $G$ are indexed such that $\\widehat{f}(e_i) \\leq \\widehat{f}(e_j)$ for $1 \\leq i &lt; j \\leq m$. Our aim in this work is to determine the minimum gradation vector, following the lexicographical order, among the gradation vectors of all greyscales of $G$. A single procedure is performed that works as main subroutine of the polynomial algorithms that obtain the minimum gradation vector and all greyscales that give rise to it, in two cases: (a) the values of the greyscale of some vertices are prefixed, (b) no information is given a priori.	string

1295	en_US	title	Automorphism Groups of Walecki Tournaments with Zero Pattern	string
1295	en_US	cleanTitle	Automorphism Groups of Walecki Tournaments with Zero Pattern	string
1295	en_US	abstract	<p>Walecki tournaments were defined by Alspach in 1966. They form a class of regular tournaments that posses a natural Hamilton directed cycle decomposition. It has been conjectured by Kelly in 1964 that every regular tournament possesses such a decomposition. Therefore Walecki tournaments speak in favor of the conjecture. A second interest in Walecki tournaments arises from the mapping between cycles of the complementing circular shift register and isomorphism classes of Walecki tournaments. The problem of enumerating non-isomorphic Walecki tournaments has not been solved to date. We char-<br />acterize the arc structure of Walecki tournaments whose corresponding binary sequences have zero pattern and determine their automorphism groups.</p>	string

1296	en_US	title	Circular chromatic number of induced subgraphs of Kneser graphs	string
1296	en_US	cleanTitle	Circular chromatic number of induced subgraphs of Kneser graphs	string
1296	en_US	abstract	Investigating the equality of the chromatic number and the circular chromatic number of graphs has been an active stream of research for last decades. In this regard, Hajiabolhassan and Zhu in 2003 proved that if <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span> is sufficiently large with respect to <span class="math inline"><em>k</em></span>, then the Schrijver graph <span class="math inline">SG(<em>n</em>, <em>k</em>)</span> has the same chromatic and circular chromatic number. Later, Meunier in 2005 and independently, Simonyi and Tardos in 2006 proved that <span class="math inline"><em>χ</em>(SG(<em>n</em>, <em>k</em>)) = <em>χ</em><sub><em>c</em></sub>(SG(<em>n</em>, <em>k</em>))</span> if <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span> is even. In this paper, we study the circular chromatic number of induced subgraphs of Kneser graphs. In this regard, we shall first generalize the preceding result to <span class="math inline"><em>s</em></span>-stable Kneser graphs for large even <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span> and even <span class="math inline"><em>s</em></span>. Furthermore, as a generalization of the Hajiabolhassan-Zhu result, we prove that if <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span> is large enough with respect to <span class="math inline"><em>k</em></span>, then any sufficiently large induced subgraph of the Kneser graph <span class="math inline">KG(<em>n</em>, <em>k</em>)</span> has the same chromatic number and circular chromatic number.	string

1297	en_US	abstract	<p>The modified Hosoya polynomial of double weighted graphs, i.e. edge and vertex weighted graphs, is introduced that enables derivation of closed expressions for Hosoya polynomial of some special graphs including unicyclic graphs. 1303	en_US	title	Hamiltonian properties on a class of circulant networks	string
1303	en_US	cleanTitle	Hamiltonian properties on a class of circulant networks	string
1303	en_US	abstract	<p>Classes of circulant graphs play an important role in modeling interconnection networks in parallel and distributed computing. They also find applications in modeling quantum spin networks supporting the perfect state transfer. It has been noticed that unitary Cayley graphs as a class of circulant graphs possess many good properties such as small diameter, mirror symmetry, recursive structure, regularity, etc. and therefore can serve as a model for efficient interconnection networks.In this paper we go a step further and analyze some other characteristics of unitary Cayley graphs important for the modeling of a good interconnection network. We show that all unitary Cayley graphs are hamiltonian. More precisely, every unitary Cayley graph is hamiltonian-laceable (up to one exception for $X_6$) if it is bipartite, and hamiltonian-connected if it is not. We prove this by presenting an explicit construction of hamiltonian paths on $X_{nm}$ using the hamiltonian paths on $X_n$ and $X_m$ for $\\gcd(n,m)=1$. Moreover, we also prove that every unitary Cayley graph is bipancyclic and every nonbipartite unitary Cayley graph is pancyclic.</p>	string

1304	en_US	title	The Domination Number of the Intersection Graph of Subgroups of a Group	string
1304	en_US	cleanTitle	The Domination Number of the Intersection Graph of Subgroups of a Group	string
1304	en_US	abstract	<p>‎Let $G$ be a non-trivial group and $|G|$ is not a prime‎. ‎The intersection graph of $G$‎, denoted by $\\Gamma(G)$ is a graph‎, ‎whose vertex set is the set of all non-trivial proper subgroups of $G$ and two distinct vertices $H$ and $K$ are adjacent if and only if $H\\cap K\\neq 1$‎. ‎In this paper‎, ‎we determine the domination number of $\\Gamma(G)$‎, ‎where $G$ is an abelian group or a $p$-group of order at least $p^3$‎, ‎which has a cyclic subgroup of index $p$ ($p$ is a prime)‎. ‎Also‎, ‎it is shown that if $G$ is a nilpotent group‎, ‎a super-solvable group or a finitely generated solvable group‎, ‎then the domination number of $\\Gamma(G)$ is finite‎, ‎but if $G$ is a $p$-group‎, ‎a solvable group or a finitely generated group‎, ‎then the domination number of $\\Gamma(G)$ is not necessarily finite‎. ‎Finally‎, ‎we obtain some upper bounds for the domination number of some groups for instance symmetric groups‎.</p>	string

1305	en_US	abstract	<p>In this paper we determine all tetravalent Cayley graphs of the non-abelian group of order 3p^2, where p is a prime number greater than 3, and with cyclic Sylow p-subgroup. We show that all of these tetravalent Cayley graphs are normal Cayley graphs. The full automorphism group of these Cayley graphs will be given and the half-transitivity and the arc-transitivity of<br />these graphs are investigated. We show that this group is a 5-CI-group.</p>	string

1309	en_US	title	On the distance signless Laplacian spectral radius and the distance signless Laplacian energy of graphs	string
1309	en_US	cleanTitle	On the distance signless Laplacian spectral radius and the distance signless Laplacian energy of graphs	string
1309	en_US	abstract	<p>The distance signless Laplacian spectral radius of a connected graph $G$ is the largest eigenvalue of the distance signless Laplacian matrix of $G,$ defined as $D^Q(G) = Tr(G) + D(G),$ where $D(G)$ is the distance matrix of $G$ and $Tr(G)$ is the diagonal matrix of vertex transmissions<br />of $G.$ In this paper, we determine some bounds on the distance signless Laplacian spectral radius of $G$ based on some graph invariants, and characterize the extremal graphs. In addition, we define distance signless Laplacian energy, similar to that in [J. Yang, L. You and I. Gutman, Bounds on the distance Laplacian energy of graphs, Kragujevac J. Math., 37 (2013) 245–255] and give some bounds on the distance signless Laplacian energy of graphs.</p>	string

1310	en_US	abstract	A singed graph is a graph which its edges are marked by two negative and positive signs. A main eigenvalue of a signed graph is an eigenvalue of its adjacency matrix which corresponding eigenspace has an eigenvector whose the sum of entries is not equal to zero. In this paper, some properties of signed graphs which have exactly s, s&gt; 0, are stuudied. We also determine<br />all signed trees and unicyclic graphs with exactly one eigenvalue. 1312	en_US	abstract	<p>Platonic solids (the tetrahedron, the octahedron, the cube, the dodecahedron and icosahedron) have been studied by mathematicians, chemists, physicists and the other<br />scientists for a long time. The excellent symmetry of the Platonic solids have made them perfect models for the studying on symmetries. There are many studies that<br />specically cube and octahedron have been associated with the metric geometry and metric topology [1], [2], [3]. Although existence of the norms for arbitrary convex symmetric bodies in Rn is known, it is not known how dened norms [4]. In this article, the metric of which unit sphere is the dodecahedron is the first time dened by us. To find<br />this metric, we have developed a procedure. Thus, the dodecahedron is associated with metric geometry. Also, we have analytically proved that the group of isometries of<br />the R3 with respect to this new metric is the semi-direct group Ih and T (3) ; where Ih is symmetry group of the dodecahedron and T (3) is the group of all translations of the 3-dimensional space.</p>	string

1316	en_US	title	Transversals in generalized Latin squares	string
1316	en_US	cleanTitle	Transversals in generalized Latin squares	string
1316	en_US	abstract	<p>We are seeking a sufficient condition that forces a transversal in a generalized Latin square. A generalized Latin square of order <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span> is equivalent to a proper edge-coloring of <span class="math inline"><em>K</em><sub><em>n</em>, <em>n</em></sub></span>. A transversal corresponds to a multicolored perfect matching. Akbari and Alipour defined <span class="math inline"><em>l</em>(<em>n</em>)</span> as the least integer such that every properly edge-colored <span class="math inline"><em>K</em><sub><em>n</em>, <em>n</em></sub></span>, which contains at least <span class="math inline"><em>l</em>(<em>n</em>)</span> different colors, admits a multicolored perfect matching. They conjectured that <span class="math inline"><em>l</em>(<em>n</em>) ≤ <em>n</em><sup>2</sup>/2</span> if <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span> is large enough. In this note we prove that <span class="math inline"><em>l</em>(<em>n</em>)</span> is bounded from above by <span class="math inline">0.75<em>n</em><sup>2</sup></span> if <span class="math inline"><em>n</em> &gt; 1</span>. We point out a connection to anti-Ramsey problems. We propose a conjecture related to a well-known result by Woolbright and Fu, that every proper edge-coloring of <span class="math inline"><em>K</em><sub>2<em>n</em></sub></span> admits a multicolored <span class="math inline">1</span>-factor.</p>	string

1317	en_US	title	Weight choosability of oriented hypergraphs	string
1317	en_US	cleanTitle	Weight choosability of oriented hypergraphs	string
1317	en_US	abstract	<p>The <span class="math inline">1</span>-<span class="math inline">2</span>-<span class="math inline">3</span> conjecture states that every simple graph (with no isolated edges) has an edge weigthing by numbers <span class="math inline">1, 2, 3</span> such that the resulting weighted vertex degrees form a proper coloring of the graph. We study a similar problem for oriented hypergraphs. We prove that every oriented hypergraph has an edge weighting satisfying a similar condition, even if the weights are to be chosen from arbitrary lists of size two. The proof is based on the Combinatorial Nullstellensatz and a theorem of Schur for permanents of positive semi-definite matrices. We derive several consequences of the main result for uniform hypergraphs. We also point on possible applications of our results to problems of <span class="math inline">1</span>-<span class="math inline">2</span>-<span class="math inline">3</span> type for non-oriented hypergraphs.</p>	string

1320	en_US	cleanTitle	Relations between Wiener index hyperWiener index  and some Zagreb type indices	string
1320	en_US	abstract	The Wiener($W$) and hyper Wiener ($WW$) indices are two  oldest distanced-based topological indices that for a simple graph $G=(V(G),E(G))$ are defined as $W(G)=\\sum_{\\{u,v\\}\\subset V(G)}d_G(u,v)$ and<br />$WW(G)=\\frac{1}{2}\\sum_{\\{u,v\\}\\subset V(G)}[d_G(u,v)+d_G(u,v)^2]$, where $d_{G}(u, v)$, is the distance  between vertices $u$ and $v$.<br />On the other hand Zagreb indices and their families, which we call them Zagreb type indices, are famous degree-based topological indices.<br />In this paper we deduced several inequalities, relating  $W$ and $WW$ and some Zagreb type indices (the first and second Zagreb indices, the reformulated Zagreb indices and the general Zagreb indices).<br /><br />	string

1321	en_US	title	Some notes on minimal potentially eventually exponentially positive sign patterns	string
1321	en_US	cleanTitle	Some notes on minimal potentially eventually exponentially positive sign patterns	string
1321	en_US	abstract	<p>An $n\\times n$ matrix $A$ is said to be eventually<br />exponentially positive if there exists some nonnegative integer $t_{0}$ such that for all $t\\geq t_{0}$,<br />$$e^{tA}=\\sum_{k=0}^{\\infty}\\frac{t^{k}A^{k}}{k!}&gt;0.$$ A sign pattern is a matrix whose entries belong to the set $\\{+, -, 0\\}$. An $n\\times n$ sign pattern $\\mathcal{A}$ is said to be potentially eventually exponentially positive if there exists some<br />real matrix $A$ with the same sign pattern as $\\mathcal{A}$ such that $A$ is eventually exponentially positive. Identifying the necessary and sufficient conditions for an $n\\times n$ sign pattern<br />to be potentially eventually exponentially positive and classifying all potentially eventually exponentially positive sign patterns are two open problems. In this article, we define $\\mathcal{A}$ to be a minimal potentially eventually exponentially positive sign pattern, if $\\mathcal{A}$ is a potentially eventually exponentially positive sign pattern and no proper subpattern of $\\mathcal{A}$ is potentially eventually exponentially positive. All minimal potentially eventually exponentially positive sign patterns of small<br />orders are identified. For the $n\\times n$ tridagonal sign patterns $\\mathcal{T}_{n}$, we show that there exists exactly one minimal potentially eventually exponentially positive tridiagonal sign pattern $\\mathcal{T}_{n}^{1}$. Consequently, we classify all<br />potentially eventually exponentially positive tridiagonal sign patterns. We also classify all potentially eventually exponentially positive star sign patterns $\\mathcal{S}_{n}$ and double star sign<br />patterns $\\mathcal{DS}(n, m)$ by identifying the minimal potentially eventually exponentially positive star sign patterns and the minimal potentially eventually exponentially positive double star sign<br />patterns, respecitvely.</p>	string

1324	en_US	title	Connected Domination Value in Graphs	string
1324	en_US	cleanTitle	Connected Domination Value in Graphs	string
1324	en_US	abstract	In a connected graph $G=(V,E)$, a set $D \\subset V$ is a {\\it connected dominating set} if for every vertex $v \\in V\\setminus D$, there exists $u \\in D$ such that $u$ and $v$ are adjacent, and the subgraph $\\langle D \\rangle$ induced by $D$ in $G$ is connected. A connected dominating set of minimum cardinality is called a $\\gamma_c$-set of $G$. For each vertex $v \\in V$, we define the {\\it connected domination value} of $v$ to be the number of $\\gamma_c$-sets of $G$ to which $v$ belongs. In this paper, we study the properties of connected domination value of a connected graph $G$ with respect to other graph parameters like number of $\\gamma_c$-sets in $G$, maximum degree $\\Delta$ etc. Finally, we compute the connected domination value and number of $\\gamma_c$-sets for a few well-known family of graphs.	string

1325	en_US	cleanTitle	On the transitivity of  a zero divisor graph	string
1325	en_US	abstract	<p>The article concerns the transitive property of a zero divisor<br />graph. Let $a, b$ be two elements of a non empty set (here we<br />consider a ring $R$) such that $ab=0$, i.e. there is an edge from<br />$a$ to $b$, We investigate certain cases for which there is an edge<br />from $ac$ to $b$ and an edge from $a$ to $cb$ for all $c\\in R$. We<br />also consider the other case, i.e. if there is an edge from $ac$ to<br />$b$ and an edge from $a$ to $cb$ for all $c\\in R$, does there exist<br />an edge from $a$ to $b$?</p>	string

1327	en_US	title	The arc-types of Cayley graphs	string
1327	en_US	cleanTitle	The arctypes of Cayley graphs	string
1327	en_US	abstract	<p>Let <span class="math inline"><em>X</em></span> be a finite vertex-transitive graph of valency <span class="math inline"><em>d</em></span>, and let <span class="math inline"><em>A</em></span> be the full automorphism group of <span class="math inline"><em>X</em></span>. Then the <span><em>arc-type</em></span> of <span class="math inline"><em>X</em></span> is defined in terms of the sizes of the orbits of the action of the stabiliser <span class="math inline"><em>A</em><sub><em>v</em></sub></span> of a given vertex <span class="math inline"><em>v</em></span> on the set of arcs incident with <span class="math inline"><em>v</em></span>. Specifically, the arc-type is the partition of <span class="math inline"><em>d</em></span> as the sum <span class="math inline"><em>n</em><sub>1</sub> + <em>n</em><sub>2</sub> + … + <em>n</em><sub><em>t</em></sub> + (<em>m</em><sub>1</sub> + <em>m</em><sub>1</sub>) + (<em>m</em><sub>2</sub> + <em>m</em><sub>2</sub>) + … + (<em>m</em><sub><em>s</em></sub> + <em>m</em><sub><em>s</em></sub>)</span>, where <span class="math inline"><em>n</em><sub>1</sub>, <em>n</em><sub>2</sub>, …, <em>n</em><sub><em>t</em></sub></span> are the sizes of the self-paired orbits, and <span class="math inline"><em>m</em><sub>1</sub>, <em>m</em><sub>1</sub>, <em>m</em><sub>2</sub>, <em>m</em><sub>2</sub>, …, <em>m</em><sub><em>s</em></sub>, <em>m</em><sub><em>s</em></sub></span> are the sizes of the non-self-paired orbits, in descending order.</p><p>In a recent paper, it was shown by Conder, Pisanski and <span>Ž</span>itnik that with the exception of the partitions <span class="math inline">1 + 1</span> and <span class="math inline">(1 + 1)</span> for valency <span class="math inline">2</span>, every such partition occurs as the arc-type of some vertex-transitive graph. In this paper, we extend this to show that in fact every partition other than <span class="math inline">1</span>, <span class="math inline">1 + 1</span> and <span class="math inline">(1 + 1)</span> occurs as the arc-type of infinitely many connected finite Cayley graphs with the given valency <span class="math inline"><em>d</em></span>. As a consequence, this also shows that for every <span class="math inline"><em>d</em> &gt; 2</span>, there are infinitely many finite zero-symmetric graphs (or GRRs) of valency <span class="math inline"><em>d</em></span>.</p>	string

1330	en_US	title	Linear separation of connected dominating sets in graphs	string
1330	en_US	cleanTitle	Linear separation of connected dominating sets in graphs	string
1330	en_US	abstract	<p>A connected dominating set in a graph is a dominating set of vertices that induces a connected subgraph. Following analogous studies in the literature related to independent sets, dominating sets, and total dominating sets, we study in this paper the class of graphs in which the connected dominating sets can be separated from the other vertex subsets by a linear weight function. More precisely, we say that a graph is connected-domishold if it admits non-negative real weights associated to its vertices such that a set of vertices is a connected dominating set if and only if the sum of the corresponding weights exceeds a certain threshold. We characterize the graphs in this non-hereditary class in terms of a property of the set of minimal cutsets of the graph. We give several characterizations for the hereditary case, that is, when each connected induced subgraph is required to be connected-domishold. The characterization by forbidden induced subgraphs implies that the class properly generalizes two well known classes of chordal graphs, the block graphs and the trivially perfect graphs. Finally, we study certain algorithmic aspects of connected-domishold graphs. Building on connections with minimal cutsets and properties of the derived hypergraphs and Boolean functions, we show that our approach leads to new polynomially solvable cases of the weighted connected dominating set problem.</p>	string
1330	en_US	discipline	Graph Theory	string
1330	en_US	subjectClass	05C69, 05C75, 05C65, 05C85	string

1332	en_US	title	Characterising CCA Sylow cyclic groups whose order is not divisible by four	string
1332	en_US	cleanTitle	Characterising CCA Sylow cyclic groups whose order is not divisible by four	string
1332	en_US	abstract	<p>A Cayley graph on a group <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> has a natural edge-colouring. We say that such a graph is <em>CCA</em> if every automorphism of the graph that preserves this edge-colouring is an element of the normaliser of the regular representation of <span class="math"><em>G</em></span>. A group <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> is then said to be <em>CCA</em> if every connected Cayley graph on <span class="math"><em>G</em></span> is CCA.</p><p>Our main result is a characterisation of non-CCA graphs on groups that are Sylow cyclic and whose order is not divisible by four. We also provide several new constructions of non-CCA graphs.</p>	string

1344	en_US	title	Vertex connectivity of the power graph of a finite cyclic group	string
1344	en_US	cleanTitle	Vertex connectivity of the power graph of a finite cyclic group	string
1344	en_US	abstract	Let $n=p_1^{n_1}p_2^{n_2}\\cdots p_r^{n_r}$, where $r,n_1,\\cdots, n_r$ are positive integers and $p_1,p_2,\\cdots,p_r$ are distinct prime numbers with $p_1&lt;p_2&lt;\\cdots &lt;p_r$. For the cyclic group $C_n$ of order $n$, let $\\mathcal{P}(C_n)$ be the power graph of $C_n$ and $\\kappa(\\mathcal{P}(C_n))$ be the vertex connectivity of $\\mathcal{P}(C_n)$. Clearly, $\\kappa(\\mathcal{P}(C_n))=p_1^{n_1} -1$ if $r=1$. So assume that $r\\geq 2$. We determine $\\kappa(\\mathcal{P}(C_n))$ when $2\\phi(p_1\\cdots p_{r-1})\\geq p_1\\cdots p_{r-1}$. If $2\\phi(p_1\\cdots p_{r-1}) &lt; p_1\\cdots p_{r-1}$, then we give an upper bound for $\\kappa(\\mathcal{P}(C_n))$ which is sharp for many values of $n$.	string

1346	en_US	title	Generating a probability measure on the completion of a fractal structure	string
1346	en_US	cleanTitle	Generating a probability measure on the completion of a fractal structure	string
1346	en_US	abstract	<p><!--StartFragment-->Fractal structures were introduced to characterize non-archimedean quasi-metrization and they can be used to study self similar sets and fractals in general. In this paper we show how to construct a probability measure by defining it iteratively on some key subsets. In fact, given a space with a fractal structure and a pre-measure on some families of subsets determined by the fractal structure, we prove that it can be extended to a measure on the Borel sigma-algebra of the completion and that this extension is unique. The key elements of this construction is the recursive character of the fractal structure as well as the use of the completion of the fractal structure.</p>	string

1354	en_US	title	Maximum connected even factors of Supereulerian graphs	string
1354	en_US	cleanTitle	Maximum connected even factors of Supereulerian graphs	string
1354	en_US	abstract	<p>A connected even factor of a graph is a connected spanning subgraph in which each vertex has a positive even degree. Catlin raised the problem of determining the best possible constant $c&gt; 0$ such that every graph $G$ containing a connected even factor has one such even factor $F$ satisfying $|E(F)|\\geq c|E(G)|$.<br />Catlin conjectured that $c=\\frac{2}{3}$. Li et al. constructed a class of simple graphs $G$ with maximum connected even factor of size $\\frac{3}{5}|E(G)| +\\frac{4}{5}$, and conjectured that $c = \\frac{3}{5}$ instead.</p><p>In this paper, we take the set of vertices of degree 2 of a graph $G$ (say $V_2(G)$) into consideration and prove the following theorems for a simple graph $G$.</p><p>(1) Let $F$ be a maximum connected even factor of $G$. If $|V_2(G)|\\geq \\frac{1}{2}|V(G)|$, then $|E(F)|\\geq \\frac{2}{3}|E(G)|$.</p><p>(2) Let $F$ be a maximum connected even factor of $G$. If $|V_2(G)|\\geq \\frac{1}{3}|V(G)|$, then $|E(F)|\\geq \\frac{3}{5}|E(G)|$ and if $|V_2(G)|\\geq \\frac{1}{2}|V(G)|$, then $|E(F)|\\geq \\frac{3}{5}(|E(G)|+1)+\\frac{1}{5}|V_{2}(G)|$.</p><p>Extremal graphs reaching the lower bound of (2) are presented and so the lower bound of (2) is best possible.</p>	string

1355	en_US	abstract	<p>We consider a family of <span class="math inline"><em>I</em></span>-graphs <span class="math inline"><em>I</em>(<em>n</em>, <em>k</em>, <em>l</em>),</span> which is a generalization of the class of generalized Petersen graphs. 1359	en_US	title	The isolated-pentagon rule and nice substructures in fullerenes	string
1359	en_US	cleanTitle	The isolatedpentagon rule and nice substructures in fullerenes	string
1359	en_US	abstract	<p>After fullerenes were discovered, Kroto in 1987 proposed first the isolated-pentagon rule (IPR): the most stable fullerenes are those in which no two pentagons share an edge, that is, each pentagon is completely surrounded by hexagons. To now the structures of the synthesized and isolated (neutral) fullerenes meet this rule. The IPR can be justified from local strain in geometry and <span class="math inline"><em>π</em></span>-electronic resonance energy of fullerenes. If two pentagons abut in a fullerene, a <span class="math inline">8</span>-circuit along the perimeter of the pentalene (a pair of abutting pentagons) occurs. This paper confirms that such a <span class="math inline">8</span>-circuit is always a conjugated cycle of the fullerene in a graph-theoretical approach. Since conjugated circuits of length <span class="math inline">8</span> destabilize the molecule in conjugated circuit theory, this result gives a basis for the IPR in <span class="math inline"><em>π</em></span>-electronic resonance. We also prove that each <span class="math inline">6</span>-circuit (hexagon) and each <span class="math inline">10</span>-circuit along the perimeter of a pair of abutting hexagons are conjugated. Two such types of conjugated circuit satisfy the <span class="math inline">(4<em>n</em> + 2)</span>-rule, and thus stabilise the molecule.</p>	string
1359	en_US	discipline	graph theory; perfect matching; fullerene graph	string

1359	en_US	subject	Fullerene, patch, stability, isolated pentagon rule, Kekulé structure, conjugated cycle, cyclic edge-cut	string
1359	en_US	sponsor	C.N.R.S.-Université Paris-sud; NSFC	string
1357	en_US	abstract	For a connected graph $G$, the total number of independent vertex sets (including the empty vertex set) is denoted by $i(G)$. In this paper, we firstly establish a transformations on graphs that increases $i(G)$ and $i(\\overline{G})$. Secondly, we obtain the minimum and maximum value of $i(G)+i(\\overline{G})$, where graph $G$ is tree $T$ with connected complement and unicyclic graph $G$ with connected complement, respectively. In each case, we characterize the extremal graphs. Finally, we establish an upper bound on the $i(G)$ in terms of the Wiener polarity index.	string

1361	en_US	title	The harmonic index of two-trees and quasi-tree graphs	string
1361	en_US	cleanTitle	The harmonic index of twotrees and quasitree graphs	string
1361	en_US	abstract	The harmonic index of a graph G is defined as the sum of the weights 2/( d(u)+d(v)) of all edges uv of G, where d(u) denotes the degree of the vertex u in G. A graph G is called quasi-tree, if there exists u ∈ V (G) such that G − u is a tree. The graphs called two-trees are defined by recursion. The smallest two-tree is the complete graph on two vertices. A two-tree on n + 1 vertices (where n ≥ 2) is obtained by adding a new vertex adjacent to the two end vertices of one edge in a two-tree on n vertices. In this work, the sharp lower and upper bounds on the harmonic index of quasi-tree graphs are presented. Furthermore, the lower bound on the harmonic index of two-tree is presented, and the two-trees with the minimum and the second minimum harmonic index, respectively, are determined.	string

1362	en_US	title	Majorization and the spectral radius of starlike trees	string
1362	en_US	cleanTitle	Majorization and the spectral radius of starlike trees	string
1362	en_US	abstract	A starlike tree is a tree with exactly one vertex of degree greater than two. The spectral radius of a graph $G$, $\\lambda(G)$, is the largest eigenvalues of $G$.<br />Let $T(n_1,\\ldots,n_k)$ be the starlike tree $T$ with a vertex $v$ of degree $k\\geq3$ such that $T\\setminus v$ is the disjoint union of the paths $P_{n_1-1},\\ldots,P_{n_k-1}$.<br />Let $P=(p_1,\\ldots,p_k)$ and<br />$Q=(q_1,\\ldots,q_k)$, where $p_1\\geq \\cdots\\geq p_k\\geq1$ and<br />$q_1\\geq\\cdots\\geq q_k\\geq1$ are integer. We say $P$ majorizes $Q$ and let $P\\succeq_M Q$,<br />if for every $j$, $1\\leq j\\leq k$,<br />$\\sum_{i=1}^{j}p_i\\geq \\sum_{i=1}^{j}q_i$, with equality if $j=k$.<br />In this paper we show that if $P$ majorizes $Q$, that is $(p_1,\\ldots,p_k)\\succeq_M(q_1,\\ldots,q_k)$, then $\\lambda(T(q_1,\\ldots,q_k))\\geq\\lambda(T(p_1,\\ldots,p_k))$.	string

1363	en_US	title	Most Rigid Representations and Cayley index	string
1363	en_US	cleanTitle	Most Rigid Representations and Cayley index	string
1363	en_US	abstract	For any finite group <em>G</em>, a natural question to ask is the order of the smallest possible automorphism group for a Cayley graph on <em>G</em>. A particular Cayley graph whose automorphism group has this order is referred to as an MRR (Most Rigid Representation), and its Cayley index is a numerical indicator of this value. Study of GRRs showed that with the exception of two infinite families and thirteen individual groups, every group admits a Cayley graph whose MRR is a GRR, so that the Cayley index is 1. The full answer to the question of finding the smallest possible Cayley index for a Cayley graph on a fixed group was almost completed in previous work, but the precise answers for some finite groups and one infinite family of groups were left open. We fill in the remaining gaps to completely answer this question.<br /><br />	string

1364	en_US	title	On the difference between the (revised) Szeged index and the Wiener index of cacti	string
1364	en_US	cleanTitle	On the difference between the revised Szeged index and the Wiener index of cacti	string
1364	en_US	abstract	A connected graph is said to be a cactus if each of its blocks is either a cycle or an edge. Let $\\mathscr{C}_n$ be the set of all $n$-vertex cacti with circumference at least 4, and let $\\mathscr{C}_{n,k}$ be the set of all $n$-vertex cacti containing exactly $k\\geqslant1$ cycles where $n\\geqslant 3k+1$. In this paper, lower bounds on the difference between the (revised) Szeged index and Wiener index of graphs in $\\mathscr{C}_n$ (resp. $\\mathscr{C}_{n,k}$) are proved. The minimum and the second minimum values on the difference between the Szeged index and Wiener index of graphs among $\\mathscr{C}_n$ are determined. The bound on the minimum value is strengthened in the bipartite case. A lower bound on the difference between the revised Szeged index and Wiener index of graphs among $\\mathscr{C}_{n,k}$ is also established. Along the way the corresponding extremal graphs are identified.	string
