1366	en_US	title	On the spectral determinations of the join of a clique with s copies of an arbitrary other clique	string
1366	en_US	cleanTitle	On the spectral determinations of the join of a clique with s copies of an arbitrary other clique	string
1366	en_US	abstract	<p>A long-standing question connecting graph theory and linear algebra has to do with the set of eigen-<br />values of the adjacency matrix of a graph, called the spectrum of the graph. Although it is well known<br />that different graphs can have the same spectrum, it remains an open question as to whether most graphs<br />have a spectrum shared by another graph or not. In fact, not many families of graphs are known that have<br />their own spectrum, not shared by any other graphs. In the past decades, graphs that are determined<br />by their spectrum have received much more and more attention, since they have been applied to several<br />fields, such as randomized algorithms, combinatorial optimization problems and machine learning. An<br />important part of spectral graph theory is devoted to determining whether given graphs or classes of<br />graphs are determined by their spectra or not. So, finding and introducting any class of graphs which are<br />determined by their spectra can be an interesting and important problem. In this study we investigate<br />the spectra of the family of connected multicone graphs. A multicone graph is defined to be the join of a<br />clique and a regular graph. Let r, t and s be natural numbers, and let Kr denotes a complete graph on<br />r vertices. It is proved that connected multicone graphs Kr▽sKt, a natural generalization of friendship<br />graphs, are determined by their adjacency spectra as well as their Laplacian spectra. Also, we show that<br />the complement of multicone graphs Kr▽ sKt are determined by their adjacency spectra, where s ̸= 2.<br />Furthermore, we prove that any graph cospectral with a multicone graph Kr▽ sKt is perfect</p>	string

1367	en_US	abstract	A long-standing question connecting graph theory and linear algebra has to do with the set of eigenvalues of the adjacency matrix of a graph, called the spectrum of the graph. Although it is well known that different graphs can have the same spectrum, it remains an open question as to whether most graphs have a spectrum shared by another graph or not. In fact, not many families of graphs are known that have their own spectrum, not shared by any other graphs. In the past decades, graphs that are determined by their spectrum have received much more and more attention, since they have been<a class="PbbUpenMg R87xWMbczoMi" style="z-index: 2147483647;" title="Click to Continue &gt; by Ads" href="#57983787"> applied to<img src="http://cdncache-a.akamaihd.net/items/it/img/arrow-10x10.png" alt="" /></a> several fields, such as randomized algorithms, combinatorial optimization problems and machine learning. An important part of spectral graph theory is devoted to determining whether given graphs or classes of graphs are determined by their spectra or not. So, finding and introducting any class of graphs which are determined by their spectra can be an interesting and important problem. In this study we investigate the spectra of the family of connected multicone graphs. A multicone graph is defined to be the join of a clique and a regular graph. Let r, t and s be natural numbers, and let Kr denotes a complete graph on r vertices. It is proved that connected multicone graphs Kr ▽ sKt, a natural generalization of friendship graphs, are determined by their adjacency spectra as well as their Laplacian spectra. Also, we show that the complement of multicone graphs Kr ▽ sKt are determined by their adjacency spectra, where s ̸= 2. Furthermore, we prove that any graph cospectral with a multicone graph Kr ▽ sKt is perfect	string

1368	en_US	title	The spectral determinations of connected multicone graphs Kw ▽Ic and Kw ▽H	string
1368	en_US	cleanTitle	The spectral determinations of connected multicone graphs Kw ▽Ic and Kw ▽H	string
1368	en_US	abstract	<p>In mathematics, spectral graph theory is the study of properties of a graph in relationship to the<br />characteristic polynomial, eigenvalues, and eigenvectors of matrices associated to the graph, such as its<br />adjacency matrix or Laplacian matrix. An important part of spectral graph theory is devoted to deter-<br />mining whether given graphs or classes of graphs are determined by their spectra or not. Characterizing<br />classes of graphs which are determined by their spectra is often a hard and challenging problem. So,<br />nding and introducting any class of these graphs can be an interesting and important problem. In<br />the past decades, graphs that are determined by their spectrum have received much more and more<br />attention, since they have been applied to several elds, such as randomized algorithms, combinatorial<br />optimization problems and machine learning. The main goal of this study is to characterize classes of<br />multicone graphs which are determined by both adjacency and Laplacian spectra. A multicone graph is<br />dened to be the join of a clique and a regular graph. Let Kw denotes a complete graph on w vertices,<br />and let Ic and H denote the Icosahedron graph and the Heawood graph, respectively. In this work, we<br />show that connected multicone graphs Kw ▽Ic and Kw ▽H are determined by their adjacency spectra<br />as well as their Laplacian spectra.</p>	string

1369	en_US	title	The spectral determinations of the join of two friendship graphs	string
1369	en_US	cleanTitle	The spectral determinations of the join of two friendship graphs	string
1369	en_US	abstract	<p>A long-standing question connecting graph theory and linear algebra has to do with the set of eigenvalues of the adjacency matrix of a graph, called the spectrum of the graph. Although it is well known that different graphs can have the same spectrum, it remains an open question as to whether most graphs<br />have a spectrum shared by another graph or not. In fact, not many families of graphs are known that have their own spectrum, not shared by any other graphs. In the past decades, graphs that are determined<br />by their spectrum have received much more and more attention, since they have been applied to several fields, such as randomized algorithms, combinatorial optimization problems and machine learning. A<br />multicone graph is defined to be the join of a clique and a regular graph. If n is a positive integer, a friendship graph Fn consists of n edge-disjoint triangles that all of them meet in one vertex. It is proved<br />that any connected graph cospectral to a multicone graph Fn▽Fn = K2▽nK2▽nK2 is determined by its adjacency spectra as well as its Laplacian spectra. In addition, we show that if n ̸= 2, the complement of these graphs are determined by their adjacency spectra. At the end of the paper, it is proved that any graph cospectral to one of multicone graphs Fn▽Fn is perfect. Finally, we pose one problem for further<br />research.</p>	string

1369	en_US	subjectClass	05C50	string
1369	en_US	subject	Adjacency spectrum, Laplacian spectrum, Multicone graph, DS graph, Friendship graph.	string

1371	en_US	title	The Prime Index Graph of a Group	string
1371	en_US	cleanTitle	The Prime Index Graph of a Group	string
1371	en_US	abstract	Let $G$ be a group. The prime index graph of $G$, denoted by $\\Pi(G)$, is the graph whose vertex set is the set of all subgroups of $G$ and two distinct comparable vertices $H$ and $K$ are adjacent if and only if the index of $H$ in $K$ or the index of $K$ in $H$ is prime. In this paper, it is shown that for every group $G$, $\\Pi(G)$ is bipartite and the girth of $\\Pi(G)$ is contained in the set $\\{4,\\infty\\}$. Also we prove that if $G$ is a finite solvable group, then $\\Pi(G)$ is connected.	string

1382	en_US	abstract	Let <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span> denote a positive integer. A graph <span class="math inline">Γ</span> of diameter at least <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span> is said to be <span><em><span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span>-distance-balanced</em></span> whenever for any pair of vertices <span class="math inline"><em>u</em>, <em>v</em></span> of <span class="math inline">Γ</span> at distance <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span>, the number of vertices closer to <span class="math inline"><em>u</em></span> than to <span class="math inline"><em>v</em></span> is equal to the number of vertices closer to <span class="math inline"><em>v</em></span> than to <span class="math inline"><em>u</em></span>. 1587	en_US	cleanTitle	Perfect Packing of Squares	string
1587	en_US	abstract	<p>It is known that $\\sum\\limits_{i =1}^\\infty {1/ i^2}={\\pi^2/6}$. We<br />can ask what is the smallest $\\epsilon$ such that all the squares of<br />sides of length $1$, $1/2$, $1/3$, $\\ldots$ can be packed into a<br />rectangle of area ${\\pi^2/6}+\\epsilon$. A packing into a rectangle<br />of the right area is called perfect packing. Chalcraft packed the<br />squares of sides of length $1$, $2^{-t}$, $3^{-t}$, $\\ldots$ and he<br />found perfect packing for $1/2&lt;t\\le3/5$. We will show based on an<br />algorithm by Chalcraft that there are perfect packings if<br />$1/2&lt;t\\le2/3$. Moreover we show that there is a perfect packing for<br />all $t$ in the range $\\log_32\\le t\\le2/3$.</p>	string

1383	en_US	abstract	<p><br />Let $R$ be a commutative ring with non-zero identity. The complement of the Jacobson graph of $R$ denoted by $\\overline{\\mathfrak{J}_{R}}$ is a graph with the vertex set $R\\setminus J(R)$, and two distinct vertices $x,y \\in V(\\overline{\\mathfrak{J}_{R}})$ are adjacent if and only if $1-xy \\in U(R)$, where $J(R)$ is the Jacobson radical of $R$ and $U(R)$ is the set of all unit elements of $R$. In this paper, we determine the diameter, the girth, the domination number and the edge chromatic number of the complement of the Jacobson graph of a commutative ring. Also, we prove that for every finite commutative ring $R$, $\\overline{\\mathfrak{J}_R}$ is a regular graph if and only if $R$ is a local ring with residual field of order at most $3$.</p>	string

1384	en_US	abstract	The distinguishing number (index) $D(G)$ ($D'(G)$) of a graph $G$ is the least integer $d$ such that $G$ has an vertex labeling (edge labeling)  with $d$ labels  that is preserved only by a trivial automorphism. 1387	en_US	title	On König-Egerváry Collections of Maximum Critical Independent Sets	string
1387	en_US	cleanTitle	On KönigEgerváry Collections of Maximum Critical Independent Sets	string
1387	en_US	abstract	<p>Let G be a simple graph with vertex set V(G). A set S⊆V(G) is independent if no two vertices from S are adjacent. Let Ind(G) denote the family of all independent sets.<br />The graph G is known to be a König-Egerváry if α(G)+μ(G)= |V(G)|, where α(G) denotes the size of a maximum independent set and μ(G) is the cardinality of a maximum matching. A family Γ⊆Ind(G) is a König-Egerváry collection if |⋃Γ|+|⋂Γ|=2α(G) &lt;Jarden, Levit, Mandrescu, 2015&gt;.<br />The number d(X)= |X|-|N(X)| is the difference of X⊆V(G), and a set A∈Ind(G) is critical if d(A)=max{d(I):I∈Ind(G)} &lt;Zhang, 1990&gt;.<br />In this paper, we show that if the family of all maximum critical independent sets of a graph G is a König-Egerváry collection, then G is a König-Egerváry graph. It generalizes one of our conjectures recently validated in &lt;Short, 2016&gt;.</p>	string

1395	en_US	title	Hitting times for random walks on quadrilateral graphs and their applications	string
1395	en_US	cleanTitle	Hitting times for random walks on quadrilateral graphs and their applications	string
1395	en_US	abstract	Let $G$ be a connected graph. The quadrilateral graph of $G$, denoted by $Q_G,$ is the graph obtained from $G$ by replacing each edge in $G$ with two parallel paths of lengths 1 and 3. In this paper, the complete information for the eigenvalues of the probability transition matrix of a random walk on $Q_G$ in terms of those of $G$ is provided. Then the expected hitting time between any two vertices of $Q_G$ in terms of those of $G$ is completely determined. Finally, as applications, the correlation between the degree-Kirchhoff index (resp.  Kemeny's constant, number of spanning trees) of $Q_G$ and $G$ is derived. Furthermore, based on the relationship of the expected hitting time between any two vertices of $Q_G$ and $G$, the resistance distance between any two vertices of $Q_G$ is presented in terms of that of $G$.<br /><br />	string

1396	en_US	title	Strong $q$-log-concavity for certain combinatorial triangle and linear transformations	string
1396	en_US	cleanTitle	Strong qlogconcavity for certain combinatorial triangle and linear transformations	string
1396	en_US	abstract	<p>Let $[A_{n,k}(q)]_{n, k\\geq0}$ be an infinite lower triangular array<br />of polynomials in $q$ with nonnegative coefficients satisfying the<br />recurrence<br />\\begin{eqnarray*}\\label{re}<br />A_{n,k}(q)=f_{n,k}(q)\\,A_{n-1,k-1}(q)+g_{n,k}(q)\\,A_{n-1,k}(q)+h_{n,k}(q)\\,A_{n-1,k+1}(q),<br />\\end{eqnarray*}<br />for $n\\geq 1$ and $k\\geq 0$, where $A_{0,0}(q)=1$,<br />$A_{0,k}(q)=A_{0,-1}(q)=0$ for $k&gt;0$. We present criterions for the<br />strong $q$-log-concavity of the sequences in each row of<br />$[A_{n,k}(q)]_{n, k\\geq0}$. As applications, we get the strong<br />$q$-log-concavity or the log-concavity of the sequence in each row<br />of many well-known triangular arrays, such as the Catalan triangles<br />of Aigner and Shaprio, large Schr\\"oder triangle, the Motzkin<br />triangle, the Bell polynomials triangle, the Eulerian polynomials<br />triangle and the Narayana polynomials triangle in a unified<br />approach.</p><p> It is well-known that the binomial<br />transformation  preserves the log-concavity property and<br />log-convexity property. Let $\\binom{a+n}{b+k}$ be the binomial<br />coefficients and $\\binom{n,k}{j}$ be defined by<br />$(b_0+b_1x+\\cdots+b_kx^{k})^n:=\\sum_{j=0}^{kn}\\binom{n,k}{j}x^j,$<br />where the sequence $(b_i)_{0\\leq i\\leq k}$ is log-concave. In this<br />paper, we also prove that the linear transformation<br />$$y_n(q)=\\sum_{k=0}^n\\binom{a+n}{b+k}x_k(q)$$ preserves the strong $q$-log-concavity<br />property for any fixed nonnegative integers $a$ and $b$, which<br />strengthens and gives a simple proof of results of Ehrenborg and<br />Steingrimsson, and Wang, respectively, on linear transformations<br />preserving the log-concavity property. We also show that the linear<br />transformation<br />$$y_n=\\sum_{i=0}^{kn}\\binom{n,k}{j}x_i$$ not only preserves the log-concavity property, but also preserves the log-convexity<br />property, which extends the results of Ahmia and Belbachir about the<br />$s$-triangle transformation preserving the log-convexity property<br />and log-concavity property.</p>	string

1405	en_US	abstract	In the paper we introduce and study partitions of vectors in N p , as a natural extension<br />of the classical partitions of integers. 1406	en_US	abstract	<p>Tutte’s <span class="math inline">3</span>-flow conjecture claims that every bridgeless graph with no <span class="math inline">3</span>-edge-cut admits a nowhere-zero <span class="math inline">3</span>-flow. In this paper we verify the validity of Tutte’s <span class="math inline">3</span>-flow conjecture on Cayley graphs of certain classes of finite groups. 1862	en_US	abstract	Let $G=(V,E)$ be a simple connected graph, where $V(G)$ and $E(G)$ represent the vertex set and edge set of $G$ respectively. 1408	en_US	abstract	<p>The purpose of this research is to study the stochastic pantograph differential equations (SPDEs) in the G-framework. We determine that any solution $Z(t)$ of stochastic pantograph differential equation in the G-framework is bounded i.e.,<br />in particular $Z(t)\\in M_G^2([0,T];\\R^n).$ Subject to growth and Lipschitz conditions, we prove that SPDEs in the G-framework admit unique solution. Some useful inequalities, such as the H$\\ddot{o}$lder's inequality, Doobs martingale's inequality, Burkholder-Davis-Gundy's (BDG) inequalities and Gronwall's<br />inequality are utilized to derive our results. In addition, we obtain the asymptotic estimates for the solutions to SPDEs in the G-framework.</p>	string

1409	en_US	abstract	<p>A regular cover of a connected graph is called <em>cyclic</em> or <em>dihedral</em> if its transformation group is cyclic or dihedral respectively, and <em>arc-transitive</em> (or <em>symmetric</em>) if the fibre-preserving automorphism subgroup acts arc-transitively on the regular cover. 1412	en_US	abstract	Let $X$ denote a set of non-negative integers and $\\sP_0(X)$ be the collection of all non-empty subsets of $X$. An integer additive set-labeling (IASL) of a graph $G$ is an injective set-valued function $f:V(G)\\to \\sP_0(X)$ where induced function $f^+:E(G) \\to \\sP_0(X)$ is defined by $f^+(uv)=f(u)+f(v)$, where $f(u)+f(v)$ is the sumset of $f(u)$ and $f(v)$. A set-labeling $f:V(G)\\to \\sP_0(X)$ is said to be a topological set-labeling if $f(V(G))\\cup\\{\\emptyset\\}$ is a topology on the ground set $X$ and a set-labeling $f:V(G)\\to \\sP_0(X)$ is said to be a topogenic set-labeling if $f(V(G))\\cup f^+(E(G))\\cup\\{\\emptyset\\}$ is a topology on $X$. In this article, we critically review some interesting studies on the properties and characteristics of different topological and topogenic integer additive set-labeling of certain graphs.	string

1414	en_US	title	Coloring properties of categorical product of general Kneser hypergraphs	string
1414	en_US	cleanTitle	Coloring properties of categorical product of general Kneser hypergraphs	string
1414	en_US	abstract	<p>More than 50 years ago Hedetniemi conjectured that the chromatic number of categorical product of two graphs is equal to the minimum of their chromatic numbers. This conjecture has received a considerable attention in recent years. Hedetniemi’s conjecture was generalized to hypergraphs by Zhu in 1992. Hajiabolhassan and Meunier, in 2016, introduced the first nontrivial lower bound for the chromatic number of categorical product of general Kneser hypergraphs and using this lower bound, they verified Zhu’s conjecture for some families of hypergraphs. In this paper, we shall present some colorful type results for the coloring of categorical product of general Kneser hypergraphs, which generalize the Hajiabolhassan-Meunier result. Also, we present a new lower bound for the chromatic number of categorical product of general Kneser hypergraphs which can be much better than the Hajiabolhassan-Meunier lower bound. Using this lower bound, we enrich the family of hypergraphs satisfying Zhu’s conjecture.</p>	string

1415	en_US	title	Signless Laplacian spectral determinations of some multicone graphs	string
1415	en_US	cleanTitle	Signless Laplacian spectral determinations of some multicone graphs	string
1415	en_US	abstract	<p>The main aim af this study is to characterize new classes of multicone graphs which are determined<br />by their signless Laplacian spectra. A multicone graph is defined to be the join of a clique and a regular<br />graph. Let G be an r-regular graph of order n and Kw be an arbitrary complete graph on w vertices.<br />In [B. Changjiang, and J. Zhou, Signless Laplacian spectral characterization of the cones over some<br />regular graphs, Linear Algebra Appl., 436.9 (2012): 3634-3641], it were proved that the multicone graphs<br />K1▽ G are determined by their signless Laplacian spectrum for r = 1,n − 2,r = 2 (for r = 2, n ≥ 11).<br />In addition, these authors shown that the multicone graphs K1 ▽ G are determined by their signless<br />Laplacian spectrum if and only if the complement of G has no triangles, when r = n − 3. In another<br />paper [On the signless Laplacian spectral determination of the join of regular graphs, Discrete Math.,<br />Algorithms and Appl., 6.04 (2014): 1450050], X. Lizhen, and C. He proved these facts for K2▽G, when<br />r = 1,2,n − 3. Also, X. Liu and L. Pengli, [Signless Laplacian spectral characterization of some joins,<br />Elect. J. Linear Algebra 30.1 (2015), 30.] shown that the multicone graphs Kw▽ G are determined by<br />their signless Laplacian spectrum, when G is a (n−2)-regular. In this study, we generalize these facts and<br />by simple ways we prove that the multicone graphs Kw▽ G are determined by their signless Laplacian<br />spectrum for r = 1,n − 2. For r = n − 3, we show that the multicone graphs Kw▽ G are determined<br />by their signless Laplacian spectrum if and only if the complement of G has no triangles. For, n = 2, it<br />is proved that if w ≥ 3, then the multicone graphs Kw▽ G are determined by their signless Laplacian<br />spectrum.</p>	string

1418	en_US	abstract	A path in an edge-colored graph is called \\emph{conflict-free}<br />if it contains at least one color used on exactly one of its edges.<br />An edge-colored graph $G$ is \\emph{conflict-free connected}<br />if for any two distinct vertices of $G$, there is a conflict-free path connecting them.<br />For a connected graph $G$, the \\emph{conflict-free connection number} of $G$, denoted by $cfc(G)$,<br />is defined as the minimum number of colors that are required to make $G$<br />conflict-free connected.<br />In this paper, we investigate the conflict-free connection numbers of<br />connected claw-free graphs, especially line graphs.<br />We first show that for an arbitrary connected graph $G$, there exists a positive integer $k$ such that $cfc(L^k(G))\\leq 2$.<br />Secondly, we get the exact value of the conflict-free connection number of a connected claw-free graph, especially a connected line graph.<br />Thirdly, we prove that for an arbitrary connected graph $G$<br />and an arbitrary positive integer $k$, we always have $cfc(L^{k+1}(G))\\leq cfc(L^k(G))$,<br />with only the exception that $G$ is isomorphic to a star of order at least~$5$ and $k=1$.<br />Finally, we obtain the exact values<br />of $cfc(L^k(G))$, and use them as an efficient tool to get the smallest<br />nonnegative integer $k_0$ such that $cfc(L^{k_0}(G))=2$.	string

1419	en_US	title	Enumerating regular graph coverings whose covering transformation groups are  ℤ<sub>2</sub>-extensions of a cyclic group	string

1419	en_US	abstract	<p>Several types of the isomorphism classes of graph coverings have been enumerated by many authors. In 1988, Hofmeister enumerated the double covers of a graph, and this work was extended to <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span>-fold coverings of a graph by the second and third authors. For <span><em>regular</em></span> coverings of a graph, their isomorphism classes were enumerated when the covering transformation group is a finite abelian or dihedral group. In this paper, we enumerate the isomorphism classes of graph coverings when the covering transformation group is a <span class="math inline">ℤ<sub>2</sub></span>-extension of a cyclic group, including generalized quaternion and semi-dihedral groups.</p>	string

1420	en_US	title	The number of direct-sum decompositions of a finite vector space	string
1420	en_US	cleanTitle	The number of directsum decompositions of a finite vector space	string
1420	en_US	abstract	The theory of q-analogs develops many combinatorial formulas for finite vector spaces over a finite field with q elements--all in analogy with formulas for finite sets (which are the special case of q=1). A direct-sum decomposition of a finite vector space is the vector space analogue of a set partition. This paper uses elementary methods to develop the formulas for the number of direct-sum decompositions that are the q-analogs of the formulas for: (1) the number of set partitions with a given number partition signature; (2) the number of set partitions of an n-element set with m blocks (the Stirling numbers of the second kind); and (3) for the total number of set partitions of an n-element set (the Bell numbers). The paper also develops the new formulas to enumerate: (4) the number of direct-sum decompositions in an n-dimensional vector space over GF(q) with m blocks and where any given nonzero vector is in one of the blocks, and (5) the number of direct-sum decompositions in an n-dimensional vector space over GF(q) where any given nonzero vector is in one of the blocks. Initial computations are included for the case of q=2 with applications to the pedagogical model of quantum mechanics over ℤ₂, QM/Sets, and with four new sequences added to the On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences.	string
1420	en_US	discipline	Enumerative Combinatorics; q-analogs	string

1421	en_US	title	The role of insoluble surfactants on the dynamical behavior of two layers channel flow	string
1421	en_US	cleanTitle	The role of insoluble surfactants on the dynamical behavior of two layers channel flow	string
1421	en_US	abstract	The purpose of this study is to establish the effects of insoluble surfactants on the stability of two layers<br />flow down an inclined wall in the limit of Stokes and long-wavelength approximations. The dynamics of<br />the liquid-liquid interface is described for arbitrary amplitudes by evolution equations derived from the<br />basic hydrodynamic equations, in which the fluids are subjected to a uniform electric field. The principle<br />aim of this work is to investigate the influence of interfacial stability on the growth rate in the presence<br />of interfacial insoluble surfactants. The parameters governing the flow system, such as Marangoni, Weber,<br />capillary numbers and the inclined substrate strongly effect the wave forms and their amplitudes and hence<br />the stability of the fluid. Analytical and numerical simulations of this system of linear evolution equations<br />are performed. Depend on the selected parameters, the phenomenon of the dual role is found to increase<br />the electric Weber number as well as the viscosity ratio. The interfacial waves will be more stable with the<br />increasing of the values of the Marangoni number, while the opposite effect is found for the increase capillary<br />number. In the long wave perturbations, the stability process is found to confirm the stabilizing effect of<br />the Marangoni number and the destabilizing influence of both capillary and Reynolds numbers, whereas the<br />dual role is observed for increasing dielectric ratio.	string

1423	en_US	title	The distinguishing number of groups based on the distinguishing number of subgroups	string
1423	en_US	cleanTitle	The distinguishing number of groups based on the distinguishing number of subgroups	string
1423	en_US	abstract	Let $\\Gamma$ be a group acting on a set $X$. The distinguishing number for this action of $\\Gamma$ on $X$, denoted by $D_{\\Gamma}(X)$, is the smallest natural number $k$ such that the elements of $X$ can be labeled with $k$ labels so that any label-preserving element of $\\Gamma$ fixes all $x \\in X$. In particular, if the action is faithful, then the only element of $\\Gamma$ preserving labels is the identity. In this paper, we  obtain an upper bound on the distinguishing number of a set knowing the distinguishing number of a set under the action of a subgroup. By the concept of motion, we obtain an upper bound for the distinguishing number of a group. Motivated by a  problem  (Chan 2006),  we characterize $D_{\\Gamma,H}(X)$ which is the smallest number of labels admitting a labeling of $X$ such that the only elements of $\\Gamma$ that induce label-preserving permutations lie in $H$. Finally, we state  two algorithms for obtaining an upper and a lower bound for $D_{\\Gamma , H}(X)$.	string

1424	en_US	abstract	A $(d,1)$-total labelling of graph $G$ is an integer-valued function defined on the set<br /> $V(G) \\cup E(G)$ such that<br />$$|f(x)-f(y)|\\geq\\left\\{\\begin{array}{l} {1, if~vertices~x ~and~ y ~are~ adjacent,}\\\\<br /> {1, if~edges~x~and~y~are~adjacent,}\\\\<br /> {d,<br />if~vertex~x~and~edge~y~are ~incident.} \\end{array} \\right.$$ In<br />this paper,  the $(d,1)$-total labelling of the square of cycle<br />  and  its Cartesian products<br />   with complete bipartite graphs  are studied, and<br />  their $(d,1)$-total numbers for different cases are obtained.	string

1427	en_US	abstract	<p>Let <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span>, <span class="math inline"><em>q</em></span> and <span class="math inline"><em>r</em></span> be positive integers, and let <span class="math inline"><em>K</em><sub><em>N</em></sub><sup><em>n</em></sup></span> be the <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span>-skeleton of an <span class="math inline">(<em>N</em> − 1)</span>-simplex. This result is new in the classical case <span class="math inline"><em>n</em> = 1</span> (graphs embedded in <span class="math inline">ℝ<sup>3</sup></span>) as well as the higher dimensional cases <span class="math inline"><em>n</em> ≥ 2</span>; and since it implies the existence of an <span class="math inline"><em>r</em></span>-component link with all pairwise linking numbers at least <span class="math inline"><em>q</em></span> in absolute value, it also extends a result of Flapan et al. from <span class="math inline"><em>n</em> = 1</span> to higher dimensions. Additionally, for <span class="math inline"><em>r</em> = 2</span> we obtain an improved upper bound on the number of vertices required to force a two-component link with linking number a nonzero multiple of <span class="math inline"><em>q</em></span>. Our new bound has growth <span class="math inline"><em>O</em>(<em>n</em><em>q</em><sup>2</sup>)</span>, in contrast to the previous bound of growth <span class="math inline"><em>O</em>(√(<em>n</em>)4<sup><em>n</em></sup><em>q</em><sup><em>n</em> + 2</sup>)</span>.</p>	string

1428	en_US	title	Upper bounds on the $k$-tuple domination number and $k$-tuple total domination number of a graph	string
1428	en_US	cleanTitle	Upper bounds on the ktuple domination number and ktuple total domination number of a graph	string
1428	en_US	abstract	Let $k$ be a positive integer. A subset $S$ of vertices of a<br />graph $G$ is called a \\textit{$k$-tuple dominating set} in $G$ if<br />for every vertex $v\\in V (G)$, $|N[v] \\cap S|\\geq k$. The minimum<br />cardinality of a $k$-tuple dominating set in $G$ is the<br />\\textit{$k$-tuple domination number} $\\gamma_{\\times k}(G)$ of<br />$G$. A subset $S$ of vertices of a graph $G$ is called a<br />\\textit{$k$-tuple total dominating set} in $G$ if for every<br />vertex $v\\in V(G)$, $|N(v) \\cap S|\\geq k$. The minimum<br />cardinality of a $k$-tuple total dominating set in $G$ is the<br />\\textit{$k$-tuple total domination number} $\\gamma_{\\times<br />k,t}(G)$ of $G$. We present probabilistic upper bounds for the<br />$k$-tuple domination number of a graph as well as for the<br />$k$-tuple total domination number of a graph, and improve<br />previous bounds given in [J. Harant and M. A. Henning, On double<br />domination in graphs, Discuss. Math. Graph Theory 25 (2005),<br />29--34], [E. J. Cockayne, A. G. Thomason, An upper bound for the<br />$k$-tuple domination number, J. Combin. Math. Combin. Comput. 64<br />(2008), 251--254], and [M.A. Henning, A.P. Kazemi, $k$-tuple<br />total domination in graphs, Discrete Appl. Math. 158 (2010),<br />1006--1011] for graphs with sufficiently large minimum degree.	string

1432	en_US	title	Automorphism group of the Bouwer graph	string
1432	en_US	cleanTitle	Automorphism group of the Bouwer graph	string
1432	en_US	abstract	<p>Let $k, m, n$ be three positive integers such that $2^{m}\\equiv 1~(\\mod n)$ and $k\\geq 2$. The {\\em Bouwer graph}, denoted by $B(k, m, n)$, is a graph with vertex set $$\\{(a, \\mathbf{b})\\ |\\ a\\in\\mz_m, \\mathbf{b}\\in\\underbrace{\\mz_n\\times\\cdots\\times\\mz_n}_{k-1\\ {\\rm times}}\\},$$ and two vertices are adjacent if they can be written as $(a, \\mathbf{b})$ and $(a+1, \\mathbf{c})$, where either $\\mathbf{c}=\\mathbf{b}$ or $\\mathbf{c}=(c_{1}, c_{2}, \\cdots, c_{k-1})$ differs from $\\mathbf{b}=(b_{1}, b_{2}, \\cdots, b_{k-1})$ in exactly one position, say the $j$th position, where $c_{j}=b_{j}+2^{a}$. Every $B(k,m,n)$ is a vertex- and edge-transitive graph, and in 1970, Bouwer proved that $B(k, 6, 9)$ is half-arc-transitive for every $k\\geq 2$.<br />In 2016, Conder and \\v Zitnik proved that $B(k, m, n)$ is arc-transitive only when $n=3$, or $(k, n)=(2, 5)$, or $(k, m, n)=(2,3,7)$ or $(2,6,7)$ or $(2,6,21)$. In this paper, it is first shown that every $B(k,m,n)$ is a Cayley graph, and then the full automorphism group of every $B(k,m,n)$ is determined.</p>	string

1435	en_US	title	Vertex transitive graphs <i>G</i> with χ<sub><i>D</i></sub>(<i>G</i>) > χ(<i>G</i>) and small automorphism group	string

1435	en_US	abstract	<p>For a graph <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> and a positive integer <span class="math inline"><em>k</em></span>, a vertex labelling <span class="math inline"><em>f</em>: <em>V</em>(<em>G</em>) → {1, 2, …, <em>k</em>}</span> is said to be <span class="math inline"><em>k</em></span>-distinguishing if no non-trivial automorphism of <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> preserves the sets <span class="math inline"><em>f</em><sup> − 1</sup>(<em>i</em>)</span> for each <span class="math inline"><em>i</em> ∈ {1, …, <em>k</em>}</span>. 1436	en_US	abstract	<p>The space of linearly recursive sequences of complex numbers admits two distinguished topologies. Namely, the adic topology induced by the ideal of those sequences whose first term is <span class="math inline">0</span> and the topology induced from the Krull topology on the space of complex power series via a suitable embedding. 1437	en_US	title	Edge-transitive bi-<i>p</i>-metacirculants of valency <i>p</i>	string
1437	en_US	cleanTitle	Edgetransitive bi<i>p</i>metacirculants of valency <i>p</i>	string
1437	en_US	abstract	<p>Let <span class="math inline"><em>p</em></span> be an odd prime. A graph is called a bi-<span class="math inline"><em>p</em></span>-metacirculant on a metacyclic <span class="math inline"><em>p</em></span>-group <span class="math inline"><em>H</em></span> if admits a metacyclic <span class="math inline"><em>p</em></span>-group <span class="math inline"><em>H</em></span> of automorphisms acting semiregularly on its vertices with two orbits. A bi-<span class="math inline"><em>p</em></span>-metacirculant on a group <span class="math inline"><em>H</em></span> is said to be abelian or non-abelian according to whether or not <span class="math inline"><em>H</em></span> is abelian.</p><p>By the results of Malnič et al. in 2004 and Feng et al. in 2006, we see that up to isomorphism, the Gray graph is the only cubic edge-transitive non-abelian bi-<span class="math inline"><em>p</em></span>-metacirculant on a group of order <span class="math inline"><em>p</em><sup>3</sup></span>. This motivates us to consider the classification of cubic edge-transitive bi-<span class="math inline"><em>p</em></span>-metacirculants. Previously, we have proved that a cubic edge-transitive non-abelian bi-<span class="math inline"><em>p</em></span>-metacirculant exists if and only if <span class="math inline"><em>p</em> = 3</span>. In this paper, we give a classification of connected edge-transitive non-abelian bi-<span class="math inline"><em>p</em></span>-metacirculants of valency <span class="math inline"><em>p</em></span>, and consequently, we complete the classification of connected cubic edge-transitive non-abelian bi-<span class="math inline"><em>p</em></span>-metacirculants.</p>	string

1437	en_US	subject	Bi-p-metacirculant, edge-transitive, inner-abelian p-group	string
1437	en_US	sponsor	National Natural Science Foundation of China	string

1440	en_US	title	Shift-transitive and uniquely shift-transitive graphs of small degrees	string
1440	en_US	cleanTitle	Shifttransitive and uniquely shifttransitive graphs of small degrees	string
1440	en_US	abstract	An automorphism $\\sigma$ of a finite simple graph $\\Gamma$ is a shift,<br />if for every vertex $v\\in V(\\Gamma), \\sigma v$ is adjacent to $v$ in $\\Gamma$.<br />The graph $\\Gamma$ is shift-transitive,<br />if for every pair of vertices $u, v\\in V(\\Gamma)$ there exists a sequence of<br />shifts $\\sigma_1, \\sigma_2, ..., \\sigma_k\\in \\Aut(\\Gamma)$ such that $\\sigma_{1}\\sigma_{2}...\\sigma_{k}u=v$.<br />If, in addition, for every pair of adjacent vertices $u, v\\in V( \\Gamma)$ there exists exactly one<br />shift $\\sigma\\in \\Aut(\\Gamma)$ sending $u$ to $v$, then $\\Gamma$ is uniquely shift-transitive.<br />%Uniquely shift-transitive graphs have been studied by Pisanski et al, in~\\cite{ptz}.<br />The purpose of this paper is to prove that, if $\\Gamma$ is a uniquely shift-transitive graph of valency at most 5<br />and $S_{\\Gamma}$ is the set of shifts in $\\Gamma$ then $&lt;S_{\\Gamma}&gt;$ is an abelian<br />subgroup of $\\Aut(\\Gamma).$	string

1443	en_US	title	Some New Classes of Perfect Graphs	string
1443	en_US	cleanTitle	Some New Classes of Perfect Graphs	string
1443	en_US	abstract	A graph $G$ is called {\\it perfect} if for any induced subgraph $H$ of $G$, $\\chi(H)=\\omega(H)$, where $\\chi(H)$ and $\\omega(H)$ denotes the vertex chromatic number and clique number of $H$ respectively.<br />  Let $\\mathbb{V}$ be a finite dimensional vector space over a finite field $\\mathbb{F}$ with $\\mathcal{B}=\\{\\alpha_1,\\alpha_2,\\ldots,\\alpha_n\\}$ as a basis and $\\theta$ as the null vector. Then any vector $\\mathbf{a} \\in \\mathbb{V}$ can be expressed uniquely as a linear combination of the form $\\mathbf{a}=a_1\\alpha_1+a_2\\alpha_2+\\cdots+a_n\\alpha_n$. Let the skeleton of $\\mathbf{a}$, denoted by $S_{\\mathbf{a}}^\\mathbb{V}$ or simply $S_{\\mathbf{a}}$, be $S_{\\mathbf{a}}=\\{\\alpha_i:a_i \\neq 0\\}$. The non-zero component intersection graph of $\\mathbb{V}$ with respect to $\\{\\alpha_1,\\alpha_2,\\ldots,\\alpha_n\\}$, denoted by $\\Gamma(\\mathbb{V})$, is a graph on the vertex set $\\mathbb{V}\\setminus \\{\\theta\\}$ and two distinct vertices $\\mathbf{a}$ and $\\mathbf{b}$ are adjacent if and only if $S_{\\mathbf{a}}\\cap S_{\\mathbf{b}}\\neq \\emptyset$. The non-zero component union graph of $\\mathbb{V}$ with respect to $\\{\\alpha_1,\\alpha_2,\\ldots,\\alpha_n\\}$, denoted by $\\mathcal{G}(\\mathbb{V})$, is a graph on the vertex set $\\mathbb{V}\\setminus \\{\\theta\\}$ and two distinct vertices $\\mathbf{a}$ and $\\mathbf{b}$ are adjacent if and only if $S_{\\mathbf{a}}\\cup S_{\\mathbf{b}}=\\mathcal{B}$.  In this paper, we show that $\\Gamma(\\mathbb{V})$ and $\\mathcal{G}(\\mathbb{V})$ are perfect if and only if $n \\leq 4$. Moreover, we show that the family of zero component intersection graphs and union graphs with $n \\leq 4$ forms new classes of perfect graphs.	string

1445	en_US	title	THE FORCING EDGE FIXED STEINER NUMBER OF A GRAPH	string
1445	en_US	cleanTitle	THE FORCING EDGE FIXED STEINER NUMBER OF A GRAPH	string
1445	en_US	abstract	<p>Let G be a connected graph with at least 3 vertices. For an edge e = xy in G, a<br />set W sub set of  V(G) − {x, y} is called an edge fixed steiner set of G if W’ = W U {x, y} is a Steiner set of G. The minimum cardinality of an edge fixed steiner set is called the edge fixed steiner number of G and is denoted by se(G). For a minimum edge fixed steiner set W of G, a subset T sub set of W is called an edge fixed forcing subset for W if W is the unique minimum edge fixed steiner set containing T. An edge fixed forcing subset for W of minimum cardinality is a minimum edge fixed forcing subset of W. The cardinality of a minimum edge fixed forcing subset of W is called the forcing edge fixed steiner number of W and is denoted by fes(W). For each edge e in G, the forcing edge fixed steiner number of G, denoted by fes(G) is defined as fes(G) = min {fes(W)} where the minimum is taken over all the minimum edge fixed steiner sets<br />W in G. In this article, we study some properties of this parameter and determine fes(G) for some standard graphs.</p>	string

1454	en_US	abstract	<p>‎Let $\\delta$ and $\\Delta$ be the minimum and the maximum degree of the vertices of a simple connected graph $G$‎, ‎respectively‎.</p><p>‎The distinguishing index of a graph $G$‎, ‎denoted by $D'(G)$‎, ‎is the‎</p><p>‎least number of labels in an edge labeling of $G$ not preserved by‎</p><p>‎any non-trivial automorphism‎. ‎Motivated by a conjecture by Pil\\'sniak (2017)‎</p><p>‎that implies that for any $2$-connected graph $D'(G) \\leq \\lceil \\sqrt{\\Delta (G)}\\rceil‎ +1$, ‎we prove that for any graph $G$ with $\\delta\\geq 2$‎, ‎$D'(G) \\leq \\lceil \\sqrt[\\delta]{\\Delta }\\rceil‎ +1$. ‎Also‎, ‎we show that for any $k\\geq 5$‎, ‎the distinguishing index of $k$-regular graphs is at most $2$‎. ‎Finally‎, ‎as a consequence of our results‎, ‎we‎</p><p>‎describe a family of graphs whose settles in the affirmative a conjecture (the Nordhaus-Gaddum type relation for the distinguishing index of graph) stating that $2 \\leq D'(G)‎ + ‎D'(\\overline{G}) \\leq {\\rm max}\\{\\Delta(G)‎, ‎\\Delta(\\overline{G})\\}‎ + ‎2$‎. </p>	string

1459	en_US	title	Mirrors of reflections of regular maps	string

1459	en_US	abstract	<p>A regular map <span class="math inline">ℳ</span> is an embedding of a finite connected graph into a compact surface <span class="math inline"><em>S</em></span> such that its automorphism group <span class="math inline"><em>A</em><em>u</em><em>t</em><sup>+</sup>(ℳ)</span> acts transitively on the directed edges. A reflection of <span class="math inline">ℳ</span> fixes a number of simple closed geodesics on <span class="math inline"><em>S</em></span>, which are called mirrors. In this paper, we prove two theorems which enable us to calculate the total number of mirrors fixed by the reflections of a regular map and the lengths of these mirrors. 1461	en_US	abstract	<p>Let $R$ be a Noetherian integral domain which is also an algebra<br />over $\\mathbb{Q}$ ($\\mathbb{Q}$ is the field of rational numbers).<br />Let $\\sigma$ be an endomorphism of $R$ and $\\delta$ a<br />$\\sigma$-derivation of $R$. 1460	en_US	cleanTitle	The conductivity of superimposed keygraphs with a common onedimensional adjacency nullspace	string
1460	en_US	abstract	<p>Two connected labelled graphs <span class="math inline"><em>H</em><sub>1</sub></span> and <span class="math inline"><em>H</em><sub>2</sub></span> of nullity one, with identical one-vertex deleted subgraphs <span class="math inline"><em>H</em><sub>1</sub> − <em>z</em><sub>1</sub></span> and <span class="math inline"><em>H</em><sub>2</sub> − <em>z</em><sub>2</sub></span> and having a common eigenvector in the nullspace of their <span class="math inline">0</span>-<span class="math inline">1</span> adjacency matrix, can be overlaid to produce the superimposition <span class="math inline"><em>Z</em></span>. The graph <span class="math inline"><em>Z</em></span> is <span class="math inline"><em>H</em><sub>1</sub> + <em>z</em><sub>2</sub></span> and also <span class="math inline"><em>H</em><sub>2</sub> + <em>z</em><sub>1</sub></span> whereas <span class="math inline"><em>Z</em> + <em>e</em></span> is obtained from <span class="math inline"><em>Z</em></span> by adding the edge <span class="math inline">{<em>z</em><sub>1</sub>, <em>z</em><sub>2</sub>}</span>. We show that the nullity of <span class="math inline"><em>Z</em></span> cannot take all the values allowed by interlacing. We propose to classify graphs with two chosen vertices according to the type of the vertices occurring by using a <span class="math inline">3</span>-type-code. Out of the <span class="math inline">27</span> values it can take, only <span class="math inline">9</span> are hypothetically possible for <span class="math inline"><em>Z</em></span>, <span class="math inline">8</span> of which are known to exist. Moreover, the SSP molecular model predicts conduction or insulation at the Fermi level of energy for <span class="math inline">11</span> possible types of devices consisting of a molecule and two prescribed connecting atoms over a small bias voltage. All <span class="math inline">11</span> molecular device types are realizable for general molecules, but the structure of <span class="math inline"><em>Z</em></span> and of <span class="math inline"><em>Z</em> + <em>e</em></span> restricts the number to just <span class="math inline">5</span>.</p>	string

1462	en_US	title	M-polynomial and related degree-based descriptors of 2 Smart Polymers SP[n]	string
1462	en_US	cleanTitle	Mpolynomial and related degreebased descriptors of 2 Smart Polymers SP[n]	string
1462	en_US	abstract	Discovery of smart polymers opens up a new era in the field of pharmaceutical and biological 14 therapeutics. Smart polymeric drug delivery systems provide a link between therapeutic needs and drug 15 delivery and are engineered to carry specific cargo molecules to the desired site. The drug is released at the site 16 of action upon a change in pH, stimulus, and temperature change and bio responsiveness. M-polynomial and 17 topological indices have been subject matter for many extensively used chains of molecules. Topological 18 indices are numerical parameters used to study the structural and chemical properties of compounds. These 19 indices are used to build a quantitative structure-activity relationship between compounds (QSARs). QSARs 20 correlate the biological activity of compounds with their physical properties like boiling point, stability, 21 melting point distortion and strain energy etc. In this paper, we determine M-polynomials of Smart polymers 22 SP[n]. Then we derive closed formulas for some well-known classes of topological indices using calculus. We 23 also give other important topological indices by using basic definitions. In the end, we have used Maple 13 to 24 plot surfaces associated to M-polynomials and characterize some facts about these smart polymers.	string

1464	en_US	abstract	<p>Given a graph denoted by Γ with <em>n</em> number of vertices, Its Laplacian matrix is defined as L(Γ)= D(Γ)-A(Γ), where A(Γ), is the adjacency matrix of Γ and D(Γ) is the degree matrix of Γ.  The Laplacian spectrum of the graph L-SpectL(Γ)  is a set of the eigenvalues of its Laplacian matrix L(Γ)  In this paper we introduce and prove the generalized formula for the Laplacian spectrum of commuting and non-commuting graphs of the dihedral groups, for generalized quaternion group and for quasidihedral group.</p>	string

1463	en_US	cleanTitle	Stabilizing   the distinguishing number of a graph	string
1463	en_US	abstract	<p>‎The distinguishing number $D(G)$ of a graph $G$ is the least integer $d$‎</p><p>‎such that $G$ has a vertex labeling with $d$ labels that is preserved only by a trivial‎</p><p>‎automorphism‎. ‎The distinguishing stability‎,</p><p>‎of a graph $G$ is denoted by $st_D(G)$ and is the minimum number of vertices whose‎</p><p>‎removal changes the distinguishing number‎. ‎We show that for every natural number $k$‎, ‎there exists a graph $G$ such that $st_D(G)=k$‎. ‎Then we give some upper bounds for $st_D(G)$‎. ‎We also study the edge distinguishing stability number (distinguishing bondage number) of $G$‎. </p>	string

1466	en_US	abstract	<p>Fibonacci cubes $|Gamma_n$ are the subgraphs of the hypercubes induced by<br />the binary strings without two consecutive 1’s. 1468	en_US	title	Restricted size Ramsey number for $P_3$ versus cycle	string
1468	en_US	cleanTitle	Restricted size Ramsey number for P_3 versus cycle	string
1468	en_US	abstract	Let $F$, $G$ and $H$ be simple graphs. We say $F \\rightarrow (G, H)$ if for every \\linebreak  $2$-coloring of the edges of $F$ there exists a red copy of $G$ or a blue copy of $H$ in $F$. The Ramsey number $r(G, H)$ is defined as $r(G, H) = min\\{|V (F)|: F \\rightarrow (G, H)\\}$, while the restricted size Ramsey number $r^{*}(G, H)$ is defined as $r^{*}(G, H) = min\\{|E (F)|: F \\rightarrow (G, H) , |V (F) | = r(G, H)\\}$. In this paper we determine previously unknown restricted size Ramsey numbers $r^{*}(P_3, C_n)$ for $7 \\leq n \\leq 12$. We also give new upper bound $r^{*}(P_3, C_n) \\leq 2n-2$ for even $n \\geq 8$.	string

1471	en_US	title	An explicit descent of real algebraic varieties	string
1471	en_US	cleanTitle	An explicit descent of real algebraic varieties	string
1471	en_US	abstract	Let $X$ be an smooth complex affine algebraic variety admitting a symmetry $L$, that is, an antiholomorphic automorphism of order two. If both, $X$ and $L$ are defined over $\\overline{\\mathbb Q}$, then Koeck, Lau and Singerman showed the existence of a complex smooth algebraic variety $Z$ admitting a symmetry $T$, both defined over ${\\mathbb R} \\cap \\overline{\\mathbb Q}$, and of an isomorphism $R:X \\to Z$ so that $R \\circ L \\circ R^{-1}=T$. The provided proof is existential and, if explicit equations for $X$ and $L$ are given over $\\overline{\\mathbb Q}$, then it is not described how to get the explicit equations for $Z$ and $T$ over ${\\mathbb R} \\cap \\overline{\\mathbb Q}$. In this paper we provide an explicit rational map $R$ defined over $\\overline{\\mathbb Q}$ so that $Z=R(X)$ is defined over ${\\mathbb R} \\cap \\overline{\\mathbb Q}$, $Q:X \\to Z$ is an isomorphisms and $T=R \\circ L \\circ R^{-1}$ being the usual conjugation map.	string

1473	en_US	cleanTitle	Orlicz mean dual aﬃne quermassintegrals	string
1473	en_US	abstract	In the paper, our main aim is to generalize the mean dual aﬃne<br />quermassintegrals to Orlicz space. Under the framework of Orlicz dual Brunn Minkowski theory, we introduce a new aﬃne geometric quantity by calculating the ﬁrst Orlicz variation of the mean dual aﬃne quermassintegrals, and call as the Orlicz mean dual aﬃne quermassintegrals. The fundamental notions<br />and conclusions of the mean dual aﬃne quermassintegrals, and the Minkoswki and Brunn-Minkowski inequalities for the mean dual aﬃne quermassintegrals are extended to an Orlicz setting, and the related concepts and inequalities of Orlicz dual mixed volumes are also included in our conclusions. The new Orlicz isoperimetric inequalities in special case yield the Orlicz dual Minkowski inequality and orlicz dual Brunn-Minkowski inequality, which also imply the Lp-dual Minkowski inequality and Brunn-Minkowski inequality for the mean<br />dual aﬃne quermassintegrals.	string

1474	en_US	title	Extremal embedded graphs	string
1474	en_US	cleanTitle	Extremal embedded graphs	string
1474	en_US	abstract	<p>Let <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> be a ribbon graph and <span class="math inline">μ(<em>G</em>)</span> be the number of components of the virtual link formed from <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> as a cellularly embedded graph via the medial construction. In this paper we first prove that <span class="math inline">μ(<em>G</em>) ≤ <em>f</em>(<em>G</em>) + γ(<em>G</em>)</span>, where <span class="math inline"><em>f</em>(<em>G</em>)</span> and <span class="math inline">γ(<em>G</em>)</span> are the number of boundary components and Euler genus of <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span>, respectively. A ribbon graph is said to be extremal if <span class="math inline">μ(<em>G</em>) = <em>f</em>(<em>G</em>) + γ(<em>G</em>)</span>. We then obtain that a ribbon graph is extremal if and only if its Petrial is plane. We introduce a notion of extremal minor and provide an excluded extremal minor characterization for extremal ribbon graphs. We also point out that a related result in the monograph by Ellis-Monaghan and Moffatt is not correct and prove that two related conjectures raised by Huggett and Tawfik hold for more general ribbon graphs.</p>	string

1475	en_US	abstract	<p>A skew morphism <span class="math inline"><em>φ</em></span> of a finite group <span class="math inline"><em>A</em></span> is a permutation on <span class="math inline"><em>A</em></span> fixing the identity element of <span class="math inline"><em>A</em></span> and for which there exists an integer-valued function <span class="math inline"><em>π</em></span> on <span class="math inline"><em>A</em></span> such that <span class="math inline"><em>φ</em>(<em>a</em><em>b</em>) = <em>φ</em>(<em>a</em>)<em>φ</em><sup><em>π</em>(<em>a</em>)</sup>(<em>b</em>)</span> for all <span class="math inline"><em>a</em>, <em>b</em> ∈ <em>A</em></span>. In the case where <span class="math inline"><em>π</em>(<em>φ</em>(<em>a</em>)) = <em>π</em>(<em>a</em>)</span>, for all <span class="math inline"><em>a</em> ∈ <em>A</em></span>, the skew morphism is smooth. The concept of smooth skew morphism is a generalization of that of <span class="math inline"><em>t</em></span>-balanced skew morphism. The aim of this paper is to develop a general theory of smooth skew morphisms. As an application we classify smooth skew morphisms of dihedral groups.</p>	string

1485	en_US	title	Decomposition method related to saturated hyperball packings	string
1485	en_US	cleanTitle	Decomposition method related to saturated hyperball packings	string
1485	en_US	abstract	<p>In this paper we study the problem of hyperball (hypersphere) packings in 3-dimensional hyperbolic space. We introduce a new definition of the non-compact saturated ball packings with generalized balls (horoballs, hyperballs) and describe to each saturated hyperball packing, a new procedure to get a decomposition of 3-dimensional hyperbolic space ℍ<sup>3</sup> into truncated tetrahedra. Therefore, in order to get a density upper bound for hyperball packings, it is sufficient to determine the density upper bound of hyperball packings in truncated simplices.</p>	string

1486	en_US	title	Semiregular automorphisms in vertex-transitive graphs with a solvable group of automorphisms	string
1486	en_US	cleanTitle	Semiregular automorphisms in vertextransitive graphs with a solvable group of automorphisms	string
1486	en_US	abstract	It has been conjectured that automorphism groups of vertex-transitive (di)graphs, and more generally <span class="math inline">2</span>-closures of transitive permutation groups, must necessarily possess a fixed-point-free element of prime order, and thus a non-identity element with all orbits of the same length, in other words, a <span><em>semiregular</em></span> element. The known affirmative answers for graphs with primitive and quasiprimitive groups of automorphisms suggest that solvable groups need to be considered if one is to hope for a complete solution of this conjecture. It is the purpose of this paper to present an overview of known results and suggest possible further lines of research towards a complete solution of the problem.	string

1492	en_US	abstract	We study the structure of linear codes over the ring $B_k$ which is defined by<br />$\\mathbb{F}_{p^r}[v_1,\\dots,v_k]/\\langle v_i^2=v_i,~v_iv_j=v_jv_i \\rangle_{i,j=1}^k.$<br />In order to study the codes, we first study the structure of the ring $B_k$<br />via a Gray map which also induce a relation between codes over $B_k$ and codes<br />over $\\mathbb{F}_{p^r}.$<br />We consider Euclidean and Hermitian self-dual codes, MacWilliams relations, as well as Singleton-type bound<br />for this codes.<br />Further, we characterize cyclic and quasi-cyclic codes using their images under the Gray map,<br />and give the generators for these type of codes.	string

1493	en_US	title	Balanced complexes and effective divisors on $\\overline{M}_{0,n}$	string
1493	en_US	cleanTitle	Balanced complexes and effective divisors on \\overline{M}_{0n}	string
1493	en_US	abstract	<p>Doran, Jensen and Giansiracusa showed a bijection between homogeneous elements in the Cox ring of $\\overline{M}_{0,n}$ not divisible by any exceptional divisor section, and weighted pure-dimensional simplicial complexes satisfying a zero-tension condition. Motivated by the study of the monoid of effective divisors, the pseudoeffective cone and the Cox ring of $\\overline{M}_{0,n}$, we point out a simplification of the zero-tension condition and study the space of balanced complexes. We give examples of irreducible elements in the monoid of effective divisors of $\\overline{M}_{0,n}$ for large $n$. In the case of $\\overline{M}_{0,7}$, we classify all such irreducible elements arising from nonsingular complexes and give an example of how irreducibility can be shown in the singular case.</p>	string

1496	en_US	cleanTitle	Distant sum distinguishing index of graphs with bounded minimum degree	string
1496	en_US	abstract	<p>For any graph <span class="math inline"><em>G</em> = (<em>V</em>, <em>E</em>)</span> with maximum degree <span class="math inline">Δ</span> and without isolated edges, and a positive integer <span class="math inline"><em>r</em></span>, by <span class="math inline">χ′<sub>Σ, <em>r</em></sub>(<em>G</em>)</span> we denote the <span class="math inline"><em>r</em></span>-distant sum distinguishing index of <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span>. This is the least integer <span class="math inline"><em>k</em></span> for which a proper edge colouring <span class="math inline"><em>c</em>: <em>E</em> → {1, 2, …, <em>k</em>}</span> exists such that <span class="math inline">∑<sub><em>e</em>∋<em>u</em></sub> <em>c</em>(<em>e</em>) ≠ ∑<sub><em>e</em>∋<em>v</em></sub> <em>c</em>(<em>e</em>)</span> for every pair of distinct vertices <span class="math inline"><em>u</em>, <em>v</em></span> at distance at most <span class="math inline"><em>r</em></span> in <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span>. It was conjectured that <span class="math inline">χ′<sub>Σ, <em>r</em></sub>(<em>G</em>) ≤ (1 + <em>o</em>(1))Δ<sup><em>r</em> − 1</sup></span> for every <span class="math inline"><em>r</em> ≥ 3</span>. Thus far it has been in particular proved that <span class="math inline">χ′<sub>Σ, <em>r</em></sub>(<em>G</em>) ≤ 6Δ<sup><em>r</em> − 1</sup></span> if <span class="math inline"><em>r</em> ≥ 4</span>. Combining probabilistic and constructive approach, we show that this can be improved to <span class="math inline">χ′<sub>Σ, <em>r</em></sub>(<em>G</em>) ≤ (4 + <em>o</em>(1))Δ<sup><em>r</em> − 1</sup></span> if the minimum degree of <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> equals at least <span class="math inline">ln<sup>8</sup> Δ</span>.</p>	string

1497	en_US	abstract	<p>The \\textit{induced closed neighborhood $2$-edge coloring number} $\\psi_{2ie}^{'}(G)$ of a graph $G$ is the maximum<br />number of colors that can occur in a coloring of the edges of $G$ such that at most two different colors are used to color the<br />edges in the subgraph $\\big \\langle N[v]\\big\\rangle$ induced by the closed neighborhood $N[v]$ of a vertex $v$ in $G$.\\\\</p><p>The \\textit{star $2$-edge coloring number} $\\psi_{2*}^{'}(G)$ of $G$ is the maximum number of colors that occur<br />in a coloring of the edges of $G$ such that at most two different colors are used to color the edges incident to a vertex $v$ in $G$.<br />In this work we initiate a study of these two edge coloring numbers, besides finding exact values of these parameters, we obtain some bounds.</p>	string

1498	en_US	cleanTitle	Direct product of automorphism groups of digraphs	string
1498	en_US	abstract	<p>We study the direct product of automorphism groups of digraphs, where automorphism groups are considered as permutation groups acting on the sets of vertices. By a direct product of permutation groups <span class="math inline">(<em>A</em>, <em>V</em>) × (<em>B</em>, <em>W</em>)</span> we mean the group <span class="math inline">(<em>A</em> × <em>B</em>, <em>V</em> × <em>W</em>)</span> acting on the Cartesian product of the respective sets of vertices. We show that, except for the infinite family of permutation groups <span class="math inline"><em>S</em><sub><em>n</em></sub> × <em>S</em><sub><em>n</em></sub></span>, <span class="math inline"><em>n</em> ≥ 2</span>, and four other permutation groups, namely <span class="math inline"><em>D</em><sub>4</sub> × <em>S</em><sub>2</sub></span>, <span class="math inline"><em>D</em><sub>4</sub> × <em>D</em><sub>4</sub></span>, <span class="math inline"><em>S</em><sub>4</sub> × <em>S</em><sub>2</sub> × <em>S</em><sub>2</sub></span>, and <span class="math inline"><em>C</em><sub>3</sub> × <em>C</em><sub>3</sub></span>, the direct product of automorphism groups of two digraphs is itself the automorphism group of a digraph. In the course of the proof, for each set of conditions on the groups <span class="math inline"><em>A</em></span> and <span class="math inline"><em>B</em></span> that we consider, we indicate or build a specific digraph product that, when applied to the digraphs representing <span class="math inline"><em>A</em></span> and <span class="math inline"><em>B</em></span>, yields a digraph whose automorphism group is the direct product of <span class="math inline"><em>A</em></span> and <span class="math inline"><em>B</em></span>.</p>	string

1508	en_US	title	Block allocation of a sequential resource	string
1508	en_US	cleanTitle	Block allocation of a sequential resource	string
1508	en_US	abstract	<p>An <span class="math inline"><em>H</em></span>-packing of <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> is a collection of vertex-disjoint subgraphs of <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> such that each component is isomorphic to <span class="math inline"><em>H</em></span>. An <span class="math inline"><em>H</em></span>-packing of <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> is maximal if it cannot be extended to a larger <span class="math inline"><em>H</em></span>-packing of <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span>. In this paper we consider problem of random allocation of a sequential resource into blocks of <span class="math inline"><em>m</em></span> consecutive units and show how it can be successfully modeled in terms of maximal <span class="math inline"><em>P</em><sub><em>m</em></sub></span>-packings. We enumerate maximal <span class="math inline"><em>P</em><sub><em>m</em></sub></span>-packings of <span class="math inline"><em>P</em><sub><em>n</em></sub></span> of a given cardinality and determine the asymptotic behavior of the enumerating sequences. We also compute the expected size of <span class="math inline"><em>m</em></span>-packings and provide a lower bound on the efficiency of block-allocation.</p>	string

1510	en_US	title	The spectral characterizations of some graph	string
1510	en_US	cleanTitle	The spectral characterizations of some graph	string
1510	en_US	abstract	The main purpose of this study is to characterize new classes of graphs which are determined by their spectra. A multicone graph is defined to be the join of a clique and a regular graph. If n is a positive integer, a friendship graph Fn consists of n edge-disjoint triangles that all of them meet in one vertex. Let CP(n) and Kw denote a Cocktail-Party graph and a complete graph on w vertices, respectively and let m be a natural number. A graph is said to be DQS if there is no other non-isomorphic graph with the same signless Laplacian spectrum. In this work, it is proved that any connected graph cospectral to one of multicone graphs Kw ▽ mCP(n), a natural generalization of friendship graphs, is determined by its adjacency spectra as well as its Laplacian spectra. In addition, we prove that graphs cospectral to one of these multicone graphs must be perfect. For a DQS graph G, we show that G ∪ rK1,2 is DQS under certain conditions, where r and K1,2 denote a natural number and the bipartite complete graph on three vertices, respectively. Applying these results, some DQS graphs with r copies of K1,2 are obtained	string

1513	en_US	abstract	This paper presents a symbolic method for solving an initial value problem (IVP) for the system of higher-order linear differential equations (HLDEs) with constant coefficients. In the proposed symbolic method, we apply the algebra of integro-differential operators for computing the Green's operator and Green's function of a fully-inhomogeneous IVP on the level of operators. Th algorithm of the proposed method will help to implement the manual calculations in commercial packages such as Mathematica, Matlab, Singular, Scilab etc. Maple implementation of the proposed method is discussed and provided sample computations. Certain examples are presented to illustrate the proposed method.	string

1514	en_US	abstract	<p>The jump of the Milnor number of an isolated singularity f_0 is the minimal non-zero difference between the Milnor number of f_ 0 (a discrete invariant of f_0) and one of its deformation (f_s). 1516	en_US	abstract	<p>The inertia of a graph <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> is defined to be the triplet <span class="math inline">In(<em>G</em>) = (<em>p</em>(<em>G</em>), <em>n</em>(<em>G</em>), <em>η</em>(<em>G</em>))</span>, where <span class="math inline"><em>p</em>(<em>G</em>)</span>, <span class="math inline"><em>n</em>(<em>G</em>)</span> and <span class="math inline"><em>η</em>(<em>G</em>)</span> are the numbers of positive, negative and zero eigenvalues (including multiplicities) of the adjacency matrix <span class="math inline"><em>A</em>(<em>G</em>)</span>, respectively. 1517	en_US	abstract	<p>Let <span class="math inline"><em>A</em></span> be a <span class="math inline">(0, 1)</span>-matrix such that <span class="math inline"><em>P</em><em>A</em></span> is indecomposable for every permutation matrix <span class="math inline"><em>P</em></span> and there are <span class="math inline">2<em>n</em> + 3</span> positive entries in <span class="math inline"><em>A</em></span>. 1521	en_US	title	The cost number and the determining number of a graph	string
1521	en_US	cleanTitle	The cost number and the determining number of a graph	string
1521	en_US	abstract	The distinguishing number $D(G)$ of a graph $G$ is the least integer $d$ such that $G$ has an vertex labeling with $d$ labels that is preserved only by a trivial automorphism. The minimum size of a label class in such a labeling of $G$ with $D(G) = d$ is called the cost of $d$-distinguishing $G$ and is denoted  by $\\rho_d(G)$.<br />A set of vertices $S\\subseteq V(G)$ is a determining set for $G$ if every automorphism of $G$ is uniquely determined by its action on $S$. The determining number of $G$, ${\\rm Det}(G)$,  is the minimum cardinality of determining sets of $G$.  In this paper we obtain some general upper and lower bounds for $\\rho_d(G)$ based on ${\\rm Det}(G)$. Finally, we compute the cost and the determining number for the  friendship graphs and corona product of two graphs.	string

1524	en_US	abstract	<p>The energy of a digraph $D$ is defined as $E(D)=\\sum_{i=1}^{n}|Re(\\lambda_{r})|$, where $\\lambda_{1},\\lambda_{2},\\cdots,\\lambda_{n}$ are the<br />(possibly complex) eigenvalues of $D$. 1525	en_US	title	A characterization of graphs with disjoint total dominating sets	string
1525	en_US	cleanTitle	A characterization of graphs with disjoint total dominating sets	string
1525	en_US	abstract	<p>A set <span class="math inline"><em>S</em></span> of vertices in a graph <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> is a total dominating set of <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> if every vertex is adjacent to a vertex in <span class="math inline"><em>S</em></span>. A fundamental problem in total domination theory in graphs is to determine which graphs have two disjoint total dominating sets. In this paper, we solve this problem by providing a constructive characterization of the graphs that have two disjoint total dominating sets. Our characterization gives an entirely new description of graphs with two disjoint total dominating sets and places them in another context, developing them from four base graphs and applies a sequence of operations from seventeen operations that are independent and necessary to produce all such graphs. We show that every graph with two disjoint total dominating sets can be constructed using this method.</p>	string

1528	en_US	title	A family of multigraphs with large palette index	string
1528	en_US	cleanTitle	A family of multigraphs with large palette index	string
1528	en_US	abstract	Given a proper edge-coloring of a loopless multigraph, the palette of a vertex is defined as the set of colors of the edges which are incident with it. The palette index of a multigraph is defined as the minimum number of distinct palettes occurring among the vertices, taken over all proper edge-colorings of the multigraph itself. In this framework, the palette pseudograph of an edge-colored multigraph is defined in this paper and some of its properties are investigated. We show that these properties can be applied in a natural way in order to produce the first known family of multigraphs whose palette index is expressed in terms of the maximum degree by a quadratic polynomial. We also attempt an analysis of our result in connection with some related questions.	string

1530	en_US	abstract	It is known that the diameter of commuting graph of $n$-by-$n$ matrices is bounded above by six if the graph is connected.<br />In the commuting graph of $p^2$-by-$p^2$ matrices over a  sufficiently large field which admits a cyclic Galois extension of degree $p^2$ we construct  two matrices at distance<br />at least five. 1531	en_US	title	Capacity of Permutations	string
1531	en_US	cleanTitle	Capacity of Permutations	string
1531	en_US	abstract	Permutations of $[n]$ can be represented graphically as words over an alphabet $[n]$. The height of the $i$-th column in the word equals the size of the $i$-th part of the permutation. We define the notion of capacity in permutations of $[n]$ to be the amount of water such a word would retain if the region above it was a full container of water. Water is allowed to escape left and right if not contained. We let $C(n)$ be the capacity across all permutations of $[n]$; it is measured as the area of water in the plane. We obtain, in a unique manner, all permutations of $[n+1]$ from the permutations of $[n]$. This process yields a recursion for $C(n+1)$ in terms of $C(n)$ which we then solve. Finally we consider permutations that have a single dam (a single area of water) and compute the capacity for such permutations, as well as the total number of one-dam permutations.	string

1540	en_US	abstract	The decycling number $\\nabla (G)$  of a graph $G$ is the smallest number of vertices that have to be deleted from $G$ to obtain a forest.    Bau and Beineke studied  the dependency of decycling number of a graph on its connectivity. They proved that $\\kappa (G)\\leq \\nabla(G)+1$ holds for all graphs. In this paper,  we consider the relationship between $\\kappa (G)$ and $\\nabla(G)$,  and  establish  sufficient conditions for a graph $G$ with $\\kappa (G)= \\nabla(G)+1$  to be  Hamiltonian, pancyclic and edge-Hamilton, respectively.  As a matter of fact, forbidding large decycling sets could guarantee  the above three Hamilton properties  in graphs.	string

1544	en_US	title	A Short Note on Undirected Fitch Graphs	string
1544	en_US	cleanTitle	A Short Note on Undirected Fitch Graphs	string
1544	en_US	abstract	Fitch graphs have been introduced as a model of xenology relationships in phylogenomics. Directed Fitch graphs G=(X,E) are di-graphs that are explained by {0,1}-edge-labeled rooted trees with leaf set X: there is an arc xy\\in E if and only if the unique path in T that connects the least common ancestor lca(x,y) of x and y with $y$ contains at least one edge with label 1. In this contribution, we consider the undirected version of Fitch's xenology relation, in which x and y are xenologs if and only if the unique path between x and y in T contains an edge with label 1. We show that symmetric Fitch relations coincide with class of complete multipartite graph and thus cannot convey any non-trivial phylogenetic information.<br /><br />	string

1546	en_US	abstract	<p>A line-coloring of the finite affine space <span class="math inline"><em>A</em><em>G</em>(<em>n</em>, <em>q</em>)</span> is <em>proper</em> if any two lines from the same color class have no point in common, and it is <em>complete</em> if for any two different colors <span class="math inline"><em>i</em></span> and <span class="math inline"><em>j</em></span> there exist two intersecting lines, one is colored by <span class="math inline"><em>i</em></span> and the other is colored by <span class="math inline"><em>j</em>.</span> The pseudoachromatic index of <span class="math inline"><em>A</em><em>G</em>(<em>n</em>, <em>q</em>),</span> denoted by <span class="math inline"><em>ψ</em>′(<em>A</em><em>G</em>(<em>n</em>, <em>q</em>)), </span> is the maximum number of colors in any complete line-coloring of <span class="math inline"><em>A</em><em>G</em>(<em>n</em>, <em>q</em>).</span> When the coloring is also proper, the maximum number of colors is called the achromatic index of <span class="math inline"><em>A</em><em>G</em>(<em>n</em>, <em>q</em>).</span> We prove that <span class="math inline"><em>ψ</em>′(<em>A</em><em>G</em>(<em>n</em>, <em>q</em>)) ∼ <em>q</em><sup>1.5<em>n</em> − 1</sup></span> for even <span class="math inline"><em>n</em>,</span> and that <span class="math inline"><em>q</em><sup>1.5(<em>n</em> − 1)</sup> &lt; <em>ψ</em>′(<em>A</em><em>G</em>(<em>n</em>, <em>q</em>)) &lt; <em>q</em><sup>1.5<em>n</em> − 1</sup></span> for odd <span class="math inline"><em>n</em>.</span> Moreover, we prove that the achromatic index of <span class="math inline"><em>A</em><em>G</em>(<em>n</em>, <em>q</em>)</span> is <span class="math inline"><em>q</em><sup>1.5<em>n</em> − 1</sup></span> for even <span class="math inline"><em>n</em>,</span> and we provide the exact values of both indices in the planar case.</p>	string

1555	en_US	title	On smallest (generalized) ideals and semilattices of (2,2)-regular non-associative ordered semigroups	string
1555	en_US	cleanTitle	On smallest generalized ideals and semilattices of 22regular nonassociative ordered semigroups	string
1555	en_US	abstract	<p>An ordered AG-groupoid can be referred to as a non-associative<br />ordered semigroup, as the main di¤erence between an ordered semigroup and an<br />ordered AG-groupoid is the switching of an associative law. 1556	en_US	abstract	<pre>The <span>Hosoya</span> polynomial is a well known vertex-distance based polynomial, </pre><pre>closely correlated to the <span>Wiener</span> index and the hyper-<span>Wiener</span> index, which </pre><pre>are widely used molecular-structure descriptors. In the present paper we </pre><pre>consider the edge version of the <span>Hosoya</span> polynomial. For a connected graph </pre><pre><span>$G$</span> let <span>$d_e(G,k)$</span> be the number of (unordered) edge pairs at distance </pre><pre>$k$\\,. Then the edge-Hosoya polynomial of $G$ is $H_e(G,x) = </pre><pre>\\sum_{k \\geq 0} d(G,k)\\,x^k$\\,. We investigate the edge-Hosoya </pre><pre>polynomial of important chemical graphs known as benzenoid chains </pre><pre>and derive the recurrence relations for them. These recurrences are </pre><pre>then solved for linear benzenoid chains, which are also called </pre><pre>polyacenes.</pre>	string

1559	en_US	cleanTitle	A diagram associated with the subconstituent algebra of a distanceregular graph	string
1559	en_US	abstract	<p>In this paper we consider a distance-regular graph <span class="math inline">Γ</span>. Fix a vertex <span class="math inline"><em>x</em></span> of <span class="math inline">Γ</span> and consider the corresponding subconstituent algebra <span class="math inline"><em>T</em> = <em>T</em>(<em>x</em>)</span>. The algebra <span class="math inline"><em>T</em></span> is the <span class="math inline">ℂ</span>-algebra generated by the Bose-Mesner algebra <span class="math inline"><em>M</em></span> of <span class="math inline">Γ</span> and the dual Bose-Mesner algebra <span class="math inline"><em>M</em><sup>*</sup></span> of <span class="math inline">Γ</span> with respect to <span class="math inline"><em>x</em></span>. In our notation, <span class="math inline"><em>M</em><em>M</em><sup>*</sup></span> means <span class="math inline">Span{<em>R</em><em>S</em> ∣ <em>R</em> ∈ <em>M</em>, <em>S</em> ∈ <em>M</em><sup>*</sup>}</span>, and so on. We introduce a diagram that describes how these subspaces are related. We describe in detail that part of the diagram up to <span class="math inline"><em>M</em><em>M</em><sup>*</sup> + <em>M</em><sup>*</sup><em>M</em></span>. For each subspace <span class="math inline"><em>U</em></span> shown in this part of the diagram, we display an orthogonal basis for <span class="math inline"><em>U</em></span> along with the dimension of <span class="math inline"><em>U</em></span>. For an edge <span class="math inline"><em>U</em> ⊆ <em>W</em></span> from this part of the diagram, we display an orthogonal basis for the orthogonal complement of <span class="math inline"><em>U</em></span> in <span class="math inline"><em>W</em></span> along with the dimension of this orthogonal complement.</p>	string

1560	en_US	title	Tetrahedral and pentahedral cages for discs	string
1560	en_US	cleanTitle	Tetrahedral and pentahedral cages for discs	string
1560	en_US	abstract	<p>This paper is about cages for compact convex sets. A cage is the <span class="math inline">1</span>-skeleton of a convex polytope in <span class="math inline">ℝ<sup>3</sup></span>. A cage is said to hold a set if the set cannot be continuously moved to a distant location, remaining congruent to itself and disjoint from the cage.</p><p>In how many “truly different” positions can (compact <span class="math inline">2</span>-dimensional) discs be held by a cage? We completely answer this question for all tetrahedra. Moreover, we present pentahedral cages holding discs in a large number (<span class="math inline">57</span>) of positions.</p>	string

1561	en_US	abstract	The problem of classifying<br />equivalence classes of presentations up to isomorphism of Cayley<br />graphs is considered in this article in the case of dicyclic<br />groups. 1566	en_US	cleanTitle	The chromatic distinguishing index of certain graphs	string
1566	en_US	abstract	The distinguishing index of a graph $G$, denoted by $D'(G)$, is the<br />least number of labels in an edge labeling of $G$ not preserved by<br />any non-trivial automorphism.  The distinguishing chromatic index $\\chi'_D (G)$ of a graph $G$ is the least number $d$ such that $G$ has a proper edge labeling with $d$ labels that is preserved only by the identity automorphism of $G$. In this paper we compute the distinguishing chromatic index for some specific graphs.   Also we study the distinguishing chromatic index of corona product and join of two graphs.	string

1569	en_US	abstract	A (face-)primer hypermap is a regular oriented  hypermap whose<br /> group $G$ of the  orientation-preserving automorphisms  acts   faithfully  on its hyperfaces.<br />In this paper, we investigate    the primer hypermaps $\\HH$ such that   $G$   is nilpotent and the hypervertex-valency is a prime  $p$ (simply call them $PNp$ hypermaps).<br />We prove that $G$ is a finite $p$-group and the number of hyperfaces  of any $PNp$ hypermap is bounded by a function  of the nilpotent class  of  $G$.<br /> Moreover, we show that for any integer $c\\ge 1$, there is a unique  $PNp$ hypermap $\\HH_c$ of class $c$ attaining the bound and every other $PNp$ hypermap $\\HH$ of the class at most  $c$ is a quotient of $\\HH_c$,  see Theorem 1.1	string
