1570	en_US	title	Cycle extendability in circulants	string
1570	en_US	cleanTitle	Cycle extendability in circulants	string
1570	en_US	abstract	A graph $H$ is \\emph{cycle extendable} if it has at least one cycle and for every non-Hamiltonian cycle $C$ in $H$ there exists cycle $C'$ in $H$ such that $V(C) \\subseteq V(C')$ and $|V(C')| = |V(C)|+1$. In addition, if every vertex of $H$ is contained in a triangle then $H$ is \\emph{fully cycle extendable}.<br />Let $G = G_n(a_1,a_2, \\dots , a_k)$ be a circulant of order $n$ with jumps $a_1, a_2, \\dots , a_k$. We give the necessary and sufficient conditions for $G_n(a_1,a_2)$ (directed and undirected) to be cycle and fully cycle extendable. For $k \\ge 3$ we give several necessary conditions for undirected circulant $G$ to be cycle extendable. Finally, we prove that a connected directed $G_n(1 \\cdot a_1, 2 \\cdot a_1, \\dots , k \\cdot a_1)$ is fully cycle extendable for $k \\ge \\frac{n}{3}$, and a connected undirected $G_n(1 \\cdot a_1, 2 \\cdot a_1, \\dots , k \\cdot a_1)$  is fully cycle extendable for $k \\ge 3$.	string

1574	en_US	abstract	In this paper, we consider statistics on bargraphs. Our motivation comes from among the most popular game of all time Pac-Man. More precisely, we define a statistic pac which is the number cells in Pac-Man walk in a given bargraph. During its walks, we identify several types of moves. Here, we find a generating function formula for the statistics on bargraphs of n with m columns recording the number of walks of types rh, uv and lh. We also find an asymptotic/explicit formula for the total number of walks of either type in all bargraphs of n.	string

1578	en_US	title	Structural and computational results on platypus graphs	string
1578	en_US	cleanTitle	Structural and computational results on platypus graphs	string
1578	en_US	abstract	A <em>platypus graph</em> is a non-hamiltonian graph for which every vertex-deleted subgraph is traceable. They are closely related to families of graphs satisfying interesting conditions regarding longest paths and longest cycles, for instance hypohamiltonian, leaf-stable, and maximally non-hamiltonian graphs.<br /><br />In this paper, we first investigate cubic platypus graphs, covering all orders for which such graphs exist: in the general and polyhedral case as well as for snarks.<br />We then present (not necessarily cubic) platypus graphs of girth up to 16---whereas no hypohamiltonian graphs of girth greater than 7 are known---and study their maximum degree, generalising two theorems of Chartrand, Gould, and Kapoor. <br />Using computational methods, we determine the complete list of all non-isomorphic platypus graphs for various orders and girths.<br />Finally, we address two questions raised by the third author in [J. Graph Theory 86 (2017) 223--243].	string

1580	en_US	title	The  automorphism group  of the bipartite Kneser graph	string
1580	en_US	cleanTitle	The  automorphism group  of the bipartite Kneser graph	string
1580	en_US	abstract	<p>Let $n$ and $k$ are integers with $n&gt; k\\geq1$. We denote by $H(n, k)$ the bipartite Kneser<br />graph, that is, a graph with the family of $k$-subsets and ($n-k$)-subsets of $[n] = \\{1, 2, ... , n\\}$ as vertices, in which<br /> any two vertices are adjacent if and only if one of them is a subset of the other.<br />In this paper, we want to determine the automorphism group of $H(n, k)$. We show that $Aut(H(n, k))\\cong Sym([n]) \\times \\mathbb{Z}_2$ where $\\mathbb{Z}_2$ is the cyclic group of order $2$. Then, as an application of the obtained result, we give a new proof for determining the automorphism group of the Kneser graph $K(n,k)$. In fact, we show how we can have the automorphism group of the Kneser graph $K(n,k)$ in one hand, if we have the automorphism group of the Johnson graph $J(n,k)$ in another hand.</p>	string

1581	en_US	abstract	<p>There are many results on graphs with the smallest eigenvalue at least <span class="math inline">−2</span>. In order to study graphs with the eigenvalues at least <span class="math inline">−1 − √2</span>, R. Woo and A. Neumaier introduced Hoffman graphs and <span class="math inline">ℋ</span>-line graphs. They proved that a graph with the sufficiently large minimum degree and the smallest eigenvalue at least <span class="math inline">−1 − √2</span> is a slim <span class="math inline">{[<strong>h</strong><sub>2</sub>], [<strong>h</strong><sub>5</sub>], [<strong>h</strong><sub>7</sub>], [<strong>h</strong><sub>9</sub>]}</span>-line graph. 1582	en_US	title	Automorphism Groups of Walecki Tournaments with Zero and Odd Signatures	string
1582	en_US	cleanTitle	Automorphism Groups of Walecki Tournaments with Zero and Odd Signatures	string
1582	en_US	abstract	<p>Walecki tournaments were defined by Alspach in 1966. They form a class of regu-<br />lar tournaments that posses a natural Hamilton directed cycle decomposition. It has been conjectured by Kelly in 1964 that every regular tournament possesses such a decomposition. Therefore Walecki tournaments speak in favor of the conjecture. A second interest in Walecki tournaments arises from the mapping between cycles of the complementing circular shift register and isomorphism classes of Walecki tournaments. The problem of enumerating non-isomorphic Walecki tournaments has not been solved to date. We characterize the arc structure of Walecki tournaments whose corresponding binary sequences have zero and odd signature. Automorphism groups are determined for zero signature Walecki tournaments and for odd signature Walecki tournaments with the zero signature Walecki subtournaments.<br />Walecki tournaments possess a broad range of subtournaments isomorphic to some<br />Walecki tournament. Subtournaments of odd signature Walecki tournaments induced by the outsets of vertex t (0) are proven to be either regular or almost regular.</p>	string

1586	en_US	cleanTitle	Symmetry breaking in planar and maximal outerplanar graphs	string
1586	en_US	abstract	<p>The distinguishing number (index) $D(G)$ ($D'(G)$) of a graph $G$ is the least integer $d$ such that $G$ has a vertex (edge) labeling with $d$ labels that is preserved only by a trivial automorphism. In this paper we consider the maximal outerplanar graphs (MOP graphs) and show that MOP graphs, except $K_3$, can be distinguished by at most two vertex (edge) labels. We also compute the distinguishing number and the distinguishing index of Halin and Mycielskian graphs.</p>	string

1589	en_US	title	Metric dimension of Cayley digraphs of metacyclic groups	string
1589	en_US	cleanTitle	Metric dimension of Cayley digraphs of metacyclic groups	string
1589	en_US	abstract	A directed Cayley graph $Cay(\\Gamma,X)$ is specified by a group $\\Gamma$ and an identity-free generating set $X$ for this group. Vertices of $Cay(\\Gamma,X)$ are elements of $\\Gamma$ and there is a directed edge from the vertex $u$ to the vertex $v$ in $Cay(\\Gamma,X)$ if and only if there is a generator $x \\in X$ such that $ux = v$. We study the metric dimension for directed Cayley graphs of general metacyclic groups and we present exact values of the metric dimension of directed Cayley graphs $Cay(\\Gamma_s,\\{a,b\\})$ for metacyclic groups $\\Gamma_s=\\langle a,b \\ | \\ a^n=b^{2s}=1,ba=a^{-1}b\\rangle$.	string

1590	en_US	title	Characterization of finite metric space By their isometric sequences	string
1590	en_US	cleanTitle	Characterization of finite metric space By their isometric sequences	string
1590	en_US	abstract	Let $(X,d)$ be a finite metric space with $|X|=n$.<p style="margin: 0px; text-indent: 0px; -qt-block-indent: 0;">For a positive integer $k$ we define $A_k(X)$ to be the quotient set of all $k$-subsets of $X$</p><p style="margin: 0px; text-indent: 0px; -qt-block-indent: 0;">by isometry, and we denote $|A_k(X)|$ by $a_k$.</p><p style="margin: 0px; text-indent: 0px; -qt-block-indent: 0;">The sequence $(a_1,a_2,\\ldots,a_{n})$ is called the \\textit{isometric} sequence of $(X,d)$.</p><p style="margin: 0px; text-indent: 0px; -qt-block-indent: 0;">In this article we aim to characterize finite metric spaces by their isometric sequences</p><p style="margin: 0px; text-indent: 0px; -qt-block-indent: 0;">under one of the following assumptions: (i) $a_k=1$ for some $k$ with $2\\leq k\\leq n-2$;</p><p style="margin: 0px; text-indent: 0px; -qt-block-indent: 0;">(ii) $a_k=2$ for some $k$ with $4\\leq k\\leq \\frac{1+\\sqrt{1+4n}}{2}$;</p><p style="margin: 0px; text-indent: 0px; -qt-block-indent: 0;">(iii) $a_3=2$; (iv) $a_2=a_3=3$. Furthermore, we give some criterion on how to embed such finite metric spaces to Euclidean spaces.</p><p style="margin: 0px; text-indent: 0px; -qt-block-indent: 0;">We give some maximum cardinalities of subsets in the $d$-dimensional Euclidean space with small $a_3$, which are analogue problems on a sets with few distinct triangles discussed by</p><p style="margin: 0px; text-indent: 0px; -qt-block-indent: 0;">Epstein, Lott, Miller and Palsson.</p>	string

1591	en_US	title	On the domination number and the total domination number of Fibonacci cubes	string
1591	en_US	cleanTitle	On the domination number and the total domination number of Fibonacci cubes	string
1591	en_US	abstract	Fibonacci cubes are special subgraphs of the hypercube graphs. Their domination numbers and total domination numbers are obtained for some small dimensions by integer linear programming. For larger dimensions upper and lower bounds on these numbers are given. In this paper, we present the up-down degree polynomials for Fibonacci cubes containing the degree information of all vertices in more detail. Using these polynomials we define optimization problems whose solutions give better lower bounds on the domination numbers and total domination numbers of Fibonacci cubes. Furthermore, we present better upper bounds on these numbers.	string

1593	en_US	title	Order Graph: A new representation of finite groups	string
1593	en_US	cleanTitle	Order Graph: A new representation of finite groups	string
1593	en_US	abstract	<p dir="LTR">There are many ways to associate a graph with a finite group. Such  an association declares many of the group properties. The link established  between a graph and a group, is usually determined by the definition of the adjacent vertices. In this research, the elements orders will take a place in the graph creation. The order graph of a finite group is the directed graph whose vertices are the elements of the group order classes, and for two distinct vertices x and y there is an arc from x to y if and only if x divides y. This research will interest on the creation of the order graph in general, then study  this topic for some groups.</p>	string

1597	en_US	title	Smallest non-dismantlable posets with contractible order complexes	string
1597	en_US	cleanTitle	Smallest nondismantlable posets with contractible order complexes	string
1597	en_US	abstract	We apply the theory of finite topological spaces to characterize the non-dismantlable posets of minimum cardinality such that the geometric realization of their order complexes are contractible. This is equivalent to finding finite topological spaces of minimum cardinality which are weakly contractible but not contractible. Specifically, we prove that all weakly contractible topological spaces with fewer than nine points are contractible. We also prove that there exist (up to homeomorphism) exactly two topological spaces of nine points which are weakly contractible but not contractible.	string

1599	en_US	title	Distance Laplacian spectra of graphs obtained by generalization of join and lexicographic product	string
1599	en_US	cleanTitle	Distance Laplacian spectra of graphs obtained by generalization of join and lexicographic product	string
1599	en_US	abstract	<p>The distance Laplacian matrix of a simple connected graph $G$ is defined as $D^L(G) = T r(G)−D(G),$ where $D(G)$ is the distance matrix of $G$ and $T r(G)$ is the diagonal matrix whose main diagonal entries are the vertex transmissions in $G.$ In this article, we determine the distance Laplacian spectra of the graphs obtained by generalization of the join and lexicographic product of graphs (namely joined union). It is shown that the distance Laplacian spectra of these graphs not<br />only depend on the distance Laplacian spectra of the participating graphs but also depend on the spectrum of another matrix of vertex-weighted Laplacian kind (analogous to the definition given by Chung and Langlands [F.R.K. 1600	en_US	title	The chemical trees with maximum Wiener polarity index	string
1600	en_US	cleanTitle	The chemical trees with maximum Wiener polarity index	string
1600	en_US	abstract	The Wiener polarity index (appeared in 1947 within the study of paraffins' boiling points and usually denoted by $W_p$) of a chemical graph $G$ is defined as the number of unordered pairs of those vertices of $G$ which are at distance $3$. Deng [On the extremal Wiener polarity index of chemical trees, \\textit{MATCH Commun. Math. Comput. Chem.} 66 (2011) 305--314] proved that the maximum $W_p$ value in the collection of all $n$-vertex chemical trees is $3n+15$. The main purpose of present paper is to determine all the $n$-vertex chemical trees which attain maximum $W_p$ value (that is $3n+15$).	string

1601	en_US	title	Smallest snarks with oddness 4 and cyclic connectivity 4 have order 44	string
1601	en_US	cleanTitle	Smallest snarks with oddness 4 and cyclic connectivity 4 have order 44	string
1601	en_US	abstract	<p>The family of snarks – connected bridgeless cubic graphs that cannot be <span class="math inline">3</span>-edge-coloured – is well-known as a potential source of counterexamples to several important and long-standing conjectures in graph theory. These include the cycle double cover conjecture, Tutte’s <span class="math inline">5</span>-flow conjecture, Fulkerson’s conjecture, and several others. One way of approaching these conjectures is through the study of structural properties of snarks and construction of small examples with given properties. In this paper we deal with the problem of determining the smallest order of a nontrivial snark (that is, one which is cyclically <span class="math inline">4</span>-edge-connected and has girth at least <span class="math inline">5</span>) of oddness at least <span class="math inline">4</span>. Using a combination of structural analysis with extensive computations we prove that the smallest order of a snark with oddness at least <span class="math inline">4</span> and cyclic connectivity <span class="math inline">4</span> is <span class="math inline">44</span>. Formerly it was known that such a snark must have at least <span class="math inline">38</span> vertices and one such snark on <span class="math inline">44</span> vertices was constructed by Lukoťka, Máčajová, Mazák and Škoviera in 2015. The proof requires determining all cyclically <span class="math inline">4</span>-edge-connected snarks on <span class="math inline">36</span> vertices, which extends the previously compiled list of all such snarks up to <span class="math inline">34</span> vertices. As a by-product, we use this new list to test the validity of several conjectures where snarks can be smallest counterexamples.</p>	string

1605	en_US	title	The dimension of the negative cycle vectors of a signed graph	string
1605	en_US	cleanTitle	The dimension of the negative cycle vectors of a signed graph	string
1605	en_US	abstract	A <em>signed graph</em> is a graph Γ with edges labeled “+” and “−”. The sign of a cycle is the product of its edge signs. Let SpecC(Γ) denote the list of lengths of cycles in Γ. We equip each signed graph with a vector whose entries are the numbers of negative <em>k</em>-cycles for <em>k</em> ∈ SpecC(Γ). These vectors generate a subspace of ℝ<sup>|SpecC(Γ)|</sup>. Using matchings with a strong permutability property, we provide lower bounds on the dimension of this space; in particular, we show for complete graphs, complete bipartite graphs, and a few other graphs that this space is all of ℝ<sup>|SpecC(Γ)|</sup>.	string

1606	en_US	title	A Short Note on Undirected Fitch Graphs	string
1606	en_US	cleanTitle	A Short Note on Undirected Fitch Graphs	string
1606	en_US	abstract	Fitch graphs have been introduced as a model of xenology<br />      relationships in phylogenomics. Directed Fitch graphs $G=(X,E)$ are<br />    di-graphs that are explained by $\\{0,1\\}$-edge-labeled rooted trees<br />    with leaf set $X$: there is an arc $xy\\in E$ if and only if the unique<br />    path in $T$ that connects the least common ancestor $\\lca(x,y)$ of $x$<br />    and $y$ with $y$ contains at least one edge with label $1$. In this<br />    contribution, we consider the undirected version of Fitch's xenology<br />    relation, in which $x$ and $y$ are xenologs if and only if the<br />    unique path between $x$ and $y$ in $T$ contains an edge with label $1$.<br />    We show that symmetric Fitch relations coincide with class of complete<br />  multipartite graph and thus cannot convey any non-trivial phylogenetic<br />  information.<br /><br />	string

1607	en_US	abstract	Let $G=(V,E)$ be a finite and simple graph with $\\lambda_1, \\lambda_2, \\dots,  \\lambda_n$ as its eigenvalues.<br />The Estrada index of $G$ is $EE(G)=\\sum_{i=1}^{n}e^{\\lambda_{i}}$. For a positive integer $k$, a connected graph<br />$G$ is called strict $k$-quasi tree if there exists a set $U$ of vertices of size $k$ such that<br />$G \\setminus U$ is a tree and  this is as small as possible with this property. In this paper, we define point<br />attaching strict $k$-quasi tree graphs and obtain the graph with minimum Estrada index among point attaching<br />strict $k$-quasi tree graphs with $k$ even cycles.	string

1608	en_US	title	Axiomatic Characterization of Transit Functions ofWeak Hierarchies	string
1608	en_US	cleanTitle	Axiomatic Characterization of Transit Functions ofWeak Hierarchies	string
1608	en_US	abstract	<p>Transit functions provide a unified approach to study notions of intervals, convexities, and betweenness. Recently, their scope has been extended to certain set systems associated with clustering. We characterize here the class of set systems that correspond to k-ary monotonic transit functions. Convexities form a subclass and are characterized in terms<br />of transit functions by two additional axioms. We then focus on axiom systems associated with weak hierarchies as well as other generalizations of hierarchical set systems.</p><p> </p>	string

1610	en_US	title	On the Hamilton-Waterloo problem: the case of two cycles sizes of different parity	string
1610	en_US	cleanTitle	On the HamiltonWaterloo problem: the case of two cycles sizes of different parity	string
1610	en_US	abstract	<p>The Hamilton-Waterloo problem asks for a decomposition of the complete graph of order <span class="math inline"><em>v</em></span> into <span class="math inline"><em>r</em></span> copies of a <span class="math inline">2</span>-factor <span class="math inline"><em>F</em><sub>1</sub></span> and <span class="math inline"><em>s</em></span> copies of a <span class="math inline">2</span>-factor <span class="math inline"><em>F</em><sub>2</sub></span> such that <span class="math inline"><em>r</em> + <em>s</em> = ⌊(<em>v</em> − 1) / 2⌋</span>. If <span class="math inline"><em>F</em><sub>1</sub></span> consists of <span class="math inline"><em>m</em></span>-cycles and <span class="math inline"><em>F</em><sub>2</sub></span> consists of <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span> cycles, we say that a solution to <span class="math inline">(<em>m</em>, <em>n</em>)</span>-<span class="math inline">HWP(<em>v</em>; <em>r</em>, <em>s</em>)</span> exists. The goal is to find a decomposition for every possible pair <span class="math inline">(<em>r</em>, <em>s</em>)</span>. In this paper, we show that for odd <span class="math inline"><em>x</em></span> and <span class="math inline"><em>y</em></span>, there is a solution to <span class="math inline">(2<sup><em>k</em></sup><em>x</em>, <em>y</em>)</span>-<span class="math inline">HWP(<em>v</em><em>m</em>; <em>r</em>, <em>s</em>)</span> if <span class="math inline">gcd (<em>x</em>, <em>y</em>) ≥ 3</span>, <span class="math inline"><em>m</em> ≥ 3</span>, and both <span class="math inline"><em>x</em></span> and <span class="math inline"><em>y</em></span> divide <span class="math inline"><em>v</em></span>, except possibly when <span class="math inline">1 ∈ {<em>r</em>, <em>s</em>}</span>.</p>	string

1611	en_US	title	Connectedness of the generalized order graphs of finite groups	string
1611	en_US	cleanTitle	Connectedness of the generalized order graphs of finite groups	string
1611	en_US	abstract	Let $G$ be a finite group and let $o(g)$ denote the order of $g\\in G$. The generalized order graph $\\Gamma (G)$ of $G$ is defined as the graph with vertex set $G$ such that two distinct vertices $x$ and $y$ are adjacent in $\\Gamma (G)$ if $o(x)$ divides $o(y)$ or $o(y)$ divides $o(x)$. We show that the generalized order graph $\\Gamma(G)$ is $3$-connected when $G$ is a finite abelian group of order at least $4$ but not necessarily $3$-connected for finite groups in general.	string

1612	en_US	title	Hirano clean matrices over local rings	string
1612	en_US	cleanTitle	Hirano clean matrices over local rings	string
1612	en_US	abstract	<p>An element $a$ in a ring $R$ is Hirano clean if there exists $p^3=p\\in comm^2(a)$ such that $a+p\\in U(R)$.<br />In this paper, we completely determine when a $2\\times 2$ matrix over a local ring is Hirano clean. Generalized Drazin inverses of matrices over local rings are thereby characterized by means of tripotents. An element $a$ in a ring $R$ is Hirano J-polar if there exists $p^3=p\\in comm^2(a)$ such that $(a+p)^k\\in J(R)$ for some $k\\in {\\Bbb N}$. Hirao J-polar elements form a subclass of Hirano clean elements in a ring. Moreover, the complete characterizations of Hirano J-polar $2\\times 2$ matrices over local rings are obtained.</p>	string

1613	en_US	title	On Distance--Based Graph Invariants	string
1613	en_US	cleanTitle	On DistanceBased Graph Invariants	string
1613	en_US	abstract	<p>Let $G$ be a simple connected graph of order $n$ with $m$ edges and diameter $d$. Let $W$, $WW$, $H$, and $RCW$ be the Wiener index, hyper-Wiener index,<br />Harary index, and reciprocal complementary Wiener index of $G$. The multiplicative<br />version of Wiener index ($\\pi$-index) is equal to the product of the distances between all pairs of vertices. We compare $H$ and $RCW$. For bipartite graph of order $n&gt;5$, we prove that $\\pi&gt;2\\,WW$. In any connected graph, if $d\\geq 4$ and $m\\leq \\frac{285\\,W-6624}{287}$, then $\\pi \\geq 2\\,WW$. Some additional relations between $W$, $WW$, $H$, and $RCW$ are also obtained.</p>	string

1615	en_US	title	4-edge-connected 4-regular maps on the projective plane	string

1615	en_US	abstract	<p>In this paper rooted (near-)<span class="math inline">4</span>-regular maps on the projective plane are investigated with respect to the root-valency, the number of edges, the number of inner faces, the number of nonroot-vertex-loops and the number of separating cycles. In particular, <span class="math inline">4</span>-edge connected <span class="math inline">4</span>-regular maps (which are related to the <span class="math inline">3</span>-flow conjecture by Tutte) are handled. Formulae of several types of rooted <span class="math inline">4</span>-edge-connected <span class="math inline">4</span>-regular maps on the projective plane are presented. Several known results on the number of <span class="math inline">4</span>-regular maps on the projective plane are also derived. Finally, using Darboux’s method, a nice asymptotic formula for the numbers of this type of maps is given which implies that almost every (loopless) <span class="math inline">4</span>-regular map on the projective plane has a separating cycle.</p>	string

1617	en_US	abstract	For a (molecular) graph $G$, the atom--bond connectivity index ($ABC$) of $G$ is defined as $ABC(G)=\\sum_{uv \\in E(G)} \\sqrt{\\frac{d(u)+d(v)-2}{d(u) d(v)}}$, where $d(v)$ denotes the degree of vertex $v$ of $G$. 1618	en_US	abstract	<p>Let $R$ be a Noetherian $\\mathbb{Q}$-algebra ($\\mathbb{Q}$ is the<br />field of rational numbers). Let $\\sigma$ and $\\tau$ be automorphisms<br />of $R$ and $\\delta$ be a $(\\sigma, \\tau)$- derivation of $R$. 1622	en_US	abstract	<p>We consider matchings between a set R of red points and a set B of blue points with diametral disks. 1633	en_US	title	Equitable total coloring of corona of cubic graphs	string
1633	en_US	cleanTitle	Equitable total coloring of corona of cubic graphs	string
1633	en_US	abstract	<p>The minimum number of total independent partition sets of $V \\cup E$ of a graph $G=(V,E)$ is called the \\emph{total chromatic number} of $G$, denoted by $\\chi''(G)$. If the difference between cardinalities of any<br />two total independent sets is at most one, then the minimum number of total independent partition sets of $V \\cup E$ is called the \\emph{equitable total chromatic number}, and is denoted by $\\chi''_=(G)$.<br /> <br />In this paper we consider equitable total coloring of coronas of cubic graphs, $G \\circ H$. It turns out that, independly on the values of equitable total <br />chromatic number of factors $G$ and $H$, equitable total chromatic number of corona $G \\circ H$ is equal to $\\Delta(G \\circ H) +1$. Thereby, we confirm Total Coloring <br />Conjecture (TCC), posed by Behzad in 1964,<br />and Equitable Total Coloring Conjecture (ETCC), posed by Wang in 2002, for coronas of cubic graphs.<br />As a direct consequence we get that all coronas of cubic graphs are of Type 1.</p>	string

1636	en_US	abstract	<p>Let $G$ be a simple graph, and $G^\\sigma$ be an oriented graph of $G$<br />with the orientation $\\sigma$ and skew-adjacency matrix $S(G^\\sigma)$. Let $\\lambda_1(G^\\sigma), \\lambda_2(G^\\sigma), \\cdots ,<br />\\lambda_n(G^\\sigma)$ be the eigenvalues of $S(G^\\sigma)$. The number<br /> $\\sum_{i=1}^{n}\\lambda_i^k(G^\\sigma)$ $(k=0,1,\\ldots,n-1)$, denoted by $T_k(G^\\sigma)$, is called the<br />$k$-th {\\em skew spectral moment} of $G^\\sigma$,<br />and $T(G^\\sigma)=(T_0(G^\\sigma),T_1(G^\\sigma),\\ldots,T_{n-1}(G^\\sigma))$ is the sequence of skew spectral<br />moments of $G^\\sigma$. Suppose $G_1^{\\sigma_1}$ and $G_2^{\\sigma_2}$ are two digraphs. We shall write<br />$G_1^{\\sigma_1}\\prec_T G_2^{\\sigma_2}$ ($G_1$ comes before $G_2$ in a<br />$T$-order) if for some $k$$(1 \\leq k \\leq n-1)$, $T_i(G_1^{\\sigma_1})=T_i(G_2^{\\sigma_2})$ ($i=0,1,\\ldots,k-1$) and<br />$T_k(G_1^{\\sigma_1})&lt; T_k(G_2^{\\sigma_2})$ hold.<br />In this paper, we order some kinds of oriented trees and oriented unicyclic graphs, in a $T$-order, we get the last 2$\\lfloor\\frac{d}{4}\\rfloor$ oriented trees with underlying graph of diameter $d$ and the last 2$\\lfloor\\frac{g}{4}\\rfloor+1$ oriented unicyclic graphs with underlying graph of girth $g$, respectively.</p>	string

1638	en_US	abstract	<p>Temporal logic is of importance in theoretical computer science for its application in formal verification, to state requirements of hardware<br />or software systems. Linear temporal logic is an appropriate logical<br />environment to formalize Yablo’s paradox which is seemingly non-self-referential and basically has a sequential structure. We give a brief<br />review on Yablo’s paradox and its various versions. Formalization of<br />these paradoxes yields some theorems in Linear Temporal Logic (LTL)<br />for which we give syntactic proofs using an appropriate axiomatization<br />of LTL.</p>	string

1647	en_US	abstract	<p>A subset D of a simple graph G = (V;E) is called a dominating<br />set of G if for every vertex u in V-D, there exists v in D such that<br />u and v are adjacent. Several types of domination have been intro-<br />duced. There<br />are two fundamental varieties of domination namely, domination de-<br />ned by its nature and domination dened interms of some property<br />of the subgraph induced by the dominating set. 1649	en_US	cleanTitle	The decycle number of Halin graphs	string
1649	en_US	abstract	<p>For a graph $G$, write $\\nabla(G)$ as the decycling<br />number of $G$ and $c(G)$ as the maximum number of vertex-disjoint cycles of $G$.<br />It is proved in this paper that $\\nabla(G)\\leq 2c(G)$. For a Halin<br />graph $G$, it is called lower extremal if $\\nabla(G)=c(G)$ and upper-extremal if<br />$\\nabla(G)=2c(G)$. These two classed graphs are characterized in this paper. Furthermore, we construct<br /> a sequence Halin graphs $G_0,G_1,\\cdots, G_{2c(G)-1}$ such that $\\nabla(G_i)=c(G)+i$, where<br />$0\\leq i\\leq 2c(G)-1$.</p>	string

1650	en_US	title	On the connectivity Waiter-Client game	string
1650	en_US	cleanTitle	On the connectivity WaiterClient game	string
1650	en_US	abstract	<p>In this short note we consider a variation of the connectivity Waiter-Client game $WC(G,q,\\mathcal{C})$ played on an $n$-vertex graph $G$ which consists of $q+1$ disjoint spanning trees. In this game in each round Waiter offers Client $q+1$ edges of $G$ which have not yet been offered. Client chooses one edge and the remaining $q$ edges are discarded. The aim of Waiter is to force Client to build a connected graph. If this happens Waiter wins. Otherwise Client is the winner. We consider the case where $2 &lt; q+1 &lt; \\lfloor \\frac{n-1}{2}\\rfloor$ and show that for each such $q$ there exists a graph $G$ for which Client has a winning strategy. This result stands in opposition to the case where $G$ consists of just 2 spanning trees or where $G$ is a complete graph, since it has been shown that for such graphs Waiter can always force Client to build a connected graph.</p>	string
1650	en_US	discipline		string
1650	en_US	subjectClass	91A43	string
1650	en_US	subject	positional games, Picker-Chooser game, Waiter-Client game, connectivity	string

1652	en_US	title	Advances in the semi-local convergence of Newton's method	string
1652	en_US	cleanTitle	Advances in the semilocal convergence of Newton's method	string
1652	en_US	abstract	The aim of this paper is to present a new semi-local convergence analysis for Newton's method in a Banach space setting. The novelty of this paper is that by using more precise Lipschitz constants than in earlier studies and our new idea of restricted convergence domains, we extend the applicability of Newton's method as follows: the convergence domain is extended; the error estimates are tighter and the information on the location of the solution is at least as precise as before. These advantages are obtained using the same information as before, since new Lipschitz constant are tighter and special cases of the ones used before. Numerical examples further justify the theoretical results.	string

1653	en_US	title	Super Complementary Domination in Graphs	string
1653	en_US	cleanTitle	Super Complementary Domination in Graphs	string
1653	en_US	abstract	Let G = (V, E) be a simple, finite and undirected graph. A non-empty subset D of V(G) is called a dominating set of G if for any vertex u in V (G) − D, there exists a vertex v in D such that u and v are adjacent. There are several types of domination depending on the nature of domination or the nature of the dominating set. In this paper, a new type of domination namely, Super complementary domination is defined and its properties are studied. A new parameter called Super complementary domination number is defined and its value is determined for some well-known graphs. Trees with super complementary domination number having the value half of the order of the tree are characterized.	string

1654	en_US	title	The minimum degree sum of bigraphic pairs with an $A$-connected realization	string
1654	en_US	cleanTitle	The minimum degree sum of bigraphic pairs with an Aconnected realization	string
1654	en_US	abstract	<p>Let $S=(a_1,\\dots,a_m;b_1,\\dots,b_n)$,<br />where $a_1,\\dots,a_m$ and $b_1,\\dots,b_n$ are two nonincreasing<br />sequences of nonnegative integers. The pair<br />$S=(a_1,\\dots,a_m;b_1,\\dots,b_n)$ is said to be a {\\it bigraphic<br />pair} if there is a simple bipartite graph $G=(X\\cup Y,E)$ such that<br />$a_1,\\dots,a_m$ and $b_1,\\dots,b_n$ are the degrees of the vertices<br />in $X$ and $Y$, respectively. Let $A$ be an (additive) Abelian<br />group. We define $\\sigma(A,m,n)$ to be the minimum integer $k$ such<br />that every bigraphic pair $S=(a_1,\\dots,a_m; b_1,\\dots,b_n)$ with<br />$a_m,b_n\\ge 2$ and $\\sigma(S)=a_1+\\cdots +a_m\\ge k$ has an<br />$A$-connected realization. In this paper, we determine the values of<br />$\\sigma(A,m,n)$ for $|A|=k$ and $m\\ge n\\ge2$, where $k\\ge6$ is an<br />even integer, and the values of $\\sigma(A,m,n)$ for $|A|=4$ and<br />$m\\ge n\\ge 3$. Therefore, the values of $\\sigma(A,m,n)$ for $|A|\\ge<br />3$ are determined completely.</p>	string

1656	en_US	title	on the thickness of some complete tripartite graphs	string
1656	en_US	cleanTitle	on the thickness of some complete tripartite graphs	string
1656	en_US	abstract	<p>We know very little about the thickness of the complete tripartite graphs. In this paper, two planar decompositions for $K_{1,g,g(g-1)}$ when $g$ is even and for $K_{1,g,\\frac{1}{2}(g-1)^2}$ when $g$ is odd are obtained. Using a recursive construction, we also obtain the thickness for some complete tripartite graphs. The results here also imply that the thickness of $K_{s,t}$ is $\\left\\lceil\\frac{st}{2(s+t-2)}\\right\\rceil$ for odd $s$ and $t&gt;\\frac{(s-3)(s-2)}{3},$ which support a folklore conjecture on the thickness of all complete bipartite graphs.</p>	string

1657	en_US	abstract	<p>The number of ways to place <span class="math inline"><em>q</em></span> nonattacking queens, bishops, or similar chess pieces on an <span class="math inline"><em>n</em> × <em>n</em></span> square chessboard is essentially a quasipolynomial function of <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span> (by Part I of this series). The period of the quasipolynomial is difficult to settle. Here we prove that the empirically observed period <span class="math inline">2</span> for three to ten bishops is the exact period for every number of bishops greater than <span class="math inline">2</span>. 1658	en_US	title	Arithmetic of triangles	string
1658	en_US	cleanTitle	Arithmetic of triangles	string
1658	en_US	abstract	<p>In this paper we consider a set of similar triangles with parallel sides together<br />with a set of points of the plane. Each element of such a set, denoted<br />by R2, is described by an ordered pair of numbers (if we want to describe<br />the triangles with regard to its sides and vertices, we need an ordered three<br />numbers). The set R2 has an algebraic structure with two operations. The<br />multiplication is binary while the addition is three-argument and describes a<br />homothety and a translation of elements of the set R2 simultaneously. Depending<br />on the size of the arguments of the addition we have six kinds of<br />geometric interpretations of such sums. 2006	en_US	cleanTitle	Simultaneous current graph constructions for minimum triangulations and complete graph embeddings	string
2006	en_US	abstract	<p>The problems of calculating the genus of the complete graphs and of finding a minimum triangulation for each surface were both solved using the theory of current graphs, and each of them divided into twelve different cases, depending on the residue modulo <span class="math inline">12</span> of the number of vertices. Cases <span class="math inline">8</span> and <span class="math inline">11</span> were of particular difficulty for both problems, with multiple families of current graphs developed to solve these cases. We solve these cases, in addition to Cases <span class="math inline">6</span> and <span class="math inline">9</span>, in a unified manner, greatly simplifying previous constructions by Ringel, Youngs, Guy, and Jungerman. All these new constructions are index <span class="math inline">3</span> current graphs sharing nearly all of the structure of the simple solution for Case <span class="math inline">5</span> of the Map Color Theorem.</p>	string

1673	en_US	abstract	<p>A Riemann surface $\\mathcal{S}$ having field of moduli $\\mathbb{R}$, but not a field of definition, is called \\emph{pseudoreal}. This means that $\\mathcal{S}$ has anticonformal automorphisms, but non of them is an involution. We call a Riemann surface $\\mathcal{S}$ \\emph{plane} if it can be described by a smooth plane model of some degree $d\\geq4$ in $\\mathbb{P}^2_{\\mathbb{C}}$.</p><p>We characterize pseudoreal-plane Riemann surfaces $\\mathcal{S}$, whose conformal automorphism group $\\operatorname{Aut}_+(\\mathcal{S})$ is $\\operatorname{PGL}_3(\\mathbb{C})$-conjugate to a finite non-trivial group $G$ that leaves invariant infinitely many points of $\\mathbb{P}^2_{\\mathbb{C}}$. In particular, we show that such pseudoreal-plane Riemann surfaces exist only if $\\operatorname{Aut}_+(\\mathcal{S})$ is cyclic of even order $n$ dividing the degree $d$; Theorems 3.10, 3.11 and 3.20. Explicit families of pseudoreal-plane Riemann surfaces are given, for any degree $d=2pm$ with $m&gt;1$ odd, $p$ is prime and $n=d/p$; Example 3.14 and Theorem 3.15.</p>	string

1674	en_US	abstract	<p>For a graph $G=(V, E)$, a Roman \\{2\\}-dominating function $f:V\\rightarrow \\{0,1,2\\}$ has the property that $\\sum_{u\\in N(v)}f(u)\\geq 2$ for<br />every vertex $v\\in V$ with $f(v)= 0$, where $N(v)$ is the set of neighbors of $v$ in $G$. The weight of a Roman \\{2\\}-dominating function $f$ is the sum $\\sum_{v\\in V}f(v)$ and the minimum weight of a Roman \\{2\\}-dominating function is the Roman \\{2\\}-domination number. In this paper, we prove that any maximal outerplanar graph $G$ has Roman \\{2\\}-domination number at most $4|V(G)|/7$. Moreover, we give improved bounds on some special classes of maximal outerplanar graphs.</p>	string

1675	en_US	abstract	<p>The cyclic chromatic number $\\chi_c(G)$ of a plane graph $G$ is the smallest integer $k$ for which $G$ admits a proper vertex coloring using $k$ colors such that any two vertices incident with the same face receive distinct colors. The {\\bf Cyclic Coloring Conjecture} asserts that every plane graph $G$ with maximum face degree $\\Delta^*$ satisfies<br /> $\\chi_c(G)\\le \\lfloor\\frac{3}{2}\\Delta^{*}\\rfloor$. This conjecture has been confirmed for plane graphs with $\\Delta^{*}=3,4,6$. In this paper, we show that every plane subcubic graph $G$ with $\\Delta^{*}=5$ has<br /> $\\chi_c(G)\\le 7$, and moreover $\\chi_c(G)=7$ if and only if $G$ is one of three specific graphs.</p>	string

1679	en_US	abstract	<p>We define a bijection between permutations and valued Dyck paths, namely, Dyck paths whose odd vertices are labelled with an integer that does not exceed their height. 1683	en_US	title	On Z-orientabilty and square roots of meromorphic maps	string
1683	en_US	cleanTitle	On Zorientabilty and square roots of meromorphic maps	string
1683	en_US	abstract	The notion of Z-orientability, originally stated by Zapponi for the case of $2$-cell decompositions of surfaces, is generalized for triples $(\\Gamma,K,P)$, where $K$ is a $n$-dimensional Kleinian group with fundamental polyhedron $P$ and $\\Gamma$ is a proper subgroup of $K$. To be more precise, the $K$-translates of $P$ induce an $n$-cell decomposition for the $n$-dimensional orbifold uniformized by $\\Gamma$. If the faces of such a decomposition may be labelled using two labels such that adjacent ones have different labels, then we say that $\\Gamma$ is Z-orientable with respect to $(K,P)$. Necessary and sufficient conditions are provided for this to happen. We use this notion to provide a geometrical necessary and sufficient condition for a non-constant surjective meromorphic map $\\varphi:S \\to \\widehat{\\mathbb C}$, where $S$ is a connected Riemann surface, to admit an square root, that is, a meromorphic map $\\psi:S \\to \\widehat{\\mathbb C}$ such that $\\varphi=\\psi^{2}$.	string

1684	en_US	abstract	<p>We introduce a notion of a <span><em>girth-regular</em></span> graph as a <span class="math inline"><em>k</em></span>-regular graph for which there exists a non-descending sequence <span class="math inline">(<em>a</em><sub>1</sub>, <em>a</em><sub>2</sub>, …, <em>a</em><sub><em>k</em></sub>)</span> (called the <span><em>signature</em></span>) giving, for every vertex <span class="math inline"><em>u</em></span> of the graph, the number of girth cycles the edges with end-vertex <span class="math inline"><em>u</em></span> lie on. Girth-regularity generalises two very different aspects of symmetry in graph theory: that of vertex transitivity and that of distance-regularity. For general girth-regular graphs, we give some results on the extremal cases of signatures. 1686	en_US	cleanTitle	SIMPLE AND SHORT PROOFS OF THE FERMAT'S LAST THEOREM	string
1686	en_US	abstract	There are several attempts and approaches to establish FLT. Among these are the usage of Shimurah-Taniyama-Wiel Conjecture and modular forms by Wiles; the application of ``infinite descent" by Fermat himself. Other approaches employed by mathematicians are: the invocation of cyclotomic field and ideal complex numbers, the exploration of the relationship between exponent `p' and triple (x,y,z), the investigation of finiteness of non-trivial primitive integer solutions to Fermat's equation, and the investigation of regular primes with respect to Bernoulli numbers including in-depth computer search. In this paper, by deriving some tools to further x-ray the properties of Fermat's triples, we establish certain contradictions implied by (x)^n + (y)^n=(z)^n. We finally look beyond the assertion that FLT implies that at least one of the triple (.,.,.) in the frame (.)^n + (.)^n=(.)^n is an irrational algebraic number to present a new conjecture which generalizes abc-conjecture for further studies	string

1687	en_US	abstract	Let $A$ be a $K$-subalgebra of the  polynomial ring $S=K[x_1,\\ldots,x_d]$ of dimension $d$, generated by finitely many monomials  of degree $r$.   Then the Gauss algebra $\\GG(A)$  of $A$ is generated by monomials  of degree $(r-1)d$ in $S$. We describe the generators and the structure of $\\GG(A)$, when $A$ is a Borel fixed algebra, a squarefree Veronese algebra, generated in degree $2$, or the edge ring of a bipartite graph with at least   one loop.  For a bipartite graph  $G$  with one loop, the embedding dimension of $\\GG(A)$ is bounded by the complexity of the graph $G$.<br /><br />	string

1700	en_US	abstract	If the face-cycles at all the vertices in a map are of same type then the map is said to be a semi-equivelar map. There are eleven types of semi-equivelar maps on the torus.<br />In 1972 Altshuler has presented a study of Hamiltonian cycles in semi-equivelar maps of three types $\\{3^{6}\\},$ $\\{4^{4}\\}$ and $\\{6^{3}\\}$ on the torus. In this article we study Hamiltonicity of semi-equivelar maps of the other eight types $\\{3^{3}, 4^{2}\\},$ $\\{3^{2}, 4^1, 3^1, 4^1\\}, $ $\\{3^1, 6^1, 3^1, 6^1\\},$ $ \\{3^{4}, 6^1\\},$ $\\{4^1, 8^{2}\\}, $ $\\{3^1, 12^{2}\\}, $ $\\{4^1,6^1, 12^1\\}$ and $\\{3^1, 4^1, 6^1, 4^1\\}$ on the torus. This gives a partial solution to the well known Conjecture that every $4$-connected graph on the torus has a Hamiltonian cycle.	string

1707	en_US	abstract	A graph G = (V,E) is called singed cordial (S–cordial) if it is possible to label the vertex by the function f:V-&gt;{-1,1} and label the edges by f^*:E-&gt;{-1,1}, where f^*(uv)=f(u).f(v), u,v in V so that |v_{-1}-v_1|&lt;= 1 and |e_{-1}-e_1|&lt;=1. J.Devaraj and P.Delphy, they have defined signed graphs, and they have started by labeling edges and then induced the labeling of vertices. 1711	en_US	title	On domination and 2-packing numbers in intersecting linear systems	string
1711	en_US	cleanTitle	On domination and 2packing numbers in intersecting linear systems	string
1711	en_US	abstract	<p>A linear system is a pair $(P,\\mathcal{L})$ where $\\mathcal{L}$ is a family of subsets on a ground finite set $P$ such that $|l\\cap l^\\prime|\\leq 1$, for every $l,l^\\prime \\in \\mathcal{L}$, and the linear system is called intersecting if any pair of lines intersect in exactly one point. A subset $D$ of points of a linear system $(P,\\mathcal{L})$ is a dominating set of $(P,\\mathcal{L})$ if for every $u\\in P\\setminus D$ there exists $v\\in D$ such that $u,v\\in l$, for some $l\\in\\mathcal{L}$. The cardinality of a minimum dominating set of a linear system $(P,\\mathcal{L})$ is called domination number of $(P,\\mathcal{L})$, denoted by $\\gamma(P,\\mathcal{L})$. On the other hand, a subset $R$ of lines of a linear system $(P,\\mathcal{L})$ is a 2-packing if any three elements of $R$ have not a common point (are triplewise disjoint). The cardinality of a maximum 2-packing of a linear system $(P,\\mathcal{L})$ is called 2-packing number of $(P,\\mathcal{L})$, denoted by $\\nu_2(P,\\mathcal{L})$.</p><p>It is know that for intersecting linear systems $(P,\\mathcal{L})$ of rank $r$ it satisfies $\\gamma(P,\\mathcal{L})\\leq r-1$. In this paper, we prove if $(P,\\mathcal{L})$ is an intersecting linear system of rank 5 satisfying $\\gamma(P,\\mathcal{L})=4$ then this li\\-near system can be constructed from an 4-uniform intersec\\-ting linear subsystem $(P^\\prime,\\mathcal{L}^\\prime)$ of the projective plane of order 3 satisfying $\\tau(P^\\prime,\\mathcal{L}^\\prime)=\\nu_2(P^\\prime,\\mathcal{L}^\\prime)=4$, and we give a complete characterization of this 4-uniform intersecting linear subsystems. Furthermore, we prove if $(P,\\mathcal{L})$ is an intersecting linear system of rank $(q+2)$ satisfying $\\gamma(P,\\mathcal{L})=q+1$ then this linear system can be constructed from a spanning $(q+1)$-uniform intersecting linear subsystem $(P^\\prime,\\mathcal{L}^\\prime)$ of the projective plane of order $q$ satisfying $\\tau(P^\\prime,\\mathcal{L}^\\prime)=\\nu_2(P^\\prime,\\mathcal{L}^\\prime)=q+1$.</p>	string

1714	en_US	title	On the revised Szeged index of unicyclic graphs with given diameter	string
1714	en_US	cleanTitle	On the revised Szeged index of unicyclic graphs with given diameter	string
1714	en_US	abstract	<p>The revised Szeged index of a connected graph $G$ is defined as<br />\\begin{displaymath}<br />Sz^*(G)=\\sum_{e=uv\\in E(G)}(n_u(e|G)+\\frac{n_0(e|G)}{2})(n_v(e|G)+\\frac{n_0(e|G)}{2}),<br />\\end{displaymath}<br />where $E(G)$ is the edge set of $G$, and for any $e = uv\\in E(G)$, $n_u(e|G)$ is the number of vertices of $G$ lying closer to vertex $u$ than to $v$, $n_v(e|G)$ is the number of vertices of $G$ lying closer to vertex $v$ than to $u$, and $n_0(e|G)$ is the number of vertices with equal distances from both end vertices of the edge $e$. In this paper, we characterize the graph with the minimum revised Szeged index among all the unicyclic graphs with given order and diameter.</p>	string

1716	en_US	abstract	In this article, it was shown that the biharmonic hypersurfaces in Euclidean space with recurrent operators are minimal. Infact, the biharmonic hypersurfaces with recurrent curvature operator, recurrent Ricci operator, recurrent Jacobi operator and recurrent Weyl operator in $E^{n+1}$ have at most three distinct principal curvatures. Consequently, we obtained the result.	string

1718	en_US	title	Optimal Continuous Facility Placement on the Square Grid Network	string
1718	en_US	cleanTitle	Optimal Continuous Facility Placement on the Square Grid Network	string
1718	en_US	abstract	<p>Continuous square grid network $\\mathcal{L}_{m,n}$ is defined most simply as a square lattice graph embedded in the plane so that the distance between neighboring vertices is $\\ell$.<br />A {\\em covering} of $\\mathcal{L}_{m,n}$ is a set of points $X \\subseteq \\mathcal{L}_{m,n}$ such that<br />for every point $y\\in \\mathcal{L}_{m,n}$, there is a point $x\\in X$ such that $d(x,y)\\leq \\ell$.<br />The {\\em covering number} of $\\mathcal{L}_{m,n}$, denoted as $\\alpha(m,n)$, is the minimum size of a covering of $\\mathcal{L}_{m,n}$.<br />We prove that $\\alpha(m,n)=\\left\\lceil\\frac{mn-1}{2}\\right\\rceil$ for $mn&gt;1$.</p>	string

1719	en_US	title	Zero pattern matrix rings, reachable pairs in digraphs, and Sharp's topological invariant $\\tau$	string
1719	en_US	cleanTitle	Zero pattern matrix rings reachable pairs in digraphs and Sharp's topological invariant \\tau	string
1719	en_US	abstract	<p>Let $R$ be an associative commutative ring with unity and $M_n(R)$ the ring of $n \\times n$ matrices over $R$. A zero pattern matrix ring is a subring of $M_n(R)$ defined by the location of zero and nonzero entries of matrices in the subring. It is known that the set of zero pattern matrix rings of $M_n(R)$ is in bijective correspondence with the set of transitive directed graphs on $n$ vertices, and also with the set of topologies on a set with $n$ elements.</p><p>We define the weight of a zero pattern matrix ring $\\mathcal{P}$ to be the maximum number of nonzero entries of a matrix in $\\mathcal{P}$, which is the rank of $\\mathcal{P}$ as an $R$-module. In this paper, we study the set $W(n)$ of possible weights of $n \\times n$ zero pattern matrix rings. We prove that $W(n)$ can be determined recursively and describe the integers in the set. In particular, we prove that most values in $W(n)$ lie in a interval of $\\mathbb{N}$ that can be determined recursively and independently of $W(n)$ itself. By establishing asymptotic bounds on this interval, we are able to provide effective estimates of $|W(n)|$. Finally, we describe techniques to determine those elements of $W(n)$ that lie outside of the aforementioned interval. Since the weight corresponds to the number of edges in a transitive directed graph, as well as to the number of containments among the minimal open sets of a topology, our theorems are applicable to digraphs and topologies as well as to matrix rings.</p>	string

1721	en_US	title	On constant sum partitions and applications to distance magic-type graphs	string
1721	en_US	cleanTitle	On constant sum partitions and applications to distance magictype graphs	string
1721	en_US	abstract	Let $G$ be an additive abelian group of order $n$ and let $n=a_{1}+a_{2}+...+a_{p}$ be a partition of $n$ where $1 \\leq a_{1} \\leq a_{2} \\leq ...\\leq a_{p}.$  A constant sum partition (or $t$-sum partition) of $G$ is a pairwise disjoint union of subsets $A_{1},A_{2},...,A_{p}$ such that $G=A_{1} \\cup A_{2} \\cup ... \\cup A_{p},$ $|A_{i}|=a_{i},$ and $\\sum_{a \\in A_{i}}^{} a = t,$  for some fixed $t \\in  G$ and every $1 \\leq i \\leq p.$ In 2009, Kaplan, Lev, and Roditty proved that a $0$-sum partition of the cyclic group $\\mathbb{Z}_{n}$ exists for $n$ odd if and only if $a_{2} \\geq 2.$ In this paper, we address the case when $n$ is even. In particular, we show that a $\\frac{n}{2}$-sum partition of $\\mathbb{Z}_{n}$  exists for $n$ even and $p$ odd if and only if $a_{2} \\geq 2.$ Moreover, we provide applications to distance magic-type graphs including the classification of  $\\mathbb{Z}_{n}$-distance magic complete $p$-partite graphs for $p$ odd.	string

1723	en_US	abstract	<p>Let $G$ be a graph. Its Graovac-Pisanski index is defined as<br />$\\GP(G)=\\frac{|V(G)|}{2|\\Aut(G)|}\\sum_{u\\in V(G)}<br />\\sum_{\\alpha\\in\\Aut(G)}d_G(u,\\alpha(u))$, where $\\Aut(G)$ is the group of<br />automorphisms of $G$.<br />This index is considered to be an extension of the original Wiener index,<br />since it takes into account not only the distances, but also the symmetries<br />of the graph.<br />In this paper, for each $n$ we find all trees on $n$ vertices with the<br />maximal value of Graovac-Pisanski index.<br />With the exception of several small values of $n$, there are exactly two<br />extremal trees, one of them being the path.</p>	string

1725	en_US	title	Strong geodetic problem on complete multipartite graphs	string
1725	en_US	cleanTitle	Strong geodetic problem on complete multipartite graphs	string
1725	en_US	abstract	The strong geodetic problem is to find the smallest number of vertices such that by fixing one shortest path between each pair, all vertices of the graph are covered. In this paper we study the strong geodetic problem on complete bipartite graphs. Some results for complete multipartite graphs are also derived. Finally, we prove that the strong geodetic problem restricted to (general) bipartite graphs is NP-complete.	string

1727	en_US	title	The k-metric dimension of graphs: a general approach	string
1727	en_US	cleanTitle	The kmetric dimension of graphs: a general approach	string
1727	en_US	abstract	<p>Let $(X,d)$ be a metric space. A set $S\\subseteq X$ is said to be a $k$-metric generator for $X$ if and only if for any pair of different points $u,v\\in X$, there exist at least $k$ points $w_1,w_2, \\ldots w_k\\in S$ such that $d(u,w_i)\\ne d(v,w_i),\\; \\mbox{\\rm for all}\\; i\\in \\{1, \\ldots k\\}.$ Let $\\mathcal{R}_k(X)$ be the set of metric generators for $X$.<br />The $k$-metric dimension $\\dim_k(X)$ of $(X,d)$ is defined as<br />$$\\dim_k(X)=\\inf\\{|S|:\\, S\\in \\mathcal{R}_k(X)\\}.$$ Here, we discuss the $k$-metric<br />dimension of $(V,d_t)$, where $V$ is the set of vertices of a simple graph $G$ and the metric $d_t:V\\times V\\rightarrow \\mathbb{N}\\cup \\{0\\}$ is defined by $<br />d_t(x,y)=\\min\\{d(x,y),t\\}<br />$ from the geodesic distance $d$ in $G$ and a positive integer $t$.<br />The case $t\\ge D(G)$, where $D(G)$ denotes the diameter of $G$, corresponds to the original theory of $k$-metric dimension and the case $t=2$ corresponds to the theory of $k$-adjacency dimension. Furthermore, this approach allows us to extend the theory of $k$-metric dimension to the general case of non-necessarily connected graphs.</p>	string

1731	en_US	title	g-Extra connectivity and diagnosability of hyper petersen graphs	string
1731	en_US	cleanTitle	gExtra connectivity and diagnosability of hyper petersen graphs	string
1731	en_US	abstract	Connectivity and diagnosability play an important role in measuring the fault tolerance of interconnection networks. In 2016, Zhang et al. proposed a new measure for fault diagnosis of the system, namely, the $g$-extra diagnosability, which restrains that every fault-free component has at least $(g + 1)$ fault-free nodes. As a famous topology structure of interconnection networks, the hyper petersen graph~$HP_{n}$ has many good properties. In this paper, we show that the $g$-extra connectivity of $HP_n$ is $n(g + 1)-\\frac{1}{2}g(g + 3)$ for $n\\geq 4$ and $0\\leq g\\leq n-3$ and the $g$-extra diagnosability of $HP_{n}$ is $n(g+1)-\\frac{1}{2}g(g+1)$ for $n\\geq 4$ and $0\\leq g\\leq n-3$ under the PMC model and for $n\\geq 7$ and $0\\leq g\\leq n-3$ under the MM$^*$ model.	string

1740	en_US	title	Integral regular net-balanced signed graphs with vertex degree at most four	string
1740	en_US	cleanTitle	Integral regular netbalanced signed graphs with vertex degree at most four	string
1740	en_US	abstract	<p>A signed graph is called integral if its spectrum consists entirely of integers, it is <span class="math inline"><em>r</em></span>-regular if its underlying graph is regular of degree <span class="math inline"><em>r</em></span>, and it is net-balanced if the difference between positive and negative vertex degree is a constant on the vertex set (this constant is called the net-balance and denoted <span class="math inline"><em>ρ</em></span>). We determine all the connected integral <span class="math inline">3</span>-regular net-balanced signed graphs. In the next natural step, for <span class="math inline"><em>r</em> = 4</span>, we consider only those whose net-balance is a simple eigenvalue. There, we complete the list of feasible spectra in bipartite case for <span class="math inline"><em>ρ</em> ≠ 0</span> and prove the non-existence for <span class="math inline"><em>ρ</em> = 0</span>. Certain existence conditions are established and the existence of some <span class="math inline">4</span>-regular (simple) graphs is confirmed. In this study we transferred some results from the theory of graph spectra; in particular, we give a counterpart to the Hoffman polynomial.</p>	string

1733	en_US	abstract	<p>We investigate the minimum number <span class="math inline"><em>t</em><sub>0</sub>(<em>G</em>)</span> of faces in a Hamiltonian triangulation <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> so that any Hamiltonian cycle <span class="math inline"><em>C</em></span> of <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> has at least <span class="math inline"><em>t</em><sub>0</sub>(<em>G</em>)</span> faces that do not contain an edge of <span class="math inline"><em>C</em></span>. 1734	en_US	abstract	A $k$-cycle system $(V(G),\\mathcal{C})$ is said to be resolvable, if the cycles belonging to $\\mathcal{C}$ can be partitioned into parallel classes. And it is called almost resolvable if the cycles belonging to $\\mathcal{C}$ can be partitioned into almost parallel classes, any one of which consists of vertex disjoint $k$-cycles missing just one vertex, such that the remaining $k$-cycles are vertex disjoint. Paper \\cite {PEJDC} generalized the definition of almost resolvable $k$-cycle systems of $(V(G),\\mathcal{C^{'}})$ by considering the case that $k$ does not divide $n$, and investigated almost resolvable $2k$-cycle systems of $K_{n}$ for $n$ odd. In this paper, we consider almost resolvable $2k$-cycle systems of $K_{n}-I$, where $n$ is even and I is a $1$-factor of $K_{n}$.	string

1738	en_US	cleanTitle	Graph exponentiation and neighborhood reconstruction	string
1738	en_US	abstract	<p>Any graph <em>G</em> admits a <em>neighborhood multiset </em>$\\mathscr{N}(G)= \\{N_G(x) \\mid x\\in V(G)\\}$ whose elements are precisely the open neighborhoods of <em>G</em>. 1745	en_US	title	Perfect 3-Colorings of non orientable surface of Euler Characteristic -2.	string
1745	en_US	cleanTitle	Perfect 3Colorings of non orientable surface of Euler Characteristic 2	string
1745	en_US	abstract	We study the perfect $3$-colorings (also known as the equitable partitions into three parts) of degree-regular triangulations of the surface of Euler Characteristic -2. A perfect $n$-coloring of a graph is a partition of its vertex set into $n$ parts  $A_{1}, A_{2},..., A_{n}$ such that for all $p,q\\in\\{1, 2,..., n\\}$, each vertex of $A_{p}$ is adjacent to $a_{pq}$ number of vertices of $A_{q}$. Perfect $n$-coloring of a triangulation of a surface is the perfect $n$-coloring of the corresponding edge graph of the triangulation.  The matrix $A=(a_{pq})_{n\\times n}$ is called quotient matrix or parameter matrix. The concept of a perfect coloring generalizes the concept of completely regular code introduced by P. Delsarte. In particular, we classify all the realizable parameter matrices of perfect $3$-colorings for degree-regular triangulations of the surface of Euler Characteristic -2.	string

1748	en_US	title	Complete regular dessins and skew-morphisms of cyclic groups	string
1748	en_US	cleanTitle	Complete regular dessins and skewmorphisms of cyclic groups	string
1748	en_US	abstract	<p>A dessin is a <span class="math inline">2</span>-cell embedding of a connected <span class="math inline">2</span>-coloured bipartite graph into an orientable closed surface. A dessin is regular if its group of orientation- and colour-preserving automorphisms acts regularly on the edges. In this paper we study regular dessins whose underlying graph is a complete bipartite graph <span class="math inline"><em>K</em><sub><em>m</em>, <em>n</em></sub></span>, called <span class="math inline">(<em>m</em>, <em>n</em>)</span>-complete regular dessins. The purpose is to establish a rather surprising correspondence between <span class="math inline">(<em>m</em>, <em>n</em>)</span>-complete regular dessins and pairs of skew-morphisms of cyclic groups. A skew-morphism of a finite group <span class="math inline"><em>A</em></span> is a bijection <span class="math inline"><em>φ</em>: <em>A</em> → <em>A</em></span> that satisfies the identity <span class="math inline"><em>φ</em>(<em>x</em><em>y</em>) = <em>φ</em>(<em>x</em>)<em>φ</em><sup><em>π</em>(<em>x</em>)</sup>(<em>y</em>)</span> for some function <span class="math inline"><em>π</em>: <em>A</em> → ℤ</span> and fixes the neutral element of <span class="math inline"><em>A</em></span>. We show that every <span class="math inline">(<em>m</em>, <em>n</em>)</span>-complete regular dessin <span class="math inline"><strong>D</strong></span> determines a pair of reciprocal skew-morphisms of the cyclic groups <span class="math inline">ℤ<sub><em>n</em></sub></span> and <span class="math inline">ℤ<sub><em>m</em></sub></span>. Conversely, <span class="math inline"><strong>D</strong></span> can be reconstructed from such a reciprocal pair. As a consequence, we prove that complete regular dessins, exact bicyclic groups with a distinguished pair of generators, and pairs of reciprocal skew-morphisms of cyclic groups are all in a one-to-one correspondence. Finally, we apply the main result to determining all pairs of integers <span class="math inline"><em>m</em></span> and <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span> for which there exists, up to interchange of colours, exactly one isomorphism class of <span class="math inline">(<em>m</em>, <em>n</em>)</span>-complete regular dessins. We show that the latter occurs precisely when every group expressible as a product of cyclic groups of order <span class="math inline"><em>m</em></span> and <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span> is abelian, which eventually comes down to the condition <span class="math inline">gcd (<em>m</em>, <em>ϕ</em>(<em>n</em>)) = gcd (<em>ϕ</em>(<em>m</em>), <em>n</em>) = 1</span>, where <span class="math inline"><em>ϕ</em></span> is Euler’s totient function.</p>	string

1750	en_US	abstract	A $\\Gamma$-magic rectangle  set $MRS_{\\Gamma}(a, b; c)$  of order $abc$ is a collection of $c$ arrays $(a\\times b)$<br />whose entries are elements of group $\\Gamma$, each appearing once, with all row sums in<br />every rectangle equal to a constant $\\omega\\in \\Gamma$ and all column sums in every rectangle equal to a<br />constant $\\delta \\in \\Gamma$.\\\\<br /><br /><br />In this paper we prove that for  $\\{a,b\\}\\neq\\{2^{\\alpha},2k+1\\}$ where $\\alpha$ and $k$ are some natural numbers, a  $\\Gamma$-magic rectangle set MRS$_{\\Gamma}(a, b;c)$ exists if and only if $a$ and $b$ are both even or and $|\\Gamma|$ is odd or   $\\Gamma$ has more than one involution. Moreover we obtain  sufficient and necessary conditions for existence a $\\Gamma$-magic rectangle MRS$_{\\Gamma}(a, b)$=MRS$_{\\Gamma}(a, b;1)$.\\\\<br /><br /> This work will also be potentially useful<br />for the graph theorists who work in graph labeling.<br /><br /><br />	string

1752	en_US	title	The average domination polynomial of graphs is unimodal	string
1752	en_US	cleanTitle	The average domination polynomial of graphs is unimodal	string
1752	en_US	abstract	Let $G$ be a simple graph on $n$ vertices. A dominating set of $G$ is a subset of vertices of $G$, say $S$,<br />such that every vertex in $V(G)\\setminus S$ is adjacent to at least one vertex<br />of $S$. The domination polynomial of $G$ is the polynomial $D(G,x)=\\sum_{i=1}^{n}d(G,i)x^i$, where $d(G,i)$ is the number of dominating sets of $G$ of size $i$. For every $n\\geq1$, let $\\Phi_n(x)$ be the average of the domination polynomial of all labeled graphs on $n$ vertices. In this paper we study this polynomial. In particular we show that $\\Phi_n(x)$ is log-concave and unimodal.	string

1753	en_US	title	Top-heavy property for transformations	string
1753	en_US	cleanTitle	Topheavy property for transformations	string
1753	en_US	abstract	Let $S$ be a transformation semigroup acting on a set $\\Omega$.  The action of $S$ on $\\Omega$ can be naturally extended to be an action on all subsets of $\\Omega$. We say that $S$ is $\\ell$-homogeneous provided it can send $A$ to $B$ for any two (not necessarily distinct)  $\\ell$-subsets $A$ and  $B$ of $\\Omega$.  On the condition that $k \\le \\ell &lt; k+\\ell \\le |\\Omega|$, we show that every $\\ell$-homogeneous transformation semigroup acting on $\\Omega$ must be  $k$-homogeneous.  We report other variants of this result for Boolean lattices and projective geometries. In general, any semigroup action on a poset gives rise to an automaton and we associate some sequences of integers with the phase space of this automaton. When the poset is a geometric lattice, we propose to study various possible regularity properties of these sequences, especially the so-called top-heavy property.	string

A total labeling $\\phi: V \\cup E<br />\\rightarrow \\{1,2,...,k\\}$ is called totally irregular total-$k$<br />labeling of $G$ if every two distinct vertices $x$ and $y$ in $V(G)$<br />satisfies $wt(x) \\neq wt(y)$ and every two distinct edges $ x_{1}<br />x_{2}$ and $y_{1}y_{2}$ satisfies $ wt(x_{1} x_{2}) \\neq\\<br />wt(y_{1}y_{2})$, where $wt(x)= \\phi (x)+ \\sum \\limits_{xz \\in E(G)}<br />\\phi (xz)$ and $wt(x_{1} x_{2}) = \\phi(x_{1})+ \\phi (x_{1} x_{2})+<br />\\phi (x_{2})$. 1758	en_US	title	<i>S</i><sub>12</sub> and <i>P</i><sub>12</sub>-colorings of cubic graphs	string
1758	en_US	cleanTitle	<i>S</i><sub>12</sub> and <i>P</i><sub>12</sub>colorings of cubic graphs	string
1758	en_US	abstract	If <em>G</em> and <em>H</em> are two cubic graphs, then an <em>H</em>-coloring of <em>G</em> is a proper edge-coloring <em>f</em> with the edges of <em>H</em>, such that for each vertex <em>x</em> of <em>G</em>, there is a vertex <em>y</em> of <em>H</em> with <em>f</em>(<em>∂<sub>G</sub></em>(<em>x</em>)) = <em>∂<sub>H</sub></em>(<em>y</em>). If <em>G</em> admits an <em>H</em>-coloring, then we will write <em>H</em> ≺ <em>G</em>. The Petersen coloring conjecture of Jaeger (<em>P</em><sub>10</sub>-conjecture) states that for any bridgeless cubic graph <em>G</em>, one has: <em>P</em><sub>10</sub> ≺ <em>G</em>. The <em>S</em><sub>10</sub>-conjecture states that for any cubic graph <em>G</em>, <em>S</em><sub>10</sub> ≺ <em>G</em>. In this paper, we introduce two new conjectures that are related to these conjectures. The first of them states that any cubic graph with a perfect matching admits an <em>S</em><sub>12</sub>-coloring. The second one states that any cubic graph <em>G</em> whose edge-set can be covered with four perfect matchings, admits a <em>P</em><sub>12</sub>-coloring. We call these new conjectures <em>S</em><sub>12</sub>-conjecture and <em>P</em><sub>12</sub>-conjecture, respectively. Our first results justify the choice of graphs in <em>S</em><sub>12</sub>-conjecture and <em>P</em><sub>12</sub>-conjecture. Next, we characterize the edges of <em>P</em><sub>12</sub> that may be fictive in a <em>P</em><sub>12</sub>-coloring of a cubic graph <em>G</em>. Finally, we relate the new conjectures to the already known conjectures by proving that <em>S</em><sub>12</sub>-conjecture implies <em>S</em><sub>10</sub>-conjecture, and <em>P</em><sub>12</sub>-conjecture and (5, 2)-Cycle cover conjecture together imply <em>P</em><sub>10</sub>-conjecture. Our main tool for proving the latter statement is a new reformulation of (5, 2)-Cycle cover conjecture, which states that the edge-set of any claw-free bridgeless cubic graph can be covered with four perfect matchings.	string

1761	en_US	title	Extremal matching energy and the largest matching root of complete multipartite graphs	string
1761	en_US	cleanTitle	Extremal matching energy and the largest matching root of complete multipartite graphs	string
1761	en_US	abstract	<span style="color: #231f20;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><span class="fontstyle0">The matching energy </span><span class="fontstyle2">ME</span><span class="fontstyle0">(</span><span class="fontstyle2">G</span><span class="fontstyle0">) of a graph </span><span class="fontstyle2">G </span><span class="fontstyle0">was introduced by Gutman and Wagner, which is defined as the sum of the absolute values of the roots of the matching<br />polynomial </span><span class="fontstyle2">m</span><span class="fontstyle0">(</span><span class="fontstyle2">G, x</span><span class="fontstyle0">). The largest matching root </span><span class="fontstyle2">λ</span></span><span class="fontstyle3"><span style="font-size: small;">1</span></span><span style="font-size: medium;"><span class="fontstyle0">(</span><span class="fontstyle2">G</span><span class="fontstyle0">) is the largest root of the<br />matching polynomial </span><span class="fontstyle2">m</span><span class="fontstyle0">(</span><span class="fontstyle2">G, x</span><span class="fontstyle0">). 1762	en_US	title	Perfect Degree Support Graphs	string
1762	en_US	cleanTitle	Perfect Degree Support Graphs	string
1762	en_US	abstract	<p>In a graph <em>G(V,E)</em>, the support <em>s(v)</em> of a vertex <em>v</em> is defined as the sum of degrees of its neighbours. Let <em>k</em> be any positive integer. In this paper, we introduce two new concepts in graph theory, namely, <em>k</em> – perfect degree support graph and <em>(k,c) –</em> linear degree support graph. A graph <em>G</em> is said to be a <em>k</em> – perfect degree support graph (<em>k – pds </em>graph) if for any vertex <em>v</em> in <em>G</em>, the ratio of its support to its degree is the constant <em>k</em>. A graph G is called a <em>(k, c) </em>– linear degree support graph (<em>(k,c) – lds</em> graph) if, the support of any vertex is <em>k</em> times its degree with a constant integer <em>c</em> added to it. Some families of <em>(k,c) – lds </em>graphs and <em>k</em> – pds graphs have been constructed in this paper. In addition, an interesting relationship between the eigen values of the adjacency matrix of a <em>k</em> – pds graph with the degree sequence of <em>G</em> as its eigen vector has been studied.</p>	string

1763	en_US	abstract	<p>Let <span class="math inline"><em>q</em> &gt; 2 ⋅ 3<sup>4<em>t</em></sup></span> be even. We prove that the only symplectic semifield spread of <span class="math inline">PG(5, <em>q</em><sup><em>t</em></sup>)</span>, whose associate semifield has center containing <span class="math inline"><strong>F</strong><sub><em>q</em></sub></span>, is the Desarguesian spread. Equivalently, a commutative semifield of order <span class="math inline"><em>q</em><sup>3<em>t</em></sup></span>, with middle nucleus containing <span class="math inline"><strong>F</strong><sub><em>q</em><sup><em>t</em></sup></sub></span> and center containing <span class="math inline"><strong>F</strong><sub><em>q</em></sub></span>, is a field. 1765	en_US	abstract	<p>Let <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> be the simple group <span class="math inline">PSU(3, 2<sup>2<sup><em>n</em></sup></sup>)</span>, <span class="math inline"><em>n</em> &gt; 0</span>. 1766	en_US	title	On the Coloring of the Cozero-divisor Graph of a Commutative Ring	string
1766	en_US	cleanTitle	On the Coloring of the Cozerodivisor Graph of a Commutative Ring	string
1766	en_US	abstract	Let $R$ be a commutative  ring with unity. The cozero-divisor  graph of $R$ denoted by $\\Gamma'(R)$ is a graph with the vertex set $W^{*}(R)$, where $W^{*}(R)$ is the set of all non-zero and non-unit elements of $R$, and two distinct vertices $a$ and $b$ are adjacent if and only if $a\\notin Rb$ and $b\\notin Ra$. Let $\\omega(\\Gamma'(R))$ and $\\chi(\\Gamma'(R))$ denote the clique number and the chromatic number of $\\Gamma'(R)$, respectively. In this paper, we prove that if $R$ is a finite commutative ring, then $\\Gamma'(R)$ is perfect. Also, we prove that if $R$ is a commutative Artinian non-local ring and $\\omega(\\Gamma'(R))$ is finite, then $\\chi(\\Gamma'(R))=\\omega(\\Gamma'(R))$. For Artinian local ring we obtain an upper bound for the chromatic number of cozero-divisor graph. Among other results, we prove that if $R$ is a commutative ring, then $\\Gamma'(R)$ is a complete bipartite graph if and only if $R\\cong F_{1}\\times F_{2}$, where $F_{1}$ and $F_{2}$ are fields. Moreover, we present some results on the complete $r$- partite cozero-divisor graphs.	string

1767	en_US	title	On the connected and weakly convex domination numbers	string
1767	en_US	cleanTitle	On the connected and weakly convex domination numbers	string
1767	en_US	abstract	In this paper we study relations between connected and weakly convex domination numbers.  We show that in general the difference between these numbers can be arbitrarily large and we focus on the graphs for which a weakly convex domination number equals a connected domination number. We also study the influence of the edge removing on the weakly convex domination number, in particular we prove that the weakly convex domination number is an interpolating function	string

1771	en_US	title	Smooth skew morphisms of dihedral groups	string
1771	en_US	cleanTitle	Smooth skew morphisms of dihedral groups	string
1771	en_US	abstract	<p>A skew morphism of a finite group $A$ is a permutation $\\varphi$ on $A$ fixing the<br />identity element of $A$ and for which there exists an integer function $\\pi$ on $A$<br />such that $\\varphi(xy)=\\varphi(x)\\varphi^{\\pi(x)}(y)$ for all<br />$x,y\\in A$. In the case where $\\pi(\\varphi(x))=\\pi(x)$, for all $x\\in A$,<br />the skew morphism is smooth. <br />The concept of smooth skew morphism is a generalization of that of <br />$t$-balanced skew morphism. The aim of this paper is to develop a general <br />theory of smooth skew morphisms. As an application we classify smooth <br /> skew morphisms of dihedral groups.</p>	string

1773	en_US	abstract	<p>A graph G is said to be edge-distance-balanced if for any edge uv of<br />G, the number of edges closer to u than to v is equal to the number of<br />edges closer to v than to u. Let GP(n, k) be a generalized Petersen graph.<br />It is proven that for any integers n =&gt; 3 , the generalized Petersen graph<br />GP(4n + 7, 2) is not edge-distance-balanced.</p>	string

1774	en_US	title	The M\\"obius function of ${\\rm PSU}(3,2^{2^n})$	string
1774	en_US	cleanTitle	The M\\obius function of {\\rm PSU}32^{2^n}	string
1774	en_US	abstract	Let $G$ be the simple group ${\\rm PSU}(2,2^{2^n})$, $n&gt;0$.<br />For any subgroup $H$ of $G$, we compute the M\\"obius function $\\mu_L(H,G)$ of $H$ in the subgroup lattice $L$ of $G$, and the M\\"obius function $\\mu_{\\bar L}([H],[G])$ of $[H]$ in the poset $\\bar L$ of conjugacy classes of subgroups of $G$.<br />For any prime $p$, we provide the Euler characteristic of the order complex of the poset of $p$-subgroups of $G$.	string

1775	en_US	title	Graphs with Arbitrarily Large Adversary Degree Associated Reconstruction Number	string
1775	en_US	cleanTitle	Graphs with Arbitrarily Large Adversary Degree Associated Reconstruction Number	string
1775	en_US	abstract	<p>A vertex deleted unlabeled subgraph of a graph is a card. A dacard specifies the degree of the deleted vertex along with the card. The adversary degree associated reconstruction number of a graph G, denoted adrn(G), is the minimum number k such that every collection of k dacards of G uniquely determines G. A strong double broom is the graph on at least 5 vertices obtained from a union of (at least two) internally vertex disjoint paths with same ends u and v by appending leaves at u and v. The strong double broom, obtained from a union of m internally vertex disjoint paths of order k with same ends u and v by appending n leaves at each u and v, is denoted by B(n, n,mPk). In this paper, we show that the drn of all strong double brooms is two and we determine adrn(B(n, n,mPk)) for all n, m, k. For n ≥ 1 and m ≥ 2, usually adrn(B(n, n,mP3)) = n + 2 and adrn(B(n, n,mP4)) = n+m+2, except adrn(B(1, 1, 2P3)) = 4. For n ≥ 1,m ≥ 2 and k &gt; 4, usually adrn(B(n, n,mPk)) = n + 2, except adrn(B(n, n,mP5)) = max{m, n} + 2 when (n,m) 6= (1, 2) and adrn(B(1, 1, 2P5)) = 5.</p>	string

1779	en_US	title	Generalized Jordan derivations of Incidence Algebras.	string
1779	en_US	cleanTitle	Generalized Jordan derivations of Incidence Algebras	string
1779	en_US	abstract	For a given ring R and a locally finite pre-ordered set (X, ≤), consider I(X, R ) to be the incidence algebra of X over R . Motivated by a Xiao’s result which states that every Jordan derivation of I(X, R ) is a derivation in the case R is 2-torsion free, one proves that each generalized Jordan derivation of I(X, R ) is a generalized derivation provided R is 2-torsion free, getting as a consequence the above mentioned result.	string

1780	en_US	title	Structure of the directed graph of a ring of order p^2	string
1780	en_US	cleanTitle	Structure of the directed graph of a ring of order p^2	string
1780	en_US	abstract	For a finite ring $R$, let $\\Psi(R)$ denote the directed graph associated with $R$. In this paper, we determine the structure of $\\Psi (I)$ where $I$ is the ring of order $p^2$ with presentation given by $I=\\langle a,b\\mid pa=pb=0, a^2=b,ab=0\\rangle$, $p$ is a prime. We obtain an explicit formula for determining the number of non-sources in $\\Psi(I)$. We also prove that $\\Psi(I)$ is symmetric in that it has exactly $p^2$ connected components with $p^2$ vertices in each connected component.	string

1781	en_US	title	Structure and substructure connectivity of balanced hypercubes	string
1781	en_US	cleanTitle	Structure and substructure connectivity of balanced hypercubes	string
1781	en_US	abstract	<p>The connectivity of a network directly signifies its reliability and fault-tolerance. Structure and substructure connectivity are two novel generalizations of the connectivity. Let $H$ be a subgraph of a connected graph $G$. The structure connectivity (resp. substructure connectivity) of $G$, denoted by $\\kappa(G;H)$ (resp. $\\kappa^s(G;H)$), is defined to be the minimum cardinality of a set $F$ of connected subgraphs in $G$, if exists, whose removal disconnects $G$ and each element of $F$ is isomorphic to $H$ (resp. a subgraph of $H$). In this paper, we shall establish both $\\kappa(BH_n;H)$ and $\\kappa^s(BH_n;H)$ of the balanced hypercube $BH_n$ for $H\\in\\{K_1,K_{1,1},K_{1,2},K_{1,3},C_4\\}$.</p>	string

1782	en_US	title	On identities of Watson type	string
1782	en_US	cleanTitle	On identities of Watson type	string
1782	en_US	abstract	<p>We prove several identities of the type <span class="math inline"><em>α</em>(<em>n</em>) = Σ<sub><em>k</em>=0</sub><sup><em>n</em></sup> <em>β</em>((<em>n</em> − <em>k</em>(<em>k</em> + 1)/2) / 2)</span>. Here, the functions <span class="math inline"><em>α</em>(<em>n</em>)</span> and <span class="math inline"><em>β</em>(<em>n</em>)</span> count partitions with certain restrictions or the number of parts in certain partitions. Since Watson proved the identity for <span class="math inline"><em>α</em>(<em>n</em>) = <em>Q</em>(<em>n</em>)</span>, the number of partitions of <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span> into distinct parts, and <span class="math inline"><em>β</em>(<em>n</em>) = <em>p</em>(<em>n</em>)</span>, Euler’s partition function, we refer to these identities as Watson type identities. Our work is motivated by results of G. E. Andrews and the second author who recently discovered and proved new Euler type identities. We provide analytic proofs and explain how one could construct bijective proofs of our results.</p>	string

1783	en_US	abstract	This paper deals with the controllability and optimal control results for the quasilinear evolution system in abstract spaces. Secondly, shown that the optimal control results for the quasilinear system. The results are obtained and fixed point theorems.
