1785	en_US	title	Topological Properties of Octahedral and Icosahedral Networks	string
1785	en_US	cleanTitle	Topological Properties of Octahedral and Icosahedral Networks	string
1785	en_US	abstract	<p>Graph theory plays an important role in modeling and designing any chemical structure or network. The molecular topological descriptors are the numerical invariants of a molecular graph and are very useful for predicting their bioactivity.<br />In this paper, we have computed topological indices of two metal organic frameworks of considerable interest in reticular chemistry, namely octahedral and icosahedral networks. We have discussed and computed exact results for degree based topological indices namely Zagreb indices, forgotten topological index, Balaban index and Zagreb polynomials.</p>	string
1785	en_US	discipline	Chemical graph Theory, Combinatorics	string

1785	en_US	copyrightHolder	ARS MATHEMATICA CONTEMPORANEA	string
1785		licenseURL		string
1788	en_US	subject	spanning trees; bipartite perfect matching; complete bipartite graph; plane tree; bichromatic points	string
1788	en_US	discipline		string
1788	en_US	subjectClass	68R05; 68R10; 05C85	string
1788	en_US	abstract	Given two sets R and B of disjoint points on the plane, such that R contains n red and B contains n blue points, and the points are in general position, that is, no three of the points are collinear. A plane bichromatic spanning tree is a spanning tree, where each edge has a red endpoint and a blue endpoint, and no two edges intersect each other. One of the interesting topics in bichromatic trees is finding a plane bichromatic tree that its degree be as low as possible. In this paper, we consider the relation between the bipartite perfect matching and the plane bichromatic spanning tree and propose two new algorithms for computing the plane bichromatic trees. We first propose an O(n \\log n)-time algorithm for computing a plane bichromatic spanning tree, and then present a near O(n^{2})-time algorithm, for computing a plane bichromatic spanning tree of minimum degree, when two point sets R and B have the same cardinality.	string

1794	en_US	abstract	<p>A total labeling $\\Phi : V \\cup E\\rightarrow \\{1, 2, \\dots, k\\}$ is called totally irregular total<br />$k$-labeling of $G$ if every two distinct vertices $u$ and $v$ in $V(G)$ satisfy $wt(u) \\ne wt(v),$ and every two distinct edges<br />$u_1u_2$ and $v_1v_2$ in $E(G)$ satisfy $wt(u_1u_2) \\ne wt(v_1v_2),$ where $wt(u) = \\Phi(u) + \\sum\\limits_{uv\\in E(G)} \\Phi(uv)$ and<br />$wt(u_1u_2) = \\Phi(u_1) + \\Phi(u_1u_2) + \\Phi(u_2).$ The minimum $k$ for which a graph $G$ has a totally irregular total $k$-labeling is<br />called the total irregularity strength of $G$, denoted by $ts(G).$ In \\cite{NK} \\emph{Naeem et al.} determined the total irregularity<br />strength of disjoint union of isomorphic copies of generalized Petersen graph and gave an open problem about disjoint union of non<br />isomorphic copies of generalized Peterson graph. 1797	en_US	title	The Decycling Number of Plane Triangulations	string
1797	en_US	cleanTitle	The Decycling Number of Plane Triangulations	string
1797	en_US	abstract	The decycling number ∇(G) of a graph G is the smallest number of vertices which can be removed from G so that the resultant graph contains no cycle. An important problem on decycling graphs due to Albertson and Berman. They conjectured that every planar graph has an induced acyclic subgraph with at least half the vertices. Up to now it has been solved for triangle-free planar graphs. In this paper, we construct a type of plane triangulation graph denoted by GnK4 . We show that ∇(GnK4 ) =|V (GnK4 )|/2 for n = 1, 2, 3, 4. The results confirm the above conjecture and offer a type of graphs achieving the lower bound. The case for n &gt; 5 remains open.	string

1800	en_US	title	New methods for finding minimum genus embeddings of graphs on orientable and non-orientable surfaces	string
1800	en_US	cleanTitle	New methods for finding minimum genus embeddings of graphs on orientable and nonorientable surfaces	string
1800	en_US	abstract	The question of how to find the smallest genus of all embeddings of a given finite connected graph on an orientable (or non-orientable) surface has a long and interesting history. In this paper we introduce four new approaches to help answer this question, in both the orientable and non-orientable cases. One approach involves taking orbits of subgroups of the automorphism group on cycles of particular lengths in the graph as candidates for subsets of the faces of an embedding. Another uses properties of an auxiliary graph defined in terms of compatibility of these cycles. We also present two methods that make use of integer linear programming, to help determine bounds for the minimum genus, and to find minimum genus embeddings. This work was motivated by the problem of finding the minimum genus of the Hoffman-Singleton graph, and succeeded not only in solving that problem but also in answering several other open questions.	string

1806	en_US	title	New algorithms for computing plane bichromatic trees	string
1806	en_US	cleanTitle	New algorithms for computing plane bichromatic trees	string
1806	en_US	abstract	<p>Given two sets R and B of disjoint points on the plane, such that R contains n red and B contains n blue points, and the points are in general position, that is, no three of the points are collinear. A plane bichromatic spanning tree is a spanning tree, where each edge has a red endpoint and a blue endpoint, and no two edges intersect each other. One of the interesting topics in bichromatic trees is finding a plane bichromatic tree that its degree be as low as possible. In this paper, we consider the relation between the bipartite perfect matching and the plane bichromatic spanning tree and propose two new algorithms for computing the plane bichromatic trees. We first propose an O(n log n)-time algorithm for computing a plane bichromatic spanning tree, and then present a near O(n^{2})-time algorithm, for computing a plane bichromatic spanning tree of minimum degree, when two point sets R and B have the same cardinality.</p><p> </p>	string

1815	en_US	abstract	<p>A finite graph is called a tricirculant if admits a cyclic group of automorphism which has precisely three orbits on the vertex-set of the graph, all of equal size. We classify all finite connected cubic vertex-transitive tricirculants. We show that except for some small exceptions of order less than <span class="math inline">54</span>, each of these graphs is either a prism of order <span class="math inline">6<em>k</em></span> with <span class="math inline"><em>k</em></span> odd, a Möbius ladder, or it falls into one of two infinite families, each family containing one graph for every order of the form <span class="math inline">6<em>k</em></span> with <span class="math inline"><em>k</em></span> odd.</p>	string

1816	en_US	abstract	Identifying codes are used to locate malfunctioning processors in multiprocessor systems. In this paper, we study identifying codes in a q-ary hypercube which is used in parallel processing. Computing upper and lower bounds of M_{r,q} (n), the smallest cardinality<br />among all r-identifying codes in Z_q^n with respect to the Lee metric, is an important research<br />problem in this area. Using our constructions (in Sections 2 and 4), we produce tables for<br />upper and lower bounds for M_{r,q}(n) in Sections 3 and 4. The upper and the lower bounds<br />of M_{r,4} (n) are so far known only when r=1 but using our results we compute the bounds for M_{r,4} (n) for all r ≥ 1 (Tables 3 and 6). Also we improve upon the currently known upper<br />bounds of M_{1,4} (n) due to J. L. Kim and S. J. Kim (Table 3). Upper bounds of M_{r,q} (n) for<br />q &gt; 4 are known previously for some cases of n. We improve some of these bounds and we<br />also compute bounds for all n by using our results (Tables 4 and 5).	string

1813	en_US	title	Reconfiguring vertex colourings of 2-trees	string
1813	en_US	cleanTitle	Reconfiguring vertex colourings of 2trees	string
1813	en_US	abstract	<p>Let <span class="math inline"><em>H</em></span> be a graph and let <span class="math inline"><em>k</em> ≥ χ(<em>H</em>)</span> be an integer. The <span><em><span class="math inline"><em>k</em></span>-colouring graph of <span class="math inline"><em>H</em></span></em></span>, denoted <span class="math inline"><em>G</em><sub><em>k</em></sub>(<em>H</em>)</span>, is the graph whose vertex set consists of all proper <span class="math inline"><em>k</em></span>-vertex-colourings (or simply <span class="math inline"><em>k</em></span>-colourings) of <span class="math inline"><em>H</em></span> using colours <span class="math inline">{1, 2, …, <em>k</em>}</span>; two vertices of <span class="math inline"><em>G</em><sub><em>k</em></sub>(<em>H</em>)</span> are adjacent if and only if the corresponding <span class="math inline"><em>k</em></span>-colourings differ in colour on exactly one vertex of <span class="math inline"><em>H</em></span>. If <span class="math inline"><em>G</em><sub><em>k</em></sub>(<em>H</em>)</span> has a Hamilton cycle, then <span class="math inline"><em>H</em></span> is said to have a <span><em>Gray code</em></span> of <span class="math inline"><em>k</em></span>-colourings, and the <span><em>Gray code number</em></span> of <span class="math inline"><em>H</em></span> is the least integer <span class="math inline"><em>k</em><sub>0</sub>(<em>H</em>)</span> such that <span class="math inline"><em>G</em><sub><em>k</em></sub>(<em>H</em>)</span> has a Gray code of <span class="math inline"><em>k</em></span>-colourings for all <span class="math inline"><em>k</em> ≥ <em>k</em><sub>0</sub>(<em>H</em>)</span>. Choo and MacGillivray determine the Gray code numbers of trees. We extend this result to <span class="math inline">2</span>-trees. A <span><em><span class="math inline">2</span>-tree</em></span> is constructed recursively by starting with a complete graph on three vertices and connecting each new vertex to an existing clique on two vertices. We prove that if <span class="math inline"><em>H</em></span> is a <span class="math inline">2</span>-tree, then <span class="math inline"><em>k</em><sub>0</sub>(<em>H</em>) = 4</span> unless <span class="math inline"><em>H</em></span> is isomorphic to the join of a tree <span class="math inline"><em>T</em></span> and a vertex <span class="math inline"><em>u</em></span>, where <span class="math inline"><em>T</em></span> is a star on at least three vertices, or the bipartition of <span class="math inline"><em>T</em></span> has two even parts; in these cases, <span class="math inline"><em>k</em><sub>0</sub>(<em>H</em>) = 5</span>.</p>	string

1817	en_US	title	The existence of square non-integer Heffter arrays	string
1817	en_US	cleanTitle	The existence of square noninteger Heffter arrays	string
1817	en_US	abstract	<p>A Heffter array <span class="math inline"><em>H</em>(<em>n</em>; <em>k</em>)</span> is an <span class="math inline"><em>n</em> × <em>n</em></span> matrix such that each row and column contains <span class="math inline"><em>k</em></span> filled cells, each row and column sum is divisible by <span class="math inline">2<em>n</em><em>k</em> + 1</span> and either <span class="math inline"><em>x</em></span> or <span class="math inline"> −<em>x</em></span> appears in the array for each integer <span class="math inline">1 ≤ <em>x</em> ≤ <em>n</em><em>k</em></span>. Heffter arrays are useful for embedding the graph <span class="math inline"><em>K</em><sub>2<em>n</em><em>k</em> + 1</sub></span> on an orientable surface. An integer Heffter array is one in which each row and column sum is <span class="math inline">0</span>. Necessary and sufficient conditions (on <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span> and <span class="math inline"><em>k</em></span>) for the existence of an integer Heffter array <span class="math inline"><em>H</em>(<em>n</em>; <em>k</em>)</span> were verified by Archdeacon, Dinitz, Donovan and Yazıcı (2015) and Dinitz and Wanless (2017). In this paper we consider square Heffter arrays that are not necessarily integer. We show that such Heffter arrays exist whenever <span class="math inline">3 ≤ <em>k</em> &lt; <em>n</em></span>.</p>	string

1819	en_US	title	Hosoya Polynomial of the Line Graph of Polygonal Cylinder $C_{m,n}$	string
1819	en_US	cleanTitle	Hosoya Polynomial of the Line Graph of Polygonal Cylinder C_{mn}	string
1819	en_US	abstract	<p>The Hosoya polynomial was introduced by Hosoya in 1988 for a graph $G$ as $H(G,x) =\\sum_{k=1}^{d(G)} d(G,k)x^{k}$, where $d(G,k)$ is the number of pairs of vertices of $G$ laying at distance $k$ from each other, to count the number of paths in $G$. <br />In this article we give Hosoya polynomial of the line graph of the polygonal cylinder $C_{m,n}$, which is constructed using Cartesian product of paths $P_{m}$ and $P_{n}$ and using topological identification of vertices and edges of two opposite sides of $P_{m}\\times P_{n}$. Depending on odd and even $m$, the polynomial is covered in fourteen separate cases. Finally, we give geometric representation to understand the behavior of this polynomial.</p>	string

1825	en_US	title	Archimedean toroidal maps and their minimal almost regular covers	string
1825	en_US	cleanTitle	Archimedean toroidal maps and their minimal almost regular covers	string
1825	en_US	abstract	<p>The automorphism group of a map acts naturally on its flags (triples of incident vertices, edges, and faces). An Archimedean map on the torus is called almost regular if it has as few flag orbits as possible for its type; for example, a map of type <span class="math inline">(4.8<sup>2</sup>)</span> is called almost regular if it has exactly three flag orbits. Given a map of a certain type, we will consider other more symmetric maps that cover it. In this paper, we prove that each Archimedean toroidal map has a unique minimal almost regular cover. By using the Gaussian and Eisenstein integers, along with previous results regarding equivelar maps on the torus, we construct these minimal almost regular covers explicitly.</p>	string

1826	en_US	abstract	In this paper, we focus on combining the theories of interval-valued fuzzy soft sets over semigroups, and establishing a new framework for interval-valued fuzzy soft semigroups. 1828	en_US	title	Automorphisms of the moduli space of Higgs pairs over a compact Riemann surface	string
1828	en_US	cleanTitle	Automorphisms of the moduli space of Higgs pairs over a compact Riemann surface	string
1828	en_US	abstract	Let $X$ be a compact Riemann surface of genus $g\\geq 2$, $G$ be a complex reductive Lie group and $\\rho:G\\rightarrow\\Gl(V)$ be a faithful complex representation of $G$. In this work we define certain automorphisms of the moduli space of $(G,\\rho)$-Higgs pairs, describe the fixed points subvarieties of those automorphisms and particularize the study to certain types of $(\\Sl(n,\\mathbb{C}),\\rho)$-Higgs pairs. The fixed points obtained in these cases can be described as certain types of orthogonal or symplectic Higgs pairs. 1829	en_US	title	On the Shannon entropy of the number of vertices with zero in-degree in randomly oriented hypergraphs	string
1829	en_US	cleanTitle	On the Shannon entropy of the number of vertices with zero indegree in randomly oriented hypergraphs	string
1829	en_US	abstract	<p class="p1">Suppose that you have $n$ colours and $m$<span class="Apple-converted-space">  </span>mutually independent dice, each of which has $r$ sides.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span>Each dice lands on any of its sides with equal probability. You may colour the sides of each die in any way you wish, but there is one restriction: you are not allowed to use the same colour more than once on the sides of a die. Any other colouring is allowed. Let $X$ be the number of different colours that you see after rolling the dice. How should you colour the sides of the dice in order to maximize the Shannon entropy of $X$? In this article we investigate this question. It is shown that the entropy of $X$ is at most $\\frac{1}{2} \\log(n) + \\frac{1}{2}\\log(\\pi e)$ and that the bound is tight, up to a constant additive factor, in the case of there being equally many coins and colours. Our proof employs<span class="Apple-converted-space">  </span>the differential entropy bound on discrete entropy, along with a lower bound on the entropy of binomial random variables whose outcome is conditioned to be an even integer. We conjecture that the entropy is maximized when the colours are distributed<span class="Apple-converted-space">  </span>over the sides of the dice as evenly as possible.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span></p>	string
1829	en_US	discipline	Probability	string

1829	en_US	subject	Shannon entropy; randomly oriented hypergraphs	string

1833	en_US	title	The Adjacency Graph Determined by a Given Hypergraph	string
1833	en_US	cleanTitle	The Adjacency Graph Determined by a Given Hypergraph	string
1833	en_US	abstract	<p>Adjacency graph is a graph obtained from a hypergraph whose vertex set is the<br />vertex set of that hypergraph and any two vertices are adjacent in adjacency graph if and only if they are adjacent in the hypergraph. With the help of this adjacency graph this paper established some results. Concept of bipartite in hypergraph is generalized into a general concept named n-partite and mentioned a problem in connection with the characterization of n-partite hypergraph. Two newly concepts strongly bipartite and strongly stable set is introduced. This article introduced complement and self complement of hypergraph and established some results<br />with the help of adjacency graph. In the last section, adjacent degree and strong chromatic number of a hypergraph is introduced and established some results from know results</p>	string

1836	en_US	abstract	A vertex subset $W\\subseteq  V$ of the graph $G = (V,E)$ is an independence dominating set if every vertex in $V\\setminus W$ is adjacent to at least one vertex in $W$ and the vertices of $W$ are pairwise non-adjacent. <br />We enumerate independence dominating sets  in several classes<br />of graphs made by a linear or cyclic concatenation of basic building blocks.  Explicit recurrences are derived for  the number of  independence dominating sets  of these kind of graphs. 1838	en_US	title	Co-minimal ideal graphs of commutative rings	string
1838	en_US	cleanTitle	Cominimal ideal graphs of commutative rings	string
1838	en_US	abstract	Given two ideals $I$ and $J$ of a commutative ring $R$, there are two extreme connections between $I$ and $J$:<br />$I+J=R$ and $I\\bigcap J=\\{0\\}$. For the former case, one has defined the graph whose vertices are the proper ideals of $R$ and two vertices are adjacent if and only if their sum is the whole ring $R$, which is known as the co-maximal ideal graph. In this paper, we introduce a new kind of graph structure on $R$, called  co-minimal ideal graph, according to the second case: Its vertices are the nonzero ideals of $R$ and two vertices are adjacent if and only if their intersection is zero. Some important graph parameters (including girth, diameter, clique number and chromatic number) and graph structures (including tree and bipartite graph)<br />of co-minimal ideal graphs over finite commutative rings are studied. In particular, we show that the co-maximal ideal graphs and the co-minimal ideal graphs over<br />$R$ are isomorphic if and only if the number of maximal ideals of $R$ and   the number of minimal ideals of $R$ coincide.	string

1839	en_US	abstract	Face-Centred Cubic Lattice $FCC(n)$ has attracted large attention in recent years owing to its distinguished properties and non-toxic nature, low-cost, abundance, and simple fabrication process. A topological  index of a   chemical graph $G$ is a  numeric  quantity related to $G$ which   describes  its topological properties.   In  this  paper, using graph theory tools, we   determine the topological indices namely,  Zagreb types indices, Forgotten index, Balaban index, fourth version of atom bond connectivity index and fifth version of geometric arithmetic index     for Face-Centred Cubic Lattice $FCC(n)$.	string

1847	en_US	title	METHOD OF OPTIMIZING THE RULE BASE IN THE SUGENO FUZZY INFERENCE SYSTEM USING FUZZY CLUSTER ANALYSIS	string
1847	en_US	cleanTitle	METHOD OF OPTIMIZING THE RULE BASE IN THE SUGENO FUZZY INFERENCE SYSTEM USING FUZZY CLUSTER ANALYSIS	string
1847	en_US	abstract	<p>In this paper developed a method of optimizing the rule base in the Sugeno type fuzzy inference system using fuzzy cluster analysis for design problems of control systems for complex technical objects. A hybrid control model with sequential interaction of classical and fuzzy controllers is used to validate the results. In the developed adaptive system of neuro-fuzzy inference, the rule base of the fuzzy controller is automatically formed on the basis of knowledge about the object obtained when it is controlled by the classical controller, which excludes the expert's participation in the formation of the rule base. The optimization problem is solved using the developed method of grouping the values of the input and output signals in order to reduce the number of rules and increase the speed of the control system of the technical object. The FCM clustering algorithm is used to group values. As a result of the algorithm operation, not all of the set input actions arrive to the fuzzy controller input. Only cluster centers arrive by fuzzy sets arrive, and the boundaries between clusters are also fuzzy. The effectiveness of the proposed grouping method for ensuring effective control of a complex technical object under conditions of uncertainty is proved.</p>	string

1853	en_US	title	Counterexamples for Some Conjectures of Finite Groups	string
1853	en_US	cleanTitle	Counterexamples for Some Conjectures of Finite Groups	string
1853	en_US	abstract	<p>For finite group $G$, let $\\pi_e(G)$ be the set of group element orders. The order classes of $G$ is dened to be the collection of all pairs $[k,m]$, where $k\\in \\pi_e(G)$ and $m$ is number of elements in $G$ of order $k$ and denoted by $OC(G)$ [3]. Two finite groups $G$ and $H$ are said to be of the same order type if $OC(G) = OC(H)$. In 2009, Vasilev et al. [7] showed that, two simple groups G1 and G2 of the same order type are isomorphic. One of our examples in this research is to show that this is not true for none-simple groups. Moreover, for none-simple groups, many properties can not be held by the two orders (the group order and the element orders). Also, we will answer an open problem found in [6].</p>	string

1860	en_US	title	An equivalent formulation of the Fan-Raspaud Conjecture and related problems	string
1860	en_US	cleanTitle	An equivalent formulation of the FanRaspaud Conjecture and related problems	string
1860	en_US	abstract	<p>In 1994, it was conjectured by Fan and Raspaud that every simple bridgeless cubic graph has three perfect matchings whose intersection is empty. In this paper we answer a question recently proposed by Mkrtchyan and Vardanyan, by giving an equivalent formulation of the Fan-Raspaud Conjecture. We also study a possibly weaker conjecture originally proposed by the first author, which states that in every simple bridgeless cubic graph there exist two perfect matchings such that the complement of their union is a bipartite graph. Here, we show that this conjecture can be equivalently stated using a variant of Petersen-colourings, we prove it for graphs having oddness at most four and we give a natural extension to bridgeless cubic multigraphs and to certain cubic graphs having bridges.</p>	string

1863	en_US	title	Nested Block Design as Key Predistribution in Wireless Sensor Networks	string
1863	en_US	cleanTitle	Nested Block Design as Key Predistribution in Wireless Sensor Networks	string
1863	en_US	abstract	An accumulation of wireless sensor nodes is combined together to form the Wireless Sensor Networks. The sensor nodes are distributed haphazardly without any decided method into a natural setting, which is generally inhospitable and it is difficult to provide key-chains to each nodes for security as they are haphazardly distributed. In this paper, we use Nested Block Design (NBD) and found out that NBD support large networks with less keys in each node than Symmetric Balanced Incomplete Block Designs (SBIBD) and Transversal Design (TD$(2,k,q)$), provide higher resiliency than SBIBDs and better connectivity than TD$(2,k,q)$, trade off between local connectivity and resiliency ($\\rho$) is lower than SBIBD but more than TD$(2,k,q)$ and key-node ratio ($\\sigma$) is same for $TD(2,k,q)$ but lower than SBIBD.	string

1867	en_US	title	On Some Algebraic Properties of the Wilson Loop	string
1867	en_US	cleanTitle	On Some Algebraic Properties of the Wilson Loop	string
1867	en_US	abstract	The latest developments in algebra and graph theory allow us to ask a natural question, what is the application in real world of this graph associated with some mathematical system? Groups can be used to construct new non-associative algebraic structures, loops. Graph theory plays an important role in various fields through the concept of loop.  In this article some algebraic properties of the Wilson loop have been investigated in a broad manner. These properties include identities, autotopisms and implications. We use some equivalent conditions to study the behavior of holomorphism of this loop. Under the shadow of this holomorphism we are able to observe coincident loops.	string

1869	en_US	title	Mapification of <i>n</i>-dimensional abstract polytopes and hypertopes	string
1869	en_US	cleanTitle	Mapification of <i>n</i>dimensional abstract polytopes and hypertopes	string
1869	en_US	abstract	<p>The <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span>-dimensional abstract polytopes and hypertopes, particularly the regular ones, have gained great popularity over recent years. The main focus of research has been their symmetries and regularity. The planification of a polyhedron helps its spatial construction, yet it destroys symmetries. No “planification” of <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span>-dimensional polytopes do exist, however it is possible to make a “mapification” of an <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span>-dimensional polytope; in other words it is possible to construct a restrictedly-marked map representation of an abstract polytope on some surface that describes its combinatorial structures as well as all of its symmetries. There are infinitely many ways to do this, yet there is one that is more natural that describes reflections on the sides of <span class="math inline">(<em>n</em> − 1)</span>-simplices (flags or <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span>-flags) with reflections on the sides of <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span>-gons. The restrictedly-marked map representation of an abstract polytope is a cellular embedding of the flag graph of a polytope. We illustrate this construction with the <span class="math inline">4</span>-cube, a regular <span class="math inline">4</span>-polytope with automorphism group of size <span class="math inline">384</span>. This paper pays a tribute to Lynne James’ last work on map representations.</p>	string

1874	en_US	title	On distance signless Laplacian Estrada index and energy of graphs	string
1874	en_US	cleanTitle	On distance signless Laplacian Estrada index and energy of graphs	string
1874	en_US	abstract	For a connected graph $G$, the distance signless Laplacian matrix is defined as $D^{Q}(G)=Tr(G)+D(G)$, where $D(G)$ is the distance matrix of $G$ and $Tr(G)$ is the diagonal matrix of vertex transmissions of $G$. The eigenvalues $\\rho_{1}, \\rho_{2}, \\ldots , \\rho_{n}$ of $D^{Q}(G)$ are the distance signless Laplacian eigenvalues of the graph $G$. In this paper, we define the distance signless Laplacian Estrada index of the graph $G$ as $D^{Q}_{E}E(G)=\\sum_{i=1}^{n}e^{\\big(\\rho_{i}-\\frac{2\\sigma(G)}{n}\\big)}$, where $\\sigma(G)$ is the transmission of a graph $G$. We obtain upper and lower bounds for $D^{Q}_{E}E(G)$ and the distance signless Laplacian energy in terms of other graph invariants. Further, we derive some relations between $D^{Q}_{E}E(G)$ and the distance signless Laplacian energy of $G$.	string

1879	en_US	title	On the complexity for graphs with equal domination number and independence number	string
1879	en_US	cleanTitle	On the complexity for graphs with equal domination number and independence number	string
1879	en_US	abstract	<p>A subset $S$ of vertices of a graph $G$ is called a dominating set<br />if every vertex not in $S$ is adjacent to a vertex in $S$. The<br />domination number of $G$ is the minimum cardinality of a<br />dominating set of $G$.</p><p>A subset $S$ of vertices of a graph $G$ is<br />called an independent set if no pair of vertices of $S$ are<br />adjacent. The independence number of $G$ is the maximum<br />cardinality of an independent set of $G$.</p><p>An independent<br />dominating set of $G$ is a set that is both dominating set<br />and independent set. The independent domination number of<br />$G$ is the minimum cardinality of an<br />independent dominating set of $G$.</p><p><br /> It this paper we show<br />that the problem of deciding whether a graph has equal domination<br />number and independence number is NP-hard even when restricted to<br /> chordal graphs.<br />Then, we give a linear algorithm that decides whether<br /> a given bipartite graph has equal domination<br />number and independence number.<br /> Also, we show<br /> that the problem of deciding whether a graph has equal domination<br /> number and independent domination number or<br /> independent domination number and independence number<br /> is NP-hard even when restricted to<br /> chordal or bipartite graphs.</p>	string

1881	en_US	title	Grundy domination and zero forcing in Kneser graphs	string
1881	en_US	cleanTitle	Grundy domination and zero forcing in Kneser graphs	string
1881	en_US	abstract	<p>In this paper, we continue the investigation of different types of (Grundy) dominating sequences. We consider four different types of Grundy domination numbers and the related zero forcing numbers, focusing on these numbers in the well-known class of Kneser graphs <span class="math inline"><em>K</em><sub><em>n</em>, <em>r</em></sub></span>. In particular, we establish that the Grundy total domination number <span class="math inline"><em>γ</em><sub><em>gr</em></sub><sup><em>t</em></sup>(<em>K</em><sub><em>n</em>, <em>r</em></sub>)</span> equals <span class="math inline">(2<em>r</em> choose <em>r</em>)</span> for any <span class="math inline"><em>r</em> ≥ 2</span> and <span class="math inline"><em>n</em> ≥ 2<em>r</em> + 1</span>. For the Grundy domination number of Kneser graphs we get <span class="math inline"><em>γ</em><sub><em>gr</em></sub>(<em>K</em><sub><em>n</em>, <em>r</em></sub>) = <em>α</em>(<em>K</em><sub><em>n</em>, <em>r</em></sub>)</span> whenever <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span> is sufficiently larger than <span class="math inline"><em>r</em></span>. On the other hand, the zero forcing number <span class="math inline"><em>Z</em>(<em>K</em><sub><em>n</em>, <em>r</em></sub>)</span> is proved to be <span class="math inline">(<em>n</em> choose <em>r</em>) − (2<em>r</em> choose <em>r</em>)</span> when <span class="math inline"><em>n</em> ≥ 3<em>r</em> + 1</span> and <span class="math inline"><em>r</em> ≥ 2</span>, while lower and upper bounds are provided for <span class="math inline"><em>Z</em>(<em>K</em><sub><em>n</em>, <em>r</em></sub>)</span> when <span class="math inline">2<em>r</em> + 1 ≤ <em>n</em> ≤ 3<em>r</em></span>. Some lower bounds for different types of minimum ranks of Kneser graphs are also obtained along the way.</p>	string

1882	en_US	title	Consecutive colouring of oriented graphs	string
1882	en_US	cleanTitle	Consecutive colouring of oriented graphs	string
1882	en_US	abstract	We consider arc colourings of oriented graphs in which the colours of all out-arcs incident with each vertex and the colours of all in-arcs incident with each vertex form intervals. We prove that the existence of such a colouring is NP-complete problem. We give the solution of the problem for circulant or r-regular oriented graphs, transitive tournaments, oriented graphs with small maximum degree, small order and some others. We state the conjecture that for each graph there exists its consecutive colourable orientation and confirm the conjecture for complete graphs, 2-degenerate graphs, planar graphs with girth at least 8, bipartite graphs with arboricity less than three including all planar bipartite graphs. Additionally, we prove that the conjecture is true for all perfect consecutively colourable graphs and for all forbidden graphs for the class of perfect consecutively colourable graphs.	string

1883	en_US	title	On the status sequences of trees	string
1883	en_US	cleanTitle	On the status sequences of trees	string
1883	en_US	abstract	The status of a vertex v in a connected graph is the sum of the distances from v to all other vertices. The status sequence of a connected graph is the list of the statuses of all the vertices of the graph. In this paper we investigate the status sequences of trees. Particularly, we show that it is NP-complete to decide whether there exists a tree that has a given sequence of integers as its status sequence. We also present some results about trees whose status sequences are comprised of a few distinct numbers or many distinct numbers. In this direction, we provide a partial answer to a conjecture of Shang and Lin from 2011, showing that any status injective tree is unique among trees. Finally, we investigate how orbit partitions and equitable partitions relate to the status sequence.	string

1884	en_US	title	The finite embeddability property for IP loops and local embeddability of groups into finite IP loops	string
1884	en_US	cleanTitle	The finite embeddability property for IP loops and local embeddability of groups into finite IP loops	string
1884	en_US	abstract	We prove that the class of all loops with the inverse property (IP loops) has the Finite Embeddability Property (FEP). As a consequence, every group is locally embeddable into finite IP loops. The first one of these results is obtained as a consequence of a more general embeddability theorem, contributing to a list of problems posed by T. Evans in 1978, namely, that every finite partial IP loop can be embedded into a finite IP loop.	string

1891	en_US	abstract	<p>In this article, we study flag-transitive automorphism groups of non-trivial symmetric <span class="math inline">(<em>v</em>, <em>k</em>, <em>λ</em>)</span> designs, where <span class="math inline"><em>λ</em></span> divides <span class="math inline"><em>k</em></span> and <span class="math inline"><em>k</em> ≥ <em>λ</em><sup>2</sup></span>. 1892	en_US	title	On separable abelian <i>p</i>-groups	string

1892	en_US	abstract	<p>An <span class="math inline"><em>S</em></span>-ring (a Schur ring) is said to be <em>separable</em> with respect to a class of groups <span class="math inline"><strong><em>K</em></strong></span> if every algebraic isomorphism from the <span class="math inline"><em>S</em></span>-ring in question to an <span class="math inline"><em>S</em></span>-ring over a group from <span class="math inline"><strong><em>K</em></strong></span> is induced by a combinatorial isomorphism. 2175	en_US	abstract	In this paper, we propose a kind of triangle related to the Pascal triangle that we call \\textit{rising-Pascal triangle}. Useful properties, such as recursion relations, symmetry relations of its coefficients and their analogs are established. In addition, a combinatorial interpretations using a type of polynomial functions, lattice paths and tiling are given.	string

1895	en_US	title	The generalization of Gallai's Lemma	string
1895	en_US	cleanTitle	The generalization of Gallai's Lemma	string
1895	en_US	abstract	<p>Gallai's Lemma states that if a graph $G$ satisfies $\\nu(G-u)=\\nu(G)$ for any $u\\in V(G)$ then $G$ is factor-critical. In this paper, we present sufficient conditions of perfect matching and near prefect matching, respectively. As an application, we generalize Gallai's Lemma and obtain that a $p$-connected graph $G$ of order $n$ is $p$-factor-critical if and only if $\\nu(G-S)=\\nu(G)-\\lfloor\\frac p2\\rfloor$ for any $S\\subset V(G)$ with $|S|=p$, where $p$ and $n$ have the same parity and $n&gt;p\\geq 1$.</p>	string

1896	en_US	abstract	<p>A vertex irregular total $k$-labeling $\\varphi:V(G)\\cup E(G)\\rightarrow \\{1,2,3, \\dots, k\\}$ such that the vertex weights $wt_{\\varphi}(x)=\\varphi(x)+\\sum\\limits_{y\\in N(x)}\\varphi(xy)$ (where $N(x)$ is the set of neighbors of $x$) are distinct for all vertices, i.e $wt_{\\varphi}(x)\\ne wt_{\\varphi}(x')$ for all vertices $x, x'\\in V(G)$ with $x\\ne x'$. 1898	en_US	title	On minimum leaf spanning trees and a criticality notion	string
1898	en_US	cleanTitle	On minimum leaf spanning trees and a criticality notion	string
1898	en_US	abstract	The minimum leaf number of a connected non-hamiltonian graph G is the number of leaves of a spanning tree of G with the fewest leaves among all spanning trees of G. Based on this quantity, Wiener introduced leaf-stable and leaf-critical graphs, concepts which generalise hypotraceability and hypohamiltonicity. In this article, we present new methods to construct leaf-stable and leaf-critical graphs and study their properties. Furthermore, we improve several bounds related to these families of graphs. These extend previous results of Horton, Thomassen, and Wiener.	string

1899	en_US	title	Hamiltonicity of some Cayley graphs whose order has two distinct prime factors	string
1899	en_US	cleanTitle	Hamiltonicity of some Cayley graphs whose order has two distinct prime factors	string
1899	en_US	abstract	<p>The "Hamiltonian Cycle Problem" is one of the most fundamental problems in Graph Theory which has applications in many fields such as computer networking, computer graphics, combinatorics, coding theory, electric circuit designing etc. The problem of finding Hamiltonian cycles can be studied in all kinds of graphs and this study focuses on Cayley graphs which is a type of vertex transitive graphs. In this paper, an extension of the results related to the Hamiltonicity of Cayley graphs of groups whose order has few prime factors is presented. In particular, the existence of a Hamiltonian cycle in the Cayley graphs of semidirect product of Zp X Zp by Zq, where p and q are distinct<br />primes with p not equat to 2, with respect to the generating set S ={s, t1, t2} with orders of t1, t2 being p and order of s being q is proved. The<br />proof is then extended to Cayley graphs of semidirect products of Zp{^n} by Zq, where n is a positive integer and n is greater than or equal to 2 with respect to analogous generating sets.<br />Moreover, the existence of a Hamiltonian cycle in every connected Cayley graph of groups of order p^2q, where p and q are distinct primes, except for the isomorphism type of semidirect product of Zp X Zp by Zq is shown by the existing literature and our results prove Hamiltonicity of Cayley graphs of  semidirect product of Zp X Zp by Zq with respect to the generating set S mentioned above.</p>	string

1903	en_US	title	Bounding the minimal number of generators of groups of cellular automata	string
1903	en_US	cleanTitle	Bounding the minimal number of generators of groups of cellular automata	string
1903	en_US	abstract	For a group $G$ and a finite set $A$, denote by $\\CA(G;A)$ the monoid of all cellular automata over $A^G$ and by $\\ICA(G;A)$ its group of units. We study the minimal cardinality of a generating set, known as the rank, of $\\ICA(G;A)$. In the first part, when $G$ is a finite group, we give upper bounds for the rank in terms of the number of conjugacy classes of subgroups of $G$. The case when $G$ is a finite cyclic group has been studied before, so here we focus on the cases when $G$ is a finite dihedral group or a finite Dedekind group. In the second part, we find a basic lower bound for the rank of $\\ICA(G;A)$ when $G$ is a finite group, and we apply this to show that, for any infinite abelian group $H$, the monoid $\\CA(H;A)$ is not finitely generated. The same is true for various kinds of infinite groups, so we ask if there exists an infinite group $H$ such that $\\CA(H;A)$ is finitely generated.	string

1904	en_US	abstract	<p>The boundary-value problem for a second order singularly perturbed Fredholm integro-differential equation was considered in this paper. For the numerical solution of this problem, we use an exponentially fitted difference scheme on an uniform mesh which is succeeded by the method of integral identities with the use of exponential basis functions and interpolating quadrature rules with the weight and remainder terms in integral form. 1905	en_US	title	The Distance Laplacian and Distance Signless Laplacian Spectrum of the subdivision vertex join and subdivision edge join of two regular graphs	string
1905	en_US	cleanTitle	The Distance Laplacian and Distance Signless Laplacian Spectrum of the subdivision vertex join and subdivision edge join of two regular graphs	string
1905	en_US	abstract	Let $G$ be a connected graph with a distance matrix $D$. Let $D^L(G)= Diag(Tr)-D(G)$ and $D^Q(G)=Diag(Tr)+D(G)$ be, respectively, the distance laplacian matrix and the distance signless laplacian matrix of graph $G$, where $Diag(Tr)$ denotes the diagonal matrix of the vertex transmissions in $G$. The eigenvalues of $D^L(G)$ and $D^Q(G)$ constitute the distance laplacian spectrum and distance signless laplacian spectrum respectively. The subdivision graph $S(G)$ of a graph $G$ is obtained by inserting a new vertex into every edge of $G$. We denote the set of such new vertices by $I(G)$. The subdivision- vertex join of two vertex disjoint graphs $G_1$ and $G_2$ denoted by $G_1 \\dot{\\vee}  G_2$, is the graph obtained from $S(G_1)$ and $G_2$ by joining each vertex of $V(G_1)$ with every vertex of $V(G_2)$. The subdivision-edge join of two vertex disjoint graphs $G_1$ and $G_2$ denoted by $G_1 \\underline{\\vee} G_2$, is the graph obtained from $S(G_1)$ and $G_2$ by joining each vertex of $I(G_1)$ with every vertex of $V(G_2)$. In this paper, we determine the distance laplacian and distance signless laplacian  spectra of subdivision-vertex join and subdivision - edge join of a connected regular graph with an arbitrary regular graph in terms of their eigenvalues. As an application we exhibit some infinite families of cospectral graphs and find the respective spectra of the Jahangir graph $J_{2,n}$.	string

1907	en_US	abstract	<p>Carlitz defined the degenerate Bernoulli polynomials <span class="math inline"><em>β</em><sub><em>n</em></sub>(<em>λ</em>, <em>x</em>)</span> by means of the generating function <span class="math inline"><em>t</em>((1 + <em>λ</em><em>t</em>)<sup>1/<em>λ</em></sup> − 1)<sup>−1</sup>(1 + <em>λ</em><em>t</em>)<sup><em>x</em>/<em>λ</em></sup></span>. 1908	en_US	title	The distance spectrum of two new operations of graphs	string
1908	en_US	cleanTitle	The distance spectrum of two new operations of graphs	string
1908	en_US	abstract	Let $G$ be a connected graph with vertex set $V(G)=\\{v_1,v_2,\\cdots,v_n\\}$. The distance matrix $D=D(G)$ of $G$ is defined so that its $(i,j)$-entry is equal to the distance $d_G(v_i,v_j)$ between the vertices $v_i$ and $v_j$ of $G$. The eigenvalues ${\\mu_1,\\mu_2,\\cdots,\\mu_n}$ of $D(G)$ are the $D$-eigenvalues of $G$ and form the distance spectrum or the $D$-spectrum of $G$, denoted by $Spec_D(G)$. In this paper, we introduce two new operations $G_1\\blacksquare_k G_2$ and $G_1\\blacklozenge_k G_2$ on graphs $G_1$ and $G_2$, and describe the distance spectra of $G_1\\blacksquare_k G_2$ and $G_1\\blacklozenge_k G_2$ of regular graphs $G_1$ and $G_2 $ in terms of their adjacency spectra. By using these results, we obtain some new integral adjacency spectrum graphs, integral distance spectrum graphs and a number of families of sets of noncospectral graphs with equal distance energy.	string

1909	en_US	title	The regular graph of a finite dimensional vector space	string
1909	en_US	cleanTitle	The regular graph of a finite dimensional vector space	string
1909	en_US	abstract	In this paper, we introduce a graph structure, called regular graph $\\mathscr{R}(\\mathscr{V})$ on a finite dimensional vector space $\\mathscr{V}$ where the vertex set is the set of non-zero vectors of $\\mathscr{V}$ and two vertices $u$ and $v$ of $\\mathscr{R}(\\mathscr{V})$ are adjacent if and only if the set $\\{u,v\\}$ is linearly independent. The connectedness, diameter, girth, clique number, chromatic number of $\\mathscr{R}(\\mathscr{V})$ are studied, the beck conjecture for $\\mathscr{R}(\\mathscr{V})$ has also been proved. It is shown that two Regular graphs  $\\mathscr{R}(\\mathscr{V}_{1})$ and $\\mathscr{R}(\\mathscr{V}_{2})$ are isomorphic if and only if $\\mathscr{V}_{1}$ and $\\mathscr{V}_{2}$ are of same dimension.	string

1910	en_US	abstract	The system of nonlinear neutral difference equations with delays  in the following form<br />\\begin{displaymath} <br />\\left\\{\\begin{array}{l}<br />\\Delta \\Big(x_i(n)+p_i(n)\\,x_i(n-\\tau_i)\\Big)=a_i(n)\\,f_i(x_{i+1}(n))+g_i(n),\\\\<br />\\Delta \\Big(x_k(n)+p_k(n)\\,x_k(n-\\tau_k)\\Big)=a_k(n)\\,f_k(x_1(n))+g_k(n),<br />\\end{array}\\right.<br />\\end{displaymath}<br />where $i=1,\\dots,k-1$,  $k\\geq 2$, is considered. The sufficient conditions for the existence of an asymptotically periodic solution of the above system are established. Here sequences $(p_i(n))$, $i=1,\\dots,k$, are bounded away from -1.	string

1911	en_US	title	A result on fractional (a,b,k)-critical covered graphs	string
1911	en_US	cleanTitle	A result on fractional abkcritical covered graphs	string
1911	en_US	abstract	<p>For a graph $G$, the set of vertices in $G$ is denoted by $V(G)$, and the set of edges in $G$ is denoted by $E(G)$.<br />A fractional $[a,b]$-factor of a graph $G$ is a function $h$ from $E(G)$ to $[0,1]$ satisfying $a\\leq d_G^{h}(v)\\leq b$ for<br />every vertex $v$ of $G$, where $d_G^{h}(v)=\\sum\\limits_{e\\in E(v)}{h(e)}$ and $E(v)=\\{e=uv:u\\in V(G)\\}$. A graph $G$ is called<br />fractional $[a,b]$-covered if $G$ contains a fractional $[a,b]$-factor $h$ with $h(e)=1$ for any edge $e$ of $G$. A graph $G$<br />is called fractional $(a,b,k)$-critical covered if $G-Q$ is fractional $[a,b]$-covered for any $Q\\subseteq V(G)$ with $|Q|=k$.<br />In this article, we demonstrate a neighborhood condition for a graph to be fractional $(a,b,k)$-critical covered. Furthermore,<br />we claim that the result is sharp.</p>	string

1912	en_US	abstract	Directed candelabra quadruple systems ($DCQS_{\\lambda}(g^{n}:s)$s) are the extension of candelabra quadruple systems, and they are useful in recursive constructions of building directed quadruple systems. In this paper, we give the necessary conditions for the existence of a $DCQS_{\\lambda}(g^{n}:s)$. By using some recursive and direct constructions, we prove that the necessary conditions are also sufficient for $n\\geq2, s=0$ and $n=3,4,5, 0&lt;s\\leq g(n-2)$ with the possible exceptions for $n=3,5, \\lambda\\equiv1 \\pmod 2, g\\equiv1 \\pmod 2,~s\\equiv1 \\pmod 2, 0&lt;s\\leq g(n-2)$.	string

1913	en_US	cleanTitle	Vertex connectivity of line graph of \\Gamma\\mathbb{Z}_n	string
1913	en_US	abstract	Line graph of zero divisor graph of $\\mathbb{Z}_n$ was introduced in 2005 and is denoted by $L(\\Gamma(\\mathbb{Z}_n))$. The line graph $L(\\Gamma(G))$ of a zero divisor graph $\\Gamma(G)$ is defined as a graph with vertex set $V(L(\\Gamma(G)))=E(G)$ i.e., vertices of line graph $L(G)$ represents an edge of $G$, and distinct vertices in $L(G)$ are connected if and only if their corresponding edges in $G$ share a common vertex. $$V(L(G))=\\{(a,b) \\mid a.b=0,\\ a \\mbox { and } \\ b \\mbox{ are non-zero zero divisors of } G \\}.$$ In this article, we derive a relation to find the vertex connectivity of $L(\\Gamma(\\mathbb{Z}_n))$ for $n=pq$ and $p^n$, where $p$, $q$ are any prime numbers.\\\\	string

1914	en_US	title	Metric dimension of generalized Franklin and Dodecahedron graphs	string
1914	en_US	cleanTitle	Metric dimension of generalized Franklin and Dodecahedron graphs	string
1914	en_US	abstract	<span>Let $G$ be a connected graph and $d(x, y)$ be the distance between the<br />vertices $x$ and $y$. A subset of vertices $W =<br />\\{w_1,w_2,\\cdots,w_k\\}$ is called a resolving set for $G$ if for<br />every two distinct vertices $x,y\\in V(G)$, there is a vertex $w_i\\in<br />W$ such that $d(x,w_i)\\neq d(y,w_i)$. A resolving set containing a<br />minimum number of vertices is called a metric basis for $G$ and the<br />number of vertices in a metric basis is its metric dimension<br />$dim(G)$.\\\\<br />The metric dimension of some classes of plane graphs has been<br />determined in [3-5, 10, 12, 15, 22], while metric<br />dimension of some classes of convex polytopes has been studied in<br />[10]. In this paper we extended the study by considering generalized Franklin<br />graph $Fr_{n}$ and Dodecahedron graph $Dd_n$.</span>	string

1918	en_US	title	Finite, fiber- and orientation-preserving group actions on totally orientable Seifert manifolds	string
1918	en_US	cleanTitle	Finite fiber and orientationpreserving group actions on totally orientable Seifert manifolds	string
1918	en_US	abstract	In this paper we consider the finite groups that act fiber- and orientation-preservingly on orientable Seifert manifolds that fiber over an orientable base space without boundary. We establish a method of constructing such group actions and then show that if an action satisfies a condition on the obstruction term of the Seifert manifold, it can be derived from the given construction. The obstruction condition is refined and the general structure of the finite groups that act via the construction is provided.	string

1919	en_US	title	Decompositions of Some Classes of Regular Graphs and Digraphs into Cycles of Length $4p$	string
1919	en_US	cleanTitle	Decompositions of Some Classes of Regular Graphs and Digraphs into Cycles of Length 4p	string
1919	en_US	abstract	In this paper, we prove the existence of a $4p$-cycle decomposition of the graph $K_m\\times K_n$ and a directed $4p$-cycle decomposition of the symmetric digraph $(K_m\\circ \\overline{K}_n)^*$, where $\\circ$ and $\\times$ denote the wreath product and tensor product of graphs,  respectively, and $p$ is a prime. It is proved that for $m,\\,n\\geq 3$, the obvious necessary conditions for the existence of a $4p$-cycle decomposition of $K_m\\times K_n$ are sufficient, where $p$ is a prime. Also, it is shown that the necessary conditions for the existence of a directed $4p$-cycle decomposition of the symmetric digraph $(K_m\\circ \\overline{K}_n)^*$ are sufficient, where $p$ is an odd prime. Recently, the same type of results are obtained for $2p$ (see Discrete Math. 341 (2018) 2197-2210).	string

1920	en_US	abstract	<p>For a finite group $G$ and a generating set $C$ of $G$, let<br />$\\Aut(G;C)$ consist of group automorphisms of $G$ which preserves<br />$C$ setwise, and let $G_R$ be the right regular representation of $G$. The Cayley<br />graph $\\Cay(G,C)$ is called normal edge-transitive, if $G_R\\rtimes<br />\\Aut(G;C)$ acts transitively on edges of $\\Cay(G,C)$.<br />Note that since there is a natural action of $G_R\\rtimes<br />\\Aut(G;C)$ on $G$, we can consider $G$ as $(G_R\\rtimes<br />\\Aut(G;C))$-group. Using this algebraic structure and universal algebra methods, we answer three well-known<br />questions about normal edge-transitive Cayley graphs which are posed<br />by Praeger.</p>	string

1925	en_US	abstract	<p>Let <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> be a graph and let <span class="math inline">Γ</span> be its group of automorphisms. Graovac-Pisanski index of <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> is <span class="math inline">GP(<em>G</em>) = |<em>V</em>(<em>G</em>)| / (2|Γ|) ∑<sub><em>u</em> ∈ <em>V</em>(<em>G</em>)</sub> ∑<sub><em>α</em> ∈ Γ</sub><em> d</em>(<em>u</em>, <em>α</em>(<em>u</em>))</span>, where <span class="math inline"><em>d</em>(<em>u</em>, <em>v</em>)</span> is the distance from <span class="math inline"><em>u</em></span> to <span class="math inline"><em>v</em></span> in <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span>. One can observe that <span class="math inline">GP(<em>G</em>) = 0</span> if <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> has no nontrivial automorphisms, but it is not known which graphs attain the maximum value of Graovac-Pisanski index. In this paper we show that among unicyclic graphs on <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span> vertices the <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span>-cycle attains the maximum value of Graovac-Pisanski index.</p>	string

1926	en_US	title	Decompositions of the automorphism groups of edge-colored graphs	string
1926	en_US	cleanTitle	Decompositions of the automorphism groups of edgecolored graphs	string
1926	en_US	abstract	In the paper <em>Graphical complexity of products of permutation groups</em>,<br />M. Grech, A. Jeż, and A. Kisielewicz have proved that the direct product of automorphism groups of edge-colored graphs is itself the automorphism groups of an edge-colored graph.<br />In this paper, we study the direct product of two permutation groups such that at least one of them fails to be the automorphism group of an edge-colored graph.<br />We find necessary and sufficient conditions for the direct product to be the automorphism group of an edge-colored graph. 1927	en_US	title	ON THE INJECTIVE CHROMATIC INDEX OF GRAPHS	string
1927	en_US	cleanTitle	ON THE INJECTIVE CHROMATIC INDEX OF GRAPHS	string
1927	en_US	abstract	An injective coloring of a graph $ G=(V(G), E(G)) $ is a vertex coloring such that any two vertices with a common vertex receive distinct colors. In this paper, we introduce $k-$ injective edge coloring of a graph as a mapping $C:E(G)\\rightarrow \\{1,2,...,k\\}$, such that for every edge $e\\in E(G)$, all the neighbors edges of $e$ are assigned with distinct colors. The injective chromatic index $\\chi^{'}_{in}(G)$ of $G$ is the least positive integer $k$ such that $G$ has $k-$ injective edge coloring, exact value of the injective chromatic index of different families of graphs is obtained, some related results and bounds are established. Finally, we define the injective clique number $\\omega_{in}$ and state a conjecture, that, for any graph $G$, $\\omega_{in}\\leq\\chi^{'}_{in}(G)\\leq\\omega_{in} +2.$	string

1937	en_US	abstract	<p>Given <span class="math inline"><em>m</em> ∈ ℕ</span>, a numerical semigroup with multiplicity <span class="math inline"><em>m</em></span> is called a packed numerical semigroup if its minimal generating set is included in <span class="math inline">{<em>m</em>, <em>m</em> + 1, …, 2<em>m</em> − 1}</span>. 1943	en_US	title	Strong metric dimension of generalized Jahangir graph	string
1943	en_US	cleanTitle	Strong metric dimension of generalized Jahangir graph	string
1943	en_US	abstract	<p>Let $G$ be a simple and connected graph<br /> with vertex set $V(G)$. A vertex $w\\in V(G)$ strongly resolves two vertices $u,v \\in V(G)$ if  $v$ belongs to a shortest $u-w$ path or<br /> $u$ belongs to a shortest $v-w$ path. A set $W \\subseteq V(G)$ is a strong resolving set for $G$ if every pair of vertices of $G$ is strongly resolved by some vertex of $W$. A strong metric basis of $G$ is a strong resolving set for $G$ with minimum cardinality.  The strong metric dimension of $G$, denoted by $sdim(G)$, is the cardinality of a strong metric basis of $G$. <br /> In this paper we compute the strong metric dimension of generalized <br /> Jahangir graph $J(n,m)$, where $m\\geq 3$ and $n\\geq 2$.</p>	string

1945	en_US	title	Properties of π-Skew Graphs with Applications	string
1945	en_US	cleanTitle	Properties of πSkew Graphs with Applications	string
1945	en_US	abstract	<p>The skewness of a graph $G$, denoted by $sk(G)$, is the minimum number of edges in $G$ whose removal results in a planar graph. It is an important parameter that measures how close a graph is to planarity, and it is complementary, and computationally equivalent, to the Maximum Planar Subgraph Problem. For any connected graph $G$ on $p$ vertices and $q$ edges with girth $g$, one can easily verify that $sk(G)\\ge \\pi(G)$, where $\\pi(G)=\\big\\lceil q-\\frac{g}{g-2}(p-2)\\big\\rceil$, and the graph $G$ is said to be $\\pi$-skew if the equality holds. The $\\pi$-skew graphs with girth 3 are actually such graphs that contain a triangulation as a spanning subgraph. The purpose of this paper is to explore the properties of $\\pi$-skew graphs. Some families of $\\pi$-skew graphs are obtained by applying these properties, including join of two graphs, complete multipartite graphs and Cartesian product of two graphs. We also discuss the threshold for the existence of a spanning triangulation. Among other results some sufficient conditions regarding the minimum degree and size of a graph, which ensure a spanning triangulation, are given.</p>	string
1945	en_US	discipline	mathematics;combinatorics;topological graph theory	string
1945	en_US	subjectClass	05C10; 05C62	string
1945	en_US	subject	Skewness of graph; Cartesian product; Join product; π-skew	string

1946	en_US	title	Bounds for generalized distance spectral radius and the entries of the principal eigenvector	string
1946	en_US	cleanTitle	Bounds for generalized distance spectral radius and the entries of the principal eigenvector	string
1946	en_US	abstract	<p>For a simple connected graph $G$, the convex linear combinations $D_{\\alpha}(G)$ of $Tr(G)$ and $D(G)$ is defined as $D_{\\alpha}(G)=\\alpha Tr(G)+(1-\\alpha)D(G), ~~~~ 0\\leq \\alpha\\leq 1$. As $D_{0}(G)=D(G), ~~~ 2D_{\\frac{1}{2}}(G)=D^{Q}(G), ~~~ D_{1}(G)=Tr(G)$ and $D_{\\alpha}(G)-D_{\\beta}(G)=(\\alpha-\\beta)D^{L}(G)$, this matrix reduces to merging the distance spectral, signless Laplacian spectral and distance signless Laplacian spectral theories. In this paper, we<br />study the spectral properties of the generalized distance matrix $D_{\\alpha}(G)$. We obtain some lower and upper bounds for the generalized distance spectral radius, involving different graph parameters and characterize the extremal graphs. <br />Further, we obtain the upper and lower bounds for the maximal and minimal entries of the $ p $-norm normalized Perron vector corresponding to spectral radius $ \\partial(G) $ of the generalized distance matrix $D_{\\alpha}(G)$ and characterize the extremal graphs.</p>	string

1947	en_US	cleanTitle	Resonance Graphs and Perfect Matchings of Graphs on Surfaces	string
1947	en_US	abstract	<pre>Let <span>$G$</span> be a graph embedded in a surface and let <span>$\\mathcal F$</span> be a set of </pre><pre>even faces of <span>$G$</span> (faces bounded by a cycle of even length). The resonance</pre><pre> graph of <span>$G$</span> with respect to <span>$\\mathcal F$</span>, denoted by  <span>$R(G;\\mathcal F)$</span>,</pre><pre> is a graph such that its vertex set is the set of all perfect matchings of <span>$G$</span></pre><pre> and two vertices <span>$M_1$</span> and <span>$M_2$</span> are adjacent if and only if the </pre><pre>symmetric difference <span>$M_1\\oplus M_2$</span> is a cycle bounding some face in </pre><pre><span>$\\mathcal F$</span>. It has been shown that if <span>$G$</span> is a  plane elementary</pre><pre> bipartite graph, the resonance graph of <span>$G$</span> with respect to the set of </pre><pre>all inner faces is isomorphic to the covering graph of a distributive lattice. </pre><pre>Moreover, it is known that the resonance graph of a plane graph <span>$G$</span> with </pre><pre>respect to an even-face set $\\mathcal F$ may not be the covering graph </pre><pre>of a distributive lattice. In this paper, we show the resonance graph of a </pre><pre>graph $G$ on a surface with respect to a given even-face set </pre><pre>$\\mathcal F$ can always be embedded into a hypercube as an induced </pre><pre>subgraph. Furthermore, we show that the Clar covering polynomial of </pre><pre>$G$ with respect to $\\mathcal F$ is equal to the cube polynomial of the </pre><pre>resonance graph  $R(G;\\mathcal F)$, which generalizes previous results </pre><pre>on some subfamilies of plane graphs.</pre>	string

1949	en_US	title	THE STRONG CHROMATIC INDEX OF PRODUCTS OF SOME GRAPHS	string
1949	en_US	cleanTitle	THE STRONG CHROMATIC INDEX OF PRODUCTS OF SOME GRAPHS	string
1949	en_US	abstract	A strong edge coloring of a graph $G$ is a proper edge coloring of $G$ such that every color class is an induced matching.<br />The minimum number of colors required is termed the strong chromatic index.<br /> In this paper we give tight bounds for the strong chromatic index of the Cartesian product of two trees, also including an exact formula for the product of two stars.<br />Further, we give bounds for the strong chromatic index of the product of a tree with a cycle.<br />For any tree, those bounds differ only by a small additive constant<br /> (at most 2 for even cycles and at most 5 for odd cycles), moreover they<br /> yield the exact value when the length of the cycle is divisible by $4$.	string

1950	en_US	title	On an annihilation number conjecture	string
1950	en_US	cleanTitle	On an annihilation number conjecture	string
1950	en_US	abstract	<p>Let <span class="math inline"><em>α</em>(<em>G</em>)</span> denote the cardinality of a maximum independent set, while <span class="math inline"><em>μ</em>(<em>G</em>)</span> be the size of a maximum matching in the graph <span class="math inline"><em>G</em> = (<em>V</em>,<em>E</em>)</span>. If <span class="math inline"><em>α</em>(<em>G</em>) + <em>μ</em>(<em>G</em>) = |<em>V</em>|</span>, then <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> is a <em>König-Egerváry graph</em>. If <span class="math inline"><em>d</em><sub>1</sub> ≤ <em>d</em><sub>2</sub> ≤ ⋯ ≤ <em>d</em><sub><em>n</em></sub></span> is the degree sequence of <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span>, then the <em>annihilation number</em> <span class="math inline"><em>a</em>(<em>G</em>)</span> of <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> is the largest integer <span class="math inline"><em>k</em></span> such that <span class="math inline">sum<sub><em>i</em> = 1</sub><sup><em>k</em></sup> <em>d</em><sub><em>i</em></sub> ≤ |<em>E</em>|</span>. A set <span class="math inline"><em>A</em> ⊆ <em>V</em></span> satisfying <span class="math inline">∑<sub><em>v</em> ∈ <em>A</em></sub>deg (<em>v</em>) ≤ |<em>E</em>|</span> is an <em>annihilation set</em>; if, in addition, <span class="math inline">deg (<em>x</em>) + ∑<sub><em>v</em> ∈ <em>A</em></sub>deg (<em>v</em>) &gt; |<em>E</em>|</span>, for every vertex <span class="math inline"><em>x</em> ∈ <em>V</em>(<em>G</em>) − <em>A</em></span>, then <span class="math inline"><em>A</em></span> is a <em>maximal annihilation set</em> in <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span>.</p><p>In 2011, Larson and Pepper conjectured that the following assertions are equivalent:</p><p>(i) <span class="math inline"><em>α</em>(<em>G</em>) = <em>a</em>(<em>G</em>)</span>;</p><p>(ii) <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> is a König-Egerváry graph and every maximum independent set is a maximal annihilating set.</p><p>It turns out that the implication “<span class="math inline">(i) ⇒ (ii)</span>” is correct.</p><p>In this paper, we show that the opposite direction is not valid, by providing a series of generic counterexamples.</p>	string

1952	en_US	abstract	<p>‎Let ‎$‎G‎$‎ be a graph of order ‎$‎n‎$‎ with vertices labeled as ‎$‎v_1, v_2, ... , v_n‎$‎. Let ‎$‎d_i‎$‎ be</p><p>the degree of the vertex ‎$‎v_i‎$‎, for ‎$‎i = 1, 2, ..., n‎$‎.</p><p>‎‎The sigma‎ adjacency matrix of ‎$‎G‎$‎</p><p>‎‎‎‎‎‎‎‎ is the square matrix of order $n$ whose $(i‎, ‎j)$-entry is equal to $|d_i-d_j|$ if the‎</p><p>‎vertices $v_i$ and $v_j$ of $G$ are adjacent or $(v_iv_j \\in E(G ))$‎, is equal to ‎$d_i$‎</p><p>‎if $i=j$ and zero otherwise‎.‎‎ In this paper‎, some of the properties of its characteristic polynomial are studied.</p><p>‎We introduce and investigate the sigma energy and sigma</p><p>Estrada index of a graph, both base on the eigenvalues of the sigma matrix and find the formula for them. 1955	en_US	title	Weak-odd edge-colorings of tournaments	string
1955	en_US	cleanTitle	Weakodd edgecolorings of tournaments	string
1955	en_US	abstract	A weak-odd edge-coloring of a digraph $D$ is a (not necessarily proper) coloring of its edges such that for each vertex $v\\in V(D)$ at least one color $c$ satisfies the following: if $d_D^-(v)&gt;0$ then $c$ appears an odd number of times on the ingoing edges at $v$; and if $d_D^+(v)&gt;0$ then $c$ appears an odd number of times on the outgoing edges at $v$. The minimum number of colors sufficient for a weak-odd edge-coloring of $D$ is the weak-odd chromatic index, denoted $\\chi'_{\\mathrm{wo}}(D)$. It is known that $\\chi'_{\\mathrm{wo}}(D)\\leq 3$ for every digraph $D$, and that this bound is sharp. This raises the question whether the weak-odd chromatic index can be determined in polynomial time. In this article we confirm this question for the class of tournaments by characterizing them in terms of the weak-odd chromatic index.	string

1956	en_US	abstract	<p style="margin-bottom: 0in;"><span style="color: #000000;"><span style="font-family: Times New Roman, serif;"><span style="font-size: medium;"><span lang="en-US"><span style="font-style: normal;"><span style="text-decoration: none;"><span style="font-weight: normal;"><span style="background: #ffffff;">We prove two parallel lines are tautologous in Euclidean geometry. 1957	en_US	title	On the general position problem on Kneser graphs	string
1957	en_US	cleanTitle	On the general position problem on Kneser graphs	string
1957	en_US	abstract	<p>In a graph <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span>, a <em>geodesic</em> between two vertices <span class="math inline"><em>x</em></span> and <span class="math inline"><em>y</em></span> is a shortest path connecting <span class="math inline"><em>x</em></span> to <span class="math inline"><em>y</em></span>. A subset <span class="math inline"><em>S</em></span> of the vertices of <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> is <em>in general position</em> if no vertex of <span class="math inline"><em>S</em></span> lies on any geodesic between two other vertices of <span class="math inline"><em>S</em></span>. The size of a largest set of vertices in general position is the <em>general position number</em> that we denote by <span class="math inline"><em>g</em><em>p</em>(<em>G</em>)</span>. Recently, Ghorbani et al. proved that for any <span class="math inline"><em>k</em></span> if <span class="math inline"><em>n</em> ≥ <em>k</em><sup>3</sup> − <em>k</em><sup>2</sup> + 2<em>k</em> − 2</span>, then <span class="math inline"><em>g</em><em>p</em>(<em>K</em><em>n</em><sub><em>n</em>, <em>k</em></sub>) = (<em>n</em> − 1 choose <em>k</em> − 1)</span>, where <span class="math inline"><em>K</em><em>n</em><sub><em>n</em>, <em>k</em></sub></span> denotes the Kneser graph. We improve on their result and show that the same conclusion holds for <span class="math inline"><em>n</em> ≥ 2.5<em>k</em> − 0.5</span> and this bound is best possible. Our main tools are a result on cross-intersecting families and a slight generalization of Bollobás’s inequality on intersecting set pair systems.</p>	string

1958	en_US	title	Distinct tuples in integer partitions	string
1958	en_US	cleanTitle	Distinct tuples in integer partitions	string
1958	en_US	abstract	<pre>We study the total number of distinct (sequential) <span>$r$</span>-<span>tuples</span> in partitions of <span>$n$</span>. These statistics generalise the number of distinct parts in a partition. In the early part of this paper we develop the generating functions for small values of <span>$r$</span>. Then we use these methods in the case of general <span>$r$</span>-<span>tuples</span>. We find the average number of distinct <span>$r$</span>-<span>tuples</span> for fixed <span>$r$</span>, as <span>$n\\rightarrow\\infty$</span>. Finally we show that as <span>$n$</span> grows, the total number of distinct <span>$r$</span>-<span>tuples</span> (normalised by <span>$q^r$</span>) converges to an explicitly determined ``enveloping" power series.</pre><pre> </pre>	string

1960	en_US	title	On Detour  Index of Join of Hamilton-connected Graphs	string
1960	en_US	cleanTitle	On Detour  Index of Join of Hamiltonconnected Graphs	string
1960	en_US	abstract	The structure of a chemical compound can be represented by a molecular graph, a labeled graph whose vertex and edge labels specify the atom and bond types, respectively. Topological indices are graph invariants defined to analyze the drug molecular structures and pharmacy characteristics, such as melting point, boiling point, and other biochemical activities. Of the numerous topological indices, the detour index has proven to be among the most useful at estimating many biochemical properties of molecules. In this paper we contribute to the literature of computational chemistry by providing exact expressions for the detour index of joins of Hamilton-connected ($HC$) graphs. This improves upon existing results by loosening the requirement of a molecular graph being Hamilton-connected and only requirement certain subgraphs to be Hamilton-connected.	string

1961	en_US	title	On the inducibility of small trees	string
1961	en_US	cleanTitle	On the inducibility of small trees	string
1961	en_US	abstract	The quantity that captures the asymptotic value of the maximum number of appearances of a given topological tree (a rooted tree with no vertices of outdegree $1$) $S$ with $k$ leaves in an arbitrary tree with sufficiently large number of leaves is called the inducibility of $S$. Its precise value is known only for some specific families of trees, most of them exhibiting a symmetrical configuration. In an attempt to answer a recent question posed by Czabarka, Sz{\\'e}kely, and the second author of this article, we provide bounds for the inducibility $J(A_5)$ of the $5$-leaf binary tree $A_5$ whose branches are a single leaf and the complete binary tree of height $2$. It was indicated before that $J(A_5)$ appears to be `close' to $1/4$. We can make this precise by showing that $0.24707\\ldots \\leq J(A_5) \\leq 0.24745\\ldots$. Furthermore, we also consider the problem of determining the inducibility of the tree $Q_4$, which is the only tree among $4$-leaf topological trees for which the inducibility is unknown.	string
1961	en_US	discipline	Combinatorics; Graph Theory	string
1961	en_US	subjectClass	Primary 05C05; secondary 05C07, 05C30, 05C60	string
1961	en_US	subject	inducibility, binary trees, ternary trees, leaf-induced subtrees, maximum density, $d$-ary trees, topological trees	string

1964	en_US	title	Distance-regular Cayley graphs with small valency	string
1964	en_US	cleanTitle	Distanceregular Cayley graphs with small valency	string
1964	en_US	abstract	<p>We consider the problem of which distance-regular graphs with small valency are Cayley graphs. We determine the distance-regular Cayley graphs with valency at most <span class="math inline">4</span>, the Cayley graphs among the distance-regular graphs with known putative intersection arrays for valency <span class="math inline">5</span>, and the Cayley graphs among all distance-regular graphs with girth <span class="math inline">3</span> and valency <span class="math inline">6</span> or <span class="math inline">7</span>. We obtain that the incidence graphs of Desarguesian affine planes minus a parallel class of lines are Cayley graphs. We show that the incidence graphs of the known generalized hexagons are not Cayley graphs, and neither are some other distance-regular graphs that come from small generalized quadrangles or hexagons. Among some “exceptional” distance-regular graphs with small valency, we find that the Armanios-Wells graph and the Klein graph are Cayley graphs.</p>	string

1965	en_US	title	Geodesic ball packings generated by regular prism tilings in Nil geometry	string
1965	en_US	cleanTitle	Geodesic ball packings generated by regular prism tilings in Nil geometry	string
1965	en_US	abstract	In this paper we study the regular prism tilings and construct ball packings by geodesic balls related to the above tilings in the projective model of Nil geometry. Packings are generated by action of the discrete prism groups pq21. We prove that these groups are realized by prism tilings in Nil space if (p, q) = (3, 6), (4, 4) or (6, 3) and determine packing density formulae for geodesic ball packings generated by the above prism groups. Moreover, studying these formulae we determine the conjectured maximal dense packing arrangements and their densities and visualize them in the projective model of Nil geometry. We get a dense (conjectured locally densest) geodesic ball arrangement related to the parameters (p, q) = (6, 3) where the kissing number of the packing is 14, similarly to the densest lattice-like Nil geodesic ball arrangement investigated by the second author.	string

1969	en_US	title	Realizations of certain odd-degree surface branch data	string
1969	en_US	cleanTitle	Realizations of certain odddegree surface branch data	string
1969	en_US	abstract	We consider surface branch data with base surface the sphere, odd degree d, three branching points, and two partitions of d of the form (2,...,2,1) and (2,...,2,2h+1). If the third partition has length L, this datum satisfies the Riemann-Hurwitz necessary condition for realizability if h-L is odd and at least -1. For several small values of h and L (namely, for h+L&lt;6) we explicitly compute the number n of realizations of the datum up to the equivalence relation given by the action of automorphisms (even unoriented ones) of both the base and the covering surface. The expression of n depends on arithmetic properties of the entries of the third partition. In particular we find that in the only case where n is 0 these entries have a common divisor, in agreement with a conjecture of Edmonds-Kulkarny-Stong and a stronger one of Zieve.	string
1969	en_US	discipline	Mathematics	string
1969	en_US	subjectClass	57M12	string
1969	en_US	subject	surface, branched cover	string

1970	en_US	title	The Sierpi\\'nski product of graphs	string
1970	en_US	cleanTitle	The Sierpinski product of graphs	string
1970	en_US	abstract	In this paper we introduce a product-like operation that generalizes the construction of generalized Sierpi\\'nski graphs. Let $G,H$ be graphs and let $f: V(G) \\to V(H)$ be a function. Then the {\\em Sierpi\\'nski product of $G$ and $H$ with respect to $f$} is defined as a pair $(K,\\varphi)$, where $K$ is a graph on the vertex set $V(G) \\times V(H)$ with two types of edges:<p style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; margin: 0px;">\\begin{itemize}</p><p style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; margin: 0px;">\\item $\\{(g,h),(g,h')\\}$ is an edge in $K$ for every $g\\in V(G)$ and every $\\{h,h'\\}\\in E(H)$,</p><p style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; margin: 0px;">\\item $\\{(g,f(g'),(g',f(g))\\}$ is an edge in $K$ for every edge $\\{g,g'\\} \\in E(G)$;</p><p style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; margin: 0px;">\\end{itemize}</p><p style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; margin: 0px;">and $\\varphi: V(G) \\to V(K)$ is a function that maps every vertex $g \\in V(G)$ to the vertex $(g,f(g)) \\in V(K)$. Graph $K$ will be denoted by $G \\otimes_f H$. Function $\\varphi$ is needed to define the product of more than two factors. By applying this operation $n$ times to the same graph we obtain the $n$-th generalized Sierpi\\'nski graph.</p><p style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; margin: 0px;"> </p><p style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; margin: 0px;">Some basic properties of the Sierpi\\'nski product are presented. In particular, we show that $G \\otimes_f H$ is connected if and only if both $G$ and $H$ are connected and we present some necessary and sufficient conditions that $G,H$ must fulfill in order for $G \\otimes_f H$ to be planar. As for symmetry properties, we show which automorphisms of $G$ and $H$ extend to automorphisms of $G \\otimes_f H$. In many cases we can also describe the whole automorphism group of $G \\otimes_f H$.</p>	string
1970	en_US	discipline		string

1970	en_US	subject	Sierpi\\'nski graphs, graph products, connectivity, planarity, symmetry	string

1971	en_US	title	S2 coverings by isosceles and scalene triangles - adjacency case II	string
1971	en_US	cleanTitle	S2 coverings by isosceles and scalene triangles  adjacency case II	string
1971	en_US	abstract	The aim of this paper is to complete the study and classification of spherical f-tilings by scalene triangles T and isosceles triangles T' within a subclass performed by the adjacency of the lower side of T and the longest side of T'. It consists of seven families of f-tilings (two families with one continuous parameter, one family with one discrete parameter and one continuous parameter, and four families with one discrete parameter). We also analyze the combinatorial structure of all these families of f-tilings, as well as the group of symmetries of each tiling; the transitivity classes of isogonality are included.	string

1973	en_US	title	Degree sequence  of the generalized Sierpinski ‎graph	string
1973	en_US	cleanTitle	Degree sequence  of the generalized Sierpinski ‎graph	string
1973	en_US	abstract	<p>‎Decomposition into special substructures inheriting significant properties is an important method for the investigation of some mathematical structures, ‎especially when the considered structures have self-similarity properties. Sierpinski ‎‎graphs are studied in fractal theory and have applications in diverse areas including dynamic systems, chemistry, psychology, probability and computer science. Polymer networks and WK-recursive networks can be modeled by generalized Sierpinski graphs. The degree sequence of (ordinary) Sierpinski graphs and Hanoi graphs (and some of their topological indices) are determined in the literature. ‎</p><p>‎‎The number of leaves (vertices of degree one) of the generalized Sierpinski ‎$‎S(T, t)‎$ of any tree ‎$‎T‎$ was determined in 2017 and in terms of ‎$‎t‎$‎, ‎$‎|V(T)|‎$ ‎‎‎‎‎‎and ‎ the number of leaves of the base graph ‎$‎T‎$‎. ‎</p><p>In this paper, ‎‎‎‎‎we generalize these results. More precisely, for every simple graph ‏‎$‎‎‎G‎$ ‎of order ‎$‎n‎$‎, ‎‎‎‎‎‎‎‎we completely determine the degree sequence of the generalized Sierpinski ‎graph $‎‎S(G,t)$ ‎of ‎‎$‎G‎$ ‎in ‎terms ‎of ‎‎$n‎$‎, ‎$t‎$ ‎and ‎the ‎degree ‎sequence ‎of ‎‎$‎G‎$‎. By using it, we determine the exact value of the general first Zagreb index of $‎‎S(G,t)$ in terms of the same parameters of ‎$‎G‎$‎. </p>	string
