1974	en_US	title	Atoms of  cyclic edge connectivity in tetravalent graphs	string
1974	en_US	cleanTitle	Atoms of  cyclic edge connectivity in tetravalent graphs	string
1974	en_US	abstract	‎A {\\it cyclic edge-cut} of a connected graph $G$ is an edge set‎, ‎the‎<p style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; -qt-user-state: 0; margin: 0px;">‎removal of which separate two cycles‎. ‎If $G$ has a cyclic edge-cut‎,</p><p style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; -qt-user-state: 0; margin: 0px;">‎then it is {\\it called cyclically separable}‎.</p><p style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; -qt-user-state: 0; margin: 0px;">‎An induced subgraph $P$ of $G$ is‎</p><p style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; -qt-user-state: 0; margin: 0px;">‎called a {\\it cyclic part} of $G$ if there exists a cyclic edge-cut‎</p><p style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; -qt-user-state: 0; margin: 0px;">‎$S$ such that $P$ is a component of $G-S$‎. ‎A cyclic part minimal‎</p><p style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; -qt-user-state: 0; margin: 0px;">‎under inclusion is called an {\\it atom}‎. ‎Also a cyclic part with‎</p><p style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; -qt-user-state: 0; margin: 0px;">‎minimum cardinality is called {\\it proper atom}‎. ‎For a cyclically‎</p><p style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; -qt-user-state: 0; margin: 0px;">‎separable graph $G$‎, ‎the {\\it cyclic edge connectivity} of a graph‎</p><p style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; -qt-user-state: 0; margin: 0px;">‎$G$‎, ‎denoted by $\\lambda_c(G)$‎, ‎is the ‎minimum ‎cardinality over all‎</p><p style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; -qt-user-state: 0; margin: 0px;">‎cyclic edge cuts‎. ‎In this article‎, ‎we establish some properties of‎</p><p style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; -qt-user-state: 0; margin: 0px;">‎atoms and cyclic parts in tetravalent graphs‎. ‎We show that if $P$‎</p><p style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; -qt-user-state: 0; margin: 0px;">‎is a nontrivial cyclic part of $G$‎</p><p style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; -qt-user-state: 2; margin: 0px;">‎then except some graphs in Table 1‎,‎ $‎v‎(P)\\geq k$‎. ‎Moreover‎, ‎if $P$ is a nontrivial atom of $G$ then $‎v‎(P) \\geq‎</p><p style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; -qt-user-state: 0; margin: 0px;">‎k$‎.</p><p style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; -qt-user-state: 0; margin: 0px;">‎Using this bound we proved that if two cyclic parts intersect‎</p><p style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; -qt-user-state: 0; margin: 0px;">‎then either each of them contains a smaller cyclic part‎, ‎or one of‎</p><p style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; -qt-user-state: 0; margin: 0px;">‎them or their complements is isomorphic to a $k$-cycle‎, ‎where $k$ is‎</p><p style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; -qt-user-state: 0; margin: 0px;">‎the cyclic connectivity of $G$‎, ‎or one of the graphs in‎</p><p style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; -qt-user-state: 0; margin: 0px;">‎Table 1‎. ‎Also we get some other results‎.</p>	string

1980	en_US	title	Path cover in connected quasi-claw-free graphs	string
1980	en_US	cleanTitle	Path cover in connected quasiclawfree graphs	string
1980	en_US	abstract	A path cover of a graph $G$ is a spanning subgraph of $G$ consisting of vertex disjoint paths, and a path cover number of $G$ denoted by $p(G)=\\min\\{|\\mathcal{P}|:$ $\\mathcal{P}$ is a path cover of $G\\}$. A graph is quasi-claw-free if for any two vertices $x,y$ with $d(x,y)=2$, there exists a vertex $u$ such that $u\\in N(x)\\cap N(y)$ and $N(u)\\subseteq N[x]\\cup N[y]$. In this paper, we prove that if the minimum degree sum of an independent set with $k+1$ vertices in a connected quasi-claw-free graph $G$ of order $n$ is no less than $n-k$, then $p(G)\\leq k-1$, where $k\\geq 2$.	string

1981	en_US	title	Nonplanarity of iterated line graphs	string
1981	en_US	cleanTitle	Nonplanarity of iterated line graphs	string
1981	en_US	abstract	The 1-crossing index of a graph $G$ is the smallest integer $k$ such that the $k$th iterated line graph of $G$ has crossing number greater than 1. In this paper, we show that the 1-crossing index of a graph is either infinite or it is at most 5. Moreover, we give a full characterization of all graphs with respect to their 1-crossing index.	string
1979	en_US	title	On the inducibility of small trees	string
1979	en_US	cleanTitle	On the inducibility of small trees	string
1979	en_US	abstract	The quantity that captures the asymptotic value of the maximum number of appearances of a given topological tree (a rooted tree with no vertices of outdegree $1$) $S$ with $k$ leaves in an arbitrary tree with sufficiently large number of leaves is called the inducibility of $S$. Its precise value is known only for some specific families of trees, most of them exhibiting a symmetrical configuration. In an attempt to answer a recent question posed by Czabarka, Sz{\\'e}kely, and the second author of this article, we provide bounds for the inducibility $J(A_5)$ of the $5$-leaf binary tree $A_5$ whose branches are a single leaf and the complete binary tree of height $2$. It was indicated before that $J(A_5)$ appears to be `close' to $1/4$. We can make this precise by showing that $0.24707\\ldots \\leq J(A_5) \\leq 0.24745\\ldots$. Furthermore, we also consider the problem of determining the inducibility of the tree $Q_4$, which is the only tree among $4$-leaf topological trees for which the inducibility is unknown.	string

1985	en_US	abstract	<pre><!--StartFragment-->Let <span>$\\Gamma(G,S)$</span> denote the <span>Cayley</span> graph of a group <span>$G$</span> with respect to a set <span>$S \\subset G$</span>. In this paper, we analyze the spectral properties of the <span>Cayley</span> graphs <span>$\\ST_{m,n,k} = \\Gamma(\\mathbb{Z}_m \\ltimes_k \\mathbb{Z}_n, \\{(\\pm 1,0),(0,\\pm 1)\\})$</span>, where <span>$m,n \\geq 3$</span> and <span>$k^m \\equiv 1 \\pmod{n}$</span>. We show that the adjacency matrix of <span>$\\ST_{m,n,k}$</span>, upto relabeling, is a block <span>circulant</span> matrix, and obtain an explicit description of these blocks. By applying some known bounds on the eigenvalues of <span>Hermitian</span> matrices, we show that <span>$\\ST_{m,n,k}$</span> is not Ramanujan, when either <span>$m &gt; 8$</span>, or <span>$n \\geq 400$</span>. Finally, we list the collection of all pairs in <span>$\\{(m,n) : 3 \\leq m \\leq 8 \\text{ and } 3 \\leq n &lt; 400\\}$</span> for which there exist at least one <span>$k &gt;1$</span> such that <span>$\\ST_{m,n,k}$</span> is Ramanujan.<!--EndFragment--></pre>	string

1987	en_US	title	Supereulerian 3-path-quasi-transitive digraphs	string
1987	en_US	cleanTitle	Supereulerian 3pathquasitransitive digraphs	string
1987	en_US	abstract	A digraph $D$ is supereulerian if $D$ has a spanning eulerian subdigraph.<br />For any distinct four vertices $x_{1},x_{2},x_{3},x_{4}$,<br />$D$ is $\\mathcal{H}_{1}$-quasi-transitive if $x_{1}\\rightarrow x_{2}\\leftarrow x_{3}\\leftarrow x_{4}$, $x_{1}$ and $x_4$ are adjacent;<br />$D$ is $\\mathcal{H}_{2}$-quasi-transitive if $x_{1}\\leftarrow x_{2}\\rightarrow x_{3}\\rightarrow x_{4}$, $x_{1}$ and $x_4$ are adjacent;<br />$D$ is $\\mathcal{H}_{3}$-quasi-transitive if $x_{1}\\rightarrow x_{2}\\rightarrow x_{3}\\rightarrow x_{4}$, $x_{1}$ and $x_4$ are adjacent;<br />$D$ is $\\mathcal{H}_{4}$-quasi-transitive if $x_{1}\\rightarrow x_{2}\\leftarrow x_{3}\\rightarrow x_{4}$, $x_{1}$ and $x_4$ are adjacent.<br />There are four different possible orientations of a 3-path.<br />For convenience, we will refer to $\\mathcal{H}_{i}$-quasi-transitive digraphs as 3-path-quasi-transitive digraphs, for $i\\in[4]$.<br />Bang-Jensen and Thomass\\'{e} conjectured that if the<br />arc-strong connectivity $\\lambda(D)$ of a digraph $D$ is not less than<br />the independence number $\\alpha(D)$, then $D$ is supereulerian.<br />In this paper, we prove that the conjecture is ture for the class of 3-path-quasi-transitive digraphs.	string

1987	en_US	subjectClass	05C20, 05C45	string

1988	en_US	title	The cubical matching complex revisited	string
1988	en_US	cleanTitle	The cubical matching complex revisited	string
1988	en_US	abstract	Ehrenborg noted that all tilings of a bipartite planar graph are<br />encoded by its cubical matching complex and claimed that this<br />complex is collapsible. We point out to an oversight in his proof<br />and explain why these complexes can be the union of collapsible<br />complexes. Also, we prove that all links in these complexes are<br />suspensions up to homotopy. Furthermore, we extend the definition<br />of a cubical matching complex to planar graphs that are not<br />necessarily bipartite, and show that these complexes are either<br />contractible or a disjoint union of contractible complexes.<br /><br />For a simple connected region that can be tiled with dominoes<br />($2\\times 1$ and $1\\times 2$) and $2\\times 2$ squares, let $f_i$<br />denote the number of tilings with exactly $i$ squares. We prove<br />that $f_0-f_1+f_2-f_3+\\cdots=1$ (established by Ehrenborg) is the<br />only linear relation for the numbers $f_i$.	string

1989	en_US	title	Panchromatic patterns by paths	string
1989	en_US	cleanTitle	Panchromatic patterns by paths	string
1989	en_US	abstract	Let $H=(V_H,A_H)$ be a digraph, possibly<br />with loops, and let $D=(V_D, A_D)$ be a<br />loopless multidigraph with a colouring of<br />its arcs $c: A_D \\rightarrow V_H$. An<br />$H$-path of $D$ is a path $(v_0, \\dots,<br />v_n)$ of $D$ such that $(c(v_{i-1}, v_i),<br />c(v_i,v_{i+1}))$ is an arc of $H$<br />for every $1 \\le i \\le n-1$. For $u, v<br />\\in V_D$, we say that $u$ reaches $v$ by<br />$H$-paths if there exists an $H$-path from<br />$u$ to $v$ in $D$. A subset $S \\subseteq<br />V_D$ is $H$-absorbent of $D$ if every<br />vertex in $V_D-S$ reaches by $H$-paths<br />some vertex in $S$, and it is $H$-independent<br />if no vertex in $S$ can reach another<br />(different) vertex in $S$ by $H$-pahts.<br />An $H$-kernel is an independent by $H$-paths<br />and absorbent by $H$-paths subset of $V_D$.<br /><br />We define $\\tilde{\\mathscr{B}}_1$ as the<br />set of digraphs $H$ such that any<br />$H$-arc-coloured tournament has an<br />$H$-absorbent by paths vertex; the set<br />$\\tilde{\\mathscr{B}}_2$ consists of the<br />digraphs $H$ such that any $H$-arc-coloured<br />digraph $D$ has an independent,<br />$H$-absorbent by paths set; analogously,<br />the set $\\tilde{\\mathscr{B}}_3$ is the set<br />of digraphs $H$ such that every<br />$H$-arc-coloured digraph $D$ contains an<br />$H$-kernel by paths.<br /><br />In this work, we present a characterization<br />of $\\tilde{\\mathscr{B}}_2$, and provide<br />structural properties of the digraphs in<br />$\\tilde{\\mathscr{B}}_3$ which settle up its<br />characterization except for the analysis of<br />a single digraph on three vertices.	string

1991	en_US	title	Decycling Number of Halin graphs	string
1991	en_US	cleanTitle	Decycling Number of Halin graphs	string
1991	en_US	abstract	A set $S$ of vertices of a graph $G$ is called a decycling set if $G-S$ is acyclic. The minimum order of a decycling set<br />is called the decycling number of $G$, and denoted by $\\nabla(G)$. In this paper, we main study the decycling number of Halin graphs. Our result confirms a conjecture due to Albertson and Berman [M.O. Albertson, D.M. Berman, The acyclic chromatic number. Congr. Numer. 17(1976) 51-69]. Meanwhile, we determine exact values for the decycling number of a type of Halin graphs. Finally, we get a lower bound for the decycling number of $k$-regular graphs and give a necessary and sufficient conditions for the bound achieving.	string

1992	en_US	title	The number of  same order classes of  non-abelian subgroups	string
1992	en_US	cleanTitle	The number of  same order classes of  nonabelian subgroups	string
1992	en_US	abstract	<p>Let $G$ be a finite group and $\\pi(G)$ denote the set of the prime divisors of $|G|$.<br /> The symbol $\\tau_0(G)$ denotes the number of<br />same order classes of all non-abelian subgroups of $G$. Firstly, the finite groups with $\\tau_0(G)=2$ are classified completely. Secondly, the lower bounds on $\\tau_0(G)$ are obtained by the functions of $|\\pi(G)|$. In particular, it is<br />showed that $\\tau_0(G)\\geq |\\pi(G)|+1$ for non-solvable groups $G$.<br />Finally, the structure of groups with $\\tau_0(G)=|\\pi(G)|+1$ are investigated.</p>	string

1993	en_US	abstract	We investigate linear codes over the ring $\\mathbb{Z}_4 +u\\mathbb{Z}_4 +v\\mathbb{Z}_4 +w\\mathbb{Z}_4 +uv\\mathbb{Z}_4 +uw\\mathbb{Z}_4 +<br />vw\\mathbb{Z}_4 + uvw\\mathbb{Z}_4,$ with conditions $u^2=u$, $v^2=v$, $w^2=w$, $uv=vu$, $uw=wu$ and $vw=wv.$ We first analyze the structure of the ring and then define linear codes over<br />this ring. 1994	en_US	title	Cayley properties of  the line graphs induced by consecutive layers of  the hypercube	string
1994	en_US	cleanTitle	Cayley properties of  the line graphs induced by consecutive layers of  the hypercube	string
1994	en_US	abstract	Let $n &gt;3$ and $  0&lt; k &lt; \\frac{n}{2} $  be integers. In this paper, we  investigate some algebraic properties of  the  line graph of the graph $ {Q_n}(k,k+1) $  where $ {Q_n}(k,k+1) $  is the subgraph of the hypercube $Q_n$  which is induced by the set of vertices of weights $k$ and $k+1$. In the first step, we determine the automorphism groups of these graphs for all values of $n,k$. In the second step,<br />   we   study  Cayley properties of the line graphs of these graphs. In particular,  we show that  if $k\\geq 3$  and $  n \\neq 2k+1$, then  except for the cases $k=3, n=9$ and $k=3, n=33$, the line graph of the graph $ {Q_n}(k,k+1)  $   is a vertex-transitive non-Cayley graph. Also, we show that the line graph of the graph   $ {Q_n}(1,2) $ is a Cayley graph if and only if $ n$ is  a power of a prime $p$. Moreover, we show that for \\lq{}almost all\\rq{} even values of    $k$, the line graph of the graph   $ {Q_{2k+1}}(k,k+1) $ is a vertex-transitive non-Cayley graph.	string

1996	en_US	title	On the incidence maps of incidence structures	string
1996	en_US	cleanTitle	On the incidence maps of incidence structures	string
1996	en_US	abstract	<p>By using elementary linear algebra methods we exploit properties of the incidence map of certain incidence structures with finite block sizes. We give new and simple proofs of theorems of Kantor and Lehrer, and their infinitary version. Similar results are obtained also for diagrams geometries.</p><p>By mean of an extension of Block’s Lemma on the number of orbits of an automorphism group of an incidence structure, we give informations on the number of orbits of: a permutation group (of possible infinite degree) on subsets of finite size; a collineation group of a projective and affine space (of possible infinite dimension) over a finite field on subspaces of finite dimension; a group of isometries of a classical polar space (of possible infinite rank) over a finite field on totally isotropic subspaces (or singular in case of orthogonal spaces) of finite dimension.</p><p>Furthermore, when the structure is finite and the associated incidence matrix has full rank, we give an alternative proof of a result of Camina and Siemons. We then deduce that certain families of incidence structures have no sharply transitive sets of automorphisms acting on blocks.</p>	string

2000	en_US	title	Consecutive Detecting Arrays for Interaction Faults	string
2000	en_US	cleanTitle	Consecutive Detecting Arrays for Interaction Faults	string
2000	en_US	abstract	<p>The concept of detecting arrays was developed to locate and detect interaction faults arising between the factors in a component-based system during software testing. In this paper, we propose a family of consecutive detecting arrays (CDAs) in which the interactions between factors are considered to be ordered. CDAs can be used to generate test suites for locating and detecting interaction faults between neighboring factors. We establish a general criterion for measuring the optimality of CDAs in terms of their size. Based on this optimality criterion, the equivalence between optimum CDAs and consecutive orthogonal arrays with prescribed properties is explored. Using the advantages of this equivalence, a great number of<br />optimum CDAs are presented. In particular, the existence of optimum CDAs with few factors is almost completely determined.</p>	string

641	en_US	abstract	<p>Universality theorems (in the sense of N. Mnëv) claim that the realization space of a combinatorial object (a point configuration, a hyperplane arrangement, a convex polytope, etc.) can be arbitrarily complicated. 2004	en_US	abstract	Let $R$ be an associative ring with an identity and suppose that $a,b,c,d\\in R$ satisfy $$bdb=bac, dbd=acd.$$ If $ac$ has generalized Drazin (respectively, pseudo Drazin, Drazin) inverse, we prove that $bd$ has generalized Drazin (respectively, pseudo Drazin, Drazin) inverse. 2005	en_US	title	Ks-WORM Colorings of Some Graphs: Chromatic Spectrum	string
2005	en_US	cleanTitle	KsWORM Colorings of Some Graphs: Chromatic Spectrum	string
2005	en_US	abstract	An H-WORM coloring of a simple graph G is the coloring of the vertices of G such that no copy of H b G is monochrome or rainbow. A recent result ([3]) suggested that the number of r-partitions in a Ks-WORM coloring of Kn is \\zeta_r = \\stirr{n}{r}, where $\\stirr{n}{r}$ denotes the Stirling number of the second kind, for all $3\\le r\\le s &lt; n$. We found that  \\displaystyle \\zeta_r &lt; \\stirr{n}{r} when  s\\le {\\lceil \\frac{n+1}{2} \\rceil}. Further investigations in$\\zeta_2$ given any $K_3$-WORM coloring reveal its relation with the number of spanning trees for some graphs and the kth Catalan number. Moreover, for distinct subgraphs H1 and H2 of G, we extend the<br />notion of H-WORM colorings to (H1;H2)-mixed colorings which are closely related to the concept of mixed hypergraph colorings.	string

2007	en_US	title	Real Forms of the Complex Neumann System: A Method for Finding Real Roots of Polynomial $U_{\\cal S}(\\lambda)	string
2007	en_US	cleanTitle	Real Forms of the Complex Neumann System: A Method for Finding Real Roots of Polynomial U_{\\cal S}\\lambda	string
2007	en_US	abstract	The topology of Arnold-Liouville level sets of the real forms of the complex generic Neumann system depends indirectly on the positions of the roots of the special polynomial $U_{\\cal S}(\\lambda)$. For certain polynomials, the existence and positions of the real roots, according to the suitable parameters of the system, is not obvious.<br />   In the paper, a method for checking the existence and positions of the real roots of the polynomials $U_{\\cal S}(\\lambda)$ is given. The method and algorithm are based on searching of a positive solution of a system of linear equations. In case $n=2$, we provide a complete solution to the problem of existence of real roots for all special polynomials and determine the topology of the Arnold-Liouville level sets.	string

2010	en_US	title	Equality of graphs up to complementation	string
2010	en_US	cleanTitle	Equality of graphs up to complementation	string
2010	en_US	abstract	We prove the following: Let $G$ and $G'$ be two graphs on the same set $V$ of $v$  vertices, and let $k$ be an integer, $4\\leq k\\leq v-4$. If for all $k$-element subsets $K$ of $V$, the induced subgraphs $G_{\\restriction K}$ and $G'_{\\restriction K}$ have the same numbers of $3$-homogeneous subsets, the same numbers of $P_4$'s, and the same numbers of claws or co-claws,   then $G'$ is equal to $G$ or to the complement $\\overline{G}$ of $G$. We give also a similar result whenever the same numbers are modulo a prime.	string

2013	en_US	title	Graphs with large injective chromatic number and injective chromatic sums	string
2013	en_US	cleanTitle	Graphs with large injective chromatic number and injective chromatic sums	string
2013	en_US	abstract	The injective chromatic number of a graph $G$, denoted by $\\chi_i(G)$ is the minimum number of colors needed to color the vertices of $G$ such that two vertices with a common neighbor are assigned distinct colors. The injective chromatic sum of a graph $G$, denoted as $\\sum_i(G)$ is the smallest sum of colors among all injective colorings with natural numbers. In this paper, $\\chi_i(G)$ and $\\sum_i(G)$ of Mycielskian of certain classes of graphs are calculated and a sharp bound is obtained for the injective chromatic number of the Mycielskian of any graph $G$.	string

2014	en_US	title	Repdigits base b as products of two Fibonacci numbers	string
2014	en_US	cleanTitle	Repdigits base b as products of two Fibonacci numbers	string
2014	en_US	abstract	<p> </p><p>&lt;abstract/&gt;Let (F_{n}) be the sequence of Fibonacci numbers defined by F₀=0, F₁=1, and F_{n}=F_{n-1}+F_{n-2} for n≥2. Let 2≤m≤n and b=2,3,4,5,6,7,8,9. In this study, we show that if F_{m}F_{n} is a repdigit in the base b and has at least two digits, then</p><p>F_{m}F_{n}∈{3,4,5,6,8,9,10,13,15,16,21,24,26,40,42,63,170,273}.</p><p>Furthermore, it is shown that if F_{n} is a repdigit in the base b and has at least two digits, then</p><p>(n,b)=(7,3),(8,4),(8,6),(4,2),(5,4),(6,3),(6,7).</p><p> </p>	string

2015	en_US	title	Note on the Roman Bondage Number of Trees	string
2015	en_US	cleanTitle	Note on the Roman Bondage Number of Trees	string
2015	en_US	abstract	<p>Let $G=(V,E)$ be a simple undirected graph. A Roman dominating function on $G$ is a function $f: V\\to \\{0,1,2\\}$ satisfying the condition that every vertex $u$ with $f(u)=0$ is adjacent to at least one vertex<br />$v$ with $f(v)=2$. The weight of a Roman dominating function is the value $f(G)=\\sum_{u\\in V} f(u)$. The Roman domination number of $G$ is the minimum weight of a Roman dominating function on $G$. The Roman bondage number of a nonempty graph $G$ is the minimum number of edges whose removal results in a graph with the Roman domination number larger than that of $G$. Rad and Volkmann [Roman bondage in graphs, Discussiones Mathematicae Graph Theory, 31 (2011), 763-773] proposed a problem that is to determine the trees $T$ with Roman bondage number 1. In this paper, we characterize trees with Roman bondage number 1.</p>	string

2016	en_US	title	Lie symmetries and conserved quantities of fractional nonconservative singular systems	string
2016	en_US	cleanTitle	Lie symmetries and conserved quantities of fractional nonconservative singular systems	string
2016	en_US	abstract	<p align="justify"><span> The Lie symmetry theory of fractional nonconservative singular systems is studied based on fractional factor derivative method in form space. The Lagrange equations with fractional factor are established through the variational principle. The determining equation and limiting  equation of Lie symmetry under infinitesimal group transformation are studied. Furthermore, the conserved quantity form of fractional order singular system caused by Lie symmetry is obtained by constructing the gauge generating function satisfy the structural equation, which conforms to the Noether criterion equation. Finally, an example is given to illustrate the application. The results show that comparing with the conservative systems, the nonconservative force has impact on the condition of Lie symmetry, but because of enhancing the invariance condition, it does not change the form of conserved quantity, at the same time, we use fractional factor method to study</span><span> </span><span>the nonconservative singular systems,</span><span> </span><span>some conclusions is highly natural consistent with the classical integer order singular systems, so it is simple and accurate.</span></p>	string

2018	en_US	title	Algorithmic releases on the spanning trees of some graphs	string
2018	en_US	cleanTitle	Algorithmic releases on the spanning trees of some graphs	string
2018	en_US	abstract	In this paper algebraic and combinatorial properties and a computation of the number of the spanning trees are developed for certain graphs. For this purpose, an original method, independent of the spectrum of the Laplacian matrix associated to the graph, is discussed. It represents an alternative process to compute how many and which are the spanning trees of any graph and substantially consists in joining the spanning trees on the ground of the number of common edges between the inner cycles of it. The algorithm and its source code for determining the collection of all edge-sets of the spanning trees for Jahangir graphs are displayed. An application involving such graphs in order to get a satisfactory degree of security in transmitting conﬁdential information is given, and ﬁnally symmetry properties of them are highlighted.	string

2019	en_US	title	Schur numbers involving rainbow colorings	string
2019	en_US	cleanTitle	Schur numbers involving rainbow colorings	string
2019	en_US	abstract	<p>In this paper, we introduce two different generalizations of Schur numbers that involve rainbow colorings. Motivated by well-known generalizations of Ramsey numbers, we first define the rainbow Schur number <span class="math inline"><em>RS</em>(<em>n</em>)</span> to be the minimum number of colors needed such that every coloring of <span class="math inline">{1, 2, …, <em>n</em>}</span>, in which all available colors are used, contains a rainbow solution to <span class="math inline"><em>a</em> + <em>b</em> = <em>c</em></span>. It is shown that</p><p style="text-align: center;"><em>RS</em>(<em>n</em>) = ⌊log<sub>2</sub>(<em>n</em>)⌋ + 2,   for all <em>n</em> ≥ 3.</p><p>Second, we consider the Gallai-Schur number <span class="math inline"><em>GS</em>(<em>n</em>)</span>, defined to be the least natural number such that every <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span>-coloring of <span class="math inline">{1, 2, …, <em>GS</em>(<em>n</em>)}</span> that lacks rainbow solutions to the equation <span class="math inline"><em>a</em> + <em>b</em> = <em>c</em></span> necessarily contains a monochromatic solution to this equation. By connecting this number with the <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span>-color Gallai-Ramsey number for triangles, it is shown that for all <span class="math inline"><em>n</em> ≥ 3</span>,</p><p style="text-align: center;"><span class="math inline"><em>GS</em>(<em>n</em>) = 5<sup><em>k</em></sup>   if <em>n</em> = 2<em>k</em>;    <span class="math inline"><em>GS</em>(<em>n</em>) = 2 · 5<sup><em>k</em></sup>   if <em>n</em> = 2<em>k</em> + 1.</span></span></p>	string

2020	en_US	title	Total colorings of Circulant graphs	string
2020	en_US	cleanTitle	Total colorings of Circulant graphs	string
2020	en_US	abstract	The total chromatic number chi′′(G) is the least number of colors needed to color the vertices and edges of a graph G such that no incident or adjacent elements (vertices or edges) receive the same color. Behzed and Vizing proposed a well known total coloring conjecture (TCC): chi′′(G) ≤Delta (G) + 2, where (G) is the maximum degree of G. For the<br />powers of cycles, Campos and de Mello have proposed the following conjecture:<br />Let G = C_k^n<br /> denotes the graphs of powers of cycles of order n and length k with 2 ≤ k &lt; ⌊n/2 ⌋.<br />Then,<br />chi′′(G) =Delta(G) + 2, if k &gt; n/3 − 1 and n is odd; and<br />Delta(G) + 1, otherwise.<br />In this paper, we prove the Campos and de Mello’s conjecture for some classes of powers of<br />cycles. Also, we prove the TCC for complement of powers of cycles.	string

2022	en_US	title	Properties of double Roman domination on cardinal products of graphs	string
2022	en_US	cleanTitle	Properties of double Roman domination on cardinal products of graphs	string
2022	en_US	abstract	<p>Double Roman domination is a stronger version of Roman domination that doubles the protection. The areas now have <span class="math inline">0</span>, <span class="math inline">1</span>, <span class="math inline">2</span> or <span class="math inline">3</span> legions. Every attacked area needs <span class="math inline">2</span> legions for its defence, either their own, or borrowed from <span class="math inline">1</span> or <span class="math inline">2</span> neighbouring areas, which still have to keep at least <span class="math inline">1</span> legion to themselves. The minimal number of legions in all areas together is equal to the double Roman domination number.</p><p>In this paper we determine an upper bound and a lower bound for double Roman domination numbers on cardinal product of any two graphs. Also we determine the exact values of double Roman domination numbers on <span class="math inline"><em>P</em><sub>2</sub> × <em>G</em></span> (for many types of graph <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span>). Also, the double Roman domination number is found for <span class="math inline"><em>P</em><sub>2</sub> × <em>P</em><sub><em>n</em></sub></span>, <span class="math inline"><em>P</em><sub>3</sub> × <em>P</em><sub><em>n</em></sub></span>, <span class="math inline"><em>P</em><sub>4</sub> × <em>P</em><sub><em>n</em></sub></span>, while upper and lower bounds are given for <span class="math inline"><em>P</em><sub>5</sub> × <em>P</em><sub><em>n</em></sub></span> and <span class="math inline"><em>P</em><sub>6</sub> × <em>P</em><sub><em>n</em></sub></span>.</p><p>Finally, we will give a case study to determine the efficiency of double protection. We will compare double Roman domination versus Roman domination by running a simulation of a battle.</p>	string

2023	en_US	abstract	‎The flower at a point $x$ in a Steiner triple system $(X,\\mathcal{B})$ is the set of all triples containing $x$‎. ‎Denote by $J^3_F(r)$ the set of all integers $k$ such that there exists a collection of three $STS(2r+1)$ mutually intersecting in the same set of $k+r$ triples‎, ‎$r$ of them being the triples of a common flower‎. ‎In this article we determine the set $J^3_F(r)$ for any positive integer $r\\equiv 0,1$ (mod $3$) (only some cases are left undecided for $r =6,~7,~9,~24$)‎, ‎and establish that $J^3_F(r)=I^3_F (r)$ for $r\\equiv 0,1$ (mod $3$) where $I^3_F(r)=\\{0,1,\\ldots‎ ‎,\\frac{2r(r-1)}{3}-8,\\frac{2r(r-1)}{3}-6,\\frac{2r(r-1)}{3}\\}$.‎	string

2027	en_US	abstract	Graph constructing algorithms and their mapping with real life problems for scientific data analysis are getting popular. Standard algorithms construct the graph in a way that it can deal with all possibilities of input data to calculate the desired output. This article gives an algorithmic computational model for edge based eccentric topological indices by constructing zero divisor graph containing finite rings as $\\mathbb{Z}_{p_1p_2} \\times \\mathbb{Z}_q$ and $\\mathbb{Z}_{p^2} \\times \\mathbb{Z}_q$, where $p$, $p_1$, $p_2$ and $q$ are primes numbers. 2029	en_US	title	The number of rooted forests in circulant graphs	string
2029	en_US	cleanTitle	The number of rooted forests in circulant graphs	string
2029	en_US	abstract	<p>In this paper, we develop a new method to produce explicit formulas for the number $f_{G}(n)$ of rooted spanning forests in the circulant graphs $G=C_{n}(s_1,s_2,\\ldots,s_k)$ and $G=C_{2n}(s_1,s_2,\\ldots,s_k,n).$ These formulas are expressed through Chebyshev polynomials. We prove that in both cases the number of rooted spanning forests can be represented in the form $f_{G}(n)=p\\,a(n)^2,$ where $a(n)$ is an integer sequence and $p$ is a prescribed natural number depending on the parity of $n$.</p><p>Finally, we find an asymptotic formula for $f_{G}(n)$ through the Mahler measure of the associated Laurent polynomial $P(z)=2k+1-\\sum\\limits_{i=1}^k(z^{s_i}+z^{-s_i}).$</p>	string

2033	en_US	abstract	<p>We give a possible extension of the definition of quaternionic power series, partial derivatives and vector fields in the case of two (and then several) non commutative (quaternionic) variables. 2038	en_US	abstract	<p>Classifying   integral graphs is a hard problem that initiated by Harary and Schwenk in 1974.In this paper, with the help of character table, we treat the corresponding problem for Cayley graphs over the semi-dihedral group $SD_{8n}=\\langle a,b~|~a^{4n}=b^2=1,bab=a^{2n-1}\\rangle$,  $n\\geq 2$. We present several necessary and sufficient conditions for the integrality of Cayley graphs over $SD_{8n}$, we also obtain some simple sufficient conditions for the integrality of Cayley graphs over $SD_{8n}$ in terms of the Boolean algebra of $\\langle a \\rangle$. In particular, we  give the sufficient conditions for the integrality of Cayley graphs over semi-dihedral groups $SD_{2^n}$ $(n\\geq 4)$ and $SD_{8p}$  for a prime $p$, from which we determine several infinite classes of  integral Cayley graphs over $SD_{2^n}$  and $SD_{8p}$.</p>	string

2039	en_US	abstract	<p>Using a technique which is inspired by topology, we construct original examples of <span class="math inline">3</span>- and <span class="math inline">4</span>-edge critical graphs. 2043	en_US	abstract	<p>The bouquet of circles $B_n$ and dipole graph $D_n$ are two important classes of graphs in topological graph theory. 2045	en_US	cleanTitle	The characteristic polynomials of signed ksubdivision graphs	string
2045	en_US	abstract	Let $G=(V(G),E(G))$ be a graph, and $S_k(G)$ be its $k-subdivision$ which is obtained from $G$ by replacing every edge $e=uv$ of $G$ with a path $P_{k+2}=ue^1e^2\\ldots e^kv$. Let $\\Sigma(G)=\\{\\sigma: E(G)\\rightarrow\\{-1,+1\\}\\} $ and $\\Sigma(S_k(G))=\\{\\sigma: E(S_k(G))\\rightarrow\\{-1,+1\\}\\} $ be the set of sign functions  defined on the edges of $G$ and $S_k(G)$, respectively. In this paper, we first define a mapping $\\Theta$ from $\\Sigma(S_k(G))$ to $\\Sigma(G)$ as follows: for any $\\eta\\in \\Sigma(S_k(G))$, $\\Theta_\\eta\\in \\Sigma(G)$ satisfying $\\Theta_\\eta(e)=\\eta(ue^1)\\eta(e^1e^2)\\ldots \\eta(e^{k-1}e^k)\\eta(e^kv)$ for any $e=uv$.   Then we show that  several characteristic polynomials related to signed graph $S_k(G)_\\eta$ can be expressed in terms of that of $G_{\\Theta_\\eta}$ and $P_k$. Finally, as applications,  we express the   matching polynomial and Hosoya index of $S_k(G)$ in terms of that of $G$ and $P_k$, respectively.	string

2046	en_US	abstract	In his 1878/79 paper, Klein produced his famous 14-sided polygon representing the Klein quartic,his Riemann surface of genus 3 which has PSL(2,7) as its automorphism group. The constructionand method of side pairings are fairly complicated. By considering the Farey map modulo 7 we show howto obtain a fundamental polygon for Klein's surface using arithmetic. Now the side pairings are immediateand essentially the same as in Klein's paper. We also extend this idea from 7 to 11 as Klein attempted todo in his follow up paper in 1879.	string

2048	en_US	cleanTitle	Strong chromatic index of outerplanar graphs	string
2048	en_US	abstract	<p>The strong chromatic index $\\chi'_{\\rm s}(G)$ of a graph $G$ is the minimum number of colors needed in a proper edge coloring so that every color class induces a matching. In 2013, Hocquard, Ochem, and Valico proved that every outerplanar graph $G$ with $\\Delta\\ge 3$ satisfies $\\chi'_{\\rm s}(G)\\le 3\\Delta-3$. In this paper, we characterize outerplanar graphs with the strong chromatic index $3\\Delta-3$. We also show that if $G$ is a bipartite and outerplanar graph, then $\\chi'_{\\rm s}(G)\\le 2\\Delta$; and<br /> $\\chi'_{\\rm s}(G)=2\\Delta$ if and only if $G$ contains a specific configuration.</p>	string

2049	en_US	abstract	We discuss recent progress on the problem of classifying point-primitive generalised polygons. 2051	en_US	abstract	<p>Wiener index is defined as the sum of distances between all unordered pairs of vertices in a graph.</p><p><br /> Here in this paper, we explore some graphs which do not satisfy the conjectures of M. Knor et al. [Martin Knor, Riste \\v{S}krekovski, Aleksandra Tepeh, Mathematical aspects of Wiener index,  <em>Ars Math. Contemp</em>. <strong>11</strong> (2016) 327--352] that among all $r$-regular graphs on $n$ vertices, the maximum Wiener index is attained by a graph with the maximum possible diameter and among all $r$-regular graphs on $n$ vertices, the minimum Wiener index is attained by a graph with the minimum possible diameter. 2052	en_US	abstract	<p>In this paper we study the metric dimension problem in maximal outerplanar graphs. </p><p>Concretely, if $\\beta (G)$ is the metric dimension of a maximal outerplanar graph $G$ of order $n$, we prove that $2\\le \\beta (G) \\le \\lceil \\frac{2n}{5}\\rceil$ and that the bounds are tight. 2053	en_US	title	A-trails of embedded graphs and twisted duals	string
2053	en_US	cleanTitle	Atrails of embedded graphs and twisted duals	string
2053	en_US	abstract	<p>Kotzig showed that every connected 4-regular plane graph has an $A$-trail---an Eulerian circuit that turns either left or right at each vertex. However, this statement is not true for Eulerian plane graphs and determining if an Eulerian plane graph has an $A$-trail is NP-hard. The aim of this paper is to give a characterisation of Eulerian embedded graphs having an $A$-trail. Andersen et al showed the existence of orthogonal pairs of $A$-trails in checkerboard colourable 4-regular graphs embedded on the plane, torus and projective plane. A problem posed in their paper is to characterize Eulerian embedded graphs (not necessarily checkerboard colourable) which contain two orthogonal $A$-trails. In this article, we solve this problem in terms of twisted duals. Several related results are also obtained.</p>	string

2054	en_US	abstract	<pre><span>This article explores exotic connections between group actions and their corresponding vector spaces. Given an action of a group </span><span>$G$</span><span> on a nonempty set </span><span>$X$</span><span>, we examine the space </span><span>$L(X)$</span><span> of scalar-valued functions on </span><span>$X$</span><span> and its fixed subspace:</span></pre><pre><span>$$</span></pre><pre><span>L^G(X) = \\{f\\in L(X)\\colon \\forall a\\in G\\forall x\\in X, f(a\\cdot x) = f(x)\\}.</span></pre><pre><span>$$</span></pre><pre><span>In particular, we show that </span><span>$L^G(X)$</span><span> is an invariant of the action of </span><span>$G$</span><span> on </span><span>$X$</span><span>. In the case when the action is finite, we count the dimension of </span><span>$L^G(X)$</span><span> in terms of fixed points of </span><span>$X$</span><span> and prove several well-known results for </span><span>$L^G(X)$</span><span>, including </span><span>Bessel's</span><span> inequality and </span><span>Frobenius</span><span> reciprocity.</span></pre>	string

2058	en_US	title	Doubly semi-equivelar maps on torus and Klein bottle	string
2058	en_US	cleanTitle	Doubly semiequivelar maps on torus and Klein bottle	string
2058	en_US	abstract	<p>tiling of the Euclidean plane, by regular polygons, is called 2-uniform tiling if<br />it has two orbits of vertices under the action of its symmetry group. There are 20<br />distinct 2-uniform tilings of the plane, also named as 2-isogonal tilings. Plane being<br />the universal cover of torus and Klein bottle, it is natural to ask about generalization<br />of maps associated with the 2-isogonal tilings to these two close surfaces. We call such generalized maps as doubly semi-equivelar maps. In this article, we study and classify (up to isomorphism) some doubly semi-equivelar maps on torus and Klein bottle with few vertices.</p>	string

2059	en_US	title	Answering Time-Windowed Stay Region Queries	string
2059	en_US	cleanTitle	Answering TimeWindowed Stay Region Queries	string
2059	en_US	abstract	A stay region of a moving entity is a region in which it spends a significant amount of time. Given the location of a moving object through a certain time interval, i.e.~its trajectory, our goal is to find its stay regions. We consider axis-parallel square stay regions of fixed side length, which contain the longest contiguous portion of the trajectory. Gudmundsson, van Kreveld, and Staals (2013) presented an algorithm to find a stay region of a trajectory in $O(n \\log n)$, in which $n$ is the number of the vertices of the trajectory. We present an algorithm for answering \\emph{time-windowed} stay region queries, to find a stay region in any given time interval. The algorithm has an approximation factor of $1/2$ and answers each query with the time complexity $O(\\log^2 n)$. The time complexity of the preprocessing step of the algorithm is $O(n)$. When the query contains the whole trajectory, it implies an $O(n)$ algorithm for finding approximate stay regions.	string
2059	en_US	discipline	Computational geometry	string
2059	en_US	subjectClass	68U05	string
2059	en_US	subject	Trajectory; Stay regions; Geometric algorithms; Time-windowed queries	string
2059	en_US	sponsor		string
2059	en_US	copyrightHolder	ARS MATHEMATICA CONTEMPORANEA	string
2059		licenseURL		string
2060	en_US	title	Some hyperbolic iterative methods for linear systems	string
2060	en_US	cleanTitle	Some hyperbolic iterative methods for linear systems	string
2060	en_US	abstract	The indefinite inner product defined by $$J=diag(j_1,...,j_n),~ j_k\\in \\{-1,+1\\},$$ arises frequently in some applications such as the theory of relativity and the research of the polarized light. This indefinite scalar product is referred to as hyperbolic inner product. In this papre, we introduce three hyperbolic iterative methods; hyperbolic Arnoldi's method, hyperbolic Lanczos method (HLM) and hyperbolic full orthogonalization method (HFOM). The hyperbolic Arnoldi's method is introduced as a process that constructs a J-orthonormal bases for the nondegenerated Krylov subspace. The HLM mathod is introduced as a special case of the hyperbolic Arnoldi's method for J-Hermitian matrices. HFOM is mentioned as a process for solving linear systems of equations with J-Hermitian coefficient matrices.  Finally, by providing  numerical examples, the FOM, IFOM and ILM processes have been compared with each other in terms of the required time for solving linear systems and also from the point of the number of itterations.	string
2060	en_US	discipline	linear algebra, matrix theory,	string

2063	en_US	title	Semi-equivelar maps of Euler characteristics -2	string
2063	en_US	cleanTitle	Semiequivelar maps of Euler characteristics 2	string
2063	en_US	abstract	Semi equivelar maps are generalizations of Archimedean solids to the surfaces other than 2-sphere as are equivelar maps of Platonic solids.  We show that there does not exist a semi equivelar map on the surface of Euler characteristics -2 with vertices less than or equal to 11 and classify all the semi equivelar maps on this surface with 12 vertices. We determine their automorphism groups and comment on their symmetry. We show that there are exactly 77 semi equivelar maps with $\\leq 12$ vertices out of which 17 are orientable and 60 are non orientable. Further, for this surface, we give a complete characterization of semi equivelar maps of those types whose faces are combinations of triangles and quadrangles.	string

2068	en_US	cleanTitle	Protected cells in Compositions	string
2068	en_US	abstract	<p>Compositions of $n$ are finite sequences of positive integers that sum to $n$.<br />We represent a composition of $n$ as a bargraph with area $n$ such that the height of the $i$-th column of the bargraph equals the size of the $i$-th part of the composition. We consider the concept of {\\em protected cells and protected columns} in the bargraph representation of the composition. An $r$-protected cell is a cell in which the shortest path to the outside has at least $r+1$ steps (up, down, left or right). Finally we define and study the {\\em total protection number} of a composition of $n$.</p>	string

2070	en_US	title	Computing Curve-Restricted Simplifications Faster	string
2070	en_US	cleanTitle	Computing CurveRestricted Simplifications Faster	string
2070	en_US	abstract	<pre>A polygonal curve is simplified to reduce its number of vertices, while maintaining similarity to its original shape. Numerous results have been published for vertex-restricted simplification, in which the vertices of the simplified curve are a subset of the vertices of the input curve. In curve-restricted simplification, i.e.~when the vertices of the simplified curve are allowed to be placed on the edges of the input curve, the number of vertices may be much more reduced. For a polygonal curve with $n$ vertices, we present an algorithm with the time complexity $O(n^3 \\log n)$ to obtain a curve-restricted simplification of size at most $2C_{\\epsilon/3}$, in which $\\epsilon$ is the maximum allowed amount of error and $C_{\\epsilon/3}$ is the minimum number of edges of a curve-restricted simplification when the error is bounded by $\\epsilon/3$.</pre>	string

2073	en_US	abstract	<pre>In the present paper, a random sequence is defined by the binary recurrence <span>$x_{n+1}=A \\alpha x_n-qx_{n-1}$</span>, where <span>$\\alpha$</span> is a random variable which assumes the values <span>$+1$</span> and <span>$-1$</span> with probability <span>$1/2$</span> each where <span>$A$</span> is a positive integer and <span>$q$</span> is a non-zero integer. 2076	en_US	title	Lower bounds for energy of matrices and energy of regular graphs	string
2076	en_US	cleanTitle	Lower bounds for energy of matrices and energy of regular graphs	string
2076	en_US	abstract	Let $A=[a_{ij}]$ be a $n\\times n$ real symmetric matrix and $\\lambda_1,\\ldots,\\lambda_n$ be the eigenvalues of $A$. The energy of $A$, denoted by $\\E(A)$, is defined as $|\\lambda_1|+\\cdots+|\\lambda_n|$. In this paper we find a lower bound for the energy of real symmetric matrices. More precisely, we show that if $A\\neq0$, then $$\\E(A)\\geq\\frac{n|\\lambda_1||\\lambda_n|+\\sum_{1\\leq i,j\\leq n}a^2_{ij}}{|\\lambda_1|+|\\lambda_n|},$$<br />where $|\\lambda_1|\\geq\\cdots\\geq|\\lambda_n|$. In particular, we obtain that<br />$$\\E(A)\\geq\\frac{\\sum_{1\\leq i,j\\leq n}a^2_{ij}}{\\xi(A)},$$<br />where $\\xi(A)$ is the maximum value of the sequence $\\sum_{j=1}^{n}|a_{1j}|,\\sum_{j=1}^{n}|a_{2j}|,\\ldots,\\sum_{j=1}^{n}|a_{nj}|$.<br />Let $H$ be a simple graph. The energy of $H$, denoted by $\\E(H)$, is the sum of the absolute values of all eigenvalues of the adjacency matrix of $H$.<br />Let $G$ be a $t$--regular graph on $n$ vertices, where $t\\neq0$. Gutman showed that $\\E(G)\\geq n$. As an application of the above lower bound, we improve the Gutman's result and prove that if $G$ has no eigenvalue in the interval $(-1,1)$, then $\\E(G)\\geq\\frac{2tn}{t+1}$, and the equality holds if and only if every connected component of $G$ is the complete graph $K_{t+1}$ or the crown graph $K^{\\star}_{t+1}$.	string

2077	en_US	title	On the sizes of $k$-edge-maximal $r$-uniform hypergraphs	string
2077	en_US	cleanTitle	On the sizes of kedgemaximal runiform hypergraphs	string
2077	en_US	abstract	<p>Let $H=(V,E)$ be a hypergraph, where $V$ is a set of vertices and $E$ is a set of non-empty subsets of $V$ called edges. If all edges of $H$ have the same cardinality $r$, then $H$ is a $r$-uniform hypergraph; if $E$ consists of all $r$-subsets of $V$, then $H$ is a complete $r$-uniform hypergraph, denoted by $K_n^r$, where $n=|V|$. A hypergraph $H'=(V',E')$ is called a subhypergraph of $H=(V,E)$ if $V'\\subseteq V$ and $E'\\subseteq E$. The edge-connectivity of a hypergraph $H$ is the cardinality of a minimum edge set $F\\subseteq E$ such that $H-F$ is not connected, where $H-F=(V,E\\setminus F)$. A $r$-uniform hypergraph $H=(V,E)$ is $k$-edge-maximal if every subhypergraph of $H$ has edge-connectivity at most $k$, but for any edge $e\\in E(K_n^r)\\setminus E(H)$, $H+e$ contains at least one subhypergraph with edge-connectivity at least $k+1$.</p><p>Let $k$ and $r$ be integers with $k\\geq2$ and $r\\geq2$, and let $t=t(k,r)$ be the largest integer such that $(^{t-1}_{r-1})\\leq k$. That is, $t$ is the integer satisfies $(^{t-1}_{r-1})\\leq k&lt;(^{t}_{r-1})$.<br />We prove that if $H$ is a $r$-uniform $k$-edge-maximal hypergraph such that $n=|V(H)|\\geq t$, then</p><p>($i$) $|E(H)|\\leq (^{t}_{r})+(n-t)k$, and this bound is best possible;</p><p>($ii$) $|E(H)|\\geq (n-1)k -((t-1)k-(^{t}_{r}))\\lfloor\\frac{n}{t}\\rfloor$, and this bound is best possible.</p><p>This extends former results in [8] and [6].</p>	string

2079	en_US	abstract	Detecting meaningful communities has become crucial to advance our knowledge in diverse research areas that deal with datasets which can be naturally represented as networks. By regarding vertex clustering as the opposite problem of vertex colouring, we were able to leverage the Petford-Welsh colouring algorithm to develop a fast, efficient, and highly-scalable decentralised clustering algorithm. 2080	en_US	title	On generalized order graphs of finite groups and relations with power graphs	string
2080	en_US	cleanTitle	On generalized order graphs of finite groups and relations with power graphs	string
2080	en_US	abstract	<span style="color: #000000;">Let </span><span style="color: #008000;">$G$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> be a finite group and let </span><span style="color: #008000;">$o(g)$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> denote the order of </span><span style="color: #008000;">$g\\in G$</span><span style="color: #000000;">.</span><span style="color: #000000;"> The generalized order graph of </span><span style="color: #008000;">$G$</span><span style="color: #000000;">, denoted by </span><span style="color: #008000;">$\\Gamma(G)$</span><span style="color: #000000;">, is defined as the graph with vertex set </span><span style="color: #008000;">$G$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> such that two distinct vertices </span><span style="color: #008000;">$x$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> and </span><span style="color: #008000;">$y$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> are adjacent in </span><span style="color: #008000;">$\\Gamma(G)$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> if </span><span style="color: #008000;">$o(x)$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> divides </span><span style="color: #008000;">$o(y)$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> or </span><span style="color: #008000;">$o(y)$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> divides </span><span style="color: #008000;">$o(x)$</span><span style="color: #000000;">. The power graph of </span><span style="color: #008000;">$G$</span><span style="color: #000000;">, denoted by </span><span style="color: #008000;">$P(G)$</span><span style="color: #000000;">, </span><span style="color: #000000;">is defined as the graph with vertex set </span><span style="color: #008000;">$G$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> such that two distinct vertices </span><span style="color: #008000;">$x$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> and </span><span style="color: #008000;">$y$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> are adjacent in </span><span style="color: #008000;">$P(G)$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> if </span><span style="color: #008000;">$x=y^{m}$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> or </span><span style="color: #008000;">$y=x^{n}$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> for some positive integers </span><span style="color: #008000;">$m, n$</span><span style="color: #000000;">. In this paper,</span><span style="color: #000000;"> we determine some properties of </span><span style="color: #008000;">$\\Gamma (G)$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> and obtain relations between </span><span style="color: #008000;">$\\Gamma (G)$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> and </span><span style="color: #008000;">$P(G)$</span><span style="color: #000000;">. </span><span style="color: #000000;">We prove that if </span><span style="color: #008000;">$G$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> is cyclic, then the graphs </span><span style="color: #008000;">$\\Gamma(G)$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> and </span><span style="color: #008000;">$P(G)$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> are isomorphic </span><span style="color: #000000;">with one another. We also show that </span><span style="color: #008000;">$\\Gamma(G)$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> is perfect, and that </span><span style="color: #008000;">$\\Gamma (G)$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> is complete if and only if </span><span style="color: #008000;">$G$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> is a </span><span style="color: #008000;">$p$</span><span style="color: #000000;">-group. </span><span style="color: #000000;">In addition, we obtain some results on the connectedness and minimum degree of generalized order graphs of finite groups. <br /></span>	string

2081	en_US	title	Impact of Some Graph Operations on Double Roman Domination	string
2081	en_US	cleanTitle	Impact of Some Graph Operations on Double Roman Domination	string
2081	en_US	abstract	Given a graph G = (V;E), a function f : V -&gt; {0; 1; 2; 3} having<br />the property that if f(v) = 0, then there exist v1; v2 in N(v) such that f(v1) = f(v2) = 2 or there exists w in N(v) such that f(w) = 3, and if f(v) = 1, then there exists w in N(v) such that f(w) = 2 is called a double Roman dominating function (DRDF). The weight of a DRDF f is the sum of values assigned to the vertices. The double Roman domination number is the minimum among the weights of DRDFs on G. In this paper, we study the impact of some graph operations, such as cartesian product, addition of twins and corona with a graph, on double Roman domination number.	string

2083	en_US	title	Sum-list-colouring of $\\theta$-hypergraphs	string
2083	en_US	cleanTitle	Sumlistcolouring of \\thetahypergraphs	string
2083	en_US	abstract	Given a hypergraph ${\\mathcal H}$ and a function $f: V({\\mathcal H})\\longrightarrow \\mathbb{N}$, we say that ${\\mathcal H}$ is  $f$-choosable if there is a proper vertex coloring $\\phi$ of ${\\mathcal H}$ such that<br />$\\phi(v)\\in L(v)$ for all $v\\in V({\\mathcal H})$, where $L: V({\\mathcal H})\\longrightarrow 2^{\\mathbb{N}}$ is any assignment of $f(v)$ colors to a vertex $v$. The<br />sum choice number $\\chi_{sc}({\\mathcal H})$ of ${\\mathcal H}$ is defined to be the minimum of<br />$\\sum_{v\\in V({\\mathcal H})}f(v)$  over all functions $f$ such that ${\\mathcal H}$ is $f$-choosable. A trivial upper bound on $\\chi_{sc}({\\mathcal H})$ is $|V({\\mathcal H})|+|{\\mathcal E}({\\mathcal H})|$. The class $\\Gamma_{sc}$ of hypergraphs that achieve this bound is induced hereditary. We analyze some properties of hypergraphs in $\\Gamma_{sc}$ as well as properties of hypergraphs in the class  of forbidden hypergraphs for $\\Gamma_{sc}$. We characterize all $\\theta$-hypergraphs in $\\Gamma_{sc}$, which leads to the characterization of all $\\theta$-hypergraphs that are  forbidden for $\\Gamma_{sc}$.	string

2088	en_US	cleanTitle	C4facemagic toroidal labelings on Cm x Cn	string
2088	en_US	abstract	<p>For a graph <em>G = (V, E)</em> embedded in the torus, let <em>F(G)</em> denote the set of faces of <em>G</em>. Then, <em>G</em> is called a <em>C<sub>n</sub>-face-magic toroidal  graph</em> if there exists a bijection<em> f: V(G) </em><em>→ {1, 2, …, |V(G)|}</em> such that for any<em> F </em><em>є F(G)</em> with <em>F </em><em>≈ C<sub>n</sub></em>, the sum of all the vertex labelings along <em>C<sub>n</sub></em> is a constant <em>S</em>. Let <em>x<sub>v</sub> =f(v)</em> for all <em>v </em><em>є V(G)</em>. We call <em>{x<sub>v</sub> : v </em><em>є V(G)}</em> a <em>C<sub>n</sub></em>-face-magic toroidal labeling on <em>G</em>. We show that, for all <em>m,n </em><em>≥ 2,</em> <em>C<sub>m</sub> x C<sub>n</sub></em> admits a <em>C<sub>4</sub></em>-face-magic toroidal labeling if and only if either <em>m=2</em>, or <em>n=2</em>, or both <em>m</em> and <em>n</em> are even. We say that a <em>C<sub>4</sub></em>-face-magic toroidal labeling <em>{x<sub>i,j </sub>: (i,j) </em><em>є V(C<sub>2m</sub> x C<sub>2n</sub>)}</em> on <em>C<sub>2m</sub> x C<sub>2n</sub></em> is <em>antipodal balanced</em> if <em>x<sub>i,j</sub> + x<sub>i+m,j+n</sub> = </em><em>½S</em> for all <em>(i,j) </em><em>є V(C<sub>2m</sub> x C<sub>2n</sub>).</em> We show that there exists an antipodal balanced <em>C<sub>4</sub></em>-face-magic toroidal labeling on <em>C<sub>2m</sub> x C<sub>2n</sub></em> if and only if the parity of <em>m</em> and <em>n</em> are the same. Furthermore, when both <em>m</em> and <em>n</em> are even, an antipodal balanced <em>C<sub>4</sub></em>-face-magic toroidal labeling on <em>C<sub>2m</sub> x C<sub>2n</sub></em> is both row-sum balanced and column-sum balanced. In addition, when <em>m=n</em> is even, an antipodal balanced <em>C<sub>4</sub></em>-face-magic toroidal labeling on <em>C<sub>2n</sub> x C<sub>2n</sub></em> is diagonal-sum balanced.</p>	string

2089	en_US	cleanTitle	On strong Skolem Starters	string
2089	en_US	abstract	In 1991, Shalaby conjectured that any additive group $\\mathbb{Z}_n$, where $n\\equiv1$ or 3 (mod 8) and $n \\geq11$, admits a strong Skolem starter and constructed these starters of all admissible orders $11\\leq n\\leq57$. Next, Shalaby and et al. in [O. Ogandzhanyants, M. Kondratieva and N. Shalaby, \\emph{Strong Skolem Starters}, J. Combin. Des. {\\bf 27} (2018), no. 1, 5--21], it was proved that, if $n=\\Pi_{i=1}^{k}p_i^{\\alpha_i}$, where $p_i$ is an odd prime such that $ord(2)_{p_i}\\equiv 2$ (mod 4) and $\\alpha_i$ is a non-negative integer, then $\\mathbb{Z}_n$ admits a strong Skolem starter. In this paper, we show other families of strong Skolem starters which were constructed in that paper by using a simple observation of such construction. Also, we give families of strong Skolem starters for $\\mathbb{Z}_p$, $\\mathbb{Z}_{p^n}$ and $\\mathbb{Z}_{pq}$, for infinitely many odd primes $p,q\\equiv1$ (mod 8), and $n&gt;1$ being an odd integer.	string

2090	en_US	cleanTitle	New fractal dimensions and some applications to arithmetic patches	string
2090	en_US	abstract	<p><span>In this paper, we define new fractal dimensions of a metric space in order to calculate the roughness of a set on a large scale. These fractal dimensions are called upper zeta dimension and lower zeta dimension.  The upper zeta dimension is an extension of the zeta dimension introduced by Doty, Gu, Lutz, Elvira, Mayordomo, and Moser. We show that the upper zeta dimension is always a lower bound for the Assouad dimension. Moreover, we apply the upper zeta dimension to the existence of weak arithmetic patches of a given set. Arithmetic patches are higher dimensionalized arithmetic progressions. As a corollary,  we get the affirmative solution to a higher dimensional weak analogue of the Erd\\H{o}s-Tur\\'an conjecture. Here the one dimensional case is proved by Fraser and Yu. As examples, we prove the existence of weak arithmetic patches of the set of all irreducible elements of $\\mathbb{Z}[\\alpha]$, and the set of all prime numbers of the form $p(p(n))$, where $\\alpha$ is an imaginary quadratic integer and $p(n)$ denotes the $n$-th prime number.</span></p>	string

2094	en_US	title	ON SOME PROPERTIES OF CO-MAXIMAL GRAPHS OF COMMUTATIVE RINGS	string
2094	en_US	cleanTitle	ON SOME PROPERTIES OF COMAXIMAL GRAPHS OF COMMUTATIVE RINGS	string
2094	en_US	abstract	Let $R$ be a finite commutative ring with identity. The co-maximal graph $\\varGamma(R)$ is a graph with vertices as elements of $R$, where two distinct vertices $a$ and $b$ are adjacent if and only if $Ra+Rb = R$. Also, $\\Gamma_{2}(R)$ is the subgraph of $\\varGamma(R)$ induced by non-unit elements and $\\varGamma_{2}^{'}(R) = \\varGamma_{2}(R)\\setminus J(R)$ where $J(R)$ is Jacobson radical. In this paper, we characterize the rings for which the graphs $\\varGamma(R)$, $L(\\varGamma(R))$, $\\varGamma_{2}^{'}(R)$ and $L(\\varGamma_{2}^{'}(R))$ are planar. Also, we characterize rings for which $\\varGamma_{2}^{'}(R)$ and $L(\\varGamma_{2}^{'}(R))$ are split graph, and obtain nullity of co-maximal graph for local rings and non-local rings.	string

2096	en_US	title	Distance-balanced graphs and travelling salesman problems	string
2096	en_US	cleanTitle	Distancebalanced graphs and travelling salesman problems	string
2096	en_US	abstract	<p>For every probability <span class="math inline"><em>p</em> ∈ [0, 1]</span> we define a distance-based graph property, the <span class="math inline"><em>p</em></span>TS-distance-balancedness, that in the case <span class="math inline"><em>p</em> = 0</span> coincides with the standard property of distance-balancedness, and in the case <span class="math inline"><em>p</em> = 1</span> is related to the Hamiltonian-connectedness. In analogy with the classical case, where the distance-balancedness of a graph is equivalent to the property of being self-median, we characterize the class of <span class="math inline"><em>p</em></span>TS-distance-balanced graphs in terms of their equity with respect to certain probabilistic centrality measures, inspired by the Travelling Salesman Problem. We prove that it is possible to detect this property looking at the classical distance-balancedness (and therefore looking at the classical centrality problems) of a suitable graph composition, namely the wreath product of graphs. More precisely, we characterize the distance-balancedness of a wreath product of two graphs in terms of the <span class="math inline"><em>p</em></span>TS-distance-balancedness of the factors.</p>	string

2097	en_US	title	Implicit degree sum conditions for spanning trees with at most 3 leaves in $K_{1,4}$-free graphs	string
2097	en_US	cleanTitle	Implicit degree sum conditions for spanning trees with at most 3 leaves in K_{14}free graphs	string
2097	en_US	abstract	Let $G$ be a connected $K_{1,4}$-free graph of order $n$. Kyaw proved that:  (1) If the degree sum of any four independent vertices of $G$ is at least $n-1$, then $G$ contains a spanning tree with at most 3 leaves; (2) if the degree sum of any three independent vertices of $G$ is at least $n$, then $G$  contains a hamiltonian path. In this paper, we generalize these two results by using implicit degree sum conditions. More precisely, we prove that: (i) If the implicit degree sum of any four independent vertices of $G$ is at least $n-1$, then $G$ contains a spanning tree with at most 3 leaves; (ii) if the implicit degree sum of any three independent vertices of $G$ is at least $n$, then $G$  contains a hamiltonian path. Moreover, we give examples to show that the low bounds $n-1$ and $n$ are best possible, respectively.	string

2103	en_US	abstract	<p>Shareshian and Woodroofe asked if for every positive integer <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span> there exist primes <span class="math inline"><em>p</em></span> and <span class="math inline"><em>q</em></span> such that, for all integers <span class="math inline"><em>k</em></span> with <span class="math inline">1 ≤ <em>k</em> ≤ <em>n</em> − 1</span>, the binomial coefficient <span class="math inline">(<em>n</em> choose <em>k</em>)</span> is divisible by at least one of <span class="math inline"><em>p</em></span> or <span class="math inline"><em>q</em></span>. 2104	en_US	title	The forcing nonsplit domination number of a graph	string
2104	en_US	cleanTitle	The forcing nonsplit domination number of a graph	string
2104	en_US	abstract	A dominating set S of a graph G is said to be nonsplit dominating set if the subgraph hV −Si is connected. The minimum cardinality of a nonsplit dominating set is called the nonsplit domination number and is denoted by γns(G). For a minimum nonsplit dominating set S of G, a set T ⊆ S is called a forcing subset for S if S is the unique γns - set containing T. A forcing subset for S of minimum cardinality is a minimum forcing subset of S. The forcing nonsplit domination number of S, denoted by fγns(S), is the cardinality of a minimum forcing subset of S. The forcing nonsplit domination number of G, denoted by fγns(G) is defined by fγns(G) = min{fγns(S)}, where the minimum is taken over all fγns - sets S in G. The forcing nonsplit domination number of certain standard graphs are determined. It is shown that for every pair of positive integers a and b with 0 ≤ a ≤ b and b ≥ 1, there exists a connected graph G such that fγns(G) = a and γns(G) = b. It is shown that for every positive integer a ≥ 0, there exists a connected graph G with fγ(G) = fγns(G) = a. Also, it is shown that for every pair a, b of integers with a ≥ 0 and b ≥ 0 there exists a connected graph G such that fγ(G) = a and fγns(G) = b, where fγ(G) is the forcing domination number of the graph.	string

2105	en_US	cleanTitle	Combinatorial Proof of the Minimal Excludant Theorem	string
2105	en_US	abstract	The minimal excludant of a partition $\\lambda$, $\\mathrm{mex}(\\lambda)$, is defined to be the least gap of $\\lambda$. For each positive integer $n$, the function $ \\sigma\\,  \\mathrm{mex}(n)$ is defined to be the sum of the least gaps in all partitions of $n$. Recently, Andrews and Newman  obtained a new combinatorial interpretations for $\\sigma\\,  \\mathrm{mex}(n)$. They used generating functions to show that $\\sigma\\, \\mathrm{mex}(n)$ equals the number  of partitions of $n$ into distinct parts using two colors. <br /> In this paper, we provide a purely combinatorial proof of this result and new properties of the function $\\sigma\\,  \\mathrm{mex}(n)$.	string

2106	en_US	cleanTitle	Dominating sets in finite generalized quadrangles	string
2106	en_US	abstract	<p>A dominating set in a graph is a set of vertices such that each vertex not in the set has a neighbor in the set. The domination number is the smallest size of a dominating set. We consider this problem in the incidence graph of a generalized quadrangle. We show that the domination number of a generalized quadrangle with parameters <span class="math inline"><em>s</em></span> and <span class="math inline"><em>t</em></span> is at most <span class="math inline">2<em>s</em><em>t</em> + 1</span>, and we prove that this bound is sharp if <span class="math inline"><em>s</em> = <em>t</em></span> or if <span class="math inline"><em>s</em> = <em>q</em> − 1</span> and <span class="math inline"><em>t</em> = <em>q</em> + 1</span>. Moreover, we give a complete classification of smallest dominating sets in generalized quadrangles where <span class="math inline"><em>s</em> = <em>t</em></span>, and give some general results for small dominating sets in the general case.</p>	string

2107	en_US	abstract	Matching number and the spectral properties depending on the characteristic polynomial of a graph has many applications in different areas. 2110	en_US	cleanTitle	Relative Heffter arrays and biembeddings	string
2110	en_US	abstract	<p>Relative Heffter arrays, denoted by <span class="math inline">H<sub><em>t</em></sub>(<em>m</em>, <em>n</em>; <em>s</em>, <em>k</em>)</span>, have been introduced as a generalization of the classical concept of Heffter array. A <span class="math inline">H<sub><em>t</em></sub>(<em>m</em>, <em>n</em>; <em>s</em>, <em>k</em>)</span> is an <span class="math inline"><em>m</em> × <em>n</em></span> partially filled array with elements in <span class="math inline">ℤ<sub><em>v</em></sub></span>, where <span class="math inline"><em>v</em> = 2<em>n</em><em>k</em> + <em>t</em></span>, whose rows contain <span class="math inline"><em>s</em></span> filled cells and whose columns contain <span class="math inline"><em>k</em></span> filled cells, such that the elements in every row and column sum to zero and, for every <span class="math inline"><em>x</em> ∈ ℤ<sub><em>v</em></sub></span> not belonging to the subgroup of order <span class="math inline"><em>t</em></span>, either <span class="math inline"><em>x</em></span> or <span class="math inline">−<em>x</em></span> appears in the array. In this paper we show how relative Heffter arrays can be used to construct biembeddings of cyclic cycle decompositions of the complete multipartite graph <span class="math inline"><em>K</em><sub>(2<em>n</em><em>k</em> + <em>t</em>)/<em>t</em> × <em>t</em></sub></span> into an orientable surface. 2115	en_US	title	On Horadam-Lucas sequence	string
2115	en_US	cleanTitle	On HoradamLucas sequence	string
2115	en_US	abstract	Horadam has introduced a new generalized sequence of numbers, describing its key features and the special sub-sequences that are obtained depending on the choices of initial parameters. This sequence and its sub-sequences are known as the Horadam, generalized Fibonacci, and generalized Lucas numbers, respectively. In the present study, we propose another new sequence, which satisfies a second-order recurrence relation, in addition to Horadam's definition. Further, we prove the Binet's formula, some famous identities, and summation formulas for this new sequence. In particular, we demonstrate the interrelationships between our new sequence and the Horadam sequence.	string

2118	en_US	title	Extremal structures of graphs with  given connectivity or number of pendant vertices	string
2118	en_US	cleanTitle	Extremal structures of graphs with  given connectivity or number of pendant vertices	string
2118	en_US	abstract	For a graph $G$, the first multiplicative Zagreb index $\\prod_1(G) $ is the product of squares of vertex degrees, and the second multiplicative Zagreb index $\\prod_2(G) $ is the product of  products of degrees of pairs of adjacent vertices.   In this paper, we explore graphs with extremal $\\Pi_{1}(G)$ and $\\Pi_{2}(G)$ in terms of (edge) connectivity and pendant vertices. The corresponding extremal graphs are characterized with given connectivity at most $k$ and $p$ pendant vertices.  In addition,  the maximum and minimum values of $\\prod_1(G) $ and $\\prod_2(G) $  are provided. Our results extend and enrich some known conclusions.	string

2119	en_US	title	SYMMETRIC GRAPHS OF ORDER FOUR TIMES AN ODD PRIME POWER AND PRIME VALENCY	string
2119	en_US	cleanTitle	SYMMETRIC GRAPHS OF ORDER FOUR TIMES AN ODD PRIME POWER AND PRIME VALENCY	string
2119	en_US	abstract	<p>This paper studies symmetric graphs of order four times an odd prime power and any prime valency. It includes a classication of such graphs that are vertex quasiprimitive or vertex biquasiprimitive, and a classication of the normal quotient graphs of such graphs. Moreover, by using the classications, such graphs with order four times a prime or a prime square are determined. Notice that special cases for valency 5 and 7 have been investigated in [Yang, Feng, Kwak, Lee, Europ. J. Combin. 80 (2019), 236{246] and [Pan, Yin, J. Algebraic Application 17 (2018), no. 5, 1850093], respectively.</p>	string

2120	en_US	title	Balancing polyhedra	string
2120	en_US	cleanTitle	Balancing polyhedra	string
2120	en_US	abstract	<p>We define the mechanical complexity <span class="math inline"><em>C</em>(<em>P</em>)</span> of a <span class="math inline">3</span>-dimensional convex polyhedron <span class="math inline"><em>P</em></span>, interpreted as a homogeneous solid, as the difference between the total number of its faces, edges and vertices and the number of its static equilibria; and the mechanical complexity <span class="math inline"><em>C</em>(<em>S</em>, <em>U</em>)</span> of primary equilibrium classes <span class="math inline">(<em>S</em>, <em>U</em>)<sup><em>E</em></sup></span> with <span class="math inline"><em>S</em></span> stable and <span class="math inline"><em>U</em></span> unstable equilibria as the infimum of the mechanical complexity of all polyhedra in that class. We prove that the mechanical complexity of a class <span class="math inline">(<em>S</em>, <em>U</em>)<sup><em>E</em></sup></span> with <span class="math inline"><em>S</em>, <em>U</em> &gt; 1</span> is the minimum of <span class="math inline">2(<em>f</em> + <em>v</em> − <em>S</em> − <em>U</em>)</span> over all polyhedral pairs <span class="math inline">(<em>f</em>, <em>v</em>)</span>, where a pair of integers is called a polyhedral pair if there is a convex polyhedron with <span class="math inline"><em>f</em></span> faces and <span class="math inline"><em>v</em></span> vertices. In particular, we prove that the mechanical complexity of a class <span class="math inline">(<em>S</em>, <em>U</em>)<sup><em>E</em></sup></span> is zero if and only if there exists a convex polyhedron with <span class="math inline"><em>S</em></span> faces and <span class="math inline"><em>U</em></span> vertices. We also give asymptotically sharp bounds for the mechanical complexity of the monostatic classes <span class="math inline">(1, <em>U</em>)<sup><em>E</em></sup></span> and <span class="math inline">(<em>S</em>, 1)<sup><em>E</em></sup></span>, and offer a complexity-dependent prize for the complexity of the Gömböc-class <span class="math inline">(1, 1)<sup><em>E</em></sup></span>.</p><p><em> <strong>Dedicated to the memory of John Horton Conway.</strong></em></p>	string

2121	en_US	title	Proof of Stahl's conjecture in some new cases	string
2121	en_US	cleanTitle	Proof of Stahl's conjecture in some new cases	string
2121	en_US	abstract	Saul Stahl defined the $s$-tuple coloring of a graph $G$ and formulated a conjecture on the multichromatic numbers of the Kneser graph $KG_{m,n}$. The conjecture was completely proved for graph parameters $n=2,3$, and $m=2n+1$ by Stahl, and in specially for $m=10$ and $n=4$ by Kincses et al. Furthermore we know that the conjecture is true if $s=qn$. In this paper we present a new lower bound for the multichromatic numbers of $KG_{m,n}$, which is sharp for graph parameters $2n&lt; m&lt; 3n$ and cases $qn-\\frac{n}{m-2n}&lt;s&lt;qn$. So we confirm Stahl's conjecture in these new cases.	string

2122	en_US	title	On generalized truncations of complete graphs	string
2122	en_US	cleanTitle	On generalized truncations of complete graphs	string
2122	en_US	abstract	<p>For a <span class="math inline"><em>k</em></span>-regular graph <span class="math inline">Γ</span> and a graph <span class="math inline">Υ</span> of order <span class="math inline"><em>k</em></span>, a generalized truncation of <span class="math inline">Γ</span> by <span class="math inline">Υ</span> is constructed by replacing each vertex of <span class="math inline">Γ</span> with a copy of <span class="math inline">Υ</span>. E. Eiben, R. Jajcay and P. <span>Š</span>parl introduced a method for constructing vertex-transitive generalized truncations. For convenience, we call a graph obtained by using Eiben <em>et al.</em>’s method a <span><em>special generalized truncation</em></span>. In their paper, Eiben <em>et al.</em> proposed a problem to classify special generalized truncations of a complete graph <span class="math inline"><strong>K</strong><sub><em>n</em></sub></span> by a cycle of length <span class="math inline"><em>n</em> − 1</span>. In this paper, we completely solve this problem by demonstrating that with the exception of <span class="math inline"><em>n</em> = 6</span>, every special generalized truncation of a complete graph <span class="math inline"><strong>K</strong><sub><em>n</em></sub></span> by a cycle of length <span class="math inline"><em>n</em> − 1</span> is a Cayley graph of <span class="math inline">AGL(1, <em>n</em>)</span> where <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span> is a prime power. 2123	en_US	abstract	<pre>Let <span>$S$</span> be a <span>subring</span> of a finite ring <span>$R$</span> and <span>$r\\in R$</span>. 2124	en_US	title	On non-hamiltonian graphs of connectivity 2 with many hamiltonian vertex-deleted subgraphs	string
2124	en_US	cleanTitle	On nonhamiltonian graphs of connectivity 2 with many hamiltonian vertexdeleted subgraphs	string
2124	en_US	abstract	A 2-connected non-hamiltonian graph G is a k-graph if for exactly k &lt; |V (G)| vertices in G, removing such a vertex yields a non-hamiltonian graph. We characterise k-graphs of connectivity 2, and describe examples of such graphs containing no cubic vertex or of minimum degree at least 4, with a special emphasis on the planar case. In particular, it is shown that among graphs of connectivity 2, for every k \\ge 2 there are infinitely many k-graphs with neither cubic nor quartic vertices, and that a planar k-graph of minimum degree 4 exists for every k \\ge 16 but no k \\le 5. We also prove that there exists a k_0 such that for every k \\ge k_0 infinitely many planar k-graphs of connectivity 2 and minimum degree 4 exist. As a variation of a result of Thomassen, we show that certain planar 2- and 3-graphs without cubic vertices do not exist.	string

2128	en_US	title	Building maximal green sequences via component preserving mutations	string
2128	en_US	cleanTitle	Building maximal green sequences via component preserving mutations	string
2128	en_US	abstract	<p>We introduce a new method for producing both maximal green and reddening sequences of quivers. The method, called component preserving mutations, generalizes the notion of direct sums of quivers and can be used as a tool to both recover known reddening sequences as well as find reddening sequences that were previously unknown. We use the method to produce and recover maximal green sequences for many bipartite recurrent quivers that show up in the study of periodicity of <span class="math inline"><em>T</em></span>-systems and <span class="math inline"><em>Y</em></span>-systems. Additionally, we show how our method relates to the dominance phenomenon recently considered by Reading. Given a maximal green sequence produced by our method, this relation to dominance gives a maximal green sequence for infinitely many other quivers. Other applications of this new methodology are explored including computing of quantum dilogarithm identities and determining minimal length maximal green sequences.</p>	string

2129	en_US	cleanTitle	Square roots of automorphisms of cyclic groups	string
2129	en_US	abstract	<p>A skew morphism of a finite group $A$ is a permutation $\\varphi$<br />on $A$ fixing the identity element of $A$ and for which there exists<br /> an integer-valued function $\\pi$ on $A$ such that<br /> $\\varphi(ab) = \\varphi(a)\\varphi^{\\pi(a)}(b)$ for<br />all $a,b\\in A$. If $\\pi(a)=1$ for all $a\\in A$, then $\\varphi$<br />is an automorphism of $A$. Thus, skew morphisms can be viewed as<br />a generalization of group automorphisms. If $\\varphi$ is<br />not an automorphism but $\\varphi^2$ is an automorphism, then<br />$\\varphi$ is called a proper square root of an automorphism.<br />In this paper, the proper square roots of automorphisms<br />of the cyclic groups are classified.</p>	string

2131	en_US	abstract	Let $P(G,\\lambda)$ and $\\mu (G)$ denote the chromatic polynomial  and mean color number of a graph $G$,<br /> respectively.
