2134	en_US	title	Convex Drawings of the Complete Graph:Topology meets Geometry	string
2134	en_US	cleanTitle	Convex Drawings of the Complete Graph:Topology meets Geometry	string
2134	en_US	abstract	In a geometric drawing of K(n), trivially each 3-cycle bounds a convex region:  if two vertices are in that region, then so is the (geometric) edge between them.  We define a topological drawing D of K(n) to be convex if  each 3-cycle bounds a closed region R such that any two vertices in R have the (topological) edge between them contained in R.  While convex drawings generalize geometric drawings, they specialize topological ones.  Therefore it might be surprising if all optimal (that is, crossing-minimal) topological drawings of K(n) were convex.     However, we take a first step to showing that they are convex: we show that if D has a non-convex K(5) all of whose extensions to a K(7) have no other non-convex K(5), then D is not optimal (without reference to the conjecture for the crossing number of K(n)).  This is the first example of non-trivial local considerations providing  sufficient conditions for suboptimality.  At our request, Aichholzer has computationally verified that, up to n=12, every optimal drawing of K(n) is convex.     Convexity naturally lends itself to refinements, including hereditarily convex (h-convex) and face convex (f-convex).   The hierarchy rectilinear is a subset of f-convex is a subset of h-convex is a subset of convex is a subset of  topological provides links between geometric and topological drawings.  It is known that f-convex is equivalent to pseudolinear (generalizing rectilinear) and h-convex is equivalent to pseudospherical (generalizing spherical geodesic).  We characterize h-convexity by three forbidden (topological) subdrawings.<br /> <br />This hierarchy provides a framework to consider generalizations of other geometric questions for point sets in the plane.  We provide two examples of such questions, namely  numbers of empty triangles and existence of convex k-gons.  <br /><br />	string

2141	en_US	title	Approximation of Differential Equations of Chaotic Attractors:  Numerical Method as Encryption Key Field	string
2141	en_US	cleanTitle	Approximation of Differential Equations of Chaotic Attractors:  Numerical Method as Encryption Key Field	string
2141	en_US	abstract	<p>Several cryptographic systems rely on the generation of pseudo-random sequences to conceal messages, chaotic attractors with intrinsic characteristics such as high sensitivity to initial conditions and the randomness of generated signals, have become able to replace their pseudo-random generator. In a crypto-chaotic system, one chooses one of the temporal functions resulting from the dynamic law characterizing the attractor so that it delivers stream-keys. The attractor plays the role of the generator (Ali-Pacha Generator) of the random data and this by applying to it a sampling and then a quantification and finally an encoding so that it satisfies the condition of the sensitivity to the initial conditions and then it is added to the data to be secured.</p><p>The majority of the chaotic attractors  are defined by a system of differential equations (DE). A differential equation is an equality relation linking a function y with one or even several of its derivatives [2]. When the differential equation is completed by an initial condition, that is, by the knowledge of the image of a particular real, we say that we have to solve a Cauchy problem. They do not have analytical solutions except approximations by numerical methods. Indeed, there are several types of differential equations. Each type requires a particular resolution method.</p><p>The question that arises, “How to choose the numerical method that best approximates from a cryptographic point of view the attractor that delivers a chaotic stream (streamkeys), which will be added to the data to be secured”.</p><p>Obtained results  show that  all the different numerical analysis methods approximate globally the same differential equation. However, they do not give the same results as locally for all the points. This difference can be exploited by cryptography system. In other words, the name of the numeric method can be a parameter of the encryption key. So, the result found in this work poses another condition for the extraction of the data coming from a coordinate of a given attractor which are the same for the encryption and the decryption. Therefore, we must be used the same numerical analysis technique to find solutions of  the differential equations of the attractor for encryption and for decryption. In other words, the name of the numeric analysis method can be a parameter of the encryption key.</p>	string

2144	en_US	title	A note on the neighbour-distinguishing index of digraphs	string
2144	en_US	cleanTitle	A note on the neighbourdistinguishing index of digraphs	string
2144	en_US	abstract	<pre>In this note, we introduce and study a new version of neighbour-distinguishing arc-colourings of digraphs.</pre><pre>An arc-colouring <span>$\\gamma$</span> of a digraph <span>$D$</span> is proper if no two arcs with the same head or</pre><pre>with the same tail are assigned the same colour. </pre><pre>For each vertex <span>$u$</span> of <span>$D$</span>, we denote by <span>$S_\\gamma^-(u)$</span> and <span>$S_\\gamma^+(u)$</span> the sets of colours that</pre><pre>appear on the incoming arcs and on the outgoing arcs of <span>$u$</span>, respectively.</pre><pre>An arc colouring <span>$\\gamma$</span> of <span>$D$</span> is <span>\\emph</span>{neighbour-distinguishing} </pre><pre>if, for every two adjacent vertices <span>$u$</span> and <span>$v$</span> of <span>$D$</span>, </pre><pre>the ordered pairs <span>$(S_\\gamma^-(u),S_\\gamma^+(u))$</span> and <span>$(S_\\gamma^-(v),S_\\gamma^+(v))$</span></pre><pre>are distinct.</pre><pre>The neighbour-distinguishing index of <span>$D$</span> is then the smallest number of colours needed</pre><pre>for a neighbour-distinguishing arc-colouring of <span>$D$</span>.</pre><pre> </pre><pre>We prove upper bounds on the neighbour-<span>distingui</span><span>\\-shing</span> index of various classes of digraphs.</pre>	string

2149	en_US	cleanTitle	Quasilanda; ndistancebalanced graphs	string
2149	en_US	abstract	For every pair of vertices u and v with d(u; v) = n, WG<br />unv denotes the set of all vertices of G that are closer to<br />u than to v. A graph G is said to be quasi-(; n)-distance-balanced if jWG<br />unvj = 1jWG<br />vnuj, for some positive<br />rational number &gt; 1: In this paper, we study some properties of these graphs and present a formula to<br />construct such graphs for arbitrarily diameter d. For n = 1, this class of graphs contains the quasi--DB<br />graphs recently introduced by Abedi et al. [Quasi--distance-balanced graphs, Discrete Appl. Math. 227<br />(2017) 21{28]. Moreover, we will take a look at the problems arisen by Abedi et al. Some problems and a<br />conjecture are involved.	string

2152	en_US	abstract	Assume that the linear matrix equation $AXB = C$ is solvable for $X$, and divide the equation in the partitioned form $AXB = A_1X_{11}B_1 + A_1X_{12}B_2  + A_2X_{21}B_1 + A_2X_{22}B_2 = C$. By pre- and post-multiplying certain orthogonal projectors induced from $A_1$, $A_2$, $B_1$, and $B_2$ on both sides of the equation, we obtain four reduced linear matrix equations that involve the submatrices $X_{11}$, $X_{12}$, $X_{21}$, and $X_{22}$, separately. There are profound relations between the original equation and its four reduced equations, and the aim of this note is to establish some equalities among the general solutions of the original equation and its four reduced equations using the ranks, ranges, and generalized inverses of the given matrices in the original equation.	string

2154	en_US	title	Graphical Frobenius representations of non-abelian groups	string
2154	en_US	cleanTitle	Graphical Frobenius representations of nonabelian groups	string
2154	en_US	abstract	<p>A group <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> has a Frobenius graphical representation (GFR) if there is a simple graph <span class="math inline"><em>Γ</em></span> whose full automorphism group is isomorphic to <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> acting on the vertices as a Frobenius group. In particular, any group <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> with a GFR is a Frobenius group and <span class="math inline"><em>Γ</em></span> is a Cayley graph. By very recent results of Spiga, there exists a function <span class="math inline"><em>f</em></span> such that if <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> is a finite Frobenius group with complement <span class="math inline"><em>H</em></span> and <span class="math inline">|<em>G</em>| &gt; <em>f</em>(|<em>H</em>|)</span> then G admits a GFR. This paper provides an infinite family of graphs that admit GFRs despite not meeting Spiga’s bound. In our construction, the group <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> is the Higman group <span class="math inline"><em>A</em>(<em>f</em>, <em>q</em><sub>0</sub>)</span> for an infinite sequence of <span class="math inline"><em>f</em></span> and <span class="math inline"><em>q</em><sub>0</sub></span>, having a nonabelian kernel and a complement of odd order.</p>	string

2156	en_US	title	Further generalizations of the parallelogram law	string
2156	en_US	cleanTitle	Further generalizations of the parallelogram law	string
2156	en_US	abstract	In recent work \\cite{FON}, a generalization of the parallelogram law in any dimension $N\\geq 2$ was given by considering the ratio of the quadratic mean of the measures of the $N-1$-dimensional diagonals to the quadratic mean of the measures of the faces of a parallelotope. In this paper, we provide a further generalization considering not only $(N-1)$-dimensional diagonals and faces, but the $k$-dimensional ones for every $1\\leq k\\leq N-1$.	string

2157	en_US	title	Weighted Distance Transforms on the Triangular Tiling	string
2157	en_US	cleanTitle	Weighted Distance Transforms on the Triangular Tiling	string
2157	en_US	abstract	<p>Digital geometry is a field in the intersection of discrete mathematics and geometry. In digital spaces, in grids, distances can be defined based on steps in paths in somewhat similarly as in graph theory. However, the grids have more definite structure, thus one may obtain more concrete results, e.g., close formulae, than on (arbitrary) graphs. In this paper, the weighted (also called chamfer) distances, and based on them, the distance transform are investigated on the regular triangular grid. Three types of neighborhood relations are used on the grid, and therefore, three weights are used to define a distance function. Natural conditions are used on the weights such as they are positive and a larger step (in the usual and also in the Euclidean sense) cannot have a smaller weight than a smaller one. Some properties of the weighted distances are discussed; \\textit{e.g.}, they are proven to be metrics. We also give algorithms and formulae that compute the weighted distance of any point-pair on a triangular grid. Algorithm for weighted distance transform is provided based on wave-front propagation. Therefore, these new distance functions are ready for further<br /> applications in image processing, computer vision, graphics and other applied fields.</p>	string

2159	en_US	cleanTitle	A parameter to measure the difficulty of rational approximation	string
2159	en_US	abstract	For irrational numbers, a parameter is introduced as a measure of the difficulty of rational approximation. It is shown that this parameter is the largest for the golden ratio. Hence, based on this parameter, a correspondence is proposed between the golden ratio and the equilibrium state, further explaining as to why the golden ratio is ubiquitous in nature.	string

2160	en_US	title	Derivations and identities for Chebyshev polynomials of  the first and second kinds	string
2160	en_US	cleanTitle	Derivations and identities for Chebyshev polynomials of  the first and second kinds	string
2160	en_US	abstract	<pre>In this paper, we follow the general approach, previously proposed by the first author, which is derived from the invariant theory field and provides a way of obtaining of the polynomial identities for any arbitrary polynomial family.  </pre><pre> </pre><pre>We introduce the notion of <span>Chebyshev</span> derivations of the first and second kinds, which is  based on the polynomial algebra, and corresponding specific differential operators. We derive the elements of their kernels and prove that any element of the kernel of the derivations  defines a polynomial identity satisfied by the <span>Chebyshev</span> polynomials of the first and second kinds.  Combining elementary methods and combinatorial techniques, we obtain  several new polynomial identities involving the <span>Chebyshev</span> polynomials of the both kinds and a special case of the Jacobi polynomials.</pre><pre> </pre><pre>Using the properties of the generalised <span>hypergeometric</span> function, we specify  the <span>Chebyshev</span> polynomials of the first and second kinds  via  the generalised <span>hypergeometric</span> function and, as a consequence, derive the corresponding identities involving the generalised <span>hypergeometric</span> function and the <span>Chebyshev</span> polynomials of the first and second kinds.</pre>	string

2161	en_US	title	On sign-symmetric signed graphs	string
2161	en_US	cleanTitle	On signsymmetric signed graphs	string
2161	en_US	abstract	<p>A signed graph is said to be sign-symmetric if it is switching isomorphic to its negation. Bipartite signed graphs are trivially sign-symmetric. We give new constructions of non-bipartite sign-symmetric signed graphs. Sign-symmetric signed graphs have a symmetric spectrum but not the other way around. We present constructions of signed graphs with symmetric spectra which are not sign-symmetric. This, in particular answers a problem posed by Belardo, Cioabă, Koolen, and Wang in 2018.</p>	string

2165	en_US	title	{A proof of the twin prime conjecture by a recursive sieve method}	string
2165	en_US	cleanTitle	{A proof of the twin prime conjecture by a recursive sieve method}	string
2165	en_US	abstract	In discrete mathematics we seek for an algorithm to solve the twin prime conjecture.<br />Extending both arithmetic operations +, x into finite sets of natural numbers, from the entire set of natural numbers successively deleting two residue classes 0,-2 modulo a prime, we invent a recursive sieve method or  algorithm on natural numbers and their finite sets. The sifting process mechanically yields a sequence of sets of almost twin primes, which converges to the set of all twin primes, and the corresponding cardinal sequence is strictly  increasing. The new algorithm itself reveals  structures of the set of all twin primes, example the order topological structure. The existing theory of those structures allows us to prove that  the set of all twin primes is infinite.	string

2167	en_US	title	Strong cliques in claw-free graphs	string
2167	en_US	cleanTitle	Strong cliques in clawfree graphs	string
2167	en_US	abstract	<pre>For a graph <span>$G$</span>, <span>$L(G)^2$</span> is the square of the line graph of <span>$G$</span> -- <span>that</span> is, <span>vertices</span> of <span>$L(G)^2$</span> <span>are</span> <span>edges</span> of <span>$G$</span> and <span>two</span> <span>edges</span> <span>$e,f\\in E(G)$</span> <span>are</span> <span>adjacent</span> in <span>$L(G)^2$</span> if at least one vertex of <span>$e$</span> is <span>adjacent</span> to a vertex of <span>$f$</span> and <span>$e\\neq f$</span>. The <span>\\emph</span>{strong <span>chromatic</span> index} of <span>$G$</span>, <span>denoted</span> by <span>$s'(G)$</span>, is the <span>chromatic</span> number of <span>$L(G)^2$</span>. A strong <span>clique</span> in <span>$G$</span> is a <span>clique</span> in <span>$L(G)^2$</span>. <span>Finding</span> a <span>bound</span> for the maximum size of a strong <span>clique</span> in <span>$G$</span>, <span>equals</span> to <span>$\\omega(L(G)^2)$</span>, is a problem <span>connected</span> to a <span>famous</span> <span>conjecture</span> of <span>Erd</span>{<span>\\H</span> o}s and Ne<span>\\v</span>{s}et<span>\\v</span>{r}il <span>about</span> strong <span>chromatic</span> index from 1985.</pre><pre> </pre><pre>In this <span>note</span> we <span>prove</span> <span>that</span> a size of a strong <span>clique</span> in a <span>claw</span>-free graph <span>with</span> maximum <span>degree</span> <span>$\\Delta$</span> is at most <span>$\\Delta^2 + \\frac{1}{2}\\Delta$</span>. <span>This</span> <span>result</span> <span>improves</span> the <span>only</span> <span>know</span> <span>result</span> <span>$1.125\\Delta^2+\\Delta$</span>, <span>which</span> is a <span>bound</span> for the strong <span>chromatic</span> index of <span>claw</span>-free <span>graphs</span>.</pre>	string

2169	en_US	abstract	Let $G = \\PGL_{2}(q)$, where $q$ is a power of an odd and even prime. Let $M$ be a fixed maximal subgroup of $G$. 2171	en_US	title	THE ULAM SEQUENCE OF THE INTEGER POLYNOMIAL RING	string
2171	en_US	cleanTitle	THE ULAM SEQUENCE OF THE INTEGER POLYNOMIAL RING	string
2171	en_US	abstract	<p>An Ulam sequence U(1,n) is defined as the sequence starting with integers<br />1,n such that n &gt; 1, and such that every subsequent term is the smallest integer that can be written as the sum of distinct previous terms in exactly one way. This family of sequences is notable for being the subject of several remarkable rigidity conjectures. We introduce an analogous notion of an Ulam sequence in the polynomial ring Z[X], and use it both to give new, constructive proofs of old results as well as producing a new conjecture that implies many of the other existing conjectures.</p>	string

2172	en_US	abstract	We prove that a set $A$ of at most $q$ non-collinear points in the finite plane $\\mathbb{F}_{q}^{2}$ spans at least $\\approx\\frac{|A|}{\\sqrt{q}}$ directions: this is based on a lower bound contained in [FST13], which we prove again together with a different upper bound than the one given therein. 2173	en_US	abstract	The distinguishing index of~a~graph $G$, denoted by $D'(G)$, is the~least number of~colours in~an edge colouring of~$G$ not preserved by any nontrivial automorphism. This invariant  is defined for any graph without $K_2$ as a~connected component and without two isolated vertices, and such a~graph is called admissible graph. We prove the~Nordhaus-Gaddum type relation: $$2\\leq D'(G)+D'(\\overline{G})\\leq \\Delta(G)+2$$ for every admissible connected graph of~order $|G|\\geq 7$ such that $\\overline{G}$ is also admissible.<br /><br />	string

2176	en_US	title	The algebraic and geometric classification of nilpotent terminal algebras	string
2176	en_US	cleanTitle	The algebraic and geometric classification of nilpotent terminal algebras	string
2176	en_US	abstract	<p>We give algebraic and geometric classifications of $4$-dimensional complex nilpotent terminal algebras. <br /> Specifically, we find that, up to isomorphism, <br /> there are <br /> $41$ one-parameter families of $4$-dimensional nilpotent terminal (non-Leibniz) algebras, <br /> $18$ two-parameter families of $4$-dimensional nilpotent terminal (non-Leibniz) algebras, <br /> $2$ three-parameter families of $4$-dimensional nilpotent terminal (non-Leibniz) algebras,<br /> complemented by $21$ additional isomorphism classes (see Theorem~\\ref{main-alg}). <br /> The corresponding geometric variety has dimension 17 and decomposes into 3 irreducible components determined by the Zariski closures of a one-parameter family of algebras, a two-parameter family of algebras and a three-parameter family of algebras (see Theorem~\\ref{main-geo}). <br /> In particular, there are no rigid $4$-dimensional complex nilpotent terminal algebras.</p>	string

2184	en_US	title	Nonseparating Independent Sets and Maximum Genus of Graphs	string
2184	en_US	cleanTitle	Nonseparating Independent Sets and Maximum Genus of Graphs	string
2184	en_US	abstract	A subset $S$ of vertices of an undirected connected graph $G$ is a nonseparating independent set (NSIS) if no two vertices of $I$ are adjacent and $G-I$ is connected. Let $Z(G)$ denote the cardinality of a maximum NSIS of $G$. A nonseparating independent set of<br />$Z(G)$ vertices is called the maximum nonseparating independent set. In this paper, we give a new upper bound of $Z(G)$ of regular graphs and determine $Z(G)$ for some types of circular graphs. Nextly, the relationships between $Z(G)$ and the maximum genus $\\gamma_{M}(G)$ are investigated. Finally, we offer an important formula to compute $Z(G)$, i.e., $$Z(G)=\\sum_{x\\in I}d(x)+2\\Bigg(\\gamma_M(G-I)- \\gamma_M(G)\\Bigg)+\\Bigg(\\xi(G-I)-\\xi(G)\\Bigg),$$ where $I$ is the maximum nonseparating independent set and $\\xi(G)$ is the Betti deficiency (Xuong, 1979) of $G$.	string

2185	en_US	abstract	Consider the diophantine equation $(3^{x_1}-1)(3^{x_2}-1)=(5^{y_1}-1)(5^{y_2}-1)$ in positive integers $x_1\\le x_2$, and $y_1\\le y_2$. Each side of the equation is a product of two terms of a given binary recurrence, respectively. In this paper, we prove that the only solution to the title equation is $(x_1,x_2,y_1,y_2)=(1,2,1,1)$. The novelty is the products of two terms appearing on the sides.	string

2188	en_US	title	On the maximum CEI of graphs with parameters	string
2188	en_US	cleanTitle	On the maximum CEI of graphs with parameters	string
2188	en_US	abstract	The connective eccentricity index (CEI) of a graph $G$ is defined as $\\xi^{ce}(G)=\\sum_{v \\in V(G)}\\frac{d_G(v)}{\\varepsilon_G(v)}$, where $d_G(v)$ is the degree of $v$ and $\\varepsilon_G(v)$ is the eccentricity of $v$. In this paper, we characterize  the unique graphs with  maximum CEI from three classes of graphs: the $n$-vertex graphs with fixed connectivity and diameter, the $n$-vertex graphs  with fixed connectivity and independence number, and the $n$-vertex graphs with fixed connectivity and minimum degree.	string

2190	en_US	title	The Varchenko Determinant	string
2190	en_US	cleanTitle	The Varchenko Determinant	string
2190	en_US	abstract	<span>Varchenko introduced a distance function on chambers of hyperplane arrangements that he called quantum bilinear form. That gave rise to a determinant, indexed by those chambers, whose entry in position (C,D) is the distance between C and D: that is the Varchenko determinant. His purpose was to show that the Varchenko determinant has a nice factorization. Aguiar and Mahajan deﬁned later a generalization of the quantum bilinear form, and showed that, for central hyperplane arrangements, the determinant given rise by their distance function has also a nice factorization. We aim to prove that, for arbitrary hyperplane arrangements, the determinant given rise by that generalized quantum bilinear form has a nice factorization. Moreover, we prove that, if the determinant is indexed by the chambers of apartments, then it also has a nice factorization.<br /></span>	string

2191	en_US	abstract	Recently, Khalili and Yadollahzadeh [1] investigated the uniqueness and existence of solution $u(t),~t\\in[0,1]$ for class of nonlocal boundary conditions to Langevin equation. In the current contribution, we show the correct method for using this condition and study the existence and uniqueness of solution for the same class of equation in slightly different form with anti-periodic and nonlocal integral boundary conditions as well as the boundary condition $u'(0)=0$. An exemplar is provided to illustrate our results.	string

2192	en_US	title	Extremal problems on full binary trees with respect to the cover cost and the reverse cover cost	string
2192	en_US	cleanTitle	Extremal problems on full binary trees with respect to the cover cost and the reverse cover cost	string
2192	en_US	abstract	Full binary trees are trees in which every vertex has degree 1 or 3. For a connected graph $G =(V(G), E(G))$, the cover cost (resp. reverse cover cost) of a vertex $u$ in $G$ is defined as $CC_G(u)=\\sum_{v\\in V(G)}H_{uv}$ (resp. $RC_G(u)=\\sum_{v\\in V(G)}H_{vu}$), where $H_{uv}$ is the expected hitting time for random walk beginning at $u$ to visit $v$. In this paper, the unique tree with the maximum cover cost and maximum reverse cover cost among all full binary trees with given order are identified. Furthermore, the unique tree with the minimal reverse cover cost among all full binary trees with given order is also characterized.	string

2193	en_US	title	On a certain class of 1-thin distance-regular graphs	string
2193	en_US	cleanTitle	On a certain class of 1thin distanceregular graphs	string
2193	en_US	abstract	<p>Let <span class="math inline"><em>Γ</em></span> denote a non-bipartite distance-regular graph with vertex set <span class="math inline"><em>X</em></span>, diameter <span class="math inline"><em>D</em> ≥ 3</span>, and valency <span class="math inline"><em>k</em> ≥ 3</span>. Fix <span class="math inline"><em>x</em> ∈ <em>X</em></span> and let <span class="math inline"><em>T</em> = <em>T</em>(<em>x</em>)</span> denote the Terwilliger algebra of <span class="math inline"><em>Γ</em></span> with respect to <span class="math inline"><em>x</em></span>. For any <span class="math inline"><em>z</em> ∈ <em>X</em></span> and for <span class="math inline">0 ≤ <em>i</em> ≤ <em>D</em></span>, let <span class="math inline"><em>Γ</em><sub><em>i</em></sub>(<em>z</em>) = {<em>w</em> ∈ <em>X</em> : ∂(<em>z</em>, <em>w</em>) = <em>i</em>}.</span> For <span class="math inline"><em>y</em> ∈ <em>Γ</em><sub>1</sub>(<em>x</em>)</span>, abbreviate <span class="math inline"><em>D</em><sub><em>j</em></sub><sup><em>i</em></sup> = <em>D</em><sub><em>j</em></sub><sup><em>i</em></sup>(<em>x</em>, <em>y</em>) = <em>Γ</em><sub><em>i</em></sub>(<em>x</em>) ∩ <em>Γ</em><sub><em>j</em></sub>(<em>y</em>) (0 ≤ <em>i</em>, <em>j</em> ≤ <em>D</em>)</span>. For <span class="math inline">1 ≤ <em>i</em> ≤ <em>D</em></span> and for a given <span class="math inline"><em>y</em></span>, we define maps <span class="math inline"><em>H</em><sub><em>i</em></sub>: <em>D</em><sub><em>i</em></sub><sup><em>i</em></sup> → ℤ</span> and <span class="math inline"><em>V</em><sub><em>i</em></sub>: <em>D</em><sub><em>i</em> − 1</sub><sup><em>i</em></sup> ∪ <em>D</em><sub><em>i</em></sub><sup><em>i</em> − 1</sup> → ℤ</span> as follows: <br /><span class="math display"><em>H</em><sub><em>i</em></sub>(<em>z</em>) = |<em>Γ</em><sub>1</sub>(<em>z</em>) ∩ <em>D</em><sub><em>i</em> − 1</sub><sup><em>i</em> − 1</sup>|,  <em>V</em><sub><em>i</em></sub>(<em>z</em>) = |<em>Γ</em><sub>1</sub>(<em>z</em>) ∩ <em>D</em><sub><em>i</em> − 1</sub><sup><em>i</em> − 1</sup>|.</span><br /> We assume that for every <span class="math inline"><em>y</em> ∈ <em>Γ</em><sub>1</sub>(<em>x</em>)</span> and for <span class="math inline">2 ≤ <em>i</em> ≤ <em>D</em></span>, the corresponding maps <span class="math inline"><em>H</em><sub><em>i</em></sub></span> and <span class="math inline"><em>V</em><sub><em>i</em></sub></span> are constant, and that these constants do not depend on the choice of <span class="math inline"><em>y</em></span>. We further assume that the constant value of <span class="math inline"><em>H</em><sub><em>i</em></sub></span> is nonzero for <span class="math inline">2 ≤ <em>i</em> ≤ <em>D</em></span>. We show that every irreducible <span class="math inline"><em>T</em></span>-module of endpoint 1 is thin. Furthermore, we show <span class="math inline"><em>Γ</em></span> has exactly three irreducible <span class="math inline"><em>T</em></span>-modules of endpoint 1, up to isomorphism, if and only if three certain combinatorial conditions hold. As examples, we show that the Johnson graphs <span class="math inline"><em>J</em>(<em>n</em>, <em>m</em>)</span> where <span class="math inline"><em>n</em> ≥ 7,</span> <span class="math inline"> 3 ≤ <em>m</em> &lt; <em>n</em>/2</span> satisfy all of these conditions.</p>	string

2194	en_US	cleanTitle	Strongly involutive selfdual polyhedra	string
2194	en_US	abstract	<p>A polyhedron is a graph G which is simple, planar and 3-connected. In this note, we classify the family of strongly involutive self-dual polyhedra. The latter is done by using a well-known result due to Tutte characterizing 3-connected graphs. We also show that this special class of polyhedra self-duality behaves topologically as the antipodal mapping. These self-dual polyhedra are related with several problems in convex and discrete geometry including the Vázsonyi problem.</p>	string

2199	en_US	abstract	<p>This paper deals with some of the algebraic properties of Sierpiński graphs and a family of regular generalized Sierpiński graphs. 2201	en_US	cleanTitle	Geometry of the parallelism in polar spine spaces and their line reducts	string
2201	en_US	abstract	The concept of spine geometry over a polar Grassmann space was introduced in [9]. The geometry in question belongs also to a wide family of partial affine line spaces. It is known that such a geometry -- e.g. the ``ordinary'' spine geometry, as considered in [13, 14] can be developed in terms of points, so called affine lines, and their parallelism (in this case this parallelism is not intrinsically definable: it is not `Veblenian', cf. [11]). This paper aims to prove an analogous result for polar spine spaces. As a by-product we  obtain several other results on primitive notions for the geometry of polar spine spaces.	string

2202	en_US	title	An algebraic reduction of Hedetniemi's conjecture	string
2202	en_US	cleanTitle	An algebraic reduction of Hedetniemi's conjecture	string
2202	en_US	abstract	<p>For a graph $G$, let $\\chi (G)$ denote the chromatic number. In graph theory, the following famous conjecture posed by Hedetniemi has been studied: For two graphs $G$ and $H$, $\\chi (G\\times H)=\\min\\{\\chi (G),\\chi (H)\\}$, where $G \\times H$ is the tensor product of $G$ and $H$. In this paper, we give a reduction of Hedetniemi's conjecture to an inclusion relation problem on ideals of polynomial rings, and we demonstrate computational experiments for partial solutions of Hedetniemi's conjecture along such a strategy using Gr\\"{o}bner basis.</p>	string

2203	en_US	title	Module derivations on commutative Banach modules	string
2203	en_US	cleanTitle	Module derivations on commutative Banach modules	string
2203	en_US	abstract	In this paper, the module commutative module amenable Banach algebras are characterized. The hereditary and permanence properties of module amenability and the relations between module amenability of a Banach algebra and its ideals are explored. Analogous to the classical case of amenability, it is shown that the projective tensor product and direct sum of module amenable Banach algebras are again module amenable. By an application of Ryll-Nardzewski fixed point theorem, it is shown that for an inverse semigroup $S$, every module derivation of  $\\ell^1(S)$ into a reflexive module is inner.	string

2204	en_US	title	On Combinatorial Rectangles with Minimum ∞−Discrepancy	string
2204	en_US	cleanTitle	On Combinatorial Rectangles with Minimum ∞−Discrepancy	string
2204	en_US	abstract	<p>A combinatorial rectangle may be viewed as a matrix whose entries are all ±1. The discrepancy of<br />an m × n matrix is the maximum among the absolute values of its m row sums and n column sums.<br />In this paper, we investigate combinatorial rectangles with minimum discrepancy (0 or 1 for each line<br />depending on the parity). Specifically, we get explicit formula for the number of matrices with minimum<br />L ∞ -discrepancy up to 4 rows, and establish the order of magnitude of the number of such matrices<br />with m rows and n columns while m is fixed and n approaches infinity. By considering the number of<br />column-good matrices with a fixed row-sum vector, we have developed a theory of decreasing criterion<br />on based row-sum vectors with majorization relation, which turns out to be a helpful tool in the proof<br />of our main theorems.</p>	string

2205	en_US	title	A note on the optimal rubbling in ladders and prisms	string
2205	en_US	cleanTitle	A note on the optimal rubbling in ladders and prisms	string
2205	en_US	abstract	<p>A pebbling move on a graph $G$ consists of the removal of two pebbles from one vertex and the placement of one pebble on an adjacent vertex. Rubbling is a version of pebbling where an additional move is allowed, which is also called the strict rubbling move. In this new move, one pebble each is removed from $u$ and $v$ adjacent to a vertex $w$, and one pebble is added on $w$. The rubbling number of a graph $G$ is the smallest number $m$, such that one pebble can be moved to each vertex from every distribution with $m$ pebbles.<br />The optimal rubbling number of a graph $G$ is the smallest number $m$, such that one pebble can be moved to each vertex from some distribution with $m$ pebbles. In this paper, we give short proofs to determine the rubbling number of cycles and the optimal rubbling number of paths, cycles, ladders, prisms and M$\\rm \\ddot{o}$bius-ladders.</p>	string
2205	en_US	discipline		string
2205	en_US	subjectClass	05c99	string
2205	en_US	subject	pebbling; rubbling; ladders; prisms	string
2205	en_US	sponsor	Natural Science Research of Anhui Provincial Department of Education; NSFC	string

2208	en_US	title	On the minimum eccentric distance sum of trees with given distance $k$-domination number	string
2208	en_US	cleanTitle	On the minimum eccentric distance sum of trees with given distance kdomination number	string
2208	en_US	abstract	<p>Let $k$ be a positive integer and $G$ be a simple connected graph. The eccentric distance sum of $G$ is defined as $\\xi^d(G)=\\sum_{v\\in V(G)}\\varepsilon_{G}(v)D_{G}(v)$, where $\\varepsilon_G(v)$ is the maximum distance from $v$ to any other vertex and $D_G(v)=\\sum_{u\\in V(G)}d_G(u,v)$ is the sum of all distances from $v$. A set $D\\subseteq V(G)$ is a distance $k$-dominating set of $G$ if for every vertex $u\\in V(G)\\setminus D$, $d_G(u,v)\\leq k$ for some vertex $v\\in D$.<br />The minimum cardinality among all distance $k$-dominating sets of $G$ is called the distance $k$-domination number $\\gamma_k(G)$ of $G$. In this paper, the trees among all $n$-vertex trees with distance $k$-domination number $\\gamma_{k}$ having the minimal eccentric distance sum are determined.</p>	string

2212	en_US	cleanTitle	Minimal Wiener Index of Trees with Given Number of Vertices of Maximum Degree	string
2212	en_US	abstract	The Wiener index of a graph is defined as the sum of distances between all unordered pairs of vertices. As one of the most well known chemical indices, the extremal structures that maximize or minimize the Wiener index have been extensively studied for many different classes of graphs, among which are trees with a given degree sequence or segment sequence. In this paper we consider trees with given number of vertices of maximum degree and solve the minimal extremal problem for that class. Characteristics of the extremal structures are presented, some directly from previously established methods.	string

2210	en_US	cleanTitle	Tense Operators on Dynamic Algebras and Related Representation Theorems on GFA	string
2210	en_US	abstract	<p>The present paper is an attempt to suggest and scrutinize tense operators in the dynamic logic <strong>B </strong>which is regarded as a set of propositions about the general fuzzy automaton , in which its underlying structure has been a bounded poset. Here, the operators <em>; </em><em>;</em>and <em> </em>are proposed regardless of what propositional connectives the logic comprises. For this purpose, the axiomatization of universal quantifiers is applied as a starting point and these axioms are modified. In this study, firstly, we demonstrate that the operators can be identified as modal operators and the pairs (<em>;</em>) are examined as the so-called dynamic pairs. In addition, constructions of these operators are attained in the corresponding algebra provided and in the following a transition frame is suggested. Besides, the problem of finding a transition frame is solved in the case when the tense operators are given. Specifically, this study shows that the tense algebra <strong>B </strong>is representable in its Dedekind-MacNeille completion. Representation theorems for dynamic and tense algebra are explicated in details in Theorem 4.5 and 5.4.</p>	string

2213	en_US	cleanTitle	The Ramsey number for tree versus wheel with odd order	string
2213	en_US	abstract	<p class="p1">Chen et al. (2004) conjectured that for even $m$, $R(T_n,W_m)=2n-1$ if the maximum<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span>degree $\\Delta(T_n)$ is small. However, they did not state how small it is. Related to this conjecture, it is also interesting to know which tree $T_n$ causes<span class="Apple-converted-space">  </span>the Ramsey number $R(T_n,W_m)$ is greater than $2n-1$ whenever $m$ is even.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span>In this paper, we determine the Ramsey number $R(T_n,W_8)$ for all trees $T_n$ with<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span>$\\Delta(T_n) \\geq n-3$. For most cases of these trees,<span class="Apple-converted-space">  </span>$R(T_n,W_8) &gt; 2n-1$. Furthermore, we also prove that for certain values of $n$, the Ramsey number<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span>$R(T_n,W_m)$ is greater than $2n-1$ if $\\Delta(T_n) \\geq n-3$ and $m$ is even.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span>Finally, we refine the above conjecture by giving an upper bound of the maximum degree<span class="Apple-converted-space">  </span>of the tree $T_n$.</p>	string

2216	en_US	abstract	<p>Adding new classes of integers to literature is both challenging and charming. Unless a new class is fully characterized, its mathematics is not worthwhile. While, it's absurd to play with integers without intended consequences. <br />In this work, we introduce and investigate four new classes of<br />integers namely, anti-totient numbers, half anti-totient numbers, near and half near<br />Zumkller numbers by using the notion of non co-prime residues of $n$<br />including $n$. 2218	en_US	title	On the minimal number of generators of endomorphism monoids of full shifts	string
2218	en_US	cleanTitle	On the minimal number of generators of endomorphism monoids of full shifts	string
2218	en_US	abstract	For a group $G$ and a finite set $A$, denote by $\\End(A^G)$ the monoid of all continuous shift commuting self-maps of $A^G$ and by $\\Aut(A^G)$ its group of units. We study the minimal cardinality of a generating set, known as the \\emph{rank}, of $\\End(A^G)$ and $\\Aut(A^G)$. In the first part, when $G$ is a finite group, we give upper and lower bounds for the rank of $\\Aut(A^G)$ in terms of the number of conjugacy classes of subgroups of $G$. In the second part, we apply our bounds to show that if $G$ has an infinite descending chain of normal subgroups of finite index, then $\\End(A^G)$ is not finitely generated; such is the case for wide classes of infinite groups, such as infinite residually finite or infinite locally graded groups.	string

2221	en_US	cleanTitle	The Tur{a}n numbers of two classes of forests	string
2221	en_US	abstract	<p>A graph is called $H$-free if it does not contain $H$ as a subgraph. The Tur\\'{a}n number of $H$, denoted by $ex(n,H)$, is the maximum number of<br />edges in any $H$-free graph on $n$ vertices. For sufficiently large $n$ ($n=k_2+3d+r$), Lidick\\'{y}, Liu and Palmer [\\emph{On the Tur\\'{a}n number of forests,} Electron. J. Combin. {20} (2013) \\#P62] determined $ex(n,F)$,<br />where $F$ denotes a class of forest with components each of order 4, and they characterized all the extremal graphs.<br />Moreover, Lan \\emph{et al.} [\\emph{The Tur\\'{a}n number of star forests,} Appl Math Comput. {348} (2019) 270-274] proved that the extremal graph is unique when $n\\ge 10k_1+13k_2+3$.<br />Motivated by their results, we consider a class of forests (that is, $F=k_1\\cdot P_6 \\cup k_2\\cdot S_5$) with components each of order 6,<br />we determine $ex(n,F)$ for sufficiently large $n$ ($n=k_2+5d+r$),<br />and we also characterize all the extremal graphs. Furthermore, we prove that the extremal graph is unique when $n\\ge 23k_1+31k_2+3$.<br />Recently, Lan, Qin and Shi [\\emph{The Tur\\'{a}n number of $2P_7$,} Discuss. Math. Graph Theory {39} (2019) 805-814] determined the exact value of $ex(n,2\\cdot P_7)$. Motivated by their results, we show that<br />$ex(n,2\\cdot P_9)=max\\{[n,18,9],7n-27\\}$ for all $n\\ge 18$, where $[n,18,9]=(7n+153+r(r-8)/2, n-17\\equiv r\\pmod{8}$ and $0\\le r&lt;8$.</p>	string

2222	en_US	title	MATHEMATICAL MODELING OF THE MEMBRANE CONCENTRATION OF WHEY BY THE STATE SPACE METHOD	string
2222	en_US	cleanTitle	MATHEMATICAL MODELING OF THE MEMBRANE CONCENTRATION OF WHEY BY THE STATE SPACE METHOD	string
2222	en_US	abstract	<p>Development of a mathematical model for the membrane concentration process and methods for determining the design parameters of the pilot membrane (ultra-filtration) device based on tubular membrane filters. The state space method was used to compile the state and control matrices, including coefficients that were obtained taking into account the structure of transfer functions. The experimental studies allowed carrying out a parametric identification of the mathematical model of the membrane concentration process of whey in the membrane (ultra-filtration) device with tubular membranes. The authors of the research developed a set of interrelated mathematical models that make it possible to evaluate the dynamics of the membrane concentration process of whey, taking into account its technological parameters and the design peculiarities of the membrane device. The authors carried out software implementation of the set of models and developed methods for calculating the rational values of the design parameters of a pilot device. The main parameters of the mathematical models include high prediction accuracy (the discrepancy between experimental values and values obtained using the model does not exceed 7.8%) and simplicity of implementation in most modern software products. The effectiveness of the methods for calculating the design parameters of the membrane device is determined by their versatility in the design of pilot membrane plants based on tubular membrane filters.</p>	string

2224	en_US	title	Spiders Everywhere	string
2224	en_US	cleanTitle	Spiders Everywhere	string
2224	en_US	abstract	A <em>spider</em> is a tree with at most one branch (a vertex of degree at least 3) centred at the branch if it exists, and <em>centred</em> at any vertex otherwise. A graph G is <em>arachnoid</em> if for any vertex v of G, there exists a spanning spider of G centred at v -- in other words: there are spiders everywhere! <em>Hypotraceable</em> graphs are non-traceable graphs in which all vertex-deleted subgraphs are traceable. Gargano, Hammar, Hell, Stacho, and Vaccaro [<em>Discrete Math.</em> <strong>285</strong> (2004) 83-95] defined arachnoid graphs as natural generalisations of traceable graphs and asked for the existence of arachnoid graphs that are (i) non-traceable and non-hypotraceable, or (ii) in which some vertex is the centre of only spiders with more than three legs. An armative answer to (ii) implies an affirmative answer to (i). While non-traceable, non-hypotraceable arachnoid graphs were described in [<em>J. Graph Theory</em> <strong>84</strong> (2017) 443-459], (ii) remained open. In this paper we give an affirmative answer to this question and discuss spanning spiders whose legs must have some minimum length.	string
2224	en_US	discipline	Graph theory	string

2224	en_US	subject	Spanning tree; hamiltonian path; hypotraceable	string

2224		licenseURL		string
2226	en_US	title	On plane subgraphs of complete topological drawings	string
2226	en_US	cleanTitle	On plane subgraphs of complete topological drawings	string
2226	en_US	abstract	<p>Topological drawings are representations of graphs in the plane, where vertices are represented by points, and edges by simple curves connecting the points. A drawing is <em>simple</em> if two edges intersect at most in a single point, either at a common endpoint or at a proper crossing. In this paper we study properties of maximal plane subgraphs of simple drawings <span class="math inline"><em>D</em><sub><em>n</em></sub></span> of the complete graph <span class="math inline"><em>K</em><sub><em>n</em></sub></span> on <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span> vertices. Our main structural result is that maximal plane subgraphs are <span class="math inline">2</span>-connected and what we call <em>essentially</em> <span class="math inline">3</span><em>-edge-connected</em>. Besides, any maximal plane subgraph contains at least <span class="math inline">⌈3<em>n</em>/2⌉</span> edges. We also address the problem of obtaining a plane subgraph of <span class="math inline"><em>D</em><sub><em>n</em></sub></span> with the maximum number of edges, proving that this problem is NP-complete. However, given a plane spanning connected subgraph of <span class="math inline"><em>D</em><sub><em>n</em></sub></span>, a maximum plane augmentation of this subgraph can be found in <span class="math inline"><em>O</em>(<em>n</em><sup>3</sup>)</span> time. As a side result, we also show that the problem of finding a largest compatible plane straight-line graph of two labeled point sets is NP-complete.</p>	string

2226	en_US	subjectClass	05C10; 68R10	string
2226	en_US	subject	Graph,  topological drawing,  plane subgraph,  NP-complete problem	string

2227	en_US	title	The enclaveless competition game	string
2227	en_US	cleanTitle	The enclaveless competition game	string
2227	en_US	abstract	<p>For a subset <span class="math inline"><em>S</em></span> of vertices in a graph <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span>, a vertex <span class="math inline"><em>v</em> ∈ <em>S</em></span> is an enclave of <span class="math inline"><em>S</em></span> if <span class="math inline"><em>v</em></span> and all of its neighbors are in <span class="math inline"><em>S</em></span>, where a neighbor of <span class="math inline"><em>v</em></span> is a vertex adjacent to <span class="math inline"><em>v</em></span>. A set <span class="math inline"><em>S</em></span> is enclaveless if it does not contain any enclaves. The enclaveless number <span class="math inline"><em>Ψ</em>(<em>G</em>)</span> of <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> is the maximum cardinality of an enclaveless set in <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span>. As first observed in 1997 by Slater [J. Res. Nat. Bur. Standards 82 (1977), 197–202], if <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> is a graph with <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span> vertices, then <span class="math inline"><em>γ</em>(<em>G</em>) + <em>Ψ</em>(<em>G</em>) = <em>n</em></span> where <span class="math inline"><em>γ</em>(<em>G</em>)</span> is the well-studied domination number of <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span>. In this paper, we continue the study of the competition-enclaveless game introduced in 2001 by Philips and Slater [Graph Theory Notes N. Y. 41 (2001), 37–41] and defined as follows. Two players take turns in constructing a maximal enclaveless set <span class="math inline"><em>S</em></span>, where one player, Maximizer, tries to maximize <span class="math inline">|<em>S</em>|</span> and one player, Minimizer, tries to minimize <span class="math inline">|<em>S</em>|</span>. The competition-enclaveless game number <span class="math inline"><em>Ψ</em><sub><em>g</em></sub><sup>+</sup>(<em>G</em>)</span> of <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> is the number of vertices played when Maximizer starts the game and both players play optimally. We study among other problems the conjecture that if <span class="math inline"><em>G</em></span> is an isolate-free graph of order <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span>, then <span class="math inline"><em>Ψ</em><sub><em>g</em></sub><sup>+</sup>(<em>G</em>) ≥ (1/2)<em>n</em></span>. We prove this conjecture for regular graphs and for claw-free graphs.</p>	string

2228	en_US	abstract	By studying the symmetry of roots of polynomials called quantum integers, we classify in this paper all solutions with cyclic and semi-cyclic supports of the functional equations arising from multiplication of quantum integers with fields of coefficients of characteristic zero. This solves completely the classification problem proposed by Melvyn Nathanson and Yang Wang concerning the solutions, with supports which are not prime subsemigroups of $\\mathbb{N}$, to these functional equations for the case of rational field of coefficients. As a consequence, results for other problems raised by Nathanson concerning maximal solutions and extension of supports of solutions to these functional equations are also obtained.	string

2229	en_US	abstract	Let $D=(V,E)$ be a strongly  connected digraph and let $u ,v\\in  V(D)$.  The maximum distance $md(u,v)$ is defined as $md(u,v)=\\mathrm{max}\\,\\{\\overrightarrow{d}(u,v), \\overrightarrow{d}(v,u)$\\} where $\\overrightarrow{d}(u,v)$ denotes the length of a shortest directed $u-v$ path in $D$.  This is a metric.  The boundary, contour, eccentric and peripheral sets of a strongly connected digraph $D$ with respect to this metric have been defined.  In this paper we investigate the above boundary-type sets of a strong product of digraphs.	string

2231	en_US	title	Chromatic number and signless Laplacian spectral radius of graphs	string
2231	en_US	cleanTitle	Chromatic number and signless Laplacian spectral radius of graphs	string
2231	en_US	abstract	Let $G$ be a simple graph with vertices $v_1,\\ldots,v_n$. Let $A(G)$ be the adjacency matrix of $G$ and $D(G)$ be the diagonal matrix $(d_1,\\ldots,d_n)$, where $d_i$ is the degree of vertex $v_i$, for $i=1,\\ldots,n$. The matrix $Q(G)=D(G)+A(G)$ is called the signless Laplacian matrix of $G$. By the signless Laplacian spectral radius of $G$, denoted by $q(G)$, we mean the largest eigenvalue of $Q(G)$. Let $\\chi(G)$ be the chromatic number of $G$. In this paper we find some relations between the chromatic number and the signless Laplacian spectral radius of graphs. We show that for every graph $G$ with $n$ vertices,<br />$$q(G)\\leq 2n-2\\Big\\lfloor\\frac{n}{\\chi(G)}\\Big\\rfloor.$$<br />Moreover we prove that the equality holds if and only if $G=\\overline{K_n}$ or $G=K_{n_1,n_2}$ where $n_1+n_2=n$ is even or $G=K_{n_1,\\ldots,n_t}$ where $t\\geq3$ and $t|n$ and $n_1=\\cdots=n_t=\\frac{n}{t}$. Using this inequality we obtain a lower bound for the chromatic number of graphs. In fact we obtain that<br />$$\\chi(G)&gt;\\frac{2n}{2n-q(G)+2}.$$<br />In particular we find that if $\\chi(G)|n$, then<br />$$\\chi(G)\\geq\\frac{2n}{2n-q(G)},$$<br />and the equality holds if and only if $G$ is one of the three graphs that mentioned above. Finally we obtain that if $G$ is planar, then<br />$q(G)&lt;\\frac{3n}{2}+2$.	string

2234	en_US	abstract	<p>For a connected graph G = (V,E) of order p, a Steiner set W of V is said to be a complement connected Steiner set if W = V or the subgraph &lt;V- W&gt; is connected. The minimum cardinality of a complement connected Steiner set of G is the complement connected Steiner number of G and is denoted by s<sub>cc</sub>(G). The complement connected Steiner number of certain classes of graphs are determined. Necessary conditions for the complement connected Steiner number to be 2, or p - 1 is given. It is shown that for every pair of integers , b with 3 less than or equal to  less than or equal to b, there exists a connected graph G with s(G) =  and s<sub>cc</sub>(G) = b. 2235	en_US	title	(1,0,0)-colorability of planar graphs without cycles of length 4 or 6	string
2235	en_US	cleanTitle	100colorability of planar graphs without cycles of length 4 or 6	string
2235	en_US	abstract	<span>A graph $G$ is $(d_1,d_2,d_3)$-colorable if the vertex set $V(G)$ can be partitioned into three subsets $V_1,V_2$ and $V_3$ such that for $i\\in\\{1,2,3\\}$, the induced graph $G[V_i]$ has maximum vertex-degree at most $d_i$. So, $(0,0,0)$-colorability is exactly 3-colorability.<br /> <br />The well-known Steinberg's conjecture states that every planar graph without cycles of length 4 or 5 is 3-colorable. As this conjecture being disproved by Cohen-Addad etc. in 2017, <br />a similar question, whether every planar graph without cycles of length 4 or $i$ is 3-colorable for a given $i\\in \\{6,\\ldots,9\\}$, is gaining more and more interest. In this paper, we consider this question for the case $i=6$ from the viewpoint of improper colorings. More precisely, we prove that every planar graph without cycles of length 4 or 6 is (1,0,0)-colorable, which improves on earlier results that they are (2,0,0)-colorable and also (1,1,0)-colorable, and on the result that planar graphs without cycles of length from 4 to 6 are (1,0,0)-colorable.</span>	string

2236	en_US	title	New methods in constructing Ramsey $(mK_2,H)$-minimal graphs	string
2236	en_US	cleanTitle	New methods in constructing Ramsey mK_2Hminimal graphs	string
2236	en_US	abstract	For simple graphs $F, G$, and $H$, we write $F<br />\\rightarrow (G,H)$ to mean that if the edges of $F$ are colored by red or blue,<br />then the red subgraph contains a monochromatic copy of $G$ or the blue subgraph contains a monochromatic copy of $H$.<br />A $(G,H)$-coloring of edges of $F$ is a red-blue coloring of all edges of $F$ such that there is neither a monochromatic copy of $G$ in the red subgraph of $F$ nor a monochromatic copy of $H$ in the blue subgraph of $F$.<br />The graph $F$ (without isolated vertices) is a Ramsey $(G,H)$-minimal if $F \\rightarrow (G,H)$<br />but for every $e \\in E(F),$ there exists a $(G,H)$-coloring of edges of $F-e$.<br />Herein, we propose a new method for constructing Ramsey $(mK_2,H')$-minimal graphs from a known Ramsey $(mK_2,H)$-minimal graph<br />for some graph $H'$ containing $H$.	string

2238	en_US	title	Semi-perimeter and inner site-perimeter of $k$-ary words and bargraphs	string
2238	en_US	cleanTitle	Semiperimeter and inner siteperimeter of kary words and bargraphs	string
2238	en_US	abstract	<p>Given a bargraph $B$, a {\\em border cell} of $B$ is a cell of $B$ that shares at least one common edge with an outside cell of $B$. Clearly, the inner site-perimeter of $B$ is the number of border cells of $B$. A {\\em tangent cell} of $B$ is a cell of $B$ which is not a border cell of $B$ and shares at least one vertex with an outside cell of $B$. In this paper, we study the generating function for the number of $k$-ary words, represented as bargraphs, according to the number of horizontal steps, up steps, border cells and tangent cells. This allows us to express some cases via Chebyshev polynomials of the second kind. Moreover, we find an explicit formula for the number of bargraphs according to the number of horizontal steps, up steps, and tangent cells/inner site-perimeter. Also, we derive asymptotic estimates for the mean number of tangent cells/inner site-perimeter.</p>	string

2239	en_US	title	The expansion of a chord diagram and the Genocchi numbers	string
2239	en_US	cleanTitle	The expansion of a chord diagram and the Genocchi numbers	string
2239	en_US	abstract	<p>A chord diagram <span class="math inline"><em>E</em></span> is a set of chords of a circle such that no pair of chords has a common endvertex. Let <span class="math inline"><em>v</em><sub>1</sub>, <em>v</em><sub>2</sub>, …, <em>v</em><sub>2<em>n</em></sub></span> be a sequence of vertices arranged in clockwise order along a circumference. A chord diagram <span class="math inline">{<em>v</em><sub>1</sub><em>v</em><sub><em>n</em> + 1</sub>, <em>v</em><sub>2</sub><em>v</em><sub><em>n</em> + 2</sub>, …, <em>v</em><sub><em>n</em></sub><em>v</em><sub>2<em>n</em></sub>}</span> is called an <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span>-crossing and a chord diagram <span class="math inline">{<em>v</em><sub>1</sub><em>v</em><sub>2</sub>, <em>v</em><sub>3</sub><em>v</em><sub>4</sub>, …, <em>v</em><sub>2<em>n</em> − 1</sub><em>v</em><sub>2<em>n</em></sub>}</span> is called an <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span>-necklace. For a chord diagram <span class="math inline"><em>E</em></span> having a <span class="math inline">2</span>-crossing <span class="math inline"><em>S</em> = {<em>x</em><sub>1</sub><em>x</em><sub>3</sub>, <em>x</em><sub>2</sub><em>x</em><sub>4</sub>}</span>, the expansion of <span class="math inline"><em>E</em></span> with respect to <span class="math inline"><em>S</em></span> is to replace <span class="math inline"><em>E</em></span> with <span class="math inline"><em>E</em><sub>1</sub> = (<em>E</em> \\ <em>S</em>) ∪ {<em>x</em><sub>2</sub><em>x</em><sub>3</sub>, <em>x</em><sub>4</sub><em>x</em><sub>1</sub>}</span> or <span class="math inline"><em>E</em><sub>2</sub> = (<em>E</em> \\ <em>S</em>) ∪ {<em>x</em><sub>1</sub><em>x</em><sub>2</sub>, <em>x</em><sub>3</sub><em>x</em><sub>4</sub>}</span>. Beginning from a given chord diagram <span class="math inline"><em>E</em></span> as the root, by iterating chord expansions in both ways, we have a binary tree whose all leaves are nonintersecting chord diagrams. Let <span class="math inline"><strong>NCD</strong>(<em>E</em>)</span> be the multiset of the leaves. Among other results, it is shown that the multiplicity of an <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span>-necklace generated from an <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span>-crossing equals the Genocchi number when <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span> is odd and the median Genocchi number when <span class="math inline"><em>n</em></span> is even.</p>	string

2240	en_US	abstract	‎Let $G=(V_G‎, ‎E_G)$ be a simple and connected graph‎. ‎A set $M\\subseteq E_G$ is called a matching of‎ $G$ if no two edges of $M$ are adjacent‎. ‎The number of edges in $M$ is called‎ its size‎. ‎A matching $M$ is maximal if it cannot be extended to a larger‎ matching in $G$‎. ‎The smallest size of a maximal matching is called the‎ saturation number of $G$‎. ‎In this paper we are concerned with the saturation‎ numbers of lexicographic product of graphs‎. ‎We also address and solve an open‎ problem about the size of maximum matchings in graphs with a given maximum‎ degree $\\Delta$‎.	string

2241	en_US	title	Dominating induced matching and other graph parameters	string
2241	en_US	cleanTitle	Dominating induced matching and other graph parameters	string
2241	en_US	abstract	<p>Let $G$ be a graph, a matching $M$ is an induced matching if no edge<br />connects two edges of $M$. A dominating induced matching (DIM) of<br />$G$ is an induced matching that dominates every edge of $G$. Any two<br />dominating induced matchings of $G$ are of the same size \\cite{AB}.<br />The dominating induced matching number of $G$, denoted by $\\rm<br />dim(G)$, is the size of a dominating induced matching of $G$. In<br />this paper we continue the study of dominating induced matching. We<br />prove that if $G$ has a DIM, then the induced matching number of $G$<br />is equal to the independence number of line graph $G$ and edge<br />domination number of $G$. It is also shown that $\\rm dim(G)\\leq<br />2dim(L(G))$ provided that $G$ and $L(G)$ have a DIM. We present some<br />bounds for $\\rm dim(G)$. Specially, for a tree $T$ with a DIM we<br />show that $\\lceil\\frac{n-l+1}{3}\\rceil \\leq \\rm dim(T)\\leq \\lfloor<br />\\dfrac{n-1+l}{3} \\rfloor$, where $l$ is the number of leaves.<br />Moreover, for regular graph $G$ we establish some Nordhaus-Gaddum<br />bounds.</p>	string

2242	en_US	title	$Z$-oriented triangulations of surfaces	string
2242	en_US	cleanTitle	Zoriented triangulations of surfaces	string
2242	en_US	abstract	The main objects of the paper are $z$-oriented triangulations of connected closed $2$-dimensional surfaces. A $z$-orientation of a map is a minimal collection of zigzags which double covers the set of edges. We have two possibilities for an edge - zigzags from the $z$-orientation pass through this edge in different directions (type I) or in the same direction (type II). Then there are two types of faces in a triangulation: the first type is when two edges of the face are of type I and one edge is of type II and the second type is when all edges of the face are of type II. We investigate $z$-oriented triangulations with all faces of the first type (in the general case, any $z$-oriented triangulation can be shredded to a $z$-oriented triangulation of such type). A zigzag is homogeneous if it contains precisely two edges of type I after any edge of type II. We give a topological characterization of the homogeneity of zigzags; in particular, we describe a one-to-one correspondence between $z$-oriented triangulations with homogeneous zigzags and closed $2$-cell embeddings of directed Eulerian graphs in surfaces. At the end, we give an application to one type of the $z$-monodromy.	string
2242	en_US	discipline	Discrete mathematics	string
2242	en_US	subjectClass	05C62	string
2242	en_US	subject	directed Eulerian embedding, triangulation of a surface, zigzag, $z$-monodromy, $z$-orientation	string

2242		licenseURL		string
2243	en_US	title	Fractional arboricity, strength and eigenvalues of graphs with fixed girth or clique number	string
2243	en_US	cleanTitle	Fractional arboricity strength and eigenvalues of graphs with fixed girth or clique number	string
2243	en_US	abstract	<p>Let $c(G)$, $g(G)$, $\\omega(G)$ and $\\mu_{n-1}(G)$ denote the number of components, the girth,<br />the clique number and the second smallest Laplacian eigenvalue of the graph $G$, respectively.<br />The strength $\\eta(G)$ and the fractional arboricity $\\gamma(G)$ are defined by<br />$$<br />\\eta(G)=\\min_{F\\subseteq E(G)}\\frac{|F|}{c(G-F)-c(G)} \\text{~and~} \\gamma(G)=\\max_{H\\subseteq G}\\frac{|E(H)|}{|V(H)|-1}.<br />$$<br />Nash-Williams and Tutte proved that $G$ has $k$ edge-disjoint spanning trees<br />if and only if $\\eta(G)\\ge k$; and Nash-Williams showed that $G$<br />can be covered by at most $k$ forests if and only if $\\gamma(G)\\le k$.<br />For integers $r\\ge 2$, $s$ and $t$,<br />and any simple graph $G$ of order $n$ with minimum degree $\\delta\\ge \\frac{2s}{t}$<br />and either clique number $\\omega(G)\\leq r$ or girth $g\\ge 3$, we prove that<br />if $\\mu_{n-1}(G) &gt; \\frac{2s-1}{t\\varphi(\\delta,r)}$ or<br />$\\mu_{n-1}(G) &gt; \\frac{2s-1}{t N(\\delta,g)}$, then $\\eta(G)\\ge \\frac{s}{t}$,<br />where $\\varphi(\\delta,r)=\\max\\{\\delta+1,\\lfloor\\frac{r\\delta}{r-1}\\rfloor\\}$ and<br />$N(\\delta,g)$ is the Moore bound on the smallest possible number of vertices<br />such that there exists a $\\delta$-regular simple graph with girth $g$.<br />Former results in [Linear Algebra Appl. 458 (2014) 128--133] and [Discrete Appl. Math. 213 (2016) 219--223] are extended,<br />and the result in [Linear Algebra Appl. 578 (2019) 411--424] is improved.</p>	string

2248	en_US	cleanTitle	A double Sylvester determinant	string
2248	en_US	abstract	<p>Given two <span class="math inline">(<em>n</em>+1) × (<em>n</em>+1)</span>-matrices <span class="math inline"><em>A</em></span> and <span class="math inline"><em>B</em></span> over a commutative ring, and some <span class="math inline"><em>k</em> ∈ {0, 1, …, <em>n</em>}</span>, we consider the <span class="math inline">(<em>n</em> choose <em>k</em>) × (<em>n</em> choose <em>k</em>)</span>-matrix <span class="math inline"><em>W</em></span> whose entries are <span class="math inline">(<em>k</em>+1) × (<em>k</em>+1)</span>-minors of <span class="math inline"><em>A</em></span> multiplied by corresponding <span class="math inline">(<em>k</em>+1) × (<em>k</em>+1)</span>-minors of <span class="math inline"><em>B</em></span>. Here we require the minors to use the last row and the last column (which is why we obtain an <span class="math inline">(<em>n</em> choose <em>k</em>) × (<em>n</em> choose <em>k</em>)</span>-matrix, not a <span class="math inline">(<em>n</em> + 1 choose <em>k</em> + 1) × (<em>n</em> + 1 choose <em>k</em> + 1)</span>-matrix). We prove that the determinant <span class="math inline">det <em>W</em></span> is a multiple of <span class="math inline">det <em>A</em></span> if the <span class="math inline">(<em>n</em>+1, <em>n</em>+1)</span>-th entry of <span class="math inline"><em>B</em></span> is <span class="math inline">0</span>. Furthermore, if the <span class="math inline">(<em>n</em>+1, <em>n</em>+1)</span>-th entries of both <span class="math inline"><em>A</em></span> and <span class="math inline"><em>B</em></span> are <span class="math inline">0</span>, then <span class="math inline">det <em>W</em></span> is a multiple of <span class="math inline">(det<em>A</em>)(det<em>B</em>)</span>. This extends a previous result of Olver and the author.</p>	string

2250	en_US	title	The chromatic number of triangle-free and broom-free graphs in terms of the number of vertices	string
2250	en_US	cleanTitle	The chromatic number of trianglefree and broomfree graphs in terms of the number of vertices	string
2250	en_US	abstract	<p>Gy\\'arf\\'as-Sumner conjecture asks whether for every tree $T$,<br />the class of $T$-free graphs is $\\chi$-bounded.<br />The conjecture is solved for several special trees, but it is still open in general.<br />Motivated by the conjecture, the chromatic number of the triangle-free and broom-free graphs is well studied, since a broom is one of the generalization of a star,<br />where a {\\em broom} $B(m,n)$ is the graph obtained <br />from a star $K_{1,n}$ and an $m$-vertex path $P_m$<br />by identifying the center of $K_{1,n}$ and a leaf of $P_m$.<br />Gy\\'{a}rf\\'{a}s, Szemeredi and Tuza proved that <br />for every triangle-free and $B(m,n)$-free graph $G$, $\\chi(G) \\leq m+n-1$, and then the upper bound is improved by Wang and Wu to $m+n-2$ for $m\\geq 2, n\\geq 1$.<br />In this paper, we prove that any triangle-free and $B(4,2)$-free graph $G$ is 3-colorable if the number of vertices of $G$ is at least $17$.<br />Furthermore, the above estimation is best possible since there exists<br />a triangle-free and $B(4,2)$-free 4-chromatic graph <br />with sixteen vertices, named the Clebsch graph.</p>	string

2254	en_US	abstract	<span>In this article rooted (near-) $4$-regular maps on the plane are investigated with respect to the root-valency, the number of edges, the number of inner faces, the number of nonroot-vertex-loops and the number of separating cycles. As special cases, formulae of several types of rooted $4$-edge-connected $4$-regular maps on the plane are presented. Several known results on the number of $4$-regular planar maps are also concluded. Finally, using  Darboux's method, a very nice asymptotic formula for the number<br />of this type of maps is given. 2256	en_US	abstract	In this paper, we introduce the shifted Bernoulli numbers as a different natural extension of the classical Bernoulli numbers, in particular, in terms of continued fraction and determinant expressions. We give several arithmetical and combinatorial properties of shifted Bernoulli numbers.  <br />Fubini numbers form an integer sequence in which the $n$th term counts the number of weak orderings of a set with $n$ elements.  We also introduce the shifted Fubini numbers as one kind of their generalizations and show several similar properties.  <br />Though Bernoulli numbers and Fubini numbers do not seem to be so related to each other, the shifted Bernoulli numbers and shifted Fubini numbers have several similarities and relations.	string

2257	en_US	title	Maximal Order Group Actions On Riemann Surfaces	string
2257	en_US	cleanTitle	Maximal Order Group Actions On Riemann Surfaces	string
2257	en_US	abstract	<span style="color: #000000;">A natural problem is to determine, for each value of the integer </span><span style="color: #008000;">$g \\geq 2$</span><span style="color: #000000;">, the largest order of a group that acts on a Riemann surface of genus </span><span style="color: #008000;">$g$</span><span style="color: #000000;">. Let </span><span style="color: #008000;">$N(g)$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> (respectively </span><span style="color: #008000;">$M(g)$</span><span style="color: #000000;">) be the largest order of a group of </span><span style="text-decoration: underline; color: #000000;">automorphisms</span><span style="color: #000000;"> of a Riemann surface of genus </span><span style="color: #008000;">$g \\geq 2$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> preserving the orientation (respectively possibly reversing the orientation) of the surface.</span><pre style="-qt-paragraph-type: empty; -qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; margin: 0px;"> </pre><pre style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; margin: 0px;"><span style="color: #000000;">The basic inequalities comparing </span><span style="color: #008000;">$N(g)$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> and </span><span style="color: #008000;">$M(g)$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> are <br /></span><span style="color: #008000;">$N(g) \\leq M(g) \\leq 2N(g)$</span><span style="color: #000000;">. It is easy to see that the upper bound is satisfied<br />for an infinite number of integers </span><span style="color: #008000;">$g$</span><span style="color: #000000;">. We also show that there are an infinite <br />number of positive integers </span><span style="color: #008000;">$g$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> such that </span><span style="color: #008000;">$N(g) = M(g)$</span><span style="color: #000000;">.</span></pre><pre style="-qt-paragraph-type: empty; -qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; margin: 0px;"> </pre><pre style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; margin: 0px;"><span style="color: #000000;">Specifically, if </span><span style="color: #008000;">$p$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> is a prime satisfying </span><span style="color: #008000;">$p \\equiv 1\\pmod 6$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> and <br /></span><span style="color: #008000;">$g = 3p + 1$</span><span style="color: #000000;">, there is a group of order </span><span style="color: #008000;">$24(g - 1)$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> that acts on a surface of <br />genus </span><span style="color: #008000;">$g$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> preserving the orientation of the surface. For all such values of <br /></span><span style="color: #008000;">$g = 3p + 1$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> larger than a fixed constant, there are no groups with order <br />larger than </span><span style="color: #008000;">$24(g - 1)$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> that act on a surface of genus </span><span style="color: #008000;">$g$</span><span style="color: #000000;">.</span></pre>	string

2258	en_US	title	Vizing-Goldberg type bounds for the equitable chromatic number of  block graphs	string
2258	en_US	cleanTitle	VizingGoldberg type bounds for the equitable chromatic number of  block graphs	string
2258	en_US	abstract	An equitable coloring of a graph $G$ is a proper vertex coloring of $G$ such that the sizes of any two color classes differ by at most one. In the paper, we pose a conjecture that offers a gap-one bound for the smallest number of colors needed to equitably color every block graph. In other words, the difference between the upper and the lower bounds of our conjecture is at most one. Thus, in some sense, the situation is similar to that of chromatic index, where we have the classical theorem of Vizing and the Goldberg conjecture for multigraphs. The results obtained in the paper support our conjecture. More precisely, we verify it in the class of well-covered block graphs, which are block graphs in which each vertex belongs to a maximum independent set. We also show that the conjecture is true for block graphs, which contain a vertex that does not lie in an independent set of size larger than two. Finally, we verify the conjecture for some symmetric-like block graphs. In order to derive our results we obtain structural characterizations of block graphs from these classes.	string

2260	en_US	cleanTitle	A generalization of balanced tableaux and marriage problems with unique solutions	string
2260	en_US	abstract	We consider families of finite sets that we call shellable and that have been characterized by Chang and by Hirst and Hughes as being the families of sets that admit unique solutions to Hall's marriage problem. In this paper, we introduce a natural generalization of Edelman and Greene's balanced tableaux that involves families of sets that satisfy Hall's marriage Condition and certain words in $[n]^m$, then prove that shellable families can be characterized by a strong existence condition relating to this generalization. As a consequence of this characterization, we show that the average number of such generalized tableaux is given by a generalization of the hook-length formula.	string

2264	en_US	abstract	<p>In this<br />paper, we first constructed the current graphs of the complete graph<br />$K_{12s+9}$ ($s$ is an odd natural number) and $K_{8s+5}$ ($s$ is a<br />natural number), and found $(3s+1)!$ current assignments of the<br />current graph of $K_{12s+9}$, $(2s)!$ current assignments of the<br />current graph of $K_{8s+5}$. And then, we proved that each current<br />graph of $K_{12s+9}$ has at least $ 2^{3s+2}\\times<br />3^{\\frac{3s+1}{2}}$distinct orientable surface embeddings with one<br />face, and each current graph of $K_{8s+5}$ has at least<br />$2^{2s+1}\\times 3^{s}$ distinct orientable surface embeddings with<br />one face. By these results, we proved that the complete graph<br />$K_{12s+9}$ has at least $(3s+1)!\\times 2^{3s+2}\\times<br />3^{\\frac{3s+1}{2}}$ distinct orientable quadrangular embeddings, and<br />these embeddings determine polyhedra with a minimal number of<br />quadrangles (vertices); we proved that the complete graph $K_{8s+5}$<br />has at least $(2s)!\\times 2^{2s+1}\\times 3^{s}$ distinct orientable<br />quadrangular embeddings, and these embeddings determine polyhedra<br />with a minimal number of quadrangles (vertices).</p>	string

2265	en_US	title	CLASS OF CROSSCAP TWO GRAPHS ARISING FROM LATTICES-I	string
2265	en_US	cleanTitle	CLASS OF CROSSCAP TWO GRAPHS ARISING FROM LATTICESI	string
2265	en_US	abstract	<p>Let (L,∧,∨) be a finite lattice with a least element 0. The annihilating-ideal<br />graph of L is a simple graph in which the vertex set is the set of all nontrivial<br />ideals of L, and two distinct vertices I and J are joined by an edge provided I∧J = 0. In this paper, we classify all finite lattices L with at most 4 atoms whose annihilating-ideal graph has crosscap two. Further, we correct some flaws in the statement and proof of Theorem 2.6 in [Bull. Malays. Math. Sci. Soc., 42 (2019), 1625–1638.].</p>	string

2267	en_US	title	Korselt Rational Bases and Sets	string
2267	en_US	cleanTitle	Korselt Rational Bases and Sets	string
2267	en_US	abstract	For  a positive integer $N$ and $\\mathbb{A}$ a subset of $\\mathbb{Q}$, let  $\\mathbb{A}$-$\\mathcal{KS}(N)$ denote the set of $\\alpha=\\dfrac{\\alpha_{1}}{\\alpha_{2}}\\in \\mathbb{A}\\setminus \\{0,N\\}$   verifying $\\alpha_{2}p-\\alpha_{1}$ divides $\\alpha_{2}N-\\alpha_{1}$ for every prime divisor $p$ of $N$. The set  $\\mathbb{A}$-$\\mathcal{KS}(N)$ is   called the set of Korselt bases of $N$ in $\\mathbb{A}$ or simply the $\\mathbb{A}$-Korselt set of $N$.<br /><br />In this paper, we prove that for each squarefree composite number $N\\in\\mathbb{N}\\setminus\\{0,1\\}$ the $\\mathbb{Q}$-Korselt set of $N$ is finite where we provide an upper and lower bounds for each Korselt base of $N$ in $\\mathbb{Q}$. Furthermore, we give a necessary and a sufficient condition for the upper  bound  of a Korselt base to be reached. The  $N$-Korselt bases in $\\mathbb{Q}$ not relatively prime to $N$ are more studied where we provide some information about their forms and belonging set.	string

2268	en_US	title	Shortness parameters of polyhedral graphs with few distinct vertex degrees	string
2268	en_US	cleanTitle	Shortness parameters of polyhedral graphs with few distinct vertex degrees	string
2268	en_US	abstract	<p>We devise several new upper bounds for shortness parameters of regular polyhedra and of the polyhedra that have two vertex degrees, and relate these to each other.</p><p>Gr\\"unbaum and Walther showed that quartic polyhedra have shortness exponent at most $\\log 22 / \\log 23$. This was subsequently improved by Harant to $\\log 16 / \\log 17$, which holds even when all faces are either triangles or of length $k$, for infinitely many~$k$. We complement Harant's result by strengthening the Gr\\"unbaum-Walther bound to $\\log 4 / \\log 5$, and showing that this bound even holds for the family of quartic polyhedra with faces of length at most~7.</p><p>Furthermore, we prove that for every \\(4 \\le k \\le 8\\) the shortness exponent of the polyhedra having only vertices of degree $3$ or $k$ is at most $\\log 5 / \\log 7$. Motivated by work of Ewald and Reynolds, we show that polyhedral quadrangulations with maximum degree at most~5 have shortness coefficient at most $30/37$. Finally, we define path analogues for shortness parameters, and propose first dependencies between these measures.</p>	string

2269	en_US	title	Szeged indices of bicyclic graphs	string
2269	en_US	cleanTitle	Szeged indices of bicyclic graphs	string
2269	en_US	abstract	<p>The Szeged index is a graph invariant. Let $G$ be a simple graph and $e=uv$ be an edge of it. Suppose that $n_u(e)$ is the number<br />of vertices which their distance to vertex $u$ is smaller than their distance to vertex $v$ and $n_v(e)$ is defined analogously. The Szeged index $Sz(G)$ is equal to the sum of $n_u(e)n_v(e)$ over all edges of $G$. In this paper, we obtain lower and upper bounds on some Szeged indices and the difference between vertex-edge Szeged index and edge-vertex Szeged index of bicyclic graphs.</p>	string
