2271	en_US	title	Irreducible No-hole Colorability of Circulant Graphs	string
2271	en_US	cleanTitle	Irreducible Nohole Colorability of Circulant Graphs	string
2271	en_US	abstract	An $L(2,1)$-coloring of a simple connected graph $G$ is an assignment $f$ of non-negative integers to the vertices of $G$ such that $|f(u)-f(v)|\\geq 2$ for all edges $uv$ in $G$ and $|f(u)-f(v)|\\geq 1$ if $d(u,v)=2$. The span of an $L(2, 1)$-coloring is the greatest color assigned by it. The span $\\lambda(G)$ of a graph $G$ is the smallest integer $\\lambda$ such that there is an $L(2,1)$-coloring of $G$, with span $\\lambda$. A non-negative integer less than the span of an $L(2,1)$-coloring $f$ of a graph $G$ is said to be a hole in $f$ if no vertex of $G$ receives it. An $L(2,1)$-coloring without holes is called a no-hole $L(2,1)$-coloring. An $L(2,1)$-coloring of $G$ is said to be irreducible if none of the colors used can be decreased to yield another $L(2,1)$-coloring of $G$. An irreducible no-hole coloring, simply, inh-coloring, of $G$ is an $L(2,1)$-coloring of $G$ which is both irreducible and no-hole. The inh-span $\\lambda_{inh}(G)$ of a graph $G$ is the smallest number $k$ such that there is an inh-coloring of $G$, with span $k$. The maximum number of holes $H_\\lambda(G)$ in $G$ is the maximum number of holes over all irreducible span colorings of $G$. In this paper, we first determine the span, the inh-span and the maximum number of holes for $Ci_n(1,3)$ except for few $n&lt;66$. Later, we characterize the span $6$ circulant graphs $Ci_n(1,m)$. We determine the span of $Ci_n(1,m)$ when $m+2$ and $n-(m+2)\\lfloor\\frac{n}{m+2}\\rfloor$ are liner combinations (with non-negative integer coefficients) of $7$ and $8$. Also, we show that these graphs are inh-colorable with $\\lambda_{inh}(Ci_n(1,m)) =\\lambda(Ci_n(1,m))$. Further, for $n&gt;3$, we show that $H_\\lambda(Ci_n(1,m))=0$ if $\\lambda(Ci_n(1,m))$ is $6$ or $7$.	string
2271	en_US	discipline	Graph Theory; Graph Colorings	string
2271	en_US	subjectClass	05C78; 05C15	string
2271	en_US	subject	L(2,1)-coloring; span of a garph; irreducible coloring; no-hole coloring; inh-coloring	string

2272	en_US	title	Even pebbling and optimal even pebbling in graphs	string
2272	en_US	cleanTitle	Even pebbling and optimal even pebbling in graphs	string
2272	en_US	abstract	A pebbling move on a graph $G$ consists of the removal of two pebbles from one vertex and the placement of one pebble on an adjacent vertex. Rubbling is a version of pebbling where an additional move is allowed, which is also called the strict rubbling move. In this new move, one pebble each is removed from $u$ and $v$ adjacent to a vertex $w$, and one pebble is added on $w$. We say that a distribution is $t$-solvable, if we can move $t$ pebbles to each given vertex from this distribution. An even distribution is a distribution so that the number of pebbles on each vertex is even. The even $t$-pebbling number, $f^e_t(G)$, is the minimum integer $m$, such that every even distribution with $m$ pebbles is $t$-solvable. Similarly, the optimal even $t$-pebbling number, $f^e_{t-opt}(G)$, is the minimum integer $m$, such that there exists an even distribution with $m$ pebbles which is $t$-solvable. In this paper, we show that even pebbling is a generalization of rubbling, we also give some bounds and the exact values about the even pebbling number and the optimal even pebbling number.	string

2277	en_US	title	Distance sequences	string
2277	en_US	cleanTitle	Distance sequences	string
2277	en_US	abstract	<p>Let $S=(s_1,s_1,\\ldots,s_1, s_2,\\ldots, s_l,\\ldots, s_l)$ be a sequence of nonnegative integers where, (i) $s_i&lt;s_j$ whenever $i&lt;j$ and (ii) each number $s_i$ appears $k_i$ times, for $i=1,2,\\ldots, l$. We say that $S$ is a {\\it $\\delta$-sequence} if there is a simple graph $G$ that admits a partition of the vertices $V(G)=\\cup_{i=1}^lV_i$ such that, for all $i\\in\\{1,2,\\ldots, l\\}$, $|V_i|=k_i$, and if $u,v\\in V_i$ then $d_G(u,v)=s_i$.<br />In that case, we say that the graph $G$ realizes the sequence $S$.</p><p>The relative new concept of $\\delta$-sequences has been inspirired (and is in fact a generalization) of the well known concepts of Skolem and Langford sequences. In this paper, we study properties of $\\delta$-sequences, as for instance, their length as well<br />as the properties of the graphs that realize them, as for instance, the connectness of such graphs. A remarkable number of different open problems and distinct research lines also emerge from this work.</p>	string

2278	en_US	title	On $\\BCI$-groups and $\\CI$-groups	string
2278	en_US	cleanTitle	On \\BCIgroups and \\CIgroups	string
2278	en_US	abstract	<p>Let $G$ be a finite group and<br />$S$ be a subset of $G.$ A bi-Cayley graph $\\BCay(G,S)$ is a simple and an undirected<br />graph with vertex-set $G\\times\\{1,2\\}$ and edge-set<br />$\\{\\{(g,1),(sg,2)\\}\\mid g\\in G, s\\in S\\}$. A bi-Cayley graph $\\BCay(G,S)$ is called a<br />$\\BCI$-graph if for any bi-Cayley graph $\\BCay(G,T)$, whenever<br />$\\BCay(G,S)\\cong\\BCay(G,T)$ we have $T=gS^\\sigma$ for some $g\\in G$<br />and $\\sigma\\in\\Aut(G).$ A group $G$ is called a $\\BCI$-group if<br />every bi-Cayley graph of $G$ is a $\\BCI$-graph. In this paper, we<br />showed that every $\\BCI$-group is a $\\CI$-group, which gives a positive answer to a conjecture<br />proposed by Arezoomand and Taeri in \\cite{arezoomand1}. Also we<br />proved that there is no any non-Abelian $4$-$\\BCI$-simple group. In<br />addition all $\\BCI$-groups of order $2p$, $p$ a prime, are characterized.</p>	string

2279	en_US	title	Parallel graph of submodules of a module	string
2279	en_US	cleanTitle	Parallel graph of submodules of a module	string
2279	en_US	abstract	Let $R$ be a ring with identity and $M$ be a unitary left $R$-module. The parallel graph of an $R$-module $M$, denoted by   $G_\\parallel(M)$, is defined to be the undirected simple graph whose vertices are in one to one correspondence with all non-zero proper submodules of $M$ and two distinct vertices are adjacent if and only if the corresponding submodules of $M$ are parallel. In this paper,  we investigrate the interplay between the module-theoretic properties of $M$ and the graph-theoretic properties of $G_\\parallel(M)$. We characterize all modules for which the parallel graph of submodules is connected. Also the diameter and the girth of  $G_\\parallel(M)$ are determined. Among other resultts, it is shown that if $G_\\parallel(M)$ is a connected and bipartite graph, then $G_\\parallel(M)$ is star graph. Furthermore, we characterize Abelian groups for which their parallel graphs are star garph or bipartite graph.	string

2281	en_US	abstract	<p>The edge revised Szeged index $Sz_e^*(G)$ of a graph $G$ is defined as $Sz_e^*(G)=\\sum_{e=uv\\in E(G)}(m_{u}(e)+\\frac{m_0(e)}{2})(m_{v}(e)+\\frac{m_0(e)}{2})$, where $m_u(e)$ and $m_v(e)$ are, respectively, the number of edges of $G$ lying<br />closer to vertex $u$ than to vertex $v$ and the number of edges of $G$ lying closer to vertex $v$<br />than to vertex $u$, and $m_0(e)$ is the number of edges equidistant to $u$ and $v$. 2282	en_US	title	Feedback game on Eulerian graphs	string
2282	en_US	cleanTitle	Feedback game on Eulerian graphs	string
2282	en_US	abstract	<p>In this paper, we introduce a two-player impartial game on graphs, called a {\\em feedback game}, which is a variant of the generalized geography.<br />The feedback game can be regarded as the undirected edge geography with an additional rule that the first player who goes back to the starting vertex wins the game.<br />We consider the feedback game on Eulerian graphs since the game ends only by going back to the starting vertex.<br />We first show that deciding the winner of the feedback game on Eulerian graphs is PSPACE-complete in general even if its maximum degree is at most~4.<br />In the latter half of the paper, we discuss the feedback game on two subclasses of Eulerian graphs, triangular grid graphs and toroidal grid graphs.</p>	string

2284	en_US	title	Closed formulas for the total Roman domination number of lexicographic product graphs	string
2284	en_US	cleanTitle	Closed formulas for the total Roman domination number of lexicographic product graphs	string
2284	en_US	abstract	<pre>Let <span>$G$</span> be a graph with no isolated vertex and   <span>$f:V(G)\\rightarrow \\{0,1,2\\}$</span> a</pre><pre> function. Let <span>$V_i=\\{x\\in V(G):\\, f(x)=i\\}$</span> for every <span>$i\\in \\{0,1,2\\}$</span>. We say </pre><pre>that <span>$f$</span> is a   total Roman dominating function on <span>$G$</span> if every vertex in <span>$V_0$</span> </pre><pre> is adjacent to at least one vertex in <span>$V_2$</span>  and  the <span>subgraph</span> induced by</pre><pre> <span>$V_1\\cup V_2$</span> has no isolated vertex. The weight of <span>$f$</span> is <span>$\\omega(f)=\\sum_{v\\in V(G) }f(v)$</span>. </pre><pre>The minimum weight among all total Roman dominating functions on <span>$G$</span> is the </pre><pre>total Roman domination number of <span>$G$</span>, denoted by <span>$\\gamma_{tR}(G)$</span>.  </pre><pre>It is known that the general problem of computing <span>$\\gamma_{tR}(G)$</span> is NP-hard.</pre><pre>In this paper, we show that if <span>$G$</span> is a graph with no isolated vertex and <span>$H$</span> is a</pre><pre> <span>nontrivial</span> graph, then  the total Roman domination number of the lexicographic </pre><pre>product graph <span>$G\\circ H$</span> is given by</pre><pre><span>$$\\gamma_{tR}(G\\circ H)=\\left\\{\\begin{array}{ll}</span></pre><pre><span> 2\\gamma_t(G) &amp; \\mbox{if $</span><span>\\gamma</span>(H)<span>\\ge</span> 2<span>$,} \\\\[5pt]</span></pre><pre><span> \\xi(G) &amp; \\mbox{if $</span><span>\\gamma</span>(H)=1<span>$,}</span></pre><pre><span> \\end{array}</span></pre><pre><span>\\right.$$</span></pre><pre>where <span>$\\gamma(H)$</span> is the domination number of <span>$H$</span>,   <span>$\\gamma_t(G)$</span> is the</pre><pre> total domination number of <span>$G$</span> and <span>$\\xi(G)$</span> is a domination parameter</pre><pre> defined on <span>$G$</span>.</pre>	string

2285	en_US	title	Progress on sufficient conditions for a graph to have a spanning $k-$ended tree	string
2285	en_US	cleanTitle	Progress on sufficient conditions for a graph to have a spanning kended tree	string
2285	en_US	abstract	<p>In 1998, Broersma and Tuinstra [J. Graph Theory \\textbf{29} (1998), 227-237] proved that if $G$ is a connected graph satisfying $\\sigma_2(G) \\geq |G|-k+1$ then $G$ has a spanning $k-$ended tree. They also gave an example to show that the condition "$\\sigma_2(G) \\geq |G|-k+1$" is sharp. In this paper, we introduce a new progress for this result.<br />Let $K_{m,m+k}$ be a complete bipartite graph with bipartition $V(K_{m,m+k})=A\\cup B, |A|=m, |B|=m+k.$ Denote by $H$ to be the graph obtained from $K_{m,m+k}$ by adding (or no adding) some edges with two end vertices in $A.$ We prove that if $G$ is a connected graph satisfying $\\sigma_2(G) \\geq |G|-k$ then $G$ has a spanning $k-$ended tree except for the case $G$ is isomorphic to a graph $H.$ As a corollary of our main result, a sufficient condition for a graph to have a few branch vertices is given.</p>	string

2286	en_US	abstract	<p>We study polygon spaces arising from planar configurations of necklaces with some of the beads fixed and some of the beads sliding freely. 2289	en_US	title	Minimal effort algorithm for generating Cartesian product of finite sets	string
2289	en_US	cleanTitle	Minimal effort algorithm for generating Cartesian product of finite sets	string
2289	en_US	abstract	The issue of generating Cartesian product of arbitrary finite sets can be replaced by numbering each term of those sets and generating Cartesian product of finite sets in form of Z(i)={0,1, ... L(i-1)} for i=1,..., N. Subsequently this problem can by replaced by generating numbers with N digits using positional numeral system (possibly with mixed radix) and mapping digits into given Cartesian product. In this article there is presented an algorithm which requires minimal effort to generate such sequence. The property of minimal effort means that the every next vector (of digits) in the sequence differs from the previous only by one coordinate and the coordinate which differs is obtained by adding 1 in modular arithmetic sense (with respect to a relevant base). The algorithm is minimal in terms of how many elements are changed every step and in terms how they are changed. The second property is the main difference between the algorithm and Gray code, in which the changed term is increased or decreased by one.	string

2296	en_US	abstract	We show that the Waring number over a finite field $\\mathbb{F}_q$, denoted $g(k,q)$, when exists, coincides with the diameter of the generalized Paley graph $\\Gamma(k,q)  = Cay(\\mathbb{F}_{q},R_k)$ with $R_k=\\{x^k : x \\in \\mathbb{F}_q^*\\}$. We find infinite new families of exact values of $g(k,q)$ from  a characterization of graphs $\\Gamma(k,q)$ which are also Hamming graphs proved by Lim and Praeger in 2009. <br />Then, we show that every positive integer is the Waring number for some pair $(k,q)$ with $q$ not a prime. 2298	en_US	title	Finite metric and $k$-metric bases on ultrametric spaces	string
2298	en_US	cleanTitle	Finite metric and kmetric bases on ultrametric spaces	string
2298	en_US	abstract	Given a metric space $(X,d)$, a set $S\\subseteq X$ is called a $k$-\\emph{metric generator} for $X$ if any pair of different points of $X$ is distinguished by at least $k$ elements of $S$.  A $k$-\\emph{metric basis} is a $k$-metric generator of the minimum cardinality in $X$. We prove that ultrametric spaces do not have finite $k$-metric bases for $k&gt;2$. We also characterize when the metric and 2-metric bases of an ultrametric space are finite and, when they are finite, we characterize them. Finally, we prove that an ultrametric space can be easily recovered knowing only the metric basis and the coordinates of the points in it.	string

2300	en_US	title	ATTRACTIVE AND QUASI-ATTRACTIVE PAIRINGS AND THEIR MODELS FROM GRAPH THEORY	string
2300	en_US	cleanTitle	ATTRACTIVE AND QUASIATTRACTIVE PAIRINGS AND THEIR MODELS FROM GRAPH THEORY	string
2300	en_US	abstract	In the present paper, given an arbitrary fixed non-empty set $\\Omega$ and a triple (called {\\em pairing}) $\\mfP:=(U,F,\\Lambda)$, where $U$ and $\\Lambda$ are two sets and $F: U \\times \\Omega \\longrightarrow \\Lambda$ is a map, we consider a preorder $\\Lar\\mfp$ on the power set of $\\Omega$ having the further property that $B \\leftarrow\\mfp A$ if and only if $\\{b\\} \\leftarrow\\mfp A$ for any $b \\in B$. When we take the symmetrization of the above preorder, we obtain an equivalence relation $\\approx\\mfp$ on $\\mcP(\\Omega)$ which induces a Moore family $\\mcM\\mfp$ and an abstract simplicial complex $\\mcN\\mfp$ on $\\Omega$. They are defined by taking respectively the maximum and the minimal elements of any equivalence class with respect to $\\approx\\mfp$. We find a sufficient condition on $\\mfP$ ensuring that the family $\\mcN\\mfp$ is a matroid when $\\Omega$ is a finite set. We call the resulting pairings {\\em attractive}. The aforementioned condition can be generalized even for a non-finite ground set $\\Omega$. In this case, jointly with a finitess condition, it turns out that for each $A \\in \\mcM\\mfp$ the minimal members of the corresponding equivalence class $[A]_{\\approx\\mfp}$ all have the same cardinality. Nevertheless, the converse does not hold. As a counterexample, we shall consider a second kind of pairing, which we call {\\em quasi-attractive} and whose main properties, above all in relation to exchange properties of specific set systems, have been largely investigated. Finally, we shall consider the adjacency matrix of a graph $G$ as a concrete model of pairing (still denoted by $G$) and interpret the corresponding relation $\\Lar_G$ as a measure of how a kind of {\\em local symmetry} between vertices and subsets of the graph itself is transmitted when we vary the vertex subsets. We shall demonstrate that the pairing induced by the adjacency matrix of the Petersen graph is attractive, while that of the so-called {\\em Erd\\"{o}s' friendship graph} induces a quasi-attractive but not attractive pairing on the vertex set.	string
2300	en_US	discipline	Combinatorics	string
2300	en_US	subjectClass	05B35; 05C75; 68R10; 05C65; 06A15; 68P01	string

2300		licenseURL		string
2301	en_US	title	Counterexamples to “A conjecture on induced subgraphs of Cayley graphs”	string
2301	en_US	cleanTitle	Counterexamples to “A conjecture on induced subgraphs of Cayley graphs”	string
2301	en_US	abstract	<p>Recently, Huang gave a very elegant proof of the Sensitivity Conjecture by proving that hypercube graphs have the following property: every induced subgraph on a set of more than half the vertices has maximum degree at least <span class="math inline">√d</span>, where <span class="math inline"><em>d</em></span> is the valency of the hypercube. This was generalised by Alon and Zheng who proved that every Cayley graph on an elementary abelian <span class="math inline">2</span>-group has the same property. Very recently, Potechin and Tsang proved an analogous results for Cayley graphs on abelian groups. They also conjectured that all Cayley graphs have the analogous property. We disprove this conjecture by constructing various counterexamples, including an infinite family of Cayley graphs of unbounded valency which admit an induced subgraph of maximum valency <span class="math inline">1</span> on a set of more than half the vertices.</p>	string

2302	en_US	title	The extremal sizes of arc-maximal $(k,l)$-digraphs	string
2302	en_US	cleanTitle	The extremal sizes of arcmaximal kldigraphs	string
2302	en_US	abstract	Boesch and McHugh in [J.Combinatorial Theory Ser.B 38 (1985),1-7]<br />introduced the edge-maximal $(k, \\ell)$-graphs to<br />study of network subcohesion, and obtained best possible upper size bounds for all<br />edge-maximal $(k, \\ell)$-graphs. The best possible lower bounds are obtained in<br />[J. Graph Theory 18 (1994), 227-240].<br />Let $k,\\ell &gt; 0$ be integers. A strict digraph $D$<br />is a $(k,\\ell)$-digraph if for any subdigraph $H$ of $D$,<br />that $|V(H)|\\geq \\ell$ implies $\\lambda(H)\\leq k-1$. An arc-maximal<br />$(k,\\ell)$-digraph $D$ is one such that for any $e\\in A(D^c)$, $D+e$ is<br />not a $(k,\\ell)$-digraph. We show that there is a close relationship between<br />the extremal edge-maximal $(k,\\ell)$-graphs and<br />the extremal arc-maximal $(k,\\ell)$-digraphs. This is applied to<br />determine the optimal upper and lower bounds of the sizes of an arc-maximal<br />$(k,\\ell)$-digraphs. Moreover, the arc-maximal $(k,\\ell)$-digraphs<br />reaching the lower bounds and the upper bounds are respectively<br />characterized. Former results in [J.Combinatorial Theory Ser.B 38 (1985),1-7], [J. Graph<br />Theory 18 (1994), 227-240], [Discrete Math. 339 (2016), 2500-2510]<br />and [J. Graph Theory 84 (2017), 17-25] are extended.	string

2304	en_US	title	The structure of k-Lucas cubes	string
2304	en_US	cleanTitle	The structure of kLucas cubes	string
2304	en_US	abstract	Fibonacci cubes and Lucas cubes have been studied as alternatives for the classical hypercube topology for interconnection networks. These families of graphs have interesting graph theoretic and enumerative properties. Among the many generalization of Fibonacci cubes are k-Fibonacci cubes, which have the same number of vertices as Fibonacci cubes, but the edge sets determined by a parameter k. In this work, we consider k-Lucas cubes, which are obtained as subgraphs of k-Fibonacci cubes in the same way that Lucas cubes are obtained from Fibonacci cubes. We obtain a useful decomposition property of k-Lucas cubes which allows for the calculation of basic graph theoretic properties of this class, such as the number of edges, the average degree of a vertex, the number of hypercubes they contain, the diameter and the radius.	string
2304	en_US	discipline	Mathematics, Graph Theory	string
2304	en_US	subjectClass	05C31, 05A15, 11B37, 11B39	string
2304	en_US	subject	Hypercube, Fibonacci cube, Lucas cube, k-Fibonacci cube, Fibonacci number, Lucas number	string
2304	en_US	sponsor		string
2304	en_US	copyrightHolder	ARS MATHEMATICA CONTEMPORANEA	string
2304		licenseURL		string
2305	en_US	title	Best possible bounds on the matching number of a graph with given edge-connectivity, and its associated convex set	string
2305	en_US	cleanTitle	Best possible bounds on the matching number of a graph with given edgeconnectivity and its associated convex set	string
2305	en_US	abstract	Let $L_{k,\\lambda}$ be the set of pairs $(\\gamma,\\beta)$ of real numbers with the property there exists a constant $K$ such that $\\alpha'(G) \\ge \\gamma n + \\beta m - K$ for every connected graph $G$ of order~$n$, size~$m$, with maximum degree at most~$k$ and edge-connectivity at least~$\\lambda \\ge 1$. In a recent paper [J. Graph Theory 89(2) (2018), 115--149] the authors give a complete description of the set $L_{k,1}$. In this paper we extend this result to graphs of higher edge connectivity. For this purpose, we establish new tight lower bounds on the matching number in a graph with given maximum degree  and edge-connectivity in terms of its order and size. We show that these new bounds, together with earlier known bounds of the authors, are powerful enough to give a complete description of the set $L_{k,\\lambda}$ for all $k \\ge \\lambda \\ge 2$. We show that $L_{k,\\lambda}$ is a convex set, and determine its extreme points.	string

2308	en_US	title	The (non-)existence of perfect codes in Lucas cubes	string
2308	en_US	cleanTitle	The nonexistence of perfect codes in Lucas cubes	string
2308	en_US	abstract	<p>The Fibonacci cube of dimension $n$, denoted as $\\Gamma_n$, is the subgraph of the $n$-cube $Q_n$ induced by vertices with no consecutive 1's. Ashrafi and his co-authors proved the non-existence of perfect codes in $\\Gamma_n$ for $n\\geq 4$. As an open problem the authors suggest to consider the existence of perfect codes in generalizations of Fibonacci cubes. The most direct generalization is the family $\\Gamma_n(1^s)$ of subgraphs induced by strings without $1^s$ as a substring where $s\\geq 2$ is a given integer. In a precedent work we proved the existence of a perfect code in $\\Gamma_n(1^s)$ for $n=2^p-1$ and $s \\geq 3.2^{p-2}$ for any integer $p\\geq 2$.\\\\<br />The Lucas cube $\\Lambda_n$ is obtained from $\\Gamma_n$ by removing vertices that start and end with 1. Very often the same problems are studied on Fibonacci cubes and Lucas cube. In this note we prove the non-existence of perfect codes in $\\Lambda_n$ for $n\\geq 4$ and prove the existence of perfect codes in some generalized Lucas cube $\\Lambda_n(1^s)$.</p>	string

2310	en_US	title	Weighted Distances in Cairo Pattern	string
2310	en_US	cleanTitle	Weighted Distances in Cairo Pattern	string
2310	en_US	abstract	The Cairo Pattern is an interesting tiling of the plane. It consists<br />of pentagons which completely cover the plane without overlapping. The<br />Cairo Pattern is the dual of a semi-regular grid. It is assumed that one can<br />walk on the pentagons such that it is possible to step only two neighboring<br />pentagons. Dierent types of steps have dierent weights. The distance<br />of two pentagons is the length of the minimal path between them. All<br />distances are determined based on a linear programming model. The main<br />tool of the analysis is the simplex method of linear programming. The<br />analysis also uses the special properties of the model of minimal path.<br />All minimal paths are given explicitly. Therefore, the complexity of our<br />nal result is O(1) inspite of the fact that the general simplex method is<br />thought to be exponential.	string

2311	en_US	abstract	Our article describes the concept of generalized $\\pi$weak ($g\\pi(w)$) closed sets in weak structure spaces, which has many applications in information systems. Generally, we will give  proofs of the essential properties and relations among all the deliberated notions. Some topological concepts such as separation axioms, continuous functions and strongly closed $w$graph in terms of $g\\pi(w)$closed sets are established with some of their principle advantages.	string

2312	en_US	title	AVERAGE TERMINAL WIENER INDEX	string
2312	en_US	cleanTitle	AVERAGE TERMINAL WIENER INDEX	string
2312	en_US	abstract	For a tree T, the terminal Wiener index TW(T) is defined as half the sum of all distances of the form d(u,v), where the summation is over all possible pairs of pendent vertices u,v in T . In this paper, we discuss about average terminal Wiener index of trees. The trees with maximum, minimum, second maximum and second minimum value of average terminal Wiener index is determined. We obtain the tree with minimum average terminal Wiener index among all trees of order n and with diameter d. We also obtain the tree with maximum average terminal Wiener index among all trees of order n and with maximum degree Δ. We also prove that every even integer is the average terminal Wiener index of some non-path tree.	string

2313	en_US	abstract	This paper seeks to define the var-folding and the limit var-folding on manifolds. Also, we characterize the effect of induced var-folding from the viewpoint of the fundamental group. For many adjunctions in the context, we investigate the var-folding and induced var-folding on the wedge sum of some types of manifolds. 2315	en_US	title	Duality pairs and homomorphisms to oriented and unoriented cycles	string
2315	en_US	cleanTitle	Duality pairs and homomorphisms to oriented and unoriented cycles	string
2315	en_US	abstract	In the homomorphism order of digraphs, a duality<br />pair is an ordered pair of digraphs $(G,H)$ such that for<br />any digraph, $D$, $G\\to D$ if and only if $D\\not \\to H$.<br />The directed path on $k+1$ vertices together with the<br />transitive tournament on $k$ vertices is a classic<br />example of a duality pair. This relation between paths<br />and tournaments implies that a graph is $k$-colourable<br />if and only if it admits an orientation with no<br />directed path on more than $k$-vertices.<br /><br />In this work, for every undirected cycle $C$ we find an<br />orientation $C_D$ and an oriented path $P_C$, such that<br />$(P_C,C_D)$ is a duality pair.  As a consequence we obtain<br />that there is a finite set, $F_C$, such that an undirected<br />graph is homomorphic to $C$, if and only if it admits an<br />$F_C$-free orientation. As a byproduct of the proposed<br />duality pairs, we show that if $T$ is a tree of height<br />at most $3$, one can choose a dual of $T$ of linear size<br />with respect to the size of $T$.	string

2316	en_US	abstract	<p>In this article, we prove the<br />existence of entropy solutions for the Dirichlet problem<br />\\[<br />(P)\\left\\{ \\begin{array}{ll} &amp; -\\,{\\mathrm{div}}[{\\mathcal{A}}(x,<br />{\\nabla}u)\\,{\\omega}_1 + {\\mathcal{B}}(x,u,{\\nabla}u)\\,{\\omega}_2] = f(x) \\ {\\mathrm{in}} \\ {\\Omega}, \\\\<br />&amp; u(x) = 0 \\ {\\mathrm{on}} \\ {\\partial\\Omega},<br />\\end{array}<br />\\right.<br />\\]<br />\\noindent where $\\Omega$ is a bounded open set of ${\\real}^N$,<br />$N\\,{\\geq}\\,2$ and $f\\,{\\in}\\,L^1(\\Omega)$.</p>	string

2317	en_US	title	A duality for labeled graphs and factorizations with applications to graph embeddings	string
2317	en_US	cleanTitle	A duality for labeled graphs and factorizations with applications to graph embeddings	string
2317	en_US	abstract	<p>The set of factorizations of permutations in to $m$ transpositions<br /> of some symmetric group $\\mathcal{S}_n$ is naturally in bijection<br /> with the set of graphs of order $n$ and size $m$ with both edges and<br /> vertices labeled. We define a notion of duality (the<br /> \\emph{mind-body duality}) for factorizations and such labeled graphs<br /> and interpret it in terms of Properly Embedded Graphs, a class of<br /> graphs embedded in a bounded compact oriented surface with all the<br /> vertices lying in the boundary, and show a close connection of this<br /> duality with the Hurwitz action of the Braid Group. Connections<br /> with the theory of Cellularly Embedded Graphs are highlighted and<br /> hints of possible applications are given. In this paper we focus on<br /> developing the necessary theory, leaving specific applications and<br /> further developments for future projects.</p>	string

2318	en_US	title	From Italian domination in lexicographic product graphs to $w$-domination in graphs	string
2318	en_US	cleanTitle	From Italian domination in lexicographic product graphs to wdomination in graphs	string
2318	en_US	abstract	<span style="color: #000000;">In this paper, we show that the Italian domination number of every lexicographic product graph </span><span style="color: #008000;">$G\\circ H$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> can be expressed in terms of five different domination parameters of </span><span style="color: #008000;">$G$</span><span style="color: #000000;">. These parameters can be defined under the following unified approach, which encompasses the definition of several well-known domination parameters and introduces new ones. Let </span><span style="color: #008000;">$N(v)$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> denote the open neighbourhood of </span><span style="color: #008000;">$v\\in V(G)$</span><span style="color: #000000;">, </span><pre style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; margin: 0px;"><span style="color: #000000;"> and let </span><span style="color: #008000;">$w=(w_0,w_1, \\dots,w_l)$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> be a vector of </span><span style="text-decoration: underline; color: #000000;">nonnegative</span><span style="color: #000000;"> integers such that </span><span style="color: #008000;">$ w_0\\ge 1$</span><span style="color: #000000;">. We say that a function </span><span style="color: #008000;">$f: V(G)\\longrightarrow \\{0,1,\\dots ,l\\}$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> is a </span><span style="color: #008000;">$w$</span><span style="color: #000000;">-dominating function if </span><span style="color: #008000;">$f(N(v))=\\sum_{u\\in N(v)}f(u)\\ge w_i$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> for every vertex </span><span style="color: #008000;">$v$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> with </span><span style="color: #008000;">$f(v)=i$</span><span style="color: #000000;">. The weight of </span><span style="color: #008000;">$f$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> is defined to be </span><span style="color: #008000;">$\\omega(f)=\\sum_{v\\in V(G)} f(v)$</span><span style="color: #000000;">.</span></pre><pre style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; margin: 0px;"><span style="color: #000000;"> The </span><span style="color: #008000;">$w$</span><span style="color: #000000;">-domination number of </span><span style="color: #008000;">$G$</span><span style="color: #000000;">, denoted by </span><span style="color: #008000;">$\\gamma_{w}(G)$</span><span style="color: #000000;">, is the minimum weight among all </span><span style="color: #008000;">$w$</span><span style="color: #000000;">-dominating functions on </span><span style="color: #008000;">$G$</span><span style="color: #000000;">. If we impose restrictions on the minimum degree of </span><span style="color: #008000;">$G$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> when needed, under this approach we can define, for instance, the domination number </span></pre><pre style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; margin: 0px;"><span style="color: #008000;">$\\gamma(G)=\\gamma_{(1,0)}(G)=\\gamma_{(1,0,\\dots, 0)}(G)$</span><span style="color: #000000;">, the total domination number </span></pre><pre style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; margin: 0px;"><span style="color: #008000;">$\\gamma_t(G)=\\gamma_{(1,1)}(G)$</span><span style="color: #000000;">, the </span><span style="color: #008000;">$k$</span><span style="color: #000000;">-domination number </span></pre><pre style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; margin: 0px;"><span style="color: #008000;">$\\gamma_k(G)=\\gamma_{(k,0)}(G)$</span><span style="color: #000000;">, the </span><span style="color: #008000;">$k$</span><span style="color: #000000;">-</span><span style="text-decoration: underline; color: #000000;">tuple</span><span style="color: #000000;"> domination number </span></pre><pre style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; margin: 0px;"><span style="color: #008000;">$\\gamma_{\\times k}(G)=\\gamma_{(k,k-1)}(G)$</span><span style="color: #000000;">, the </span><span style="color: #008000;">$k$</span><span style="color: #000000;">-</span><span style="text-decoration: underline; color: #000000;">tuple</span><span style="color: #000000;"> total domination number </span></pre><pre style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; margin: 0px;"><span style="color: #008000;">$\\gamma_{\\times k,t}(G)=\\gamma_{(k,k)}(G)$</span><span style="color: #000000;">, the Italian domination number </span></pre><pre style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; margin: 0px;"><span style="color: #008000;">$\\gamma_{I}(G)=\\gamma_{(2,0,0)}(G)$</span><span style="color: #000000;">, the total Italian domination number </span></pre><pre style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; margin: 0px;"><span style="color: #008000;">$\\gamma_{t{I}}(G)=\\gamma_{(2,1,1)}(G)$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> and the </span><span style="color: #008000;">$\\{k\\}$</span><span style="color: #000000;">-domination number </span><span style="color: #008000;">$\\gamma_{\\{k\\}}(G)=\\gamma_{(k,k-1,\\dots,0)}(G)$</span><span style="color: #000000;">.</span></pre><pre style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; margin: 0px;"> </pre><pre style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; margin: 0px;"> </pre><pre style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; margin: 0px;"><span style="color: #000000;">Specifically, we show that </span><span style="color: #008000;">$\\gamma_{I}(G\\circ H)=\\gamma_{w}(G)$</span><span style="color: #000000;">, where </span><span style="color: #008000;">$w\\in \\{2\\}\\times\\{0,1,2\\}^{l}$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> and </span><span style="color: #008000;">$l\\in \\{2,3\\}$</span><span style="color: #000000;">. The decision on whether the equality holds for specific values of </span><span style="color: #008000;">$w_0,\\dots,w_l$</span></pre><pre style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; margin: 0px;"><span style="color: #000000;"> will depend on the value of the domination number of </span><span style="color: #008000;">$H$</span><span style="color: #000000;">.</span></pre><pre style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; margin: 0px;"><span style="color: #000000;"> This paper also provides preliminary results on </span><span style="color: #008000;">$\\gamma_{w}(G)$</span><span style="color: #000000;"> and raises the challenge of conducting a detailed study of the topic. </span></pre>	string

2324	en_US	title	On two M\\"obius functions for a finite non-solvable group	string
2324	en_US	cleanTitle	On two M\\obius functions for a finite nonsolvable group	string
2324	en_US	abstract	<p>Let $G$ be a finite group, $\\mu$ be the M\\"obius function on the subgroup lattice of $G$, and $\\lambda$ be the M\\"obius function on the poset of conjugacy classes of subgroups of $G$. It was proved by Pahlings that, whenever $G$ is solvable, the property $\\mu(H,G)=[N_{G^\\prime}(H):G^{\\prime}\\cap H]\\cdot\\lambda(H,G)$ holds for any subgroup $H$ of $G$. It is known that this property does not hold in general; for instance it does not hold for every simple groups, the Mathieu group $M_{12}$ being a counterexample. In this paper we investigate the relation between $\\mu$ and $\\lambda$ for some classes of non-solvable groups; among them, the minimal non-solvable groups. We also provide several examples of groups not satisfying the property.</p>	string

2325	en_US	title	Subdirect products and propagating equations with an application to Moufang theorem	string
2325	en_US	cleanTitle	Subdirect products and propagating equations with an application to Moufang theorem	string
2325	en_US	abstract	We introduce the concept or propagating equations and focus on the case of associativity propagating in varieties of loops.<br /><br />An equation e propagates in an algebra X if e(<strong>y</strong>) holds whenever e(<strong>x</strong>) holds and the elements of <strong>y</strong> are contained in the subalgebra of X generated by the elements of <strong>x.</strong> If e propagates in X then it propagates in all subalgebras and products of X but not necessarily in all homomorphic images of X. If V is a variety, the propagating core V<sub>[e]</sub> = {X in V : e propagates in X} is a quasivariety but not necessarily a variety.<br /><br />We prove by elementary means Goursat's Lemma for loops and describe all subdirect products of X<sup>k</sup> and all finitely generated loops in <strong>HSP(X)</strong> for a nonabelian simple loop X. If V is a variety of loops in which associativity propagates, X is a finite loop in which associativity propagates and every subloop of X is either nonabelian simple or contained in V, then associativity propagates in the join of <strong>HSP</strong>(X) and V.<br /><br />We study the propagating core S<sub>[x(yz)=(xy)z]</sub> of Steiner loops with respect to associativity. While this is not a variety, we exhibit many varieties contained in S<sub>[x(yz)=(xy)z]</sub>, each providing a solution to Rajah's problem, i.e., a variety of loops not contained in Moufang loops in which Moufang Theorem holds.	string

2326	en_US	title	Combining subspace codes	string
2326	en_US	cleanTitle	Combining subspace codes	string
2326	en_US	abstract	In the context of constant--dimension subspace codes, an important problem is to determine the largest possible size $A_q(n, d; k)$ of codes whose codewords are $k$-subspaces of $\\F_q^n$ with minimum subspace distance $d$. Here in order to obtain improved constructions, we investigate several approaches to combine subspace codes. This allow us to present improvements on the lower bounds for constant--dimension subspace codes for many parameters, including $A_q(10, 4; 5)$, $A_q(12, 4; 4)$,  $A_q(12, 6, 6)$ and $A_q(16, 4; 4)$.	string

2330	en_US	title	Steiner Wiener index of line graphs	string
2330	en_US	cleanTitle	Steiner Wiener index of line graphs	string
2330	en_US	abstract	Let S be a set of vertices of a connected graph G. The Steiner distance of S is the minimum size of a connected subgraph of G containing all vertices of S. The sum of all Steiner distances on sets of size k is called the Steiner k Wiener index. We obtain formulae for the Steiner Wiener index of line graphs and its iterations. Also we study relations among Steiner Wiener index of line graphs, Steiner edge Wiener index and Steiner Gutman index.	string

2343	en_US	abstract	<p><strong>Abstract </strong>In the current study, we define the different L-valued operators on <em>L</em><em>B</em>-valued general fuzzy automata or simply <em>L</em><em>B</em>-valued GFA, where B is considered as a complete infinitely distributive lattice of propositions about the GFA. 2345	en_US	title	On some projective triply-even binary codes invariant under the Conway group ${\\rm Co}_1$	string

2345	en_US	abstract	<p>A binary triply-even $[98280, 25, 47104]_2$ code invariant under the sporadic simple group ${\\rm Co}_1$ is constructed by adjoining the all-ones vector to the faithful and absolutely irreducible 24-dimensional code of length 98280. Using the action of ${\\rm Co}_1$ on the code we give a description of the nature of the codewords of any non-zero weight relating these to vectors of types 2, 3 and 4, respectively of the Leech lattice. 2347	en_US	title	Cyclotomic quotients of two conjugates of an algebraic number	string
2347	en_US	cleanTitle	Cyclotomic quotients of two conjugates of an algebraic number	string
2347	en_US	abstract	<p>Let $\\al$ be an algebraic number of degree $d \\geq 2$. In this note we consider the set $E(\\alpha)$ of positive integers $n$ such that the primitive $n$th root of unity $e^{2\\pi i/n}$ is expressible by a quotient of two conjugates of $\\al$ over $\\Q$. In particular, our results imply that the set $E(\\al)$ is small. We prove the bound $|E(\\al)| &lt; d^{\\frac{c}{\\log \\log d}}$, where $c=1.04$ for each sufficiently large $d$. We also show that in terms of $d$ this estimate is best possible up to a constant, since the number $1.04$ cannot be replaced by any number smaller than or equal to $0.69$. </p>	string

We prove that the group <span class="math inline"><em>C</em><sub>2</sub><sup>5</sup> × <em>C</em><sub><em>p</em></sub></span>, where <span class="math inline"><em>p</em></span> is a prime, is a DCI-group if and only if <span class="math inline"><em>p</em> ≠ 2</span>. 2351	en_US	title	On the displacement numbers of graphs	string
2351	en_US	cleanTitle	On the displacement numbers of graphs	string
2351	en_US	abstract	<p>The sum of distances between every pair of vertices in a graph $G$ is called the \\textit{Wiener index} of $G$.  This graph invariant was initially utilized to predict certain physico-chemical properties of organic compounds.  However, the Wiener index of $G$ does not account for any of its symmetries, which are also known to effect these physico-chemical properties. Graovac and Pisanski modified the Wiener index of $G$ to measure the average distance each vertex is displaced under the elements of the symmetry group of $G$; we call this the \\textit{displacement number} of $G$.  In this article, we prove that the set of all displacement numbers of graphs with isomorphic symmetry groups is dense in a half-line.  Moreover, for each finite group $\\Gamma$ and each rational number $q$ within this half-line, we present a construction for a graph whose displacement number is $q$ and whose symmetry group is isomorphic to $\\Gamma$. This construction results in graphs whose vertex orbits are not connected; we also consider an analogous construction which ensures that all vertex orbits are connected.</p>	string
2351	en_US	discipline	graph theory	string
2351	en_US	subjectClass	05C12; 05C25; 05C35; 05C92	string
2351	en_US	subject	Wiener index,  Graovac-Pisanski index, graph automorphism group, chemical graph theory	string
2351	en_US	sponsor		string
2351	en_US	copyrightHolder	ARS MATHEMATICA CONTEMPORANEA	string
2351		licenseURL		string
2340	en_US	title	Bootstrap Percolation via Automated Conjecturing	string
2340	en_US	cleanTitle	Bootstrap Percolation via Automated Conjecturing	string
2340	en_US	abstract	Bootstrap percolation is a simple monotone cellular automaton with a long history in physics, computer science, and discrete mathematics. In $k$-neighbor bootstrap percolation, a collection of vertices are initially infected.  Vertices with at least $k$ infected neighbors subsequently become infected; the process continues until stability is reached. In this paper, we hunt for graphs which can become entirely infected from initial sets which are as small as possible.  We use automated conjecture-generating software and a large group lab-based model as a fundamental part of our exploration.	string
2340	en_US	discipline		string

2352	en_US	title	Tight relative $t$-designs on two shells in hypercubes, and Hahn and Hermite polynomials	string
2352	en_US	cleanTitle	Tight relative tdesigns on two shells in hypercubes and Hahn and Hermite polynomials	string
2352	en_US	abstract	<p class="p1">Relative $t$-designs in the $n$-dimensional hypercube $\\mathcal{Q}_n$ are equivalent to weighted regular $t$-wise balanced designs, which generalize combinatorial $t$-$(n,k,\\lambda)$ designs by allowing multiple block sizes as well as weights. Partly motivated by the recent study on tight Euclidean $t$-designs on two concentric spheres, in this paper we discuss tight relative $t$-designs in $\\mathcal{Q}_n$ supported on two shells. We show under a mild condition that such a relative $t$-design induces the structure of a coherent configuration with two fibers. Moreover, from this structure we deduce that a polynomial from the family of the Hahn hypergeometric orthogonal polynomials must have only integral simple zeros. The Terwilliger algebra is the main tool to establish these results. By explicitly evaluating the behavior of the zeros of the Hahn polynomials when they degenerate to the Hermite polynomials under an appropriate limit process, we prove a theorem which gives a partial evidence that the non-trivial tight relative $t$-designs in $\\mathcal{Q}_n$ supported on two shells are rare for large $t$.</p>	string
2352	en_US	discipline		string

2353	en_US	title	Every tree is an Integral Sum Graph	string
2353	en_US	cleanTitle	Every tree is an Integral Sum Graph	string
2353	en_US	abstract	<p>A finite simple graph G is called an integral sum graph(respectively, sum graph)<br />if there is a bijection f from the vertices of G to a set of integers S (respectively, a<br />set of positive integers S) such that uv is an edge of G if and only if f(u)+f(v) in S.<br />In 1999, Liaw et al (Ars Comb.,Vol.54, 259-268) posed the conjecture that every<br />tree is an integral sum graph. In this note, we prove that all trees are integral sum<br />graphs. Further, we prove that every bipartite graph is an induced subgraph of a<br />sum graph G with sum number \\sigma(G) = 1.</p>	string

2354	en_US	cleanTitle	Coarse distinguishability of graphs with symmetric growth	string
2354	en_US	abstract	Let X be a connected, locally finite graph with symmetric growth. We prove that there is a vertex coloring φ: X → {0,1} and some R ∈ N such that every automorphism f preserving φ is R-close to the identity map; this can be seen as a coarse geometric version of symmetry breaking. We also prove that the infinite motion conjecture is true for graphs where at least one vertex stabilizer S<sub>x</sub> satisfies the following condition: for every non-identity automorphism f ∈ S<sub>x</sub>, there is a sequence x<sub>n</sub> such that lim d(x<sub>n</sub>,f(x<sub>n</sub>)) = ∞.	string

2359	en_US	title	Wiener-type Indices of Parikh Word Representable Graphs	string
2359	en_US	cleanTitle	Wienertype Indices of Parikh Word Representable Graphs	string
2359	en_US	abstract	A new class of graphs G(w), called  Parikh word representable graphs (PWRG), corresponding to words $w$ that are finite sequence of symbols, was considered in the recent past. Several properties of these graphs have been established. In this paper, we consider these graphs corresponding to binary core words of the form $aub$ over a binary alphabet {a,b}.  We derive formulas for computing the Wiener index of the PWRG of a binary core word. Sharp bounds are established on the value of this index in terms of different parameters related to binary words over {a,b} and the corresponding PWRGs. Certain other Wiener-type indices that are variants of Wiener index are also considered. Formulas for computing these indices in the case of PWRG of a binary core word are obtained.	string

2363	en_US	title	Dessins d'enfants with two vertices and one face	string

2363	en_US	abstract	<p>For a fixed positive integer N, we determine the cardinalities of some typical sets of equivalence classes of dessins d'enfants which have (just) N edges and either a unique white vertex, a unique black vertex or a unique face. Taking any positive divisor r of N, we enumerate among others the equivalence classes of dessins with N edges, two vertices and one face whose automorphism groups are cyclic and have order r. Our arguments are based upon a natural one-to-one correspondence of the equivalence classes of all dessins with N edges to the equivalence classes of all pairs of permutations whose components generate transitive subgroups of the symmetric group of degree N.</p>	string

2365	en_US	title	Bicritical properties in connected domination critical graphs	string
2365	en_US	cleanTitle	Bicritical properties in connected domination critical graphs	string
2365	en_US	abstract	<pre>A subset <span>$S$</span> of vertices in  a graph <span>$G=(V, E)$</span> is a  connected dominating set of <span>$G$</span> if every vertex of <span>$V\\setminus S$</span> is adjacent to a vertex in <span>$S$</span> and  the subgraph induced by <span>$S$</span> is connected. The minimum cardinality of a connected dominating set is the connected dominating number <span>$\\gamma_{c}(G)$</span> of <span>$G$</span>. <span>$G$</span> is a <span>$3$</span>-<span>$\\gamma_{c}$</span>-critical graph if <span>$\\gamma_{c}(G)=3$</span> and <span>$\\gamma_{c}(G+uv)\\leq 2$</span> for any pair of vertices <span>$u$</span> and <span>$v$</span> such that <span>$uv\\not\\in E$</span>; <span>$G$</span> is bicritical if <span>$G-u-v$</span> contains a perfect matching for every pair of distinct vertices <span>$u, v\\in V$</span>.</pre><pre>We show, for any integer <span>$t(\\geq 3)$</span>, a <span>$3$</span>-connected <span>$3$</span>-<span>$\\gamma_{c}$</span>-critical <span>$K_{1, t}$</span>-free graph of even order with <span>$\\delta(G)\\geq t-1$</span> is bicritical, where <span>$\\delta(G)$</span> is the minimum degree of <span>$G$</span>, and show the bounds on connectivity and minimum degree are best possible by giving two kinds of counterexamples. 2366	en_US	abstract	<p>The random polyphenyl chains with n hexagons are the special graphs of unbranched poly-<br />cyclic aromatic hydrocarbons. The Randic (R) index and first Zagreb index (M1) index<br />are two well-studied topological indices and found to be useful tools in QSPR and QSAR<br />investigations. 2367	en_US	title	Prime Factorization and  A Non-Distributive Algebra	string
2367	en_US	cleanTitle	Prime Factorization and  A NonDistributive Algebra	string
2367	en_US	abstract	In this paper, using fundamental theorem of arithmetic, first a non-negative integer is expressed in the form of prime factors. Only power-free integers are allowed, whereas the power-full integers are equivalent to other integers in the set. Since only power-free integers are allowed, the exponents of the corresponding primes only take binary values 0 or 1. In the prime factorization, the primes (bases) are then dropped, and the integer is expressed as a string of exponents. These binary strings satisfy certain product and sum rules. These binary numbers form groups under addition and multiplication. It does not, however, form a field as the distributive property does not hold. In the same paper, we also explore the algebra of infinity. It turns out that infinity plays the rule of additive identity.	string

2370	en_US	title	Dual finite frames for vector spaces over an arbitrary field	string
2370	en_US	cleanTitle	Dual finite frames for vector spaces over an arbitrary field	string
2370	en_US	abstract	<p>Frames have various advantages over bases which have made them very<br />useful in several areas of sciences and engineering. Applications<br />mainly require working in a finite-dimensional setting. In this<br />case, a frame is a spanning set. In the present paper we consider<br />frames for finite-dimensional vector spaces over an arbitrary field.<br />In order to obtain and study the different representations of the<br />elements of the vector space provided by a frame, we develop a<br />general theory of dual frames.</p><p>We introduce a notion of dual frame. We give several<br />characterizations of dual frames. Different methods for the<br />construction of all dual frames of a given frame are provided. We<br />also consider the construction of specific dual frames. This general<br />theory is related with the classical theory of dual frames for<br />Hilbert spaces.</p><p>The theory of dual frames developed here gives the possibility to<br />apply frames in very general contexts using only algebraic tools. It<br />also allows to consider dual frames for different vector spaces<br />which may have additional structures. In this paper, we use it to<br />study dual frames for three types of vector spaces. For vector<br />spaces over conjugate closed subfields of the complex numbers, and<br />in particular for cyclotomic fields. For metric vector spaces, i.e.,<br />vector spaces with a bilinear form defined on it that is either<br />symmetric, skew-symmetric or alternate. Finally, for ultrametric<br />normed vector spaces over complete nonarchimedean valued fields.</p>	string

2371	en_US	title	Classical meanness property of some graphs and its line graph	string
2371	en_US	cleanTitle	Classical meanness property of some graphs and its line graph	string
2371	en_US	abstract	A classical mean labeling of a graph $G$ with $q$ edges is an injective function from the vertex set of $G$ to $1, 2, 3,..., q+1$ such that the edge labels obtained from the flooring function of classical mean of the vertex labels of the end vertices of each edge are all distinct, and the set of edge labels is $1, 2, 3,..., q.$ A graph is said to be a classical mean graph if it admits a classical mean labeling. The line graph is one among the graph operations. In this paper, it is found that the line graph operation preserves the classical meanness property for the path $P_n,$ the cycle $C_n,$ the graph $P_n\\circ S_m,$  the graph $M(P_n),$  the graph $[P_n;S_m],$ the graph $S(P_n\\circ K_1)$ and the graph $T_n$.	string

2373	en_US	title	Trivalent dihedrants and bi-dihedrants	string
2373	en_US	cleanTitle	Trivalent dihedrants and bidihedrants	string
2373	en_US	abstract	<p>A Cayley (resp. bi-Cayley) graph on a dihedral group is called a {\\em dihedrant} (resp. {\\em bi-dihedrant}).<br />In 2000, a classification of trivalent arc-transitive dihedrants was given by Maru\\v si\\v c and Pisanski, and several years later, trivalent non-arc-transitive dihedrants of order $4p$ or $8p$ $(p$ a prime) were classified by Feng et al. As a generalization of these results, our first result presents a classification of trivalent non-arc-transitive dihedrants. Using this, a complete classification of trivalent vertex-transitive non-Cayley bi-dihedrants is given, thus completing the study of trivalent bi-dihedrants initiated in our previous paper [Discrete Math. 340 (2017) 1757--1772]. As a by-product, we generalize a theorem in [The Electronic Journal of Combinatorics 19 (2012) $\\#$P53].</p>	string

2374	en_US	abstract	<p>We prove new existence and nonexistence results for modular Golomb rulers in this paper. 2379	en_US	title	Total Colouring of New Classes of Subcubic Graphs	string
2379	en_US	cleanTitle	Total Colouring of New Classes of Subcubic Graphs	string
2379	en_US	abstract	<p>The total chromatic number of a graph $G$, denoted<br />$\\chi^{\\prime\\prime}(G)$, is the least number of colours needed to<br />colour the vertices and the edges of $G$ such that no incident or<br />adjacent elements (vertices or edges) receive the same colour. The<br />popular Total Colouring Conjecture (TCC) posed by Behzad states that, <br />for every simple graph $G$, $\\chi^{\\prime\\prime}(G) \\leq \\Delta(G)+2$.<br />In this paper, we prove that the total chromatic number for a family of <br />subcubic graphs called cube connected paths and also for a class of subcubic<br />graphs having the property that the vertices are covered by<br />independent triangles are exactly $\\Delta(G)+1$. More precisely, these two<br />families of subcubic graphs are shown to be Type 1 graph.</p>	string

2383	en_US	title	The decycling number of a surface-outer-embeddable graph	string
2383	en_US	cleanTitle	The decycling number of a surfaceouterembeddable graph	string
2383	en_US	abstract	Let $G$ be a connected graph with $n$ vertices which has a $2$-cell<br />embedding in the orientable surface $S_g (g\\ge 1)$ with a facial trail containing all vertices. The paper proves that<br />the decycling number of $G$ is at most $\\frac{n-10}{3}+6g$.<br />A similar result is proved for the nonorientable<br />surface $N_h$ where the decycling number is at most $\\frac{n-8}{3}+4h$.<br />In addition, the decycling number of a plane graph $H$ with $n$ vertices<br />and $k$ vertex-disjoint faces containing all vertices is<br />shown to be at most $\\frac{n+4k-4}{3}$. This means that<br />the conjecture that the decycling number of a planar graph with $n$ vertices is at most $\\frac{n}{2}$<br />holds for $H$ if $k\\le \\frac{n}{8}+1$.	string

2384	en_US	title	General d-position sets	string
2384	en_US	cleanTitle	General dposition sets	string
2384	en_US	abstract	The general $d$-position number ${\\rm gp}_d(G)$ of a graph $G$ is the cardinality of a largest set $S$ for which no three distinct vertices from $S$ lie on a common geodesic of length at most $d$. This new graph parameter generalizes the well studied general position number. We first give some results concerning the monotonic behavior of ${\\rm gp}_d(G)$ with respect to the suitable values of $d$. We show that the decision problem concerning finding ${\\rm gp}_d(G)$ is NP-complete for any value of $d$. The value of ${\\rm gp}_d(G)$ when $G$ is a path or a cycle is computed and a structural characterization of general $d$-position sets is shown. Moreover, we present some relationships with other topics including strong resolving graphs and dissociation sets. We finish our exposition by proving that ${\\rm gp}_d(G)$ is infinite whenever $G$ is an infinite graph and $d$ is a finite integer.	string

2385	en_US	title	Circulant almost cross intersecting families	string
2385	en_US	cleanTitle	Circulant almost cross intersecting families	string
2385	en_US	abstract	<p>Let $\\mathcal{F}$ and $\\mathcal{G}$ be two $t$-uniform families of subsets over $[k] \\eqdef \\{1,2,...,k\\}$, where $|\\mathcal{F}| = |\\mathcal{G}|$,<br />and let $C$ be the adjacency matrix of the bipartite graph whose vertices are the subsets in $\\mathcal{F}$ and $\\mathcal{G}$,<br />and there is an edge between $A\\in \\mathcal{F}$ and $B \\in \\mathcal{G}$ if and only if $A \\cap B \\neq \\emptyset$.<br />The pair $(\\mathcal{F},\\mathcal{G})$ is $q$-almost cross intersecting if every row and column of $C$ has exactly $q$ zeros.</p><p>We consider $q$-almost cross intersecting pairs that have a circulant intersection matrix $C_{p,q}$,<br />determined by a column vector with $p &gt; 0$ ones followed by $q &gt; 0$ zeros.<br />This family of matrices includes the identity matrix in one extreme, and the adjacency matrix of the bipartite crown graph in the other extreme.</p><p><br />We give constructions of pairs $(\\mathcal{F},\\mathcal{G})$ whose intersection matrix is $C_{p,q}$,<br />for a wide range of values of the parameters $p$ and $q$, and in some cases also prove matching upper bounds.<br />Specifically, we prove results for the following values of the parameters:<br />(1) $1 \\leq p \\leq 2t-1$ and $1 \\leq q \\leq k-2t+1$.<br />(2) $2t \\leq p \\leq t^2$ and any $q&gt; 0$, where $k \\geq p+q$.<br />(3) $p$ that is exponential in $t$, for large enough $k$.</p><p>Using the first result we show that if $k \\geq 4t-3$ then<br />$C_{2t-1,k-2t+1}$ is a maximal isolation submatrix of size $k\\times k$ in the $0,1$-matrix $A_{k,t}$,<br />whose rows and columns are labeled by all subsets of size $t$ of $[k]$,<br />and there is a one in the entry on row $x$ and column $y$ if and only if subsets $x,y$ intersect.</p>	string

2390	en_US	title	MODULARLY EQUIDISTANT NUMERICAL SEMIGROUPS	string
2390	en_US	cleanTitle	MODULARLY EQUIDISTANT NUMERICAL SEMIGROUPS	string
2390	en_US	abstract	If $S$ is a numerical semigroup and $s\\in S$, we denote by $\\text{next}_S(s)=\\min\\left\\{x \\in S ~|~ s&lt;x\\right\\}$. Let $a$ be an integer greater than or equal to two. A numerical semigroup is equidistant modulo $a$ if $\\text{next}_S(s)-s-1$ is a multiple of $a$ for every $s\\in S$. In this note we give algorithms for computing the whole set of equidistant numerical semigroups modulo $a$ with fixed multiplicity, genus and Frobenius number. 2392	en_US	abstract	<p>In this paper, we associate an undirected graph $\\mathfrak{I}^{n}(\\mathbb{V}),$ $the$ $zero$ $intersection$ $ graph,$ to a finite dimensional vector space $\\mathbb{V}.$ The vertex set of this graph is $V(\\mathfrak{I}^{n}(\\mathbb{V})),$ where $V(\\mathfrak{I}^{n}(\\mathbb{V}))$ is the collection of all proper subspaces of $\\mathbb{V}.$ Two distinct vertices $\\mathfrak{W}_{1}$ and $\\mathfrak{W}_{2}$ of $V(\\mathfrak{I}^{n}(\\mathbb{V}))$ are defined to be adjacent in $\\mathfrak{I}^{n}(\\mathbb{V})$ if and only if $\\mathfrak{W}_{1}\\cap\\mathfrak{W}_{2}=(0).$ The connectivity, diameter, maximal independent sets, clique number, chromatic number of $\\mathfrak{I}^{n}(\\mathbb{V})$ have been studied.</p>	string

2393	en_US	title	Integral homology of real isotropic and odd orthogonal Grassmannians	string
2393	en_US	cleanTitle	Integral homology of real isotropic and odd orthogonal Grassmannians	string
2393	en_US	abstract	<pre>We obtain a combinatorial expression for the coefficients of the boundary map of real isotropic and odd orthogonal Grassmannians providing a natural generalization of the formulas already obtained for Lagrangian and maximal isotropic Grassmannians. The results are given in terms of the classification into four types of covering pairs among the Schubert cells when identified with signed <span>$k$</span>-Grassmannian permutations. It turns out that these coefficients only depend on the positions changed over each pair of permutations. As an application, we give an <span>orientability</span> criterion, exhibit a symmetry of these coefficients and, compute low-dimensional homology groups.</pre>	string

2394	en_US	title	On graphs with equal total domination and Grundy total domination number	string
2394	en_US	cleanTitle	On graphs with equal total domination and Grundy total domination number	string
2394	en_US	abstract	<pre>A sequence <span>$(v_1,\\ldots ,v_k)$</span> of vertices in a graph <span>$G$</span> without isolated vertices</pre><pre> is called a total dominating sequence if every vertex <span>$v_i$</span> in the sequence totally dominates </pre><pre>at least one vertex that was not totally dominated by <span>$\\{v_1,\\ldots , v_{i-1}\\}$</span> and <span>$\\{v_1,\\ldots ,v_k\\}$</span> </pre><pre>is a total dominating set of <span>$G$</span>. The length of a shortest such sequence is the total domination number of G (<span>$\\gt(G)$</span>), </pre><pre>while the length of a longest such sequence is the Grundy total domination number of <span>$G$</span> (<span>$\\ggrt(G)$</span>). </pre><pre>In this paper we study graphs with equal total and Grundy total domination number. We characterize bipartite graphs with </pre><pre>both total and Grundy total domination number equal to 4, and show that there is no connected chordal graph <span>$G$</span> with <span>$\\gt(G)=\\ggrt(G)=4$</span>. </pre><pre>The main result of the paper is a characterization of regular bipartite graphs with <span>$\\gt(G)=\\ggrt(G)=6$</span> proved by establishing a surprising </pre><pre>correspondence between existence of such graphs and a classical but still open problem of the existence of certain finite projective planes.</pre>	string

2395	en_US	title	Some bounds on the $A_\\alpha$-index of connected graphs with fixed order and size	string
2395	en_US	cleanTitle	Some bounds on the A_\\alphaindex of connected graphs with fixed order and size	string
2395	en_US	abstract	Let $A(G)$ and $D(G)$ be the adjacency matrix and the degree diagonal matrix of a graph $G$, respectively. For any real $\\alpha\\in [0, 1]$, Nikiforov \\cite{0001} proposed the matrix $A_{\\alpha}(G)=\\alpha D(G)+(1-\\alpha)A(G)$, whose largest eigenvalue is called the $A_\\alpha$-index of $G$. In this contribution, we study this novel and interesting matrix of $G$. On the one hand, we show that in the set of connected graphs with fixed order and size, the graphs with the maximum $A_\\alpha$-index are the nested split graphs (i.e., threshold graphs). On the other hand, we establish some upper and lower bounds on the $A_\\alpha$-index of nested split graphs using eigenvector techniques. Finally, we present some computational results to compare these bounds.	string

2401	en_US	title	Equivalence, Partial Order and Lattice of Neighborhood Sequences on the Triangular Grid	string
2401	en_US	cleanTitle	Equivalence Partial Order and Lattice of Neighborhood Sequences on the Triangular Grid	string
2401	en_US	abstract	<p>In (digital) grids, neighbor relation is a crucial concept, digital distances are based on paths through neighbor points. Neighborhood sequences, i.e., infinite sequences of the possible types of neighbors are defining digital distances with lower rotational dependency as the distances based only on a sole neighborhood. They allow to change the used neighborhood condition in every step along a path. They are defined in various grids and they could be periodic. Generalised neighborhood sequences do not need to be periodic.<br />In this paper the triangular grid is studied. An equivalence and two partial order relations on the set of generalized and periodic neighborhood sequences are shown on this grid. The first partial order, the ``faster'' relation, is based on distances defined by neighborhood sequences and it does not provide a lattice, but give a relatively complex relation already for neighborhood sequences with a short period. The other partial order, the relation ``componentwise dominates'', results a complete distributive lattice on the set of generalised neighborhood sequences. Finally, a relation of the above mentioned relations is established.</p>	string

2404	en_US	title	On Location Number of Some Classes of Radially Symmetrical Graphs	string
2404	en_US	cleanTitle	On Location Number of Some Classes of Radially Symmetrical Graphs	string
2404	en_US	abstract	Let $\\Phi=\\Phi(\\mathbb{V},\\mathbb{E})$ be a basic associated (simple and connected) and indirected (i.e., all edges are unidirectional, with no direction associated with them) graph (or network) with an edge set $\\mathbb{E}$ and a node set $\\mathbb{V}$. A metric basis $\\mathbb{F}$ of a graph $\\Phi$ is the subset of nodes of least cardinality with the end goal that all different nodes are extraordinarily dictated by their separations to the nodes in $\\mathbb{F}$. The metric dimension of $\\Phi$ is the cardinality of the subset $\\mathbb{F}$. The problem of characterizing the classes of plane graphs with a constant metric dimension is of great interest nowadays. In this article, we characterize three classes of plane graphs (viz., $A_{n}$, $B_{n}$, and $C_{n}$), which has the spiral symmetry and has a consistent metric dimension. We demonstrate that just $3$ nodes properly chosen are adequate to determine all the vertices of these three classes of the radially symmetrical plane graphs.	string

2405	en_US	abstract	<p>Recent classification of $\\frac{3}{2}$-transitive permutation groups leaves us with three infinite families of groups which are neither $2$-transitive, nor Frobenius, nor one-dimensional affine. The groups of the first two families correspond to special actions of ${\\mathrm{PSL}}(2,q)$ and ${\\mathrm{P\\Gamma L}}(2,q),$ whereas those of the third family are the affine solvable subgroups of ${\\mathrm{AGL}}(2,q)$ found by D. Passman in~1967. The association schemes of the groups in each of these families are known to be pseudocyclic. It is proved that apart from three particular cases, each of these exceptional pseudocyclic schemes is characterized up to isomorphism by the tensor of its $3$-dimensional intersection numbers.</p>	string

2408	en_US	cleanTitle	Generalized Cayley maps and their Petrie duals	string
2408	en_US	abstract	<p>Cayley maps are embeddings of Cayley graphs in orientable surfaces which possess a group of orientation preserving automorphisms acting regularly on the vertices. We generalize the concept of a Cayley map by considering embeddings of Cayley graphs in both orientable and non-orientable surfaces and by requiring a group of automorphisms acting regularly on vertices that does not have to consist entirely of orientation preserving automorphisms. This leads to new families of maps in both the orientable and non-orientable cases. Beside regular generalized Cayley maps we also consider dart-regular generalized Cayley maps. Since the Petrie dual operator preserves the property of being a generalized Cayley map, throughout the paper we consider the action of this operator on our maps.</p>	string

2415	en_US	title	Classification of minimal Frobenius hypermaps	string
2415	en_US	cleanTitle	Classification of minimal Frobenius hypermaps	string
2415	en_US	abstract	In this paper, we give a classification of orientably regular hypermaps with an automorphism group<br />of a minimal Frobenius group. A Frobenius group $G$ is called minimal if  it doesn't have a nontrivial normal subgroup $N$  such that $G/N$ is a Frobenius group. An orientably regular hypermap $\\HH$ is called a Frobenius hypermap if $\\Aut(\\HH)$ acting on the hyperfaces is a Frobenius group. A minimal Frobenius hypermap is a Frobenius hypermap whose automorphism group is a minimal Frobenius group with cyclic point stabilizers. Every Frobenius hypermap covers a minimal Frobenius hypermap. The main theorem of this paper generalizes the main result of Breda D'Azevedo and Fernandes (European J. Combin. 32: 233--242, 2011).	string

2416	en_US	title	On the spectral reconstruction problem for digraphs	string
2416	en_US	cleanTitle	On the spectral reconstruction problem for digraphs	string
2416	en_US	abstract	<p>The idiosyncratic polynomial of a graph $G$ with adjacency matrix $A$ is the characteristic polynomial of the matrix $ A + y(J-A-I)$, where $I$ is the <br /> identity matrix and $J$ is the all-ones matrix. It follows from a theorem of Hagos (2000) combined with an earlier result of Johnson and Newman (1980) that the idiosyncratic polynomial of a graph is reconstructible from the multiset of the idiosyncratic polynomial of its vertex-deleted subgraphs.<br /> For a digraph $G$ with adjacency matrix $A$, we define its idiosyncratic polynomial as the characteristic polynomial of the matrix $ A + y(J-A-I)+zA^{t}$. By forbidding two fixed digraphs on three vertices as induced subdigraphs, we prove that the idiosyncratic polynomial of a digraph is reconstructible from the multiset of the idiosyncratic polynomial of its induced subdigraphs on three vertices. As an immediate consequence, the idiosyncratic polynomial of a tournament is reconstructible from the collection of its $3$-cycles. Another consequence is that all the transitive orientations of a comparability graph have the same idiosyncratic polynomial.</p>	string

2417	en_US	title	Next-to-minimum size blocking sets of external lines to a nondegenerate quadric in PG(3,q), q in { 2,3 }	string
2417	en_US	cleanTitle	Nexttominimum size blocking sets of external lines to a nondegenerate quadric in PG3q q in { 23 }	string
2417	en_US	abstract	<p style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; margin: 0px;">Consider a hyperbolic or elliptic quadric $Q^\\epsilon(3,q)$, $\\epsilon \\in \\{ +,- \\}$, in $PG(3,q)$ and let $\\mathcal{E}^\\epsilon$ denote the set of all lines of $PG(3,q)$ that are external with respect to $Q^\\epsilon(3,q)$. If $\\pi$ is a (tangent or secant) plane of $PG(3,q)$, then $\\pi \\setminus Q^\\epsilon(3,q)$ is an $\\mathcal{E}^\\epsilon$-blocking set which is minimal, except when $(q,\\epsilon) = (2,+)$ and $\\pi$ is a secant plane. In this way, we obtain two families of (minimal) blocking sets of sizes $m_1^\\epsilon$ and $m_2^\\epsilon$, with $(m_1^+,m_2^+)=(q^2-q,q^2)$ and $(m_1^-,m_2^-)=(q^2,q^2+q)$, where those of size $m_1^\\epsilon$ are also the minimum size $\\mathcal{E}^\\epsilon$-blocking sets. Motivated by the search for new (families of) minimal $\\mathcal{E}^\\epsilon$-blocking sets with sizes in the open interval $]m_1^\\epsilon,m_2^\\epsilon[$, we determine here all $\\mathcal{E}^\\epsilon$-blocking sets of size $m_1^\\epsilon+1$ in $PG(3,q)$ in case $q \\in \\{ 2,3 \\}$.</p>	string

2418	en_US	title	A strategy for Isolator in the Toucher-Isolator game on trees	string
2418	en_US	cleanTitle	A strategy for Isolator in the ToucherIsolator game on trees	string
2418	en_US	abstract	<p>In the Toucher-Isolator game, introduced recently by Dowden, Kang, Mikalacki and Stojakovic, Toucher and Isolator alternately claim an edge from a graph such that Toucher aims to touch as many vertices as possible, while Isolator aims to isolate as many vertices as possible, where Toucher plays first. Among trees with n vertices, they showed that the star is the best choice for Isolator and they asked for the most suitable tree for Toucher. Later, Raty showed that the answer is the path with n vertices. We give a simple alternative proof of this result. The method to determine where Isolator should play is by breaking down the gains and losses in each move of both players.</p>	string

2419	en_US	title	Seidel energy of complete multipartite graphs	string
2419	en_US	cleanTitle	Seidel energy of complete multipartite graphs	string
2419	en_US	abstract	The Seidel energy of a simple graph $G$ is the sum of the absolute values of the eigenvalues of the Seidel matrix of $G$. We obtain a relation between the Seidel energy of the complete multipartite graph and its smallest Seidel eigenvalue. Using this we find that among all complete $t$-partite graphs with $n$ vertices the Turan graphs have the minimum smallest Seidel eigenvalue, and maximum Seidel energy, and the complete split graphs have the maximum smallest Seidel eigenvalue and minimum Seidel energy.	string

2420	en_US	cleanTitle	Barycenters and some applications in a triangle	string
2420	en_US	abstract	By means of the barycentric coordinates of the main points in a triangle, we can easily justify some geometric properties such as the collinearity of $G,H,O'$ (The Euler Line), the fact that the orthocenter of a triangle coincides with the incenter of its orthic triangle, that the centroids of a triangle and of its median triangle coincide, that a non right angle triangle for which any two of the points $G,H,O',I$ coincide must be equilateral etc. The originality of the paper consists of the new proofs for some well-known results from elementary Euclidean geometry. For the sake of completeness, we included also some trivial statements.	string

2422	en_US	title	Decomposition Dimension of some class of Trees	string
2422	en_US	cleanTitle	Decomposition Dimension of some class of Trees	string
2422	en_US	abstract	<p>For an ordered k-decomposition D = {G1, G2, … , Gk} of a connected graph G = (V, E), the D-representation of an edge e is the k-tuple  (d(e,G1), d(e,G2), . . . , d(e,Gk)) , where d(e, Gi) represents the distance from e to Gi. A decomposition D is resolving if every two distinct edges of G have distinct representations. The minimum k for which G has a resolving k-decomposition is its decomposition dimension dec(G).  In this paper, the decomposition dimension of broomgraph, double broom graph and upper bounds for the decomposition dimension of banana tree graph and fire cracker graph are determined.</p>	string

2424	en_US	title	The Vertex-Distance-Complement Spectrum of Subdivision-Vertex Join and Subdivision-Edge Join of Two Regular Graphs	string

2424	en_US	abstract	The Vertex-Distance-Complement (VDC) matrix $\\textit{C}$, of a connected graph  $G$ with vertex set consisting of $n$ vertices, is a real symmetric matrix $[c_{ij}]$ that takes the value $n - d_{ij}$ where $d_{ij}$ is the distance between the vertices $v_i$ and $v_j$ of $G$ for $i \\neq j$ and 0 otherwise. The Vertex-Distance-Complement spectrum of the subdivision-vertex join, $G_1 \\dot{\\bigvee} G_2$ and the subdivision-edge join $G_1 \\underline{\\bigvee} G_2$ of regular graphs $G_1$ and $G_2$  in terms of the adjacency spectrum are determined in this paper.	string

2425	en_US	title	On the convexity number of complementary prisms of trees	string
2425	en_US	cleanTitle	On the convexity number of complementary prisms of trees	string
2425	en_US	abstract	A set of vertices $S$ of a graph $G$ is a (geodesic) convex set, if $S$ contains all the vertices belonging to any shortest path connecting between two vertices of $S$. The cardinality of maximum proper convex set of $G$ is called the convexity number, $\\con(G)$, of $G$. The complementary prism $\\GG$ of $G$ is obtained from the disjoint union of $G$ and its complement $\\overline{G}$ by adding the edges of a perfect matching between them. In this work, we examine the convex sets of the complementary prism of a tree and derive formulas for the convexity numbers of the complementary prisms of all trees.	string

2426	en_US	title	Symmetric road interchanges	string
2426	en_US	cleanTitle	Symmetric road interchanges	string
2426	en_US	abstract	A road interchange where n roads meet and in which drivers do not need to change lanes inside the junction can be modelled as an embedding of a 2-coloured (hence bipartite) multigraph G with equal-sized colour classes into an orientable surface such that there is a face bounded by a Hamiltonian cycle [10]. The case of G a complete bipartite graph Kn,n corresponds to a complete n-way interchange where drivers approaching from each of n directions can exit to any other direction. The genus of the underlying surface can be interpreted as the number of bridges in an interchange.<br />In this paper we study the minimum genus, or the minimum number of bridges, of a complete interchange with a restriction that it is symmetric under the cyclic permutation of its roads. We consider both (a) abstract combinatorial/topological symmetry, and (b) symmetry in the 3-dimensional Euclidean space R 3 . The proof of (a) is based on the classic voltage and transition graph constructions. For (b) we use, among other techniques, a simple new combinatorial lower bound.	string

2429	en_US	title	Some results on Dominating Induced matching	string
2429	en_US	cleanTitle	Some results on Dominating Induced matching	string
2429	en_US	abstract	Let $G$ be a graph, a dominating induced matching (DIM) of $G$ is an induced matching that dominates every edge of $G$. In this paper we show that if a graph $G$ has a DIM, then $\\chi(G) \\leqslant  3$. Also, it is shown that if $G$ is a connected graph whose all edges can be partitioned into DIM, then $G$ is either a regular graph or a biregular graph and indeed we characterize all graphs whose edge set can be partitioned into DIM. Also, we prove that if $G$ is an $r$-regular graph of order $n$ whose edges can be partitioned into DIM, then $n$ is divisible by $\\binom{2r - 1}{r - 1}$ and $n = \\binom{2r - 1}{r - 1}$ if and only if $G$ is the Kneser graph with parameters $r-1$, $2r-1$.	string
