2430	en_US	title	On the problems of $\\mathcal{CF}$-connected graphs	string
2430	en_US	cleanTitle	On the problems of \\mathcal{CF}connected graphs	string
2430	en_US	abstract	The crossing number $\\mathrm{cr}(G)$ of a graph $G$ is the minimum number of edge crossings over all drawings of $G$ in the plane, and the optimal  drawing of $G$ is any drawing at which the desired minimum number of  crossings is achieved.  The main aim of the paper is to establish an unambiguous characterization of $\\mathcal{CF}$-connected graphs in a manner similar to that of the well-known Kuratowski's theorem giving  a  necessary  and  sufficient condition for planarity. We conjecture that a  complete graph  $K_n$ is $\\mathcal{CF}$-connected if and only if it does not contain a~subgraph  of $K_8$, where a  connected graph $G$ is $\\mathcal{CF}$-connected if  there is a path between every pair of vertices  with no crossing on its edges for each  optimal drawing of $G$. We establish the validity of this conjecture for the complete graphs $K_n$ for any $n\\leq 12$, and by assuming  the Harary-Hill's conjecture that $\\mathrm{cr}(K_n)=H(n)=\\frac{1}{4}\\big \\lfloor \\frac{n}{2} \\big \\rfloor \\big \\lfloor \\frac{n-1}{2} \\big \\rfloor \\big \\lfloor \\frac{n-2}{2} \\big \\rfloor \\big \\lfloor \\frac{n-3}{2} \\big \\rfloor$ is also valid for all $n&gt;12$.	string

2431	en_US	title	Resolvent Energy of Digraphs	string
2431	en_US	cleanTitle	Resolvent Energy of Digraphs	string
2431	en_US	abstract	The  resolvent energy of a graph $G$ is defined as $ER(G) =\\sum_{i=0}^n\\frac{1}{n-\\lambda_i}$, where $\\lambda_1, \\lambda_2, \\ldots, \\lambda_n$ are the eigenvalues of the adjacency matrix of $G$. We extend this concept to directed graphs using singular values of the adjacency matrix.  If $G$ is a directed graph, then we consider $ER(G)=\\sum_{i=1}^{n}\\frac{1}{n-\\sigma_i}$, where $\\sigma_1\\geq \\sigma_2\\geq \\ldots\\geq \\sigma_n$ are the singular values of adjacency matrix of graph $G$. In this paper, we prove some properties of resolvent energy for  some special digraphs and determine the resolvent energy of unicyclic and bicyclic digraphs.	string

2433	en_US	title	Characterization of a Family of Rotationally Symmetric Spherical Quadrangulations	string
2433	en_US	cleanTitle	Characterization of a Family of Rotationally Symmetric Spherical Quadrangulations	string
2433	en_US	abstract	A \\emph{spherical quadrangulation} is an embedding of a graph $G$ in the sphere in which each facial boundary walk has length four. Vertices that are not of degree four in $G$ are called \\emph{curvature vertices}. In this paper we classify all spherical quadrangulations with $n$-fold rotational symmetry ($n\\geq 3$) that have minimum degree 3 and the least possible number of curvature vertices, and describe all such spherical quadrangulations in terms of nets of quadrilaterals. The description reveals that such rotationally symmetric quadrangulations necessarily also have dihedral symmetry.	string

2434	en_US	title	Average Terminal Wiener Index	string
2434	en_US	cleanTitle	Average Terminal Wiener Index	string
2434	en_US	abstract	<p>For a tree T, the terminal Wiener index TW(T) is defined as half the sum of all distances of the form d(u,v), where the summation is over all possible pairs of pendent vertices u,v in T . In this paper, we discuss about average terminal Wiener index of trees. The trees with maximum, minimum, second maximum and second minimum value of average terminal Wiener index is determined. We obtain the tree with minimum average terminal Wiener index among all trees of order n and with diameter d. We also obtain the tree with maximum average terminal Wiener index among all trees of order n and with maximum degree Δ. We also prove that every even integer is the average terminal Wiener index of some non-path tree.</p>	string

2435	en_US	cleanTitle	The chromatic index of strongly regular graphs	string
2435	en_US	abstract	We determine (partly by computer search) the chromatic index (edge-chromatic number) of many strongly regular graphs (SRGs), including the SRGs of degree $k\\leq 18$ and their complements, the Latin square graphs and their complements, and the triangular graphs and their complements.<br />Moreover, using a recent result of Ferber and Jain, we prove that an SRG of even order $n$, which is not the block graph of a Steiner $2$-design or its complement, has chromatic index $k$, when $n$ is big enough.<br />Except for the Petersen graph, all investigated connected SRGs of even order have chromatic index equal to $k$, i.e., they are class $1$, and we conjecture that this is the case for all connected SRGs of even order.<br /><br />	string

2441	en_US	title	Compactifications of topological spaces via commutative algebra	string
2441	en_US	cleanTitle	Compactifications of topological spaces via commutative algebra	string
2441	en_US	abstract	In this paper, using commutative algebra, then new and significant advances on the compactifications of topological spaces, especially on the Alexandroff and Stone-\\v{C}ech compactifications have been made. The Alexandroff compactification of a discrete space is constructed by a new and interesting approach. It is proved that the minimal spectrum of the direct product of a family of integral domains and also the maximal spectrum of the direct product of a family of local rings both indexed by a set $X$ are the Stone-\\v{C}ech compactification of the discrete space $X$. These results improve all of the previous constructions of the Stone-\\v{C}ech compactification of a discrete space. Some applications of this study are given. Specially and surprisingly, it is shown that the Stone-\\v{C}ech compactification of an arbitrary topological space $X$ is obtained from the Stone-\\v{C}ech compactification of the discrete space $X$ by passing to a its appropriate quotient. A natural and simple way to construct ultra-rings is introduced, then this new approach is used to obtain non-trivial results on the Stone-\\v{C}ech compactification.	string

2442	en_US	title	Generalized dot total graph	string
2442	en_US	cleanTitle	Generalized dot total graph	string
2442	en_US	abstract	Let $R$ be a ring with $1 \\neq 0$, $Z(R)$ be the set of zero-divisors of $R$, and $Reg(R)$ be the set of regular elements of $R$. \\textit{A generalized dot total graph of $R$} is the directed graph, denote by $ \\vec{T}_{Z(R)}(\\Gamma(R)) $  with all elements of $R$ as set of vertices, such that $x \\rightarrow y$ is a directed edge from a vertex $x$ to a vertex $y$ if and only if $ xy \\in Z(R) $. The present paper is devoted to study various properties of $ \\vec{T}_{Z(R)}(\\Gamma(R)) $ and it is shown that $ \\vec{T}_{Z(R)}(\\Gamma(R)) $ is always symmetric, strongly connected, and has a small diameter of at most two. Further, connectivity and clique number of $ \\vec{T}_{Z(R)}(\\Gamma(R)) $ have also been studied. Finally, we define several digraphs in the same manner as $ \\vec{T}_{Z(R)}(\\Gamma(R)) $ by replacing $Z(R)$ by one of the sets ($Reg(R)$, $Nil(R)$ or $SReg(R)$) and sub-digraphs of $ \\vec{T}_{Z(R)}(\\Gamma(R)) $ have been defined by replacing $R$ by a subset of $R$ viz. $Z(R)$, $Nil(R)$, $Reg(R)$ or $SReg(R)$.	string

2443	en_US	title	Generalized Dihedral CI-groups	string
2443	en_US	cleanTitle	Generalized Dihedral CIgroups	string
2443	en_US	abstract	<p>In this paper, we find a strong new restriction on the structure of<br />CI-groups. We show that, if R is a generalised dihedral group and if R is a<br />CI-group, then for every odd prime p the Sylow p-subgroup of R has order p,<br />or 9. Consequently, any CI-group with quotient a generalised dihedral group<br />has the same restriction, that for every odd prime p the Sylow p-subgroup of<br />the group has order p, or 9. We also give a counter example to the conjecture<br />that every BCI-group is a CI-group.</p>	string

2445	en_US	title	A tight relation between series--parallel graphs and Bipartite Distance Hereditary graphs.	string
2445	en_US	cleanTitle	A tight relation between seriesparallel graphs and Bipartite Distance Hereditary graphs	string
2445	en_US	abstract	Bandelt and Mulder's structural characterization of Bipartite<br />Distance Hereditary graphs asserts that such graphs can be built<br />inductively starting from a single vertex and by repeatedly adding<br />either pending vertices or twins (i.e., vertices with the same<br />neighborhood as an existing one). Dirac and Duffin's structural characterization<br />of 2--connected series--parallel graphs asserts that such graphs<br />can be built inductively starting from a single edge by adding<br />either edges in series or in parallel. In this paper we give an elementary proof that the two constructions are the same construction when bipartite graphs are viewed as the fundamental graphs of a graphic matroid. We then apply the result to re-prove known results concerning bipartite distance hereditary graphs and series--parallel graphs and  to provide a new class of polynomially-solvable instances for the integer multi commodity flow of maximum value.	string

2446	en_US	abstract	<pre>Consider a simple graph <span>$G$</span>. 2451	en_US	title	The antistrong property for special digraph families	string
2451	en_US	cleanTitle	The antistrong property for special digraph families	string
2451	en_US	abstract	A \\textit{forward antidirected trail} is a walk with no arc repeated which begins and ends with forward arcs and in which the arcs alternate between forward and backward arcs. A digraph $D$ is \\textit{antistrong} if it has at least three vertices and contains a forward antidirected $(x,y)$-trail for every pair of distinct vertices $x$, $y$ of $D$. In this paper, we show that the \\textit{Cartesian product} of two antistrong digraphs is antistrong. Moreover, one of the results is that the \\textit{Lexicographic product} of an antistrong digraph and a digraph is antistrong. Finally, we study the problem of giving a necessary and sufficient condition to decide whether a tournament is antistrong.	string

2454	en_US	title	Efficient proper embedding  of a daisy cube	string
2454	en_US	cleanTitle	Efficient proper embedding  of a daisy cube	string
2454	en_US	abstract	For a set $X$ of binary words of length $h$ the daisy cube $Q_h(X)$ is defined as the subgraph of the hypercube $Q_h$ induced by the set of all vertices on shortest paths that connect vertices of $X$ with the vertex $0 ^h$. A vertex in the intersection of all of these paths is a minimal vertex of a daisy cube. A graph $G$ isomorphic to a daisy cube admits several isometric embeddings into a hypercube. We show that an isometric embedding is proper if and only if the label<p style="-qt-block-indent: 0; text-indent: 0px; margin: 0px;">$0 ^h$ is assigned to a minimal vertex of $G$. This result allows us to devise an algorithm which finds a proper embedding of a graph isomorphic to a daisy cube into a hypercube in linear time.</p>	string

2455	en_US	title	Full friendly index sets of a family of cubic graphs	string
2455	en_US	cleanTitle	Full friendly index sets of a family of cubic graphs	string
2455	en_US	abstract	<p>Let $G=(V,E)$ be a graph. For a vertex labeling $f: V\\rightarrow \\mathbb{Z}_2$, it induces an edge labeling $f^{+}: E\\rightarrow \\mathbb{Z}_2$, where for each edge $v_{1}v_{2}\\in E$ we have $f^{+}(v_{1}v_{2})=f(v_{1})+f(v_{2})$. For each $i\\in \\mathbb{Z}_2$, we use $v_{f}(i)$ (respectively, $e_{f}(i)$) to denote the number of vertices (respectively, edges) with label $i$. A vertex labeling $f$ of $G$ is said to be friendly if vertices with different labels differ in size by at most one.<br /> The full~friendly~index set of a graph $G$, denoted by $FFI(G)$, consists of all possible values of $e_{f}(1)-e_{f}(0)$, where $f$ ranges over all friendly labelings of $G$. In this paper, motivated by a problem raised by Gao et. al. (Bull. Malays. Math. Sci. Soc. 41 (2018) 443--453) we study the full friendly index sets of a family of cubic graphs.</p>	string

2458	en_US	title	A predictor-corrector scheme for the nonlinear chaotic variable-order fractional three -dimensional system	string
2458	en_US	cleanTitle	A predictorcorrector scheme for the nonlinear chaotic variableorder fractional three dimensional system	string
2458	en_US	abstract	<p>In this paper a two-step fractional Adams-Bashforth-Moulton scheme based on the Hadamard fractional derivative is formulated for the solution of nonlinear fractional variable order diﬀerential equations. 2465	en_US	title	Well-Totally-Dominated Graphs	string
2465	en_US	cleanTitle	WellTotallyDominated Graphs	string
2465	en_US	abstract	A subset of vertices in a graph is called a total dominating set if every vertex of the graph is adjacent to at least one vertex of this set. A total dominating set is called minimal if it does not properly contain another total dominating set. In this paper, we study graphs whose all minimal total dominating sets have the same size, referred to as well-totally-dominated (WTD) graphs. We first show that WTD graphs with bounded total domination number can be recognized  in polynomial time. Then we focus on WTD graphs with total domination number two. In this case, we characterize triangle-free WTD graphs and WTD graphs with packing number two, and we show that there are only finitely many planar WTD graphs with minimum degree at least three. Lastly, we show that if the minimum degree is at least three then the girth of a WTD graph is at most 12. We conclude with several open  questions.	string

2466	en_US	title	A new class of graceful graphs: k-enriched fan graphs and their characterisations	string
2466	en_US	cleanTitle	A new class of graceful graphs: kenriched fan graphs and their characterisations	string
2466	en_US	abstract	The Graceful Tree Conjecture stated by Rosa in the mid 1960s says that every tree can be gracefully labelled and  is one of the best known open problems in Graph Theory. It has caused a great interest in the study of gracefulness of simple graphs - yet one has to admit that not much is known about the structure of graceful graphs after 55 years -- and in new contributions to the list of simple graphs known to be graceful.<br /><br />Our paper brings an infinite family of classes of graceful graphs to the mentioned list. We introduce classes of $k$-enriched fan graphs $kF_n$ for all positive integers $k\\ge 1$ and $n\\ge2$ and we prove that these  graphs are graceful. Moreover, we provide characterizations of the $k$-enriched fan graphs $kF_n$ among all simple graphs via Sheppard's labelling sequences introduced in the 1970s as well as via labelling relations and graph chessboards as new tools for the study of graceful graphs introduced by Haviar and Iva\\v ska in 2015. The labelling relations<br />are closely related to Sheppard's labelling sequences while the graph chessboards provide a nice visualization of graceful labellings. We close our paper with an open problem concerning an another infinite family of extended fan graphs.	string

2467	en_US	title	Modifications of the Floyd-Warshall algorithm with nearly quadratic expected-time	string
2467	en_US	cleanTitle	Modifications of the FloydWarshall algorithm with nearly quadratic expectedtime	string
2467	en_US	abstract	The paper describes two relatively simple modifications of the well-known Floyd-Warshall algorithm for computing all-pairs shortest paths. A fundamental difference of both modifications in comparison to the Floyd-Warshall algorithm is that the relaxation is done in a smart way. We show that the expected-case time complexity of both algorithms is  $O(n^2 \\log^2 n)$ on a graph with $n$ vertices. Since almost all expected-case algorithms for the all-pairs shortest path problem  are based on Dijkstra's algorithm, it is interesting that a competitive approach can also be obtained by a modification of the Floyd-Warshall algorithm. This   avoids use of any kind of priority queues or complicated data structures. Moreover, we supplement the theoretical analysis with the empirical evaluation proving also practical competitiveness of  our algorithms in comparison to the best known algorithms.	string

2468	en_US	title	On BC-subtrees in Multi-fan and Multi-wheel Graphs	string
2468	en_US	cleanTitle	On BCsubtrees in Multifan and Multiwheel Graphs	string
2468	en_US	abstract	BC-tree (a tree in which any two leaves are at even distance apart) is an important graph structure with many pure mathematical properties and applications, such as generic chemical structures storage problem. A BC-subtree of a graph is simply a subtree that is also a BC-tree. The BC-subtree number index (or simply the BC-subtree index) is the total number of non-empty BC-subtrees of a graph, and is defined as a counting-based topological index that incorporates leaf distance constraint. In this paper, we study the BC-subtrees of multi-fan and multi-wheel graphs through generating functions. In particular, we find recursive formulas for computing the BC-subtree index of these graphs. With these findings we also consider the behavior of the BC-subtree number in these structures through the study of extremal problems and BC-subtree density. Our study offers a new perspective on understanding new structural properties of cyclic graphs.	string

2470	en_US	title	DP-4-colorability of planar graphs without two subgraphs	string
2470	en_US	cleanTitle	DP4colorability of planar graphs without two subgraphs	string
2470	en_US	abstract	<p>DP-coloring was introduced recently by Dvo\\v{r}\\'ak and Postle (2017) as a generalization of list coloring. Lih and Wang (2002) conjectured that every planar graph without adjacent triangles is 4-choosable. The DP-version of this conjecture is that every planar graph without adjacent triangles is DP-4-colorable. On the other hand, Kim and Ozeki (2018) showed that a planar graph is DP-4-colorable if it has no $4$-cycles. Kim and Yu (2019) showed that a planar graph without $4$-cycles adjacent to $3$-cycles is DP-$4$-colorable. Liu and Li (2019) showed that every planar graph without a $4$-cycle adjacent to two triangles is DP-$4$-colorable.<br />In this paper, we prove two results: (1) every planar graph without intersecting triangles is DP-4-colorable; (2) every planar graph without adjacent triangle and without a 4-cycle adjacent two intersecting two triangle is DP-4-colorable. Theses two results improve early results of Lih and Wang, Liu and Li, Kim and Yu, Li and Wang.</p>	string

2476	en_US	title	Generic spectrum of the weighted Laplacian operator on Cayley graphs	string
2476	en_US	cleanTitle	Generic spectrum of the weighted Laplacian operator on Cayley graphs	string
2476	en_US	abstract	In this paper we address the problem of determining whether the eigenspaces of a class of weighted Laplacians on Cayley graphs are generically irreducible or not. This work is divided into two parts.  In the first part, we express the weighted Laplacian on Cayley graphs as the divergence of a gradient in an analogous way to the approach adopted in Riemannian geometry. In the second part, we analyze its spectrum on left-invariant Cayley graphs endowed with an invariant metric in both directed and undirected cases.  We give some criteria for a given eigenspace being generically irreducible. Finally, we introduce an additional operator which is comparable to the Laplacian, and we verify that the same criteria hold.	string

2479	en_US	title	Cut vertex and unicyclic graphs with the maximum number of connected induced subgraphs	string
2479	en_US	cleanTitle	Cut vertex and unicyclic graphs with the maximum number of connected induced subgraphs	string
2479	en_US	abstract	Cut vertices are often used as a measure of nodes' importance within a network. They are those nodes whose failure disconnects a graph. Let $\\N(G)$ be the number of connected induced subgraphs of a graph $G$. In this work, we investigate the maximum of $\\N(G)$ where $G$ is a unicyclic graph with $n$ nodes of which $c$ are cut vertices. For all valid $n,c$, we give a full description of those maximal (that maximise $\\N(.)$) unicyclic graphs. It is found that there are generally two maximal unicyclic graphs. For infinitely many values of $n,c$, however, there is a unique maximal unicyclic graph with $n$ nodes and $c$ cut vertices. In particular, the well-known negative correlation between the number of connected induced subgraphs of trees and the Wiener index (sum of distances) fails for unicyclic graphs with $n$ nodes and $c$ cut vertices: for instance, the maximal unicyclic graph with $n=3,4\\mod 5$ nodes and $c=n-5&gt;3$ cut vertices is different from the unique graph that was shown by Tan et al.~[{\\em The Wiener index of unicyclic graphs given number of pendant vertices or cut vertices}. J. Appl. Math. Comput., 55:1--24, 2017] to minimise the Wiener index. Our main characterisation of maximal unicyclic graphs with respect to the number of connected induced subgraphs also applies to unicyclic graphs with $n$ nodes, $c$ cut vertices and girth at most $g$, where $g&gt;3$.	string
2478	en_US	title	Enumerating Symmetric Peaks in nondecreasing Dyck paths	string
2478	en_US	cleanTitle	Enumerating Symmetric Peaks in nondecreasing Dyck paths	string
2478	en_US	abstract	<p class="p1">Local maxima and minima of a Dyck path are called \\emph{peaks} and \\emph{valleys}, respectively.<span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span>A Dyck path is \\emph{non-decreasing} if the heights ($y$-coordinates) of its valleys increase from left to right. A peak is symmetric if it is surrounded by two valleys (or endpoints of the path) at the same height.<span class="Apple-converted-space">  </span>In this paper we give multivariate generating functions, recurrence relations, and closed formulas <span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span>to count the number of symmetric and asymmetric peaks in non-decreasing Dyck paths.<span class="Apple-converted-space">  </span>Finally, we use Riordan arrays to study weakly symmetric peaks, <span class="Apple-converted-space"> </span>namely those for which the valley preceding the peak is at least as high as the valley following it.</p>	string

2480	en_US	abstract	<span style="font-family: CMR10; font-size: 9pt; color: #000000; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal;">A graph <span style="font-family: CMMI10; font-size: 9pt; color: #000000; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal;"><em>G </em><span style="font-family: CMR10; font-size: 9pt; color: #000000; font-style: normal; font-variant: normal;">is called irregular if the degrees of all its vertices are not the same. 2482	en_US	abstract	A graph $G$ is a DTDP-graph if it has a pair $(D,T)$ of disjoint sets of vertices of $G$ such that $D$ is a dominating set and $T$ is a total dominating set of $G$. 2492	en_US	title	On split graphs with three or four distinct eigenvalues with respect to some degree-based matrices	string
2492	en_US	cleanTitle	On split graphs with three or four distinct eigenvalues with respect to some degreebased matrices	string
2492	en_US	abstract	A graph is split if its vertex set can be partitioned into a clique and an independent set. The diameter of a split graph is  at most 3. The $A_{ex}$ (resp. $GA,\\, \\Omega_\\alpha,\\, AG$) eigenvalues of a graph $G$ are the eigenvalues of its extended adjacency (resp. geometric-arithmetic adjacency, generalized $ABC$, arithmetic-geometric adjacency) matrix. A graph is said to be $l_{A_{ex}}$ (resp. $l_{GA},\\, l_{\\Omega_\\alpha},\\, l_{AG}$) -extremal if the graph is of diameter $l$ having exactly $l+1$ distinct $A_{ex}$ (resp. $GA,\\, \\Omega_\\alpha,\\, AG$) eigenvalues. In this paper, using the relationship between bidegreed split graphs and combinatorial designs, all the connected $l_{A_{ex}}$ (resp. $l_{GA},\\, l_{\\Omega_\\alpha},\\, l_{AG}$) -extremal bidegreed split graphs are characterized for $l=2$ and 3, respectively. Then all the connected bidegreed split graphs of diameter 2 having just 4 distinct $A_{ex}$ (resp. $GA,\\, \\Omega_\\alpha,\\, AG$) eigenvalues are also identified. Furthermore, we establish the connections between the sum construction for combinatorial designs and extremal bidegreed split graphs.	string

2494	en_US	title	On Languages of Transduced-Input Finite Automata with Translucent Letters	string
2494	en_US	cleanTitle	On Languages of TransducedInput Finite Automata with Translucent Letters	string
2494	en_US	abstract	<p>Finite automata with translucent letters are extensions of the usual finite state automata allowing to proceed the input not strictly left to right manner: in each state there is a subset of the alphabet which letters cannot be seen in that state, thus the automaton reads the first visible letter from the remaining input at each transition. The accepted class of languages is a superset of the class of regular languages including, e.g., the Dyck language and all commutative semilinear languages. On the other hand, this class of languages is not closed under intersection with regular sets. Therefore, it can be extended by adding a preprocessing finite state transducer to the system. The resulted model, the Transduced-Input Nondeterministic Finite Automata with Translucent Letters, i.e., T-inputNFAwtl is even more powerful than nite automata with translucent<br />letters. In this paper, some closure properties of the class of languages accepted by this model is studied. Closure under various operations is shown for the case when languages over disjoint alphabets are studied. Most importantly, it is shown that, in the general case, the language class dened by T-inputNFAwtl is closed under intersection with regular sets, moreover the class contains every language that is obtained as the intersection of a T-inputNFAwtl language and a regular language.</p>	string

2495	en_US	abstract	This paper discusses algorithms adapted for a construction of three types of wavelets. We build in the first case scaling functions and associated wavelets which are fast decreasing. In the second case, we construct wavelets which are exponential decreasing. In the last one, we construct scaling functions which are regular and have compact support and we prove that the associated wavelets have compact support and preserve the original regularity of the scaling functions. As applications, we prove that the wavelet bases constructed in this paper are adapted for the study of regular functional spaces C s (R) and Hs (R) (s ∈ R) and are easy to implement.	string

2496	en_US	title	The adjacency dimension of graphs	string
2496	en_US	cleanTitle	The adjacency dimension of graphs	string
2496	en_US	abstract	<p>It is known that the problem of computing the adjacency dimension of a graph is NP-hard. This suggests finding the adjacency dimension for special classes of graphs or obtaining good bounds on this invariant.<br />In this work we obtain general bounds on the adjacency dimension of a graph $G$ in terms of known parameters of $G$.<br />We discuss the tightness of these bounds and, for some particular classes of graphs, we obtain closed formulae. In particular, we show the close relationships that exist between the adjacency dimension and other parameters, like the domination number, the location-domination number, the $2$-domination number, the independent $2$-domination number, the vertex cover number, the independence number and the super domination number.</p>	string

2497	en_US	title	Iteration of the mincut graph operator	string
2497	en_US	cleanTitle	Iteration of the mincut graph operator	string
2497	en_US	abstract	An intersection graph, the mincut graph of a graph, with vertex set the minimum edge-cuts of a graph was introduced in <em>The mincut graph of a graph</em>, and it was shown that every graph is a mincut graph, that is, every graph lies in the image of the mincut operator. In this paper we introduce and study the properties of the mincut operator, as per the research program introduced by Prisner in<em> Graph Dynamics</em>. Specifically we show that the property of being super-lambda and r-regular is both necessary and sufficient for a graph to be fixed under the operator. Furthermore, we show that no graph diverges under iteration of the operator.	string

2498	en_US	abstract	<p>Let $k$ be the largest integer such that $m \\ge \\frac{(n-k)(n-k-1)}{2}+qk \\ge q(n-1)$ for some positive integers $n, m, q$. Let $S(q,n,m)$ be a set of all $q$-connected chordal graphs on $n$ vertices and $m$ edges for $\\frac{n-k}{2} \\ge q \\ge 2$. Let $t(G)$ be the number of spanning trees in graph $G$. We identify $G \\in S(q,n,m)$ such that $t(G) &lt; t(H)$ for any $H$ that satisfies $H \\in S(q,n,m)$ and $H \\ncong G$. 2499	en_US	title	The edge geodetic fault tolerant domination number of a graph	string
2499	en_US	cleanTitle	The edge geodetic fault tolerant domination number of a graph	string
2499	en_US	abstract	<p>For a connected graph G = (V, E), a set F ⊆ V is said to be an edge geodetic fault tolerant dominating set of G if F is both edge geodetic set and fault tolerant dominating set of G. The minimum cardinality of an edge geodetic fault tolerant dominating set of G is called the edge geodetic fault tolerant domination number of G and is denoted by γ<sub>gef t</sub>(G). The edge geodetic fault tolerant domination number of certain classes of graphs are determined. The upper and lower bounds of edge geodetic fault tolerant domination number are characterized. It is shown that for each pair of integers 3 ≤ a &lt; b, there exists a connected graph G such that γ(G) = a, γ<sub>ge </sub>(G) = b and γ<sub>gef t</sub>(G) = a+b−1, where γ(G), γ<sub>ge</sub> (G) and γ<sub>gef t</sub>(G) are the domination number, edge geodetic domination number and edge geodetic fault tolerant domination number of G, respectively.</p>	string

2503	en_US	abstract	<p>There are two well known maps representations of hypermaps, namely the Walsh and the Vince map representations, being dual of each other.<br />They correspond to normal subgroups of index two of a free product $\\Gamma=(C_2\\times C_2)*C_2$ which decompose as ``elementary'' free product $C_2*C_2*C_2$.<br />However $\\Gamma$ has three normal subgroups that decompose as ``elementary" free product $C_2*C_2*C_2$, the third of these sbgroups giving the less known petrie-path map representation.<br />By relaxing the ``elementary" free product %$C_2*C_2*C_2$<br />condition to free product of rank 3, and under the extra condition ``words of smaller length" on the generators, we prove that the number of map representations of hypermaps increases to 15 (up to a restrictedly dual), all of which described in this paper.</p>	string

2505	en_US	title	Upper bounds for inverse domination in graphs	string
2505	en_US	cleanTitle	Upper bounds for inverse domination in graphs	string
2505	en_US	abstract	<p>In any graph $G$, the domination number $\\gamma(G)$ is at most the independence number $\\alpha(G)$. The \\emph{Inverse Domination Conjecture} says that, in any isolate-free $G$, there exists pair of vertex-disjoint dominating sets $D, D'$ with $|D|=\\gamma(G)$ and $|D'| \\leq \\alpha(G)$. Here we prove that this statement is true if the upper bound $\\alpha(G)$ is replaced by $\\frac{3}{2}\\alpha(G) - 1$ (and $G$ is not a clique). We also prove that the conjecture holds whenever $\\gamma(G)\\leq 5$ or $|V(G)|\\leq 16$.</p>	string

2506	en_US	title	Comparing the Wiener and Kirchhoff indices of random pentagonal chains	string
2506	en_US	cleanTitle	Comparing the Wiener and Kirchhoff indices of random pentagonal chains	string
2506	en_US	abstract	Let G be a connected (molecule) graph. The Wiener index W(G) and Kirchhoff index Kf(G) of G are defined as the sum of distances and the resistance distances between all unordered pairs of vertices in G, respectively. In this paper, explicit formulae for the expected values of the Wiener and Kirchhoff indices of random pentagonal chains are derived by the difference equation and recursive method. Based on these formulae, we then make comparisons between the expected values of the Wiener index and the Kirchhoff index in random pentagonal chains, and present the average values of the Wiener and Kirchhoff indices with respect to the set of all random pentagonal chains<br />with n pentagons.	string

2525	en_US	title	On the least size of a graph with a given degree set -- II	string
2525	en_US	cleanTitle	On the least size of a graph with a given degree set  II	string
2525	en_US	abstract	The degree set of a finite simple graph $G$ is the set of distinct degrees of vertices of $G$. A theorem of Kapoor, Polimeni &amp; Wall asserts that the least order of a graph with a given degree set $D$ is $1+max D$. Tripathi &amp; Vijay considered the analogous problem concerning the least size of graphs with degree set $D$. We expand on their results, and determine the least size of graphs with degree set $D$ when (i) $min D \\mid d$ for each $d \\in D$; (ii) $min D=2$; (iii) $D={m,m+1,\\ldots,n}$. In addition, given any $D$, we produce a graph $G$ whose size is within $min D$ of the optimal size, giving a $\\big(1+\\frac{2}{d_1+1})$-approximation, where $d_1=max D$.	string

2530	en_US	abstract	<p>In the present paper, we investigate a family of circulant graphs with non-fixed jumps</p><p>G<sub>n</sub>= C<sub>βn</sub>(s<sub>1</sub>, ... , s<sub>k</sub>, α<sub>1</sub>n, ... , α<sub>l</sub>n), 1 ≤ s<sub>1</sub>&lt; ... &lt; s<sub>k</sub>≤ [βn/2], 1 ≤ α<sub>1</sub>&lt; ... &lt; α<sub>l</sub> ≤ [β/2]. </p><p>Here n is an arbitrary large natural number and integers s<sub>1</sub>, ... , s<sub>k</sub>, α<sub>1</sub>, ... , α<sub>l</sub> are supposed to be fixed.</p><p>First, we present an explicit formula for the number of spanning trees in the graph G<sub>n</sub>. We show that the number of spanning trees in G<sub>n</sub> can be represented in the form τ(n) = p n a(n)<sup>2</sup>, where a(n) is an integer sequence and p is a prescribed natural number depending of parity of β and n.</p><p>Finally, we find an asymptotic formula for τ(n) through the Mahler measure of the associated Laurent polynomials.<br /><br /></p>	string

2532	en_US	abstract	<p>Let $G$ be a finite and simple graph with vertex set $V(G)$.<br /> Let $f$ be a function that assigns label from the set $\\{0, 1, 2,3,4,5\\}$ to the vertices of a graph $G$.<br /> For a vertex $v\\in V(G)$, the active neighbourhood of $v$, denoted by $\\mbox{AN}(v)$,<br /> is the set of vertices $w\\in N_{G}(v)$ such that $f(w)\\geq1$.<br /> A quadruple Roman dominating function (QRDF) is a function $f:V(G)\\longrightarrow\\{0, 1, 2,3,4,5\\}$ satisfying the condition that for any vertex $v\\in V(G)$ with $f(v)&lt;4,<br /> f(N_{G}[v])\\geq|\\mbox{AN}(v)|+4$. The weight of a QRDF is $\\omega(f)=\\Sigma_{v\\in V(G)}f(v)$.<br /> The quadruple Roman domination number $\\gamma_{[4R]}(G)$ of $G$ is the minimum weight of an QRDF on $G$.<br /> In this paper we investigate the properties of the quadruple Roman domination number of graphs,<br /> present bounds on $\\gamma_{[4R]}(G)$ and give exact values for some graph families.<br /> In addition, complexity results are also obtained.</p>	string

2533	en_US	abstract	<p>The palette of a vertex <em>v</em> of a graph <em>G</em> in a proper edge coloring is the set of colors assigned to the edges which are incident to <em>v</em>. The palette index of <em>G</em> is the minimum number of palettes occurring among all proper edge colorings of <em>G</em>. In this paper, we consider the palette index of Sierpiński graphs S_p^n and Sierpiński triangle graphs Ŝ_3^n. In particular, we determine the exact value of the palette index of Sierpiński triangle graphs. We also determine the palette index of Sierpiński graphs S_p^n where p is even, p=3, or n=2 and p=4l+3. Additionally, we give an upper bound and a lower bound on the palette index of Sierpiński graphs S_p^n.</p>	string

2539	en_US	title	The Connected Edge Fixed Geodetic Number of a Graph	string
2539	en_US	cleanTitle	The Connected Edge Fixed Geodetic Number of a Graph	string
2539	en_US	abstract	<p>For an edge xy in a connected graph G of order at least 3, a set S ⊆ V (G) is an<br />xy-geodetic set of G if every vertex in G lies on either an x − z geodesic or a y − z geodesic for some element z in S. The minimum cardinality of an xy-geodetic set of G is defined as the xy-geodetic number of G, is denoted by gxy(G). A connected xy-geodetic set of G is an xy-geodetic set S such that the subgraph G[S] induced by S is connected. The minimum cardinality of a connected xy-geodetic set of G is the connected xy-geodetic number of G and is denoted by cgxy(G). We determine bounds for the parameter cgxy(G) and find the same for some standard graphs. It is shown that for integers d, n and p with 2 ≤ d ≤ p − 2 and 1 ≤ n ≤ p − 1, there exists a connected graph G of order p, diameter d and cgxy(G) = n for some edge xy in G. Also, we give an algorithm for finding the connected edge fixed geodetic set of a graph.</p>	string

2522	en_US	title	Paired domination stability in graphs	string
2522	en_US	cleanTitle	Paired domination stability in graphs	string
2522	en_US	abstract	A set $S$ of vertices in a graph $G$ is a paired dominating set if every vertex of $G$ is adjacent to a vertex in $S$ and the subgraph induced by $S$ contains a perfect matching (not necessarily as an induced subgraph). The paired domination number, $\\gpr(G)$, of $G$ is the minimum cardinality of a paired dominating set of $G$. A set of vertices whose removal from $G$ produces a graph without isolated vertices is called a non-isolating set. The minimum cardinality of a non-isolating set of vertices whose removal decreases the paired domination number is the $\\gpr^-$-stability of $G$, denoted $\\st^-(G)$. The paired domination stability of $G$ is the minimum cardinality of a non-isolating set of vertices in $G$ whose removal changes the paired domination number. We establish properties of paired domination stability in graphs. We prove that if $G$ is a connected graph with $\\gpr(G) \\ge 4$, then $\\st^-(G) \\le 2\\Delta(G)$ where $\\Delta(G)$ is the maximum degree in $G$, and we characterize the infinite family of trees that achieve equality in this upper bound.	string
2522	en_US	discipline	Paired domination; Paired domination stability	string
2522	en_US	subjectClass	05C69	string
2522	en_US	subject		string
2522	en_US	sponsor		string
2522	en_US	copyrightHolder	ARS MATHEMATICA CONTEMPORANEA	string

2523	en_US	title	Fault-Tolerant Metric Dimension of Two-Fold Pentagonal-Nonagonal Circular Ladder	string
2523	en_US	cleanTitle	FaultTolerant Metric Dimension of TwoFold PentagonalNonagonal Circular Ladder	string
2523	en_US	abstract	The problem of characterizing the classes of plane graphs with the bounded metric dimension, edge metric dimension, and fault-tolerant metric dimension are of great interest nowadays. In this paper, we study the standard metric dimension, the fault-tolerant metric dimension, and the edge metric dimension of the two-fold pentagonal-nonagonal circular ladder (denoted by $\\mathbb{P}^{9}_{n}$). We show that the standard metric dimension of the two-fold pentagonal-nonagonal circular ladder $\\mathbb{P}^{9}_{n}$ is $3$ i.e., $\\beta(\\mathbb{P}^{9}_{n})=3$ and the edge metric dimension is $3$ and $4$, when the positive integer $n$ is even and odd respectively. We also set some lower and upper bounds for the fault-tolerant metric dimension of the plane graph $\\mathbb{P}^{9}_{n}$. Moreover, for the plane graph $\\mathbb{P}^{9}_{n}$, we also show that the basis set $\\mathfrak{L}$ and edge metric basis set $\\mathfrak{L}_{E}$ is independent.	string

2523	en_US	subject	Metric dimension, edge metric dimension, fault-tolerant metric dimension, two-fold pentagonal-nonagonal circular ladder, connected graph.	string

2524	en_US	title	Endomorphisms of the Collatz quiver	string
2524	en_US	cleanTitle	Endomorphisms of the Collatz quiver	string
2524	en_US	abstract	<div class="page" title="Page 1"><div class="layoutArea"><div class="column"><p><span>We analyse the </span><span>3</span><span>n </span><span>+ 1 </span><span>dynamical system in terms of both the fundamental and emerging properties of the quivers it generates over odd numbers and offer a first description of the endomorphism underlying the structure of the quiver known as the ”Collatz Seaweed”. We then establish some fundamental properties of other endomorphisms generated by the </span><span>3</span><span>n </span><span>+ 1 </span><span>dynamical system, mapping this quiver onto proper subsets of </span><span>2</span><span>N</span><span>+1 </span><span>composed of the nodes we also prove any Collatz orbit must intersect and draw interesting conclusions from those properties, allowing us to claim a result strictly superior to the one of Tao (2019) on the Collatz conjecture. In particular, we prove that the Collatz quiver can be reduced to a Hydra game, and thus formally demonstrate that any Collatz orbit finitely reaches 1.</span></p></div></div></div>	string
